site_title: Twenty-first Century Fox in talks with Blackstone to buy Tribune
summary: Twenty-First Century Fox is in talks with Blackstone Group LP to submit an offer to buy Tribune Media Co, one of the largest US television station operators. Blackstone would provide the cash, while Fox would provide the TV stations for the joint venture. Bids are due on Thursday, with Nexstar Media Group Inc and Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc also considering a bid for Tribune Media. The potential bid comes after the US Federal Communications Commission reversed a 2016 decision limiting the number of television stations some broadcasters can buy.

site_title: Macron, Le Pen kick off final week with major Paris rallies
summary: French presidential candidates Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen kicked off the final week of the campaign with major rallies in Paris. Le Pen appeared to shift her stance on the euro, initially saying there was no rush for a euro exit but later stating "the euro is dead" while still wanting two currencies. Macron leads in the polls with 59.5% of voters, but Le Pen's campaign has narrowed the gap. A one-on-one debate is scheduled for Wednesday, and voters will decide between the two candidates on May 7.

site_title: California enacts fuel tax hike to raise US$52b for long-neglected road, bridge repairs
summary: California Governor Jerry Brown signed a bill into law on April 28, 2017, increasing petrol taxes by 12 cents per gallon and diesel fuel by 20 cents per gallon over 10 years to fund $52 billion in road and bridge repairs. The average motorist will see transportation costs rise by $10 a month, with the funds earmarked for repairs, mass transit, and anti-congestion projects. The measure will go into effect in November, with a constitutional amendment proposed to prohibit spending on non-transportation projects.

site_title: Sony sees highest profit since 1998 as turnaround takes root
summary: Sony reported its highest annual operating profit since 1998, with 500 billion yen (S$6.284 billion) for the fiscal year through March 2018. The company's recovery is attributed to continued dominance in gaming and strong growth in phone-camera chips. Sony's focus on gaming and finance has led to a turnaround, with operating profit in the fiscal year through March 2017 slipping 1.9% to 288.7 billion yen. Analysts expect Sony to exceed its targets, with some predicting an operating profit of 600 billion yen.

site_title: UK lawmakers criticise social media over response to extremist content
summary: UK lawmakers have criticized social media platforms, including Twitter, YouTube, and Facebook, for failing to adequately remove extremist content, despite repeated notifications. The committee's report found repeated examples of such material not being removed, including from banned groups. The government is now calling for stronger laws and for social media companies to pay for content policing and publicly report their moderating efforts. The government also expects social media to develop tools to identify and remove "terrorist propaganda." The criticism comes amid concerns over the spread of online violence and abuse.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near multi-month lows on USD, euro and pound
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near multi-month lows against the US dollar, euro, and pound due to lingering uncertainty about US trade policies. The Australian dollar eased to US$0.7477, while the New Zealand dollar drifted to US$0.6857. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold rates at a record low 1.5% at its upcoming meeting. Despite a slowdown in home prices, which may ease policymakers' concerns about a debt-fuelled real estate bubble, the currencies are expected to face further downside due to crowded one-way bets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on yen's fall
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.59% on May 1, 2017, driven by the yen's weakness and a potential US budget deal. The Nikkei index rose 113.78 points to 19,310.52, while the Topix index added 7.97 points to 1,539.77. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, and investors are also optimistic about US-EU trade talks and a potential S&P 500 record.

site_title: US Congress at 100 days: Lots of sound and fury, but few achievements
summary: US Congress has failed to achieve significant bipartisan legislation in its first 100 days under unified Republican governance, instead focusing on divisive issues and arcane rules. The Senate exempted ancient water vessel owners from fire-retardant materials requirements. A chaotic White House and a divisive election have hindered productivity, making this Congress one of the least productive in recent memory. The country's economic and international policies have also been overshadowed by internal party conflicts.

site_title: US truck, crossover sales drive GM to record gain
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a record quarterly profit of $2.6 billion, driven by strong sales of large pickup trucks and crossovers in the US. US vehicle sales rose 3.5% for Chevrolet trucks and 12% for crossovers, while pre-tax margin profit increased 8.2% year-over-year. Despite higher commodity costs and recall expenses, GM expects 2017 full-year adjusted earnings per share of $6 to $6.50. The company's shares were slightly down at $34.51.

site_title: Uncertainty to prevail in coming two years of EU-UK Brexit talks
summary: The European Union has agreed on a hardline stance in Brexit negotiations, indicating a difficult path to a compromise agreement with the UK. Despite this, sterling has rallied 14.5% against the yen and 8.7% against the euro, driven by hopes of a strong Conservative majority in the UK and concerns over global instability. The EU's phased approach to the withdrawal process and Chancellor Merkel's insistence on the UK paying an exit fee before trade talks have added to the uncertainty, with market volatility expected during the negotiations.

site_title: Government will take lead to ensure jobs: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for collective effort between the government, employers, and unions to ensure job security. He highlighted initiatives such as SkillsFuture and Professional Conversion Programmes to support workers and employers. Lee noted that economic growth in Singapore and globally is improving but remains mixed, with rising unemployment and restructuring. He aims for a 2-3% annual growth rate to create new jobs and improve lives.

site_title: American Airlines' pay hikes spark industry stock plunge
summary: American Airlines unexpectedly granted pay rises to pilots and flight attendants, adding $930 million in costs through 2019. The move weakens the airline's case for steady profits, fueling industry stock declines. Analysts predict higher costs will reduce earnings per share by 29 cents in 2017 and 46 cents in 2018. The airline's stock plummeted 7% and the US airline index fell 4.3% after the announcement, sparking concerns about industry consolidation and profit sustainability.

site_title: Fifa scandal spreads as Asia confederation official admits taking bribes
summary: A Guam Football Association president, Richard Lai, has admitted to accepting approximately $1 million in bribes from Asian soccer officials, including former AFC president Mohamed Bin Hammam. Lai implicated Hammam and another official in a US court, alleging they offered him money to influence FIFA elections and advance their interests. Lai faces decades in prison after pleading guilty to two counts of wire fraud. The scandal is part of the ongoing FIFA corruption scandal, which has led to the suspension of several officials and significant financial losses for the organization.

site_title: Trump signs executive order to expand offshore drilling
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed an executive order to expand offshore drilling in the Arctic and Atlantic Oceans, making millions of acres of federal waters eligible for oil and gas leasing. The "America-First Offshore Energy Strategy" aims to assess energy exploration in marine sanctuaries in the Pacific and Atlantic. However, it will take years to rewrite federal leasing plans and open up these areas to drilling. Environmental groups have denounced the policy shift as reckless and possibly illegal, while industry officials hail it as a step towards American energy independence.

site_title: At the Goodwill Outlet, sharpest elbows get the merchandise
summary: A Goodwill Outlet in Queens, New York, held a unique shopping event where customers competed for discounted merchandise by racing to the checkout counter. Participants, some wearing gloves and burlap sacks, lined up behind tape and were instructed to maintain a safe distance and avoid physical contact. The event aimed to promote a fun and fair shopping experience, with the manager emphasizing the importance of following the rules to ensure a smooth and enjoyable experience for all participants.

site_title: Leeches? Just what the doctor ordered - if you're in Russia
summary: In Russia, leeches are commonly prescribed as a low-cost substitute for blood thinners, with 10 million used annually. The venom in leeches is used to treat stroke and heart disease, and the treatment is often chosen for its cost savings and natural benefits. Despite Russia's impoverished medical system, leech applications have seen a resurgence, with medicinal leeches costing less than $1 each. The practice is still not widely accepted in Western medicine, where pharmaceutical companies are instead developing leech-derived products. Russia's state-run healthcare system faces significant challenges, including limited investment and a shortage of medical supplies.

site_title: SIM's international school ready for September opening
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) is set to open its first international school, the SIM International Academy, in September with up to 90 students from the region and beyond. Applications are already being accepted for the inaugural cohort.

site_title: Trump's tax cut plan sparks global tax war fears
summary: US President Donald Trump's plan to slash corporate taxes from 35% to 15% has sparked global concerns of a fiscal race to the bottom, potentially leading to negative social consequences. NGOs warn that falling tax revenues will make it harder for governments to pay for welfare and healthcare benefits, and could lead to increased VAT, disproportionately affecting the less well-off. Analysts predict a global trend of tax competition, with countries such as France, Britain, and Ireland also planning to lower their corporate tax rates.

site_title: US to probe Japanese, German automakers over alleged patent violations
summary: The US International Trade Commission (USITC) has launched an investigation into 25 companies, including BMW, Honda, Toyota, and Japanese parts suppliers, over alleged patent violations related to thermoplastic components used in vehicle models sold in the US. Intellectual Ventures II claims that these components infringe on its patents, affecting models such as the 2016 Toyota Camry and 2017 Honda Accord. The USITC aims to complete its investigation within 45 days.

site_title: China's capital controls sowing risks in its dollar bonds
summary: China's central bank has successfully stemmed outflows of capital, but the efforts have created hidden risks in the swelling market for dollar bonds sold by Chinese issuers. Banks are buying these bonds, which are often issued by government-controlled companies, and then using the proceeds to buy high-yield debt. This creates a complex web of risks, including currency risk, as the bonds are often denominated in dollars and the issuers have little foreign currency revenue. The risks are increasing, with junk-bond issuers churning out a record $12.7 billion of dollar-denominated offerings this year.

site_title: South Korea April export growth hits near 6-year high, trade surplus with US falls
summary: South Korea's exports rose 24.2% in April to $51.01 billion, the largest gain in six months, driven by strong demand for high-tech memory chips. The country's trade surplus with the US declined to $1.68 billion, easing concerns of protectionist measures. Exports to China rose 10.2% and shipments to the US rebounded 3.9% after a 5% drop in March. The trade surplus is expected to fall below $20 billion this year if it continues to decline.

site_title: China's April manufacturing PMI at six-month low
summary: China's manufacturing PMI fell to a six-month low of 51.2 in April, indicating slower growth, amid cooling producer price inflation and efforts to reduce financial risks. Demand weakened, with the biggest decline in the input price sub-index, while the employment sub-index slipped to 49.2. The services sector also slowed slightly to 54.0 in April. China's economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter, but growth is expected to slow as authorities tackle property and financial risks.

site_title: Apple Pay marks first year in S'pore as mobile payments gain traction
summary: Apple Pay marked its first anniversary in Singapore, marking significant traction for mobile payments in the country. The platform has become a rich customer engagement tool, offering convenience and security for both consumers and businesses. Key statistics include a 92% increase in transaction completion rates among Apple Pay users, and a 2.5 times boost in conversion rates for Indiegogo. Mobile wallets are expected to play a significant role in facilitating customer experiences, with companies like Stripe and Klook integrating Apple Pay to enhance their services.

site_title: US security body stops warrantless watch of American e-mails about foreign targets
summary: The National Security Agency (NSA) has halted a warrantless surveillance practice that involved collecting Americans' e-mails and texts exchanged with people overseas that mentioned foreign targets. The practice, known as "upstream" collection, was stopped after NSA analysts violated rules imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The change is unrelated to the Russia investigation and is a major development in US surveillance policy. The decision aims to prevent Americans' communications from being collected without a warrant and will be codified in federal law, according to Senator Ron Wyden.

images.alt_text: The National Security Agency will no longer collect Americans' e-mails and texts exchanged with people overseas that simply mention identifying terms - such as e-mail addresses - for foreigners whom the agency is spying on, but are neither to nor from those targets.

site_title: Pall remains over Canadian oil sands after wildfires
summary: Canada's oil sands remain bleak a year after massive wildfires, which halted oil extraction and refining for nearly a month, slashing production by over a million barrels. Persistently low oil prices have forced companies to cut costs, with several halting local production. The industry's future is threatened by environmental regulations, with Canada aiming to slash greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2030. Major companies have spent billions to buy assets and increase production, but Fort McMurray Mayor Melissa Blake says new growth in the oil sands is unlikely.

site_title: ESPN's woes: it spends too much on content and charges consumers too much
summary: ESPN is facing financial struggles due to its high content costs and pricing for consumers. The sports network pays over $7 billion annually for content, with deals for the NFL, NBA, and college football. As the cable bundle disintegrates, consumers can now choose to opt out of expensive channels like ESPN. The network has lost 12 million subscribers in the last four years, resulting in $1 billion in lost revenue. ESPN has responded with cost-cutting measures, including layoffs, but its profitability is expected to decline as the industry shifts to streaming services, where profits are typically lower.

images.alt_text: Over the last four years, ESPN has lost around 12 million subscribers, from over 100 million to 88 million. It remains hugely profitable, but is no longer the reliable cash cow for Disney that it once was.

site_title: Kudos to the serious shareholder
summary: A Pan-United AGM meeting turned into an edifying event after an investor, Annoyed Auntie (AA), clashed with Serious Shareholder (SS) over the latter's lengthy questions. The altercation led to a productive discussion, with AA and SS engaging in a respectful exchange, and other shareholders asking insightful questions about the company's growth prospects and cost-cutting activities. The meeting showcased the potential for quality questions to be posed at AGMs, offering hope for a more engaged investor community.

images.alt_text: An altercation over a long-winded but dogged investor at the Pan-United annual general meeting (AGM) last Wednesday turned into one of the more edifying meetings I've attended at the company in years.

site_title: HSI structured warrants most actively traded on SGX
summary: Structured warrants, issued by approved issuers like Macquarie Bank, are popular among professional traders in the local market. The most actively traded warrants are those written on the Hang Seng Index. There are two types: calls, which rise when the underlying asset increases, and puts, which rise when the underlying falls. Traders can cash settle positions that are "in-the-money" at expiry, receiving the difference between the index value and the exercise price. The most actively traded warrant mentioned is the HSI25200MBeCW170629, a call warrant on the Hang Seng Index, set to expire on June 29, 2017.

site_title: Korea Inc ready to kill major reforms no matter who becomes president
summary: South Korea's lawmakers are unlikely to pass major reforms aimed at breaking up family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, despite campaign promises to overhaul the system. Only lighter measures, such as electronic voting and legal liability, are likely to pass after the election. The country's economy is expected to expand at the slowest pace since 2012 due to high-profile corruption scandals, bankruptcies, and product recalls. Chaebol reform proposals have been watered down, mirroring past years' efforts, and the National Pension Service has supported the Lee family's attempts to maintain control over Samsung Group.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co, which reported the highest quarterly profit in almost four years last week, said it would not convert into a holding company.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 1, 2017, due to subdued investor sentiment from North Korea tensions and soft economic data from the US and China. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.27% to 19,144.62, and the Topix index declined 0.08% to 1,530.61.

site_title: New Cathay chief to turn carrier around amid bloated costs, new rivals
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's largest airline, has reported its first loss in eight years amid bloated costs and intensifying competition from budget carriers and state-owned Chinese carriers. New CEO Rupert Hogg, a veteran executive with the Swire Group, aims to turn the carrier around with a three-year cost-cutting plan worth US$514 million. Despite concerns that Swire group-think may hinder bold thinking, Hogg has vowed to prioritize customer needs and integrate with the existing management team. The airline's stock has tumbled 25% since the previous CEO took over in 2014, with zero buy ratings from analysts.

images.alt_text: Mr Hogg is a consummate Swire insider with a strong track record, but some analysts wonder if Cathay might be better off with an outsider at the helm.

site_title: Short week but data aplenty to drive STI direction
summary: The local bourse may start the week on a low note due to a short trading week and sluggish US economic data. The US GDP showed a 0.7% growth in the first quarter, its weakest pace in three years, and may lead to a delay in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Key Asian economies will release macro data, including China's manufacturing data and South Korea's inflation data, while Singapore will provide an update on April's PMI. The stock market's recent surge is waning due to economic data concerns and policy uncertainty, particularly with the US presidential election approaching.

site_title: Risen from the grave, Keystone XL pipeline again divides Nebraska
summary: A Nebraska landowners' fight against the Keystone XL pipeline has resumed, with several dozen rural landowners vowing to block the project despite President Donald Trump's decision to clear the way for its construction. The pipeline, which would transport oil from Canada to Nebraska, has sparked concerns over environmental damage and the impact on local agriculture. Opponents argue that the pipeline poses a risk to the Ogallala Aquifer, a vital water source, and that it could harm native grasses and destroy farmland. The Nebraska Public Service Commission will hold hearings on the project in August, with opponents planning to participate in civil disobedience if necessary.

site_title: Two consortiums lodge final bids for Australia's Endeavour Energy
summary: Two consortiums have submitted final bids for Australia's Endeavour Energy, a majority stake expected to fetch at least A$4 billion. The bids come after weeks of due diligence and follow non-binding offers from three groups in February, with one later pulling out. Consortiums led by Macquarie Group and Hastings Funds Management are involved in the process, which is expected to result in a sale of the state-owned utility. The final bids are binding, and a decision is expected soon.

site_title: Asia weighs risk, reward in budding Trump-Xi ties
summary: US President Donald Trump has taken a significant step towards improving relations with China, praising Chinese President Xi Jinping as a "good man" and seeking cooperation on North Korea. The shift in Trump's stance has been welcomed by Chinese officials, who see it as a positive development. However, the relationship's long-term prospects are uncertain, with concerns that the US may be ceding influence to China in the region. Regional allies, such as Japan and South Korea, are also wary of the potential implications of a US-China "G-2" relationship, while the US has yet to challenge China's claims in the South China Sea.

site_title: Thousands march against White House 'assault' on environment
summary: Thousands of protesters, including celebrities and ordinary people, gathered in Washington to mark the 100th day of President Donald Trump's term, denouncing his administration's environmental policies. The People's Climate March aimed to raise awareness about climate change and its impact on vulnerable communities. The protesters, many of whom were influenced by faith or economic concerns, chanted slogans and called for action against Trump's rollbacks of Obama's environmental measures. The demonstration was seen as a sign of growing opposition to Trump's policies, with organizers hoping to build a lasting opposition movement.

site_title: ECB staff appeal against hiring of Draghi adviser
summary: European Central Bank staff are appealing against the appointment of Roland Straub as Mario Draghi's adviser, alleging a breach of ECB rules and risk of demoralizing staff and fuelling euro-scepticism. The appeal claims the board broke rules by directly appointing Straub without a recruitment process, despite no issues with his qualifications. The ECB has two months to respond, and if unsuccessful, the case can go to the European Court of Justice.

site_title: Tujia, Airbnb's rival in china, seeking to raise US$300m
summary: Tujia, a Chinese rival of Airbnb, is in talks to raise over $300 million, valuing the company at over $1 billion. The platform, which has 400,000 listings, plans to split its business into two companies: one for home-sharing and the other for professionally-managed properties. The funding will be used to expand products and properties in China and abroad, particularly in Japan, where there is strong interest from Chinese travelers. This move comes as Airbnb expands rapidly in Asia, facing competition from cashed-up rivals backed by web giants.

site_title: Space mining may be only a decade away
summary: Middle Eastern oil states, such as Saudi Arabia and the UAE, are investing in companies that could mine minerals and water from the moon and asteroids, aiming to diversify their economies. These investments could lead to the establishment of a space industry, with the UAE already investing over $5 billion. Water is a critical resource for fuel, oxygen, and drinking, and the moon is a prime candidate for resource extraction. Companies like Planetary Resources and Deep Space Industries are working on asteroid mining, with some predicting a small, robotic mining operation could begin in about 10 years. Regulatory recognition of asteroid resource property rights has been made, and private companies are exploring the potential of space mining.

site_title: Digital dominant, but still human-centred
summary: A CEO from Dentsu Aegis Network Asia-Pacific envisions a workplace of the future with autonomous drones, diverse skillsets, and collaborative spaces. The workplace will prioritize employee health, energy efficiency, and flexibility. Key features include a decrease in office space, designated collaboration areas, and amenities such as showers, juice bars, and changing facilities. The CEO believes agile working concepts will become standard practice, allowing for a wider variety of skillsets and jobs that don't exist today.

site_title: Riksbank chief proves he's not a 'sadomonetarist'
summary: Swedish central bank Governor Stefan Ingves has overruled half his board to extend the country's quantitative easing program, despite criticism from economists and analysts. Ingves, set to step down in December, is rewriting his legacy after being dubbed a "sadomonetarist" for keeping interest rates too high. The move aims to boost inflation, which has been below the 2% target for over six years, but risks distorting the bond market and fueling housing market imbalances. Ingves' successor will face a challenging task in normalizing monetary policy, potentially facing headwinds from the Federal Reserve's future rate hikes.

site_title: Valuations up, China Sunsine no longer ponders delisting
summary: China Sunsine, a specialty rubber chemicals manufacturer, has abandoned plans to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its shares reaching a historic high. The company reported a 70% increase in net profit to 57.2 million yuan in the first quarter, driven by increased sales volumes and average selling prices. Revenue rose 29% to 574.6 million yuan, and the company expects to increase its annual production capacity to 172,000 tonnes by the end of 2017. With its shares trading at a high of S$0.80, China Sunsine is no longer considering delisting.

site_title: PM Lee, Donald Trump affirm deep relationship between US and Singapore
summary: US President Donald Trump and Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reaffirmed the strong relationship between the US and Singapore through a phone call. They expressed satisfaction with existing cooperation between their countries' ministers and looked forward to meeting each other soon. The two leaders also acknowledged Singapore's deep and longstanding ties with the US, according to a statement from Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

site_title: Trump says North Korea's Kim is 'a pretty smart cookie'
summary: US President Donald Trump praised North Korean leader Kim Jong Un as "a pretty smart cookie" in a television interview, despite soaring tensions over his missile and nuclear programs. Trump expressed admiration for Kim's ability to take over the country at age 27 after his father's death in 2011, but questioned whether Kim is sane. The comments came as Washington seeks China's help to rein in Kim's actions.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump offered some backhanded praise for North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, calling him "a pretty smart cookie" in a television interview that aired Sunday.

site_title: Trump at 100 days: big talk on the economy is sounding hollow
summary: US President Donald Trump is nearing the 100-day milestone in power, with a cold, hard reality setting in about his struggling to articulate a clearly defined worldview. Trump's approval ratings have plummeted, making him the least popular leader in modern US history. Despite initial setbacks, he has shown a capacity to change positions and tone, but his impulsive style and lack of experience in governance continue to pose challenges. Trump's presidency has been marked by policy flip-flops, controversy, and unpredictable behavior, raising questions about the definition of his "Trumpism" and the future of his administration.

site_title: Singapore fourth among cities with most millionaire CEO residents
summary: Singapore ranks fourth globally in terms of cities with the most millionaire CEOs, with 1% of them residing in the city-state. The top five cities are London, San Francisco, New York, Los Angeles, and Singapore. The US dominates the list, with 48% of millionaire CEOs, followed by the UK and France. The average millionaire CEO globally is a 58-year-old male with a wealth of $5 million to $30 million, with half being self-made and 38% having made their wealth from a salaried role.

site_title: First direct London-China train completes 12,000 km run
summary: China's state-run China Railway Corporation has successfully completed the first direct freight train from London to Yiwu, China, covering over 12,000 km in 20 days. The journey, part of China's "One Belt, One Road" strategy, aims to strengthen trade links with western Europe. The train, named the East Wind, is longer than Russia's Trans-Siberian railway but shorter than the record-holding China-Madrid link. The service is expected to be 30 days faster than shipping and offers a more convenient and flexible option for cargo transport.

site_title: Britain gets out the broom to clean up dirty money in London property
summary: Britain has passed a law allowing the seizure of homes from foreigners who cannot explain how they paid for them, a move aimed at exposing dirty money in the London property market. The "unexplained wealth orders" will enable authorities to seize and sell properties, returning funds to the country involved. Campaigners hail the measure as a potentially game-changing tool to stop wealthy individuals from laundering money through London properties, with similar powers already in place in the US. The law follows a campaign in memory of late Russian lawyer Sergei Magnitsky, who died in detention in 2009.

site_title: Anthem-Cigna drama shifts to break-up fee, damages
summary: A federal appeals court has likely dealt a final blow to Anthem's bid to buy Cigna Corp, with the companies now engaged in a fight over a $1.85 billion break-up fee and $13 billion in damages. Anthem claims Cigna's CEO sabotaged the deal, while Cigna accuses Anthem of harassment and sabotage. The US Department of Justice had previously blocked the $48 billion merger, citing concerns it would harm competition and raise prices. Anthem is reviewing its options, while Cigna continues to work through the litigation in Delaware court.

site_title: Significant supply of iron ore to hit market in coming years: BHP
summary: BHP Billiton predicts a significant supply of iron ore will hit the market in the coming years, with Brazil alone expected to deliver 100 million tonnes of high-quality iron ore next year. Despite this, the company remains optimistic on long-term prospects for the metal, citing growing demand in emerging economies such as China, driven by industrialization and urbanization. Iron ore prices are expected to fall further, with ANZ Research predicting a range of US$70-80 a tonne for the rest of the year.

site_title: World's most indebted developer in another fight
summary: China Evergrande Co, the world's most indebted developer, is in a fight with short-sellers after spending HK$6.3 billion on buybacks since March 29. The company's shares have surged 80% in Hong Kong, making it one of Asia's top performers. Evergrande is planning a mainland listing, which could boost its valuation, and its chairman has stated that regulators will consider valuations similar to its Hong Kong shares. The company's buybacks may divert cash from its goal of lowering leverage, but its chairman's stake will increase to 78% after the recent repurchases.

site_title: Goldman Sachs pay plan wins about 93% support from shareholders
summary: Goldman Sachs' pay plan, including CEO Lloyd Blankfein's $22 million provision, received about 93% support from shareholders in the company's annual meeting. This is a significant increase from last year's 33% opposition. The plan's support was partly due to the elimination of a long-term cash incentive award, which reduced Blankfein's pay by 27% in 2016. The decision reflects a shift in shareholder sentiment, as the "say on pay" mandate under the Dodd-Frank financial-reform law has increased scrutiny of executive compensation.

site_title: More record highs for US indexes if jobs data, tax law talks are encouraging
summary: US stocks are expected to reach record highs if jobs data and tax law negotiations are encouraging. The recent rise in technology stocks, led by Microsoft, Amazon, and Alphabet, has drawn investors back into the market. The French presidential election, where Emmanuel Macron won the first round, has also boosted investor confidence. Additionally, President Trump's proposal for a corporate tax cut and the potential for a public-private partnership to boost infrastructure spending have contributed to the market's optimism.

site_title: US wheat farmers face bad weather, but record stockpiles, low prices
summary: US wheat farmers face significant challenges due to bad weather, with Kansas farmers like David Schemm considering alternative crops. Despite record US stockpiles and low prices, global reserves are at their highest ever, and hedge funds expect prices to weaken further. The US Department of Agriculture forecasts the highest domestic stockpiles in almost three decades, and global production is expected to drop 2.3% in the 2017-2018 season. Wheat prices have fallen 11% from a year earlier, and Kansas farmers planted the fewest acres of winter wheat in over a century.

site_title: Didi's record funding round coincides with rough period for Uber
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing raised over $5.5 billion in its record funding round, valuing the company at over $50 billion. The cash infusion coincides with a rough period for Uber, which is facing lawsuits and an image problem. Didi is using the funds to ramp up efforts in artificial intelligence, driverless cars, and competing in foreign markets. The company's CEO, Cheng Wei, appears reticent and cautious, contrasting with Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick, who has faced numerous controversies. Didi's success has investors betting on the company's ability to develop driverless vehicles and expand globally.

site_title: Homes in posh Hamptons back in vogue - as long as they're not mansions
summary: Homes in the Hamptons, a popular vacation spot for Wall Street's elite, saw an 8% increase in sales in the first quarter, with 472 purchases recorded. However, luxury homes sold for $5 million or more plummeted 27, dragging the average sale price down 8.9% to $1.72 million. Discounts for all sales averaged 12%, with luxury properties receiving 16% off, indicating buyers are looking for value amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Director buying value up sharply
summary: Directors of Singapore-listed companies made significant buying activity last week, with 16 firms recording 45 purchases worth S$9.68 million. The buyback value was sharply up from the previous week, while selling activity remained low. Notable purchases included Japfa Ltd, ABR Holdings, and United Overseas Bank, with insider buys in Hai Leck Holdings and Suntec Reit. FIL Ltd became a substantial shareholder of First Resources after buying 81,000 shares. The buying activity follows a rebound in share prices for several companies, with directors taking advantage of the opportunities to increase their holdings.

site_title: Australia home prices brake in April after blistering run
summary: Australia's major cities saw home price rises slow sharply in April, with a 0.1% monthly increase, the weakest since December 2015. Annual growth slowed to 11.2% from 12.9% in March, a welcome respite for policymakers concerned about a debt-fuelled bubble. The slowdown may vindicate recent regulatory steps to cool the market, which include stricter lending standards and higher mortgage rates. However, some markets, such as Sydney and Melbourne, still experienced strong annual growth, with annual gains of 16% and 15.3% respectively.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore also noted this, despite signs of recovery in certain sectors.

site_title: Q1 private housing data points to a bottoming out
summary: Singapore's private residential market showed signs of bottoming out in Q1, with private home prices falling 0.4% and volumes reaching a 15-quarter high. Non-landed property prices remained flat, while resale volumes grew 19% year-over-year. Market watchers expect the market to recover, but with cooling measures, rising interest rates, and uncertain job market, a full recovery may take time. Analysts predict a U-shaped recovery, with prices potentially bottoming out earlier than expected.

site_title: Telcos unveil Mobile Connect service providers
summary: Singapore's Big Three telcos unveil Mobile Connect service providers, allowing users to log in to various online services using just their mobile numbers. EZ-Link, Nets, Fox Networks Group, HungryGoWhere, Singapore Press Holdings Limited, Singtel Dash, and WTS Travel are among the first batch of service providers to offer the digital identity solution. The service is expected to be available later this year, offering users an easy and secure way to sign in to websites and apps, while reducing customer frustration and increasing repeat business.

site_title: Central Region office, retail rents slide even faster in Q1
summary: Singapore's office rental index in the Central Region decreased 3.4% in Q1, the eighth straight quarterly fall, while retail rental index dropped 2.9% in the same period. Office vacancy rates rose to 11.6%, and net demand for office space declined by 64,583 sq ft. In contrast, retail space saw a 441,320 sq ft decline in net demand. Experts predict office rents will turn around earlier than retail, with Grade A CBD rents potentially reaching their inflexion point by end-2017. Retail rents are expected to decline 5-8% this year, with prime spaces moderating by 3%.

site_title: Junk bond affair betrays signs of seven-year itch
summary: The global junk-bond market, which has more than doubled to $2 trillion since 2010, is losing its luster. Investors are withdrawing $10.5 billion from high-yield bond funds, the largest outflow since December 2015. Analysts, including Pictet Asset Management's Percival Stanion, say the market is due for a correction due to benign government yield, default rate, and recovery expectations. Bank of America strategists also recommend selling into strength, citing valuations at or approaching post-crisis highs, and the need for investors to prepare for volatility and potential tax and infrastructure policy changes in the US.

site_title: Surpassing expectations
summary: A news article from April 28, 2017, discusses the challenges and opportunities presented by Thevar 2.0, a densely covered area with elevation changes. The elevation variations provided numerous routing opportunities, allowing designers to create unique structures.

site_title: The Hook Of Art Books
summary: The Singapore Art Book Fair, now in its fourth edition, showcases a variety of local self-published magazines, or zines, covering eclectic subjects such as philosophy and TV show critiques. The fair features unique titles, cool ephemera, and is held at Gillman Barracks until April 30.

site_title: Why getting fired is worse than divorce or the death of a spouse
summary: Research suggests that losing a job has a prolonged and significant impact on mental health, self-esteem, and life satisfaction, taking longer to recover than divorce or the death of a spouse. According to a review of over 4,000 research papers, fired employees never fully recover to pre-employment levels of well-being, with men being hit harder than women. The importance of having a meaningful job and social support from coworkers contribute to the negative effects of job loss, with younger workers and those who receive little support from family and friends experiencing the most significant impact.

site_title: Mother's Day Platter
summary: The Platters, featuring former lead singer Sonny Turner, will perform in Singapore on May 13 for Mothers' Day at Resorts World Convention Centre. The group is known for its classic hits like "I Love You 1000 Times" and "Only You." Turner, the only surviving member of the original Platters, has been inducted into multiple music halls of fame. Tickets are available from S$78 to S$168 with a 20% discount for senior citizens.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q1 net profit more than doubles to S$218m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings' net profit more than doubled to S$217.9 million in Q1 2017, driven by stronger insurance sales and investment gains. Gross premiums rose 19% to S$2.7 billion, while total weighted new sales increased 29% to S$279.8 million. Insurance profit doubled to S$181.8 million, with non-operating profit swinging to a S$44.7 million profit from a year-ago loss. The company attributed the growth to improved financial market conditions.

site_title: Canada's Home Capital secures US$2b credit line
summary: Canada's Home Capital Group Inc secured a US$2 billion credit line from the Healthcare of Ontario Pension Plan, offsetting a 60% drop in shares after the company reported plummeting deposits and an agreement in principle for the credit line. CEO Jim Keohane and chairman Kevin Smith are stepping down due to "potential conflicts." Home Capital, which relies on high-interest yielding deposits, has seen almost 80% of its mortgages in Ontario and faces a crisis of confidence following allegations of mortgage broker fraud.

site_title: The fat monkey between a sore loser and a Garcia winner
summary: Padraig Harrington described Sergio Garcia as a "sore loser" after Garcia's US Masters victory. However, Garcia's win marked his first major championship, ending a 72-year drought for Spanish golfers. Harrington's comment was made during a radio interview, with Garcia responding to the jab. The win marked a significant milestone for Garcia, who has been a dominant force in golf for years.

site_title: HK home prices hit record high for fifth straight month
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a record high for the fifth consecutive month in March, increasing 2.07% month-on-month and 17.8% year-on-year. This surge has been ongoing for a year, prompting incoming leader Carrie Lam to prioritize cooling the market. The high housing costs will be a key challenge for Lam's administration.

images.alt_text: Home prices in Hong Kong have more than quadrupled since 2003, while the median monthly household income has risen 61 per cent. The government expects the private market to provide some 96,000 units in the next three to four years.

site_title: Fancy watching classroom high jinks in China? Just get online
summary: In China, thousands of schools have installed webcams in classrooms to stream live online, allowing parents and teachers to monitor students' activities. The practice has sparked debate about privacy, educational ethics, and the impact on students' academic freedom. While some see it as a way to improve student motivation and academic progress, others view it as an invasion of their privacy and an excessive form of surveillance. Experts warn that the constant monitoring can influence instruction and negatively affect students' potential to grow.

site_title: Town & Country
summary: The Volvo V90 Cross Country is a luxuriously equipped estate with a raised suspension, providing 63.5mm of increased ground clearance, and all-wheel-drive capability. Despite its rugged appearance, the vehicle boasts competent handling and a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine, producing 254 hp and 350 Newton-metres of torque. The Cross Country features various driving modes, including Dynamic, which enhances power and steering, and is equipped with advanced safety features such as City Safety and Intersection Auto Brake. The vehicle offers ample space, including a spacious boot and convenient ingress and egress.

images.alt_text: Volvo V90 Cross Country.

site_title: That wasn't Twain: how a misquotation is born
summary: Mark Twain is often credited with saying "a lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is still putting on its shoes," but a researcher found that the phrase actually originated from satirist Jonathan Swift centuries ago. The quote evolved and was popularized by a Victorian-era preacher, and Twain likely never said it. Quote Investigator, a website run by researcher Gregory Sullivan, has traced the origins of many well-known sayings and offers 10 mechanisms that lead to misquotation and incorrect attribution.

site_title: Crab the opportunity
summary: Sri Lankan-Japanese chef Dharshan Munidasa, owner of Ministry of Crab, has achieved success with his fresh seafood restaurant in Colombo, appearing on Asia's 50 Best Restaurants list. Munidasa's approach to cooking emphasizes the celebration of ingredients, drawing from his Japanese upbringing and Sri Lankan heritage. He prioritizes using locally sourced, natural ingredients and innovative techniques, such as cooking tuna in a short time to preserve its moisture. Munidasa aims to elevate Sri Lankan cuisine, debunking myths like the notion that the most active crab is the healthiest to purchase.

site_title: Singapore March bank loans hit strong pace on trade, oil sector, home loans
summary: Bank lending in Singapore surged 6.3% in March, the strongest pace since November 2014, driven by stronger business lending and mortgages. Business lending rose 8.1%, while housing loans and consumer loans also grew. However, building loans and lending to financial institutions contracted, marking the first decline in two years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributed the growth to regional economic activities and a renewed interest in the domestic private residential property market.

site_title: Keeping it casual
summary: Ermenegildo Zegna, the world's largest luxury menswear brand, introduces made-to-measure casual wear, including jeans, for the first time. The service, launched as part of its overhaul project, allows customers to customize fabrics, styles, and details. Priced from $1,650, the premium denim is designed for a perfect fit and shape. A stylist from Italy will showcase the brand's best fabrics and introduce the new service in Singapore from May 4 to 7. This move aims to develop a more inclusive relationship with customers, according to new artistic director Alessandro Sartori.

site_title: Noble's resolution passed despite massive walkout
summary: Noble Group's special general meeting (SGM) resulted in a 99.73% vote in favor of its 10-into-one share consolidation proposal, despite a massive walkout by shareholders. The proposal aims to reduce volatility and improve liquidity, but shareholders expressed disagreement, citing "no real justification" for the move and concerns about the potential impact on the share price. Shareholders had requested a postponement until after the first-quarter results, but their request was rejected. The resolution will be effective from May 9.

site_title: 'Green cards for cash' facing questionable future
summary: The EB-5 investor visa program, also known as "green cards for cash," is facing a questionable future due to criticism of its two-tier immigration system favoring the rich. The program, which expires on Friday, has been accused of allowing affluent Chinese to invest in high-end real estate in the US, benefiting developers such as Donald Trump and Jared Kushner. Proponents argue it provides capital for economic development, while critics say it should be reformed or abolished. Some Congress members are refusing to re-authorise the program unless significant reform is made.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Navios extends lifeline to First Ship Lease Trust
summary: Navios Maritime Holdings Inc has extended a lifeline to financially troubled First Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) with a US$20 million second priority mortgage convertible loan. The loan, convertible into FSL Trust units, aims to pay down or refinance existing mortgage debt and other loan facilities. Navios may hold at least 50.1% of FSL Trust's issued units upon conversion. The deal is subject to restructuring and regulatory approvals, with a deadline for definitive agreements by Sept 30, 2017.

site_title: Singapore market cap up five months in a row
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen a five-month streak of gains, with the total value of 748 SGX-listed companies rising to S$962.8 billion in April, a 13.6% increase from last year. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,175.44, up 0.13% from the previous month. The finance sector led the gains, while the mining/quarry and agriculture sectors declined. Analysts predict potential impacts from US President Donald Trump's tax reform proposals, which could lead to capital flight from emerging markets to the US, and increased US Federal Reserve rate hikes.

site_title: Local pro golf gets a boost
summary: Local pro golfer Tan Teck Kee has pledged to help Singapore's professional golf scene with a series of tournaments. The 47-year-old businessman, a member of Tanah Merah Country Club, has already sponsored a S$30,000 event and committed to another in June. This support is seen as a boost to the local scene, which faces a gloomy backdrop of only eight local pros qualifying to play in regional events. The Singapore Professional Golfers' Association hopes to stage eight events in 2017, with Tan's involvement helping to alleviate the plight faced by local pros.

site_title: IE Singapore, Guangxi ink pact to develop 'Southern Transport Corridor'
summary: IE Singapore and the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region Government signed a Memorandum of Understanding to develop the 'Southern Transport Corridor', a logistics hub connecting Western China and South-east Asia via Guangxi and Singapore. The Singapore-Guangxi Integrated Logistics Park will be built in Nanning city, providing world-class logistics solutions and strengthening collaboration in Smart City and Technology developments. This partnership aims to capitalize on the Belt and Road initiative, promoting interconnectivity and solidifying Singapore's role as a key node for global connectivity.

site_title: Sweden's six-hour workday could help you live longer
summary: A 23-month pilot project in Gothenburg, Sweden, found that nurses working six-hour days were happier, healthier, and more energetic compared to those working eight-hour days. The study suggests that shorter workdays could lead to fewer sick days, higher productivity, and increased commitment. This experiment has garnered international attention, with the Swedish government considering its implications for reducing healthcare costs.

site_title: Exxon Mobil profit more than doubles on cost cuts, oil price rise
summary: Exxon Mobil's quarterly profit more than doubled to $4.01 billion, or 95 cents per share, driven by rising crude prices and cost cuts. Production fell 4% to 4.2 million barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is the company's first quarterly profit increase since 2015.

site_title: Mediacorp CEO Shaun Seow leaves to join parent Temasek Holdings
summary: Mediacorp CEO Shaun Seow is leaving the firm to join its parent company Temasek Holdings. The board will begin searching for his successor, and he will continue as CEO until September 30.

site_title: Long Storeys
summary: A Singaporean family, the Lohs, had to rebuild their 1960s home due to their growing family, resulting in a unique three-storey, six-bedroom, and six-bathroom residence. Designed by Kelvin Bing, the house maximizes space despite its narrow 19-meter-long and 8-meter-wide plot. The asymmetrical concrete façade and central cantilevered staircase create a sense of openness, while water features and sliding glass doors enhance the airy atmosphere. The family, however, had to compromise on aesthetics to meet their functional needs, with some rooms being smaller than expected.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q1 profit up 4.3% on revenue from new stores
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 4.3% increase in net profit to S$17.1 million for Q1 2017, driven by revenue growth from four new stores opened in 2016. Gross profit margin improved to 25% due to higher rebates and promotions. Earnings per share rose to 1.14 Singapore cents. The company expects the industry to remain competitive, but noted that increased input costs due to food inflation could impact gross margin.

site_title: EU's Tusk says Brexit talks must settle 'people, money, Ireland' first
summary: EU President Donald Tusk said Britain must settle "people, money, and Ireland" issues before discussing a post-Brexit trade deal, calling for phased talks. The EU 27 will adopt guidelines for Brexit negotiations at a summit, focusing on the fate of 3 million EU citizens, a £60 billion exit bill, and avoiding a "hard border" between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Tusk emphasized the need for a united front on Brexit, with leaders set to discuss the relocation of EU agencies and automatic membership for Northern Ireland after Brexit.

site_title: UOB's Q1 profit up 5.4% with boost from buffer in provisions
summary: UOB Group reported a net profit of S$807 million for the first quarter of 2017, exceeding analysts' forecasts of S$757 million. The 5.4% increase in net profit was driven by a buffer in provisions, with total allowances rising 59% to S$186 million. Shares of UOB gained 1.5% to S$21.80, outperforming its peers. Despite a rise in specific allowances on loans, the bank's non-performing loans ratio remained unchanged at 1.5%.

images.alt_text: UOB's trading and investment income was up 20.5 per cent to S$243 million due to higher trading income.

site_title: Oxley's Q3 profit down 12%
summary: Oxley Holdings' net profit for Q3 2017 dropped 12% to S$45.7 million due to lower earnings per share. Revenue grew 91% to S$386.5 million, driven by recognition of revenue from a commercial project and sales of a mixed-residential development. The company cited a lack of a significant gain from the sale of Chiba Port Square in Japan as a contributing factor to the decline.

site_title: US Q1 growth weakest in three years as consumer spending falters
summary: US economy grew at a 0.7% annual rate in the first quarter, its weakest pace in three years, as consumer spending barely increased and businesses invested less in inventories. The labor market is near full employment, but the slowdown is likely temporary. Economists expect a reacceleration in the second quarter, but it's unclear if President Trump's pledge to boost growth to 4% can be achieved. The Trump administration proposed a tax plan to achieve this goal, but no details were provided.

site_title: Big Five banks report slimmer interest margins in Q1
summary: China's Big Five banks reported near-flat first-quarter profits due to shrinking interest margins, despite a slowing economy. Net interest margins (NIMs) fell across the board, with the largest lender ICBC reporting 2.12% and BoCom at 1.57%, the lowest since 2011. Profit growth remained flat, and analysts predict added pressures from a cooling economy. However, some lenders showed a decline in non-performing loans, indicating efforts to combat bad debts may be working.

site_title: China SAIC Motor's profit up 4%
summary: China's largest automaker, SAIC Motor, reported a 4.1% rise in net profit to 8.26 billion yuan (S$1.67 billion) in the first quarter. Revenue rose 6% to 196.3 billion yuan, while vehicle sales increased 3% due to a tax cut on small sedans. The Chinese auto market saw a 7% rise in sales in the first quarter, outpacing predictions of a 5% growth. Despite this, sedan sales remain flat, with strong new offerings in SUV segments outperforming the market.

site_title: Investment philosophy for a retiree client
summary: A retiree client's portfolio was allocated using a low-cost investment approach, avoiding market timing and focusing on rebalancing when necessary. Despite predictions of a market crash in 2016, the client's portfolios generated returns, while those who followed market timing calls missed out. By sticking to a disciplined investment strategy, the client avoided stress and reaped the benefits of a stable income stream, achieving their goal of S$1 million by age 83. This approach is recommended for retirees seeking a reliable income stream and avoiding market stress.

images.alt_text: The year 2016 started with the continuation of sell-off in the emerging markets since 2015 due to fears of slowing growth in Asia. S&P 500 was also at all-time high at the beginning of the year. Then there were of course the fears over Brexit and the results of the US elections.

site_title: Q1 employment falls by 8,500; jobless rate rises to 2.3%: MOM
summary: Singapore's Q1 employment fell by 8,500, resulting in an estimated 74,400 residents, including 67,100 Singaporeans, being jobless. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for residents remained flat at 3.2%, but the overall jobless rate rose to 2.3% from 2.2% in December 2016. The decline in total employment was largely due to a fall in work permit holders in the manufacturing and construction sectors. Experts predict the unemployment rate may stabilize around 2.5% later this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's net profit for its first fiscal quarter ended March 31, 2017, increased 49.6% to US$210.4 million, with revenue rising 16% to US$4.23 billion.

site_title: Honda sees auto sales edging up, profit sliding in 2017/18
summary: Honda Motor Co forecasted a 16% fall in operating profit for the 2017/18 financial year, with an expected operating profit of 705 billion yen (S$8.85 billion). The decline is attributed to a stronger yen and higher research and development costs, despite an anticipated 1% increase in global vehicle sales to 5.08 million units. Net profit is projected to slide 14% to 530.0 billion yen. Honda's focus on developing next-generation cars, including self-driving functions and electric vehicles, is expected to impact earnings.

site_title: S-E Asia a 'homogeneous' region for startup investing
summary: A report by Jungle Ventures, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, challenges the notion that South-east Asia (SEA) is a fragmented startup investment destination. The report finds that the top 10 metros in SEA form a "homogeneous market" with a population of over 100 million and a market potential for online consumption of over $50 billion. Young demographics, Internet connectivity, and technological advances unite the markets, making them attractive for startups. Venture investment and M&A activity have grown in SEA, with total capital invested reaching $2.329 billion in 2016.

site_title: Euro zone inflation may rise quicker than thought in 2017: ECB survey
summary: The European Central Bank's Survey of Professional Forecasters indicates that euro zone inflation may accelerate more quickly than initially thought in 2017, but underlying price growth will rise slowly. The ECB maintains its stimulus measures, citing a lack of a convincing upward trend in inflation excluding energy and food products. This suggests a gradual removal of stimulus, lasting years, even if growth accelerates.

site_title: Indonesia economic growth lifts Jardine C&C Q1 earnings
summary: Indonesia's economic growth lifted Jardine Cycle & Carriage's Q1 earnings, with net profit increasing 49.6% to US$210.4 million. Revenue rose 16% to US$4.23 billion, driven by Astra's automotive and financial services businesses, as well as higher commodity prices. Earnings per share rose to 53 US cents from 36 US cents in the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported new orders of $75 million in Q1 2017, with increased enquiries for non-drilling solutions. The company raised its valuation from 1.4x to 1.6x FY17F book due to better visibility of new orders. Sembcorp Marine also booked a $47 million gain on disposal from its 30% divestment in Cosco Shipyard Group, but registered a core loss of $12 million. Duty Free International Limited, on the other hand, lowered its FY18-19F revenue growth assumptions due to the implementation of a 6% GST at border outlets and duty-free zones.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as North Korea fears weigh on sentiment
summary: US stocks remained flat on Friday, weighed down by concerns over North Korea and a weak US growth report. Despite strong earnings reports from Amazon, ExxonMobil, and Alphabet, investors were cautious due to President Trump's comments on a potential conflict with North Korea. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 lost 0.1% and 0.2% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.2%. US economic growth came in at 0.7% in the first quarter, below analyst expectations.

site_title: SIA names Dominic Ho as independent non-executive director
summary: Singapore Airlines has appointed Dominic Ho, 66, as an independent non-executive director, effective May 1. Ho, an accounting professional, brings experience as a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He previously served as co-chairman of KPMG, China and Hong Kong, and is non-executive chairman of DBS Bank (China) Limited. Ho's appointment aims to enhance the airline's audit committee and bring expertise in accounting and governance.

site_title: UIC's Q1 earnings flat at S$59.8m
summary: UIC's Q1 earnings remain flat at S$59.8 million, unchanged from the previous year. Revenue rose 31% to S$264.5 million, driven by higher sales recognition from trading properties, particularly from residential projects. Earnings per share remained unchanged at 4.2 Singapore cents. No dividend was recommended for the quarter, similar to the previous year.

site_title: Indonesia relaxes reserve requirement rules to stabilise market
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, relaxed reserve requirement rules to stabilize the overnight money market. Starting from July, banks must keep a minimum 5% of deposits at the bank daily and maintain a 6.5% average over two weeks. The new rules give banks 1.5 percentage points of flexibility, allowing them to better manage liquidity and reduce volatility. The move aims to address unequal distribution of liquidity among banks and enable smaller banks to access the market more easily.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened flat on Friday, with profit-taking weighing on the end of a choppy week's trade. The FTSE 100 index remained unchanged, while the Paris CAC 40 index and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index also declined. The focus shifted to the US release of first-quarter economic growth data, which will influence the US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

site_title: Singapore launches first technical framework for LNG bunkering
summary: Singapore has launched its first technical framework for liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering operations, TR56, to help shipowners comply with the International Maritime Organization's 0.5% sulfur content cap in ship fuel from 2020. The framework provides guidelines for two licensed LNG bunker suppliers to develop operational procedures for loading and unloading the fuel onto ships at the Singapore port. The move aims to kick-start LNG bunkering in Singapore ahead of its pilot operations in early 2017.

site_title: China: Stocks post worst month of 2017 on worries over regulation, economic growth
summary: China's main stock indexes ended the worst month of 2017 on Friday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.2% to 3,439.75 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.1% to 3,154.66 points. The country's regulatory crackdown on riskier financing and speculation, and lingering concerns over economic growth, contributed to the decline. Chinese fund managers have reduced their suggested equity exposure for the next three months, and analysts expect sustained efforts by authorities to tighten liquidity and sour investors' sentiment further.

site_title: Low water hinders Rhine shipping in Germany but levels rising
summary: Shallow water on the Rhine in Germany has hindered shipping, with freight vessels unable to sail fully loaded south of Duisburg and Cologne. However, recent rain has raised river levels, allowing normal sailings in southern sections. The Rhine and Danube have been shallow for full loadings since early April, resulting in surcharges on freight rates. The Rhine is a key shipping route for commodities, while the Danube is a major route for east European grain exports.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks pull back from 20-month high
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark stock index fell 0.3% to 24,615.13, easing from a 20-month high, as sector performance was mixed. Chinese investors bought Hong Kong stocks via the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, with 14.2% of daily quota used in the buying direction. Materials and industrial shares rose, while financials and property shares fell. The Hang Seng index rose 2.4% for the week, while the China Enterprises Index gained 1.8%.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near multi-month lows
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near multi-month lows due to investors' concerns over US President Donald Trump's trade policies. The US Commerce Department launched an investigation into aluminum imports from China, which could lead to protectionist measures and negatively impact commodity-led currencies. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7473, its lowest since January 12, and is set to end the month down 2% for its worst monthly performance since December 2016. The New Zealand dollar also sank to a ten-month low of US$0.6847.

site_title: Sharp posts narrower loss for the year, cost cuts paying off
summary: Sharp Corp reported a narrower annual loss of 24.9 billion yen (S$312.5 million), beating expectations, as cost-cutting efforts by Taiwanese owner Foxconn began to show results. The company's fourth quarter saw a net profit of 16.2 billion yen, marking the second consecutive profitable quarter. Sharp plans to give its outlook for the current fiscal year on May 26 and is considering investing in Toshiba's chip unit. The company aims to begin commercial production of OLED displays in the first quarter of the next fiscal year under its growth strategy.

site_title: Singapore shares rise over the week despite an unsure Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.08 points to 3,175.44 on Friday, ending the week with a 1.1% gain. Market uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's tax plans persisted, despite fading concerns over France's general elections. High trading volume of S$1.6 billion on Friday may be attributed to "window-dressing" ahead of the end of the month.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore manufacturers remain optimistic about the business outlook for the next six months. The services sector's business sentiment has improved, and unemployment could rise as the country faces structural changes. In corporate news, several companies reported significant earnings growth, including Great Eastern and iFAST. Meanwhile, a US$130b manager sold Singtel due to rising competition, and HDB resale prices fell 0.5% in Q1. The STI today rose despite uncertainty on Wall Street, with investors monitoring the Trump administration's tax plans.

images.alt_text: Singapore manufacturers are optimistic that business situation will improve in the next six months, based on a business expectation survey by the Economic Development Board released on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares post third straight month of gains
summary: Australian shares rose for the third consecutive month, with the S&P/ASX 200 index ending up 0.04% at 5,924.1. Gains were led by National Australia Bank and ANZ Banking, while healthcare company CSL Ltd and toll road operator Transurban Group were top gainers. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 2.5% for the month, its largest gain since July 2016. The rally was driven by weaker commodity prices and investors positioning themselves ahead of key bank earnings.

site_title: A US$130b manager sells Singtel as competition intensifies
summary: A US$130 billion manager, Henderson Global Investors, has sold its Singtel holdings due to rising competition in the telecommunications sector. Singtel's key markets in Asia are becoming increasingly crowded with Australian carrier TPG Telecom expanding its regional presence. The stock has dropped 4.3% since April 4 after exceeding spending estimates on a Singapore spectrum auction and announcing plans to build a network in Australia. Analysts predict Singtel will report a decline in annual operating profit for the fifth consecutive year. The company is facing short-term pressure, but remains a buy for two-thirds of analysts.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib warns uneven growth could fuel extremism, instability in Southeast Asia
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned that Southeast Asian countries must ensure inclusive economic growth to prevent marginalized populations from turning to violent extremism and radicalization. He noted that the region's strong growth could see Asean become the world's fourth-largest economy, but economic disparity is fueling anger and populism. Najib emphasized the need for trade integration and removal of tariffs to promote awareness and address income inequality among the 620 million people of Southeast Asia.

site_title: Singapore services sector's business sentiment improves for next 6 months
summary: Singapore's services sector business sentiment has improved for the next six months, with a net weighted balance of one percent of firms expecting less favourable conditions. A weighted 14 percent of firms are optimistic, while 15 percent foresee slower business. The information & communications and wholesale trade industries are the most optimistic, while retail trade and food & beverage services are the least optimistic. Operating receipts are expected to remain at a similar level for the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders vote against manager removal, wind-up
summary: Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against removing the underperforming manager (69.48% against) and winding up the Reit vehicle (71.67% against) at its extraordinary general meeting. Despite impassioned venting of frustration, the outcome means business will continue as usual. Unitholders demanded action from the manager to turn the Reit around, but the outcome indicates a lack of appetite for change.

site_title: Trump spurns Taiwan president's suggestion of another phone call
summary: US President Donald Trump has spurned a suggestion by Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-Wen to hold another phone call, citing concerns about creating problems for Chinese President Xi Jinping, who appears to be helping efforts to rein in North Korea. Trump said he values his relationship with Xi and doesn't want to cause any difficulties for him. The call would have been the first between a US leader and a Taiwanese president in nearly four decades, and comes amid improving ties between the US and Taiwan.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime pays US$2.6m to banks
summary: Rickmers Maritime, a distressed container ship business trust, has made a US$2.6 million voluntary prepayment to a syndicate of banks, including BNP Paribas and ING Bank. This payment will deleverage the trust and reduce interest costs, as it utilizes cash not available for other purposes. The move is part of the trust's winding-up process.

images.alt_text: THE trustee-manager of Rickmers Maritime, a distressed container ship business trust, said that it has issued a US$2.6 million voluntary prepayment of cash that had been secured for senior loan facilities extended by a syndicate of banks led by BNP Paribas.

site_title: Navios throws troubled FSL Trust a lifeline
summary: Navios Maritime Holdings Inc has extended financial support to troubled shipping trust First Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) with a US$20 million second priority mortgage convertible loan. The loan, convertible into FSL Trust units, aims to refinance existing debt and pay down mortgage debt. Navios will acquire approximately 154 million units and shares held by FSL Holdings, with the goal of holding at least 50.1% of FSL Trust's total units on a fully diluted basis. The deal is subject to restructuring and regulatory approvals, with a target execution date of September 30, 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day higher, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 0.14 points to 1,768.060. The index saw 3.1 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.89 billion, with gains outnumbering losses 544 to 403.

site_title: Fibrechem's liquidators, potential investors mulling over reverse takeover
summary: Fibrechem Technologies' provisional liquidators met with potential investors to consider a reverse takeover, amid an uncertain economic climate. The parties remain cautious. The Bermuda Court approved a series of adjournments on the liquidation, with the latest extension until October 20, 2017. This has majority support from creditor banks. The company has been suspended from trading since February 2009.

site_title: Taiwan says no plans 'at this stage' for phone call with US president
summary: Taiwan's presidential office stated they have no plans to hold a telephone call with US President Donald Trump at this stage. The decision comes after Trump dismissed the idea of such a call following a comment by Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen that she wouldn't rule it out. The office cited good mutual trust and understanding between Taiwan and the US, but acknowledged the US has priorities in handling regional affairs.

site_title: Japan:Nikkei slips as relief rally sputters
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.3% to 19,196.74, snapping a five-week high, but still posted its largest weekly gain since early December. The broader Topix fell 0.3% to 1,531.80, with Nintendo rising 2.1% after its strong Switch console sales. Despite fading European political worries, relief rally momentum fizzled, and the market remained volatile amid US trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: FLASH: HDB resale prices slipped 0.5% in Q1, after 0.1% dip in Q4
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.5% in Q1, marking a reversal from the 0.1% dip in Q4. This decline follows a period of stability in the market.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks recoil after Trump threatens to scrap trade deal
summary: South Korea's won and shares retreated after US President Donald Trump threatened to renegotiate or terminate a free trade deal with Seoul. The won fell 0.2% to 1,132.6 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 0.1% to 2,208.00 points. Despite this, market heavyweight Samsung Electronics jumped to a record high on hopes of strong quarterly earnings. The government is adopting a "wait and see" stance, awaiting a formal request for renegotiation.

site_title: All eyes on Philippines' gum-chewing, cursing Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to host Southeast Asian leaders, showcasing his unorthodox style, which includes eating with his hands, wearing casual clothes, and using street-level curses. Duterte has sparked controversy with verbal attacks on Obama, Pope Francis, and the European Union, as well as drawing parallels between his drug war and the Holocaust. His behavior has been described as "unstatesmanlike" and has raised questions about his ability to represent the Philippines internationally. Despite this, many Filipinos admire him for his man-of-the-people habits.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on solid Q1 GDP growth
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% on Friday, driven by solid Q1 GDP growth and strong global demand for electronic components. The main Taiex index closed at 9,873.50, with tech shares such as Hon Hai Precision and TSMC up 0.2% and 0.3% respectively. The growth follows a fourth consecutive quarter of expansion, fueled by Apple's new iPhone production. Markets will be closed on Monday for the Labor Day holiday and will resume trading on Tuesday.

site_title: Office rents, prices slump; vacancy rises in Q1: URA
summary: Singapore's office rental index dropped 3.4% in Q1 2017, a larger decline than the 1.8% in Q4 2016. The office price index fell 4% q-o-q, while the islandwide vacancy rate rose to 11.6% from 11.1% at end-Q4 2016. This marks the second consecutive quarter of decline in office rents and prices.

site_title: Trump says he thought being president would be easier than his old life
summary: President Donald Trump reflected on his first 100 days in office, stating he thought being president would be easier than his old life as a businessman. He misses driving and feels isolated due to 24-hour Secret Service protection. Trump also expressed surprise at the media scrutiny and lack of privacy, saying he is "really into your own little cocoon." Despite this, he remains accustomed to seeking advice from friends and former business colleagues.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Thursday reflected on his first 100 days in office with a wistful look at his life before the White House.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Great Eastern Holdings, Global Premium Hotels
summary: UOB Group reported a 5.4% increase in net earnings to S$807 million for the first quarter of 2017, driven by growth in core income. Great Eastern Holdings saw a 125% rise in net profit to S$217.9 million, attributed to improved non-operating profits. Global Premium Hotels shares will be suspended from trading after its public float fell below 10%, as it is being taken private by JK Global Capital for 36.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: 1MDB prosecutors said to eye ex-Goldman banker's money moves
