summary: US prosecutors investigating Goldman Sachs' role in raising $6 billion for Malaysia's 1MDB investment fund are questioning ex-banker Tim Leissner's money moves. They're looking into associations with Low Taek Jho, who allegedly siphoned $3 billion from the fund. US officials are also scrutinizing Goldman's marketing materials for the 1MDB bonds, which they claim were misleading. Leissner, who left Goldman in 2016, has been linked to several shell companies and made payments to himself and others. The investigation is part of a global effort to track money flows from the fund into luxury assets and real estate.

site_title: Jobless rate of Singaporeans in March 2017 stays flat at 3.5% (Amended)
summary: The jobless rate of Singaporeans in March 2017 remained unchanged at 3.5% compared to December 2016, while the total unemployment rate including foreigners increased to 2.3% from 2.2% three months ago. An estimated 74,400 residents, including 67,100 Singapore citizens, were unemployed, with a decrease in employed individuals and redundancies in the first quarter of 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.130 points to 1767.980. Volume reached 94.73 million lots worth RM31.55 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 139 to 73.

site_title: Taiwan posts solid Q1 growth as global shoppers splurge on phones, tech gadgets
summary: Taiwan's economy expanded 2.56% in the first quarter of 2017, driven by strong global demand for electronic components, particularly for the new iPhone. Exports surged, with the island's gross domestic product (GDP) growth easing from 2.88% in the previous quarter. Analysts expect the economy to gain momentum as vendors gear up for Apple's iPhone 8 launch later this year. However, concerns about US trade protectionism remain, and analysts caution that Taiwan's economy remains reliant on external demand.

site_title: Starbucks results disappoint, new CEO must brew up growth
summary: Starbucks' new CEO, Kevin Johnson, faces a challenge in restoring historic growth rates amidst US restaurant and retail slumps. The company cut its full-year profit target due to disappointing second-quarter sales and stalling growth in the US. Despite this, Johnson remained optimistic, citing strong performance in China and accelerating US business. Starbucks lowered its full-year net earnings target to $2.06-$2.10 per share and full-year revenue growth to the lower end of its previously forecast range of 8-10%. Global sales at established restaurants were up 3% for the quarter, but fell short of the 5% growth target.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers optimistic over business outlook in next six months
summary: Singapore manufacturers remain optimistic about their business outlook in the next six months, with 12% expecting an improvement and 5% foreseeing a softer outlook. All manufacturing clusters except chemicals forecast higher production and employment. The electronics and precision engineering clusters are particularly optimistic, driven by strong demand for semiconductor chips. The survey, conducted by the Economic Development Board, saw a net weighted balance of 5% of manufacturers planning to hire fewer workers.

images.alt_text: Singapore manufacturers are optimistic that business situation will improve in the next six months, based on a business expectation survey by the Economic Development Board released on Friday.

site_title: Trump vows to fix or scrap Korea trade deal, wants missile system payment
summary: US President Donald Trump has vowed to renegotiate or terminate the five-year-old US-Korean free trade deal, calling it "unacceptable" and "horrible." Trump blamed the deal on his 2016 Democratic presidential opponent, Hillary Clinton, and said Seoul should pay for a US $1 billion anti-missile system to defend against North Korean missile attacks. The US trade deficit with South Korea has more than doubled since the deal took effect, and Trump questioned why the US is paying for the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system.

site_title: Singapore private home prices continue to slide; non-landed prices stay flat in Q1(Amended)
summary: Singapore's private home prices dropped 0.4% in Q1, marking the 14th consecutive quarter of decline, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Non-landed home prices remained flat, while landed segment prices fell 1.8%. Rentals of private residential properties also declined 0.9%. Despite a decrease in unsold units, vacancy rates for completed homes decreased to 8.1%.

site_title: Ex-Olympus bosses ordered to pay 58.8b yen over fraud
summary: A Tokyo District Court ordered six former Olympus executives, including ex-president Tsuyoshi Kikukawa, to pay a total of 58.8 billion yen (approximately $738.6 million) in damages for a massive accounting fraud. The executives hid about $1.7 billion in losses using outsized consulting fees and buying unrelated companies. The court found Kikukawa, former vice-president Hisashi Mori, and auditor Hideo Yamada the most culpable in the fraud. The executives, including those who received suspended sentences, will appeal the case to a higher court.

site_title: Japan will not make concessions in two-way trade talks with US: Nikkei
summary: Japan will not make concessions in two-way trade talks with the US, according to Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso. The talks started this month, with US Vice-President Mike Pence urging results "in the near future". Aso stated that Japan cannot make concessions, especially on farm tariffs, unlike in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations. The TPP will likely be ratified by remaining 11 nations without the US, with Aso saying there is no chance for renegotiation.

site_title: Two alleged jihadists admit being at Brussels airport during attack: official
summary: Two suspected jihadists, Mohamed Lamsalak and Youssef Ben Hammou, have admitted being in Brussels airport during the 2016 attack, but deny involvement. They were arrested in Spain and charged with belonging to a terrorist organization. Investigators believe the men visited the airport from March 16-23 to buy a car, but the purpose of their trip is unclear. The two men are among nine people taken in for questioning in connection with the attack, which killed 32 people and injured over 320.

site_title: Retail rents, prices down; vacancy up in Q1: URA
summary: Singapore's retail property rental index decreased 2.9% in Q1 2017 compared to the previous quarter, while the retail property price index fell 4% year-over-year. The islandwide vacancy rate for retail space rose to 7.7% at the end of Q1 2017, up from 7.5% at the end of Q4 2016.

site_title: Unemployment could rise further as Singapore faces structural changes: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate could rise further due to structural changes in the economy, according to Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say. The country's economy is in transition, with a 2% GDP growth rate over the past two years, but some sectors remain under stress. Unlike previous recoveries, the transition period is expected to be more gradual and require more time and effort. The government and labor movement must adapt to stay relevant and anticipate the needs of the new economy. Key sectors must also cooperate to sustain productivity gains through mutual trust and effective communication.

site_title: FLASH: URA office rental index slips 3.4% q-o-q in Q1 2017
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) office rental index decreased 3.4% from the previous quarter in Q1 2017. This decline marks a reversal of the trend seen in the previous quarter. The URA office rental index had seen a 0.8% increase in Q4 2016. The drop in rental index is attributed to the available office space and reduced demand for office space.

site_title: In nod to oil industry, Trump to order review of offshore drilling bans
summary: US President Donald Trump has ordered a review of offshore areas currently off-limits to oil and gas drilling, potentially reversing bans on drilling across the Atlantic, Pacific, Arctic oceans, and the Gulf of Mexico. The move aims to expand domestic energy production and undermine environmental protections. The review will replace the Obama administration's five-year oil and gas development plan and encourage seismic surveying to determine potential reserves. Environmental groups have slammed the order, promising to fight it in court.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Friday will order a review of offshore areas currently off limits to oil and gas drilling to determine which might be reopened, in his administration's latest move to expand domestic energy production.

site_title: Japan consumer prices rise in March for third straight month: govt
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.2% in March for the third consecutive month, driven by higher energy costs, according to the internal affairs ministry. This follows a 0.2% increase in February and a trimmed annual inflation forecast by the Bank of Japan. The country's economy continues to battle deflation, despite a recent pickup in exports, as predicted by the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.1% in March: MAS
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.1% in March from February, with loans totaling S$628 billion. This growth was weaker than the 1.7% increase in February. The March figure is also lower than the 2.1% growth in March 2017. The data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore suggests a flat business lending environment.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in Singapore gained 0.1 per cent in March from the month before amid flat business lending, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Friday showed.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally up on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.09% to 3,174.37 on Friday, continuing its week-long upward momentum. The Straits Times Index gained 3.01 points, with 189.9 million shares changing hands worth S$500.1 million. Top gainers included UOB, Great Eastern, and OCBC, while top losers were TalkMed, Jardine C&C, and JSH. Asian markets traded sideways after US tech earnings and the European Central Bank's rate decision.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.06 points to 19,251.81, and the Topix index gaining 0.08% to 1,537.94. The move comes ahead of a holiday week in Japan and as monthly economic indicators largely matched expectations.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust Q2 DPS dips 4.2% (Amended)
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 4.2% dip in second-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.2063 Singapore cents, due to an increase in stapled securities following a rights issue. Despite this, the trust's gross revenue surged 43.1% to S$38.7 million, net property income spiked 29.9% to S$28.9 million, and distribution income jumped 21.4% to S$22.3 million year-over-year. The results were boosted by new properties and better performance in key markets.

site_title: HDB resale prices see steeper fall in Q1
summary: HDB resale prices fell 0.5% in Q1, steeper than the 0.1% dip in Q4 2016. Resale transactions declined 9.6% to 4,530 cases from 5,012 cases. The number of approved subletting applications dropped 6.5% to 9,981 cases. This marks the first quarter of declining HDB resale prices and transactions since Q4 2016.

images.alt_text: HDB resale prices slipped 0.5 per cent in the first quarter, steeper than the 0.1 per cent dip in Q4 2016, data from the Housing & Development Board showed on Friday.

site_title: British inventor takes flight in 'Iron Man' suit
summary: British inventor Richard Browning successfully flew in a personal 'Iron Man' suit at a TED Conference in Vancouver, using thrusters attached to his arms and back. The suit, developed by his startup Gravity, lifted him off the ground and allowed him to hover in a circle. Browning has experimented with various prototypes, including crashes, but has made significant progress, with over a million views on his YouTube video. He aims to create a flight suit that can propel wearers higher and faster, with plans for future development and potential military and commercial applications.

site_title: Boeing seeks US anti-dumping probe against Bombardier jet
summary: Boeing has petitioned the US Commerce Department to investigate alleged subsidies and unfair pricing by Canadian plane maker Bombardier for its CSeries airplane, adding to growing trade tensions between the US and Canada. Boeing claims Bombardier offered its planes at an "absurdly low" price, below production cost, to win a key order from Delta Air Lines. The US Commerce Department has already imposed duties on Canadian softwood lumber, and this investigation could lead to duties on the aircraft to offset any below-cost pricing or subsidies deemed unfair.

site_title: Singapore's automation incentives draw tech firms, boost economy
summary: Singapore's government incentives for automation and productivity have drawn foreign tech firms, boosting the economy. The city-state's strong semiconductor demand and lack of skilled labor have attracted global chipmakers such as Micron Technology and Infineon Technologies, investing billions of dollars in Singapore. This investment has led to significant output growth in the technology sector, preventing a recession late last year. The government's programs, including the Productivity and Innovation Credit and automation support packages, have encouraged manufacturers to adopt robotics and other technologies, helping Singapore move up the value chain and remain globally competitive.

site_title: The Islamic full-face veil and Europe
summary: European countries have implemented partial or total bans on the full Islamic veil. Germany, France, Austria, Belgium, Italy, and the Netherlands have all taken steps to restrict the wearing of full-face veils in public spaces. The European Court of Human Rights has upheld the burqa ban in France, and other countries are following suit, with fines and penalties for violating the bans. The move is part of a broader trend of restricting religious attire in public, with some countries allowing exceptions for health or professional reasons.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet revs up revenue, profit
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a 29% jump in quarterly profit to $5.4 billion, beating market forecasts, and a 22% increase in revenue to $24.75 billion. The Google segment generated most of the revenue, while the "other bets" segment, including smart home devices and self-driving cars, incurred an operating loss. Despite an ad boycott on YouTube, ad revenues for Google rose 19%. The company's new corporate structure has allowed for increased oversight and a more patient approach to investing in its "moonshot" efforts.

site_title: Woman shot by police in London anti-terror raid
summary: A woman in her 20s was shot by police during an anti-terror raid in north-west London, as part of an ongoing counter-terrorism investigation. Three people were arrested on terrorism charges, including a 16-year-old boy, a 20-year-old woman, and a 20-year-old man nearby. A 43-year-old woman in Kent was also arrested. The probe was unrelated to a separate terrorism arrest earlier that day near the Houses of Parliament, where a man was arrested on terrorism charges after being surrounded by firearms officers.

site_title: Singaporean sentenced in US for plot to export bomb parts to Iran
summary: A Singaporean man, Lim Yong Nam, was sentenced to 40 months in prison for helping ship US-made radio frequency modules to Iran, which were used in IED bombs in Iraq. Lim, 43, pleaded guilty to fraud charges related to US sanctions violations and had declared Singapore as the final destination for the electronics. However, the modules were forwarded to Iran, and Lim was aware of the restrictions on sending US-origin goods to the country. He was detained in Indonesia in 2014 and extradited to the US last year.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore private home prices dip 0.4% in Q1, after 0.5% fall in Q4, says URA
summary: Singapore private home prices dropped 0.4% in Q1, following a 0.5% decline in Q4, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This marks the first decline in home prices since 2013. The Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: Le Pen says voters must choose 'for or against' France
summary: Marine Le Pen, the far-right presidential candidate in France, has urged voters to choose between "for or against" France in the upcoming May 7 election runoff, emphasizing her vision of sealing France's borders and quitting the euro. Le Pen's rival, Emmanuel Macron, a pro-EU candidate, has campaigned on free trade and reforming the EU. The latest polls suggest Macron will defeat Le Pen by a margin of 21 points, but Le Pen has sought to broaden voter support by promising not to judge voters based on their origins or background.

site_title: FLASH: URA retail property rental index down 2.9% q-o-q in Q1 2017
summary: The URA retail property rental index declined 2.9% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2017, marking a decrease in rental prices. This drop is attributed to a surplus of available retail space. Meanwhile, the US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of declines. A wave of condo launches in Q3 is expected to test demand for Singapore prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark, potentially affecting the market.

site_title: United settles with dragged passenger, changes practices
summary: United Airlines has settled with the passenger dragged off a flight in April, David Dao, and has implemented changes to its practices. The airline will offer up to $10,000 in compensation to passengers bumped from overbooked flights and reduce overbooking on certain routes. CEO Oscar Munoz apologized for the incident and promised to refocus on customer service. The changes come after a two-week internal review and are intended to repair the airline's image after the viral video of Dao's removal.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q1 net profit more than double from a year ago
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$217.9 million for the first quarter of 2017, more than doubling from S$96.9 million in the same period last year. The improved performance was driven by higher non-operating profit from narrowing credit spreads and equity market rallies, as well as higher profits from shareholders' fund investments. Insurance business profit rose to S$181.8 million, mainly due to higher contributions from its Singapore business.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as ECB stands pat, banks drop
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Thursday, after a widely expected European Central Bank decision to maintain its ultra-easy policy stance. Despite acknowledging the euro zone's economic growth and lower inflation risks, the ECB failed to provide clear direction for markets. Weaker bank performances, particularly from Deutsche Bank and Spain's Banco Popular, weighed on the broader market, while some companies, such as Mediclinic and SKF, rose on upbeat earnings.

site_title: UOB's Q1 earnings up 5.4% on growth in core income
summary: UOB Group reported a 5.4% increase in net earnings to S$807 million for Q1 2017, driven by growth in core income. Total income rose 7.8% to S$2.12 billion. The non-performing loans ratio remained stable at 1.5% and NPL coverage remained high at 118%. Gross loans increased 9.4% to S$229 billion, while deposits rose 1.9% to S$260 billion. The fully-loaded Common Equity Tier 1 Capital Adequacy Ratio rose to 12.8%.

images.alt_text: UOB Group reported net earnings of S$807 million for the first quarter of 2017, up 5.4 per cent from a year ago.

site_title: Gold fails to touch highs reached before Trump's win
summary: Gold prices have failed to recover to pre-Donald Trump's election highs, despite his unpredictable policies. After a 13% drop from its peak in December 2016, gold prices have remained subdued, influenced by a strong US economy and rising bond yields. Investors now doubt gold's ability to serve as an inflation hedge, with predictions from Goldman Sachs forecasting a price drop to $1,200 in three months. Experts attribute gold's lackluster performance to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the US economy's resilience.

site_title: Zoning move fuels debate over NY's garment district
summary: New York City's garment district is facing a zoning change proposal that could force out industrial tenants and shift the industry to Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The plan, backed by Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration, aims to strip zoning protections and offer incentives for businesses to move to Brooklyn. Opponents argue that the change will destroy an ecosystem built over decades, while supporters claim it will bring in new investments and jobs. The debate is part of a long-standing discussion about the future of urban manufacturing in the city.

site_title: Euro dips against US dollar on dovish ECB tone
summary: The euro dipped against the US dollar on Thursday after European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi's statement, which suggested policymakers did not discuss removing the bank's easing bias on monetary policy. The euro was last down 0.3% against the US dollar at $1.0875. In contrast, the US dollar rose against the Swedish crown and yen after the Riksbank and Bank of Japan signaled extended stimulus efforts. The US dollar index was up 0.1% at 99.104.

site_title: StanChart renews marathon sponsorship until 2019
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has renewed its 15-year sponsorship of the Singapore Marathon until 2019, committing S$11.4 million, a 8.6% increase from its previous three-year deal. The bank's CEO, Judy Hsu, emphasized the importance of the event to the bank and the community, citing its role in promoting running and community cohesion in Singapore. The marathon is expected to attract 50,000 participants this year, with over 2,600 employees from Standard Chartered taking part in the event.

site_title: Merkel, May draw Brexit battle lines
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May and German Chancellor Angela Merkel have drawn Brexit battle lines, with Merkel warning that the UK should have no "illusions" about its future relationship with the EU after Brexit. The EU has set "red lines" for negotiations, including Britain's financial obligations and immigration rules, and Merkel has stressed that talks on Britain's future relations must be tied to progress on these issues. May has accused other EU countries of lining up to oppose Britain, but polls suggest her Conservatives will return to power in June with an increased majority.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May (right) on Thursday accused the other 27 EU countries of lining up to oppose Britain over Brexit after Germany's Angela Merkel (left) said the UK should have no "illusions" over the exit process.

site_title: Cyberattacks involving extortion are rising, says Verizon
summary: Cyberattacks involving ransomware increased by 50% in 2016, with 60% targeting vulnerable organizations and businesses, according to a report by Verizon Communications Inc. Government organizations, healthcare businesses, and financial services were the most frequent targets. The rise in ransomware attacks is linked to the growing market for bitcoin, used to demand ransom payments. Phishing e-mails, often targeting specific job functions or individuals, were used to carry out 20% of malware raids in 2016.

site_title: China needs to boost economic pressure on North Korea: US
summary: The US State Department urges China to increase economic pressure on North Korea, citing Pyongyang's recent nuclear testing. The US is stepping up sanctions to force North Korea to resume dialogue over its nuclear program. China is expected to take a lead in applying economic pressure, with US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to press for global action at the UN Security Council. The increased pace of North Korea's nuclear testing is seen as a game-changer that requires immediate attention.

images.alt_text: Beijing "frankly has to put economic leverage on North Korea," spokesman Mark Toner said.

site_title: US: Earnings lift Nasdaq to record; Amazon, Alphabet up after hours
summary: The Nasdaq Composite reached a record high on Thursday, driven by earnings gains in tech companies like Amazon and Alphabet, which jumped over 4% after hours. The S&P 500 and Dow were little changed. Earnings estimates for S&P 500 companies rose 12.4% in the first quarter, the most since 2011. The tech-heavy index is expected to extend its record-breaking gains, despite questions over the Trump administration's tax reform plan and its potential impact on deficit hawk concerns in Congress.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite ended at a record high on Thursday, boosted by results-related gains in Comcast, PayPal and Intuit, while the S&P 500 and the Dow were little changed.

site_title: Amazon delivers strong profits, shares rally
summary: Amazon delivered stronger-than-expected financial results for the first quarter, with profit rising 41% to $724 million and revenues growing 23% to $35.7 billion. The company's shares jumped 3.5% in after-hours trade. Amazon's cloud computing unit, AWS, saw significant growth, with revenue up 43% to $3.7 billion. The company is expanding into streaming video, streaming NFL games, and artificial intelligence, with Alexa-powered devices becoming increasingly popular. Amazon's Prime membership has reached 80 million US members, with an average annual spend of $1,300.

site_title: Microsoft quarterly profit up 28% at US$4.8b
summary: Microsoft reported a 28% increase in net profit to $4.8 billion in its fiscal third quarter, driven by strong revenue growth in cloud and business services. Revenue rose 8% to $22.1 billion, with cloud and business services operations contributing to the gains. However, revenue from personal computing, including the Windows operating system, fell. The company's Office commercial products and cloud services revenue increased 7%, while search advertising revenue rose 8%. Shares fell 1.8% in after-hours trade following the results.

site_title: Victoria Park Close bungalow being sold for S$40m
summary: A luxury bungalow in Singapore's Victoria Park Good Class Bungalow Area is being sold for S$40 million, with a price of S$1,335 per square foot. The 29,955 sq ft property features a two-storey house with a basement, five bedrooms, a swimming pool, and a koi pond. This deal brings the total value of S$168.25 million in GCB Area transactions this year, according to CBRE's analysis, boosting investment sentiment in the Singapore residential property market.

images.alt_text: The Victoria Park Close bungalow was built about 20 years ago and is on a sprawling site of 29,955 sq ft with 999-year leasehold tenure.

site_title: You are what you drink - and discard
summary: A photography exhibition titled "Equivalence" by Stefen Chow and Lin Hui-Yi showcases 1,000 images of discarded drink cans in Singapore, highlighting the country's karung guni (recycling) trade. The display, which features 10 rows and 50 columns of images, demonstrates the economic impact of global commodity price fluctuations on the recycling industry. The exhibition aims to portray the interconnectedness of the global economy and the effects on daily life, as the couple has previously used art to highlight socio-economic trends in their work, including the Poverty Line project.

site_title: AA Reit's Q4 DPU suffers as property income dips
summary: AA Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 5.8% to 2.78 Singapore cents, down from 3.02 cents in the same quarter last year, due to lower net property income and higher retained distributions. Full-year DPU declined 2.6% to 11.05 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income also dropped, while the net asset value decreased to S$1.39. Despite the decline, the manager expressed optimism for early signs of recovery in the Singapore industrial market.

site_title: Promoting Chinese culture through films
summary: The Singapore Chinese Film Festival is celebrating its fifth anniversary with a lineup featuring award-winning films by first-time directors, including Wong Chun's "Mad World" and Zhang Dalei's "The Summer is Gone". The festival showcases restored classics and Singapore short films, with all films screened unedited and in their original dialogue. Vice-chairman David Lee attributes the festival's focus on deserving films to its championing of social realism and promoting Chinese culture. The festival runs for ten days, featuring a diverse range of films, including dark dramas and light-hearted genre films.

site_title: Oil prices felled by Libyan oil restart and weak gasoline demand
summary: Crude oil prices fell after Libya's Sharara and El Feel oilfields restarted production, adding nearly 400,000 barrels per day. US gasoline futures led the decline, with inventories rising by the most in nearly three months. Global crude oil inventories remain high, and concerns about the persistent oil glut led OPEC and Russia to discuss extending a six-month production cut deal. US gasoline demand is down 1.8% from last year, and oil stocks in industrialized countries are 336 million barrels above the five-year average.

site_title: US launches national security probe into aluminium imports
summary: The US Commerce Department launched an investigation into national security concerns related to aluminium imports, citing extreme competitive pressure on the US aluminium industry. The probe, similar to one for steel imports, aims to determine if imports from China and other countries pose a threat to US national security. The investigation will assess the effects on US defence needs, jobs, and investments, and may lead to broad import restrictions on aluminium.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's return to growth delayed as trading revenue trails
summary: Deutsche Bank's trading revenue trailed peers in the first quarter, with bonds and currencies revenue increasing 11% and stocks revenue declining 10%. The bank's fixed income revenue rose 24% compared to the US top five investment banks. Despite net income rising to 571 million euros, investors remain cautious about the bank's return to growth, with concerns about capital strength. CEO John Cryan attributed the weaker results to the bank's growing strength, and analysts expect further growth in the coming months.

site_title: Trump's tax plan brings cheer to hedge funds
summary: US hedge fund managers are optimistic about President Donald Trump's tax cut plans, which include a 15% tax rate for pass-through businesses. Trump unveiled the plans, aiming to deliver on his pledge for sweeping tax reform. This development comes after his surprise election sparked a powerful stock market rally, further warming the hearts of US hedge fund managers.

site_title: Interchangeability of Singapore and Brunei's currencies facilitates trade and investment: MAS
summary: Singapore and Brunei have maintained a 50-year currency interchangeability agreement, facilitating trade and investment between the two countries. The agreement eliminates forex rate risks and minimizes transaction costs, allowing for stronger economic flows. Despite economic challenges, the arrangement has deepened economic and financial linkages between the two nations, preserving stability and promoting cooperation.

site_title: This isn't tax policy; it's a Trump-led heist
summary: US President Donald Trump has proposed a tax cut plan that would benefit corporations and the affluent, while largely leaving low-income families behind. The plan would eliminate the alternative minimum tax, lower the corporate tax rate, and allow business owners to dodge personal income tax. Critics argue that the plan is a "heist" and would increase the national debt, with estimates suggesting it would add $20 trillion to the federal debt by 2036. The plan's focus on corporate tax cuts is seen as hypocritical, given Trump's record-low approval rating and ongoing investigations into Russia's involvement in his election.

site_title: China spicy soup chain HaiDiLao eyes expansion overseas
summary: China's spicy soup chain, HaiDiLao, plans to open 80 outlets this year, with 10 outside China, as it expands abroad. Chairman Zhang Yong expects revenue to jump 30% to $2 billion. The company is testing its hotpot concept in the US and UK, with a focus on China's growing global influence. Despite challenges in replicating its Chinese model in the US, HaiDiLao aims to capitalize on China's growing reputation as a culinary destination.

site_title: South Korea's Kia invests in Indian factory after China troubles hit profit
summary: Kia Motors Corp, a South Korean carmaker, has signed a deal to invest $1.1 billion in its first factory in India, aiming to tap the fast-growing market amid sagging China sales. The factory, set to begin production in 2019, will produce 300,000 vehicles a year and leverage Hyundai's supply chain network. Kia's China sales slumped 19% in the first quarter due to anti-Korean sentiment and a conflict with dealers, prompting the investment in India. The move is expected to help Kia gain a foothold in the Indian market, which is tipped to become the world's third-largest by 2020.

site_title: Maritime Singapore steps up on digitisation and automation
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) is stepping up its digitisation and automation efforts, with Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs) signed with industry partners. The goal is to enable remote operation of ships in Singapore's waters, handling both manned and unmanned vessels. The MPA is also expanding its Living Lab test-bedding support, preparing the port for future advancements in maritime operations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singaporean real estate investment trusts (REITs) CDL Hospitality Trust and Suntec Reit reported Q1 2017 results in line with expectations. CDL Hospitality Trust's distribution per unit and revenue increased by 3.9% and 6.4% year-over-year, driven by strong revenue growth in New Zealand. Suntec Reit's core distribution per unit and topline revenue grew 4.2% and 12.9% year-over-year, respectively. Meanwhile, Ho Bee Land Limited's residential projects in Shanghai and Zhuhai maintained positive sales momentum, despite cooling measures. Analysts have set target prices for the REITs, with CDL Hospitality Trust at S$1.64 and Suntec Reit at S$1.80.

site_title: Draghi sees diminished growth risks even as inflation is lacking
summary: E ECB President Mario Draghi stated that euro-area growth risks have diminished, despite core inflation falling short of the European Central Bank's comfort zone. The region's recovery is becoming "increasingly solid," and the ECB will keep policy unchanged for an extended period, with rates possibly lower. Draghi emphasized that underlying inflation pressures remain subdued, and the bank will maintain flexibility in its asset purchases and interest rates.

site_title: Westports sees lower Q1 pre-tax profit despite rise in revenue
summary: Westports Holdings Bhd reported a 15% decline in pre-tax profit to RM179 million for the first quarter of 2017, despite a 9% increase in revenue to RM520 million. The decline was mainly due to higher fuel costs. Container throughput inched up 1% to 2.43 million TEUs, but the company aims to maintain similar throughput due to market changing conditions. Westports is targeting a total container handling capacity of 12.5 million TEUs per annum after expansion works.

site_title: Josephine Teo, Desmond Lee promoted to full ministers from May 1
summary: Singapore will have two women full ministers in the Cabinet for the first time, after Senior Minister of State Josephine Teo was promoted to Minister in the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) and Second Minister at the Manpower and Foreign Affairs ministries. Desmond Lee, a 40-year-old, joins her as a fellow Minister in the PMO and Second Minister for Home Affairs and National Development. The changes are part of ongoing leadership renewal, effective from May 1, and mark a milestone for Singapore's women in politics.

images.alt_text: Mrs Teo: Appointed Minister in Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Manpower and Foreign Affairs.
Mr Lee: Will be Minister in the PMO and Second Minister for Home Affairs and National Development.
Mr Teo: Stepping down to rejoin private sector and to spend more time with family.

site_title: Aftermath becomes an afterthought
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger's latest film, Aftermath, about a Ukrainian immigrant's quest for revenge against an air traffic controller blamed for a plane crash, falls flat. The drama, co-produced by Schwarzenegger, explores themes of grief, guilt, and retribution, but the heavy-handed approach and poor performances, particularly from Schwarzenegger, detract from the emotional impact. The film's conclusion, a revenge murder, feels like an afterthought, undermining the movie's potential to deliver a compelling and nuanced exploration of human error and tragedy. The movie received a rating of C.

images.alt_text: Aftermath, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger (above) and Scoot McNairy, is based on the 2002 Überlingen mid-air collision between a chartered plane and a cargo jet over Germany.
Aftermath, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Scoot McNairy (above), is based on the 2002 Überlingen mid-air collision between a chartered plane and a cargo jet over Germany.

site_title: Never too small a nation for big innovation
summary: Singapore is a prime test bed for new technologies, despite its small size, thanks to its focus and innovative ecosystem. The city-state's business-friendly environment, world-class education system, and supportive government have attracted top entrepreneurs and tech innovation from around the globe. Singapore's infrastructure, regulatory framework, and access to emerging markets make it an ideal location for startups, with the government's new umbrella brand, Startup SG, further supporting innovation. With its unique blend of East and West, Singapore is poised to continue its growth as a leading technology and innovation hub.

site_title: Netflix too big to squawk over rollback of Web protections
summary: President Donald Trump's FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, has reopened the debate on Internet regulation, potentially rolling back net neutrality protections. Pai claims the internet was not broken in 2015, dismissing concerns as "hypothetical and hysterical." The FCC is scheduled to vote on Pai's proposal on May 18, which could lead to a public fight between pro-net neutrality advocates, including Netflix, and opponents like AT&T and Verizon. The Internet Association, representing Silicon Valley companies, criticizes the proposal, stating it would result in a worse internet and less innovation.

site_title: SGX not alone in facing delistings, privatisations
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is not alone in facing delistings and privatisations, as other bourses worldwide are also experiencing a trend driven by technological disruption and low valuations. Companies like OSIM International and Eu Yan Sang have delisted from the local market, but this is a global phenomenon, with Hong Kong-listed firms also delisting to switch to mainland China due to low valuations. The trend is attributed to technological disruption, low valuations, and the availability of private funding sources, affecting markets globally, including the US, UK, and UK.

site_title: Saudis seen losing market share to Iran, Iraq after oil cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude exporter, is losing market share to Iraq and Iran due to Opec's agreement to curb supplies. Saudi Arabia, the top producer, agreed to cut 486,000 barrels a day, while Iran increased output by 90,000 barrels a day. This has led to a decline in Saudi Arabia's market share, with Iran and Iraq gaining ground. The Opec deal aims to bolster prices, but its effectiveness is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Saudi Minister of Energy and Industry Khalid Al-Falih hints of an extension to the supply curbs

site_title: 100 days of surprises and policy U-turns
summary: US President Donald Trump has defied expectations with his first 100 days in office, reversing several campaign promises and policy reversals. Despite initial fears, Trump's voters and Wall Street remain supportive, citing his economic nationalist and isolationist policies. Trump has abandoned plans to deport 11 million illegal immigrants, bar Muslims from entering the US, and withdraw from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (Nato). The US Embassy in Israel will not move to Jerusalem, and trade agreements such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) have been abandoned. Trump's approval ratings remain strong, with financial markets bullish on his economic policies.

site_title: TransferWise eyes Asia with Singapore as Asia-Pac hub
summary: TransferWise, a $1 billion remittance startup, has established Singapore as its Asia-Pacific hub to expand into the region and explore markets such as China, India, and South Korea. The company launched its international money transfer service in Singapore, with plans to hire 30 staff by the end of 2017. CEO Taavet Hinrikus cited demand from expats in Singapore who seek cheaper and faster remittance options, and the country's fintech focus as key drivers for the move. TransferWise aims to offer more competitive rates and faster transfer times compared to traditional banks.

site_title: Session mixed on doubts over US tax plan
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 2.4 points to 3,171.36, with moderate turnover of 1.8 billion units worth S$1.1 billion. The US tax plan, unveiled by President Trump, was a major concern, with analysts questioning its feasibility. Despite this, the broad market still showed an advance-decline score of 255-207. Shares of CapitaLand rose S$0.04 to S$3.76, with analysts expecting the company to benefit from its scale in the serviced apartment and shopping mall business.

site_title: PepsiCo's new Jurong plant to supply 20 Asia-Pacific markets
summary: PepsiCo has officially opened its first concentrate plant in 10 years in Jurong, Singapore, with a $130 million investment. The plant will supply beverage concentrates to 20 Asia-Pacific markets, replacing a plant in Ireland. The facility supports PepsiCo's goal of producing healthier drinks, with a target to reduce calories and added sugars in its beverages by 2025. Singapore's strategic location enables efficient distribution to the region, and the plant's flexible manufacturing and energy-efficient technology make it a model for advanced manufacturing.

site_title: Industry 4.0 smarts vital to maintain Singapore's edge in manufacturing
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded by 10.2% in March, exceeding expectations, and may have driven faster-than-thought GDP growth in the first quarter. The sector accounts for 20% of GDP, and the government aims to maintain this share through Industry 4.0 technologies like robotics, digitalization, and data analytics. To remain competitive, investments in R&D, technology adoption, and a skilled workforce are crucial. The government has budgeted S$19 billion for RIE 2020 and A*Star is building AM capabilities with initiatives like Tech Access and Tech Depot to support SMEs and multinationals.

site_title: Meijin Energy, China Broadband vie for M1
summary: Meijin Energy and China Broadband are among the bidders vying for Singapore wireless carrier M1 Ltd in a potential $1.4 billion sale. The companies have submitted first-round offers, with Meijin Energy considering the purchase despite stricter capital controls. M1's largest owners, Axiata Group Bhd, Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation Ltd, and Singapore Press Holdings Ltd, have appointed Morgan Stanley to explore options including a sale. The sale comes as Singapore prepares to roll out a fourth mobile operator, aiming to bring down phone bills and improve services.

site_title: Swee Say unveils more help for PMET job-seekers
summary: Minister of Manpower Lim Swee Say unveiled additional schemes to help professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) in the manufacturing sector. The schemes include wage and training subsidies and professional guidance through the SkillsFuture Career Advisors programme. 75 industry veterans have volunteered their services to advise PMETs on career pathways and skills required for manufacturing jobs. The schemes aim to bridge the gap between job vacancies and job seekers, with over 60 PCPs available under the Adapt and Grow initiative.

site_title: Industrial rents and prices continue decline in Q1
summary: Singapore's industrial rents and prices continued to decline in Q1, with a 2.2% drop in industrial space prices and 0.9% decrease in rentals. Despite robust trade and manufacturing data, the decline is attributed to a time lag between economic recovery and demand for industrial space, as well as an oversupply of space. Occupancy rates remained steady at 89.4%. Consultants expect a lagged recovery and anticipate downside risks, including anti-globalization sentiment and US President Trump's policies, affecting the manufacturing sector.

site_title: 'Sea spray' appeal of wines from the coast of Sonoma
summary: The Sonoma Coast wine region in California has been gaining attention for its unique wines, with a recent tasting of 20 Chardonnays showcasing its potential. Despite being geographically unwieldy, the region offers a range of styles, from coastal and fruity to inland and richer. The author, who has emotional ties to the area, notes that wine has a powerful ability to evoke memories and emotions, and the Sonoma Coast wines are no exception, with a "sea spray" quality that sets them apart.

site_title: Art ponders a world in crisis
summary: A Shanghai exhibition, "Seeds Of Time," explores the global crisis of species extinction and environmental devastation. Curated by Han Ulrich Obrist and Yongwoo Lee, the show brings together artists, architects, and experts to discuss solutions for the future. The exhibition references the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, which holds nearly a million plant seeds to help restore life on Earth. Works by artists such as Maya Lin and Diller Scofidio + Renfro highlight the issue of environmental destruction, while others, like Qiu Zhijie, envision a new world. The show aims to drive attention to the crisis and spark new alliances to address it.

site_title: Economists see MAS seeking labour market clues before next move
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released its half-yearly macroeconomic review, painting a rosier external outlook but warning that the labour market may pose a challenge. Despite a stronger global economy, Singapore's domestic-oriented sectors such as retail and construction continue to struggle. MAS expects unemployment rates to rise this year, and the labour market's development will be crucial in determining when the central bank will next adjust its policy stance. Economists believe that the case for an "extended period" of a neutral stance has weakened, and a tightening is expected once the labour market strengthens and growth becomes broad-based.

site_title: Singapore and Guangzhou sign LOI to commit to investments in technology
summary: Singapore and Guangzhou signed a letter of intent to commit to investments in technology, aiming to jointly incubate and manage technology projects. The agreement also includes a collaboration between the Chinese Academy of Sciences Holdings and the Nanyang Technological University's Sino-Singapore International Joint Research Institute. The partnership will provide technical support and advisory services, connecting the firms to leading international technology platforms. The move is expected to enhance economic cooperation and enrich the economies of both cities.

site_title: Dropbox reaches key profit milestone on path to IPO
summary: Dropbox Inc has reached a key profit milestone, generating a profit excluding interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) for the first time. CEO Drew Houston stated that the company is operating at a high scale with high profitability, growing at a rate of its peers. Dropbox has previously announced milestones, including becoming free cash-flow positive and reaching $1 billion in annualized revenue. The company is moving closer to an initial public offering (IPO) and is expected to go public by the end of this year.

site_title: Keppel unit bags US$40m contract
summary: A Keppel unit has won a US$40 million contract to deliver the first tension leg wellhead platform (TLWP) to be deployed offshore Vietnam. The TLWP, valued at US$500 million, will be built in Vietnam and deployed in the Ca Rong Do field development. Keppel O&M's Keppel FloaTEC LLC will execute the contract, marking the company's first independent TLWP win. The project is seen as a significant milestone for Vietnam's oil and gas industry, with PTSC M&C and Repsol as key partners.

site_title: BT Weekend redefines work
summary: The Business Times' Weekend magazine explores the future of work, suggesting that being a digital nomad could be a viable option, allowing individuals to work for any company globally from anywhere. This shift in work culture is redefining the concept of work and potentially changing the way we approach our daily commutes.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 DPU falls 6.3%
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 6.3% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter ended March 31, 2017, to 1.18 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also fell slightly, mainly due to lower contributions from certain properties.

images.alt_text: "The retail environment continues to be challenging as retailers face both structural and cyclical changes," said chairman Mr Yeoh.

site_title: US$ gains against euro after ECB decision
summary: The US dollar gained against the euro on Thursday after the European Central Bank (ECB) left interest rates unchanged, maintaining its unprecedented stimulus to combat low inflation. Sweden's crown fell sharply after its central bank injected more money into its economy. The ECB's decision was in line with expectations, with inflation remaining below target despite accelerating growth.

site_title: HK regulator to look into share pledge financing
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is reviewing share pledge financing, following a 85% plunge in shares of China Huishan Dairy Holdings Co Ltd last month. The regulator will examine the extent to which share pledges can unravel and may introduce guidelines for such financing. SFC CEO Ashley Alder also plans to crack down on overly-valued asset sales, initial public offerings, and IPO sponsor failures.

site_title: Hong Kong pursuing free trade agreement with Australia
summary: Hong Kong is pursuing a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with Australia, aiming to strengthen its international economic ties. This comes after the government announced plans to secure 13 more comprehensive avoidance of double taxation agreements (CDTAs) to resolve double taxation issues. The move is part of Hong Kong's efforts to enhance its economic cooperation and competitiveness globally.

site_title: Be open to ideas on addressing AGM clustering
summary: Singapore's AGM (Annual General Meeting) clustering issue may be addressed by extending the AGM deadline to five months, allowing issuers to provide longer notice periods and potentially easing the problem. This would put Singapore on par with other major markets like Australia, Hong Kong, the UK, and the US. Some argue that clustering is unavoidable, but others propose alternative solutions such as non-December year-ends, electronic online voting, and webcasting. Physical attendance remains crucial for retail investors seeking to engage with boards and hold them accountable.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q1 earnings down 44%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 44% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$5.39 million in Q1, mainly due to a 29% drop in revenue from development properties. Earnings per share fell to 0.5 Singapore cent from 0.8 Singapore cent a year ago. The decline was attributed to lower revenue from development properties.

images.alt_text: TUAN Sing Holdings' net profit slumped 44 per cent year on year to S$5.39 million for the first quarter ended March 31, weighed down by a decline in revenue.

site_title: Amgen's new cholesterol drug falls short as sales driver
summary: Amgen's new cholesterol drug Repatha underperformed in its first quarter, with sales of $49 million, missing analyst estimates of $71.6 million. This comes as the company struggles to grow sales of its older drugs, such as Enbrel, which fell 15% from last year. Despite this, Amgen raised its 2017 earnings forecast and reaffirmed its revenue projection, citing a potential tax reform under the Trump administration as a potential catalyst for growth.

site_title: Twitter shares surge as Q1 results beat expectations
summary: Twitter's Q1 results beat expectations, with monthly active users growing 9% to 328 million. The company narrowed its net loss to $62 million, and while revenue fell 8% to $548 million, shares surged 7.8% to close at $15.82, the highest level since February. Twitter remains focused on achieving profitability, with CEO Jack Dorsey expressing confidence in the company's execution and growth momentum. Analysts note that the improved user growth and increased advertiser investment are more reassuring for long-term growth, but challenges remain, including revenue declines and the need to continue spending to support the business.

site_title: M1 has a nice ring for a China coal mining firm
summary: Singapore's smallest telecom company, M1 Ltd, is on the block with a market value of S$2 billion due to vulnerability to the impending entry of a fourth player. Chinese bidders, including Shanxi Meijin Energy Co, are circling as M1 offers high capital efficiency, with a return on capital among the highest in the developed world. M1's largest owners, including Axiata Group and Keppel Telecommunications, are seeking a strategic sale to alleviate concerns about the company's future amid increased competition in the industry.

site_title: Entertaining, but falls short of the original
summary: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 fails to reach the heights of its original, despite efforts to deliver plenty of fireworks and action. The film tries to resolve personal disputes and answer the question of Peter Quill's father, but ultimately falls short. The action is fast and furious, with classic rock songs from the 1970s and 80s, but the narrative is marred by less-than-stellar storytelling and character development. The film sets the stage for Vol 3, but overall, it receives a mediocre rating of C+.

site_title: MAS urges retail sector to hop on e-commerce train for growth
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is urging the retail sector to adopt e-commerce to tap into new markets and benefit from global demand, following the success of the manufacturing sector in harnessing technology to capitalize on global demand. The sector has been disrupted by e-commerce players, and MAS notes that innovative business formats and technology are needed to transform the retail industry. With the global chip sales recovery expected to be sustained, Singapore manufacturers can continue to tap into external demand, and MAS encourages retailers to look to e-commerce to capture the wider regional market.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q1 earnings up 16.4%
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 16.4% increase in its first-quarter net profit to S$14.24 million, driven by a 78.6% rise in revenue from property sales and hotel operations. Gross profit also increased by 63% to S$23.41 million. The company's residential sales for its Millennium Waterfront project reached 99.8% completion rate, with over 6,333 units sold out of 7,302 units. First Sponsor's shares closed unchanged at S$1.32, despite the company's 10th consecutive quarter-on-quarter profit growth since its initial public offering in 2014.

site_title: GIC affiliate, ADIA unit buy minority stake in US$9b pharma company
summary: A GIC affiliate and ADIA unit have bought a minority stake in Pharmaceutical Product Development (PPD), valuing the US-based contract research organisation at $9.05 billion. The stake was bought from Hellman & Friedman and The Carlyle Group, which will maintain majority joint-ownership. PPD expects to raise $550 million through new senior unsecured notes. The investment is expected to finance the recapitalisation and support the company's continued growth. This marks the beginning of a new chapter in PPD's success, with the company's performance since going private in 2011 being described as exceptional.

site_title: Samsung shares up on biggest quarterly net profit since 2013
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its biggest quarterly net profit since 2013, jumping 46% to 7.68 trillion won (S$9.5 billion) in the January-March period. The company's semiconductor business made its largest-ever operating profit of 6.3 trillion won. Despite a stagnant smartphone market and competition with Apple, shares rose 2.8% in morning trade. However, the company dropped a proposed split plan, citing regulatory hurdles, and warned that smartphone sales may slow in the second quarter. Vice-chairman Lee Jae Yong faces bribery charges, and investors have pushed for a more transparent ownership structure.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Top Global's independent directors' financial adviser deemed SW International's offer as "not fair but reasonable" at 33 Singapore cents per share. Thakral Corp's net profit more than doubled to S$1.51 million in Q1, while Creative Technology posted a net loss of US$4.61 million. Japfa's net profit plummeted 91% to US$2.08 million due to lower prices in its key markets. The adviser advised Top Global's board to recommend shareholders accept the offer or sell on the open market for a higher price.

site_title: US durable goods data points to pickup in business spending
summary: US durable goods data showed a 0.2% increase in non-defense capital goods orders in March, a second consecutive month of growth, despite less-than-expected results. This suggests business investment accelerated in the first quarter, driven by a recovering energy sector. The data also indicates tightening labor market conditions, as first-time unemployment benefit applications rose by more than expected. The results are consistent with the overall trend of a strengthening economy.

site_title: China sets deadline for refiners to apply for oil import permits
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has set a deadline of May 5 for independent oil refiners to apply for oil import permits. The move aims to curb domestic refining overcapacity, which has led to record fuel exports. China has allowed 22 independent refiners to import crude oil since 2015, but will stop accepting new applications, targeting a total of 2 million barrels per day. The policy also signals the government's reluctance to encourage independent firms to expand crude processing capacities.

site_title: 20 homegrown acts on one stage
summary: Singapore will host the 10-hour concert NEXT, featuring 20 homegrown acts, including emerging and established artists, on April 29. The event aims to promote young talents and preserve the country's music heritage through the Sing50 Fund. The concert will also include an awards ceremony, with prizes for Best Emerging Artist in various languages. Organized by The RICE Company Ltd, Music & Movement, and UnUsUaL, the event seeks to create a platform for artists to gain exposure and build their presence in the music scene.

site_title: SGX regulatory unit plans review of rules, quarterly reporting
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) regulatory subsidiary, SGX Regco, will conduct a strategic review of its rules and quarterly reporting requirements. The review aims to improve the market while striking a balance between regulation, compliance, and cost. The review's goal is not to burden the markets with more rules but to make the regulatory framework more innovative, sustainable, and efficient. An update on the review is expected by the middle of the year, with possible changes to quarterly reporting, the Code of Corporate Governance, and minimum trading price.

site_title: PayPal excites investors as partnerships deliver strong growth
summary: PayPal reported Q1 results above projections, indicating CEO Dan Schulman's strategy to convert the online payments platform into a digital wallet is working. The company raised its annual forecast, with investors embracing the shift. This move may require deal-making that diminishes profit margins, but Schulman's strategy appears to be paying off.

site_title: 'Sunset' brokerage model must change: DBS chief
summary: DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta stated that the "sunset" brokerage industry will have to move into the digital age due to shrinking commissions. He noted that customers will eventually need to transact on their own, and the future of the industry will be more digital. This comes amid competition from fintech companies such as Robinhood, which offers zero-commission stock trading in the US. Gupta also emphasized the need for Asian banks to be proactive in spotting potential issues with their clients, rather than relying on trust from regulated entities.

site_title: Trump administration unveils plans for tax cuts
summary: The Trump administration has unveiled plans to cut corporate taxes from 35% to 15%, a significant reform aimed at boosting the economy and businesses. The move is part of the president's 100-day agenda to deliver on a promise to overhaul the tax code. However, the plan faces a tough fight in Congress, with details yet to be finalized. The goal is to benefit middle-class and working-class Americans, although the exact impact and timing of the changes remain uncertain.

site_title: Boeing Q1 surpasses estimates but investors not impressed
summary: Boeing reported a first-quarter profit that surpassed estimates, but investors were less impressed due to a 7.3% drop in revenue and concerns over its cash outlook. The company's commercial airplane business posted an operating profit of $1.22 billion, but the operating margin was below expectations. Boeing attributed the results to a low tax rate and efforts to improve efficiency in its factories. The company raised its forecast for 2017 earnings but did not boost its cash outlook, sparking concerns about its ability to navigate a difficult aerospace market.

images.alt_text: Boeing's CEO says that the company will seek new ways to improve profitability in a highly competitive and uncertain environment, and measures include investing in new sources of growth such as the proposed 737 Max 10 jet.

site_title: In search of one's identity
summary: The coming-of-age drama "Moonlight" tells the poignant story of Chiron's search for identity as a young black gay man growing up in an impoverished Miami suburb. The film, based on Tarell Alvin McCraney's play, explores three pivotal moments in Chiron's life: as a scared 10-year-old, a teenager in high school, and a fully grown adult. Director Barry Jenkins masterfully captures these moments, avoiding forced or exploitative portrayals, and encourages the viewer to accept Chiron's true self.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine averts Q1 loss with one-off disposal gain
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a 27.9% decline in Q1 net profit to S$39.5 million, driven by a one-off disposal gain from the sale of a stake in Cosco Shipyard Group. The company cut 500 workers and plans further layoffs, totaling about 9,000 jobs since 2015. Revenue dropped 17.2% to S$760.1 million, mainly due to lower rig building project recognition. Despite this, the company expects strong interest in its LNG solutions and plans to maximize usage of its newly completed Tuas Boulevard yard.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong says group continues to reallocate "excess manpower" from drilling projects to non-drilling work.

site_title: UK housing starts indicator hits 10-year high
summary: A measure of house-building plans in Britain hit a 10-year high in early 2017, with registrations with the National House-Building Council rising 17% to 42,470. This improvement in the housing market, combined with an increase in demand for commercial property, eased concerns about the impact of the Brexit vote.

site_title: United to pay bumped off customers up to US$10,000
summary: United Airlines has introduced policy changes in response to a passenger being dragged off a plane by security officers. The airline will now offer up to $10,000 to voluntarily give up seats on oversold flights, reduce overbooking, and refrain from calling law enforcement unless safety and security are at risk. The changes aim to restore customer trust after a worldwide outcry over the April 9 incident involving David Dao. The airline's CEO apologized for the mistreatment and is implementing new measures to improve customer service and employee empowerment.

site_title: The chef's catch
summary: Kappo Shunsui, a new Kyoto-style kappo restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with a focus on seasonal produce and chef Tomo Watanabe's skills. The restaurant serves a seven-course meal, with dishes such as shredded crab meat, firefly squid, and Japanese salmon, all for a reasonable price. While some dishes may be lacking, the overall experience is comforting, tasty, and filling, making it a good option for those looking for a more affordable meal. The restaurant's elegant surroundings and extensive sake selection add to its appeal, making it comparable to upper-range Tokyo restaurants. Rating: 7.5.

images.alt_text: Chef Watanabe strives for "real" seasonal produce, and freshness of ingredients drives his cooking style: firefly squid (above); fish head; and clear soup with Japanese kue fish.
Fish head.
Clear soup with Japanese kue fish.
Kappo Shunsui run by Sasaki-trained Tomo Watanabe, promises a new taste of Kyoto-style kappo cuisine.
Kappo Shunsui (above) run by Sasaki-trained Tomo Watanabe, promises a new taste of Kyoto-style kappo cuisine.

site_title: Bank of Japan chief signals no retreat on easy money in the near future
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank will not announce an exit strategy from aggressive monetary easing until Japan's consumer price inflation reaches 2% a year, likely within the next two years. This means the yen is likely to remain under downward pressure, contradicting suggestions that a weak yen gives Japan an unfair export advantage.

site_title: Potty-mouthed sock puppeteer packs a punch
summary: Actor Thomas Pang shines in "Hand to God," a 90-minute play about a teenager struggling with daddy issues and his foul-mouthed, worldly-wise hand puppet alter ego, Tyrone. The ensemble cast supports Pang's performances, which alternate between the shy teen and Tyrone. The play unfolds in a church basement, exploring themes of identity, morality, and social mores. With a mix of twisted humor and suspense, the play takes a darker turn but concludes on a positive note, with Pang's portrayal of Tyrone being the standout.

images.alt_text: Pang's verve as a puppeteer from hell is well supported by an equally talented cast of (from left) Daniel Jenkins, Janice Koh, Ann Lek and Gavin Yap from the Singapore Repertory Theatre.

site_title: Changes to Singapore's Cabinet from May 1
summary: Singapore's Cabinet is undergoing changes as part of a leadership renewal, effective May 1. Josephine Teo and Desmond Lee will be promoted to full ministers, with Teo becoming Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister in the Ministry of Manpower, and Lee becoming Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister in the Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development. Other changes include promotions to Senior Ministers of State and Senior Parliamentary Secretaries, and reappointments of mayors and coordinators for the CDCs.

site_title: Secura unit wins S$4.9m contract from Australian International School
summary: Secura Group subsidiary Soverus has won a S$4.9 million contract from the Australian International School (AIS) for unarmed security services at two locations. The 32-month contract, effective May 1, 2017, to Dec 31, 2019, includes an option to extend for two more years. This contract marks a significant win for Soverus and demonstrates its growing presence in the security services sector.

site_title: Keppel Offshore & Marine unit wins US$40m contract
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine's unit, Keppel FloaTEC, has secured a US$40 million contract from Vietnam's PTSC M&C to provide engineering, technology, and construction management support services for a tension leg wellhead platform (TLWP) at Repsol's Ca Rong Do field development off Vietnam. The contract involves providing services for the TLWP, which will be built in Vietnam and located at a water depth of 320 meters. Keppel O&M's acting CEO Chris Ong expressed confidence in the project's success, citing the company's complementary capabilities and close collaboration with partners.

site_title: China's Didi to raise up to US$6b, values firm at US$50b
summary: China's ride-hailing firm Didi Chuxing is set to raise up to $6 billion, valuing the company at over $50 billion. The latest investment round includes Softbank Group, Silver Lake Partners, China Merchants Bank, and Bank of Communications. The funds will be used for international expansion, particularly in Latin America and the US, as regulatory changes in China may impact local services. Didi has already established partnerships with US tech firms and has a research laboratory in Silicon Valley. The company's valuation surpasses that of Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi and private internet finance firm Ant Financial.

site_title: MAS close to launching A380 charter carrier for pilgrim flights
summary: Malaysia Airlines is close to launching a charter airline using its six Airbus A380s for Haj and Umrah pilgrimages. The airline plans to operate around 180-190 days a year to break even, with potential destinations including Barcelona, Rome, and London Stansted. The A380s will have over 700 seats, but can be reconfigured to 635 seats in economy and business class. The move aims to utilize the airline's largest passenger jets, which were previously deemed uneconomical due to high costs. The charter carrier is expected to attract external investors and operate non-pilgrimage flights.

site_title: Home Capital hires bankers as deposits slump
summary: Canadian alternative lender Home Capital Group Inc hired bankers to secure additional funding and explore strategic options amid a sharp decline in its assets. The company reported liquid assets of C$1.3 billion, down from C$1.5 billion the previous day, as investors pulled out of high-interest savings accounts and guaranteed investment certificates. Home Capital secured a C$2 billion credit line and hired RBC Capital Markets and BMO Capital Markets to advise on further financing and options. The company's shares recovered some losses, up 16.9%, and analysts expect a potential sale.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer for its data center business was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned that its second-quarter revenue may be lower than expected, with an operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, as its incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels shares to be suspended ahead of delistment
summary: Global Premium Hotels shares will be suspended ahead of delistment following a takeover bid by JK Global Capital, an investment holding company owned by Global Premium chairman Koh Wee Meng. The takeover offer, launched earlier this year, resulted in about 96.53% of shares being acquired. JK Global Capital intends to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares, leading to the suspension of the company's shares.

site_title: Draghi sees diminished growth risks even as inflation is lacking
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that growth risks for the euro-area economy have decreased, despite core inflation remaining below the bank's comfort zone. The ECB kept policy unchanged, with interest rates expected to stay at present or lower levels for an extended period. Draghi noted that underlying inflation pressures are subdued and the region's recovery is becoming increasingly solid, but risks still tilt to the downside, primarily due to global factors. The euro rose immediately after Draghi's remarks before settling.

site_title: Ongoing efforts to transform Changi Airport ahead of future challenges: CAG
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) will continue transforming the airport ahead of future challenges, focusing on sustainable demand growth and catering to new passenger segments such as MICE, fly-cruise, and low-cost long-haul travel. The airport has honored carriers contributing to its growth, with Singapore Airlines being the top passenger carrier and SIA Group leading in cargo volumes. Changi Airport handled 58.7 million passengers in 2016, with a target of 60 million in 2017, and is expected to receive significant growth in the future.

site_title: So much more than just a campy romp
summary: Ivan Heng stars as Albin in Wild Rice's revival of La Cage Aux Folles, a campy Broadway romp that won 11 Tony awards. The show, adapted from a 1973 stage play and 1983 Broadway musical, follows Albin, a gay man who transforms into a showgirl by night, as he navigates his relationship with his partner and the arrival of his son's fiancée's family. The production, directed by Glen Goei, features a diverse ensemble cast and emphasizes the importance of acceptance, respect, and love.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 DPU down 6.3%
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 6.3% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter ended March 31, 2017, to 1.18 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also decreased by 0.6% and 0.9% year-over-year, respectively, mainly due to lower contributions from certain properties. Unitholders will receive their DPU on May 30.

site_title: Apple in talks to launch money-transfer service
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks to launch a money-transfer service, allowing iPhone owners to digitally transfer money to other iPhone users. The service, if launched, would compete with existing digital money transfer services like PayPal's Venmo and Square's Square Cash. Apple is also exploring creating its own pre-paid cards tied to the new service, which could boost usage of its mobile payments service, Apple Pay. The launch is expected later this year, but no announcement or launch date has been confirmed.

site_title: IFA deems offer for Top Global shares as 'not fair but reasonable'
summary: The Independent Financial Adviser (IFA) to Top Global's independent directors has deemed an offer by SW International for shares at 33 Singapore cents apiece as "not fair but reasonable". The offer, valued at a 72.3% discount to Top Global's RNAV per share, has been deemed sound due to declining financial performance and no dividend paid for 12 years. The IFA advised the board to recommend shareholders accept the offer or sell on the open market for a higher price.

site_title: Yangzijiang chalks up stronger profits for Q1
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 49% year-on-year increase in net profit to 667.67 million yuan (S$135.4 million) for Q1 FY17, driven by a 73% rise in revenue to 4.68 billion yuan. The company delivered 14 vessels in Q1 2017, boosting revenue from its core shipbuilding business by 43% to 2.89 billion yuan. Earnings per share rose to 17.42 renminbi cents from 11.69 cents a year ago. The executive chairman attributed the growth to improved market sentiment and new buyers for previously terminated orders.

site_title: Japfa's Q1 profit falls
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, reported a 91% drop in Q1 net profit to US$2.08 million due to lower prices for its key markets, particularly swine in Vietnam and broiler in Indonesia. Revenue increased 3% to US$736.12 million. The decline in profitability was mainly attributed to lower selling prices, which started declining in the fourth quarter of 2016. Earnings per share fell to 0.12 US cents from 1.33 US cents a year ago.

site_title: UK police arrest man with knives in Westminster in anti-terrorism operation
summary: UK police arrested a 27-year-old man carrying knives near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in Westminster on suspicion of preparing a terrorist act. The incident occurred during a counter-terrorism operation and no one was injured. The man was detained on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon and terrorism-related offenses. He was being followed by police before his arrest. The arrest comes after a similar incident last month when a British-born convert to Islam carried out a terrorist attack on Westminster Bridge, killing four people.

site_title: ECB leaves key interest rates unchanged and bond buying intact
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) left key interest rates unchanged and maintained its bond-buying program at 60 billion euros per month until December. The rates, which have been at historic lows since 2016, remain at 0.0%, 0.25%, and -0.4%. The decision was in line with expectations, as policymakers aim to encourage banks to lend to the real economy and push inflation towards its target of 2.0%. Despite a firming recovery in the eurozone, inflation fell to 1.5% in March, and the ECB is cautious not to upset financial markets amid political uncertainty.

site_title: US:Wall St little changed with eyes on earnings
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Thursday, amid a mixed earnings season and President Donald Trump's tax reform plan. The plan proposed deep tax cuts but offered no details on funding, snapping a two-day rally. Despite this, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 11.43 points, the S&P 500 gained 0.14 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 6.55 points. PayPal jumped to an all-time high after raising its earnings forecast, while a 2% drop in oil prices weighed on the energy sector. Investors continue to monitor earnings season and the tax reform plan.

site_title: Creative Tech in the red for Q3
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$4.61 million in Q3 2017, down from a net profit of US$4.04 million in the same quarter last year, due to 13% sales decline to US$16 million. The company expects no significant change in market conditions and expects comparable revenue in the quarter, with an operating loss similar to H1.
