Loss per share was US$0.07, compared to US$0.06 previously.

site_title: Thakral Corp reports stronger profits for Q1
summary: Thakral Corp reported a 140% increase in Q1 net profit to S$1.51 million, despite a 54% year-over-year decline in revenue to S$36.9 million. Gross profit rose 25% to S$10.54 million, driven by lower cost of sales. Earnings per share increased to 1.15 Singapore cents, up from 0.48 cent a year ago.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister announced changes to the Cabinet, effective May 1, as part of leadership renewal. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported a soft labor market curbing inflation, with unemployment rates potentially rising this year. MAS also expects oil prices to average $53 per barrel in 2017. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore signed five memorandums of understanding with local and international partners. Meanwhile, Singapore's stock market finished mixed, with the Straits Times Index weakening 2.4 points to 3,171.36.

site_title: Europe needs own IMF, says Eurogroup chief
summary: Eurogroup chairman Jeroen Dijsselbloem has called for Europe to establish its own IMF, citing the need for a European monetary fund to replace the Washington-based IMF in future bailouts. He stated that the Luxembourg-based European Stability Mechanism should assume the responsibilities of the IMF and a report is being prepared to map out a way to make this happen. This move comes amid ongoing tensions between the eurozone and IMF over Greece's debt relief, with the IMF refusing to participate in a 86-billion-euro loan program.

images.alt_text: Europe needs its own European monetary fund that could replace the Washington-based IMF in any future bailouts in the eurozone, Eurogroup chairman Jeroen Dijsselbloem said on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rebound to mark six gains in a row
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded for a sixth consecutive gain, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.49% to 24,698.48, following US President Donald Trump's announcement to renegotiate the NAFTA deal, easing concerns about his potential departure. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also rose, driven by investor optimism despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Rising fuel costs hurt budget carrier Norwegian
summary: Low-cost airline Norwegian Air Shuttle posted a larger-than-expected quarterly loss of nearly 1.5 billion kroner due to rising fuel prices, a strong local currency, and calendar effects. The airline's share price initially dropped 3.4% but recovered to post a 3.6% rise. Despite a 14% increase in passengers and 9% rise in revenues, Norwegian's gross operating loss was 1.3 billion kroner, primarily attributed to higher fuel costs. The airline also launched 39 new routes, including long-haul and transatlantic routes, but saw a slight decline in fill rate to 84.4%.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end higher as financials bolster
summary: Australia's stock market ended higher on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 9.464 points or 0.16% to 5,921.50, bolstered by financials. The financial index hit a 23-month high, driven by the 'Big Four' banks, which are set to report earnings next week. Energy stocks were the biggest drag, with oil majors and LNG-related stocks falling due to lower prices and government restrictions.

site_title: Taiwan president says phone call with Trump can take place again
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen expressed openness to a direct phone call with US President Donald Trump, suggesting it could take place again if the situation and US government's consideration of regional affairs permit. She urged China to step up its global responsibility and urged President Xi Jinping to act like a leader, expressing Taiwan's need for advanced military equipment, including the F-35 fighter jet, amid improving ties with the US. China opposes any country selling arms to Taiwan.

site_title: Singapore's industrial property prices, rents, occupancies continue to slide in Q1: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial property prices, rents, and occupancies declined in Q1 2017, with prices and rents falling 2.2% and 0.9% respectively from the previous quarter. Occupancy rates dropped to 89.4%, down from 90.1% in Q1 2016. An estimated 2 million square meters of industrial space will be added to the market over the next three quarters, potentially exacerbating downward pressure on occupancy rates and business costs.

site_title: North Korea agrees to first ever UN rights expert visit
summary: North Korea has agreed to host a UN rights expert, Catalina Devandas-Aguilar, for the first time, allowing her to visit the isolated nation next week. The visit, scheduled for April 26-30, will focus on children living with disabilities, following Pyongyang's ratification of the international convention on the rights of disabled people last December. This marks a rare opportunity for the UN to study the situation in North Korea, despite the country's history of committing crimes against humanity and detaining up to 120,000 people in prison camps.

site_title: Swiss watch exports break record slump as Hong Kong revives
summary: Swiss watch exports broke a 21-month slump in March, rising 7.5% to 1.6 billion francs, driven by increased demand in Hong Kong, China, and the US. Shipments to Hong Kong rallied 18% after a 25-month decline, while China rebounded 38% and the US saw a 16% increase. The recovery is attributed to improving consumer confidence and tourism flows, with analysts optimistic that the worst may be over.

site_title: Rigbuilding a drag on SembMarine Q1 earnings
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Q1 net profit fell 27.9% to S$39.5 million, down from the previous year, due to lower revenue recognition for rig building projects. Revenue dropped 17.2% to S$760.1 million. Earnings per share sank to 1.89 cents from 2.63 cents in the same period. The company's shares closed 0.3% lower at S$1.73.

site_title: Veteran Bollywood actor Khanna dies aged 70
summary: Veteran Bollywood actor Vinod Khanna, 70, died from cancer at a Mumbai hospital on Thursday. He starred in hit movies like "Amar Akbar Anthony" and "Mere Apne", and was an MP in Punjab. Tributes poured in from the Hindi cinema world, with actors Amitabh Bachchan, Rishi Kapoor, and Akshay Kumar paying homage. Khanna won a Filmfare Best Supporting Actor Award in 1975 and a lifetime achievement award in 1999 for his performances as an angry anti-hero and villain.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed - STI weakens but broad market firms
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Thursday 2.4 points weaker at 3,171.36, despite moderate turnover of 1.8 billion units. The main reason for the decline was the overnight fall on Wall Street due to skepticism over the Trump administration's tax plan. The broad market still managed an advance-decline score of 255-207, excluding warrants. Markets are now focused on the US tax plan, which is expected to be "phenomenal" but may not be approved.

site_title: Empty Pearl River Delta branches a challenge for HSBC's China plans
summary: HSBC's expansion plans in China's Pearl River Delta region are facing challenges, with empty branches and low customer footfall. Despite hiring 4,000 new staff and investing billions, the bank is struggling to compete with local rivals that have more branches and are not subject to the same regulatory scrutiny. Tighter customer background checks and slower digital application processes are also deterring affluent Chinese customers. HSBC has seen some progress, including a 51% increase in retail banking and wealth management clients and a mortgage loan book, but faces battles with red tape and remains an outsider in the market.

site_title: New maritime apprenticeship scheme launched to ensure better job fit
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) launched a new apprenticeship scheme to strengthen the employability of Singaporeans in the maritime industry. The scheme, developed by the Tripartite Maritime Manpower Taskforce for Seafaring, provides jobseekers with a month-long shipboard work trial and a three-day foundational maritime training course. Employers will also be able to assess job suitability, leading to better job matches. Monthly training costs and allowance up to S$2,600 are supported by the tripartite partners, aiming to familiarize and match jobseekers with potential employers.

site_title: Merkel warns Britons: don't delude yourself over Brexit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned Britons not to have illusions about maintaining EU rights after Brexit, stating that a third state cannot have the same rights as EU members. She emphasized that the EU would only agree on future ties with Britain after the divorce settlement is sorted out, which must be addressed before the June 8 parliamentary election. Merkel also expressed confidence in the EU's preparedness for the talks, which will require effort over the next two years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.4% to 7,262.47 points. The Paris CAC 40 index and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index also dropped 0.2% and 0.3% respectively. The decline comes after a four-day rally in Asian equities, which were tracking a weak lead from Wall Street. Traders are assessing the chances of Congress passing US President Donald Trump's massive tax cuts.

site_title: MPA signs 5 MOUs with local, international partners
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) signed five memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with local and international partners at the Singapore Maritime Technology Conference. The MOUs aim to foster research, innovation, and pilot adoption of emerging technologies in the maritime sector. The agreements cover port technology research and development, next-generation multipurpose ports, maritime R&D and innovation, maritime technologies R&D, and a joint research centre for innovation. MPA aims to leverage new technologies to maintain Singapore's position as a world-class port and international maritime centre, driving the sector's future development.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines close to launching A380 charter carrier for pilgrim flights
summary: Malaysia Airlines is close to launching a new charter airline using its six Airbus A380s for Haj and Umrah pilgrim flights. The airline will operate around 180 days a year to break even, with potential for non-pilgrimage flights and external investors. The A380s can be reconfigured in "four to five days" to accommodate different seat configurations. The move aims to utilize the airline's A380s, which have been idle since failing to sell them. The new airline is expected to contribute to Malaysia Airlines' goal of returning to profitability by 2018 and listing on the stock market in 2019.

site_title: 25% of Funan's retail net lettable area leased before 2019 opening
summary: Funan, a Singapore retail mall, has secured leases for 81,000 square feet (25% of its total retail net lettable area) two years ahead of its scheduled opening in Q4 2019. Tenants include theatre company W!ld Rice, artisan jewelry label Carrie K., and designers' collective Keepers. Former tenants Newstead Technologies, AddOn Systems, and T K Foto will also return with expanded offerings. This has been a well-received development for CapitaLand Mall Trust Management, with CEO Wilson Tan stating it's one of their most successful projects to date.

site_title: China: Stocks end higher, small caps bolster sentiment
summary: China's stocks reversed earlier losses to end up on Thursday, with the blue-chip CSI300 index rising 0.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index adding 0.4%. Small-caps lifted sentiment, while industrial profits rose 23.8% in March, but concerns about economic growth and tighter regulations persist. Analysts warn of a difficult year for Chinese financial markets, but lower macro risk is seen as positive for risk assets globally.

site_title: Shares in Japan's Takata suspended after report on bankruptcy plan
summary: Trading in Takata Corp shares was suspended in Japan after a report that the airbag maker is considering a bankruptcy plan that would create a new company and ringfence its liabilities. Chinese-owned car parts maker Key Safety Systems (KSS) is the preferred bidder, injecting 200 billion yen to help settle claims linked to faulty airbags blamed for at least 16 deaths worldwide. A restructuring deal could enable Takata to continue supplying replacement airbag inflators and selling other vehicle components.

site_title: UK regrets Brexit for first time since referendum: poll
summary: A UK poll shows 45% of respondents believe leaving the European Union was a mistake, with 43% supporting the split and 12% unsure. This marks the first time since the 2016 referendum that the public mood has turned against Brexit. The poll comes as Prime Minister Theresa May seeks a mandate for her vision of Brexit, which includes severing ties with EU institutions.

images.alt_text: More British voters think the decision to leave the European Union is a mistake than support the split, a poll showed for the first time since last June's referendum.

site_title: Hot stock: M1 continues to soar on reports of more Chinese bidders
summary: M1's share price surged 3.35% to S$2.16, following reports of more Chinese bidders, including Shanxi Meijin Energy Co and China Broadband, making first-round offers. Bahrain Telecommunications Co and private equity funds have also submitted non-binding bids. M1's market value stands at S$1.9 billion, with Axiata Group, Keppel Corp, and SPH owning significant stakes. The telecom operator has appointed Morgan Stanley to explore options, including a potential sale.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound to 6-year high on Samsung Elec, won down
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded to a 6-year high on Thursday, driven by Samsung Electronics' surge and individual investors' buying. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 0.1% higher at 2,209.46 points, its highest close since May 2011. Samsung Electronics rose 2.4% to its highest close since listing, after announcing plans to cancel its treasury shares worth over $35 billion by 2018. The South Korean won slipped 0.4% against the US dollar due to market expectations of US President Donald Trump's tax-cut plan.

site_title: US, South Korea warn defiant North against new provocation
summary: US and South Korea agree on swift punitive measures against North Korea in case of further provocation, including a new UN Security Council resolution. The US and South Korea have stepped up warnings to North Korea over its nuclear development and missile tests, with the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier group approaching Korean waters. North Korea vows to continue nuclear and missile tests despite US "hostile acts", with a North Korean official saying the country will not be influenced by outside events.

site_title: United to offer passengers up to US$10,000 to surrender seats
summary: United Airlines announced a plan to offer passengers up to $10,000 to give up their seats on overbooked flights. The move comes after a viral video showed a passenger being forcibly removed from a flight. The airline will also reduce overbooking flights and improve customer satisfaction. United's CEO, Oscar Munoz, has faced calls to step down after referring to the removed passenger as "disruptive and belligerent." The airline has vowed to become a more customer-focused airline and reduce incidents of involuntary denial of boarding to zero.

site_title: Xiongan's 2t yuan development lifts hope for better Chinese cities
summary: China's Xiongan New Area, a 2 trillion yuan development, aims to improve urban design and reduce air pollution by 2020. The 100 sq km initial development will eventually span 2,000 sq km, boosting China's investment growth and GDP. The project, backed by President Xi Jinping, is seen as a demonstration of optimized development in densely-populated areas. However, some analysts question its ability to trigger change elsewhere, citing concerns over government control and market forces.

site_title: US launches national security probe into aluminium imports
summary: The US Commerce Department launched a national security probe into aluminium imports, citing concerns over competitive pressures and unfair trade practices. The investigation, led by Secretary Wilbur Ross, aims to determine if domestic aluminium capacity can meet US defense needs and assess the effects on national security. China, the world's top aluminium producer and consumer, is concerned and hopes to resolve the dispute through negotiations. The probe follows a similar investigation into steel imports and could lead to broad import restrictions on the metal.

site_title: China March industrial profits soar 23.8% on property but off highs
summary: China's industrial profits rose 23.8% in March to 688.7 billion yuan, driven by a construction boom and sales of building materials. This growth is off multi-year highs seen in previous months. Analysts warn that producer price inflation may be peaking, potentially tempering profitability and new investment later this year. The country's government has set a 6.5% economic growth target for 2017, despite a slowdown in capital outflows and a stable yuan.

site_title: Airbus Q1 profit slides on weak pricing, higher costs
summary: Airbus reported a 52% drop in first-quarter profit to 240 million euros, due to weaker prices and higher production costs. The company attributed the decline to changes in new models and higher costs, but reaffirmed its targets for higher profits in 2017. Airbus also warned about issues with its A320neo engine and the troubled A400M military aircraft program. Despite this, the company expects to deliver over 720 aircraft in 2017 and report mid-single-digit percentage growth in operating income. Deliveries of the A320neo are expected to fall in the latter part of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares run out of steam after four-day rally
summary: Tokyo shares fell on Thursday, snapping a four-day rally, as investors cashed in on a weak lead from US markets following the Trump administration's tax plan unveiling. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.19% to close at 19,251.87, while the Topix index edged down 0.05%. This comes amid uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Asia: Stocks steady after BOJ; yen keeps losses
summary: Stocks in Asia remained steady after the Bank of Japan's decision to keep monetary policy unchanged, with Japan's equity futures and yen continuing to decline. The US dollar fell, while the Mexican peso jumped after the Trump administration dispelled speculation about scrapping Nafta. Global shares remain at a record high due to optimism on improving economic growth, and investors are focusing on earnings reports from major companies.

site_title: Trump rules out swift Nafta withdrawal in favour of renegotiation
summary: US President Donald Trump has ruled out an immediate withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and instead plans to renegotiate the accord with Canada and Mexico. Trump spoke with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto to agree on a swift renegotiation process, which will not involve terminating US participation in the agreement. The White House statement said Trump believes the end result will make all three countries stronger and better, and a 90-day notice to Congress will be given before any renegotiation proceedings begin.

site_title: Gold slips, but Trump tax reform doubts cap losses
summary: Gold prices edged down 0.2% to $1,266.94 per ounce, despite geo-political worries, due to skepticism over US President Donald Trump's proposed tax reform. This capped losses, with US gold futures rising 0.3% to $1,268.30 an ounce.

site_title: China's bike wars escalate as Didi throws weight behind Ofo
summary: Didi Chuxing has integrated Ofo's bike-rental service into its mobile app, granting Ofo access to Didi's 400 million users across 400 Chinese cities. This move pits Didi against Tencent Holdings, which backs Mobike, Ofo's rival. Didi will allow users to rent Ofo's bicycles within its app, promoting Ofo's name across China. Ofo has received US$650 million in funding and aims to expand to 20 countries and 200 cities in China this year, joining a battle with Mobike and other bike-rental companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks track regional markets lower; Samsung Elec lends support
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.2% to 2,202.60 points, tracking a global pullback, but Samsung Electronics rose 2% on a stronger earnings outlook. The Kospi reached a near six-year high on Wednesday, but investors took profits on recent gains. Despite the decline, analysts expect the index to rise further due to strong fundamentals in sectors such as finance and steel. The South Korean won slumped 0.4% against the US dollar after US President Trump's tax cut plan was unveiled.

site_title: Thai finance ministry keeps 2017 GDP growth outlook, raises export forecast
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has maintained its 2017 GDP growth outlook of 3.6% and raised its export forecast to 3.3%, driven by government spending and improved exports. The economy is expected to be boosted by the military government's spending and investment efforts. This follows the central bank's earlier forecast increase to 3.4% in April, with exports projected to rise 2.2% this year. The growth outlook is in line with the 3.2% expansion seen in 2016.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady, revises up view on economy
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping interest rates at 0.1% and its yield target for 10-year Japanese government bonds around zero%. The central bank revised its view on the economy, now expecting a moderate expansion, and maintained its massive stimulus to achieve a 2% inflation target. It slightly cut its inflation forecast for this fiscal year, indicating continued support for its policy.

site_title: Australia shares flat as momentum cools; NZ up on A2 Milk
summary: Australian shares rose 1.564 points, or 0.03%, to 5,913.6, following a flat US market. The S&P/ASX 200 index was bolstered by financials, with the 'Big Four' banks reaching a fresh 23-month high. Gold stocks also rose, while oil majors fell. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.323%, led by consumer staple and utility stocks. A2 Milk continued to climb after reporting high demand for its infant milk formula via Chinese e-commerce.

site_title: China coal miner vying for Singapore mobile carrier M1
summary: China's Shanxi Meijin Energy Co and China Broadband Capital are among bidders for Singapore's wireless carrier M1 Ltd, with bids valued at US$1.4 billion. The sale comes as Singapore prepares for the introduction of a fourth mobile operator, aiming to increase competition and lower phone bills. M1's largest owners, Axiata Group, Keppel Telecommunications, and Singapore Press Holdings, have appointed Morgan Stanley to explore options, including a sale. M1 shares rose 4.8% following the news, with the sale potentially impacting the country's telecom landscape.

site_title: SGX Regco to conduct strategic review of market rules: chairman
summary: SGX Regulation Pte Ltd (Regco), a newly formed regulatory subsidiary, will conduct a strategic review of its market rules to improve the market while maintaining a balance between regulation, compliance, and cost. Regco aims to shape the market to be more innovative, sustainable, and efficient, and will serve as a reference point globally for its regulatory framework and standards. The review is expected to begin in August with a five-member board, led by Tan Boon Gin, who previously held the role of SGX chief regulatory officer.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) newly formed regulatory subsidiary will conduct a strategic review of its various rules after its board is fully formed to improve the market while striking a balance between regulation, compliance and cost, the subsidiary's chairman, Tan Cheng Han, said on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.07% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 2.31 points to 3,176.07. Gainers outnumbered losers 93 to 49, with top gainers including Jardine C&C, JSH, and JMH. Top losers were City Development, Dairy Farm, and Hongkong Land. The US S&P 500 Index closed marginally in the red on Wednesday, while US Treasuries advanced.

site_title: Hong Kong: Equities edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher Thursday morning, edging up 9.97 points to 24,588.40, despite a five-day rally and uncertainty surrounding US tax overhaul plans. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.30% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slid 0.25%. The gains were muted as investors digested the news.

site_title: Singapore's soft labour market curbs inflation; external outlook brightens: MAS
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), says a soft labour market and downbeat consumer sentiment are curbing price increases, with core inflation expected to average 1-2% this year. Unemployment rates may rise slightly, but the economy is expected to expand at a modest pace of 1-3% in 2017. External prospects have brightened, with domestic demand strengthening in major global economies like the US, eurozone, and Japan. However, MAS warns that global uncertainties and risk factors may impact the sustainability of the global expansion.

images.alt_text: MAS said that Singapore's employment outlook for this year will be similar to last year's as the labour market softens.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slightly down by 0.17 points to 1,768.75. The market saw 126 gainers and 56 losers, with a total volume of 84.7 million lots worth RM24.9 million.

site_title: Australia's Qantas to axe Dubai flights, boost Asian presence with Perth-London launch
summary: Qantas to axe Dubai flights and redirect capacity to Asia, launching non-stop Perth-London flights in 2018. The airline will charge a premium of up to 62% in business class for the 17-hour Perth-London route, saving three hours of travel time. The move aims to gain an edge in the London market and cut travel time to London from Melbourne by over an hour. Two A380s currently serving the Melbourne-Dubai-London route will be redeployed to meet demand in Asia.

site_title: MAS expects Brent oil to average US$53 per barrel for 2017
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, has forecast Brent oil to average US$53 per barrel for 2017, a 20% increase from last year's average of US$44. This forecast is lower than a Reuters poll estimate of US$57.25 per barrel. The forecast is based on a relatively flat oil price profile and assumes the impact of OPEC's production cuts, which led to a temporary increase in oil prices. Core inflation rose to 1.3% in Q1 2017, while headline inflation rose to 0.6% from zero in Q4 2016.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks dip; Taiwan dollar pulls back from 2-1/2-year high
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.14% on Thursday, following Asian shares and a US tax plan failure. The local currency, the Taiwan dollar, pulled back from a two-and-a-half-year high, strengthening NT$0.016 to NT$30.135 to the US dollar. The automobile subindex led losses, while Sinopac Financial Holdings Co Ltd fell 0.75%. The decline marked the end of a week-long rally.

site_title: Hong Kong's dollar drop has origin in property-lending rumbles will
summary: The Hong Kong dollar has weakened to its weakest point in 14 months due to a divergence in interest rates between the territory and the US. Tighter restrictions on bank loans and higher stamp duty have led to a surge in financing for new properties, putting pressure on banks' lending rates and causing the dollar to drop. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has maintained its commitment to the pegged currency system, but experts expect the dollar to continue to weaken as US interest rates rise.

site_title: Hackers exploited Word flaw for months while Microsoft investigated
summary: Hackers exploited a Microsoft Word flaw, CVE-2017-0199, for nine months before it was fixed in April 2017. The bug allowed hackers to seize control of personal computers with little trace. Microsoft's regular monthly security update on April 11 resolved the issue. The prolonged duration of the exploit highlights the challenges in defending computers against moderately capable hackers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars inch higher as Trump sticks with Nafta
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Thursday after US President Donald Trump agreed not to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) for now. The Australian dollar rose 0.17% to US$0.7483, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.6909, both at their highest levels in over three months. The move was seen as a relief rally, but currency strategist Rodrigo Catril warned that commodity currencies could still be hit by protectionist measures in global trade.

site_title: China had 20 nuclear reactors under construction at end-March: nuclear association
summary: China has 20 nuclear reactors under construction, with a total capacity of 23.11 gigawatts, according to the China Nuclear Energy Association. At the end of March, 36 reactors were in full commercial operation, totaling 34.72 gigawatts. The reactors, including the world's first AP1000, are expected to meet China's five-year plan for the power industry by 2020, with half being advanced "third generation" reactors. The AP1000 unit is set to go into operation in the second half of this year after several delays.

site_title: AA Reit's Q4 DPU falls 5.8% to 2.78 cents
summary: AA Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 5.8% to 2.78 cents, down from 2.92 cents in the same period last year. Full-year DPU declined 2.6% to 11.05 cents, while gross revenue rose 1.1% to S$30.6 million, driven by new property contributions. Net asset value decreased to S$1.3896, and diluted earnings per unit came in at negative 6.13 cents, worse than the same period last year. The decline was attributed to lower rental and recoveries from certain properties.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q1 profit climbs 16.4% on higher revenue
summary: FIRST Sponsor Group reported a 16.4% increase in Q1 profit to S$14.2 million, driven by a 78.6% surge in revenue to S$81.3 million, mainly due to property sales and hotel operations. This marks the group's 10th consecutive quarter of profit growth since its IPO in 2014. Earnings per share rose to 2.41 Singapore cents, while net asset value decreased to 172.01 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: First Sponsor Group reported a net profit of S$14.2 million in its first financial quarter, up 16.4 per cent from a year ago, in a Singapore Exchange filing on Thursday.

site_title: Push for South China Sea code stirs Asean suspicions about Beijing's endgame
summary: China's support for a code of conduct in the South China Sea has generated hope in Southeast Asia for settling disputes, but skepticism persists due to Beijing's continued island-building and militarization. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) aims to finalize the framework this year, but concerns remain about China's sincerity. The code seeks to advance the 2002 Declaration of Conduct, which commits to following international law and ensuring freedom of navigation. China's efforts are seen as a strategic move to project an image of responsibility while avoiding binding rules that could weaken its position.

images.alt_text: China's support for finalising a code of conduct in the hotly contested South China Sea is generating some hope in South-east Asia of settling disputes, but those working out the terms remain unconvinced of Beijing's sincerity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday, following a four-day rally, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.31% and the Topix index down 0.26%. The decline came after the Trump administration unveiled details of its tax reform plan, taking a weak lead from Wall Street. The move has caused traders to brush off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: UK tourism set for boost from weak pound and "staycationers": survey
summary: A weak pound is boosting UK tourism, with nearly two-thirds of international holidaymakers preferring to visit the UK compared to last year. The top drivers of this trend are the weaker pound (31%) and greater spending power (30%). The survey also found that nearly a third of UK holidaymakers plan to spend more time in Britain, with 38% citing the weaker pound as a factor in choosing a UK holiday over one abroad. The pound has fallen 15% since the Brexit referendum.

site_title: Daimler lifts forecasts for 2017 as Mercedes' sales gain traction
summary: Daimler AG raised its 2017 forecasts due to a surge in Mercedes-Benz luxury car sales, boosted by new models. The company's first-quarter net profit doubled to 2.8 billion euros, driven by significant growth in volume sales, revenue, and group Ebit. This growth is attributed to the successful launch of new models, leading to a revised prediction of significant growth in these areas for the entire year.

site_title: Macron campaign for French presidency off to slower start than Le Pen: poll
summary: French centrist Emmanuel Macron's campaign for the presidency is off to a slower start than far-right leader Marine Le Pen, according to a poll. Only 43% of voters believe Macron got off to a good start, compared to 50% who think Le Pen's campaign is off to a good start. Macron has faced criticism for perceived arrogance and a lack of engagement with the public, including a contentious visit to a factory in his hometown where he was heckled by striking workers. Despite this, polls indicate Macron will win the run-off against Le Pen by a comfortable margin.

site_title: South Korea's Q1 GDP expands at fastest in 3 quarters on exports, capex
summary: South Korea's economy expanded 0.9% in Q1, the fastest pace in three quarters, driven by strong exports and capital investment. The growth was a relief for policymakers ahead of a presidential election in May, but may not be enough to counter geopolitical risks from North Korea. The Bank of Korea upgraded its growth outlook to 2.6% for the year, citing improving exports, but warned of risks. Private consumption and construction investment also showed signs of growth, while intellectual property investment declined.

site_title: China's Didi said near deal to become most valuable Asia startup
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's ride-hailing giant, is near a $5 billion funding round that would value the company at $50 billion, surpassing Xiaomi Corp and making it the most valuable startup in the world. The deal, led by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son, aims to fund Didi's expansion into more countries and investments in emerging technologies like autonomous driving and artificial intelligence. The funding round is seen as a strategic move to help Didi overcome regulatory hurdles and capitalize on its near-monopoly control in the Chinese ride-sharing market.

site_title: TransferWise sets up Asia-Pac hub in Singapore
summary: TransferWise, a US$1 billion remittance start-up, has set up its Asia-Pacific hub in Singapore, with plans to have 30 employees by the end of 2017. The company launched its international money transfer service in Singapore via online verification. CEO Taavet Hinrikus stated that Singapore is the perfect location to grow the team due to the Monetary Authority's commitment to fintech companies. This expansion comes as the company aims to bring its service to everyone in the world that transfers money internationally.

site_title: GIC affiliate, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority unit buy minority stake in PPD
summary: AN affiliate of Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, the GIC, and a subsidiary of the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) have bought a minority stake in Pharmaceutical Product Development, LLC (PPD), valuing the company at over $9 billion. The stake was purchased from affiliates of Hellman & Friedman and The Carlyle Group, who will maintain majority joint ownership. PPD expects to raise $550 million through new senior unsecured notes to finance the recapitalisation, with the transaction expected to close in the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AA Reit, First Sponsor Group
summary: AA Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.78 Singapore cents in its fourth quarter, a 5.8% decline from the same period last year. The company's full-year DPU was 11.05 Singapore cents, a 2.6% decline from FY2016. First Sponsor Group reported a 16.4% increase in net profit to S$14.2 million in its first quarter, its 10th consecutive quarter of profit growth.

site_title: One Belt, One Road a catalyst for Asia's infrastructural needs: HSBC
summary: HSBC analysts say China's One Belt, One Road initiative is a catalyst for Asia's infrastructural transformation, with Singapore emerging as a focal point. The initiative is expected to attract billions of dollars in infrastructure projects, addressing the region's significant funding gap. HSBC estimates the six major Asean economies need $2.1 trillion in infrastructure spending, with the current trend covering only $910 billion. The initiative is helping raise awareness of Asia's infrastructural needs, which could have a flow-on impact into various sectors such as property, real estate, and retail.

site_title: Oscar-winning 'Silence of the Lambs' director dies
summary: Jonathan Demme, Oscar-winning director of 'The Silence of the Lambs,' died on April 26, 2017, at 73, due to complications from esophageal cancer. Demme directed 20 feature films and 12 documentaries, known for his work on 'Philadelphia,' 'The Silence of the Lambs,' and documentaries on Nelson Mandela and Bruce Springsteen. His success with 'The Silence of the Lambs' led to a commercial breakthrough, and he went on to direct 'Philadelphia,' which won Tom Hanks an Academy Award. Demme is survived by his three children and will be laid to rest in a private funeral.

site_title: UK housing starts indicator hits 10-year high, commercial market improves
summary: UK housing starts indicator hits a 10-year high in early 2017, with 42,470 registrations for new homes, a 17% increase compared to the same period last year. Demand for commercial property also improved, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' survey showing a pick-up in industrial sector demand. However, some parts of the UK, particularly Scotland and Northern Ireland, showed signs of weakness due to Brexit uncertainty, with investors expressing concerns about the UK's future relationship with the EU.

site_title: Tennis: 'Best feeling in world' as Sharapova wins on return
summary: Maria Sharapova marked her 15-month doping ban return with a 7-5, 6-3 win over Roberta Vinci in Stuttgart, describing the victory as "the best feeling in the world". Sharapova, a former world number one and five-time Grand Slam champion, fired 39 winners and 11 aces past Vinci, despite struggling with her shots in the first set. The Russian will play Ekaterina Makarova in the next round, with the French Tennis Federation set to decide her French Open participation in May.

site_title: US vows to force North Korea back to nuclear talks
summary: The US has vowed to step up sanctions to force North Korea back to nuclear talks, with President Donald Trump aiming to "pressure" the regime into dismantling its nuclear programme. Diplomatic efforts and new sanctions will be used, with the US engaging with its allies and regional partners to increase pressure on North Korea. Military action remains an option, with US troops in South Korea deploying an anti-missile system that has infuriated China. The US is also considering designating North Korea as a "state sponsor of terrorism."

site_title: US$425 jeans coated with fake dirt go viral
summary: Luxury jeans coated with fake dirt have gone viral, sparking scorn from those who prefer authentic dirt. The US$425 PRPS Barracuda straight leg jeans, sold on Nordstrom, feature a crackled, muddy coating that's meant to resemble worn workwear. Critics, including Mike Rowe, have called the jeans a "costume for wealthy people who see work as ironic - not iconic." Twitter users have also poked fun at the price, with one user joking that he'd throw them in the mud for free. The "muddy" jean jacket is also available for an additional US$425.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets signs lithium offtake deal
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited (AMA) has signed a 5-year lithium offtake deal with Burwill Holdings Limited, a Chinese steel trading and mining firm. AMA will supply lithium concentrate at a fixed price of US$880 per tonne for lithium oxide with a concentration of 6% for the initial five years. The deal includes a prepayment of A$25 million and is expected to kickstart the construction of a density media separation plant at AMA's Bald Hill project in Western Australia.

site_title: Air travel to US drops in Q1; Canada, Mexico gain
summary: US air travel declined 4.3% in Q1, while Canada and Mexico saw a 6.1% increase in arrivals. The decline may be attributed to uncertainty over President Trump's travel ban and the strong dollar. In contrast, arrivals in Canada and Mexico rose, driven by bookings from the Netherlands, China, Britain, and Germany. Forward bookings to the US for Q2 are 3.7% ahead of last year, largely due to the later Easter holiday period.

site_title: Trade tensions spike as Trump picks trade fight with Canada
summary: US President Donald Trump accused Canada of being "very rough" on America, threatening to retaliate against restrictions on US dairy products. The US imposed tariffs on Canadian softwood lumber, sparking a dispute that has been ongoing for nearly 35 years. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau vowed to defend Canada's interests, but also expressed a willingness to work together to find a solution. The US Commerce Department justified the tariffs by claiming that Canadian firms charge subsidized prices when exporting lumber to the US.

site_title: French stocks hit 9-year high as earnings power European shares
summary: French blue chips reached a nine-year high, driven by Kering's strong sales, with the CAC 40 rising 0.2%. European regional indexes hovered near a 20-month peak, with luxury stocks and financials leading gains. The Stoxx 600 benchmark ended 0.5% higher, supported by earnings results that outperformed market expectations. Other notable gains included Fiat Chrysler's 9% surge and LVMH's record high, while Bic and Dassault Systemes fell. Analysts attributed the gains to a wave of positive earnings results and a surge in luxury stocks.

site_title: StanChart beats estimates, profit swells
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 10% increase in transaction banking revenue to $785 million, surpassing estimates, as the bank recovers from an explosion of emerging-market lending and an annual loss in 2015. Underlying pretax profit for the first quarter almost doubled to $1.05 billion, beating analyst estimates. The bank's common equity tier 1 capital ratio rose to 13.8%, indicating improved financial strength. The recovery in revenue is seen as a positive step for the bank to reach its profit goals and restore the dividend.

site_title: US dollar eases from highs on Trump tax plan disappointment
summary: The US dollar eased from its highs on Wednesday after a disappointing White House tax reform announcement, with gains pared after the unveiling of a plan to cut corporate and pass-through tax rates. The dollar had surged before the announcement, but analysts said traders were disappointed by the lack of new details. The euro also trimmed losses against the US dollar, while the Mexican peso and Canadian dollar rose due to reports of a possible US withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Fed, wary of inflation, could lean against Trump tax cut
summary: The US Federal Reserve is concerned that President Trump's plan to slash business and household taxes could lead to higher interest rates and inflation, despite the administration's claims that it will boost investment and make the economy more competitive. The tax cuts, estimated to be up to $700 billion annually, could add fuel to an already near-full-capacity economy, potentially derailing the Fed's goal of keeping inflation at 2%. The Fed's decision on interest rate hikes will be closely watched, with some analysts warning of potential friction with the White House if the Fed moves faster to counter the tax cuts.

site_title: More steel companies use Singapore as gateway to market to S-E Asia
summary: Singapore has seen a surge in the number of iron-ore and steel-trading companies, with nearly 70 global companies now based in the city-state. This growth follows the expansion of the Singapore Exchange's iron ore derivatives trading and the increasing investments in infrastructure development in South-east Asia. China's "One Belt One Road" initiative is also expected to boost infrastructure spending, further fueling the trend. The city-state's role as a commodity trading hub has made it an attractive gateway for steel producers to tap into the South-east Asian market.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as Trump tax plan comes into focus
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday as the Trump administration unveiled its tax reform plan, ending a two-day rally. The plan includes cutting the corporate tax rate to 15% and increasing individual deductions, but details are scarce and its passage in Congress is uncertain. European markets edged higher ahead of the European Central Bank meeting, while Japan's Nikkei rose 1.1%. Despite the US market dip, analysts remain optimistic about the potential for tax reform, citing a history of strong market performance in May.

site_title: Brexit risks opening pandora's box of trade disputes for Britain
summary: The UK's exit from the European Union poses significant risks for trade disputes, with the World Trade Organization (WTO) being a key battleground. Britain's ambassador to the WTO, Julian Braithwaite, is tasked with navigating a seamless transition and hammering out terms without triggering conflicts among the organization's 163 members. The UK aims to replicate the EU's tariffs, but this may face opposition from countries like India and Australia, which want to protect their farmers' interests. The outcome is uncertain, with potential for protracted negotiations, mini-trade wars, and international disputes.

site_title: Oil prices stable after big draw in US crude inventories
summary: US oil prices rebounded after a surprise 3.6 million barrel drop in crude inventories, exceeding expectations. The US Energy Department reported a larger-than-expected decline, encouraging buying after several days of selling. US WTI prices rose 6 cents to $49.62 per barrel, while Brent crude fell 21 cents to $51.82 per barrel. Refining capacity utilization reached a record 94.1%, boosting gasoline inventories. However, analysts warned that weak US gasoline demand could weigh on crude prices in coming weeks unless demand spikes with the summer driving season.

images.alt_text: US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) settled up six cents at US$49.62 per barrel, while Brent crude, the international benchmark, ended down 21 cents at US$51.82 a barrel.

site_title: Govt shutdown threat ebbs as Trump relents on wall funding
summary: US President Donald Trump has retreated from his demand to fund a border wall with Mexico, easing a government shutdown threat. The White House is now working on a compromise that would keep the government running without appearing to cave in on Trump's demand. The government is set to exhaust its current funding at midnight on Friday, prompting lawmakers to inch closer to a deal. Trump's decision to relent on the wall funding comes ahead of his first 100-day milestone.

site_title: China steel futures buoyed by talk of output curbs ahead of May summit
summary: China's steel futures rose to their highest in 2.5 weeks amid speculation of production curbs in cities surrounding Beijing ahead of the May New Silk Road summit. Analysts suggest a 20-day stoppage could cut combined crude steel production by 11.5 million tonnes, but the impact may vary if only sinter plants are requested to close. This led to a 1.3% gain in rebar prices, while iron ore also rose, despite slipping for the second straight day.

site_title: EU in rush to fill the Trump trade void
summary: The European Union is under pressure to sign a new Pacific free trade deal by the end of 2017, following the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership under President Donald Trump. EU trade chief Cecilia Malmstrom has emphasized the need to defend openness and convince a skeptical EU public of the benefits of trade. The EU has set its sights on trade deals with Japan, Mexico, and the Mercosur bloc, with Japan seen as a key target. However, Brexit negotiations and internal EU issues may distract resources and limit the EU's ability to achieve these deals.

site_title: Trump unlikely to craft grand vision for Asia
summary: US President Donald Trump's upcoming visit to Southeast Asia in November is seen as a reassuring gesture to the region, but his administration's lack of a grand vision for Asia is a concern. The Trump administration will focus on maintaining US status as a Pacific power through increased military engagement and bilateral economic deals, rather than a comprehensive Asia policy. This approach is a departure from former President Barack Obama's "pivot to Asia" and may not be enough to catch up with his predecessor's efforts to engage with the region.

site_title: Rotary Engineering wins S$140m contract
summary: Rotary Engineering Limited secured a S$140 million engineering, procurement, and construction contract from Jurong Port Tank Terminals Pte Ltd for a new liquid bulk terminal on Jurong Island. The project will have an initial capacity of 232,000 cu m and can be expanded to 462,000 cu m. The terminal will be connected to Jurong Island via pipelines and will support the demand for liquid bulk storage in the region.

site_title: Goods vehicle COE premium slumps S$20,000
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for commercial vehicles in Singapore has fallen nearly S$20,000 ahead of next month's increase in supply. Cat C for goods vehicles and buses dropped S$19,405 to S$26,501, while Cat D for motorcycles fell S$877 to S$6,712. The May to July 2017 COE quota will expand 20.1% to 31,708, with Cat C leading the increase. However, some dealers believe the Cat C premium could fall further due to a wait-and-see attitude from prospective buyers.

images.alt_text: Cat C - for goods vehicles and buses - slumped S$19,405 to S$26,501.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) acquired Orange Valley Healthcare Pte Ltd for approximately S$164 million. The acquisition is expected to cater to the growing demand for aged-care services in Singapore, with the number of elderly Singaporeans projected to double by 2030. Meanwhile, Ascendas Reit is forecasted to book positive rental reversions of 2-5% for FY18, despite challenges in the industrial segment. Mapletree Industrial Trust's performance remains steady, driven by organic developments and good cost management.

site_title: Staying afloat in a wave of change
summary: Leading figures in the maritime sector discuss the challenges and opportunities ahead. Key challenges include abundant shipbuilding capacity, cheap capital, and volatility in energy prices. The growth of container liner shipping capacity has outpaced growth in cargo liftings, and the Internet of Things and digitization will have a significant impact on future products and business. To address these challenges, the industry must focus on innovation, quality workers, and sustainable practices. Singapore's maritime sector has fared well due to its business-friendly environment, strategic initiatives, and public-private partnerships. The industry must adapt to changing trends, including digitalization, anti-globalization, and nationalist agendas, to emerge stronger in the future.

site_title: Trump proposes major tax cuts, 15% corporate rate
summary: The Trump administration proposed a major tax cut, slashing the corporate rate to 15% and aiming to simplify the tax code. The overhaul is aimed at boosting the US economy and businesses, including middle-class Americans. However, the plan faces a tough fight in Congress. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced the plan as Trump's presidency nears the 100-day mark.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration unveiled plans to dramatically cut taxes for US businesses and individuals, slashing the corporate rate to 15 per cent, but the once-in-a-generation overhaul is headed for a tough fight in Congress.

site_title: Mapletree's China commercial trust chalks up 2% higher DPU
summary: Mapletree's China commercial trust, MGCCT, reported a 2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.959 Singapore cents for 4Q FY16/17, driven by a reversal of value-added tax payable and implementation at Gateway Plaza. Gross revenue rose 7.9% to S$94.78 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 6.1%. For FY16/17, available DPU rose 1% to 7.32 cents, with gross revenue and NPI growing 4.2% and 2.9%, respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: 8 Capital, a subsidiary of 8I Holdings, has obtained approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to operate as a Registered Fund Management Company (RFMC). Ascendas India Trust reported a 10% year-on-year increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit to 1.54 Singapore cents. Duty Free International saw a near 15% year-on-year drop in net profit to RM17.82 million, while Yeo Hiap Seng's net profit surged to S$138.98 million due to a gain on disposal of its investment in Super Group.

site_title: Coca-Cola renews push to slim operations
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is set to cut costs by an additional $800 million annually as part of its effort to transform into a leaner operation under incoming CEO James Quincey. The company plans to achieve $3 billion in savings, including 1,200 job cuts by 2018. Additionally, Coca-Cola will spin off its bottling operations, one of its biggest strategic changes in decades.

images.alt_text: COCA-Cola Co will step up its bid to transform the company into a far leaner operation under incoming chief executive officer James Quincey after quarterly earnings missed estimates.

site_title: Abe minister resigns following gaffe on Japan's 2011 earthquake
summary: Japan's Reconstruction Minister Masahiro Imamura resigned after apologizing for remarks he made about the country's 2011 earthquake and tsunami, stating it was "good" the quake struck the Tohoku region rather than Tokyo. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denounced the comments as hurtful and inappropriate, and Imamura had previously faced controversy over remarks to evacuees from the Fukushima nuclear disaster. The resignation comes amid a string of verbal gaffes and scandals affecting Abe's cabinet, but is unlikely to have a significant impact on his administration.

site_title: Kim Dotcom urges New Zealand police to go after FBI chief
summary: Kim Dotcom is urging New Zealand police to question FBI director James Comey, who is attending a "Five Eyes" intelligence meeting in New Zealand. Dotcom, an internet mogul, believes Comey should be grilled about alleged wrongdoing. This move is considered "doomed" and comes as Comey is attending a meeting of the intelligence sharing network in the South Island. The request is likely to be met with resistance, as it could strain relations between the US and New Zealand.

site_title: China launches first domestically built aircraft carrier
summary: China has launched its first domestically built aircraft carrier, the second of its kind, in the northeastern port of Dalian. The carrier, expected to enter service in 2020, is conventionally powered and will operate China's Shenyang J-15 fighter jets. The launch follows rising tensions over North Korea and Beijing's assertiveness in the South China Sea, with China claiming almost all the sea's resources. Experts say the launch holds prestige value for Beijing, potentially eroding US military prominence in the region.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M up as much as 27.5% in debut trading
summary: Aoxin Q&M, a Chinese dental business spun off from listed entity Q&M, made its Catalist trading debut, with its stock trading as high as 25.5 Singapore cents, a 27.5% increase from its IPO price. The stock closed at 24 cents, up 20%, after 15.6 million shares changed hands. The company operates 11 dental centers across four Liaoning cities, with 240 dental professionals. CEO Dr. Shao Yongxin expressed optimism about the listing, which he believes will enhance the group's abilities to capitalize on the private dental industry in China.

site_title: Waymo offering Arizona residents free rides in autonomous cars
summary: Waymo, a self-driving car unit of Alphabet, is offering free rides to Arizona residents as part of its "early rider" program. The program allows hundreds of people to ride in and provide feedback on Waymo's autonomous vehicles. The goal is to gather feedback and shape the way self-driving technology is brought to the public. Waymo has been conducting a small-scale trial in the Phoenix area and is adding 500 hybrid minivans to its fleet. The program aims to accelerate the development of autonomous vehicles, with the goal of bringing self-driving cars to more communities.

site_title: New platform for companies and startups to hook up
summary: Singapore-based tech startup Digital Transformation Exchange (DTE) has launched to connect large corporations and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with innovative technologies. The platform aims to facilitate collaboration and knowledge sharing, allowing companies to capitalize on new ideas and trends, while startups gain market access and the opportunity to scale up. The first session focused on HR technologies and human-capital solutions, featuring six startups and industry leaders discussing trends, opportunities, and challenges.

site_title: HK trims power returns cap to 8% amid plans to cut coal
summary: Hong Kong's power utilities, CLP Holdings Ltd and HK Electric Investment Ltd, have signed a 15-year Scheme of Control with the government, trimming the allowed return rate to 8% from 9.99%. This change aims to help the city transition away from coal and reduce electricity bills. As most coal-fired plants will be retired in the next decade, the new rate is expected to provide clarity for utilities to invest in cleaner energy sources. Power tariffs for customers could fall by over 5%.

site_title: HK dollar falls at fastest pace in 14 months on widening US rate gap
summary: The Hong Kong dollar is falling at its fastest pace in 14 months due to a widening interest-rate gap with the US, reducing the appeal of the city's assets. The currency is linked to the greenback since 1983 and has fallen 0.3% this year, touching its weakest level since February 2016. The interest rate differential has widened to 60 basis points, with investors borrowing the Hong Kong dollar to dump it in the US market for higher yields. Experts predict further weakness, with the currency potentially falling to as low as 7.79.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong dollar has fallen 0.3 per cent this year and touched 7.7849 on Tuesday, its weakest level since February 2016.

site_title: As US retreats, China is taking the lead on green energy
summary: The US has retreated from its leadership role in green energy, following President Trump's abandonment of the clean power plan and slashing of the US budget for the World Bank. China, however, has stepped in, with its global policy banks providing over $160 billion in energy finance to foreign governments, nearly triple the average annual energy lending of the World Bank and Western-backed multilateral development banks. China's energy finance model is heavily concentrated in fossil fuel operations, but the country is poised to shift towards cleaner energy finance, potentially becoming the global leader in sustainable development finance.

site_title: Texas Instruments sees chip sales growth on firm demand
summary: Texas Instruments reported strong first-quarter revenue growth of over 10% due to firm demand for its semiconductor components across various industries. The company attributed the growth to continued strength in industrial and automotive markets, where semiconductor content is increasing. Texas Instruments' CEO Rich Templeton has diversified the company's product line, moving away from digital products, and the company has maintained a broad product lineup. The company's second-quarter profit forecast is also higher than analysts' projections, with a range of 89-101 cents per share.

site_title: Virtual reality exercise machine delivers real-world results
summary: A Munich-based startup, Icaros GmbH, has developed a virtual reality exercise machine that delivers a core workout by simulating flying and deep-ocean diving. The machine, costing around $10,000, has been installed in over 200 gyms and entertainment centers worldwide. Proponents argue that VR fitness can be addictive and engaging, citing examples like Pokémon Go, which persuaded users to walk 25% more. However, fitness experts remain skeptical, stating that extrinsic motivation is not enough to keep people exercising. Icaros plans to release a home version for $2,000 and a more intense version for professional gyms, with the goal of offering a more immersive and engaging workout experience.

images.alt_text: Mr Miyajima convinced the boss of his Tokyo gym to buy an Icaros machine last August, and is eagerly awaiting new software updates as gym members have become bored with the two available modes.

site_title: Trump's steel import move aimed at placating electoral base?
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a probe into curbing steel imports, citing national security concerns. The move aims to address Chinese overcapacity in the steel industry and is seen as a response to lobbying by the US steel industry. However, experts warn that such a move could lead to retaliatory measures from China and other steel exporters, potentially sparking a trade war. The announcement has raised concerns that Trump's economic nationalist stance may be at odds with his earlier promise to avoid confrontation with China, sparking debate over his true intentions.

site_title: Higher exports seen lifting German growth, investments
summary: Germany's economy is expected to grow 1.5% this year, driven by a booming construction sector and increasing exports. Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries attributed the growth to the European Central Bank's low interest rate environment and government investments in infrastructure. Despite global uncertainties, Zypries said the German economy appears to be resilient, shrugging off risks linked to Brexit, US protectionism, and China's push for new-energy vehicles. The government maintains its forecast for 1.6% growth in 2018.

site_title: Australia's sky-high household debt a ticking time bomb
summary: Australia's household debt has reached extreme levels, with a debt-to-GDP ratio of 123%, largely due to soaring property prices. Experts warn that this could lead to a financial crisis if interest rates rise, as Australians struggle to service their mortgages. The country's reliance on a limited liquid asset base and high wage growth rates exacerbate the issue. If the jobless rate rises to 8.5%, experts predict difficulties could arise, particularly in areas that benefited from the mining boom.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance posts 13% rise in Q1 profit on cost cuts
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 13.2% year-over-year increase in Q1 profit to S$16.46 million, driven by cost cuts. Staff costs declined 6.8% and other operating expenses fell 14%. Total interest income/hiring charges decreased 11.5% due to lower interest rates. Net interest income/hiring charges decreased marginally, while annualised earnings per share rose to 14.83 Singapore cents. The bank's net loan assets stood at S$9.5 billion, down 4.2% from last year.

site_title: May's call for general election is a reckless gamble with Britain's future
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has called for a general election on June 8, despite opposition from her own party, in a bid to secure a larger majority to navigate Brexit negotiations. However, the move is seen as a gamble with the nation's future, as a hung parliament could lead to ungovernability and Scottish and Northern Irish nationalism. May's decision has raised concerns that she is prioritizing her party's interests over the country's, and that the election may backfire, leading to low voter turnout and a hung parliament.

site_title: US moves Thaad system to Korea site amid protests
summary: The US military has begun deploying parts of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system to a site in South Korea, sparking protests from villagers and criticism from China. The system, aimed at countering North Korea's nuclear and missile threat, is expected to be operational by the end of the year. China urges the US and South Korea to cancel the deployment, claiming it will undermine its security and is ineffective against North Korea's missiles. Protests have broken out in South Korea, with over 10 protesters injured in clashes with police.

site_title: Europeans flock back to buy London property
summary: European investors are flocking back to London's commercial property market, with £1.7 billion invested in the first four months of 2017, accounting for 31% of the market. The weak pound and electoral uncertainty in Europe are driving the influx, with investors seeking to diversify their portfolios. Predictions suggest a softer Brexit, and the UK's political challenges are seen as predictable and priced in. As a result, acquisitions are stacking up, with major deals including the purchase of the Olympia exhibition center and a stake in Facebook's UK headquarters.

site_title: LME favours new pricing mechanism to boost monthly trading
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) is proposing a new pricing mechanism, called implied pricing, to boost monthly trading volumes and attract funds. The mechanism would use prices from trading on other dates to generate artificial prices for monthly contracts. The LME is under pressure to increase volumes after they fell 7.7% last year, and the proposed measure is supported by members and traders. The LME aims to introduce the new pricing mechanism by June 30 to address concerns from fund investors and industrial users.

site_title: China's largest private bank opens S'pore unit, eyes US$30b AUM in three years
summary: China Merchants Bank, the country's largest private bank, has launched a unit in Singapore aiming to track the growing wealth of Chinese businessmen in the city-state. The bank expects to manage up to US$30 billion in assets under management (AUM) in three years, similar to its Hong Kong unit, which achieved this milestone in a similar timeframe. The bank's private-banking unit general manager, Wang Jing, sees a growth trajectory in Singapore similar to that in Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore scores hat-trick as world's top maritime city
summary: Singapore has emerged as the world's leading maritime capital for the third consecutive time, according to the Menon report, which ranked maritime cities based on 24 objective indicators. The city scored top marks in five categories, including shipping, finance & law, maritime technology, ports & logistics, and attractiveness and competitiveness. Despite some challenges, including valuation losses and competition from other cities, Singapore's strong operational capabilities, port development, and collaboration with other maritime capitals have contributed to its top ranking.

site_title: Strong growth from NZ hotel buoys CDL's hospitality Reit in Q1
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported strong Q1 growth, driven by a 6.4% increase in net property income to S$35.9 million. The trust's distribution per stapled security rose 9% to 2.42 Singapore cents, and gross revenue grew 3.9% to S$46.4 million. The New Zealand hotel, Grand Millennium Auckland, contributed significantly to the growth due to its variable lease structure. Despite a marginal decline in its UK hotel, CDLHT remains focused on maintaining competitiveness and pursuing acquisitions to diversify income sources.

site_title: HK set to pip NY as top property market for mainland Chinese
summary: Hong Kong is poised to surpass New York City as the top property market for mainland Chinese investors, with total transaction volume in Q1 2017 reaching HK$36.1 billion, a 213% year-on-year increase. This surpasses the HK$17.2 billion invested in New York City, which saw a 22.8% year-on-year increase. Mainland Chinese investors are shifting focus from trophy assets to development sites, and local developers may need to adapt their business models to remain competitive.

site_title: Swedish manufacturing confidence hits 20-year high
summary: Swedish manufacturers report a 20-year high in confidence, with a score of 123.2 points in April, up from 111.9 in March. This boost in confidence, combined with a supportive monetary policy and global growth, is expected to drive the economy forward. Unemployment has reached its lowest level since 2008, and the central bank is predicted to raise its 2017 economic growth forecast. Despite surging economy, inflation remains subdued, and the Riksbank is likely to maintain its monetary policy unchanged.

site_title: Euro pulls back after France-led surge
summary: The euro retreated from its 5-1/2 month highs against the US dollar after investors cashed in gains following France's presidential elections and a market rethink on eurozone monetary policy. The euro weakened to US$1.0886, while the yen remained steady, and the Aussie and kiwi dollars fell due to soft inflation numbers. The decline is attributed to concerns over US President Trump's tax cut proposal and the potential for a decrease in the US dollar's value.

images.alt_text: The euro retreated from 5-1/2 month highs against the US dollar on Wednesday, investors cashing in gains made on the back of the first round of France's presidential elections and a market rethink on eurozone monetary policy.

site_title: Singapore shares rise for 5th straight day
summary: Singapore's stock market rose for the fifth consecutive day, driven by China's commitment to support its domestic economy and anticipation of US tax cuts. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.3% higher, with blue-chip stocks such as Hongkong Land, Genting Singapore, and local banks DBS and OCBC leading the gains. The rally was also supported by a study suggesting that populist leaders can have a positive impact on markets, which may be relevant to the recent Trump trade.

site_title: S$1b Singapore fund to help IP-strong businesses go global
summary: A new billion-dollar fund, the Makara Innovation Fund (MIF), has been launched in Singapore to support companies with strong intellectual property (IP) to go global. The fund, which will invest $30-$150 million in 10-15 enterprises, aims to capitalize on cross-border regional expansion. The MIF is a key initiative under the updated IP Hub Master Plan, which also includes other initiatives to deepen engagement between IP ValueLab and the Singapore Business Federation, and a partnership with EverEdge Global Ltd to help local businesses unlock their intangible assets. The fund is expected to inject at least $1.5 billion value-add to Singapore's economy over the next five years.

site_title: Citic Envirotech Q1 net up 41% to S$17m
summary: Citic Envirotech Ltd reported a 41.2% increase in net profit to S$17.03 million in Q1 2017, driven by a 53.4% rise in engineering business. Revenue rose 14.3% to S$113.73 million, with a significant increase in government grants. The company attributed its growth to its strong presence in the water sector and expansion into river restoration and hazardous waste treatment.

site_title: China banks miss out on US investment banking bonanza
summary: China's largest state-owned banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and Bank of China, are missing out on the US investment banking bonanza due to Beijing's control over their operations. The banks are unable to seek Federal Reserve clearance for investment banking activities, despite having significant assets in the US. This is due to US rules requiring the controlling shareholder to seek clearance, which poses a hurdle for the banks. China's leadership has shown no indication of relaxing its grip, with some analysts suggesting state divestiture as the solution to boost international growth.

site_title: In London, class warfare of a different stripe
summary: A London property developer, Zipporah Lisle-Mainwaring, successfully defended her decision to paint her $8.3 million townhouse with red and white stripes, despite a planning order from the local council to cover the pattern. The High Court ruled that her decorating choice was "entirely lawful" and trumped aesthetic considerations, allowing the stripes to remain. The case, which sparked debate over creativity and class warfare, has been hailed by some as a victory for British tolerance of individuality. Lisle-Mainwaring had initially intended to repaint the house white, but now favors bare bricks with colorful shutters.

site_title: Robotic process automation firm raises US$30m to fund expansion
summary: UiPath, a robotic process automation firm, has received US$30 million in Series A funding to accelerate its global expansion and product development. Led by Accel, the funding will be used to boost hiring and invest in artificial intelligence capabilities, particularly computer vision technology. The company aims to become an AI-centric firm in two years and plans to expand its operations in North America, Western Europe, India, Japan, and Southeast Asia. With current clients including Fortune Global 500 companies, UiPath expects to grow by five times in 2017, driven by businesses' pursuit of productivity improvements and efficient compliance.

site_title: Noma opens latest Mexico pop-up
summary: Noma, the world's hottest restaurant, has opened its latest pop-up in Tulum, Mexico, with tickets selling out in two hours for its US$600-per-person dinners from April 12 to May 28. The pop-up, located on the Yucatan Peninsula under a canopy of palm trees, features dishes from renowned chef René Redzepi, including unique creations such as pig dishes and ice cream that sets the tongue on fire. The pop-up is scheduled to run for seven weeks, offering a limited opportunity for diners to experience the restaurant's signature culinary experience.

site_title: Japanese former prosecutor calls for official probe into Toshiba's woes
summary: A Japanese former prosecutor, Nobuo Gohara, is calling for a full official probe into Toshiba's financial woes, stating that the situation is "out of control". Toshiba has declared a record loss of 552 billion yen and acknowledged substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern. The firm is selling off assets without a formal liquidation process, with potential Chinese bidders for its Westinghouse stake being opposed by the Japanese and US governments. Toshiba badly needs to raise funds to escape a financial hole, with a potential group net loss of one trillion yen for the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: The situation surrounding Japan's troubled electrical and engineering Toshiba Corporation is "out of control", a former public prosecutor declared on Wednesday, while calling for a full official inquiry into events that have brought the firm to the brink of collapse.

site_title: Hyundai's Q1 profit down 21% on China tensions, US recall
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 21% decline in Q1 net profit to 1.33 trillion won, driven by a US recall and sales declines in China due to anti-Korea sentiment. The company's China retail sales plummeted 14% and sales of 23.37 trillion in the January to March quarter. Hyundai expects a gradual recovery in earnings, citing new small SUV and Genesis brand models as key factors. The company's shares rose 4.2% following the earnings announcement.

site_title: MPA signs extension of MOU with ITOPF
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation Limited (ITOPF) signed a three-year extension to their memorandum of understanding (MOU) for clean-up operations. The agreement aims to minimize disagreements and expedite claims settlements, enhancing emergency preparedness and response. The renewed agreement will apply to different types of vessels and equipment used in responding to pollution incidents. This extension will help streamline the process and reduce potential disputes.

images.alt_text: The MOU on oil spill response equipment and vessel rates in Singapore was signed at the International Chemical and Oil Pollution Conference and Exhibition (ICOPCE) by MPA's portmaster, Capt Kevin Wong, and Richard Johnson, tech director, ITOPF, and witnessed by Capt M Segar, assistant chief executive (operations), MPA.

site_title: Unified shareholding will take Baltic Exchange forward: CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has acquired the Baltic Exchange, a 273-year-old institution providing information on maritime transportation markets. Mark Jackson, former chairman of the Baltic, has returned as CEO, citing the promise of a unified shareholding structure and long-term view. The new ownership allows for more focus on serving the maritime industry, rather than appeasing diverse shareholders and directors. Jackson has announced plans to develop the use of freight futures in Asia, review the Code of Conduct, and expand the Baltic's relevance across the commodity space.

site_title: Lotte Group's restructuring plan seen boosting chairman's control
summary: Lotte Group, South Korea's fifth-largest conglomerate, plans to restructure its four listed units into a holding company, aiming to boost operational transparency and enhance chairman Shin Dong-bin's control amid a power struggle with his brother. The move aims to dispel concerns over family disputes over management rights. The new setup will reduce cross-shareholding ties and make it easier to estimate operational worth, potentially leading to better valuations for the remaining businesses. The plan was unveiled after Lotte's failed US$4.5 billion initial public offering.

site_title: Google's Brin secretly builds massive airship
summary: Google co-founder Sergey Brin is secretly building a massive airship, dubbed a zeppelin, at NASA's Ames Research Center.
