The project's details are unclear, with Brin stating he has nothing to say about it. Former Nasa director Alan Weston, leading the project, has a background in engineering and risk-taking. The airship aims to reduce fuel costs by up to an order of magnitude, with a potential capacity to carry 500 tonnes. The project is separate from Google's secretive flying car projects and shares similarities with Weston's previous work on airship technologies.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,173.76 points, driven by Chinese leaders' announcement to improve financial support for the country's real economy. About 2.66 billion shares worth S$1.35 billion changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 260 to 204. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Silent pall hangs over North Korea's ski resort
summary: North Korea's Masikryong ski resort, built by Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un, remains largely deserted, despite its luxurious facilities and high price point. The resort, which attracts 70,000 visitors annually, offers a 700m vertical drop and compares favorably to other destinations in neighboring China or South Korea. However, the area surrounding the resort is impoverished, with around 40% of the population undernourished, and the resort's emptiness is starkly contrasted with the opulence within. The resort's profitability is disputed, with some estimates suggesting it may not be viable due to the high cost of maintaining it.

site_title: Singapore women could look towards pay parity by 2041
summary: Women in Singapore could close the gender pay gap by 2041 by making key skill adjustments and career changes. Accenture's research found that women in the Class of 2020 could close the gap in 2044, with a woman earning US$100 for every US$168 a man earns. To achieve pay parity, women need critical support from government, business, and academia, and must overcome challenges such as skill set disparities and mindset barriers. By working together, women can reduce the pay gap by 15% by 2030 and boost their income by US$15.9 billion in Singapore.

site_title: EU summit to decide UK's divorce direction
summary: The European Union is set to decide the UK's direction in the Brexit process, with a special summit on Saturday to formally approve negotiating guidelines. The EU 27 will discuss key elements of the exit deal, including citizens' rights, the UK's "divorce bill," and a new customs agreement. The negotiations are expected to be complex, with a tight two-year time frame for completion. The UK aims for a "bold, ambitious free trade agreement" with the EU, but it remains unclear if these demands can be met. A disorderly hard Brexit is also a possibility, with some experts estimating a 50% chance of an orderly exit.

site_title: NTUC to accredit career coaches with eye on lifting competencies
summary: Singapore's NTUC is launching the Practicing Employability Coach framework to accredit and improve the competencies of career coaches. The framework aims to encourage coaches to practice, deepen their skills, and commit to high professional standards. This move is expected to enhance the quality of employment services in the country.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest two disqualified lawmakers: party
summary: Hong Kong police arrested two disqualified lawmakers, Yau Wai-ching and Baggio Leung, on charges of unlawful assembly over an attempt to force their way into a Legislative Council meeting in November. The pair, who represent the Youngspiration party, had their swearing-in oaths invalidated due to derogatory language towards China. The arrests are seen as a reinforcement of concern among democracy activists about interference by Beijing in Hong Kong's affairs, amid a backdrop of increasing tensions between the city and China.

images.alt_text: Yau Wai-ching (left) and Baggio Leung were picked up at their homes early in the morning and taken to a police station for questioning, their party, Youngspiration, said in a statement.

site_title: Boeing profits jump but commercial air deliveries fall
summary: Boeing reported a 19% increase in net income to $1.5 billion for the latest quarter, driven by declining costs. However, revenues fell 7.3% to $21 billion, missing analyst expectations. Commercial plane deliveries dropped 7 from the same period in 2016, with Boeing citing a "sharp focus on performance and productivity" to reach financial targets. The company modestly increased its full-year profit forecast by 10 cents a share, citing a lower-than-expected tax rate.

site_title: McDonald's shelves plans to sell stake in Japan unit after rebound
summary: McDonald's has shelved plans to sell a stake in its Japan unit, which has seen a turnaround since announcing a potential sale over a year ago. The unit's quarterly losses ended in 2014, but it has since rebounded with forecasted net income of 8.5 billion yen (S$106.5 million) for 2017 and consecutive monthly sales growth. The decision won't impact long-term financial targets or McDonald's goal to franchise 95% of its restaurants.

site_title: United Tech profit rises 17.8%, affirms full-year forecast
summary: United Technologies Corp reported a 17.8% rise in first-quarter profit, beating analysts' expectations, with net income reaching US$1.39 billion. The company affirmed its full-year earnings forecast of US$6.30 to US$6.60 per share. Sales increased 3.4% to US$13.82 billion, driven by higher sales in all four business units. A 30% growth in new orders in Europe and plans to buy local elevator makers in China were also highlighted.

site_title: Singdollar bond market on track for another big year
summary: The Singapore dollar bond market is on track for another strong year, with demand outpacing supply and foreign issuers taking notice. The market has seen a new high in the Markit SGD corporates total-return index, with the largest foreign deal sold since 2015. A S$600 million bond sale by China's Huarong Asset Management attracted S$1.1 billion in orders, and a S$500 million bond sale by Commerzbank drew S$4 billion in orders. The market is expected to remain buoyant, driven by demand for debt and infrastructure funding, with refinancing needs and rising interest rates spurring the debt market.

site_title: In dotcom bubble time, it's still only 1997 for US equities
summary: US equities are currently trading at similar valuations to 1997, a time of the dotcom bubble, according to a study by Leuthold Group LLC. The S&P 500 Index is measured by six factors, including earnings, dividends, and cash flow, and is currently trading at the same multiple as it was 20 years ago. While this may provide some relief to investors, concentrated leadership in tech giants, such as Apple, Amazon, and Google, is a warning sign that investors are chasing a small pool of big winners, which could create problems if valuations become untenable.

site_title: SGX records early success in coking coal contract (Amended)
summary: SGX has seen early success in trading its coking coal derivatives, with trading volumes surging to 40,000 lots in the first half of the year. The exchange's success is attributed to extreme price volatility in the market, which has led buyers to move away from quarterly price negotiations and instead opt for shorter time frames. Despite this, some industry players caution that it's too early to declare SGX's success, as its closest competitor, CME Group, still has a significant presence in the market.

site_title: Malaysian March online recruitment down; retail sector worst hit
summary: Malaysia's online recruitment declined 11% in March compared to the previous year, with the retail sector experiencing a 36% contraction, the largest decline. Hospitality and travel also saw significant declines, while IT and telecommunications experienced a 13% growth. Despite a slight increase in business confidence, concerns remain about unemployment, particularly among youth, which reached 10.7% in 2015. Experts warn that finding qualified candidates will be a challenge, and the retail sector's decline may impact brick-and-mortar businesses.

site_title: EGM aside, revolt has already switched things up at Sabana Reit
summary: A group of more than 60 unitholders in Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) in Singapore are attempting to unseat the manager, but the outcome is uncertain due to lack of buy-in from bigger unitholders. The Securities Investors Association of Singapore, an advocacy group, has advised unitholders to wait for the outcome of a strategic review before making a decision, potentially thwarting the manager's removal. The revolt has already led to a review and a new substantial investor, e-Shang Redwood, entering the fray, which may add promise to the Reit's prospects.

site_title: Credit Suisse makes 4b franc cash call in move to shore up capital
summary: Credit Suisse announced a 4 billion Swiss franc (S$5.6 billion) cash call to shore up capital, easing immediate concerns but raising questions about future capital raises. The bank cited a rebound in quarterly profit but struck a cautious tone, with management fighting investor protests over executive pay and facing an investigation into tax evasion and money laundering. Analysts reacted with mixed views, with some predicting more capital raises, while others saw the decision as a relief for investors.

images.alt_text: The bank reported its highest quarterly profit since a sweeping restructuring launched by CEO Tidjane Thiam.

site_title: Sydney property lifts Suntec Reit's Q1 results
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 3.1% increase in distributable income to S$61.85 million in Q1 2017, driven by a 14.6% rise in net property income to S$61.83 million. The increase was attributed to a 34.3% growth in gross office revenue from its Sydney asset, 177 Pacific Highway. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 2.3% to 2.425 Singapore cents, translating to an annualised distribution yield of 5.6%.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as Trump's tax plan eyed
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday amid a surge in corporate earnings, ahead of President Donald Trump's highly anticipated tax reform plan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.08% to 21,013.51, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.06% and 0.09%, respectively. Trump's plan aims to slash the corporate tax rate to 15% and offer multinational businesses a tax break on overseas profits. The administration expects to release details of the plan later in the day, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin indicating fundamental agreement with Congress on tax reform goals.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q4 DPU up 10%
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 10% year-over-year increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.54 Singapore cents. Total property income rose 23% to S$44.2 million, driven by positive rental reversions and new acquisitions. Net property income increased 25% to S$29 million. The distribution amount of 2.96 Singapore cents per unit will be paid out on May 26.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at one-month high on global gains, China rebound
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.5% to a one-month high on April 26, 2017, driven by global gains and an overnight Wall Street rally. Mainland China stocks also rebounded, supporting investor confidence. The Hang Seng index reached 24,578.43 points, with financials and services sectors leading the gains. Fund managers expect improved bank balance sheets and attractive sector valuations, contributing to the market's optimism.

site_title: PepsiCo's quarterly profit surges 41.6%
summary: PepsiCo Inc reported a 41.6% surge in quarterly profit to US$1.32 billion, or 91 cents per share, driven by higher demand for healthier drinks and snacks. Revenue rose 1.6% to US$12.05 billion, marking the second quarter of sales growth after eight quarters of decline. The company attributed its success to its efforts to develop healthier products to meet changing consumer tastes.

site_title: China considers raising tariffs on sugar imports - sources
summary: China is considering imposing special import duties on sugar imports, with a proposed 45% duty this fiscal year, amid an anti-dumping probe into cheaper overseas arrivals. The move aims to help domestic producers battling rising farm costs. If approved, duties would increase to 85% over two years, potentially costing importers at least 1,000 yuan (S$202.35) more per tonne. Analysts warn that penalties might increase smuggling and be less effective than intended.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's Q1 profit rises
summary: Hong Leong Finance's Q1 profit rose 13.2% to S$16.46 million, driven by a 11.5% decline in staff costs and other operating expenses. Total interest income/hiring charges fell to S$72.1 million, in line with lower interest rates. Annualised earnings per share increased to 14.83 Singapore cents, up from 13.11 cents last year.

site_title: Giant rabbit dies on United Airlines flight to US
summary: A 3-foot giant rabbit named Simon died on a United Airlines flight from London to Chicago after a 10-month-old passenger purchased him. Simon, a Continental Giant breed rabbit, was healthy before the flight but died in the cargo section of a Boeing 767. United Airlines has offered assistance to the owner and is reviewing the matter, citing the safety and wellbeing of all animals that travel with them as a top priority. This incident comes after a global backlash against the airline following the violent removal of a passenger from a flight earlier this month.

site_title: MPA signs extension of MOU with ITOPF
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has signed a three-year extension to its Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation Limited (ITOPF) on agreed rates for clean-up operations. The renewed agreement aims to minimize disagreements and expedite claims settlements. This extension follows the signing of a joint chemical spill exercise on April 28, demonstrating Singapore's readiness for oil and chemical spill incidents. The agreement also reflects the importance of vigilance in maintaining safer and cleaner waters worldwide.

site_title: Boohoo bucks UK retail trend with upbeat sales forecast
summary: British online fashion retailer Boohoo forecasted 50% sales growth in its new financial year, defying UK retail trends. The company's profit doubled in 2016-17 and has been one of the best-performing UK stocks over the last year. Boohoo expects a 10% profit margin and revenue growth, driven by acquisitions and increased popularity of e-commerce and social media. The company's shares have risen 36% this year, valuing the business at £2 billion.

site_title: MGCCT's Q4 DPU increases to 1.959 Singapore cents
summary: MAPLETREE Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 1.9% year-over-year increase in available distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.959 Singapore cents for 4Q FY16/17. The DPU increase was attributed to a reversal of value added tax payable and implementation process at Gateway Plaza. Gross revenue rose 7.9% to S$94.78 million, while net property income was 6.1% higher at S$77.48 million. The DPU is payable on May 29.

site_title: StanChart Q1 profit doubles to US$1b as bad loans fall
summary: Standard Chartered reported a pre-tax profit of $1 billion in Q1, nearly doubling from the same period last year. The bank's loan impairment charge was lower than expected, contributing to the increase. Shares rose 4% in London, with analysts praising the bank's core capital ratio and prospects for a return to dividend payments. The bank's restructuring efforts have reduced riskier exposures, and it is well-positioned to benefit from rising US interest rates and stronger trade flows in Asia.

site_title: YuuZoo to set up first eSports college, development park in Harbin
summary: YuuZoo, a Singapore-listed social-commerce company, has signed a framework agreement with the Harbin municipal government in China to establish Harbin's first eSports college and eSports development park. The municipal government will provide the venue and land, while YuuZoo will handle international partnerships, planning, and design. The project aims to promote eSports development in China and will seek investors and developers to support the ventures.

site_title: Credit Suisse raises fresh capital, drops Swiss IPO
summary: Credit Suisse launched a share issue to raise $4.0 billion, aiming to bolster capital ratios and protect against market volatility. The bank will not take part of its Swiss division public, reversing earlier plans. The move is part of its ongoing restructuring plan under new CEO Tidjane Thiam. Credit Suisse reported a net profit of $596 million in the first quarter, a significant improvement from a year-earlier loss. The bank's tier-one CET capital ratio is expected to rise to 13.4% from 11.7%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's COE premium for commercial vehicles dropped nearly S$20,000 ahead of a supply increase. The country's economy is expected to grow 2.4% in 2017, with exports and factory output increasing. Singapore's factory output rose 10.2% in March, driven by a tech-led increase. A new S$1 billion fund was launched to support innovation, while China Merchants Bank expanded its private banking arm in Singapore. Stocks closed 0.3% higher, with the Straits Times Index moving up 9.83 points.

site_title: Duty Free International reports lower Q4FY17 profit
summary: Duty Free International reported a 14.7% year-over-year decline in net profit to RM17.82 million for Q4FY17, driven by a 7.4% revenue drop due to flooding in Thailand and the implementation of a goods and services tax. Net profit for the full year increased 17.8% to RM72.73 million. Earnings per share fell to 1.49 sen from 1.90 sen in the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.12 points to close at 1,768.92 on Wednesday, driven by a 3.55 billion lots trade valued at RM3.13 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly nudge lower at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined slightly in subdued trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.1% to 7,101.53 points. The Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also declined, with the DAX flatlining at 12,466.50 points. The declines were attributed to mixed signals from US-EU trade talks and uncertainty over tariffs.

site_title: Daimler says diesel probes could result in penalties, recalls
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, warned that US authorities' probes into diesel emissions and auxiliary emission control devices could lead to significant penalties and vehicle recalls. Investigations by the US Department of Justice, EPA, and the Stuttgart prosecutor in Germany are ongoing, and Daimler reiterated that the outcome could result in monetary penalties, remediation requirements, and process improvements. The company's quarterly report stated that the probes could lead to unfavorable findings, potentially affecting Mercedes-Benz's diesel vehicles, and that Daimler could be subject to significant monetary penalties and vehicle recalls if the investigations yield unfavorable results.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng Q1 results boosted by gain on disposal
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q1 net profit surged to S$138.98 million, driven by a S$138.35 million gain from disposing of its Super Group investment. Revenue fell to S$81.87 million due to disruptions in sales and market weakness. Earnings per share rose to 24.06 cents, up from 0.94 cent a year ago. However, the group warned of declining food & beverage margins due to soft economic conditions and weak market outlook.

site_title: Frontline makes yet another offer for rival DHT
summary: Frontline has made its fifth offer for tanker operator DHT Holdings, proposing an all-share deal of 0.8 Frontline shares for each DHT share. The offer aims to maximize value for both sets of shareholders, with Frontline CEO Robert Hvide Macleod stating that the proposed combination will be beneficial. DHT has rejected the offer, calling it not an improvement on previous ones and stating it will review the approach, giving Frontline 24 hours to reconsider. The deal could forge the world's largest tanker company, with billionaire John Fredriksen hoping to complete the acquisition.

images.alt_text: Frontline has made a fifth offer for tanker operator DHT Holdings and given its rival 24 hours to reconsider a deal which billionaire John Fredriksen hopes will forge the world's largest tanker company.

site_title: Netflix poised for elusive China breakthrough
summary: Netflix has reached a content-licensing deal with Baidu's iQiyi.com, a Chinese video platform, potentially allowing the US-based video-on-demand leader to break into the massive China market. The deal, which includes popular Netflix shows like Black Mirror and Stranger Things, will provide licensed and high-definition online streaming content for Chinese users. However, the partnership will be subject to Chinese censorship. This move marks Netflix's first major breakthrough in China, where its service is currently blocked.

site_title: SBS Transit, ST Kinetics ink MOU to work together on rail maintenance
summary: SBS Transit and ST Kinetics have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to collaborate on rail maintenance and engineering capabilities. Under the agreement, ST Kinetics will provide expertise and services to refurbish electronics components for SBS Transit's trains, while SBS Transit will leverage on ST Kinetics' capabilities in testing and repair. The collaboration aims to improve operational productivity and efficiency through automation, data analytics, and robotics solutions. The partnership marks ST Kinetics' entry into the rail maintenance industry and will deepen SBS Transit's capabilities in rail repairs and maintenance.

site_title: China: Stocks rise as Wall Street surges, mainland economy fears ease
summary: China stocks rose for a second day, with the CSI300 index gaining 0.1% to 3,445.18 points, as US markets hit record highs and concerns about Beijing's deleveraging campaign eased. Investors took profits on some stocks, but others benefiting from the Xiongan New Economic Zone rebounded sharply. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.2% to 3,140.85 points, amid a broad neutral monetary stance and proactive fiscal policy in China. The country's politburo confirmed its commitment to maintaining a proactive fiscal policy and prudent monetary policy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 6-year high, won edges up
summary: South Korean shares ended at a six-year high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing up 0.5% at 2,207.84 points. Strong first-quarter earnings boosted investment sentiment, and offshore investors purchased 293.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The South Korean won also edged up due to high demand for the currency. This marks the strongest Kospi level since May 2, 2011.

site_title: Australia's sky-high household debt a ticking time bomb
summary: Australians face a "ticking time bomb" of extreme household debt, with a household debt-to-GDP ratio of 123%, largely due to soaring property prices. Experts warn that if interest rates rise, Australians may struggle to service their mortgages, affecting economic growth. The nation's reliance on a single trading partner, China, and its limited liquid assets make it vulnerable to a financial crisis. Despite warnings from the Reserve Bank of Australia, interest rates remain low, and the government is reluctant to implement policies to drive supply and affordable housing.

site_title: Goods vehicle COE premium slumps
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for commercial vehicles in Singapore has decreased ahead of a supply increase next month. Category C for goods vehicles and buses fell by S$19,405 to S$26,501, while Category D for motorcycles decreased by S$877 to S$6,712. Category A for cars below 1,600cc or 130hp slipped by S$400 to S$51,600, while Category B and E remained unchanged. This decrease is seen as a relief for drivers and businesses ahead of the increased supply.

site_title: Rowsley reports Q1 net loss due to weaker pound and ringgit
summary: Rowsley reported a Q1 net loss of S$1.6 million, down from a net profit of S$4.8 million in the same period last year, due to exchange losses from the weakening of the sterling pound and Malaysian ringgit against the Singapore dollar. Revenue rose 10% to S$22.6 million, driven by Squire Mech's contribution.

site_title: Australia shares close stronger, NZ index at 6-month high
summary: New Zealand shares reached a six-month high on April 26, driven by gains in the healthcare and materials sectors, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index also rose 0.68% to a two-year high. The rally was fueled by Wall Street's strength and the global rally following the French presidential election. Key performers included CSL Ltd, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto, with healthcare company CSL Ltd reaching a record high at A$130.395.

site_title: Pizza Hut enters Ethiopia in latest expansion into Africa
summary: Pizza Hut is set to enter Ethiopia with three outlets in Addis Ababa by November, becoming the first international restaurant chain to enter the country. The company, Yum! Brands Inc, has invested $5.5 million and plans to expand to 10 outlets, targeting 2,200 weekly transactions per outlet. This expansion is part of Pizza Hut's goal to boost its sub-Saharan Africa outlets to 100 by end-2017, with a focus on countries like Ghana and Togo.

images.alt_text: Pizza Hut is set to open three outlets in Ethiopia this year, becoming one of the first international restaurant chains to enter Africa's second-most populous country.

site_title: Air travel to US drops in Q1; Canada, Mexico gain: ForwardKeys
summary: Air passenger arrivals in the US dropped 4.3% in Q1, while Canada and Mexico saw a 6.1% increase. Middle Eastern and European travelers may have been deterred by the US travel ban. Long-haul arrivals in the US were impacted, with bookings 3.7% ahead of last year. In contrast, Canada and Mexico bookings rose 15.7% and 19.8% respectively. The travel industry's resilience was attributed to travelers finding alternative destinations and returning to previously blighted areas.

site_title: China's yuan dips against US dollar, falls to record low against currency basket
summary: China's yuan fell to a record low against a currency basket, dipping to 92.67, after the central bank set a weaker midpoint rate of 6.8845 per US dollar. The onshore yuan is expected to remain steady in the short term, driven by tighter cash conditions. In contrast, the offshore market saw a weaker yuan, with the offshore spot rate trading 0.06% lower than its onshore counterpart.

site_title: Peugeot says car parts division drove sales in Q1
summary: PSA Peugeot Citroen reported a 4.9% increase in overall sales to 13.6 billion euros in the first quarter, driven mainly by its car parts division Faurecia, which saw a 9.3% sales increase to 5.1 billion euros. The automobile division lifted sales by 2.5% to 9.0 billion euros, while vehicle sales rose 4.2% to 700,000 units worldwide. The company attributed growth to a product mix improvement that offset the negative impact of exchange rates, despite a volatile economic environment.

site_title: China Merchants Bank opens private banking arm in Singapore
summary: China Merchants Bank, the largest private bank by assets in China, has expanded its private banking arm in Singapore, managing approximately US$2 billion in assets as of March 2017. This move follows the bank's establishment of corporate banking services in Singapore in 2013, with about 1.7 trillion yuan in private-banking assets at the end of 2016. The expansion aims to capitalize on Singapore's financial hub status and tap into the country's affluent market.

images.alt_text: China Merchants Bank, China's largest private bank by assets, on Wednesday expanded its private banking business in Singapore.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Q1 profit slides as China political row, US recall drag
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 21% fall in Q1 net profit to 1.33 trillion won, attributed to a US recall and sales declines in China due to anti-Korean sentiment. The company's China retail sales dropped 14% and its heavy reliance on sedans struggles to compete with affordable SUVs. Hyundai expects a gradual recovery in earnings with new models, including a small SUV and Genesis brand, expected to help regain sales. The company's operating profit and sales were also impacted by a recall of nearly 1.5 million vehicles.

images.alt_text: South Korea's new antitrust chief said he has been in talks with the autos-to-steel conglomerate Hyundai about overhauling its complex ownership structure, which critics say gives too much power to its controlling family at the expense of shareholders.

site_title: Japan disaster minister resigns over quake gaffe
summary: Japan's disaster reconstruction minister, Masahiro Imamura, resigned after making remarks about the 2011 earthquake and tsunami that hit the northeastern region of Tohoku, saying it was lucky the disaster occurred there rather than Tokyo. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe apologized to Tohoku residents and replaced Imamura with Masayoshi Yoshino, citing Imamura's "extremely inappropriate" comments as a reason for the resignation. The move comes as Abe's government faces scandals and eroding public confidence, with Imamura's previous comments sparking outrage earlier this month.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei scales one-month peak as yen slips
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average reached a one-month peak, closing at 19,289.43, driven by a weaker yen and record highs for the Nasdaq Composite. The Nikkei was up 3.6% for the week and 2% in April. The US dollar rose against the yen in its biggest one-day gain in three months.

site_title: Vanke's home-sale permits scrapped in China's Xi'an in clampdown
summary: China's Xi'an city halted home-sale permits for Vanke Co, a suspected property market irregularity, as part of a nationwide crackdown to cool surging prices. The move follows China's housing ministry's October request to investigate "illegal" property sales. Vanke's shares fell 3.9% in Hong Kong and 1% in Shenzhen. The builder also cancelled a 1.5 billion yuan bond sale, citing market conditions. This is part of a broader effort by local governments to rein in the property market and prevent a housing bubble.

images.alt_text: A Chinese local government halted home-sales permits to China Vanke Co, as the nation's leaders escalate scrutiny of irregularities in the property market to rein in surging prices.

site_title: Oil falls on bulging US crude inventories, record global supplies
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday due to a rise in US crude inventories and record global supplies. US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures dropped 13 cents to $49.43 per barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 11 cents to $51.99 per barrel. Despite Opec's pledge to cut 1.8 million barrels per day, global fuel supplies remain high, and traders doubt the effectiveness of the cuts. Supply volumes are expected to decline over the next three weeks, which could support the market and lead to a price rebound.

site_title: Credit Suisse to raise 4b Swiss francs in rights issue, ditches Swiss unit IPO
summary: Credit Suisse is raising around 4 billion Swiss francs (S$5.6 billion) through a rights issue to strengthen its balance sheet and invest in growth. The bank, Switzerland's second-biggest bank, had initially planned to sell a minority stake in its Swiss unit through an initial public offering (IPO) but has ditched the plan. CEO Tidjane Thiam says the capital raise will allow the bank to invest in growth at attractive returns, strengthen balance sheet resilience, and afford costs associated with restructuring plans.

site_title: Luxury spenders defy Japan's tight-fisted reputation
summary: Japan's luxury market is defying its reputation for being tight-fisted, with the country logging $22.7 billion in annual spending on top-end goods. Tokyo's Ginza district is a hub for luxury shopping, with brands like Chanel and Dior drawing big crowds. Despite a shrinking population and economic growth, Japan remains a significant market for luxury brands, with some 30% of sales now generated by foreign visitors. However, challenges persist, including a declining labor force and younger people's decreased interest in luxury brands.

site_title: Saudi Arabian bank ventures start merger talks
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc and Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc's Saudi ventures are in talks to combine, potentially giving RBS an exit from Alawwal Bank, a 40%-owned asset. The board of Alawwal agreed to discuss a merger with Saudi British Bank, owned 40% by HSBC. A deal could come as Saudi authorities diversify and privatize the economy, but concerns remain about bad loans hitting the banking system. RBS's stake in Alawwal is worth around $1.3 billion, and a merger may not result in job losses.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rally at 6-year high as hopes on strong Q1 attract investors
summary: South Korean stocks reached a near six-year high, with the Kospi index rising 0.5% to 2,206.84 points. Foreign investors' optimism over strong Q1 earnings and improving economic indicators drove the rally. Analysts predict further gains, with some forecasting the Kospi could reach 2,350 points by the third quarter. The Bank of Korea is set to release preliminary first-quarter growth data on Thursday.

site_title: China banks miss out on US investment banking bonanza
summary: China's state-owned banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, Bank of China, Agricultural Bank of China, and China Construction Bank, are missing out on the US investment banking bonanza due to Beijing's control over the banks. The banks' inability to secure Federal Reserve clearance hinders their ability to advise Chinese companies on acquisitions and share and debt sales, despite having deep ties with Chinese firms. Beijing's strict control poses a significant hurdle to the banks' expansion into investment banking, with some experts suggesting that privatization of the banks may be the solution to overcome regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Thai police to review procedures for taking down content after killing on Facebook Live
summary: Thai police announced plans to review procedures for removing online content after a man broadcast his 11-month-old daughter's murder on Facebook Live. The videos were available for nearly 24 hours before being taken down. Deputy national police spokesman Kissana Phatanacharoen stated that the police will discuss removing "inappropriate online content" from various platforms. Thailand's Ministry of Digital Economy contacted Facebook about the videos, which were removed after nearly a day of being uploaded. The move comes after a disturbing incident highlighting the need for improved content removal procedures.

site_title: Economists see faster China growth, moderate consumer inflation
summary: China's economists have upgraded forecasts for the country's economic growth, predicting faster expansion in the next four quarters. The country's GDP growth accelerated to 6.9% in the first quarter, its first back-to-back acceleration in seven years. Analysts expect consumer inflation to moderate, with forecasts of 1.6% for the current quarter and 2% for the full year. The People's Bank of China is expected to maintain its benchmark interest rate and reserve ratio unchanged this year.

site_title: South-east Asian leaders to avoid direct China criticism
summary: Southeast Asian leaders will express concern over China's activities in the South China Sea at the upcoming Asean summit, but avoid direct criticism of the country. The draft statement will mention "escalation of activities" in the sea without naming China, reflecting Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's efforts to ease tensions. The statement will also note "progress" on a framework agreement for a code of conduct on the South China Sea, which may be completed by June, but does not address the UN-backed tribunal's ruling that rejected China's claims to the sea.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian leaders will express concern this week about an "escalation of activities" in the South China Sea but avoid directly criticising China, according to the draft of a summit statement.

site_title: Australia, NZ stocks higher, tracking Wall Street surge
summary: Australian and New Zealand stocks rose on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index increasing 0.8% to a 5-year high. The Nasdaq Composite broke through the 6,000 level for the first time. Financials led gains, with all four "Big Banks" and insurers QBE Insurance and Suncorp Group up. Oil stocks also solidified gains, while mining majors BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose due to Chinese steel futures climbing nearly 2%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index hit a six-month high.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.980 points higher to 1767.780 on Wednesday, with 294.03 million lots traded worth RM117.88 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 239 to 85.

site_title: Singapore factory output surprises in March with 10.2% y-o-y rise
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 10.2% year-over-year in March, driven by a 37.7% increase in the electronics cluster, with semiconductors reporting a 54.6% jump. Precision engineering and chemicals also saw significant growth. In contrast, the transport engineering cluster declined 15.6%, while general manufacturing fell 5.1%. The data surpassed economists' expectations of a 0.5% monthly advance.

site_title: Mining giants race to fill board leadership gaps
summary: Mining giants BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Anglo American are racing to fill board leadership gaps amid growing investor doubts over their conventional diversified business operations and strategies for growth. The companies are under pressure to generate more cash for shareholders, with the chairmen's retirements creating urgency to find the right candidates. The task is particularly urgent for BHP Billiton and Anglo American due to the influence of major investors questioning their future direction.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up on Wall Street gains, foreign buying
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% to 9,846.66 on Wednesday, following a 1.3% gain the previous day, its largest surge in nearly three weeks. Foreign investors' net buying and an overnight Wall Street rally fueled optimism. The Taiwan dollar reached its highest level in over two-and-a-half years, strengthening to NT$30.018 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore economy expected to grow 2.4% as exports, factory output increase: report
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 2.4% in 2017, driven by export recovery and increased demand for exports. A report by ICAEW notes that business investment may start to recover, but growth could be hindered by further US interest rate hikes. Government spending is forecast to be mildly stimulatory, and the easing of housing restrictions may aid the struggling housing sector. Employment conditions are expected to improve, but household spending will remain subdued due to negative wealth effects and higher inflation.

site_title: Pro-independence activists arrested in Hong Kong
summary: Two Hong Kong independence activists, Baggio Leung and Yau Wai-ching, were arrested and charged with "illegal assembly" over chaos at the city's parliament in November. They had been barred from taking their seats as lawmakers after deliberately misreading their oaths of office. The arrests come amid growing concerns about Hong Kong's freedoms and the city's autonomy, with Beijing intervening to ensure they were not given the chance to retake their oaths. The pair's arrest is seen as a crackdown on pro-independence activists ahead of a visit by China's president Xi Jinping on July 1.

site_title: Hot stock: Aoxin Q&M opens 3 cents higher than IPO price in Wednesday's debut
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, a Chinese dental business spun off from Q&M, made its debut on Wednesday, opening 3 cents higher than its IPO price of 20 Singapore cents. As of 10:09am, the bid price was 23.5 cents and ask price 24 cents, with over 10.6 million shares traded. The company operates 11 dental centers in northern China, and its listing aims to enhance its public image locally and internationally, according to CEO Dr. Shao Yongxin.

site_title: McDonald's shelves plans to sell Japan unit stake after rebound
summary: McDonald's Corp has shelved plans to sell a stake in its Japan unit, which had seen a turnaround since the company initially announced its intention to sell more than a year ago. The decision comes after the Japan unit reported strong quarterly sales growth and forecasted net income for 2017. McDonald's CEO Kevin Ozan stated the company is confident in its capabilities to grow the business in Japan, citing a strong market momentum. The sale plans won't impact long-term financial targets or the company's goal of franchising 95% of its restaurants.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hover near 2-year highs on US optimism, euro steady
summary: Asian stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day, driven by renewed optimism about the US economy and its potential tax reform proposals. The euro remained steady, while safe-haven assets fell. Key gains were seen in Japan and Australia, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index rising 0.3%. The Nasdaq Composite hit a record high in the US, and the Dow and S&P 500 approached recent peaks. The euro is seen as a potential beneficiary of business-friendly French President Emmanuel Macron's election victory.

site_title: Islamic romance novels set hearts aflutter in Bangladesh
summary: Islamic romance novels written by Kasem bin Abubakar in the 1970s and 1980s are experiencing a resurgence in popularity in Bangladesh as the country shifts towards a more conservative interpretation of Islam. Abubakar's debut novel, "Futonto Golap" (Blossomed Rose), was initially met with skepticism but became a bestseller, inspiring a new generation of writers to create contemporary Islamic fiction. The genre has become a favorite among young women in rural Bangladesh, who see Abubakar's stories as a way to navigate the strict moral guidelines of their society.

site_title: Australia's annual core inflation nears central bank's target
summary: Australia's annual core inflation rose to 1.9% in the last quarter, just below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target of 2-3%. The decision to leave interest rates unchanged was made due to the subdued jobs market and low inflation. Governor Philip Lowe signaled a willingness to tolerate weaker inflation, warning that rapid returns to target could lead to interest rate cuts that would fuel house prices. The Aussie dollar strengthened to 75.28 US cents following the report, which also saw annual headline CPI rise to 2.1%.

site_title: Australia dollar weaker on underwhelming inflation, kiwi dragged lower
summary: The Australian dollar fell for a second consecutive session after underwhelming inflation figures, supporting a benign interest rate outlook. The Aussie dropped to US$0.7517, while the New Zealand dollar hit a two-week low of US$0.6932 due to a distaste for commodity currencies and concerns over free trade. Investors expect no rate cuts from the Reserve Bank of Australia in coming months, and commodity currencies, including the kiwi, are underperforming.

site_title: Free rides offered by Alphabet's Waymo autonomous cars
summary: Waymo, the self-driving car unit of Alphabet, is offering free rides to residents in Phoenix, Arizona, as part of its "early rider" program. The program, which accepts hundreds of participants, aims to gather feedback on the company's autonomous vehicles. Waymo plans to add 500 hybrid minivans to its Arizona fleet, bringing its total to 600 vehicles. The goal is to test the technology and bring self-driving cars to more communities, with the ultimate aim of a ridesharing system similar to Uber and Lyft.

site_title: US missile defence equipment reaches South Korea site
summary: US missile defense equipment began being deployed to a site in South Korea on Wednesday, amid heightened tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions. The Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) system has infuriated China, which fears it will weaken its own ballistic capabilities and upset regional security balance. The deployment is part of a US-South Korea agreement to guard against missile threats from North Korea, despite Beijing's economic retaliation, including a ban on tour groups and shutting down 85 of Lotte's stores in China.

images.alt_text: US troops began delivering a missile defence system that has infuriated China to a deployment site in South Korea on Wednesday, amid heightened tensions over the North's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: Citic Envirotech Q1 profit surges 41.2% to S$17m
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a 41.2% surge in Q1 profit to S$17 million, driven by a 14.3% increase in revenue to S$113.7 million. The company attributed the growth to its engineering business. However, earnings per share declined 38.5% due to a decrease in membrane sales. The company's net asset value per share remained at 65.82 Singapore cents, while its recurring water treatment business showed an increase in revenue.

images.alt_text: The membrane-based water treatment solutions provider also saw revenue jumping 14.3 per cent to S$113.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2017, due to an increase in its engineering business.

site_title: Hong Kong: Equities open on Wednesday with gains
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.44% to 24,563.25, following a global advance that began with France's first-round election result. Investors are watching the expected unveiling of Donald Trump's tax reform plan. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.05% and 0.08% respectively.

site_title: Singapore takes top spot again as world's maritime capital: report
summary: Singapore has retained its top spot as the world's maritime capital for the third consecutive time, according to the Menon's Leading Maritime Capitals of the World Report. The city-state ranked first in shipping, ports and logistics, and attractiveness and competitiveness. It came in second place in maritime technology and fourth in finance and law. Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority chief executive, Andrew Tan, expressed gratitude and vowed to work harder to make Singapore a global maritime hub of choice.

site_title: Gold slips to two-week low on improved risk appetite; equities rally
summary: Gold prices fell to a two-week low on Wednesday, dropping 0.9% to US$1,263.55, amid rising investor appetite for riskier assets. The decline was driven by renewed optimism over the US economy and decreasing political uncertainty in France. This marks the largest one-day decline since March 2.

site_title: LG Display books record quarterly profit on demand for large TV panels
summary: LG Display Co Ltd posted a record quarterly profit of 1.03 trillion won (S$1.3 billion) in the January-March period, beating market expectations. The company's profit was boosted by rising prices of large-size TV panels and a product mix focused on ultra high-definition TVs. Revenue jumped 17.9% from a year earlier, and panel prices are expected to remain flat in the second quarter. However, some analysts are skeptical about LG's prospects due to concerns that high prices may erode margins and lead to reduced panel orders from TV makers.

site_title: China launches first domestically built aircraft carrier: media
summary: China has successfully launched its first domestically designed and built aircraft carrier in the northeastern port of Dalian. The ship, which displaces 50,000 tonnes, will use conventional propulsion and carry indigenous J-15 aircraft. The launch marks a significant step in China's efforts to build a blue water navy capable of projecting power. The new carrier will take about two years to be fully equipped and will not make its first real tests until then, making the launch a symbolic event.

images.alt_text: China has launched its first domestically designed and built aircraft carrier, state media said Wednesday, as the country seeks to transform its navy into a force capable of projecting power onto the high seas.

site_title: IPOS, Makara Capital launch S$1b fund to drive innovation
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) and private equity firm Makara Capital have launched a $1 billion fund, the Makara Innovation Fund (MIF), to support high-growth companies in Singapore. The fund targets companies with strong IP and proven business models, aiming to drive innovation and economic growth. This initiative is part of the updated IP Hub Master Plan to support the Committee on the Future Economy's Report, which identified IP as a key driver of economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.63% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.63% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 19.9 points to 3,163.93, driven by an earnings-fuelled rally in Asian markets. The top gainers were AEM, City Developments, and DBS, while UOB Bank, Keppel Corp, and SGX were among the top losers. The rally followed a strong performance in US indices, including the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching 6,000 for the first time on record.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Suntec Reit, CDL Hospitality Trusts
summary: CapitaLand Limited reported a 77.2% increase in net profit to S$386.8 million for the first quarter, driven by the sale of units and higher portfolio gains. Suntec Reit recorded a 2.3% increase in distribution per unit to 2.425 Singapore cents, while CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 9% increase in distribution per stapled security to 2.42 Singapore cents, driven by a 10% year-on-year rise in total distribution. These results may influence trading on Wednesday.

site_title: Hot stock: CRT soars on potential interest
summary: CROESUS Retail Trust (CRT) unit price surged 4.26% to S$0.98 on Wednesday after its manager, Croesus Retail Asset Management, announced a potential buyer had approached the trust. Discussions are preliminary, and no certainty exists for a transaction. Citigroup Global Markets Singapore has been appointed as the trust's financial adviser.

site_title: Lotte looks to move past family feud with restructuring plan
summary: Lotte Group, a South Korean conglomerate, is set to restructure four businesses valued at around $12 billion to tighten chairman Shin Dong-bin's control and address family disputes. The move aims to separate investment assets and operating companies, making it harder for his elder brother to gain control. The reorganisation also seeks to unravel cross-shareholdings and strengthen the chairman's grip on the group. Despite challenges, including corruption charges and economic retaliation in China, investors appear to be sticking with Lotte, with shares rising 15% over the past two weeks.

site_title: US Thaad missile defence equipment enters South Korea site: Yonhap
summary: US Thaad missile defense equipment arrived at a South Korean site on April 25, 2017, amid high tensions over North Korea's ballistic missile program. The Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system is meant to intercept and destroy short and medium-range ballistic missiles. The deployment is part of a US-South Korea agreement, but China opposes it, fearing it will undermine its military capabilities. The move comes as North Korea prepares for a possible sixth nuclear test, and US President Donald Trump has indicated a willingness to increase military pressure on the regime.

site_title: CapitaLand Q1 profit surges 77.2% to S$386.8m
summary: CapitaLand Limited reported a 77.2% surge in Q1 net profit to S$386.8 million, driven by improved operating performance and higher portfolio gains. Revenue rose 0.4% to S$897.5 million, boosted by handovers from development projects in China and rental contributions from newly acquired properties. The increase was offset by lower revenue from development projects in Singapore.

site_title: Cashless society getting closer, survey finds
summary: A survey conducted by Ipsos for the ING bank website eZonomics found that 34% of Europeans and 38% of Americans would be willing to go without cash and rely on electronic forms of payment. In Europe, 21% of respondents already rarely use cash, while 78% expect to use it less in the coming 12 months. Countries where cash is most used, such as Germany, showed a strong desire to adopt a cashless society, with 10% of Germans rarely using cash. This trend is attributed to the increasing use of contactless cards and mobile-phone digital wallets.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q1 DPU climbs 2.3%
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 2.3% increase in its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.425 Singapore cents, driven by a 12.9% rise in gross revenue to S$88.4 million. The revenue growth was mainly attributed to the rental contribution of its Sydney asset, 177 Pacific Highway. Earnings per unit also rose to 1.805 Singapore cents, up from 1.282 in the preceding year.

site_title: 8 Capital gets MAS nod to operate new asset management business in Singapore
summary: 8 Capital, a subsidiary of 8I Holdings, has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to operate as a Registered Fund Management Company (RFMC) and start its new asset management business. The company aims to raise up to S$25 million to manage up to S$250 million in assets under management for up to 30 qualified investors. This approval marks the integration of 8 Capital's investing ecosystem with its existing asset management activities.

site_title: Rotary Engineering bags S$140m contract to build new tank terminal in Singapore
summary: Rotary Engineering has secured a S$140 million contract from Jurong Port Tank Terminals to build a new tank terminal in Singapore. The 16-hectare terminal will store clean petroleum products, feature pump stations, and be connected to the Jurong Island petrochemical hub via pipelines. Construction is expected to begin soon, with the project's completion date yet to be announced.

site_title: Oil settles slightly higher, API reports surprise build
summary: Oil prices settled slightly higher on Tuesday, reversing a six-session decline, after the American Petroleum Institute reported a surprise build in US crude inventories. US crude futures rose 33 cents to $49.56 a barrel, while Brent crude rose 50 cents to $52.10 a barrel. The API also reported a 4.4 million-barrel increase in gasoline inventories, contrary to expectations of a 1 million-barrel decline. Analysts attributed the build to reduced demand and potential production increases by Russia and other countries.

images.alt_text: Oil prices settled slightly higher on Tuesday in volatile trading, then were mixed after hours when an industry group's preliminary report showed a surprise build in US crude inventories.

site_title: Uber sets 'flying car' launch for 2020
summary: Uber plans to launch a flying car system called Uber Elevate, aiming to put demonstration projects in place by 2020. The company has partnered with Bell Helicopter, Embraer, and Pipistrel to produce flying machines for short-distance urban operations. Uber's goal is to have the first demonstration network in Dubai for the 2020 World Expo and another pilot in Dallas the same year, with full-scale operations in the Texas region by 2023. The system will include "vertiports" for takeoff and landing and electric-powered changing stations.

site_title: Asean-Japan relations - past and present
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article about Asean-Japan relations:

The 50th anniversary of Asean's establishment marks a milestone in the partnership between Asean and Japan. Japan is Asean's oldest partner, and their relationship has deepened over the years through economic, cultural, and people-to-people exchanges. The two regions have collaborated on infrastructure development, trade, and security, with Japan supporting Asean's stability and prosperity. The Japan-Asean relationship has expanded beyond inter-governmental affairs to include business, culture, and personal relations, with a growing potential for a "Singapore-Japan Global Business Partnership". Japan will continue to support Asean's development and strengthen their partnership in the years to come.

site_title: Hyundai caught in perfect storm in China
summary: Hyundai Motor Co is facing a crisis in China, its largest market, due to a perfect storm of factors. Sales have plummeted, with combined sales of Hyundai and Kia dropping by half in March, and a significant number of employees have quit. The issues stem from a sedan-heavy line-up, poor brand perception, and a nationalist backlash against South Korea's decision to host the US missile defense system Thaad. Chinese consumers are turning away from Hyundai's offerings, and the company's efforts to spruce up its brand have been ineffective in addressing the shift in consumer preference towards SUVs.

site_title: Trump tax plan will sharply slash corporate tax rates
summary: US President Donald Trump will propose a tax plan that slashes corporate income tax rates to 15% from 35%, and reduces the tax rate on overseas profits to 10%. The plan also includes a cut in the top tax rate on pass-through businesses to 15% from 39.6%. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin claims the plan will pay for itself through economic growth. The plan falls short of comprehensive tax reform discussed by Republicans, but will serve as a guide for lawmakers in the US House of Representatives and Senate.

site_title: Eager for 100-day wins, Trump eyes govt funding, border, taxes
summary: US President Donald Trump is seeking key victories in his first 100 days as president, focusing on border security, tax reform, and averting a government shutdown. With funding for the government set to expire, Trump agreed to soften his demand for wall funding along the US-Mexico border, potentially delaying construction until September. Lawmakers are exploring alternative security measures, including drones and technology. Trump also plans to unveil tax reform, with some Republicans expressing concerns about deep cuts in corporate tax rates.

site_title: CDLHT reports 9% rise in Q1 distribution per stapled security
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 9% increase in Q1 distribution per stapled security to 2.42 Singapore cents, up from 2.22 cents last year. Total distribution rose 10% year-on-year to S$24.1 million, driven by a 6.4% jump in net property income to S$35.9 million, largely due to strong growth from its New Zealand hotel.

site_title: Google tweak aims to curb fake, misleading search results
summary: Google has announced changes to its search algorithm to curb fake, misleading, and offensive content. The new initiative includes tweaks to the algorithm to deliver more authoritative pages and demote low-quality content. Users can also flag inappropriate "autocomplete" suggestions and "snippets" of websites. Google aims to crack down on "fake news" and "game the system" with real people assessing search results quality. The effort is part of an ongoing process to provide users with relevant information from reliable sources.

images.alt_text: Google on Tuesday announced changes to how it delivers and ranks internet searches, the latest effort by the tech giant to weed out "fake news" and offensive content.

site_title: US judge blocks Trump financial pressure on sanctuary cities
summary: A US judge blocked President Donald Trump's attempt to deny billions of dollars in federal funds to "sanctuary cities" that protect illegal immigrants. Judge William Orrick ruled that Trump's order was unconstitutional, citing the Constitution's spending powers vested in Congress, not the president. The ruling allowed the Department of Justice to proceed with threats to cut specific program grants to nine cities that did not adequately cooperate with federal immigration officers. The decision maintained tensions between the federal government and hundreds of cities over the Trump crackdown.

site_title: Disney sets summer 2019 release for 'Star Wars IX'
summary: Disney has set the summer 2019 release date for "Star Wars: Episode IX" and delayed the next "Indiana Jones" film by a year. The ninth installment will be written by Colin Trevorrow and Derek Connolly, with returning cast members John Boyega, Daisy Ridley, Adam Driver, and Oscar Isaac expected to reprise their roles. The film will not feature the late Carrie Fisher as Leia, marking a return to summer releases for the franchise, which had experimented with mid-December openings.

site_title: US misunderstands Nafta, North American business body says
summary: The US government's misunderstanding of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) has sparked concerns among Canadian-American business leaders. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross claimed Nafta wasn't functioning properly due to Canadian subsidies and trade barriers, but a business council representing major corporations such as Coca-Cola and Ford disputed this, stating that neither dairy nor lumber are covered under the agreement. The Canadian government denies involvement in a dispute over dairy exports and US tariffs on Canadian softwood lumber have been announced, fueling tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Hotel industry using tech tools to draw guests
summary: Hotels are increasingly using technology tools to enhance the guest experience, with 57% planning to spend more on technology in 2017. Hotel occupancy rates in the US are at 65.5%, the highest since 1984. Tech tools allow guests to order food, call for services, and access activities on their own, improving satisfaction and reducing negative reviews. Hotels are spending 6% of revenue on technology, aiming to differentiate their brands, gain repeat customers, and increase revenue.

site_title: Insurance firms provide new cover in uncertain times
summary: Insurance firms are increasing coverage for multinational companies amid rising protectionism and geopolitical uncertainty. Companies are buying insurance to protect against business disruption, flouted deals, and unrest in emerging markets due to events such as the US presidential election, Brexit, and the French presidential election. Zurich Insurance reported a 14% increase in new business in 2016, driven by demand for cover against government or state-owned entity default. Insurers are seeing a growing demand for political risk and violence insurance, with companies paying up to $750,000 for coverage against expropriation, political violence, and currency risks in multiple countries.

site_title: Missing link in the diversity debate
summary: Singapore's corporate boards are under pressure to improve gender diversity, with calls to introduce gender quotas or targets. However, research on the impact of diversity on financial performance is ambiguous, with some studies finding no link and others suggesting a positive effect. Effective engagement with diversity is key to capturing its benefits, and boards must go beyond numerical diversity to make better, more creative decisions. To achieve this, companies should focus on initiatives such as better selection processes for directors, progressive refreshing and renewal of boards, and director training that promotes engagement with diversity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on sustained global rallies
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on April 26, 2017, driven by global rallies and robust US corporate earnings. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.55% and the Topix index gained 0.61% as investors lifted sentiment. The US corporate earnings boost, particularly on Wall Street, contributed to the positive market trend.

site_title: US: Nasdaq tops 6,000 as earnings boost Wall St; US tax code eyed
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching 6,036.02, its first time breaching 6,000. Strong earnings from companies like Caterpillar and McDonald's, with 11.4% profit growth in the first quarter, drove the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.12% and the S&P 500 gained 0.61%. The tax code is expected to be revised, with a potential cut in corporate tax rates, which could boost investing.

site_title: Local ship owner eyes expansion
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL), a Singapore-based shipping company, has been awarded the SRS Ship Owner of the Year Award. As the company celebrates its 50th anniversary, it plans to expand its business by taking delivery of 12 new ships from October. The new vessels will be ultra-modern, fuel-efficient, and 11,800 TEU, making them the largest PIL-operated vessels. PIL aims to leverage the new ships to improve cost competitiveness and deepen service cooperation with partners in key target markets.

site_title: US dollar surges against loonie on tariff announcement, euro gains
summary: The US dollar surged against the Canadian dollar (loonie) after the US imposed duties on Canadian softwood, reaching a 5-year high of C$1.3626. The euro also rose to a 5.5-month high against the US dollar following Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election. The euro is expected to continue its upward trend as the European Central Bank considers reducing monetary stimulus. The US dollar index was last down 0.3% at 98.844, while the yen reached a 15-day high of 111.18.

site_title: Denmark ready to end all subsidies for renewable energy sector
summary: Denmark's renewable energy industry is poised to become self-sufficient in a few years, thanks to advancements in technology and decreasing costs. Danish Energy Minister Lars Christian Lilleholt stated that renewable energy will no longer require state subsidies, a development that contradicts US President Donald Trump's stance on wind power. The country aims to cover all its energy needs with renewables by 2050, with half of that goal achieved by 2030, and most new capacity to be built without subsidies. This shift highlights the growing competitiveness of renewable energy.

site_title: Scientists urge more Antarctic protections
summary: Scientists are urging the world to protect the Antarctic wilderness and its wildlife, citing the decline of 2/3 of the world's 18 penguin species. Climate change, intense fishing pressure, and pollution are major threats to penguin populations, with only 2 types increasing in numbers. A new marine protected area will be established in the Ross Sea, but two other proposals are still under negotiation. Experts believe a network of marine protected areas could help ensure penguin survival in an uncertain future.

site_title: CDL trumps eight other bidders for Tampines residential site with S$370m bid
summary: CDL emerged as the top bidder for a Tampines residential site with a S$370.1 million offer, translating to S$565.4 per square foot per plot ratio. This bid surpasses the second-highest offer by 5.7%. The sale price signals that land prices have returned to 2013 levels, according to consultants.

site_title: DBS Marina Regatta returns on June 1-4
summary: DBS Marina Regatta returns to the Marina Bay area in Singapore from June 1-4, featuring the international dragon boat competition, a special category for those aged 40 and above, and various activities such as sailing, obstacle courses, and fitness classes. The event will also showcase interactive art installations and a lively pop-up urban beach with food and entertainment options. With a prize purse of S$134,000, the regatta is expected to attract thousands of people, with DBS Bank partnering with social enterprises to champion the development of Singapore's social entrepreneurship sector.

site_title: China wants one-fifth of car sales to be NEVs
summary: China aims to reach 35 million vehicle sales by 2025, with new energy vehicles (NEVs) making up at least one-fifth of that total. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) targets 2 million NEV sales by 2020 and 20% of total vehicle production and sales by 2025. China's urbanization drive and overseas carmaker expansion are expected to drive annual vehicle sales up 25% from last year. The government will also loosen rules on foreign joint ventures and create local champions to compete with overseas rivals.

site_title: Steadfast commitment
summary: Swire Pacific Offshore Operations (SPO) won the Excellence in Manpower Training and Development Award for its strong commitment to training and developing its people. Despite industry challenges, the company remains steadfast in its investment in its seafarers and shore-based employees. SPO offers scholarships to encourage youth to pursue maritime careers and partners with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore to raise awareness about the offshore industry. Its training centre, Swire Marine Training Centre, provides ongoing professional training in five core areas, with 739 seafarers trained in 2016.

site_title: Singapore tax regime ranks high in predictability, consistency: Deloitte
summary: Singapore's tax regime ranks high in predictability and consistency, according to Deloitte's Asia-Pacific Tax Complexity Survey. Over 87% of respondents said Singapore had an intermediate to very high level of predictability, and 91% indicated it was consistent or very consistent in enforcing tax laws. In contrast, India, China, and Indonesia are becoming less predictable due to economic reforms and BEPS initiatives. Singapore's simplicity in tax compliance and reporting obligations also ranked high, with Hong Kong and Singapore being viewed as having the simplest requirements.

site_title: PEs with deep pockets may be last resort for shipping sector
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta suggests that private equity firms with deep pockets may be the last resort for the shipping sector, which is facing difficulties in accessing bank financing and public equity markets. The sector is struggling with vast overcapacity and a decline in long-term contracts, with charterers opting for shorter-term charters instead. Gupta notes that bank financing for newbuild shipping assets is constrained, and public equity has been challenging to raise.

site_title: US should stay in Paris climate accord: energy secretary
summary: US Energy Secretary Rick Perry suggests the US should remain in the Paris climate accord but renegotiate it, citing concerns over European countries' emission reductions. Perry made the comments ahead of a decision by President Donald Trump on the US's participation in the 2015 agreement. The US is one of 194 countries that signed the accord to limit global carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: The United States should stay in the Paris climate accord but renegotiate it, energy secretary Rick Perry said on Tuesday, alleging that some European countries were not doing enough to curb emissions.

site_title: Malaysian developer Yong Tai aims to impress Chinese in Melaka
summary: Malaysian property developer Yong Tai Bhd is poised to capitalize on the booming Chinese tourist inflow into Malaysia, thanks to its exclusive franchise rights to Impression Melaka, a large-scale live cultural music performance venue. The township, expected to benefit from the venue, is expected to generate RM50 million annually from ticket sales. Analysts believe Yong Tai is undervalued, with a 35% upside potential, and could deliver an exponential earnings per share growth rate of 57% over FY16-19F.

site_title: Donald Trump picks trade fight with Canada
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked trade tensions with Canada, accusing the country of being "very rough" on the US and threatening to retaliate against new restrictions on US dairy products. The Commerce Department has imposed tariffs of up to 24% on Canadian softwood lumber, which Canada says is unfairly punitive. The dispute is the latest in a long-standing trade conflict between the two countries, with the US seeking to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has vowed to defend Canada's interests, while US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross says the tariffs are necessary to correct what he calls an effective block on US dairy exports.

site_title: Parallel imports flat despite expanding COE quota
summary: The parallel import (PI) industry in Singapore has slowed down, with a 0.9% decline in registrations in the first three months of 2017. This marks the first decline since 2013, and is attributed to authorized distributors bringing in official versions of popular PI models, such as the Toyota Vellfire MPV. The price gap between PIs and official imports has also narrowed, contributing to lower demand. The Honda Vezel remains a top seller, but its year-to-date sales are down 19% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Why Tokyo is moving to revive TPP even without the US
summary: Japan is moving to revive the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) without the US, with Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso announcing talks on an 11-member TPP at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in May. The move signals that other countries are pressing ahead with free trade despite US withdrawal, with Japan seeking to maintain economic gains in medium-sized markets like Australia and Vietnam. A revived TPP could also limit China's dominance in regional economic relations. However, reviving the pact will require a new draft and navigating technical and legal aspects of trade agreements.

site_title: Property prices inflecting, on track to double by 2030
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to inflect in 2018, driven by an improving macroeconomic outlook, with home prices projected to double by 2030. Despite 14 consecutive quarters of decline, the market is expected to rebound due to factors such as a slowing global economy, easing property curbs, and improving supply-demand dynamics. A combination of demand and supply factors, including rising household formation rates and income growth, will support medium-term home price appreciation, contradicting bearish predictions that slower population growth and a structural growth slowdown will weigh on the market.

site_title: SPH buys nursing home provider Orange Valley for S$164m
summary: SPH buys nursing home provider Orange Valley Healthcare for S$164 million, marking the media and property group's entry into the healthcare business. The deal is free of debt and acquired from private equity firm KV Asia Capital. This acquisition is seen as the first step towards building a larger healthcare business for SPH.

site_title: Slower economy, high prices boost demand for old cars
summary: In Singapore, the sluggish economy and high new car prices have driven demand for older and less expensive cars, leading to a surge in revalidations of car certificates of entitlement (COEs). Last year, a record 44,303 COEs were revalidated, a 70.1% spike from 2015. This trend is expected to stabilize COE supply in the long term, as revalidated cars will become available for deregistration and potentially boost COE quotas in future years.

site_title: Europe: Shares firm as earnings, M&A back in play
summary: European stocks rose for the fifth straight session, driven by earnings and mergers and acquisitions. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.2% and is up 7.1% for the year. Investors are taking heart from the improved economic outlook and favorable political landscape, with net flows into European mutual funds reaching $100 billion. Earnings reports from chipmaker AMS and Volvo boosted shares, while a buyout deal at Christian Dior fueled a 11% surge.

site_title: Credit-search data points to rise in trade between Singapore and East Asia
summary: Singapore companies are increasing trade with East Asia, with credit searches on East Asian companies rising to 26.7% in 2016, up from 20.6% in 2015. Merchandise trade with Hong Kong and Japan rose 4.3% and 4.5% year-over-year, respectively. The Asean region remains Singapore's single largest trading bloc, but its proportion of overseas credit searches decreased to 27.2% from 36.5% in 2015. Weakening global trade also led to a decline in foreign credit searches by Singapore companies, with overseas searches falling by 1.2% in 2016.

site_title: Trump, Australia's Turnbull to bury the hatchet in New York meeting
summary: US President Donald Trump will meet Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull in New York on May 4, marking a reboot of their relationship after a rocky start following Trump's inauguration. This will be their first encounter since a contentious phone call in January. The meeting will take place at the USS Intrepid museum, where Trump will commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea during World War II. The encounter aims to mend the alliance between the two nations, which had been strained following their initial phone call.

site_title: Consumer confidence falls; new home sales up
summary: US consumer confidence fell from a 16-year high in April, likely due to the failed attempt by Republicans to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Despite this, new home sales surged to an 8-month high, indicating underlying economic strength. House prices also saw the largest year-on-year increase in 2.5 years in February. These data suggest the economy's fundamentals remain healthy, despite a slowdown in growth in the first quarter.

site_title: Succession and board renewal at S'pore banks
summary: DBS Group has three women on its nine-member executive committee, with Jeanette Wong, Tan Su Shan, and Chng Sok Hui holding key positions. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, has stated that a woman could be his successor, and all powerful functions are run by women. Meanwhile, United Overseas Bank (UOB) is expanding its board size by a third to 12 members, a move considered unprecedented, while OCBC Bank has no plans for board expansion. The move aims to bring in fresh perspectives and expertise, particularly from the tech industry.

site_title: Dollar recovers slightly against yen
summary: The US dollar recovered slightly against the yen, rising 0.7% on Tuesday following the French presidential election result, which met investor expectations. In contrast, the Canadian dollar plummeted to four-month lows after the US imposed duties on Canadian softwood lumber.

site_title: Turkish Airlines looking to update its agreement with SIA
summary: Turkish Airlines' new CEO, Bilal Eksi, plans to refresh its agreement with Singapore Airlines, aiming to boost its collaboration and increase flights to Istanbul. The two carriers last expanded their codeshare agreement in 2014, but SIA reduced frequency to Istanbul last year. Eksi said Turkish Airlines is open to increasing flights and capacity, including on the Istanbul-Singapore route, which currently operates once a day. The airline expects to carry 67 million passengers this year, a 3% increase from 2016, and is budgeting for a fleet size of 334 aircraft.
