site_title: Red tape cut for shipping, e-commerce and logistics sectors with 2 online portals
summary: Singapore government launches two initiatives, the Maritime Single Window (MSW) and National Trade Platform (NTP), to reduce red tape and boost information flows in the shipping, e-commerce, and logistics sectors, aiming to support world trade flows through digital transformation.

site_title: Nasdaq past 6,000 mark for first time
summary: The Nasdaq index reached a record level of 6,007.72 on April 25, 2017, surpassing the 6,000 mark for the first time. The surge was driven by strong corporate earnings and President Donald Trump's promise of a major tax reform plan. Key contributors included gains in Biogen and Apple, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq rising 0.4% at its peak.

site_title: Yokohama to be host city for 50th ADB annual meet
summary: Yokohama, Japan will host the 50th Asian Development Bank (ADB) annual meeting from May 4 to May 7, with a focus on "Building together the prosperity of Asia". The event will bring over 3,000 delegates, including finance ministers and private-sector representatives. This marks the third time Yokohama has hosted a major international conference, following Apec Japan 2010. The city has been recognized for its efforts in sustainable urban development and international cooperation.

site_title: Divestment gain lifts Parkway Life Reit's Q1 DPU by 9.6%
summary: Parkway Life Reit's Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) rose 9.6% to 3.28 Singapore cents, driven by a one-off divestment gain of S$5.39 million. The trust acquired five Japan properties with a yield of 6.9% in February 2017, contributing to a 0.2% increase in gross revenue. Net property income remained steady, while the gearing ratio stood at 37.6%. The trust's weighted average lease term to expiry improved to 9.81 years, and its shares closed at S$2.60, up 7 cents or 2.767%.

site_title: Steelmakers around the world ramp up capital expenditure
summary: Steelmakers worldwide are increasing capital expenditure, with top producers ArcelorMittal, Posco, and Novolipetsk Steel PJSC planning a 29% increase to $6.7 billion in 2017, the first rise since 2014. Companies are investing in expansions and new technologies, driven by recovering prices and demand, although a global capacity surplus remains. China's plans to close unprofitable mills and US/European import restrictions are expected to improve prospects for domestic producers. Despite this, the recovery could be bumpy, with iron ore prices dropping and global demand growth expected to be slow but positive over the next decade.

site_title: Ho Bee's Q1 profit trebles on Shanghai project
summary: Ho Bee Land's net earnings tripled to S$56.32 million in the first quarter, driven by a strong contribution from its Shanghai condo project and a S$7.4 million gain from the sale of Rose Court in London. Revenue rose 13.9% year-over-year to S$42.38 million. The company expects sustainable recurring income from its portfolio of investment properties and development profits from residential projects in China and Australia.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia eye industrial parks, cruise tourism, energy sector
summary: Singapore and Indonesia aim to develop cruise tourism, industrial parks, and energy cooperation as part of their bilateral plans. Following a November meeting, Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran discussed potential collaboration, including creating more interesting itineraries for cruise companies and developing industrial parks to attract investors. Energy cooperation also offers opportunities, particularly in improving energy accessibility and renewable energy projects. The two countries plan to enhance business connections and networking among businesses through a business council.

site_title: Sharp drop in cocoa prices hits producers
summary: Cocoa prices have dropped by roughly a third since last year, hitting farmers and government coffers hard. The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) urges producers to coordinate production strategies to boost prices. The ICCO's chairman, Luis Valverde, stated that a price crisis is underway and that decisions must be made collectively. The drop in prices has dealt a major blow to West African economies, with Ghana losing nearly US$1 billion in export revenues and Ivory Coast slashing budget spending by 10%.

images.alt_text: Abundant rain mixed with sunny spells last week in most of Ivory Coast's main cocoa-growing regions boosted prospects for the upcoming main crop in the world's top producer, farmers said on Monday.

site_title: N-E Asia on high alert for further N Korean threats
summary: Tensions escalated in Northeast Asia as a US nuclear-powered submarine docked in South Korea's Busan port ahead of a strike group's arrival, amid heightened diplomatic activity involving the US, Japan, China, and South Korea. North Korea conducted a massive live-fire drill to mark the 85th anniversary of its military, while threatening to "sink" the US Carl Vinson aircraft carrier. Senior envoys met in Tokyo to discuss North Korea's refusal to abandon its nuclear program, with the US calling for tougher UN sanctions.

images.alt_text: The movements at sea came amid an intense flurry of diplomatic activity involving the US, Japan, China and South Korea and designed to prepare for a possible further missile launch by North Korea to coincide with the 85th anniversary of the founding of the Korean People's Army

site_title: ADB steps up lending operations to help meet massive infrastructure challenge
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) reported a record lending operation of $31.7 billion in 2016, exceeding $30 billion for the first time in its 50-year history. The bank aims to support infrastructure development in the Asia-Pacific region, which requires $1.5 trillion annually to sustain economic growth and reduce poverty. The ADB's private sector operations reached $2.5 billion, with $5.8 billion in co-financing, as governments and private sectors are expected to contribute to infrastructure development. The bank's president, Takehiko Nakao, emphasized the need to address pressing challenges such as climate change and poverty.

site_title: In a class of its own
summary: The American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) has received the Offshore and Marine Engineering Award at this year's International Maritime Awards. As a class society, ABS sets standards for safety and provides guidance for companies to navigate environmental and operational challenges. Established with a focus on offshore and strong collaborations, ABS has a Singapore Innovation and Research Centre (SIRC) that undertakes joint development projects with research institutions and other classification societies. This award recognizes ABS's contributions to Singapore's development and growth in the offshore and marine industries.

site_title: Enhancing trade flows for mutual gain
summary: Japanese investments in Asean are expected to boost following the formation of the Asean Economic Community, which will create a new market with cheaper supply and distribution networks. The AEC will integrate a population of 600 million, making it the third-largest market in Asia, and production bases in Asean can be used to manufacture products for export to developing nations outside the region. Japanese companies are making further investments in infrastructure and product supply chains in cooperation with local companies and governments, with a focus on logistics, transportation, and digital innovation.

site_title: Musicians in aquariums make sounds in a silent world
summary: A Danish band, Between Music, has created an underwater concerto in an aquarium, producing music that resembles whale sounds. The five-member band plays specially adapted instruments, such as a violin and crystallophone, while submerged in glass-paned water tanks. Hydrophones amplify the soundwaves, resulting in a unique timbre. The performance, called AquaSonic, is a collaboration between musicians, engineers, and makers of musical instruments. The band is touring Denmark and will perform at the International Diaghilev Festival in Russia.

site_title: Dawn of new political eras in US and France?
summary: A historic presidential election in France is pitting two candidates against each other, one a radical nationalist and the other an internationalist and free trader. Emmanuel Macron, a former investment banker and economics minister, is leading a new political movement and has been labeled a "centrist." Marine Le Pen, the leader of the National Front, has been referred to as a "far-right" figure due to her anti-globalization stance and calls for restrictions on immigration. The election has raised questions about the relevance of traditional left-right labels, with some suggesting that the old struggle between conservatives and liberals is being replaced by a conflict between nationalists and globalists.

site_title: Veteran's many contributions to shipping
summary: Veteran shipping executive Patrick Phoon has been conferred the International Maritime Centre Award in the individual category. With a four-decade career in the shipping industry, Phoon is the deputy managing director of Evergreen Shipping Agency (Singapore) Pte Ltd. He attributes his achievements to teamwork and shared success, rather than individual contributions. Phoon has been instrumental in elevating Maritime Singapore's prominence, and his company has contributed to the development of the city-state as an International Maritime Centre.

site_title: Brexit could imperil UK's lead in AI
summary: A study by The Royal Society warns that the UK's exit from the EU could jeopardize its lead in machine learning technologies, citing a substantial skill shortage in the field. British researchers have played a crucial role in advances in machine learning, but the country faces a shortage of experts, which could exacerbate the issue. The report recommends increased government funding for education and incorporating machine learning into school curricula to address the skills gap and mitigate potential negative consequences, such as increased inequality.

site_title: Possible central bank mistake a worry, says UBP
summary: UBP's Nicolas Faller warns that the biggest risk in markets is a central bank mistake, rather than political risk. Despite this, the firm is overweight on equities, expecting economic growth and optimism about market-friendly Macron's election in France. Markets have rallied in response, with the euro hitting a five-month high. UBP is also positive on emerging markets, particularly China, where valuation is cheaper and investment opportunities abound. The firm is also optimistic about private debt, which offers opportunities in middle market lending and real estate.

site_title: SME raises the bar for bunkering
summary: Sinanju Tankers, a Singapore-based SME, has received the Bunker Award for its contributions to transforming global bunkering procedures. The company, founded 25 years ago, has been a pioneer in adopting new technology, including mass flow meters, to enhance efficiency and safety in bunkering operations. Sinanju has also been actively involved in the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's efforts to implement LNG bunkering and is currently exploring new projects to further adopt technology in bunkering. The company's commitment to service excellence and quality has earned it recognition and accolades, with its managing director expressing gratitude for the award and plans to continue pushing for higher standards in the industry.

site_title: Sailing towards greener shipping
summary: Asiatic Lloyd Maritime LLP has won the Green Ship of the Year Award for its eco-friendly vessel, UASC ZAMZAM (Asiatic Summer), which achieved the highest energy efficiency in the industry. The ship features advanced technologies, including optimised hull form, anti-fouling paint, and a ballast water treatment system, allowing for better fuel consumption and reduced environmental impact. The company's efforts to improve energy efficiency and sustainability in shipping have earned it recognition, with the company's partner stating that winning the award is a significant step towards developing a competitive edge in the industry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lippo Group's takeover bid for Healthway Medical Corp now stands at 47.55% stake, after buying 785,000 shares and converting convertible notes into new shares. The deadline for the offer has been extended to May 12, 2017. Lippo's takeover bid will be unconditional if its shareholding crosses 50%.

site_title: Heinrich Jessen bags Businessman of the Year award
summary: Heinrich Jessen, chairman of Jebsen & Jessen (SEA), was named Businessman of the Year at the 32nd Singapore Business Awards. The company, which employs over 4,000 people, has become a regional powerhouse with seven core business units and is one of the first carbon-neutral industrial companies in Asia. Jessen attributed Singapore's business-friendly environment to its government, legal system, and youthful enthusiasm, saying it remains unchanged since his father started the company in 1963.

site_title: Japan's ruling party heavyweight to attend China's New Silk Road summit
summary: Japan's ruling party secretary-general Toshihiro Nikai will attend China's New Silk Road summit on May 14-15, amid efforts to improve ties with Beijing. This move comes as tensions rise over North Korea's missile and nuclear programs. Nikai's attendance is seen as a sign of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's desire to strengthen relations with China. However, Japan remains cautious about the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), created by China. Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Hiroshige Seko is also considering attending the summit.

site_title: Stamford Arts Centre to be new centre for traditional arts (Amended)
summary: The Stamford Arts Centre in Singapore will undergo a S$7 million redevelopment to preserve its facade while adding modern amenities, including lifts, linkways, and a multi-purpose hall. The project aims to improve accessibility and cater to the growth of the traditional arts industry. The National Arts Council (NAC) and Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY) will collaborate to provide a centre for arts groups and retail tenants. The works are expected to be completed by mid-2018, with an open call for interested tenants to be announced in June.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the overhauled Stamford Arts Centre (above). Much of the conservation building's facade will be kept, but its interiors will have modern amenities.
An artist's impression of the overhauled Stamford Arts Centre (above). Much of the conservation building's facade will be kept, but its interiors will have modern amenities.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial's DPU slips 9.7% in Q1
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust's (CIT) distribution per unit (DPU) slipped 9.7% to 1.004 Singapore cents in Q1, due to property conversions and divestments. Gross revenue fell 2.2% to S$27.7 million, while total distributable income decreased 9.7% to S$13.1 million. The company has divested 55 Ubi Avenue 3 for S$22.14 million as part of its capital recycling strategy. Despite a 95.4% occupancy rate, the manager expects pressures on rental terms to continue due to the soft economic environment.

site_title: The big challenge facing shipping
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has confirmed January 1, 2020, as the implementation date for a global limit of 0.50% sulphur content in marine fuel, down from 3.5%. Ships can meet the requirement by using low-sulphur fuel, gas, or approved equivalent methods such as exhaust gas cleaning systems. However, complying with the new limit will be complex and challenging, with no "one-size-fits-all" solution. Many ship operators will initially use compliant fuel, while scrubbers and liquefied natural gas (LNG) are also being explored as alternatives.

site_title: Straco: Getting down and dirty to come out on top
summary: Straco Corporation, a Chinese developer/operator of tourism assets, has achieved success by taking a hands-on approach to project management. The company's founder and executive chairman, Wu Hsioh Kwang, prioritizes in-house expertise and research, rather than relying on consultants. This approach led to Straco being conferred the Top 10 Asean Enterprises Entering China Award in 2014. The company has also transformed the Singapore Flyer into a top visitor attraction, earning the Enterprise Award at the Singapore Business Awards in 2016. Straco's success is attributed to its commitment to developing world-class attractions and staying ahead of market trends.

images.alt_text: Mr Wu says Straco is constantly building for the future and his existing assets go through major revamps from time to time.

site_title: Should companies go public or stay private?
summary: Global IPO activity surged in Q1 2017, with 369 listings raising $33.7 billion, a 92% year-over-year increase. Despite a trend of public companies seeking to delist, a public listing remains an attractive proposition, offering capital raising, liquidity, and public profile. However, concerns about the agency problem, cost of listing, and scrutiny of regulators and minority shareholders may deter private companies from going public. Alternative funding options, such as private equity, are also emerging, and the type of company and sector may influence the decision to go public or stay private.

site_title: JAB puts Jimmy Choo, Bally up for sale to focus on F&B operations
summary: JAB, the investment arm of the billionaire Reimann family, is putting luxury shoemakers Jimmy Choo and Bally up for sale to focus on its food and beverage operations. The move signals the end of JAB's nearly decade-long involvement in high-end shoemaking, following a recent revival in luxury-goods demand in Asia. Jimmy Choo shares rose 11% after the announcement, valuing the company at about £705 million. The sale process is expected to be completed by the end of the summer, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup handling the auctions.

site_title: A leader in marine insurance market
summary: Lloyd's of London, a leader in marine insurance, has been conferred the Maritime Service Provider Award. The company offers significant insurance protection to marine businesses in the Asia-Pacific region from its international underwriting hub in Singapore. Lloyd's has a long maritime heritage, dating back 328 years, and has a strong presence in the region, with 19 out of 21 service companies underwriting marine risks. The company promotes the development of the marine insurance sector through various initiatives, including its weekly Marine Open Trading Hours, and is committed to further developing its marine business through product innovation and education.

images.alt_text: Mr Chaplin: "Singapore's insurance market has developed tremendously in recent years to serve the growing needs of the marine industry."

site_title: China markets reel as banks unwind US$1.7t in shadow funds
summary: China's banking industry is experiencing significant turmoil as banks unwind US$1.7 trillion in shadow funds, causing local bonds and stocks to plummet. This reversal is attributed to regulatory guidelines that highlight the risks associated with entrusted investments, which have been criticized for adding leverage to China's financial system and reducing transparency. The move is seen as a response to concerns about the risks posed by these investments, which have been a major source of inflows into Chinese markets.

site_title: When innovation doesn't have to come from the top
summary: Good people managers can create an environment where innovators thrive, contrary to the common perception that innovation requires top-down leadership. By empowering team members to think more strategically and innovatively, leaders can foster a culture of innovation. This can be achieved by helping team members become more efficient, nurturing their capacity to think innovatively, and creating an environment where change is accepted and encouraged. Leaders can also volunteer information to their teams, ask the right questions to stimulate creative discussions, and leverage existing talent management platforms to drive innovation from within the organization.

site_title: Japan's sparkling jewel in the south
summary: Okinawa, Japan's southernmost island chain, offers a unique blend of local culture, world heritage sites, and natural beauty. The island is accessible from Singapore with direct flights, making it a convenient destination. Visitors can experience the Naha Hari dragon boat races, explore the Churaumi Aquarium, and enjoy the beautiful Yohena Ajisai Garden. The island is also home to historic sites such as Nakijin Castle Ruins and Shuri Castle, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Additionally, Okinawa World and Minpaku homestay experiences allow visitors to immerse themselves in the local culture and hospitality.

images.alt_text: Okinawa's Churaumi Aquarium, located at the centre of the Motobu Peninsula, has an enormous capacity and showcases the largest fish in the world, the whale shark.
Beautiful sub-tropical Hydrangeas can be seen at the Yohena Ajisai Garden. The flowers are in bloom from mid-May until the end of June.
Cape Manzamo, which faces the open East China Sea, is one of the most popular scenic spots visited by both Japanese and international travellers.

site_title: Growing from strength to strength
summary: K Line Pte Ltd, a leading shipping company, has been awarded the International Maritime Centre (IMC) Award in the corporate category at the Singapore International Maritime Awards. The company, which has been in Singapore since 2001, has contributed to the development of the country's maritime industry through its investments in local manpower and technology adoption projects. K Line has expanded its operations to include bulk vessels, oil tankers, and chemical tanker services, with a staff strength of over 180. The company's director, Makoto Hashizume, expressed gratitude for the recognition and commitment to continuing to contribute to Singapore's growth as an IMC.

images.alt_text: K Line was one of the first few international shipping groups to have established themselves in Singapore in the early 2000s.

"Our local team is creating a global portal for online booking and implementing a new cargo space management system to enhance our process of vessel space monitoring." - Makoto Hashizume, director, president and CEO of K Line

site_title: Transforming an icon
summary: Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong is transforming the airline by conducting a thorough review of its operations to better position the group for the future. The review includes examining network, fleet, product, and service offerings, with no "sacred cows" left untouched. To boost revenue, the airline is forming a specialized pricing department and implementing a new revenue management system. Goh is also exploring the use of data analytics to improve efficiency and forecasting. The airline is also integrating its short-haul budget carriers, Scoot and Tigerair, and is poised to launch new cabin products and long-haul flights.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a sector re-rating in the precision engineering space, driven by stronger H2 2016 results and M&A interest. Memtech International is expected to continue its earnings momentum, with potential dividend surprises. Raffles Medical Group also received a buy target, despite weaker demand in Singapore due to economic conditions. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's distribution per unit guidance was lowered due to an uncertain business outlook and rising interest rates.

site_title: CapitaLand announces key exec appointments
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-listed real estate company, has announced several key executive appointments effective May 1, 2017. Ronald Tay is appointed CEO of CapitaLand Singapore and a key management personnel of the group. Wen Khai Meng is appointed senior adviser, group strategy, while Wilson Tan Wee Yan and Tony Tan Tee Hieong take on deputy CEO and CEO roles, respectively, at CapitaLand Mall Asia. Lim Ming Yan, president & Group CEO, said the appointments will support the group's transformation journey and provide executives with development opportunities.

site_title: Acquisitions boost Ascendas Reit's Q4 DPU by 13%
summary: Ascendas Reit posted a 13% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its Q4 2017, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income. Gross revenue rose 2.4% to S$208.9m, while net property income increased 7.4% to S$154.1m. The trust divested three Chinese properties, generating S$440m in proceeds, which was used to pare debt and improve gearing. The Reit's portfolio remains concentrated in Singapore and Australia, with a focus on selective acquisitions and expansion in the latter market.

site_title: Western markets' 'relief rally' lifts local stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 19.9 points to 3,163.93, driven by a relief rally in Western markets after the first round of France's presidential election. Gains were seen in banks, property counters, and conglomerates, with Mapletree Industrial Trust and Memtech International also posting significant increases. Analysts attribute the rally to reduced European geopolitical risk and the Trump administration's pronouncements on tax cuts, with the potential for a "Frexit" exit from the European Union seen as less likely.

site_title: The growth imperative
summary: Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) chairman Heinrich Jessen aims to diversify the family company beyond its trading roots, focusing on industrial conglomerate growth. With over S$1 billion in annual revenues, Jessen believes being a market player is not sufficient, and companies must either invest to rise or exit. The 120-year-old business has expanded its product range, including hoists, food packaging, cables, and chemicals.

site_title: Revenue from VivoCity, business park boosts Mapletree Reit's Q4
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 50.4% increase in Q4 distributable income to S$64.6 million, driven by contributions from business park Mapletree Business City I and higher rents at VivoCity shopping mall. Gross revenue surged 47.3% to S$107.5 million, with VivoCity accounting for nearly half of the trust's revenue. The trust's investment properties were valued at S$6.34 billion, up 46% from the previous year.

site_title: The great data divide: Baby boomers vs millennials
summary: Millennials in the workforce store significantly more data than baby boomers, with an average of almost twice as much, due to their digitally native nature. This trend is expected to continue, with millennials accounting for over a third of the global workforce by 2020. As a result, companies must prepare for a "data deluge" and anticipate the implications for their storage needs and budget. The lack of data oversight and security risks associated with data hoarding pose significant challenges, with 74% of local millennials admitting to being data hoarders, compared to 66% of baby boomers.

site_title: Brinkmanship over North Korea spells danger for the region
summary: North Korea's escalating nuclear and chemical threats have raised concerns in the region, prompting Japan to prepare for potential missile attacks. The US has deployed a naval armada to Korean waters, sparking threats from Pyongyang, including the possibility of sinking a US aircraft carrier. The situation has been likened to a "big world problem" that requires a solution, with US President Donald Trump calling for a formal peace treaty with North Korea to replace the 1953 armistice. However, brinkmanship has a history of leading to confrontation, and a miscalculation could have catastrophic consequences, including World War III.

site_title: Rental gap between prime and suburban office space shrinks
summary: The gap between prime Central Business District (CBD) and suburban office rentals in Singapore has narrowed to 75% as of Q1 2017, the narrowest since Q4 2012. However, this trend is expected to reverse in 2018 due to rising CBD rents and increased supply. CBD rents are expected to bottom out in 2017 and climb again, making suburban space more attractive to tenants, who can enjoy rental savings of up to 70%. The upcoming supply of new projects will further widen the gap.

site_title: Lodha Group to resume selling apartments in Trump Tower Mumbai
summary: Lodha Group plans to resume selling apartments in Trump Tower Mumbai after a post-US presidential election hiatus. The building, about 60% sold, is expected to be completed in 2019. Lodha Group's managing director, Abhishek Lodha, cited a desire to avoid being seen as profiting from changed political circumstances as the reason for the pause. Despite Trump's policies being met with protests, Lodha remains confident in the tower's success due to its luxury services and post-sales amenities.

images.alt_text: The building is about 60 per cent sold and on target to be completed in 2019, says Mr Lodha.

site_title: NTUC to focus more on training and job placement: Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's NTUC will focus more on training and job placement to help workers adapt to volatile business cycles and technological disruptions. The labour movement aims to build a long-term relationship with workers, from before they start work to retirement, through training programs and career guidance services. NTUC's U Career Network and Employment and Employability Institute will provide workers with the skills and knowledge to bridge skills gaps and transition between careers. The organization also plans to expand into health and eldercare services to stay relevant in the changing economy.

site_title: Ivanka Trump jeered in Berlin after defending her father
summary: Ivanka Trump faced criticism in Berlin after defending her father, President Donald Trump, as a "tremendous champion of supporting families." During a panel on women's economic empowerment, she was met with groans and a follow-up question about her father's attitude to women. Ivanka Trump responded that she had heard the criticism from the media and that many women who worked with her father in the private sector are a testament to his support for women. She later dismissed the criticism as "politics is politics."

site_title: Putting on the cyber defence armour
summary: Singapore prioritizes cybersecurity, recognizing the threat of cyberattacks on its economy and national security. The government has established a secure and resilient cyber ecosystem through international cooperation, investing $10 million in an Asean Cyber Capacity Programme. It aims to benchmark its cybersecurity budget at 8-10% of its ICT budget, similar to South Korea and Israel. The government also introduced changes to the Computer Misuse and Cybersecurity Act to include cyber defence and protect personal data breaches. Additionally, Singapore is addressing the global shortage of cybersecurity professionals through various schemes, including the Cybersecurity Professional Scheme and industry placements.

site_title: Sina chief steers Weibo deeper into online lending waters
summary: Sina Corp, the parent company of Weibo, plans to establish a separate company for internet finance, aiming to compete with rivals Tencent and Alibaba in online lending. Chairman Charles Chao believes Sina's vast user data will give it an edge in the competitive market. Despite being late to the industry, Sina has enjoyed accelerating revenue growth, and Chao is optimistic about its chances, stating "This is a long shot. We need patience in this area."

site_title: A world first
summary: SEMBCORP Marine Ltd has won the Outstanding Maritime R&D and Technology Award at the Singapore International Maritime Awards 2017 for its Semb-Eco Ballast Water Management System, the world's first to use a combination of ultra-violet rays and bio-fouling control. The system, patented in several countries, is energy-efficient, uses no chemicals, and has the lowest power consumption among similar products. It has received IMO type approval and is currently being commercialized, with plans for US Coast Guard certification and expansion of green solutions for the maritime industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuik: "Our pipeline of strategic R&D and solutions development programmes has led to a suite of products that are cleaner, safer and smarter."

site_title: EU steel demand to grow more than 1% this year and next
summary: European steel demand is expected to rise 1.3% this year and 1.2% next, driven by a stronger-than-expected growth in apparent EU demand. The industry's sales are forecast to reach 170 billion euros, with local steelmakers set to benefit from anti-dumping measures. However, the risk of circumvention and increased protectionism due to global oversupply pressures remains a concern. Despite this, improving international trade conditions and a weaker euro are expected to support European steel exports.

site_title: Large crowds as Australia, New Zealand mark Anzac Day
summary: Thousands of Australians and New Zealanders gathered to mark Anzac Day, commemorating the 1915 Gallipoli landing and honoring soldiers in current conflict zones. Heavy rain didn't dampen spirits as ceremonies acknowledged the sacrifices of over 10,000 servicemen who died in the failed campaign. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull visited troops in Afghanistan and Iraq, pledging additional funding to combat terrorism. Indigenous veterans led the national march, calling for better support for returning service personnel, while veterans like Corporal Ben Roberts-Smith emphasized the need for mental health support.

site_title: US:Nasdaq hits 6,000 for 1st time
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index climbing above 6,000 for the first time, reaching 6,004.27. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7% to 20,911.41, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.3% to 2,381.94. The rally followed strong earnings from blue-chip companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher in line with Western markets' 'relief rally'
summary: Singapore stocks rose 19.9 points to 3,163.93 on Tuesday, following a relief rally in Western markets after France's first-round presidential election. The Straits Times Index was firm, with 272 rises and 198 falls, and turnover improved to S$1.2 billion. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: It's been 100 years since the first planting of oil palm in Malaysia. Here's its story
summary: Malaysia's palm-oil industry, a dominant cash crop, has its roots in 1917 when Frenchman Henri Fauconnier planted the first oil palm in Malaya. The palm, native to West Africa, was introduced during the colonial era. Fauconnier's book, "The Soul of Malaya," published in 1930, highlighted the impact of plantations on ordinary Malayans. Today, Malaysia is the world's largest producer of palm oil, with the industry having a significant impact on the country's economy and environment.

site_title: French tycoon's LVMH to consolidate control over Dior
summary: French billionaire Bernard Arnault has completed a 12.1 billion euro deal to consolidate control over Christian Dior, unifying ownership under one roof for the first time in decades. The deal simplifies the complex ownership structure and cements Arnault's position as the biggest consolidator in the luxury goods industry. LVMH, which already owns Dior perfumes and beauty, is acquiring Christian Dior Couture for 6.5 billion euros, valuing the fashion house at 260 euros per share. The deal is expected to increase synergies between LVMH and Christian Dior, easing access to financing and talent movement between the two companies.

site_title: At the forefront of training
summary: The Singapore Maritime Academy provides subsidized education and training for young Singaporeans in marine engineering, maritime business, and nautical studies. The academy offers courses such as the Certificate of Competency and Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping to prepare graduates for the future needs of the industry. The institution responds to the industry's constant regulatory and technological changes by introducing new courses and initiatives, ensuring its graduates are prepared for the future.

images.alt_text: Capt Mohd Salleh (right) demonstrating the capability of SMA's dynamic positioning simulator to an international visitor.

site_title: EU tightens Brexit demands on residence, banks
summary: European Union leaders will require Britain to grant permanent residence to EU citizens who arrive before Brexit in 2019 and stay five more years. The draft negotiating plan also demands Britain cover its share of new EU budget payouts for two years after leaving the bloc. Additionally, the EU will insist on "smooth and simple" processes for exercising permanent residency rights, and guarantee access to benefits such as social housing, even after Brexit. The guidelines aim to protect EU expats and prevent Britain from cutting immigrant numbers.

site_title: Taiwan president faces more grief from US than China
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen faces significant challenges as she marks her first anniversary in office, with China exerting pressure to accept the 1992 Consensus and the US under Donald Trump's leadership uncertain in its commitment to Taiwan's security. China has halted cross-strait cooperation and Xi Jinping has urged Tsai to accept "one China," while Trump's comments have left Taiwan feeling uneasy, with some viewing it as a bargaining chip. The Taiwanese Democratic Progressive Party's charter clause on independence and sovereignty remains a hurdle, but Tsai must navigate these complexities to improve relations with China and maintain US support.

site_title: Temasek, GIC 'still lagging in managing climate risks'
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings and GIC have lagged behind other global institutional investors in managing climate risks, according to the Asset Owners Disclosure Project (AODP). Despite 60% of the largest 500 investors scaling up action to tackle these risks, Temasek and GIC remain in the "laggards" category, with no consideration of climate change implications. This could result in significant losses for the funds as the world transitions to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: EU lawmakers vote to make YouTube fight online hate speech
summary: EU lawmakers voted to require video-sharing platforms like YouTube and Vimeo to take measures to protect citizens from hate speech and incitement to violence. The proposal, approved by the culture committee, defines video-sharing platforms as services that inform, entertain, or educate the public. Platforms must take "appropriate, proportionate, and efficient measures" to protect citizens, and may face fines for non-compliance. The law also aims to increase quotas for European films and TV shows on streaming platforms to 30%.

site_title: DBS/POSB introduces video teller machines at 9 locations
summary: DBS/POSB Bank has launched video teller machines (VTMs) at 9 locations in Singapore, offering round-the-clock branch banking services with live-video assistance from bank tellers. The VTMs provide services such as balance enquiries, debit card applications, and instant token dispensing. Managing Director Jeremy Soo described the introduction as a "first of its kind" and a step towards "reimagining banking" using digital technology and innovation. The move aims to enhance efficiency and extend reach, setting a new industry standard for banking services in Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS/POSB introduced video teller machines at 9 locations, offering round-the-clock branch banking services with live-video assistance. OCBC was praised by Bernstein as "very well positioned" to ride regional growth trends, with a target price of S$10.95/shr. Singapore developed two new digital platforms for its maritime sector. Credit quality of Singapore firms remained largely unchanged, while JTC put up a 0.43ha site for sale. The Straits Times Index rose 19.9 points to 3,163.93, following a relief rally in Western markets.

site_title: Volvo AB earnings surge 58% on cost cuts, construction equipment
summary: Volvo AB reported a 58% surge in first-quarter earnings to 7.03 billion kronor (S$1.1 billion) due to cost cuts and increased sales of construction equipment. The company's adjusted operating profit more than doubled from 4.46 billion kronor a year earlier. Volvo is navigating uneven demand for commercial vehicles in key markets, but expects growth in the US economy under President Trump's 3% growth goal. The company's return on sales widened to 9.1% from 6.2% a year earlier as part of its cost-cutting program.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation, South Korea's Oceanus bag US$45.2m project
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings, a South Korean company, has secured a $45.2 million project to purchase and remove decommissioned offshore and onshore facilities for a Middle Eastern national oil company. The project, managed by the Oceanus-ASM consortium, will start in June 2017 and be completed within 18 months. Atlantic Navigation will provide seven vessels and has a 49% interest in the project, aiming to diversify its business in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: CDL tops bid for Tampines residential site with S$370.1m
summary: CDL tops the bid for a Tampines residential site with a S$370.1 million offer, translating to S$565.4 per square foot per plot ratio. The site is estimated to yield 715 private apartments and attracted significant Chinese interest, with five out of nine bidders being Chinese players.

site_title: Lian Beng unit sells Melbourne property for A$35m
summary: Lian Beng Group's wholly owned subsidiary, Lian Beng Ventures (Melbourne), has sold a Melbourne property for A$35 million (S$36.7 million), comprised of 1,915.5 square meters of net lettable area. The freehold property, located on Collins Street between Swanston and Elizabeth Streets, includes units B101-501. The sale is part of the company's efforts to dispose of non-core assets and generate revenue.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust net property income rises 51.2% for Q4; DPU up 11.9%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust's net property income rose 51.2% in Q4, driven by contributions from Mapletree Business City I, and distribution per unit increased 11.9% to 2.26 Singapore cents per share. Net income and income available for distribution also rose 59.5% and 50.4% respectively. For the full year, net property income increased 32.4% to S$292.3 million, and total payout for the year is 8.62 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Tyson Foods to buy AdvancePierre for US$3.2 b
summary: Tyson Foods Inc. agreed to buy AdvancePierre Foods Holdings Inc. for approximately $3.2 billion in cash, expanding its prepared foods portfolio. The deal is a 9.8% premium to AdvancePierre's Monday close, with an enterprise value of about $4.2 billion. The acquisition includes $1.1 billion of AdvancePierre debt, and funds affiliated with Oaktree Capital Management LP have agreed to support the deal. This move follows Tyson's exploration of selling its non-protein brands to sharpen its focus on core businesses.

site_title: US consumer confidence slips
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 120.3 in April, down from a 16-year high of 124.9 in March, but new home sales reached an eight-month high. The decline is attributed to the failed attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Despite this, the economy's fundamentals remain strong, with the largest year-on-year increase in house prices in 2-1/2 years in February.

site_title: Japan's ruling party heavyweight to attend China's New Silk Road summit
summary: Japanese ruling party Secretary-General Toshihiro Nikai will attend China's New Silk Road summit in May, aiming to improve ties with Beijing amid North Korea tensions. Nikai's attendance, alongside other Japanese officials, comes as concerns grow over North Korea's nuclear program. Japan remains cautious about the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) and its dominance by China. The summit marks a significant step in Japan's efforts to balance its relations with China and the US in the face of regional tensions.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q4 DPU up 13%
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 13% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its fourth quarter, reaching 3.852 Singapore cents. This is attributed to higher gross revenue of 2.4% to S$209 million, partly due to the full quarter contribution from ONE@Changi City.

site_title: Lippo converts S$15m worth of Healthway notes into shares
summary: Lippo Group has converted S$15 million worth of Healthway Medical Corporation's convertible notes into shares, expanding the company's share base to approximately 3.2 billion shares. This conversion was part of a takeover offer launched by Lippo Group, which issued about 443 million conversion shares to Healthway. The company still holds S$45 million worth of convertible notes that will be converted into about 1.33 billion new shares.

site_title: Uber, France spar over whether company is a transport service
summary: Uber, the US ride-hailing app, has told Europe's top court that it is a digital service, not a transport service, and therefore not subject to strict licensing and safety rules. The company argues that a French law targeting online taxi services is aimed at UberPOP, its unlicensed driver service, and that the law should not apply to its main service. The case is the latest in a series of battles between Uber and taxi industries in Europe, with the outcome potentially determining the company's future in the region.

site_title: SPH to buy nursing home provider Orange Valley for S$164m
summary: SPH to buy nursing home provider Orange Valley for S$164 million, marking the media and property group's entry into the healthcare sector. The acquisition, free of debt, includes five nursing homes with over 900 beds and ancillary services. SPH expects strong demand for aged care services, citing a projected doubling of Singapore's 65-year-old population to 900,000 by 2030. This move aims to capitalize on the growing need for quality aged care services in Singapore.

site_title: Rocket Internet narrows losses, boosts sales at key startups
summary: Rocket Internet SE narrowed losses and boosted sales at key startups, including HelloFresh, Global Fashion Group, and Dafiti. The company reported a 49% sales increase for HelloFresh and adjusted losses before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization narrowed at other businesses. Rocket aims to have three of its main investments break even by the end of 2017. CEO Oliver Samwer reiterated a target to make three businesses profitable by the end of the year, despite criticism of the startup incubator's reporting.

site_title: ABB, IBM team up on industrial artificial intelligence
summary: ABB and IBM have partnered to develop and sell industrial artificial intelligence products. The collaboration combines ABB's digital offerings with IBM's Watson data analytics software, enabling machines to sense, analyze, and optimize industrial operations. The partnership aims to drive greater uptime, speed, and yield for industrial customers, and ABB CEO Ulrich Spiesshofer described it as a "next level of industrial technology."

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on April 25, 2017, amid concerns over North Korea's military anniversary. Global stocks had rallied earlier due to the first round of the French election. The Nikkei 225 and Topix indices saw minimal changes, down 0.05% and 0.01% respectively. Investors remained cautious, likely influenced by the ongoing tensions with North Korea.

site_title: US new home sales see fastest pace in 8 months
summary: US new home sales surged in March, reaching the fastest pace in 8 months with 621,000 newly built single-family homes sold at an annual rate. This represents a 15.6% increase from the same month in 2016, with the stock of homes for sale reaching its highest level in nearly 8 years. The brisk sales pace led to a supply shortage, with the average home price rising 7.5% to $315,100. This tight market is attributed to steady job creation and rising wages driving demand.

images.alt_text: Sales of new homes in the United States forged higher for the third straight month in March, hitting the fastest pace since July, the Commerce Department reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady after France-induced surge
summary: European stock markets steadied at the start of trading Tuesday after a surge in the previous session, driven by France's first-round presidential election result. The Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.1% to a record high, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index opened flat at a record high. Global markets rallied on Monday after Emmanuel Macron's moderate victory, boosting the euro. London's FTSE 100 remained flat at the open after a 2.1% jump in the previous trading session.

site_title: BOJ's Iwata says conducting simulation on exit strategy from stimulus
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Kikuo Iwata said the central bank is conducting a simulation on how to exit its massive monetary stimulus, but acknowledged it is far from achieving its 2% inflation target. Iwata stated that the BOJ would refrain from making the details of the simulation public to avoid market confusion. The central bank holds its monetary policy meeting on Wednesday and Thursday, with no expected policy changes. The simulation comes amid concerns about unwinding the BOJ's large holdings of government debt and managing liquidity.

site_title: Jebsen & Jessen chairman Heinrich Jessen named Businessman of the Year at Singapore Business Awards
summary: Heinrich Jessen, chairman of Jebsen & Jessen, was named Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards for his role in transforming the company into a regional powerhouse. Employing over 4,000 people in 50 subsidiaries, Jebsen & Jessen has grown from a foreign family trading business. The award comes after Jessen's efforts to build the company into a pan-Asian industrial and engineering enterprise.

images.alt_text: For his role in transforming Jebsen & Jessen (Southeast Asia) into a regional powerhouse, chairman Heinrich Jessen has been named Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards (SBA).

site_title: Indian farmers should pay tax, adviser says, challenging government
summary: Indian government adviser Bibek Debroy proposes that farmers pay income tax, challenging current government policy. Debroy suggests farmers be liable for tax on incomes at the same thresholds as urban dwellers, considering fluctuations in farming incomes. The move aims to increase tax revenue, but its impact on farmers remains uncertain, sparking debate over the policy's feasibility.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks have best day in 6 weeks amid French vote euphoria
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.3% to their best day in six weeks, driven by a market-friendly outcome of the French presidential election. The Hang Seng index rose to 24,455.94, while the MSCI World index reached an all-time high. French stocks jumped over 4% and Wall Street gained 1%, reducing expectations of a Brexit-like result in the second round of the French election. The market is pricing in a likely victory for internationalist Emmanuel Macron, boosting stocks across all sectors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.75 points to close at 1,765.80 on Tuesday, driven by 559 gainers and 388 losers. The index saw 3.66 billion lots valued at RM3.11 billion traded.

site_title: ECB survey sees buoyant lending growth in Q2
summary: The European Central Bank's quarterly survey of banks indicates that lending growth in the euro zone is expected to rise in Q2, despite banks tightening access to credit. Corporate credit standards eased slightly in Q1, mainly due to ultra-low interest rates. However, credit standards remain tighter compared to historical norms since 2003. Housing loans are expected to see steady standards and rising volumes in Q2, with easing collateral requirements and non-interest rate charges. The easing impact of competitive pressure was widespread, except in Germany.

site_title: Broker's take: Bernstein says OCBC is very well positioned, pegs target price at S$10.95/shr
summary: Sanford C. Bernstein's report praises Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) as "very well positioned" to ride Asia's growth trends, particularly in wealth management and China. Analyst Kevin Kwek sets a target price of S$10.95 per share, citing the bank's strong execution, large acquisitions, and potential boost from insurance and wealth management businesses. OCBC's long-term growth strategy is based on four Asia megatrends: wealth management, China, digitalisation, and regional flows.

site_title: Ho Bee Q1 profit trebles
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 93% increase in net earnings for the first quarter to S$56.3 million, driven by sales recognition from two residential development projects in Australia. Revenue rose 13.9% to S$42.4 million, and earnings per share surged to 8.46 Singapore cents from 2.77 cents in the previous year. The group also divested a commercial property in London, resulting in a gain of S$7.4 million.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Australia and New Zealand were closed on Tuesday, April 25, 2017, for a public holiday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up, building on gains
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.08% on Tuesday, following a global rally, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 19,079.33. The gains came after centrist Emmanuel Macron won the first round of the French election. Meanwhile, North Korea marked a key military anniversary, keeping traders on edge.

site_title: China markets reel as US$1.7t in shadow funds unwind
summary: China's financial markets experienced a significant downturn after US$1.7 trillion in shadow funds, managed by external asset managers, began to unwind. This has led to a sharp decline in stock and bond prices, with losses of over $315 billion in the past six days. The move is a response to regulatory guidelines that have increased scrutiny on the risks associated with entrusted investments. Chinese authorities are working to rein in shadow banking activity without destabilizing the market, with forecasters predicting a deeper selloff this year.

site_title: Luxury juggernaut LVMH folds Dior into its stable of brands
summary: French billionaire Bernard Arnault's luxury conglomerate LVMH has acquired Christian Dior for 12.1 billion euros, folding the fashion house's operations into its stable of brands. The deal values Dior at 260 euros per share, a 15% increase from Monday's closing price. LVMH will acquire Christian Dior Couture, including luxury handbags and ready-to-wear fashions, while Dior investors can choose payment in cash or Hermes International stock. The deal underscores LVMH's confidence in its long-term prospects and demonstrates Arnault's family's commitment to the luxury brand.

site_title: South Korea tourist numbers plummet in China boycott
summary: South Korea's tourist industry has been severely impacted by China's 40% boycott of the country due to the deployment of the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system. Visitor numbers from China plummeted to 360,000 in March, a 40% drop from the previous year. This has led to significant losses for South Korean duty-free shops, with sales to Chinese customers falling 40% since the group tour ban in mid-March. The losses are estimated to reach $1 billion in the first half of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips amid North Korea worries, stocks at 2-year high
summary: The South Korean won slipped 0.2% to 1,132.3 against the US dollar amid growing concerns over North Korea. US President Donald Trump's comments on imposing new sanctions on North Korea pushed the greenback up, despite slight dollar strength globally. Meanwhile, South Korean shares rose to a 2-year high as foreign investors snapped up stocks on robust earnings hopes, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 0.4% at 2,183.38 points.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won slipped early on Tuesday morning as worries over North Korea grew among investors after US President Donald Trump said the UN Security Council should be prepared to impose new sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks surge to 6-year high on large foreign demand
summary: South Korean stocks reached a six-year high on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing up 1.1% at 2,196.85 points. Foreign investors purchased 648 billion won worth of Kospi shares, driving up the South Korean won to a three-week high against the US dollar. This surge in foreign demand was fueled by optimism over firm corporate earnings, lifting the Kospi to its highest level since May 3, 2011.

site_title: Alitalia risks collapse after unions reject restructuring plan
summary: Alitalia's workers voted against a restructuring plan that included salary reductions and hundreds of job cuts. The plan, which was approved by management and union leaders, was a condition for a 2 billion-euro recapitalization. If the plan is not approved, the Italian government will likely act as a special administrator for about six months before liquidation. The airline's financial struggles continue, with UniCredit SpA having lost almost 500 million euros on the carrier. A turnaround strategy by Etihad Airways has not been sufficient to keep the company afloat.

site_title: Credit Suisse investors prepare to grill chairman Rohner over pay
summary: Credit Suisse Chairman Urs Rohner is facing his toughest shareholder meeting amid investor revolt over bonuses and losses totaling 5.65 billion Swiss francs since 2015. Rohner, 57, is under pressure to stand down after six years as chairman, with his share price more than halving to around 15 francs. Despite concessions, Rohner is confident of winning all agenda item votes, including a binding vote on bonuses and board pay, and his re-election. Investors are questioning his suitability as chairman, citing his lack of banking experience and the bank's poor performance under his leadership.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Chairman Urs Rohner faces his toughest shareholder meeting to date this week following an investor revolt over bonuses and losses totalling 5.65 billion Swiss francs (S$8 billion) since 2015.

site_title: Oslo, London lead push for greener transport: study
summary: Oslo, London, and Amsterdam are leading cities in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport, according to a study by the London-based Centre for Economics and Business Research. Oslo aims to become the world's first city with zero emissions transportation, while London plans to cut emissions by 60% by 2025. Amsterdam has implemented cycling initiatives and reduced emissions. Cairo ranks last due to population growth and poverty concerns. The study highlights the efforts of European cities to curb climate change and air pollution through green transport solutions.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator queries banks over US$200m Huishan Dairy loan: sources
summary: Hong Kong's banking watchdog, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), is questioning lenders over a $200 million loan to China Huishan Dairy Holdings Co Ltd, which has missed debt payments and breached loan covenants. Regulators are scrutinizing the loan's due diligence and credit-checking processes, which could lead to fines if compliance lapses are found. The HKMA's inquiry follows a report by US-based short-seller Muddy Waters questioning Huishan's accounting and debt burden, and the company's efforts to avert lenders calling in loans.

site_title: China: Stocks steady, sentiment still soured
summary: China's stock market steadied on Tuesday, rising 0.3% to 3,440.97 points, after a sharp 1% drop the previous session. The rebound was attributed to a "technical" bounce after being over-sold, driven by concerns over regulatory tightening. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.2% to 3,134.57 points, with consumer stocks outperforming the broader market. Analysts cited the securities regulator's crackdown, which has driven money into cash-rich blue-chips, as a factor behind the market's cautious sentiment.

site_title: Japan Post to record around 40b yen annual net loss
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co is expected to record an annual net loss of around 40 billion yen (S$507.3 million) due to a 400 billion yen impairment charge on its Australian logistics unit, Toll Holdings Ltd. This would be Japan Post's first annual loss since its privatization in 2007. The impairment charge was incurred after the unit's performance fell short of expectations.

site_title: China targets 35m vehicle sales by 2025, new energy vehicles to make up one-fifth
summary: China targets 35 million vehicle sales by 2025, with new energy vehicles (NEVs) expected to make up one-fifth of total sales. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology aims for annual NEV sales of over 7 million by 2025. Currently, green energy car sales represent less than 2% of China's overall auto market. Chinese automakers, such as SAIC and Geely, are gaining global recognition, with some expected to reach the top 10 in global sales by 2025. The government aims to create local champions in the industry and increase exports to developed nations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% at the open on Tuesday, building on a three-day gain, following a strong lead from New York and Europe after French President Emmanuel Macron's first-round presidential election success. The Hang Seng Index rose to 24,234.42, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index opened down 0.18%.

site_title: China says fewer graft suspects fleeing as controls stepped up
summary: China has seen a significant decrease in corruption suspects fleeing the country over the past four years, with 101 officials fleeing in 2014, 31 in 2015, and 19 in 2017. The government has strengthened controls, including passport issuance and restrictions on moving assets offshore, to prevent escape. Since publishing an Interpol red notice for 100 most wanted suspects in 2015, 40 have returned to China, mostly through persuasion. China continues to pursue those abroad with its "Operation Fox Hunt" as part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption efforts.

site_title: Asia: Markets, euro build on gains as eyes move to Trump
summary: Asian markets continued their gains on Tuesday, with Tokyo up 0.8%, Hong Kong 0.8%, and Seoul 0.4% higher, following Emmanuel Macron's first round presidential election win in France. The euro held steady at US$1.086, while investors now focus on US President Donald Trump's promised tax reforms, set to be unveiled on Wednesday. Global markets rallied after Macron's win, easing concerns about France's euro and EU stability, and tracking the Asian advance on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.66 points, or 0.05%, to 3,145.69 at 9:03am on Tuesday, with 66.2 million shares changing hands. Top gainers included Keppel Corp, OCBC Bank, and DBS Bank, while Jardine C&C, Dairy Farm, and ST Engineering were the top losers. The rally follows a broader Asian equity increase after the French elections, with the euro reaching its largest advance since June and the yen steady after Monday's declines.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust Q2 DPU remains steady at 3.04 Singapore cents
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a steady distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.04 Singapore cents for Q2 2017, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue fell 2.9% year-on-year to S$45.7 million, mainly due to lower contributions from Northpoint, but was partially offset by higher contributions from other properties. Net property income fell 3.3% to S$32.6 million, with a gearing level of 29.4% and a weighted average debt maturity of 2.4 years.

site_title: Singapore O&G proposes splitting one existing share into two
summary: Singapore O&G is proposing a share split, where existing ordinary shares will be split into two, resulting in an enlarged 476.8 million shares. The new shares will not be entitled to dividends, but the reduced price will make the shares more affordable and attractive to investors. The proposal is subject to SGX listing and shareholder approval, with the aim of increasing trading flexibility and liquidity.

site_title: JTC puts up Tuas South Link 3 site for sale
summary: JTC has launched a 0.43ha industrial site at Tuas South Link 3 for sale under the government land sales programme. The plot, zoned for Business-2 development, has a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. Tender closes on June 20, 2017, as part of the government's efforts to offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: China's hidden debt stirs investor angst as defaults rise
summary: China's hidden debt is sparking investor angst as defaults rise, with small firms using cross-guarantees to secure loans from banks. These guarantees are often not disclosed on balance sheets, leaving creditors in the dark. The phenomenon is less common in the US, where banks do not require such guarantees. The hidden debt poses rising risks, particularly with increasing borrowing costs and defaults on local notes. China's banking regulator has ordered checks on cross-guaranteed loans, and experts warn of a potential "butlerfly effect" where failures could ricochet across companies.

site_title: Toshiba to start taking bids in June for its Swiss unit Landis+Gyr
summary: Toshiba is set to start taking bids for its Swiss smart meter unit, Landis+Gyr, in June. Japanese firms such as Hitachi and several private equity groups are potential bidders, with a potential value of over $2 billion. Toshiba had previously hired UBS to explore a sale or initial public offering of the business. The company is targeting several buyout groups, including Carlyle and Blackstone, in a bid to sell the unit.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise, taking cues from overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.6% on Tuesday, influenced by overseas markets. The Taiex index reached 9,773.76, driven by gains in the electronics and financial subindexes. Industrial output rose 3.22% in March, contributing to sustained annual growth. The release of Taiwan's preliminary GDP data for the first quarter is expected to show continued growth. Meanwhile, the Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$30.218 per US dollar.

site_title: Hyundai faces host of China problems, from missiles to SUVs
summary: Hyundai faces significant challenges in China, with dealerships experiencing a decline in sales and customer traffic. The company's sedan-heavy lineup fails to meet the growing demand for SUVs, while poor brand perception and a nationalist backlash against South Korea's hosting of the US missile-defense system Thaad contribute to the problems. Half of Hyundai's employees in China have quit, and the company's Shanghai dealership is nearly empty, highlighting the dire situation facing the automaker in its largest market.

site_title: AEM's Q1 profit surges to S$4.1m
summary: AEM Holdings, a global equipment systems solutions provider, reported a 17-fold increase in net profit to S$4.1 million in Q1 2017, with revenue jumping 3.5 times to S$42.1 million. The company attributed the growth to its next-generation semiconductor handling platform, which has seen increasing orders since Q4 2016.

site_title: US submarine makes South Korea port call, North remains defiant
summary: A US nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Michigan, made a port call in South Korea on April 25, 2017, amid concerns about North Korea's potential nuclear test or missile launch. The move came as US President Donald Trump called for tougher UN sanctions on North Korea and top nuclear envoys met in Tokyo to discuss responses. China's President Xi Jinping also urged restraint, while North Korea warned of a "catastrophic consequence" from US military actions. The USS Michigan is equipped to carry submarine-launched ballistic missiles and Tomahawk cruise missiles.

site_title: Singapore developing 2 new digital platforms for maritime sector
summary: Singapore is developing two new digital platforms to support its maritime sector's digital transformation. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore is creating the Maritime Single Window, a single portal for submitting documents for port clearance. Another cross-government effort is underway to develop the next-generation national trade platform. These platforms aim to improve efficiency and readiness for the maritime sector.

site_title: China's environment ministry finds patchy progress on water and soil pollution
summary: China's environment ministry reported patchy progress on water and soil pollution in 2016, with uneven improvements in water quality and worsening conditions in some areas. Despite overall air, water, and soil pollutants showing improvement, 36.3% of heavy polluting industries' land and surrounding soil failed to meet government standards. China remains confident in its "war on pollution" efforts, with 78.8% of days considered "good" for air quality, but faces complex and difficult challenges in managing the environment.

images.alt_text: Efforts to tackle water pollution in China remain uneven with some areas worsening in 2016, while heavy metals and other pollutants continued to accumulate in Chinese soil, the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP) said.

site_title: Tennis: Serena fires back at Nastase for 'racist' comments
summary: Serena Williams condemned former tennis player Ilie Nastase's "racist" comments about her unborn child, calling them "disappointing" and "sexist." Nastase, 70, was quoted as saying "Let's see what color it has. Chocolate with milk?" in response to Williams' pregnancy announcement. The International Tennis Federation (ITF) launched an investigation into the remarks, which sparked outrage among players and officials. Williams thanked the ITF for their support and vowed to cooperate with the investigation, which is ongoing.

site_title: Loved and lost, Heath Ledger shows carefree side in new documentary
summary: A documentary titled "I Am Heath Ledger" showcases the actor's carefree side through thousands of hours of self-shot videos, artwork, and music videos. The film aims to counter the perception that Ledger was severely depressed before his 2008 death at 28. According to his agent and friends, Ledger was a "force of nature" who was loving life, generous with friends, and passionate about various pursuits. The documentary premiered at the Tribeca film festival and will be shown in US theaters on May 3 and on Spike TV on May 17.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari: infrastructure spending not key to US growth, education is
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari stated that increased infrastructure spending is not crucial to US economic growth, instead emphasizing the importance of education. Kashkari's comments contradict President Donald Trump's promise to boost infrastructure spending as part of his economic plan.

site_title: Credit quality of Singapore firms largely unchanged over the past year: SCCB
summary: The credit quality of Singapore firms has remained largely unchanged over the past year, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB). Most firms maintained unchanged credit ratings or financial strength and risk indicators, with a slight increase in firms experiencing no change in financial strength and risk standing. The proportion of firms experiencing an improvement in financial strength and risk standing decreased, while those experiencing a deterioration in risk standing also decreased. Overall, the credit quality of Singapore firms has shown stability over the past year.

site_title: Sina chief steers China's Twitter deeper into internet finance
summary: Sina Corp, the Chinese company behind Weibo, is preparing to enter the online lending market, competing with rivals like Tencent and Alibaba. Chairman Charles Chao plans to create a separate company to provide internet finance, leveraging the company's 313 million Weibo users and detailed user data. Despite regulatory challenges, Chao sees the move as a long shot but believes Sina's data advantage will help it succeed. The company aims to use its existing user base to gain traction in the competitive and regulated online lending space.

images.alt_text: Sina, which controls online messaging service Weibo Corp, plans to create a separate company dedicated to providing internet finance across its services, Chairman Charles Chao said in an interview with Bloomberg Television.

site_title: SK Hynix reports record quarterly revenue, profit on strong chip demand
summary: SK Hynix Inc, South Korea's second-largest memory chip maker, reported a record-high quarterly profit of 2.5 trillion won (S$3.08 billion), a 339% increase from the previous year, driven by strong demand for memory chips. Revenue rose 72% to 6.3 trillion won, surpassing market expectations. Analysts expect the industry to see a 32% revenue growth to a record US$104 billion this year, driven by supply constraints and rising chip prices.

site_title: Obama says ready to train new leaders in first post-presidency speech
summary: Former US President Barack Obama has announced his plans to train the next generation of leadership in his first post-presidency speech. In a packed auditorium at the University of Chicago, Obama expressed his optimism about the future and emphasized the importance of civic engagement among young people. He also spoke about the need for empathy and understanding among different groups, and joked about the challenges of social media. Obama's speech comes as he prepares to embark on a series of public events, including a speech in Italy and a visit to Berlin, where he will receive a prestigious award.

site_title: T-Mobile's outlook for subscriber growth brightens
summary: T-Mobile US Inc expects to gain 2.8-3.5 million subscribers this year, surpassing its original forecast of 2.4-3.4 million. Despite this growth, the company maintains its 2017 profit outlook, suggesting a potential hit on profit due to increased customer acquisition costs. T-Mobile's efforts to expand its subscriber base are seen as a challenge to its bigger rivals, Verizon and AT&T, which are also aggressively marketing unlimited data packages.

images.alt_text: T-Mobile US Inc will gain more subscribers than expected this year amid intensified competition from Verizon Communications Inc and AT&T Inc, even if it means taking a hit on profit.

site_title: Elton John recovering from 'potentially deadly' bacterial infection
summary: Elton John, 70, spent two nights in intensive care due to a potentially deadly bacterial infection contracted during his South American tour. The British musician, a Grammy, Oscar, and Tony winner, has cancelled all his concerts in Las Vegas for April and May. He is expected to make a full recovery and will resume performances on June 3. John apologised to fans for the disappointment and thanked the medical team for their care.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.340 points to 1765.080 on Tuesday, driven by a gain-to-loss ratio of 210 to 41. The market opened higher, with a total volume of 101.1 million lots worth RM42.62 million.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust Q1 DPU down 9.7%
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust reported a 9.7% decline in its distribution per unit to 1.004 Singapore cents for the first quarter of 2017. The trust's gross revenue dropped 2.2% to S$27.7 million, while its net property income fell 8.4% to S$19.7 million. Despite this, the net asset value remains unchanged at 63.4 Singapore cents. The decline is attributed to several master leased properties converted into multi-tenancy properties and recent divestments.

site_title: US Senate confirms Perdue as Trump's agriculture secretary
summary: The US Senate confirmed Sonny Perdue, a 70-year-old former governor of Georgia, as the nation's agriculture secretary, filling one of the few remaining cabinet vacancies. He received a bipartisan vote of 87-11 and will oversee the country's food and farm programs, which face proposed 21% cuts. Mexico has threatened to stop importing US corn due to Mr. Trump's trade policies, and Senator Debbie Stabenow warned that rural America has been treated as an "afterthought" by the president. Perdue will take charge of the US Department of Agriculture.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit DPU up 9.6% in Q1 2017
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 9.6% increase in DPU to 3.28 Singapore cents in Q1 2017, despite divesting four Japan nursing homes in December 2016. The DPU from recurring operations grew 2.2% to 3.06 cents. Gross revenue rose 0.2% to S$26.9 million, supported by a nursing home acquisition in March 2016 and appreciation of the Japanese yen. The net asset value per unit remained unchanged at S$1.72.

site_title: Key executive appointments at CapitaLand
summary: CapitaLand Limited has made several key executive appointments effective May 1, 2017, including Ronald Tay as CEO of CapitaLand Singapore, Wen Khai Meng as senior adviser of group strategy, and Tony Tan as CEO of CapitaLand Mall Trust Management Limited. Lim Ming Yan, president and group CEO, stated that the company reviews management roles to ensure talent renewal. The appointments aim to strengthen the company's leadership bench.

site_title: Canada: Ontario to pay guaranteed incomes to the poor
summary: Ontario, Canada, has launched a pilot program to provide a guaranteed basic income to 4,000 people living under the poverty line for three years. Provincial Premier Kathleen Wynne aims to test the program's effects on recipients and public finances, with the goal of understanding whether a basic income improves people's lives. The initiative is part of Ontario's efforts to address poverty and benefit from the province's economic growth.

site_title: Enhancing capabilities and keeping spirits up despite choppy waters
summary: The maritime and offshore sector is experiencing significant challenges due to high production levels, an oversupply of ships, and geopolitical uncertainty. Despite these challenges, industry players are taking proactive steps to improve efficiencies, consolidate fleets, and downsize workforces. Companies are investing in skills development, restructuring roles, and exploring new technologies such as smart shipping. The industry is also looking to the future, with the Sea Asia 2017 conference set to discuss opportunities and challenges facing the sector, and potential talent shortages in emerging technologies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Parkway Life Reit, Cambridge Industrial Trust, CapitaLand
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 9.6% increase in distribution per unit to 3.28 Singapore cents, driven by a nursing home acquisition and appreciation of the Japanese yen.
