Cambridge Industrial Trust saw its distribution per unit slip 9.7% to 1.004 Singapore cents, with a 2.2% drop in gross revenue. CapitaLand Limited made key executive appointments effective May 1, 2017. These announcements may influence trading on Tuesday.

site_title: Chile rocked by 7.1-magnitude quake; no major damage reported
summary: A 7.1-magnitude earthquake struck off the west coast of Chile, causing brief alarm but no major damage. The quake was centered 35 km west of Valparaiso, 137 km from Santiago, and produced small tsunami waves of 15 cm. No structural damage was reported in Valparaiso, but cellphone networks were down. Chile's copper mining operations remained unaffected, and officials described the situation as "pretty normal" despite the quake's intensity.

images.alt_text: People ran out of the facility carrying children and some headed for the hills when the tsunami alarm sounded, she said, but calm was soon restored.

site_title: Upward mobility has fallen sharply in US: study
summary: US upward mobility has sharply declined, with 92% of children born in 1940 earning more than their parents, but only half of those born in 1984 able to do so. This decline is attributed to greater inequality in the distribution of growth, primarily affecting middle-class families. Researchers suggest a concerted effort to level the playing field is needed, focusing on raising middle-class and lower-income household incomes through interventions such as universal preschool, increased public university access, and higher minimum wages. Policymakers should prioritize these measures to restore higher intergenerational income mobility.

site_title: Dealers cut prices of commercial vehicles ahead of COE quota surge
summary: Dealers in Singapore are cutting prices of commercial vehicles ahead of a surge in certificate of entitlement (COE) supply. Tan Chong Motor, a leading retailer, has reduced prices by up to S$20,000, while Cycle & Carriage and Borneo Motors have also made significant cuts. The COE supply is expected to increase by 573.3% for the May-July quota period, leading to a decrease in COE premiums, but the extent of the drop is uncertain.

site_title: Delays dog 'shovel ready' projects in Trump's infrastructure plan
summary: US President Donald Trump's $1 trillion infrastructure plan faces delays due to the difficulty in putting projects into action. Despite being labeled "shovel ready," many projects have yet to start construction, with some taking years or even decades to begin. State-level permits and regulatory hurdles are a major obstacle, and the permitting process is being criticized as overly complex and time-consuming. The delays highlight the challenges in launching infrastructure projects quickly, making it unclear whether Trump's promise of a 10-year, trillion-dollar plan can be met.

site_title: Oil slips on Opec cut extension doubts, Russia output worries
summary: Oil prices slipped nearly one percent on Monday, extending a decline, due to doubts over Opec's decision to extend output cuts and concerns over rising Russian oil output. Oil prices fell 36 cents to $51.60 per barrel for Brent crude and 39 cents to $49.23 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. The decline comes despite a relief rally over the French election, and reflects bearish market sentiment amid concerns over US shale production and Opec's potential output increase.

site_title: 'Personal flying machine' maker plans deliveries this year
summary: Kitty Hawk, a Silicon Valley startup backed by Google co-founder Larry Page, has released a video of its airborne prototype, "The Flyer," a personal flying machine. The single-seat aircraft, propelled by eight rotors, can hover at 4.5 meters high and fly at speeds up to 25 miles per hour. The company plans to deliver the machine by the end of 2017, with a three-year membership option available for $100. The Flyer is described as "safe, tested and legal to operate" in the US, requiring only two hours of training.

images.alt_text: A Silicon Valley "flying car" startup, Kitty Hawk, reportedly backed by Google co-founder Larry Page, released a video Monday of its airborne prototype and announced plans for deliveries of a "personal flying machine" this year.

site_title: Citic Envirotech wins 2 China projects worth a total of 434m yuan
summary: CITIC Envirotech has won bids for two projects in China worth a total of 434 million yuan (S$87.8 million). The projects involve a wastewater treatment plant in Xinji City and a water recycling project in Changyi City. Construction of the projects is set to commence in July and is expected to be completed by March next year. The capital injection for the projects will be funded from the proceeds of its last issuance of perpetual capital securities.

site_title: Hollande urges French voters to block Le Pen
summary: French President Francois Hollande urged voters to reject far-right candidate Marine Le Pen in the upcoming presidential runoff against Emmanuel Macron, who is the clear favorite to become France's youngest-ever president. Macron topped the first round of voting with 24.01% of the vote, ahead of Le Pen on 21.3%. Hollande warned of the "risk for our country" of a far-right victory and said he would vote for Macron. Le Pen has gained over 1.2 million new voters and is setting party affairs aside to focus on the campaign, but polls suggest Macron will beat her by more than 20 percentage points in the second round.

site_title: With execs in hot seat, Wells Fargo gets OK for bankruptcy plan
summary: US regulators have approved Wells Fargo's 2015 bankruptcy plan, allowing the bank to open new international branches. The plan had been restricted due to deficiencies in its resolution, but regulators found the bank had addressed these issues. This decision comes ahead of a shareholder meeting where the bank's board is facing a no-confidence vote. Wells Fargo had faced criticism over its handling of a 2015 scandal involving millions of sham accounts and has been working to resolve issues since a $190 million settlement with federal authorities in September 2016.

images.alt_text: Retail banking giant Wells Fargo has fixed problems in its 2015 bankruptcy plan and will now be allowed to open new international branches, US banking regulators said Monday.

site_title: US: French election results catapult Wall Street higher; Nasdaq sets record
summary: US stocks rallied on Monday, driven by relief after centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron won the first round of the French presidential election, seen as a positive sign for the European economy and the EU. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.05%, the S&P 500 gained 1.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite set a record at 1.24%. This relief rally led to a surge in European banks and lifted earnings expectations, with 77% of reported S&P 500 companies beating profit estimates.

site_title: Venezuela death toll rises as unrest enters fourth week
summary: Venezuela's death toll from anti-government protests has risen to 11, with at least one person killed and several wounded in the Andean state of Merida. The protests, now in their fourth week, demand early elections, the release of jailed activists, and autonomy for the opposition-led congress. President Nicolas Maduro's socialist government accuses the opposition of seeking a violent coup with US connivance, while the opposition claims Maduro is repressing peaceful protest. The economic crisis, with millions short of food, fuels the protests, with the opposition seeking new strategies to pressure Maduro into allowing free and fair elections.

site_title: Trump agenda is just voodoo with extra bad maths
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is nearing its 100-day mark, with little substance achieved. Trump's tax cut plan, touted as "massive," is expected to pay for itself with growth, a claim similar to "voodoo economic policy" that has failed repeatedly in the past. Historical evidence shows that tax cuts have not led to economic growth, and recent state-level experiments have also failed. Trump's agenda is seen as indistinguishable from that of other right-wing politicians, characterized by "voodoo with extra bad maths."

site_title: Hedge funds flee to gold for life raft as dollar ship sinks
summary: Hedge funds are increasing their bets on gold, with a 12% advance this year showing potential for further gains. They poured $487 million into SPDR Gold Shares, the largest daily inflow in seven months. Investors are seeking a safe-haven asset amid market uncertainty, particularly with US President Trump's tariff threats on Canada and other countries. The gold rally is seen as a response to the dollar's decline and market volatility, with investors seeking a hedge against potential economic instability.

site_title: EU for Brexit in 2019 will be nothing like the EU today
summary: The UK is set to hold a general election on June 8 to elect a new government, which will help navigate Brexit negotiations. The Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Theresa May, is expected to win a landslide victory, giving them a mandate to implement their Brexit policy. The UK's exit fee from the EU is estimated to be up to £60 billion, but the EU's audited financial records are unclear. The EU's current state is uncertain, with France, Germany, and Italy experiencing anti-EU sentiment, making the post-Brexit relationship uncertain.

site_title: Rising to tech evolution across the board
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) is at the forefront of the maritime industry's shift towards cleaner technologies, including the use of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) for ship fuelling. The MPA is driving efforts to develop advanced technologies, reskill its workforce, and promote innovation, with a focus on automation and remote operations. The authority has signed a memorandum of cooperation with Japan's Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism to promote LNG bunkering in the region. MPA is also establishing the MPA Living Lab to test-bed new systems and capabilities for future port operations.

site_title: Govt-industry team to tackle terror financing, money laundering
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have formed a steering group to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism Industry Partnership (ACIP) will identify key risk areas, while MAS will step up its use of data analytics to tackle the issue.

site_title: New NTU sports hall makes waves with innovative timber construction technology
summary: NTU's new S$35 million sports hall, The Wave, is the first large-scale project in South-east Asia to use Mass Engineered Timber (MET), a technology that reduces on-site manpower needs by 25% and construction time by 33%. The Wave features a 72-metre wave-like timber roof, energy-efficient cooling systems, and reduced maintenance needs. The use of MET is expected to boost productivity and efficiency in the construction sector, with the government aiming to increase its adoption to 40% by 2020.

site_title: Shanghai property prices expected to stabilise in 2017 as market cools
summary: Shanghai property prices are expected to stabilize in 2017 due to cooling measures, according to housing authorities. The market has seen rapid price growth in cities like Shanghai and Beijing, prompting regulators to step in to prevent a crash. Cooling measures have taken some heat out of the market, leading to a stable outlook for 2017.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as Italian, French banks soar after Macron win
summary: European shares rallied, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 2.1% higher, driven by a surge in French and Italian banks following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. Macron's win reduced the risk of an anti-establishment shock and bolstered the case for closer ties between France and Germany. The euro briefly hit five-month peaks, and French bond yields fell to multi-month lows, halting the rapid surge in market anxiety. Banks, including UniCredit and Credit Agricole, led the gains, with the euro zone's bank index rising 7.4% to its highest level in 16 months.

site_title: Data analytics to shape shipping, says Kuehne + Nagel
summary: Kuehne + Nagel CEO Detleft Trefzger emphasizes the importance of data analytics in shaping the maritime sector, citing benefits such as minimizing "phantom bookings" of shipping slots. The use of data analytics can help logistics players make informed decisions, but recruitment and planning challenges will arise due to competition with tech giants like Google and Amazon. Trefzger advocates for cross-sector collaboration to improve data management and customer service, driven by end-consumer demands for greater transparency and expedited delivery.

site_title: UK utilities hit after Tories pledge to cap energy prices
summary: The UK Conservative Party has pledged to cap domestic energy prices if it retains power in the June election, targeting energy companies it accuses of not working properly. Energy bills have doubled in Britain over the past decade, and the proposed cap could cut gas and electricity costs by £100 a year for 17 million families. Shares in energy suppliers Centrica and SSE fell 4-5% after the announcement, with analysts warning that Centrica's strategy could be impacted. The policy echoes a 2015 Labour party pledge and could lead to increased competition in the energy market.

site_title: SMEs going abroad via 'private' path
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are venturing abroad, but often face challenges due to lack of experience and knowledge of local markets. The government has urged SMEs to internationalise, offering grants and support. Private sector companies like RHB Bank and CrimsonLogic are also providing business missions and partnerships to help SMEs expand overseas. These collaborations enable SMEs to tap into local expertise and gain access to relevant contacts, while larger enterprises can benefit from the guidance and support of smaller SMEs. This partnership can lead to greater business growth and expansion, strengthening the global ecosystem.

site_title: Trump officials pick 'high priority' towns for border wall
summary: The Trump administration plans to construct a border wall along the US-Mexico border, focusing on the most highly trafficked corridors, including the Rio Grande Valley in Texas, El Paso, Tucson, and San Diego. The initial plan includes adding over 161 km of new wall, with an estimated cost of over $3.6 billion, on top of the existing 1,126 km of fencing. The areas were selected due to their proximity to urban centers and roads, allowing those who cross to vanish quickly. The plan has been met with mixed opinions from local residents, who are concerned about the impact on private landowners and the effectiveness of the wall.

site_title: Euro surges, yen dives as French election fears abate
summary: The euro surged 1.3% against the US dollar and 1.9% against the yen on Monday following Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential elections, easing concerns about the euro's stability. Investors shifted their attention to the European Central Bank meeting on Thursday. The euro's session high briefly put the currency up 2% against the greenback, while the yen sank. The outcome reduced the prospect of an anti-establishment shock similar to Britain's Brexit vote and US President Donald Trump's election.

site_title: Singapore first Asian port to go paperless with e-certs
summary: The Port of Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Denmark and Norway to promote the use of electronic certificates (e-certs) in maritime trade. The agreement aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs by going paperless, with the Port of Singapore set to become the first Asian port to adopt e-certs. The use of e-certs can speed up inspections of ships, eliminate the risk of documents becoming damaged or lost, and provide better protection against fraud. The three countries plan to share information and experiences to promote the use of e-certs globally.

site_title: 29 Chinese steel firms get licences revoked over violations
summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology revoked licenses of 29 Chinese steel firms for violating state capacity and pollution requirements, resulting in long-term production suspensions. The move is part of China's effort to reduce excess steel production capacity and shut down low-grade steel production by the end of June. Additionally, 40 steel firms have been asked to make changes in environmental protection and safety, with some facing emergency output restrictions and full rectification of violations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezra, a US$500 million offshore services group, will not pay interest on its fixed notes due April 24 as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy restructuring. Marco Polo Marine has engaged banks to discuss refinancing and debt restructuring. StarHub has increased its DNS processing capacity and security measures to prevent future disruptions. Hyflux has appointed financial advisers to evaluate its strategic options for the partial divestment of its Tuaspring plant. Old Chang Kee is being investigated by the police in connection with the Football Association of Singapore probe.

site_title: Container industry adapting to change
summary: The container shipping industry is adapting to changes, including larger vessels, shifting alliances, and new routes. Ports are evolving to meet increasing commercial and operational demands, with PSA International expanding its facilities in Singapore to handle the world's largest container ships. The industry faces economic, environmental, and social challenges, including growing volumes and costs. Consolidation has led to a reduction in major carriers and a shift in alliances, with PSA Singapore planning to develop a mega-terminal in Tuas. Other regional players, such as MMC Corp and Sime Darby, are also expanding their operations.

site_title: Leadership, skills development key to growth of emerging enterprises
summary: Emerging enterprises in Singapore require leaders who are decisive, dexterous, and display good team-building abilities. Effective leaders should have a long-term vision, be able to navigate complexity, and build passion among employees. Skills development is vital in today's digital economy, and emerging enterprises need leaders who can adapt to rapid technological and economic changes. Key skills required include strategic foresight, agility, and digital proficiency. A collective leadership approach, where team members focus on technology and passion for the business, is also crucial.

site_title: Rise of populism reshapes global risks
summary: The rise of populism globally redefines the notion of political risk, shifting from developing countries to Western nations. This shift is driven by a desire to assert domestic democratic sovereignty and rejection of the "cult of the expert." Populism seeks to reverse the power of the international community by utilizing democratic legitimacy to re-assert national interest. The phenomenon is linked to the decline of globalization, with China's Xi Jinping being the unlikely champion. The rise of populism may ultimately be beneficial for developing nations, forcing them to confront mistaken assumptions about development and reconsider their economic transformation strategies.

site_title: Has TPG overstretched itself with Singapore, Australia play?
summary: TPG Telecom, an Australian company, secured favorable spectrum deals in both Singapore and Australia, with a 70% discount on a 60 MHz spectrum package in Singapore, valued at $359.2 million, for $105 million. This move is seen as a strategic play to expand its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. However, TPG's ability to roll out its network in Singapore, estimated to be around $450 million, raises concerns about its financial sustainability and capacity to manage the costs of launching two networks simultaneously.

site_title: Google cash cow thrives below the search bar
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet, is expected to report big profits from its billboard space accompanying Google queries, as the company allocates more space to ads and creates new forms of them. The ad creep has pushed "organic" search results further down the screen, particularly on smartphones. Retailers are snapping up product ads, with 52% of Google search ad spending by retailers in the first quarter of 2017 coming from product listings. Google's goal is to deliver results that people find immediately useful, and the company has removed right-hand text ads for all queries.

site_title: Catalans celebrate St George Day with roses and books
summary: Catalans celebrated St George Day (Sant Jordi) with rose and book exchanges, a tradition dating back to the 15th century, on April 23, 2017. The event, which is now also celebrated in China, saw six million roses and 1.5 million books sold, with retailers expecting a 5-8% increase in sales. The Catalan Book Chamber plans to apply for UNESCO's "intangible world heritage" list, citing the tradition's long history, cultural significance, and potential for future preservation.

images.alt_text: Red roses and books flooded the streets of Barcelona as Spain's Catalonia region celebrated its patron saint on Sunday, with a tradition which is vying for a place on a prestigious UN list.

site_title: South Africa winemakers on quest for quality and prestige
summary: South African winemakers face significant challenges, including price pressure and unsustainable returns on investment. With 40% of producers loss-making and 900 having quit the industry in the past decade, the industry is struggling to maintain viability despite a 50% increase in production between 2005 and 2015. Industry leaders call for higher prices to match the quality and prestige of South African wines, which are often seen as value for money only. The future of the industry rests on the shoulders of young, talented winemakers who can revamp the image of South African wines globally.

site_title: Demand for nuclear shelters, purifiers surges in Japan
summary: Sales of nuclear shelters and radiation-blocking air purifiers in Japan have surged amid North Korea's missile tests. A company has received eight orders in April, compared to six in a typical year, with some shelters selling for up to 25 million yen. Concerns about a possible gas attack have grown, prompting the Japanese government to urge evacuation drills. The increased demand comes as North Korea presses ahead with missile tests, with the US responding by ordering a carrier strike group to sail to the Korean peninsula.

site_title: European markets rally on likely result of French polls
summary: European markets rallied on April 24, 2017, after Emmanuel Macron's clear victory in the first round of France's presidential election. Macron's centrist, eurozone-enthusiast campaign led to a 2.2% jump in the euro against the US dollar. French markets surged, with the CAC index rising 6.1% before settling 4.6% above last week's highs. Analysts predict Macron's new party En Marche! won't gain a majority in the National Assembly, and he'll face challenges in implementing economic reforms.

site_title: Australian player in collaborative workspaces eyes growth in S'pore, Asia
summary: Australian co-working provider WOTSO is expanding its presence in Singapore and Asia through joint ventures and franchise arrangements. The company has already set up a 950 sq m space in The Quadrant in Cecil Street under a joint venture with local management company Springboard Pte Ltd. WOTSO is in preliminary discussions with landlords and existing co-working space operators in Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur, with plans to form joint ventures for new undertakings. The company aims to grow its annualised gross turnover from A$6 million to A$11 million in the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: WOTSO took up 950 sq m at the Quadrant in Cecil Street (above) last August under a joint venture with a Singapore company. About 45 co-working members now use the space.

site_title: Soilbuild Q1 net shrinks 91% to S$0.4m
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 91% decline in Q1 net profits to S$0.4 million, down from nearly S$4 million a year ago, due to lower revenue from completed projects. Revenue dropped 35% to S$66.6 million. The company attributed the decline to projects nearing completion and lack of revenue from new projects. Gross profit margin shrunk to 4% from 7.1% previously. Despite a decrease in assets, the group has a S$493.6 million order book and plans to focus on cost efficiency and productivity in new projects.

site_title: US keeping close eye as piracy rises off Somalia; attacks linked to famine in region
summary: The US is closely monitoring a rise in piracy off the coast of Somalia, with attacks linked to famine and drought in the region. A senior US military official stated that the increase in piracy is driven by the dire conditions. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis visited Djibouti, a key military base in the region, as part of a week-long trip to the Middle East and Africa. The US is keeping a close eye on the situation, amid concerns about the impact of piracy on global security.

site_title: New Zealand mulls restricting laptops on flights from Middle East
summary: New Zealand is considering restricting laptops and other large electronic devices on flights from some Muslim-majority countries in the Middle East, following similar measures introduced by the US, Britain, and Australia. The country's Civil Aviation Authority is assessing the issue and will make a decision independently of the government. The restrictions would affect passengers flying from Dubai in the UAE and Doha, Qatar, where carriers Emirates and Qatar Airways fly direct to New Zealand. The decision is aimed at ensuring flight safety while balancing inconvenience for passengers.

site_title: Waymo urges judge to bar Uber engineer from robocar project
summary: Waymo urges a federal judge to bar Uber engineer Anthony Levandowski from working on its autonomous-driving vehicle project due to allegations of trade secret theft. Levandowski left Waymo to launch his own startup, Otto, which was acquired by Uber for $680 million. Waymo claims Levandowski downloaded thousands of confidential files before leaving the company. The judge is set to weigh whether to issue a court order that may hinder Uber's development of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Billionaire Wei Jianjun is now Jack Wey in branding push
summary: China's Great Wall Motor Co, the country's top SUV seller, is launching a new premium brand called WEY to compete with foreign brands. Chairman Wei Jianjun, who has a net worth of $5.3 billion, aims to increase profit margins by offering higher-end vehicles with features such as cruise control. The brand will target buyers who prefer luxury brands like Kate Spade and Calvin Klein. Great Wall plans to sell 56,000 WEY vehicles this year and expand globally, with a goal of surpassing Jeep and Land Rover as the world's largest SUV brand by 2020.

site_title: Sony surges as analysts say profit may reach highest since 1998
summary: Sony shares surged 4.6% in early Tokyo trading after the company reported better-than-expected preliminary earnings of 285 billion yen (S$3.6 billion) for the fiscal year through March 2017, a 19% increase over its previous forecast. The company also predicted a net income of 73 billion yen, more than twice its previous forecast. This boost in confidence has led analysts to predict that Sony's profit may reach its highest level since 1998, marking its biggest jump since February 2017.

site_title: Iswaran in Indonesia for 3-day visit
summary: Singapore Industry Minister S Iswaran is on a 3-day visit to Indonesia, starting in Jakarta and then Medan, to deepen bilateral economic relations and open up business opportunities. This visit marks Singapore's 50th anniversary of diplomatic ties with Indonesia. The trip aims to explore economic collaboration in areas such as energy, tourism, and infrastructure, with Iswaran meeting Indonesian ministers and regional officials. A business delegation of 10 Singapore companies accompanies Iswaran, highlighting efforts to expand economic ties with regional governments.

site_title: Tesla bets on risky assembly line strategy
summary: Tesla is skipping the traditional preliminary step in building new models and ordering permanent, more expensive equipment to accelerate the production of its Model 3 sedan, aiming to launch it by September. CEO Elon Musk is pushing boundaries in the factory, despite industry norms and potential risks, as the company seeks to deliver five times its current annual sales volume. This strategy, which involves advanced analytical techniques and computer simulations, is a high-risk gamble, but investors are already counting on its success, with shares soaring 39% since January.

site_title: New iPhone puts blue spotlight on Japan OLED screen suppliers
summary: Apple's plan to release at least one iPhone with an OLED screen this year is expected to boost demand by hundreds of millions of units, according to industry estimates. Japanese refiner Idemitsu Kosan Co, which has been experimenting with OLED technology since the 1980s, will join the list of suppliers that supply materials and patents for the advanced displays. The wider adoption of OLED screens is putting the spotlight on Japanese suppliers, including Canon Tokki Corp and Dai Nippon Printing Co, which are leading manufacturers of fine metal meshes needed for OLED pixels.

images.alt_text: Pick up Google's latest Pixel smartphone or a Galaxy model from Samsung Electronics Co, and chances are the blue pixels on the OLED screens are built with Idemitsu's (above) materials or patents.

site_title: Vietnam Bank aims to raise US$700m selling majority stake
summary: Saigon Commercial Bank, Vietnam's fifth-largest bank, is in talks to sell a majority stake to a foreign investor for at least US$700 million. The sale, which is the first of its kind in Vietnam, aims to strengthen the bank's financial products and resolve remaining bad debt. The bank's talks with six potential investors have been approved by the government, paving the way for the potential investment. The sale is expected to attract significant foreign investment in Vietnam's banking sector.

site_title: China's TCL Corp urges Trump to allow US tech acquisitions
summary: TCL Corp chairman Li Dongsheng urged US President Donald Trump's administration to approve a $300 million US tech investment, stating that the delay is unreasonable. TCL is seeking to expand globally by acquiring device parts manufacturers and wants to become the world's largest television producer within 5-10 years. The company has invested $30 billion in display manufacturing facilities and faces challenges from domestic smartphone brands. TCL has also expressed interest in supplying components to Apple, but has not had talks with the company.

site_title: European leaders choose sides in French run-off
summary: European leaders, including Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's top adviser Peter Altmaier, have publicly endorsed centrist Emmanuel Macron in the French presidential runoff, urging voters to choose the candidate who wants to strengthen the European Union. Macron's first-place finish in the first round has boosted hopes that he can steer France back into a central role in European affairs. However, some leaders warn that backing Macron could fan anti-establishment sentiment, while others, like Nigel Farage, have praised Marine Le Pen for her pro-European views, despite her far-right stance.

site_title: Weak medical tourism hits RafflesMed Q1 revenue
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 1.7% year-on-year dip in Q1 revenue to S$114.9 million, despite a 20-odd% decrease in medical tourism patients. The decline was attributed to the effects of currency exchange and a slowing economy. Net profit edged up 0.1% to S$15.55 million, driven by cost containment. The company expects to maintain profitability and is investing in new hospitals in China, including a 700-bed international tertiary hospital in Chongqing, set to open next year.

site_title: HPH Trust flags DPU impact from debt payment plan
summary: Hong Kong port operator Hutchison Port Holdings (HPH) Trust plans to reduce debt by HK$1 billion annually for five years, impacting its distributions per unit (DPU). CEO Gerry Yim expects shipping lines to improve this year, but notes potential tariff squeezes from shipping line mergers. Despite this, he is less concerned about the impact of shipping alliances. The trust aims to pay down debt through this plan, which is expected to take a significant chunk out of its DPU.

site_title: Japan's Mizuho Bank CEO says days of steep asset growth are over
summary: Japan's Mizuho Bank CEO Koji Fujiwara says the days of steep asset growth are over due to stricter banking regulation. Mizuho, Japan's second-largest lender by assets, will focus on balancing its balance sheet, selling existing overseas loans, and offering fee-oriented services. The bank aims to maintain its current asset size while increasing business activity, particularly in overseas lending and M&A advisory. This shift is driven by the high cost of maintaining assets in a low-interest-rate environment and the need to set aside more capital under Basel III global capital rules.

site_title: Philips posts sevenfold jump in profits in Q1
summary: Philips, a Dutch electronics giant, reported a sevenfold increase in Q1 profits to 259 million euros, driven by a spin-off of its lighting business and growth in its health technology portfolio. Sales rose 3.6% to 5.7 billion euros, with medical equipment sales increasing 3%. CEO Frans van Houten attributed the growth to the absence of incidentals and continued operational improvements. The company expects 4-6% full-year sales growth and is confident of a solid second half of the year despite market volatility, particularly in the US healthcare market.

site_title: Gentle Care buys block of HMC convertible notes
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation (HMC) has two large shareholders after Gateway Partners sold S$15 million in face value of its S$60 million convertible notes to Lippo-linked Gentle Care at a 20% premium. Gentle Care now holds 29.42% of total shares and intends to convert the notes into shares. The deal follows the approval of two resolutions at HMC's extraordinary general meeting, allowing Gentle Care to maintain a significant stake without triggering a general offer. The move aims to address HMC's immediate financial needs and stabilize the company.

site_title: RWS staff spread cheer in Clementi
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) successfully held its first volunteers' day, a community outreach effort involving 240 senior management and employees. The initiative, aRWSome Volunteer Day, saw staff spruce up over 30 rental units in the Clementi neighborhood, benefiting elderly and disabled residents. The event marked a new one-day volunteer leave scheme, allowing employees to participate in community events. RWS CEO Tan Hee Teck emphasized the importance of volunteering in improving social mobility in Singapore, with a focus on home repair and improvement works.

site_title: How SMEs can win the battle for talent
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a challenge in attracting and retaining top talent, particularly among fresh graduates. This is due to factors such as starting pay, perceived value of work experience, and resume branding. To win the talent battle, SMEs can implement four strategies: establishing a dedicated talent acquisition and development role, offering above-market compensation and rewards, embracing workforce diversity, and adopting a "coaching versus telling" leadership style. By doing so, SMEs can improve their reputation, attract top talent, and drive business growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Medical Group acquires two pediatric clinics for S$25.3 million with a profit guarantee of S$2.3 million per annum, valuing the group at 11x P/E. CapitaLand Retail China Trust faces headwinds from a weaker RMB exchange rate and higher interest rates, but its steady Q1 performance suggests the market underestimated rental reversions. Viva Industrial Trust's rental income support from Jackson International Private Limited's liquidation is expected to have minimal impact on its financials.

site_title: Market ends mixed despite French polls relief
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed with a net gain of 4.2 points at 3,144.03, despite spending most of the day in the red, due to falls in Hong Kong and China. The market was initially boosted by the result of France's presidential election, which saw the two candidates advancing to the next round, Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron. Dow futures rose 180 points, but the STI was largely unaffected. Local banks finished higher, with the FTSE ST Financials Index rising 1.50.

site_title: Higher rents beef up MIT's Q4 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.88 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter ended March 31, 2017, a 2.5% increase from the previous year. Higher rental rates and revenue contributions from a build-to-suit project for Hewlett-Packard Singapore drove the increase. Gross revenue edged up 4.5% and net property income rose 6.4%. The trust's 86 investment properties were valued at nearly S$3.75 billion, with the hi-tech buildings segment increasing by 21.6%.

site_title: Trump to sign new executive orders on environment, energy
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign new executive orders on environment and energy, including an order to review areas for offshore oil and gas exploration and a measure to designate federal land and water as national monuments. The orders aim to ease regulations and promote energy development, building on previous executive actions by Trump. The moves are part of Trump's efforts to reverse climate change regulations put in place by his predecessor Barack Obama.

site_title: Chinese leasing firms give vital lifeline to industry
summary: Chinese leasing firms are providing a vital lifeline to the shipping industry by offering innovative financing structures, including sale and leaseback agreements. Companies like ICBC Leasing, linked to Chinese banks, have grown rapidly, with ICBC Leasing expanding its portfolio to 268 vessels worth around $6 billion. This trend is helping to keep money flowing through the sector, which has faced troubles in certain segments, such as the offshore market.

site_title: US Supreme Court rejects GM bid to block ignition switch suits
summary: The US Supreme Court rejected General Motors' bid to block hundreds of lawsuits over a deadly ignition-switch defect, potentially worth billions of dollars. The court declined to review a 2016 ruling that rejected GM's attempt to block customer lawsuits due to a lack of proper notification prior to the 2009 bankruptcy. The ruling allows lawsuits to proceed over pre-bankruptcy death, injury, economic loss, and used-car economic losses, with the plaintiffs' lead counsel stating that GM "can hide no more."

site_title: Mixed expectations of price pressures
summary: Singapore's inflation rate is a mixed bag, with some expecting price pressures to rise while others anticipate a decrease. A new study suggests the city-state has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government has also announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. Meanwhile, a centre will be set up to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and the Minister of Trade and Industry will visit the US for trade talks. Employment rates are also expected to improve, with graduates advised to future-proof their careers.

site_title: Citic turns down buyers seeking dollars as bridging finance
summary: Citic Capital Holdings Ltd, the alternative-investment arm of China's largest state-owned conglomerate, has been rejecting requests from firms seeking to use its offshore dollars as a bridge for overseas acquisitions. This decision comes due to China's capital controls, which make it difficult for even state-controlled investment firms to finance deals with domestic resources. The move reflects the challenges Chinese companies face in accessing foreign funds for acquisitions.

site_title: Lawyer representing United passenger takes on American Airlines
summary: Lawyer Thomas Demetrio, representing Dr. David Dao, will also represent a woman whose confrontation with an American Airlines flight attendant went viral. The woman, seen in tears and holding a child, had a stroller forcefully taken from her by a flight attendant before takeoff. American Airlines suspended the attendant and apologized. Demetrio said the woman's case is "compelling" and reflects the "wrong" treatment of passengers in the airline industry. A settlement with United over Dao's incident has not been discussed.

site_title: 139 Cecil Street put up for sale with S$210m price tag
summary: 139 Cecil Street, a 16-storey office building in Singapore, has been put up for sale with an indicative price of S$210 million, or S$2,470 per square foot. The property, owned by the Zhou family and a joint venture between Vibrant Group and DB2 Group, is undergoing a major refurbishment to include offices, food and beverage outlets, and recreational facilities. The sale is expected to close on May 25, and the completion of the refurbishment is slated for the second quarter of 2018, coinciding with an anticipated office market upswing.

site_title: Will Reits continue to return 10% a year?
summary: Real estate investment trusts (Reits) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have delivered a median and average compounded annual return of about 10% a year over the past five years, outperforming the Straits Times Index (STI), which has returned 3.9% a year. This is attributed to Reits' ability to generate consistent dividend payments, making them an attractive investment option for investors.

site_title: Jack Ma sees more pain as Internet upends economy
summary: Jack Ma, Alibaba Group Holding Ltd chairman, warns that the Internet will cause decades of pain as it disrupts the economy, citing automation and job disruptions. He suggests changing education systems and working with robots to mitigate the effects. Ma predicts social conflicts will impact various industries and walks of life, and calls for more lending opportunities to society. He also emphasizes the need for traditional industries to adapt to the Internet's effects, citing Alibaba's creation of millions of jobs. Ma advocates for humans and machines working together, rather than as replacements.

site_title: Nera Telecom bags S$7.15m of contracts with Philippine telco
summary: Nera Telecommunications has secured approximately S$7.15 million in contracts with a Philippine telecom operator for security application equipment. The company will supply, deliver, install, and maintain the equipment under the agreements, which are not expected to significantly impact its performance for the current financial year.

site_title: India now No 2 LPG importer amid drive to use cleaner kitchen fuel
summary: India surpassed Japan as the world's second-largest importer of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), with imports rising 23% to 11 million tonnes during the financial year that ended March 31. The growth is attributed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to provide free cooking gas connections to the poor, resulting in a record distribution of 32.5 million new connections. India's active LPG user count has reached 200 million, exceeding Japan's entire population. The country aims to increase LPG usage to cover 80% of its households by March 2019, driven by a growth of 9.7% in LPG consumption.

site_title: Oldest holocaust museum recasts lessons as 'a warning sign'
summary: The Lohamei Hagetaot Holocaust museum in Israel has recast its lessons to focus on the warning signs of the Holocaust, rather than solely on the atrocities committed during World War II. The museum's director, Dorka Sternberg, shared her personal experience of witnessing the mass shooting of 25 young people in her Polish hometown during a roundup. Sternberg's story serves as a reminder of the dangers of complacency and the importance of recognizing warning signs of genocide, a message the museum aims to convey to visitors.

site_title: US: Wall St surges, Nasdaq hits record on French vote result
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high, as investors breathed a sigh of relief after Centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron won the first round of the French election. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.02%, the S&P 500 gained 1.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.14%. The rally was broad-based, with all 11 major S&P 500 sectors trading higher, led by a 2% surge in the financial index. Investors also look forward to the busiest earnings week in at least a decade, with over 190 S&P 500 members set to report results.

site_title: More than 9,000 malware-infected servers found in Singapore-based Interpol operation
summary: A cybersecurity operation by Interpol at its Global Complex for Innovation in Singapore uncovered over 9,000 malware-infected servers and hundreds of compromised websites in the Asean region, including government portals. The operation involved seven countries and seven private sector companies. This discovery highlights the scope of cyber threats in the region and underscores the importance of international cooperation in combating them. The operation's findings are expected to inform efforts to improve cybersecurity measures in the Asean region.

site_title: Hopes are rising for inclusion of China shares on MSCI
summary: MSCI may add China-listed shares to its global index, a move that could draw up to $400 billion into China stocks over the next decade. The index provider proposed a smaller slate of stocks and confining them to large-cap companies accessible to foreign investors via a trading link with Hong Kong. Despite challenges posed by China's tightly controlled market, investors say the proposal addresses concerns and a successful inclusion is likely this year. MSCI will announce its decision in June.

site_title: US carrier group heads for Korean waters, China calls for restraint
summary: US President Donald Trump sent a US aircraft carrier strike group to waters off the Korean peninsula as a warning amid growing fears North Korea could conduct another nuclear test. China's President Xi Jinping called for restraint in a phone call with Trump, urging all sides to exercise restraint and avoid worsening the tense situation. North Korea responded to the US deployment by calling it an "extremely dangerous act" and warning of catastrophic consequences. The US has vowed to prevent North Korea from hitting the US with a nuclear missile, and China is concerned about the situation spinning out of control.

site_title: Hyflux appoints DBS, China International Capital as financial advisers for Tuaspring plant divestment
summary: Hyflux appoints DBS Bank and China International Capital Corporation as financial advisers to evaluate the strategic options for the partial divestment of its Tuaspring plant. The move is part of the company's asset-light strategy, which was announced in February. Regulatory approvals are required before the divestment can proceed.

site_title: Stocks, euro surge as France's Macron favoured for presidential win
summary: France's moderate candidate Emmanuel Macron won the first round of the presidential election, with a strong chance of winning the run-off against far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. This led to a surge in European stocks, including the DAX reaching an all-time high, and the euro rising above US$1.09. Global investors breathed a sigh of relief, as a Macron victory is seen as a boost to the European Union.

site_title: Euro jumps, yen drops as French worries abate
summary: The euro surged and the yen sank on Monday after the first round of France's presidential election was in line with opinion polls, easing concerns over a systemic shock from the second round. Measures of euro volatility fell to 8.5% from their highest in a year, indicating reduced concern over Marine Le Pen's chances. This decrease in uncertainty led to a decrease in currency market worries.

images.alt_text: The euro surged and the yen sank on Monday after the first round of France's presidential election turned out in line with opinion polls, settling currency market worries of another systemic political shock from next month's second round.

site_title: K1 Ventures sinks into the red for Q3
summary: K1 Ventures reported a loss of S$2.11 million for the third quarter ended March 31, 2017, with revenue falling nearly 94% to S$3.37 million. This is a significant decrease from the profit of S$34.96 million in the same quarter last year, primarily due to the absence of investment income from Knowledge Universe Holdings. The loss per share was 0.49 cents, compared to earnings per share of 8.07 cents a year ago.

site_title: Britons buy fewer houses in Spain after Brexit vote - study
summary: Britons are buying fewer houses in Spain due to the slump in the pound and uncertainty about Britain's future relationship with the European Union following the Brexit vote. According to a Spanish property association, Britons accounted for 19% of foreign home purchases in 2016, down from 21% in 2015. Despite this, British tourists in Spain hit a record last year, and some emigrants are concerned about losing free access to healthcare.

site_title: A*Star to set up two model plants as test beds for new tech and innovation (Amended)
summary: A*Star, Singapore's Agency for Science, Technology and Research, plans to establish two model factories to test-bed cutting-edge manufacturing technologies. The facilities will be set up at the Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre and the Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology. This is part of the government's RIE 2020 plan, which aims to keep Singapore's economy competitive. A*Star will also provide companies with access to advanced manufacturing facilities and training expertise through its Tech Access scheme and Tech Depot, a suite of easy-to-use technologies.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group reviewing current and future acquisitions strategies
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) is reviewing its current and future acquisitions strategies following discussions with the Singapore Medical Council's ethical code and guidelines. The review aims to ensure that any acquisitions align with the code, prioritizing patients' interests over personal or business considerations. SMG will make further announcements as material updates or developments occur.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as French vote sparks rush into banking stocks
summary: European shares surged on Monday after Emmanuel Macron's win in France's presidential election reduced the risk of further political stress for the euro zone. French banks and companies saw significant gains, with the euro zone's bank index rising over 5% to its highest level in 16 months. The STOXX 600 index rose 1.7%, with nine of the top ten gainers being banks, including Commerzbank, Societe Generale, and UniCredit. Analysts expect French banks to be the biggest winners, with some tail risk scenarios being priced out.

site_title: Malaysia, Abu Dhabi settle 1MDB-related row
summary: Malaysia and Abu Dhabi have settled a long-drawn dispute over claims totaling $6.5 billion involving 1Malaysia Development Berhad. The settlement, conditional on the Arbitration Tribunal's consent award by May 2017, allows IPIC to receive $1.2 billion in payments and 1MDB to assume responsibility for $3.5 billion in bond payments. The agreement follows a bitter fallout between the two parties, which included allegations of payments to a British Virgin Island registered firm and claims of misappropriated funds. The settlement marks a positive development for 1MDB, which is nearing the completion of its rationalization program.

site_title: Macron likely to win face-off with Le Pen for French presidency
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron has won through to the second round of the election, defeating far-right National Front leader Marine Le Pen. Macron, who has never held elected office, is the clear favorite to replace outgoing President Francois Hollande, with polls indicating he could crush Le Pen in the final round. The election marks a historic shift, as neither of the traditional mainstream parties has qualified for the second round. Macron's centrist En Marche! movement has gained popularity, while Le Pen's National Front has surged in recent polls, driven by economic pain and anti-establishment sentiment.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Q4 DPU up 2.5%
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 2.5% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, reaching 2.88 Singapore cents. Gross revenue rose 4.5% to S$87.81 million, driven by higher rental rates and revenue from a build-to-suit project. Net property income also increased 6.4% to S$65.97 million. Unitholders will receive their quarterly DPU on May 30.

images.alt_text: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.88 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2017, up from 2.81 cents from a year ago, or a 2.5% increase.

site_title: Ezra not paying interest due on fixed notes
summary: Ezra, an offshore services group, will not pay interest due on its $150 million 4.875% fixed-rate notes due 2018, following its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in the US as part of restructuring efforts. The move is related to its US$500 million multi-currency debt issuance programme.

site_title: Centrism triumphs in France, but EU politicians have cause for concern
summary: France's first round of the general election saw a historic outcome, with centrist Emmanuel Macron beating far-right candidate Marine Le Pen by two percentage points. Macron, a self-proclaimed "neither-left-nor-right" centrist, won 24.9% of the vote, while Le Pen secured 22.1%. Macron's liberal, pro-business, and pro-European platform resonated with voters, and he is expected to win the second round against Le Pen on May 7. This outcome is seen as a victory for centrism, but European leaders, including Angela Merkel, have cause for concern as the French electorate remains divided, with over 40% voting for far-right or far-left candidates.

site_title: India's Reliance Industries posts higher quarterly profit; tops estimates
summary: Reliance Industries, India's largest conglomerate, posted a 12.8% rise in its fourth-quarter net profit to 81.51 billion rupees, topping analysts' estimates of 80.10 billion rupees. The profit increase was driven by higher margins in its core refining, petrochemicals, and oil and gas exploration businesses, controlled by India's richest man Mukesh Ambani.

site_title: Sing Investments Q1 profit doubles to S$5.6m
summary: Sing Investments & Finance's Q1 net profit doubled to S$5.6 million, driven by a 15.6% increase in net interest income and a write-back of S$377,000 in loan allowances. Net interest income rose to S$10.6 million, while loans and advances decreased by 0.1% to S$449.5 million. The company's per-share earnings were 14.18 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: SING Investments & Finance's first-quarter net profit doubled to S$5.6 million amid higher net interest income and a write-back of allowances for loan losses.

site_title: Thailand approves US$393m purchase of Chinese submarines
summary: Thailand's Cabinet has approved a US$393 million purchase of three Chinese-built submarines, worth 36 billion baht (S$1.46 billion), as part of a warming relationship with China. The purchase was confirmed in July and includes a budget of 13.5 billion baht over a six-year period for the Yuan Class S26T submarine. The move signals a shift away from the US after a 2014 military coup, following a cooling of relations with the US. The submarines are expected to enhance Thailand's naval capabilities.

site_title: EU crop monitor ups grain yields, says more rain needed
summary: The European Union's crop monitoring service, MARS, has slightly increased its forecast for this year's main grain yields, with average EU soft wheat yield at 6.05 tonnes per hectare. This would be 8.2% above last year's average yield. However, more rain is needed in several regions to sustain the positive outlook, particularly in central and northern France, Spain, Italy, and south-eastern Europe. Yields for other crops, such as winter barley, grain maize, and oilseeds, have been adjusted, with some decreases and others remaining unchanged.

site_title: Singapore, Denmark, Norway sign MOU to cut administrative burdens in shipping
summary: Singapore, Denmark, and Norway have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to reduce administrative burdens in the shipping industry by promoting the use of E-Certificates. The MOU aims to simplify documentation processes, reduce paperwork, and enhance efficiency in port entry and inspections. The agreement is the first between European maritime authorities and an Asian country, and it seeks to support the digitalization movement in the shipping sector. The three authorities will share information and experiences to promote the adoption of E-Certs.

site_title: Lawyer for Philippines hit-man files complaint against Duterte at ICC
summary: A Philippines lawyer, Jude Sabio, has filed a 77-page complaint against President Rodrigo Duterte and senior officials at the International Criminal Court (ICC), accusing them of crimes against humanity in the country's anti-drugs crackdown. The complaint alleges that Duterte and 11 senior officials are liable for murder and calls for an investigation, arrest warrants, and a trial. The ICC has received over 12,000 complaints, but the tribunal has no powers of enforcement, and the complaint is just the first step in a potentially long process.

site_title: Malaysia pays 1MDB Abu Dhabi debt in election gear-up
summary: Malaysia has agreed to pay Abu Dhabi $2.5 billion as a partial debt settlement for 1Malaysia Development Bhd, clearing a key hurdle in the scandal surrounding the state fund. The deal, set to be announced on the London Stock Exchange, could help Prime Minister Najib Razak move towards closure on the scandal ahead of an early election, possibly this year. The agreement may have a positive impact on Najib's grip on power, particularly among rural Malay voters, but lingering questions over 1MDB may resurface after the election.

site_title: SMA: Profit guarantees prohibited under medical ethics guidelines
summary: The Singapore Medical Association (SMA) has stated that profit guarantees in healthcare services are prohibited under medical ethics guidelines, as they can impose a financial imperative that conflicts with the guidelines. This stance has led to a re-examination of a proposed acquisition of two clinics by Singapore Medical Group (SMG), which had included a five-year profit guarantee of S$2.3 million per year. SMG has committed to reviewing its acquisition strategies to adhere to the highest standards of best practices and ethical guidelines governing the medical profession.

images.alt_text: SMA president Wong Tien Hua said the association hopes all medical professionals involved in buying and selling of medical practices will adhere strictly to the handbook of medical ethics currently in force.

site_title: Weird clouds may have inspired 'The Scream': scientists
summary: Scientists have proposed that Edvard Munch's iconic "The Scream" was inspired by rare clouds that form in cold, high-altitude areas. The swirling, red-orange sky in the painting may have been a depiction of these clouds, rather than a metaphor for mental anguish or volcanic fallout. The painting, released in 1893, features a dark figure clutching its head against a backdrop of eerie clouds, sparking new interest in the artist's inspiration.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose 0.7% in March, driven by foreign price increases and weakening domestic wage pressures. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) launched a partnership to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. Commercial vehicle prices are expected to drop due to a 600% increase in COE supply. Singtel's subsidiaries secured S$4.1 billion credit facilities, while StarHub increased DNS processing capacity and security measures. Singapore stocks closed with a 4.2-point net gain, despite a positive French election result.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher after French vote
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday after French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron won the first round of the French election, easing concerns over political risk. Macron's win reduces the risk of an anti-establishment shock, with him widely expected to win the final vote and keep France in the European Union. This outcome is seen as positive for markets, particularly in Hong Kong.

site_title: UMS Holdings unit lands seven projects worth S$13m
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED UMS Holdings has won seven projects worth S$13 million through its Singapore-incorporated subsidiary, Kalf Engineering, specializing in water and chemical engineering solutions. The projects, including electro-chlorination systems and drinking water treatment plants, are expected to contribute to the group's financial performance in FY17. UMS aims to diversify into the water and chemical engineering business, with CEO Andy Luong stating that the strong portfolio of Kalf's customers indicates a promising strategy.

site_title: Old Chang Kee 'not related' to football club probe, says curry puff maker
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Singapore-based curry puff chain, has denied any involvement in the ongoing police probe into the alleged misuse of Tiong Bahru Football Club funds. One of its independent directors, Zainudin Nordin, is being investigated by the police in connection with the probe, which involves a $500,000 donation. Old Chang Kee's board stated that the investigations are not related to the company and its business operations will continue as normal. The company's stock price rose by one Singapore cent to close at $0.850.

site_title: App allows renting hotel rooms by the minute
summary: A new app called Recharge allows users to rent luxury hotel rooms by the minute, starting at $0.83 per minute in New York. The app, launched in 2015, partners with 16 luxury properties in the city, offering a range of time slots and rates. Users can book rooms for as short as 20 minutes, with prices ranging from $20 to $207. Hoteliers benefit from the service, which fills rooms that would otherwise be vacant during the day. The app is seen as a more efficient way to measure hotel occupancy, with some hotels already reporting six-figure profits from by-minute reservations.

site_title: Samsung to update software over 'red screen' smartphone
summary: Samsung will release a software update to fix the "red screen" issue on its Galaxy S8 phone, a problem that affected some users after pre-ordering. The issue, where the screen displayed a reddish hue, was initially denied to be a hardware flaw but Samsung later confirmed it was a software problem. The update will allow users to adjust the color setting to their preference, addressing concerns raised by users. This move aims to restore Samsung's reputation after last year's Galaxy Note 7 recall debacle.

site_title: HPH Trust Q1 earnings sink
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 69.9% drop in net profit to HK$166.9 million in Q1, mainly due to a one-off refund in 2016. Revenue decreased 6.3% to HK$2.58 billion, while earnings per unit fell to 1.92 HK cents. HPH Trust units rose 1.2% to US$0.41.

site_title: Citic Envirotech lands two projects in China
summary: CITIC Envirotech has secured two projects in China, a 204 million yuan (S$41.3 million) PPP wastewater treatment plant in Xinji City and a 230 million yuan BOT water recycling project in Changyi City. The projects involve investments in wastewater treatment plants with capacities of 100,000 and 30,000 cubic meters per day, respectively. Construction of the Xinji City project will begin in July and be completed by March next year, while the Changyi City project's Phase 1 is expected to be completed by October this year.

site_title: Dealers slash prices ahead of 600% rise in COE quota for commercial vehicles
summary: Dealers in Singapore have cut prices of commercial vehicles ahead of a 600% increase in certificate of entitlement (COE) supply for vans, trucks, and buses. This surge is expected to make commercial vehicle prices tumble. To capitalize on this, motor dealers have reduced prices. The COE quota increase is likely to lead to lower prices for commercial vehicles.

site_title: Philips posts sevenfold jump in profits in Q1
summary: Dutch electronics giant Philips reported a sevenfold leap in Q1 profits to 259 million euros, driven by the spin-off of its lighting business last year. This represents a significant improvement from the same period last year, when the company's net profit was 37 million euros, down 63% due to tax implications.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed as traders brush off positive French election
summary: Singapore stocks closed with a net gain of 4.2 points at 3,144.03, despite a mixed day, as traders largely brushed off a positive French presidential election result. The Straits Times Index fell due to Hong Kong and China's declines, but rose on the Dow futures triple-digit increase. Turnover was 3.3 billion units worth S$1.1 billion, with 220 rises versus 247 falls.

site_title: StarHub increases DNS processing capacity, takes additional security measures
summary: StarHub has increased its DNS processing capacity and implemented additional security measures to prevent future disruptions, following an investigation by the Infocomm Media Development Authority and Cyber Security Agency of Singapore. The disruptions in October 2016 were caused by a surge in legitimate DNS traffic, not a DDoS attack. The company assures customers and regulators that it will continuously review and enhance network resilience in partnership with providers.

site_title: Dubai Aerospace to buy aircraft leasing firm AWAS
summary: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise Ltd (DAE) announced the takeover of aircraft lessor AWAS, adding over 200 planes to its fleet. The combined company will have a total of 394 aircraft valued at over $14 billion. The purchase details were not disclosed. DAE Managing Director Khalifa H. AlDaboos described the acquisition as "strategically compelling" and propelling the company into the top 10 aircraft leasing platform.

site_title: Grant Thornton fined £2.3m over AssetCo audits
summary: Grant Thornton has been fined £2.3m by Britain's accounting watchdog for failing to challenge "fictitious revenues" at listed fire and rescue services firm AssetCo. The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) said the accounting firm and its former partner, Robert Napper, admitted misconduct and agreed to fines and sanctions. The investigation found "flawed judgments" and a lack of professional scepticism, resulting in inflated balance sheets and fictitious revenue. The fine was reduced from £3.5m and Napper was banned from practicing accountancy for three years.

site_title: LafargeHolcim CEO to step down over Syria probe
summary: LafargeHolcim CEO Eric Olsen is stepping down following an internal investigation into the company's activities in Syria. The investigation focused on indirect financing by Lafarge of armed groups to keep a cement plant operational. Olsen's resignation, effective July 15, comes after LafargeHolcim admitted to "unacceptable practices" in March to continue operations at a closed factory in Syria. The company will begin searching for Olsen's successor immediately, with supervisory board chief Beat Hess taking over in the interim. Olsen cited his desire to address "strong tensions" surrounding the Syria case.

images.alt_text: French-Swiss cement maker LafargeHolcim said Monday its chief executive Eric Olsen is stepping down following an internal investigation into the company's activities in Syria.

site_title: China's yuan eases amid strong US dollar demand
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly against the US dollar on Monday, driven by strong demand for the greenback, despite a stronger midpoint fixing by the central bank. The yuan opened at 6.8800 per US dollar and was trading at 6.8875, 0.29% weaker than the previous close. The stronger fixing came after a slide in the US dollar in global markets, following the French election. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8673, and offshore yuan traded at 6.886 per US dollar, 2.74% weaker than the midpoint.

site_title: Thailand reaches for the stars with new Michelin Guide
summary: Thailand is set to receive its first Michelin Guide, becoming the latest country to join the prestigious culinary publication. The guide, released in Thai and English, will feature a star system similar to the original 1900 introduction by the French Michelin company. This marks the sixth Michelin guide in Asia, following China, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Singapore. The move comes despite Thailand's decision to shut down its street food scene, and the guide's release is expected to further boost the country's tourism industry.

site_title: GuocoLand to launch Martin Modern condo project in 2H 2017
summary: GuocoLand Limited Group plans to launch its luxury residential condominium project, Martin Modern, in the second half of 2017. The District 9 project, located near Robertson Quay, will feature 450 units with views of a unique botanic garden and arboretum. The project's group managing director, Cheng Hsing Yao, describes it as a tranquil and enchanted garden, emphasizing its contrast between the urban and natural environments.

site_title: China: Stocks post worst day in four months as regulators tighten grip
summary: China's stocks plummeted 1.4% to 3,129.53 points, marking their worst day in four months, as regulators tightened their grip on shadow banking and speculative trading. Market confidence was hit by an accelerated pace of initial public offerings and concerns about China's economic momentum. Analysts expect the clampdown to continue cautiously to avoid impacting economic growth, while investors adjust their positions amid concerns about property prices and new IPOs.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Markets in Malaysia were closed on April 24, 2017, for a national holiday. No specific events or key facts were mentioned in the provided articles, as they were published on a different date.

site_title: S.Korea: Stocks up at 4-week high
summary: South Korean shares reached a four-week high, closing up 0.4% at 2,173.74 points, driven by global investor confidence following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. The won also rose to a four-week high of 1,129.9 to the dollar. However, concerns about North Korea remain, with tensions heightened after Pyongyang threatened to sink a US aircraft carrier and detained a US citizen. Analysts expect market jitters to ease if North Korea's provocations are limited to short-range missile launches.

site_title: Luxury retailer Jimmy Choo puts itself up for sale
summary: Luxury retailer Jimmy Choo is seeking offers for the company as part of a review to maximize shareholder value. The company has discussed the process with majority shareholder JAB Luxury, which is supportive. Britain's Takeover Panel has agreed that talks with third parties can be conducted within a "formal sale process." Jimmy Choo is not currently receiving any approaches and is exploring its strategic options.

site_title: Aussie, NZ shares edge up on French vote, weaker ore price hurts miners
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.16% to their highest level in two weeks on Monday, driven by relief from centrist Emmanuel Macron's win in the French presidential election. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 9.26 points, with major banks, insurers, and oil majors contributing to the uptrend. However, mining shares fell due to weaker iron ore prices, with BHP Billiton, Fortescue Metals, and Rio Tinto among the biggest losers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Healthway, Raffles Medical, AGV
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation's convertible notes were partially redeemed by Lippo-linked Gentle Care for S$15 million. Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.1% net profit increase in the first quarter despite a 1.7% revenue decline. AGV Group Limited secured new contracts for 29,000 tonnes of steel and iron for several projects. These announcements may influence trading on Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rally on French presidential vote
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.37% on Monday following the first round of France's presidential election, with market-friendly Emmanuel Macron leading far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. The Nikkei 225 and Topix index rose 255.13 and 14.61 points respectively. The positive sentiment was attributed to investors' expectation of a more market-friendly presidency under Macron.

site_title: Aussie, NZ shares up as concerns ease on French vote
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by investors unwinding defensive positions after Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential elections. Macron's win reduced the risk of a French exit from the EU, boosting financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,871.8. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.4%, led by materials and consumer discretionary stocks. Financials and industrials sectors contributed to the gains, while metal stocks, particularly gold and iron miners, fell.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine says no need to suspend trading
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a shipping services company, has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) stating that there is no necessity to suspend trading. The company is engaging with banks and financial institutions to discuss its proposed refinancing and debt restructuring, which, if successful, would allow the company to continue as a going concern. This move aims to address concerns about its debt situation.

site_title: Singapore headline inflation up 0.7% in March
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose 0.7% in March, driven by rising global commodity prices and weakening wage pressures. Core inflation increased 1.2% and is expected to average 1-2% for 2017. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry anticipate a subdued economic environment, limiting businesses' ability to pass on higher costs to consumers.

site_title: Big gains in rail reliability: SMRT
summary: Singapore's train operator SMRT reported a three-fold improvement in rail reliability for its oldest MRT lines, with a 12-month average of Mean Kilometres Between Failure (MKBF) at 180,000km for the North-South Line and 282,000km for the Circle Line. The East-West Line maintained a steady 145,000km. SMRT president Desmond Kuek attributed the improvement to various initiatives. The company also confirmed discussions with Grab to explore partnership opportunities.

site_title: Nearly 30 Chinese steel firms have licenses revoked for violations: ministry
summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology revoked licenses of nearly 30 Chinese steel firms for violating state capacity and pollution requirements. The firms, which had already stopped producing steel, were removed from the official register of steel enterprises. Another 40 firms were asked to make changes in environmental protection and safety. China aims to shed 100-150 million tonnes of excess production capacity by 2020, and 100 million tonnes of low-grade steel production by the end of June. The move is part of a broader effort to regulate the steel industry and reduce pollution.

site_title: For Chinese fans, popular teen band members are mama's boys
summary: In China, a phenomenon of "mother fans" has emerged, where women in their mid-20s to 60s idolize and support popular teen band members, such as TFBoys. These fans, often affluent and with empty nests, lavish attention and money on their favorite idols, like singer Roy Wang, who has won millions of followers since 2013. Their devotion is driven by the idols' wholesome values, good looks, and charitable work, with some fans even making annual pilgrimages to Wang's hometown. This trend is seen as a symptom of empty nest syndrome, where older fans seek attention from their favorite celebrities.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks weak on mixed trading in tech shares, rangebound
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.3% to 9,692.95 on Monday, following a mixed trading day in technology shares. The electronics subindex sank 0.3% and the financials subindex lost 0.1%. The index has remained above 9,600 since early February, but remains short of 9,980.

site_title: UK companies are disclosing gender pay gaps and they're huge
summary: UK companies are disclosing gender pay gaps, with some revealing pay differences as high as 36% - twice the national average. Virgin Money reported a 36% gap, Schroders Plc 31%, SSE Plc 23.4%, and PwC 15%. The disclosures come ahead of a new law requiring companies to calculate the difference between average and median hourly pay rates for all male and female employees. The law aims to address pay inequality and promote transparency in the industry.

site_title: MAS, CAD partner industry players to fight money laundering and terrorism financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) launched a government-industry partnership to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism Industry Partnership (ACIP) brings together industry participants, regulators, and law enforcement agencies to identify and mitigate ML/TF risks. The partnership aims to enhance detection and mitigation of transnational risks, leveraging Singapore's position as an international financial centre and trade hub.

site_title: "Australia first" fortifies position of country's prime minister
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's "Australia first" policy has boosted his voter support, with a recent poll showing a 4% increase in personal rating. The policy, similar to Donald Trump's "America first," tightened immigration and citizenship rules. While this move may have won some support, Turnbull's position as leader remains precarious due to poor polling. The government still trails Labor by a 52-48 margin on a two-party preferred basis, and Turnbull faces a critical budget on May 9 to address economic growth and a deficit. His leadership is on a knife-edge.

site_title: Sony surges as analysts say profit may reach highest since 1998
