summary: Sony shares surged 4.6% in early Tokyo trading after the company reported better-than-expected preliminary earnings, boosting analyst confidence in its ability to hit its highest profit levels in nearly two decades. Preliminary operating profit was 285 billion yen, 19% higher than forecast, and net income was about 73 billion yen, more than twice the previous forecast. Analysts now expect Sony to reach an operating profit of 500 billion yen, a level not seen since 1998, driven by strong performance across most businesses and cost-savings.

site_title: Hopes rise for China share inclusion as MSCI pitches compromise
summary: MSCI has proposed a compromise to include China-listed shares in its global index, narrowing the gap between China and global asset managers. The proposal includes a smaller slate of 169 stocks, accessible to foreign investors via a trading link with Hong Kong, and aims to address market access concerns. While investors remain wary of Beijing's capital outflow restrictions, MSCI's proposal may still lead to up to $400 billion in investments in China stocks over the next decade, with a possible inclusion announcement in June.

site_title: Pence trims Asia trip to deal with domestic priorities
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence has cut short his Asia trip to return to Washington, where the Trump administration faces critical decisions on tax reform and government funding. Pence had planned to visit Honolulu but will now spend only one night there before returning to Washington on Tuesday. His trip was overshadowed by rising tensions in North Korea, and he will meet with US Pacific Command leaders and US troops in Honolulu instead. The trip comes as the administration faces a critical week ahead, with a government funding deadline on Friday and President Trump's 100th day in office on Saturday.

images.alt_text: US vice-president Mike Pence has cut short the final leg of his Asia trip to race back to Washington, where the Trump administration faces a critical week on tax reform and a funding plan to keep the government running, an aide said on Sunday.

site_title: London house prices post biggest annual decline in eight years
summary: London house prices declined 1.5% annually to £636,777 in April, the largest annual drop in eight years, according to Rightmove. The decline is attributed to unaffordable valuations, the Brexit vote, and tax increases on investors. Inner London areas posted a 4.2% annual decline, while outer suburbs saw a 1.7% increase.

site_title: BlackRock fund manager leans towards bonds
summary: BlackRock fund manager Justin Christofel remains cautious despite improved economic fundamentals, citing concerns over asset valuations and price. He expects equity returns to keep pace with earnings growth in the high single-digits, but not meaningfully higher. The BGF Global Multi-Asset Income Fund has shifted to a more conservative 60% fixed income allocation, seeking mid-single digit returns with less risk. Christofel is also concerned about US market multiples and interest rates, but sees room for growth in emerging markets and high-yield bonds.

site_title: Singtel units ink agreements for S$4.1b credit facilities with banks
summary: Singtel's subsidiaries, Singtel Group Treasury and Optus Finance, have signed agreements for S$4.1 billion credit facilities with 27 banks for general corporate purposes and refinancing existing facilities. The agreements, worth S$2.5 billion and A$1.5 billion respectively, reflect confidence in the Singtel Group's credit quality and business fundamentals. The facilities will be guaranteed by Singtel and certain of its subsidiaries, with a three-year term for both agreements.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won pare gains as traders eye North Korea risks
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose to multi-week highs on Monday before paring gains due to concerns over North Korea's military risks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) reached 2,171.61 points, while the won rose 0.1% against the US dollar. Investors remain cautious amid potential North Korean provocations, but are also drawn to riskier assets following the French presidential election result. Market analysts expect market jitters to decrease if North Korea limits its actions to short-range missile launches.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares and the won hit multi-week highs early on Monday before paring gains amid worries that North Korea could conduct another missile or nuclear test.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after France vote
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.60% on Monday after pro-European Emmanuel Macron won the first round of France's presidential election, setting him up for a likely victory in the run-off against far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,185.76, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.28%. This follows a broader Asian advance, with Singapore and US stocks also experiencing gains.

site_title: Boxing: Pacquiao declares 'I'm not done yet'
summary: Manny Pacquiao, a 38-year-old boxing veteran, announced his plans to defend his world title against Australian Jeff Horn in Brisbane, Australia on July 2. Pacquiao, an eight-weight world champion, aims to prove he can continue to be a global force in boxing while balancing his full-time job as a senator. He expressed excitement to face Horn and vowed to do his best to entertain the fans, despite being the overwhelming favourite in the bout. Pacquiao has not stopped an opponent since 2009, and the fight is seen as an opportunity to prove his continued relevance in the sport.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at multi-month lows vs euro on French vote
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the euro on Monday, but the euro's rise was attributed to the election of centrist Emmanuel Macron in France, reducing the risk of an anti-establishment shock in the EU. The euro surged to its highest against the Australian dollar since early January, while the Aussie held steady at US$0.7556. The New Zealand dollar was largely unchanged at US$0.7031, with the yen seeing a surge to a 3-week peak. The euro's success is seen as positive for the Australian dollar.

site_title: China cools growth in wealth products worth trillions of dollars
summary: China's wealth-management products (WMPs), worth trillions of dollars, have slowed in growth due to regulatory scrutiny. As of March 31, outstanding WMPs stood at 29.1 trillion yuan, a 18.6% increase from last year. Despite this, WMPs have nearly tripled in value over the past three years and remain at a record level. Regulators are drafting rules to plug loopholes in regulations for WMPs and have started to include them in macro prudential assessment frameworks to gauge credit expansion and potential risks.

site_title: May faces rough ride from France on Brexit if Macron wins vote
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces a "pretty tough" time in Brexit negotiations if Emmanuel Macron wins the French presidency, as he has pledged to protect the EU's integrity. Macron's pro-European stance and promise to make Britain pay for its EU departure could hinder May's efforts to secure concessions. A Macron win could also lead to increased euro-skepticism, making a benign Brexit deal less likely.

site_title: Euro rises to five-month high as Macron, Le Pen lead French vote
summary: The euro rose to a five-month high against the US dollar after the first round of the French election showed centrist Emmanuel Macron and nationalist Marine Le Pen were set to reach the second round. Macron and Le Pen each took around 23% of the vote, avoiding a potential euro slump if Le Pen had won. The euro traded 1.8% higher at US$1.0920, with investors optimistic about Macron's chances in the second round and a potential boost to French bonds.

site_title: Trump to insist on border wall funds as budget deadline looms
summary: US President Donald Trump is pressing for funding of a border wall with Mexico as a budget deadline looms, threatening a potential government shutdown. The White House is prepared to make concessions on health care reform to secure the wall funding, but Trump has vowed to veto the larger spending bill if the wall isn't funded. The president's approval ratings have reached a record low, with 42% of Americans approving of his performance. Democrats have shown little interest in compromise, with Senator Dick Durbin calling the border wall proposal "outlandish."

site_title: DeClout's unit launches incubator arm to groom local ICT startups
summary: DeClout Limited's subsidiary DeClout Investments has launched an incubator arm to support local ICT startups. The program will mentor early-stage companies in fintech, cybersecurity, data analytics, and smart logistics. DeClout will receive support under SPRING Singapore's Startup SG Accelerator scheme. The incubator aims to groom high-growth startups, focusing on disruptive innovation in key ICT market niches.

site_title: Australia okays Alinta Energy's takeover by HK's Chow Tai Fook
summary: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, a Hong Kong conglomerate, has received Australian regulatory approval to acquire Alinta Energy Holdings, a gas and electricity provider. The deal, valued at over A$4 billion, is subject to strict conditions. This follows a similar path as Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings, which recently won approval for a A$7.4 billion takeover of Duet Group. The acquisition is expected to be completed after satisfying regulatory requirements.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 12.13 points, or 0.39%, to 3,151.96 on Monday, driven by gains from banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank. The euro spiked to a five-month high against the US dollar following early voting in the French presidential election, which may favor centrist Emmanuel Macron and the National Front's Marine Le Pen. Trading volumes were high, with 249.5 million shares worth S$131.9 million changing hands.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q1 profit climbs 0.1% to S$15.5m despite lower revenue
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group reported a net profit of S$15.5 million in its first quarter, up 0.1% from the same period last year, despite a 1.7% decline in revenue to S$114.9 million. The group attributed the revenue drop to softer-than-expected demand from foreign patients. Basic earnings per share decreased marginally to 0.89 Singapore cents, and no dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: Oil recovers some lost ground, but market under pressure
summary: Oil prices recovered some ground on Monday, rising 0.5% for WTI crude and 0.5% for Brent crude, to US$49.85 and US$52.23 per barrel, respectively. The gains were driven by expectations that OPEC will extend production cuts for six months to cover all of 2017, but US drilling continued to rise, limiting gains. US crude production reached 9.25 million barrels per day, surpassing OPEC's top exporter Saudi Arabia. Oil prices remain below pre-weekend levels, with Brent and WTI down over 7.5% since the end of last year.

site_title: Staying ahead of the competition
summary: Singapore's maritime sector faces challenges in maintaining its leadership position in a fast-changing global economy. Despite its success, the country must adapt to growing competition in the region and emerging technologies disrupting businesses. To stay ahead, Singapore has invested in infrastructure, R&D initiatives, and a transparent legal system. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore has set up the IMC 2030 Advisory Committee to chart the future direction of the sector and identify new growth areas. Industry players emphasize the need for Singapore to step up its emphasis on security, efficiency, and innovation to remain relevant and competitive.

site_title: French election: what you need to know
summary: French presidential election second-round runoff is set for May 7 between centrist Emmanuel Macron and far-right Marine Le Pen, with Macron projected to win. Macron's pro-European, pro-globalization vision faces off against Le Pen's hostility to the EU and NATO. A runoff is rare, but not unprecedented, and could further shake up the West's liberal post-war order, echoing recent Brexit and Trump election outcomes.

site_title: Saudi king restores bonuses for state employees as revenue increases
summary: Saudi King Salman has restored bonuses and allowances for state employees, appointed Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman as ambassador to the US, and promoted Prince Khalid bin Salman within the energy ministry, as part of efforts to bolster economic growth and reorganize the government. The decision comes amid a slowing economy and a prolonged war in Yemen, with revenue increasing and the budget deficit declining. The king's decrees also include a two-month salary bonus for Saudi forces serving in Yemen.

site_title: Space, the final frontier seen for earth's crude oil giants
summary: The Middle East, particularly countries like the UAE and Saudi Arabia, are investing in space programs and private space initiatives to tap into the development of natural resources in space. Analysts predict that water, a crucial resource for space travel, will become a valuable commodity, with the UAE and Saudi Arabia potentially leveraging their space programs to build extraterrestrial reserves. Space mining, although still in its infancy, has the potential to ease access to space, and companies are expected to launch satellites to search for rare gases and metals in asteroids within five years.

site_title: Choice of HK listing paying off for 2 Singapore startups
summary: Two Singapore startups, CMON and Anacle, have reported increased revenues and headcounts since listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) last year. CMON, a games company, saw a 22% increase in revenue to US$21 million in 2016, while Anacle, a property and energy management systems provider, reported a 22% increase in total revenue to around S$9.93 million in the nine months ending February 2017. Both companies attribute their growth to the higher profile and increased market reach resulting from their listings.

site_title: Former Shenzhen bourse official fined 251m yuan
summary: China's securities regulator fined former Shenzhen bourse official Feng Xiaoshu 251 million yuan for making illegal trades to profit from company IPOs. Feng used relatives' accounts to buy shares ahead of listings, selling them after prices rose. He will be barred from the market for life. This fine underscores Beijing's drive to root out bad behavior in its equities markets amid rising speculative activity and leverage in the economy.

site_title: AGV Group wins new projects totalling 29,000 tonnes of steel and iron
summary: AGV Group Limited, a Singapore-based hot-dip galvanising services provider, has secured new contracts totaling 29,000 tonnes of steel and iron for public and private sector projects, including Seletar Airport and a mega oil refinery. The 15,000-tonne contracts in Singapore bring AGV's total tonnage for the current financial year to 22,618.

images.alt_text: Albert Ang(left), AGV's chief executive officer and co-founder, said: "Hot-dip galvanising is essential for the longevity of any industrial object made of steel or iron. The fact that we are servicing companies from a broad spectrum of industries is testament to our track record, and we are pleased to play a role in the development of various buildings and infrastructure not only in Singapore but also Malaysia."

site_title: He fancies shophouses in Singapore
summary: Zain Fancy, founder of Clifton Partners, remains focused on shophouses in Singapore, despite evaluating high-end residential transactions. Over the past four years, the group has sold nine conservation shophouses for about S$90 million, more than doubling its initial investment. Clifton currently holds 11 shophouses valued at nearly S$170 million, with four on the market for sale. Fancy attributes the appeal of shophouses to their limited supply, high proportion of renovated and gentrified units, and favorable government conservation policies.

site_title: Why US police would rather pass the buck when it comes to cybercrime
summary: US police lack training and resources to effectively investigate and prosecute cybercrimes, resulting in many cases going unreported and unpunished. Despite the FBI's efforts, local police officers often view cybercrime as the federal government's problem, and many lack the necessary training and expertise to tackle these cases. The lack of resources and cultural shift in policing means that perpetrators often escape punishment, with victims often bearing the financial burden. To address this, experts advocate for national training programs for prosecutors and police to improve their cybercrime skills and combat the growing threat of online crimes.

site_title: Gold tumbles most in more than seven weeks after French election
summary: Gold prices dropped 1.5% to US$1,265.51 an ounce, the largest decline in seven weeks, following Emmanuel Macron's win in the French presidential election. The euro surged, hurting the US dollar, and investors shifted to riskier assets. Macron's victory avoids a potential contest between Marine Le Pen and Jean-Luc Melenchon, reducing euro zone risk. Safe-haven buying in gold may dry up as markets become more optimistic about the economy.

images.alt_text: Gold slumped the most in more than seven weeks as investors returned to riskier assets on speculation pro-growth centrist Emmanuel Macron will become France's next president after the first round of voting.

site_title: Happy Days, Joanie Loves Chachi's Erin Moran dies at 56
summary: Erin Moran, the former child actress who played Joanie on Happy Days and Joanie Loves Chachi, has died at 56. Moran was found unresponsive in southern Indiana and an autopsy is pending. She began acting at age 5 and rose to fame with Happy Days, but her career declined after the show ended. Moran spoke publicly about the pressures of growing up in the spotlight and the decline of her acting career.

site_title: Macron, Le Pen reach French runoff as established parties crash out
summary: Centrist Emmanuel Macron and far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen won the first round of the French presidential election, triggering a runoff on May 7 between two radically different visions of the country's future. Macron, a first-time candidate, secured 23.4% of the vote, while Le Pen took 22.6%. This outcome marks the first time in modern French history that both establishment parties were eliminated in the first round, reflecting the anger and discontent of a society traumatized by Islamic terrorism and economic woes.

site_title: A grim view of urban planning
summary: A new documentary, Citizen Jane: Battle for the City, explores the life and work of urban planner Jane Jacobs, who criticized the discipline and its often-disastrous outcomes for the poor. The film, produced by Oscar-nominated filmmaker Matt Tyrnauer, examines Jacobs' legacy in the context of the current US administration's infrastructure plans, which Jacobs would have advised caution on due to concerns of collusion and self-dealing. The film is set to be shown in over 20 US cities, coinciding with the release of new books about Jacobs' life and work, including a biography and compilation of her short writings.

site_title: Bring back Glass-Steagall? Goldman Sachs would love that
summary: The Trump administration is considering revisiting the Glass-Steagall Act, which separated investment banking from commercial banking in the 1930s. However, experts argue that this would not address the root problem of improper incentives on Wall Street, where bankers are rewarded for taking big risks with other people's money. In fact, Goldman Sachs, a powerful Wall Street firm, would likely benefit from such a law, as it would eliminate its competitors. The idea is also opposed by banks' clients, customers, and counterparties. Instead, policymakers should focus on addressing the underlying issues, such as excessive risk-taking and lack of personal accountability.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up 1.4% as Macron leads French presidential race
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index rose 1.4% on Monday as investors reacted to Emmanuel Macron's lead over Marine Le Pen in the French presidential race. The Nikkei 225 jumped 270.21 points to 18,890.96, while the Topix index rose 1.25% to 1,507.24. The positive news boosted shares globally, with markets looking ahead to US-EU trade talks and the release of GDP data.

site_title: Sobbing mother video raises controversy for American Air
summary: American Airlines is facing controversy after a video surfaced of a flight attendant confronting a passenger who defended a sobbing mother with a baby in her arms. The airline is investigating the incident, which comes just weeks after United Airlines sparked a public relations crisis for dragging a passenger from his seat on an overbooked flight. The American Airlines video has sparked similar outrage and calls for the airline to take action, highlighting the need for improved customer service and handling of sensitive situations on flights.

site_title: Trump's infrastructure upgrade plan 'a boon for Australian iron ore exports'
summary: US President Donald Trump's infrastructure upgrade plan is expected to drive demand for steel, supporting Australian iron ore exports. According to Finance Minister Mathias Cormann, the plan's steel requirements will lead to increased global demand, benefiting Australian iron ore exports. This is seen as a positive development for Australia's iron ore industry.

site_title: Obama picks Chicago for first major post-presidency appearance
summary: Former US President Barack Obama is set to make his first major post-presidency appearance in Chicago, where his career began, to meet youth leaders and promote community organizing. Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel praised the choice, saying it reflects Obama's emotional and intellectual commitment to the city. The event aims to encourage and support the next generation of community leaders. Obama's continued connection to Chicago is seen as important for the city, which is grappling with issues like gun violence and economic inequality.

site_title: Japan Post may write down 400b yen over Toll acquisition
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co is considering writing down up to 400 billion yen (S$5.1 billion) in goodwill from its 2015 acquisition of Australian logistics unit Toll Holdings due to the lack of synergies and economic slowdown affecting Toll's earnings. This could lead to Japan Post's first net loss since Japan's postal system privatization. The estimated group net profit for the year ended March 31 is 320 billion yen.

site_title: Malls turn to concerts, food trucks to compete with online stores
summary: US malls are hosting events such as concerts, food-truck festivals, and carnivals in their parking lots to compete with online stores and attract visitors. The events aim to generate revenue and encourage shoppers to spend money inside the malls. Mall owners are also exploring experience-driven offerings, such as rotating pop-up shops and adding restaurants and activity centers. This strategy is seen as a way to revitalize declining mall traffic and rents, with some landlords reporting gains of up to $60,000 per week from large outdoor events.

site_title: It's time to deploy the US financial system against North Korea
summary: The US should adopt secondary sanctions against North Korea to cut its access to the international financial system, similar to the approach used against Iran. This move would isolate North Korea's banks and trading companies, forcing Chinese banks to choose between facilitating the regime's international banking capacity and maintaining their own access. The Trump administration should start by applying sanctions to midsize Chinese banks that aid North Korean front companies, sending a strong message to North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un that the financial noose is tightening. This could drive a wedge between him and the Pyongyang elite and demonstrate the US's commitment to generating leverage for a successful negotiation.

site_title: Citi gains from Asean's rapid urbanisation as middle class grows
summary: Citi's Asean business continues to grow, driven by the region's rapid urbanization and expansion of the middle class. The bank's wealth management, cards, and investment banking businesses are seeing significant traction, with globality being a key competitive advantage. Citi's Asean revenue grew 8% in Q1 2017, while the region contributes about 30% to Asia revenue. The bank has also seen success in capital raising and mergers and acquisitions, and is investing heavily in digitalization to drive revenues, with notable achievements including voice biometrics customer authentication and mobile app-based card acquisition.

site_title: May proposing energy price cap ahead of UK polls
summary: The UK's Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Theresa May, is proposing a cap on household gas and electricity prices as part of its campaign platform for the June 8 election. The plan, similar to a proposal made by former Labour leader Ed Miliband, aims to cut £100 off the average family's annual utility bill. The move is seen as an attempt to woo Labour voters in key swing districts, despite the Conservatives already holding a significant lead in polls.

site_title: Second Chance's 2nd warrant worth a punt?
summary: Second Chance Properties (SCP) has two warrants in issue, a 5-year and a 3-year instrument. The 5-year warrant, listed in 2012, has an exercise price of S$0.40 and expires soon, but its intrinsic value is minimal due to the high share price. The 3-year warrant, listed in 2023, has an exercise price of S$0.25, an intrinsic value of S$0.01, and can only be exercised after the expiration of the first warrant. The warrants are currently undervalued, with the 3-year warrant selling at S$0.008, suggesting a potential for growth if the property market improves.

site_title: Tackling Toronto's tearaway property prices through taxes
summary: Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz expressed support for Ontario's new measures to tackle Toronto's housing market, including a 15% tax on foreign property buyers. The tax aims to dampen demand and influence speculators' psychology. Poloz noted that Toronto prices have become disconnected from fundamentals, with signs of speculative demand. He highlighted the improvement in mortgage debt quality due to government tightening of mortgage rules. Poloz cautioned that uncertainty remains high, with geopolitical risks and the need for cautious optimism in economic forecasts.

site_title: Bond bulls see opportunity as US government shutdown deadline nears
summary: Bond traders anticipate a US government shutdown deadline on April 28 will drive 10-year yields down to 2%, as strategists expect a prolonged impasse. The upcoming deadline, with no major economic data or Federal Reserve speakers, is expected to take center stage this week. The potential showdown could breathe new life into the Treasury market's rally, with the rally currently underway.

site_title: French presidential poll a bellwether for Europe
summary: France held its first round of presidential election, with voters deciding on a pro-EU centrist, a scandal-ridden conservative, a far-left eurosceptic, or France's first woman president. The outcome will show whether the populist tide that saw Brexit and Trump's election is still rising or ebbing. Centrist Emmanuel Macron is favored to win the first round and beat far-right Marine Le Pen in the two-person run-off. A low turnout, around 28.54%, has added to nervousness, with some polls suggesting a high or low turnout could have significant implications for the future of Europe.

images.alt_text: A voter picking up a ballot at a polling station in Rennes, western France, during the first round of the French presidential election on Sunday.

site_title: Brexit makes campsites cool again as Britons tighten belts
summary: Brexit has led to a surge in demand for "staycations" in the UK, with British tourists opting for domestic holidays due to a weakened pound. This trend reflects the need for cost-effective alternatives as inflation rises. The plunge in the pound has pushed up the cost of holidays abroad, making foreign trips less appealing to British consumers. As a result, campsites and holiday cabins are seeing increased bookings, with some sites reporting full occupancy. This shift is expected to continue as consumers seek ways to stretch their limited budgets.

site_title: China's 6.5% GDP growth target is within reach, says PBOC governor
summary: China's PBOC governor Zhou Xiaochuan expressed confidence that the country's 6.5% GDP growth target for this year is within reach, citing control over financial risks and a prudent monetary policy. The nation aims to prevent and eliminate systemic risks through improved macro-prudential policy framework and deleveraging measures. Figures released earlier showed China's economy accelerated for a second straight quarter, driven by robust credit growth and property market strength. The country will continue to guide market interest rates and tackle excess capacity in industries such as coal and steel.

site_title: Beijing cracking down on property financing via trusts
summary: China's banking regulator has instructed trust companies to rein in funding to the booming real estate sector, amid concerns over risks in the property market and shadow-finance industry. The directive aims to curb disguised property financing through trusts, partnerships, and asset management plans. The move is part of a broader campaign to tackle China's overheated housing market and expansion of funding via lightly-regulated asset-management products.

site_title: Tough regimen helps cure Finland's economic ills
summary: Finland's economy is showing signs of progress after years of budget cuts and tax increases, with a predicted 1.6% expansion this year. The country has left recession behind and is gaining a broader growth base, driven by a recovery in exports and consumer confidence. Labour costs are decreasing, narrowing the gap with competitors, and the government is working on new measures to boost employment, including better matching of job openings and incentives for the unemployed.

site_title: HC Surgical scopes out specialist-care opportunities
summary: Colorectal surgeon Dr Heah Sieu Min has expanded his business, HC Surgical Specialists, to 12 clinics in Singapore, focusing on endoscopy services to treat patients with conditions such as haemorrhoids and colon cancer. The company, listed on the Singapore Exchange, aims to increase its presence in Asian markets, particularly Vietnam, where it has partnered with Transport Hospital to provide consultancy and training services. Dr Heah believes that by offering endoscopy services, the company can attract more patients and increase revenue. The company has a current market capitalization of over S$85 million and plans to pay out at least 70% of its profit as dividends.

images.alt_text: With multiple irons in the fire, Dr Heah has much to look forward to, and the outlook is bright.

site_title: EU mulling over uniform set of laws to fight online hate speech and calls for violence
summary: The European Union is considering a uniform set of laws to regulate online platforms' removal of hate speech and incitement to violence. A draft policy paper highlights the variation in approaches taken by companies like Facebook, Twitter, and Google, citing concerns over delayed removal of terrorist propaganda. The EU executive is exploring options to clarify the role of online platforms without compromising liability exemptions, including a "good Samaritan" principle that would encourage proactive measures to maintain a healthy online ecosystem. Legislative measures may be introduced by the end of the year to address legal fragmentation.

site_title: Clubs still milking millions from jackpot cash cows
summary: Social clubs in Singapore continue to generate significant revenue from jackpot operations, with some clubs earning millions in a single year. The Tiong Bahru Football Clubhouse, for example, generated S$36.8 million in revenue from its 29 slot machines in the last financial year. Despite concerns over the potential for addiction and the need for alternative income sources, many clubs remain dependent on jackpot machine earnings. The government's tax collection from betting duties, including slot machines, reached S$2.7 billion in 2016, highlighting the significant revenue generated from these activities.

site_title: Sabana Reit EGM: Is dismissing the manager the panacea?
summary: Sabana Reit, a Singaporean Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit), is facing challenges in the leasing environment and weak macroeconomic conditions. Unitholders expressed concerns about the Reit's manager's failure to preserve unit value, resulting in a 50% loss since listing. The Reit's board is conducting a strategic review, considering options such as changing the manager, internalizing the manager's function, or winding up the Reit. Unitholders are advised to wait for the review's recommendations and evaluate the pros and cons of the resolutions before making a decision, as voting out the manager could impact the strategic review process.

site_title: Germany's AfD picks election duo after unruly party congress
summary: Germany's Alternative for Germany (AfD) party has chosen a new election duo after a fractious party congress. Alexander Gauland, a 76-year-old hardline defector, and Alice Weidel, a 38-year-old openly lesbian investment banker, will lead the party into the September general election. Gauland and Weidel were chosen after a two-day debate on the party's platform and personnel, with the party sidelining its most prominent personality. The AfD's selection of Gauland and Weidel aims to present a more unified front ahead of the election.

images.alt_text: Ms Weidel and Mr Gauland (right) celebrating their nomination as campaign leaders of the AfD party for the next German general election, during the party congress at the Maritim Hotel in Cologne on Sunday.

site_title: Euro weakens with French election in focus
summary: The euro weakened 0.14% against the US dollar ahead of Sunday's French presidential election, with investors bracing for a tight contest between Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen. Despite polls suggesting Macron's lead, options markets indicate concern over Le Pen's chances, contributing to de-risking and a decrease in the euro. The dollar rose 0.14% as investors prepared for tax plan details from President Trump.

site_title: Rising US crude output suggests Opec may have lost its battle with shale
summary: Opec's efforts to cut oil production have failed, as US crude output has risen by over 550,000 barrels a day in 20 weeks, with shale formations accounting for much of the increase. The US Department of Energy forecasts US production to reach 9.24 million barrels a day by July, a 700,000-barrel-a-day increase since November 2016. The stronger outlook for US production has little to do with higher price expectations, and Opec faces a long-term struggle against shale, which is in its infancy and has the potential to disrupt the industry.

site_title: IReit Global widens investment mandate to include retail and industrial sectors
summary: IReit Global, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (Reit), has expanded its investment mandate to include retail and industrial sectors beyond its previous focus on European office assets. The move aims to diversify and boost long-term income growth. The trust's new manager, Aymeric Thibord, cited rising competition in the office sector and the need to reduce tenant concentration risk as reasons for the expansion. The trust will explore investment opportunities in France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the Netherlands across office, retail, and industrial sectors, with a focus on logistics.

site_title: Draghi could take faster route to tapering QE
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi may signal the start of tapering quantitative easing and revising forward guidance as early as June, six months sooner than previously thought. Economists predict the ECB will start reducing asset purchases and eventually hike interest rates, with most expecting tapering to begin by the first quarter of 2018. The decision may be influenced by the outcome of the French presidential election, which could pose a threat to the euro area.

site_title: Fed moves key factor for Indonesian central bank
summary: The Indonesian central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4.75% due to a focus on managing price pressures and bolstering the currency, despite US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. Deputy governor Perry Warjiyo noted that the Fed's fund rate increases impact emerging nations by luring capital and driving up dollar borrowing costs. The central bank expects inflation to pick up this year, but growth is seen as below expectations in the first quarter, with exports and domestic consumption expected to drive growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Frasers sells almost 400 units of Seaside Residences (Amended)
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited sold approximately 70% of the 560 released units of its Seaside Residences condominium at an average price of S$1,700 per square foot. Strong demand was seen, especially among buyers aged 30-50 who value the location's seaside lifestyle and convenience of the upcoming MRT. The sales results show buyers value the location, design, and building quality of the developer, with some 60% of buyers from the east and 30% from District 15.

site_title: eSports goes from gaming to big money league
summary: E-Sports has evolved from a niche hobby to a lucrative profession, with total prize money quadrupling in the last four years to $93.3 million in 2016. Unibet projects this year's prize money could reach $150 million, with the top players earning millions. The industry's growth is driven by increasing viewership, with 162 million frequent viewers and 161 million occasional viewers in 2016. The US is the best-represented nation, with China trailing behind in terms of historical earnings.

images.alt_text: With eSports having just been announced as an official medal sport for the 2022 Asian Games in China, it is time to recognise just how established and lucrative the competitive gaming industry has become.

site_title: Tax breaks enjoyed by Trump's own field
summary: US President Donald Trump plans a sweeping tax overhaul, aiming to lower individual and corporate rates, simplify the tax code, and boost economic growth. However, his own real estate industry interests pose a major roadblock to this goal. The tax deduction for interest payments by businesses, a provision Trump has used to great advantage, is a key target for elimination. The real estate lobby, led by Trump and his allies, is fighting to preserve these deductions, which benefit Trump's own businesses and those of small builders, brokers, and contractors. Experts warn that eliminating these deductions could offset lower tax rates and reduce overall corporate tax revenues.

site_title: BOJ policy board to meet amid trade friction threat
summary: The Bank of Japan's Policy Board is set to meet amid escalating trade friction with the US, with the US Treasury Secretary urging the IMF to monitor exchange rates. Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso rejected the idea that exchange-rate adjustments can solve trade imbalances, and the BOJ is expected to maintain its aggressive monetary easing despite US pressure. The IMF warned of growing uncertainty and downside risks, threatening global economic growth, which has been picking up recently.

site_title: Japan, Russia to approve first set of bilateral projects
summary: Japan and Russia are set to approve around 20 bilateral economic cooperation projects, including promoting Japanese pharmaceutical exports and energy development in Russia. The projects, proposed by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, cover fields such as energy, medical care, and urban development. Agreements include Mitsui & Co acquiring a stake in Russian drugmaker R-Pharm and Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation teaming up with a Russian resource development company to develop crude oil and gas in Irkutsk, Russia. The projects aim to spur the concrete realization of the 80 specific cooperation projects signed in December.

site_title: IMF members set aside trade split as French vote rattles nerves
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) members dropped their pledge to fight protectionism amid concerns over the first round of France's presidential election, which could lead to a far-right or far-left victory that could impact global economic integration. The IMF, led by Christine Lagarde, shifted its focus to a "sharing and inclusive growth" policy, and instead of targeting protectionism, pledged to reduce global trade and current account imbalances. The move reflects the growing geopolitical risks and the need for a policy shift to address the challenges posed by the French election and US trade policy.

site_title: Market's holding its breath
summary: The French election is expected to have a significant impact on the global market, with some brokerages labeling it as the biggest risk to the post-2009 bull market. Marine Le Pen, a far-right candidate, is leading in the polls, while her rivals include Jean-Luc Melenchon and Francois Fillon. The outcome could lead to a relief rally or a crash, depending on the result. The market is already volatile, with stocks finishing flat ahead of the election. The Trump administration's tax plan is also a concern, but political risk from France is seen as more potent.

site_title: Gathering of global maritime community
summary: Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) 2017, themed "Navigating through challenging times," took place from April 22-28. The event, organized by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, gathered the global maritime community for conferences, dialogues, exhibitions, and social events. SMW was co-located with SeaAsia and Iron Ore Week, featuring speakers from BHP Billiton, Tata Steel, and other industry leaders. The event addressed key trends and challenges in the maritime and iron ore industries, including supply and demand issues and volatility in iron ore prices.

site_title: China to increase supervision of insurance firms
summary: China's insurance regulator has announced plans to increase supervision of insurance firms, with a focus on risk controls and capital management. The China Insurance Regulatory Commission has issued a notice requiring companies to strengthen controls in 10 areas and implement 39 measures to prevent risky investments and behavior. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to tackle risk in the financial system, following previous calls for insurers to strengthen supervision of investment activity and correct market disorder.

site_title: New China quotas expected to charge up electric car market
summary: China is expected to introduce "new energy" vehicle quotas for carmakers as early as 2018, requiring green vehicle production under a complex system of earned credits. The move aims to boost the country's electric car market, currently the world's largest. Major manufacturers such as Volvo, Ford, and General Motors have announced plans to increase their electric vehicle offerings in China, with some predicting significant economies of scale will bring down costs. The quota system is seen as a response to China's chronic air pollution issues and is expected to drive the growth of the green car sector.

images.alt_text: China's electric car market is already the world's biggest, but a government proposal to introduce "new energy" vehicle quotas for carmakers is further charging it up.

site_title: In Murdoch empire, sons set about an elaborate overhaul
summary: James Murdoch and his brother Lachlan have implemented a significant overhaul of the Murdoch empire, seeking to modernize the company's culture and operations. Following the ousting of Bill O'Reilly and Roger Ailes, the brothers have introduced new benefits, such as paid vacation and reproductive coverage, and have shifted focus towards digital media, including investments in National Geographic. The brothers' efforts aim to change the company's "roguish, old-guard internal culture" and position 21st Century Fox for a uncertain future, but it remains to be seen whether this shift will be successful.

site_title: Laurie Anderson's glorious, chaotic New York
summary: Laurie Anderson, a renowned artist, reflects on her 50-year career in New York City. Born in suburban Chicago, she studied sculpture and violin before becoming a prominent figure in the city's avant-garde scene. Her work spans multiple mediums, including music, film, and literature. Anderson's marriage to Lou Reed influenced her artistic trajectory, and she continues to create and perform, including a new prize for emerging artists. Despite the challenges of her career and personal losses, including the death of her husband, Anderson remains dedicated to her art and continues to push boundaries, saying "I'm a journalist, trying to describe what stories are, how you make them up."

site_title: ECB stands ready to support banks if needed after France vote
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has signaled its readiness to support banks if needed after France's presidential election. Governing Council member Ignazio Visc stated that the ECB's liquidity facilities remain available to counter market tension. Despite a strong showing by anti-euro candidate Marine Le Pen, the ECB believes its facilities make it less likely that they will be needed. A majority of French voters (72%) want the country to remain in the single currency, according to recent surveys.

site_title: Better to postpone election for FAS president
summary: Singapore's Football Association (FAS) is set to hold a presidential election, but amid ongoing investigations into alleged misuse of funds and corruption, experts suggest postponing the election to ensure fairness. The FAS has faced criticism for its poor performance on the field and low world ranking. The election, which was initially smooth, has been marred by revelations of donations and alleged attempts to obstruct audits. The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) is investigating the matter, and its findings will determine the outcome of the election. Postponing the election would allow for a thorough review of the situation and prevent any potential controversy from affecting the result.

site_title: Iran nuclear accord has led to scramble for the best employees
summary: Iran's nuclear accord has led to a scramble for the best employees, with foreign companies seeking skilled professionals to navigate cultural and language barriers. The country's small pool of white-collar workers has seen a surge in job offers, with some Iranians returning home to take advantage of the economic opportunities. However, critics argue that the benefits of the accord have been unevenly felt, with poverty rates increasing during President Hassan Rouhani's first year in office. As Rouhani seeks a second term, his challengers, including conservative cleric Ebrahim Raisi, are capitalizing on the theme of economic growth and job creation.

site_title: Oil prices see biggest weekly fall in over a month
summary: Oil prices plummeted 2% on Friday, marking the largest weekly decline in over a month, as US production and inventory growth offset Opec's efforts to reduce the global crude glut. Brent futures fell to $51.96 a barrel, while US crude futures ended at $49.62 a barrel. The US Commodities Future Trading Commission reported a record high in long positions in US crude, but oil prices have sagged in recent days. Opec and non-Opec members recommended extending production cuts, but shipment data shows increased oil imports.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week 2017 opens
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2017 opened on April 22, 2017, featuring conferences, dialogues, and exhibitions to address industry challenges. Senior Minister of State Josephine Teo officiated the event, emphasizing the need for collaboration to navigate headwinds. Over 20,000 maritime professionals and 30,000 public attendees are expected to participate from April 22 to April 28, with the event aimed at discovering opportunities from challenges and preparing the industry for the future.

site_title: Director buying, selling values down sharply
summary: Singapore Exchange sees a decrease in buying and selling values among directors from April 17 to April 21, with 16 companies buying and 2 firms selling. The buying value dropped sharply from S$48 million, while the selling value decreased from S$1.88 million. Notable acquisitions include Declout Limited, Boustead Projects, and Centurion Corporation. Director buys include KTL Global and GCCP Resources, while director sells include Sinjia Land and Asian Pay Television Trust.

site_title: Freeport warns Indonesia copper mine workers as Grasberg strike looms
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc warned Indonesian copper mine workers that disciplinary actions will be enforced for absenteeism, a day after a union announced plans for a one-month strike over employment conditions. Tensions rise at Grasberg, the world's second-biggest copper mine, amid layoffs and a dispute with the Indonesian government. The strike could impact production and exports, which were temporarily halted in January under new rules requiring Freeport to adopt a special licence and pay new taxes.

site_title: All eyes on outcome of French polls
summary: France's presidential election results will be announced on Monday, with a potential far-left or far-right candidate winning the first round, prompting market jitters over a "Frexit" or France exiting the European Union. Centrist Emmanuel Macron is seen as the most market-friendly outcome, according to analysts, while a victory for Marine Le Pen or Jean-Luc Melenchon would be a worst-case scenario for financial markets. The outcome may impact global financial markets, including the local bourse, which will react on Monday.

site_title: Shanghai property market cools, prices to be stable in 2017
summary: Shanghai's property market has cooled down, with prices expected to remain stable in 2017. Cooling measures introduced in March and October last year have contained property overheating, prioritizing genuine buyers over speculators and cracking down on market irregularities. Authorities have avoided drastic measures, instead focusing on stabilizing price trends. Economists warn that a cooling market may expose China's economy to financial risks, but for now, prices are expected to remain stable.

site_title: Drawn To Murals
summary: Street artists are increasingly getting paid to create murals on walls, with some earning a living from their art. Finance director Yip Yew Chong, 48, is one such artist, creating large-scale pieces on weekends. His work is gaining recognition, and he is now part of a growing community of artists who are turning their passion into a legitimate career. This shift towards legitimate street art is seen as a positive development, allowing artists to monetize their talents and contribute to urban landscapes.

site_title: Going green: We can do a lot more
summary: Singaporeans can do more to reduce its environmental impact. The city-state's main environmental concern is air pollution, particularly haze, which can only be solved through political efforts. The country should have transitioned to fully electric vehicles and utilized surfaces for solar power and greenery to mitigate pollution. Early subsidies for green technologies and jobs could be a starting point for a desirable movement.

site_title: Mobike designates 50 preferred locations in Singapore to park its bikes
summary: Mobike, a Chinese bike-sharing company, has designated 50 preferred locations in Singapore for its bicycles, called Smart Mobike Preferred Locations (SMPLs). These locations, including university campuses and shopping malls, allow users to park their bikes and track them using Mobike's proprietary technology. The company plans to roll out up to 1,000 SMPLs by the end of the year, complementing existing bike parking locations. Mobike aims to improve efficiency and support its massive daily ride count of 20 million.

site_title: China wealth management products growth eases in Q1: regulator
summary: China's wealth management products growth slowed to 18.6% in Q1, down 35 percentage points from the previous year, according to the China Banking and Regulatory Commission. The value of these products reached 29.1 trillion yuan at the end of March. The regulator attributed this slowdown to a crackdown on risky behavior in the financial markets. Non-performing loans rose to 1.58 trillion yuan, but the rate remained low at 1.74%. The central bank governor stated that risks were well under control, with adequate capital and provisions.

site_title: France's place in Europe at issue in vote for president
summary: France held its first round of presidential election, with over 50,000 police and soldiers patrolling streets following a terrorist attack. The election pits pro-EU centrist Emmanuel Macron against far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen, with a runoff on May 7. Macron is favored to win, but Le Pen's nationalist agenda could redefine France's place in Europe and the EU. The outcome may signal a shift in the populist tide that led to Brexit and Trump's election.

site_title: French stocks slip in flat European market as vote nears
summary: French stocks slipped 0.4% on Friday as investors retreated from risky bets ahead of the first round of France's presidential election. The CAC 40 index fell, while European benchmark indexes added 0.1%. Banking stocks, seen as benefiting from a mainstream candidate's victory, rose 0.7%. Software AG jumped 7.9% after reporting first-quarter results, while ASM International rose 3.7% after a target price increase. European first-quarter earnings are expected to increase 7.2% from 2016.

site_title: Fed vice-chair still sees two more rate hikes this year: CNBC
summary: The US Federal Reserve remains on track for two more interest rate hikes in 2017, according to Fed Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer. Despite weak economic data, including a drop in inflation, Fischer dismissed speculation that US President Donald Trump's comments on the dollar would sway Fed policymaking. He also warned that France's election could raise uncertainty about the global economy, citing the importance of the Franco-German partnership. The median Fed policymaker forecast remains for two rate increases by year end.

site_title: Taiwan's Yang Ming stops container service to Iran
summary: Taiwan's Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp has stopped its container service to Iran, becoming the first foreign shipping line to abandon the route after international sanctions were lifted a year ago. This move follows the departure of several larger shipping lines that have begun serving Iran since the sanctions were lifted. Yang Ming's decision is seen as a result of the ongoing sanctions and security concerns in the region.

images.alt_text: Yang Ming is said to have adjusted some of its routes in Asia as a result of the global shipping downturn.

site_title: Oil dives, sending US crude below US$50 for first time in 2 weeks
summary: Oil prices plummeted, with Brent futures falling 2% to $51.96 a barrel and US crude futures dropping 2.2% to $49.62 a barrel, marking the largest weekly decline in over a month. US production and inventory growth offset Opec's efforts to reduce the global crude glut, sparking concerns about the cartel's ability to maintain production cuts. Despite Opec's recommendation to extend cuts, shipment data shows increased oil imports, and US drillers added rigs for a 14th consecutive week.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled at US$51.96 a barrel, down US$1.03, or 2 per cent at the market's close. US crude futures ended at US$49.62 a barrel, down 2.2 per cent, or US$1.09.

site_title: China stocks regulator fines ex-official US$36.5m over illegal trades
summary: China's securities regulator fined former Shenzhen bourse official Feng Xiaoshu 251 million yuan (S$60 million) for making illegal trades to profit from company IPOs. Feng used relatives' accounts to buy shares ahead of IPOs, selling them after the price rose. He will be barred from the market for life. This fine underscores Beijing's drive to root out bad behavior in its equities markets amid rising speculative activity and leverage in the economy.

site_title: 'Excellent chance' US will stay in Paris agreement: Al Gore
summary: Former US Vice-President Al Gore believes the US has a "better-than-even chance" of staying in the Paris Agreement on climate change. The agreement aims to limit global temperature increases to two degrees Celsius. US energy companies have urged the Trump administration not to exit the agreement. Gore also highlighted the growth of solar jobs in the US, stating they are now growing 17 times faster than overall job growth. The US president has said he will decide by the end of next month whether to stay in the agreement.

site_title: Iran elections have history of dark horses
summary: Iran is gearing up for its election season, where dark horses have a history of surprising the country's trajectory. Past elections have seen unexpected winners, including Hassan Rouhani in 2013, who won despite initial predictions, and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in 2005 and 2009. Despite many Iranians being cynical about politics, these surprises have shifted the country's direction. This time, Rouhani faces a tough fight from conservative opposition figures, including Judge Ebrahim Raisi and Mayor Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, who could potentially upset the status quo.

site_title: US naval armada to be in Sea of Japan in days
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced that the supercarrier Carl Vinson will arrive in the Sea of Japan in days, amid high tensions with North Korea. The move follows a series of confusing messages about the carrier's intended destination, and comes as the US seeks to reassure allies of its commitment to regional security. Pence warned North Korea that the US would respond with an "overwhelming and effective" response to any attack, amid North Korean threats of "all-out war" and continued missile tests. The US naval armada aims to deter the regime and protect its interests in the region.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Hashida Sushi is hosting Japan's renowned soba master, Osamu Tagata, as part of its fourth anniversary celebrations. Tagata will present handmade soba noodles made from a near-extinct strain of buckwheat from Shizuoka. The event will take place on April 25 and 26. Meanwhile, COMNAM Vietnamese Street Eats has reopened with a new menu after a two-week renovation, offering popular dishes such as banh xeo and thit kho trung.

site_title: A half-degree
summary: A half-degree increase in global temperatures is projected, highlighting the escalating threat of climate change. This slight rise, attributed to human activities, underscores the urgent need for collective action to mitigate its effects.

site_title: Tighter regulation has impacted banks' profitability: MAS
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Managing Director Ravi Menon expressed concerns over the profitability of several large banks, citing tighter regulation as a factor. Despite regulatory reforms making the financial system more robust, some banks are now operating below the cost of capital, posing a potential source of instability. Menon emphasized the need for regulators to fine-tune regulations carefully, avoiding "pendulum swings" that could undermine financial stability and economic growth.

site_title: US companies clobbered by Venezuela's crisis
summary: US companies are facing significant losses due to Venezuela's economic crisis, with General Motors, Kimberly-Clark, Mondelez, and Pepsi among those affected. The crisis, caused by hyperinflation, capital controls, and political turmoil, has led to the nationalization of GM's plant and significant losses for the other companies, with losses ranging from $1.4 billion to $778 million. The US government's policies towards the crisis, including targeted sanctions, have been criticized for being too cautious, with some lawmakers expressing concern over the potential for Russian control of US energy supplier Citgo.

images.alt_text: General Motors shut down its operations in Venezuela and laid off its 2,700 workers after the government on Wednesday seized the plant.

site_title: Heartlanders firmly in sight
summary: Fitness First, a UK-based gym chain, is expanding its presence in Singapore with plans to launch new gyms across the island at a rate of two to three per year. The company has 17 gyms in Singapore, with a total of 42,000 members, and aims to increase its membership by attracting more people to sign up for a gym membership. With a merger with Celebrity Fitness, the combined entity, Evolution Wellness Holdings, will have 152 wholly-owned fitness clubs across Asia. The company's managing director, Andrew Phillips, believes that convenience is key to attracting more members, and plans to focus on heartland locations with good public transport links.

site_title: SMRT in talks to sell taxi business to Grab
summary: SMRT is in talks to sell its taxi business to Grab, marking the third largest cab operator's exit from the business after 27 years. The deal, if successful, would see SMRT relinquish its private-hire taxi operations. No financial details or timeline for the potential sale have been disclosed.

site_title: US judge orders Volkswagen to pay US$2.8b criminal penalty
summary: A US judge ordered Volkswagen to pay a US$2.8 billion criminal penalty and placed the German automaker on three years of probation for its role in the diesel emissions cheating scandal. The company agreed to pay a total of over US$23 billion in fines and compensation in the US, including penalties to federal and state authorities, consumers, and car dealers. Volkswagen pleaded guilty to three felony charges and agreed to cooperate with federal investigators.

site_title: Pence in Australia to make Trump phone blow-up 'ancient history'
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence is set to make a more amiable approach when meeting Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, aiming to focus on cooperation on trade, defense, and other issues. The two leaders had a contentious first conversation in January, with Trump reportedly cutting short a call over a refugee deal. The Trump administration has been working to rebalance its relationship with Australia, which has been drawn to China due to the US's withdrawal from key trade deals. Pence hopes to tap Australia's expertise on the South China Sea, a key issue in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: India's economic growth being held back by bad loans: analyst
summary: India's economic growth is being hindered by high levels of bad loans in the country's banks, according to analysts. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has noted that Indian banks have some of the highest levels of bad debts in emerging markets. The arrest of Vijay Mallya, who defaulted on loans worth over $1 billion, is seen as a symptom of a larger issue. Experts warn that addressing bad loans is crucial to boosting India's economic growth. The IMF's comments highlight the need for the government to take action to address the issue and support the country's economic development.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Italian debt rating; 'stable' outlook
summary: Fitch downgraded Italy's long-term debt rating to BBB, citing persistent debt and fiscal problems. The stable outlook reflects the country's inability to reduce its debt burden due to weak economic growth and recurring spending target failures. Italy's sovereign debt rose to 132.6% of GDP in 2022 and is expected to increase to 129.3% by 2020. The downgrade is attributed to increased political risk and the potential for populist policies to hinder reforms.

site_title: Canny Humour
summary: Rishi Budhrani, a Singaporean standup comic, is set to debut with "Cannot Means Cannot," a show poking fun at Singapore's strict image. The 26 April show at Blu Jaz Cafe explores the cultural implications of the phrase "cannot means cannot" in everyday conversations. Tickets are available for S$25. The event is part of the Singapore Comedy Fringe Festival.

site_title: Florida lawmaker resigns after racist tirade
summary: Florida state senator Frank Artiles resigned after a racist tirade in a bar against two black lawmakers, leaving him mired in scandal. Artiles, 43, used the N-word and other obscenities, apologizing in his resignation letter. Republican Senate President Joe Negron condemned the incident, stating racial slurs and profane insults have no place in conversation. Artiles' resignation came after a lawyer defended him, but ultimately, he acknowledged the consequences of his actions, taking responsibility and seeking personal reflection and growth.

site_title: 'Urgent' to reach agreement on loan for Greece: IMF
summary: The IMF urges an agreement on a loan program for Greece, citing the country's deteriorating economy, but a commitment is still needed from Athens on reforms and Europe on debt relief. The IMF has refused to participate in a 86 billion euro loan program due to concerns over Greece's debt sustainability. An IMF mission will return to Athens next week, and the organization is seeking clarification on debt relief implementation. A budget surplus of 3.9% of GDP in 2016 has been welcomed by European officials, but disagreements persist over the primary surplus objective.

site_title: Kong Hee and 4 leaders surrender at State Courts to start jail terms
summary: Kong Hee, the founder of City Harvest Church, surrendered to start his 3.5-year jail term for misappropriating millions from the church's funds. Four other church leaders, including former finance managers Sharon Tan and Serina Wee, also surrendered, with sentences ranging from 7 months to 3.5 years. The group was found guilty of misusing S$50 million in church funds and had their jail terms reduced on appeal. The church's deputy senior pastor, Tan Ye Peng, and former finance manager John Lam were also sentenced.

images.alt_text: City Harvest Church (CHC) founder Kong Hee was the first of five church leaders convicted of misappropriating millions from the church's funds to arrive at the State Courts on Friday to surrender himself and begin his jail term.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: No relevant article summary found for the provided article.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of French election
summary: US stocks fell on Friday ahead of the French presidential election, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.2% to 20,547.55. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the tech-rich Nasdaq losing 0.1%. Investors are cautious due to a tight contest in France, with two anti-eurozone candidates potentially leading to a run-off. General Electric and Schlumberger fell, while Honeywell International rose on strong earnings. The market is awaiting the French election outcome, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall to their lowest levels in five months
summary: US mortgage rates have fallen to their lowest levels in five months, according to Freddie Mac. The 30-year fixed-rate average dropped to 3.97%, and the 15-year fixed-rate average fell to 3.23%. The decline is attributed to a shift in investment sentiment, driven by weak economic data and growing international tensions, which has prompted investors to seek safer investments in Treasury securities.

site_title: Aviva buys over VietinBank's 50% stake in their Vietnam joint venture
summary: Aviva plc acquired VietinBank's 50% stake in their Vietnam joint venture, VietinBank Aviva Life Insurance Limited, for an undisclosed value. The deal simplifies Aviva's operating structure in the region and expands its distribution network. Aviva Vietnam will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Aviva and has become a top 10 life insurer by premiums. The acquisition is subject to regulatory approvals and comes as Vietnam's insurance market is expected to benefit from the country's projected 6% annual GDP growth over the next three years.

site_title: Shop & savour
summary: A newly opened grocery store, Taste, in Holland Village offers a unique shopping experience with a focus on high-quality meats, seafood, and produce. The store features personalized dry-aged beef services, an oyster bar, and a selection of artisanal cheeses and wines. In addition to shopping, customers can also enjoy freshly baked breads, house-made charcuterie, and attend workshops at the on-site floral atelier. Taste aims to cater to the expat and local community, positioning itself as a destination for discovering new products rather than a traditional grocery store.

site_title: France investigates Champs Elysees attacker as vote looms
summary: French investigators are probing the attacker behind the shooting of a policeman on Paris's Champs Elysees avenue, claimed by the Islamic State as a terrorist act. The incident occurred on the eve of the country's presidential election, where candidates have clashed over security measures. Analysts believe the attack could impact the four-way contest between Marine Le Pen, Emmanuel Macron, Francois Fillon, and Jean-Luc Melenchon. The attack has heightened concerns about security and raised questions about how to protect France.

site_title: Majority support for Healthway resolutions possibly due to Lippo vote
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation's (HMC) shareholders overwhelmingly supported two resolutions, with 95.2% voting in favor of issuing S$60 million convertible notes to Gateway Partners and 98.02% voting in favor of acquiring Healthway Medical Enterprises (HME). Minority shareholder Lim Oon Hock attributed the swing in support to Lippo-linked Gentle Care, which owns 23.69% of shares. Gateway expressed commitment to working with HMC as a long-term partner to ensure the company's growth.

site_title: IE Singapore building bigger talent pool to help firms go regional
summary: International Enterprise Singapore (IE Singapore) launched initiatives to build a bigger local talent pool to support Singapore firms expanding in South-east Asia and India. The agency launched the Go SEA Award for local undergrads and inked MOUs with the Confederation of Indian Industry and three local universities to provide internship opportunities in India. The Go SEA Award aims to bridge regional talent recruitment needs and provide S$12,000 to cover living and travel expenses for students participating in a 12-week internship in South-east Asia.

site_title: Mrs May's June surprise
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May calls a surprise snap general election on June 8, three years before the scheduled date, aiming to secure a majority and a stronger mandate to negotiate Brexit. The decision, seen as a strategic move, could lead to a landslide victory for the Tories, potentially increasing their parliamentary majority to 100. The markets react positively, with the pound sterling jumping to a six-month high against the US dollar. The election is expected to be closely contested, with the opposition Labour party facing concerns about its prospects, and the Liberal Democrats' chances of success are considered a long shot.

site_title: Murky oil inventory picture leaves market groping for clarity
summary: OPEC's 50% production cut to tighten oil markets has yielded unclear results, with analysts suggesting that some inventories may be drawing down, but overall global supply remains high. Global crude shipments reached a record 47.8 million barrels per day in April, driven by increased production and exports from non-OPEC countries, including the US. Despite OPEC's efforts, oil prices remain sagging, with futures prices indicating skepticism about the market's rebalancing. Inventory levels, particularly outside the US, remain a concern, with OECD stocks falling but overall inventories rising.

site_title: Growing rice under war's shadow in the Demilitarised Zone
summary: Residents of Taesung, a South Korean village within the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) separating North and South Korea, live under constant threat of war. The village, home to 197 people, grows rice and generates significant income, but residents are aware of the danger and have strict security measures in place. The North Korean military patrols the adjacent village, Kijong, and blasts propaganda music from loudspeakers, further heightening tensions. Despite the risks, residents plan to stay, citing a sense of security and a connection to their land.

site_title: Say I Do
summary: The Summerhouse is hosting its first wedding fair on April 23, offering various themes and culinary options. The event will feature gourmet selections, nature-inspired dishes, specialty cocktails, and wedding pastries. The fair is priced at $38 per couple and will run from 5pm to 9pm at 3 Park Lane.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q2 DPU up 2.4%
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 2.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.51 Singapore cents in Q2 2017, driven by higher income from its Melbourne property and a one-off payment from a terminated lease. Net property income rose 4.1% to S$30.02 million, while gross revenue increased 3.2% to S$40.24 million. Despite lower occupancy rates at some properties, FCOT's portfolio occupancy rate remains 91.8%.

site_title: Paris shooting could influence voters as they prepare for polling on Sunday
summary: A gunman opened fire on a police patrol on the Champs Elysees in Paris, killing one officer and seriously injuring two others, on the eve of France's presidential election. The attack, claimed by ISIS, has fueled fears of terrorism and national security concerns, particularly for right-wing candidate Marine Le Pen, who has campaigned on an anti-immigrant platform. Authorities are investigating the gunman, Karim Cheurfi, who had a criminal record and was known to French intelligence. The attack is expected to impact voters' decisions on Sunday, with terrorism and national security emerging as key issues in the election.

site_title: Dark pool for college kids?
summary: US startup Ustocktrade LLC, founded by former London Stock Exchange executive Tony Weeresingh, is launching a dark pool for college students, offering cheaper stock trades ($1) and no minimum account size. The platform aims to democratize wealth by making investing more accessible to young investors, who make up a fifth of customers. Critics have voiced concerns about the platform, citing the risks of trading in a secret market. Weeresingh views the platform as a philanthropic effort to help students pay off school loans.

site_title: Luxe Meets Local
summary: Anantara's high-end Sri Lankan resorts, the Anantara Peace Haven Tangelle Resort and the Anantara Kalutara Resort, offer luxurious and authentic experiences. The resorts incorporate indigenous designs, architectural elements, and local traditions, making guests feel at home. The Anantara Kalutara Resort, in particular, pays tribute to renowned architect Geoffrey Bawa, while the Anantara Peace Haven Tangelle Resort boasts a coconut plantation and stunning beach views. Both resorts feature fine dining options, personal butler service, and opportunities to explore Sri Lanka's natural beauty and cultural heritage.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: A local programmer, Lynn Yang, shares her weekend routine, revealing her favorite spots for brunch, dinner, and drinks. Yang enjoys visiting places like Brain & Brawn, Super Loco, and Shin Gi Tai, and cooking hearty meals for friends. Her weekend typically involves spending time with family and friends, with some gym sessions and exploring the arts scene at Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay, where she works. Yang's preferences showcase her appreciation for good food, coffee, and socializing.

site_title: SMG snaps up two clinics for S$23.5m to boost O&G services
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has acquired two pediatric clinics, Children's Clinic and Kids Clinic, for S$23.5 million to boost its obstetrics and gynecology (O&G) services. The acquisition also includes a 10% stake in general cancer service provider for S$2.92 million. The deal is funded via new shares and cash payments, providing clear earnings visibility with a five-year profit guarantee. This acquisition aligns with SMG's strategy to grow its pediatric segment and expand its services in the region.

site_title: Will iPhone go the way of IBM's Selectric typewriter?
summary: Apple is repositioning the iPhone as a mature, reliable device, rather than a cutting-edge innovation, by reintroducing older models like the iPhone 6 in emerging markets. This strategy acknowledges that smartphones have become ubiquitous and are upgraded infrequently. By offering a "good enough" product, Apple aims to maintain profitability and meet customer demands, similar to how iconic products like the Selectric typewriter and KitchenAid mixer have evolved over time. The company may redirect its creative energy to new innovations, but for now, the iPhone's durability and reliability are expected to remain assets.

site_title: CRCT posts Q1 DPU of 2.74 S cents, up 1.1%; net property income rises 9.8%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 1.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.74 Singapore cents for its first quarter, driven by a 9.8% rise in net property income to S$40.3 million. Gross revenue increased by 8.2% to S$290.87 million, mainly due to the contribution from CapitaMall Xinnan. The company is well-positioned to benefit from Chinese domestic consumption growth and plans to expand its market presence.

site_title: Five vendors picked to help boost self-checkout and cash management solutions
summary: SPRING Singapore has appointed five vendors to provide self-checkout and cash management solutions for the retail industry. The move aims to support small and micro-retailers in adopting technology solutions to improve productivity. Food-Joy, a mini-mart and general wholesale trade SME, was among the first to implement self-checkout counters, reducing queueing time and operational time for cash counting. The government encourages retailers to work with the appointed solution providers to implement effective solutions and build enterprise capabilities.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry Mr S. Iswaran (right) said "The retail industry is changing fast. Our retailers can respond by adopting innovative solutions and new productive formats to drive operational efficiency and attract new customers" at the annual SME day 2017 event.

site_title: Chinese Cinema's Finest
summary: The Singapore Chinese Film Festival is set to return from April 28 to May 7, featuring 45 non-mainstream award-winning films, including documentaries and restored classics.
