site_title: Facebook out to read minds
summary: Facebook unveiled a project at its developers conference to allow users to type messages or hear words through their skin using non-invasive sensors. The goal is to create a "silent-speech interface" that can capture thoughts and semantics associated with words, eliminating language barriers. The project, led by former DARPA director Regina Dugan, aims to develop a system capable of typing 100 words-per-minute straight from the brain, using optical imaging instead of invasive surgery. The technology is still years away, but could revolutionize communication and make it possible to share thoughts directly.

site_title: Commitment to multiracialism a 'golden thread' in Othman Wok's life: PM Lee
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Othman Wok, who died at 92, was remembered for his commitment to multiracialism and unity. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described this as the "golden thread" of his life, emphasizing its significance in shaping Singapore's history. Over 600 people attended a memorial service, including family, friends, and fellow leaders, who praised Wok's contributions to journalism, politics, and diplomacy. They highlighted the importance of his ethos in promoting diversity and respect for differences, and urged others to follow his example in building a better future.

site_title: Ebay's 2nd quarter profit forecast falls short of estimates
summary: eBay Inc forecasted second-quarter profit fell short of analysts' estimates, with shares falling 2.5% to $33. The company spent heavily on revamping and marketing its e-commerce platform, shifting away from online auctions and increasing marketing spending. Sales and marketing costs rose 4.5% and product development expenses jumped 16.3%. eBay expects second-quarter adjusted profit of 43-45 cents per share, below analyst expectations, but sticking to its full-year adjusted profit forecast of $1.98-$2.03 per share.

images.alt_text: Sales and marketing costs climbed 4.5 per cent to US$562 million in the first quarter ended March 31, while product development expenses jumped 16.3 per cent to US$278 million.

site_title: Turkey should be accorded due recognition
summary: Turkey's Ambassador to BT argues that the country's relations with the EU and US are not dictated by the outcome of last Sunday's referendum, but rather by national interests. The ambassador disagrees with the author's portrayal of the referendum as a demonstration of "dictatorial behavior" by President Erdogan, instead seeing it as a hallmark of democracy. The ambassador believes Turkey is unfairly judged due to its efforts to fight terrorism and maintain democracy, stating that the country is successfully addressing multiple threats simultaneously.

site_title: China Aviation Oil's Q1 earnings up 4.72%
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) posted a 4.72% increase in Q1 earnings to US$25.29 million, driven by higher gross profit and profit contributions from its associated companies, including Shanghai Pudong International Airport Aviation Fuel Supply Company Ltd. The group's revenue rose 126.1% to US$3.31 billion, primarily due to increased supply and trading volumes of middle distillates and other oil products. CAO's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, attributed the results to the group's global diversification strategy and investments in strategic oil-related businesses.

site_title: Burberry hit by US slowdown ahead of executive reshuffle at the firm
summary: British luxury brand Burberry reported a slowdown in quarterly sales growth, with group comparable sales rising 2% in Q4, below analysts' average forecast of 4%. The slowdown was driven by tough trading in the US, Hong Kong, and South Korea, with shares down 6% following the announcement. New CEO Marco Gobbetti will address these issues, and the company plans to license its fragrances and cosmetics business and make changes in the US to boost sales. Despite this, Burberry expects demand to remain strong in Britain, with a 90% rise in American buyers expected in the second half of the year.

site_title: Wasted green power up in China: Greenpeace
summary: China's solar and wind power sectors wasted significant amounts of electricity last year, with 17% of wind power and 50% of solar power curtailed. This resulted in lost earnings of 34.1 billion yuan, enough to power Beijing for the entire year of 2015. Despite government pledges to improve transmission infrastructure, grid construction has fallen behind, and China is focusing on expensive ultra-high voltage lines. Greenpeace estimates that total solar and wind investment between now and 2030 could reach up to $780 billion.

site_title: Chapel which survived Sept 11 attacks may be killed off by rent hike
summary: A small Roman Catholic chapel in Battery Park City, New York, which survived the 9/11 attacks and was rebuilt as a memorial, is on the verge of closure due to a rent hike. The chapel's rent tripled to $264,000 in 2014, and the parish has been borrowing from the Archdiocese of New York to cover the cost, but the debt is unsustainable. The archdiocese is negotiating with the landlord to reduce the rent, but parishioners are uncertain about the intentions of the archdiocese and their current pastor. The chapel's closure would be a loss for the community, which cherishes it as a link to the 9/11 attacks.

site_title: Heineken bucks expectations with increase in Q1 beer volumes
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, exceeded expectations with a 0.6% increase in beer volumes in Q1, driven by solid sales in Asia and Europe. Expansion was strongest in Asia-Pacific, with volumes rising 5.4%, while Europe saw a 0.5% increase. The company reiterated its forecast for margin expansion in 2017, despite a challenging market in Africa, Middle East, and Eastern Europe.

site_title: Fox News dumps embattled host over harassment allegations
summary: Fox News has severed its relationship with embattled host Bill O'Reilly, sacking its biggest star and America's most-watched cable news anchor over a flood of sexual harassment allegations. The decision came after a thorough review of the allegations and a decline in advertising sales. O'Reilly's departure marks a defining point for Fox, following a similar scandal involving former executive Roger Ailes last year. Women's rights activists declared his dismissal a victory, while advertisers praised the move, citing concerns over being associated with the alleged behavior.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint's Aussie arm seals deals on Sydney hotel, commercial space
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited's Australian arm has entered into option agreements worth nearly A$190 million with Impact Investment Group to sell a 300-room hotel and commercial space in Sydney's Central Park precinct. The deal includes the Four Points by Sheraton Sydney and 100 Broadway, a commercial office component with 5,400 square meters of space. The agreements are due for completion in mid-2018, as part of the A$2 billion Central Park development. Frasers Property Australia and its partner Sekisui House Australia pursued the option agreements, with IIG managing over A$400 million in funds under management.

site_title: Europe: Results, banking sector bounce help shares recover
summary: European shares recovered 0.2% on Wednesday, ending a three-week low, driven by a rebound in banking stocks and positive first-quarter results. Banking stocks rose 1.8%, with Banco Popular and UniCredit among top gainers, while basic resources and oil and gas stocks also bounced back. However, some European companies reported mixed earnings, including Burberry and Zalando. Sterling strength weighed on British shares, which dropped 0.1%, while Vivendi fell 1.1% after Italy's watchdog ordered the firm to cut its stake in Telecom Italia.

site_title: Greek bank damaged in bomb attack
summary: A bomb attack damaged a Eurobank branch in Athens, Greece, on April 19, 2017, causing damage to the bank and surrounding buildings. The attack was claimed by extreme left or anarchist groups, similar to a 2014 blast on the Bank of Greece. Police closed off the area before the explosion and arrested activists, but the perpetrators remain at large. This non-lethal attack is part of a pattern of such incidents in Greece, often targeting economic and political targets.

images.alt_text: A bomb attack on Wednesday damaged a branch of the Greek bank Eurobank in the centre of Athens, a police source said.

site_title: Australia toughens up citizenship test
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull unveiled plans to toughen its citizenship test, emphasizing "Australian values" such as commitment to democracy, freedom, and equality. The new requirements include a four-year qualification period, competent English, and belief in gender equality. Turnbull stated that Australia's values define the nation, rather than its racial, religious, or cultural identity. The changes aim to promote a more inclusive and cohesive society.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said Australia was an "extraordinary nation... We're not defined by race or religion or culture, as many other nations are."

site_title: GIC, Mapletree fuel student housing spree in bid to spur returns
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and Mapletree Investments Pte invested a record US$19.5 billion in student housing last year, with US$3.3 billion in deals in the first quarter of 2017. This surge is driven by student accommodation offering better returns than offices and residential housing, attracting pension and sovereign wealth funds seeking stable income and higher yields in a low-return world. The investments are seen as a strategic move to spur returns in the competitive real estate market.

images.alt_text: GIC Pte and Mapletree Investments Pte are going back to school.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Stock market analysts expect Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation to enter its next phase of growth, driven by strong demand for its data centers, with high occupancy rates expected for its T20 data center and a new data center in Hong Kong. CapitaLand Commercial Trust's gross revenue and net property income jumped 33.9% and 34.3% year-over-year, respectively, with a 24.6% contribution to the full-year forecast. Singapore bank stocks have seen increases of 7-9% year-to-date, but Q1 2017 results are expected to be soft year-over-year due to lingering asset quality issues.

site_title: CCT's DPU up as CapitaGreen boosts Q1 performance
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 9.9% rise in distributable income to S$71.3 million in Q1 2017, driven by its 100% ownership of CapitaGreen. The trust also secured URA's preliminary nod for the redevelopment of Golden Shoe Car Park. However, CCT expressed concerns about Singapore's challenging office market, with rents declining 21.5% since Q1 2015. Despite this, CapitaGreen is expected to contribute to the trust's distributable income and mitigate negative rent reversions.

site_title: May's big gamble on Brexit general election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has announced a snap general election for June 8, citing opposition parties' disagreements with her Brexit plan as the primary motivation. May's government will be defined by last year's Brexit decision, and she aims to secure a mandate for her hard Brexit stance, which includes leaving the European Single Market and Customs Union. The election comes as the country is divided over the implications of the EU referendum, with some voters supporting a soft Brexit and others advocating for a more isolationist approach. May's gamble seeks to unify her party and secure a historic victory.

site_title: Putin pins housing hopes on mortgage factory
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin is launching a mortgage factory to boost home ownership and drive down borrowing costs. The factory, backed by the state, aims to simplify and standardize the process of bundling home loans, and has signed a 50 billion-ruble deal with Sberbank PJSC. The goal is to increase competition and expand the mortgage market, which is about a quarter the size of Poland's when adjusted for the economy. The move is part of Putin's efforts to address the country's cramped, subpar housing and attract foreign investors.

site_title: SBS Transit lands Seletar bus package with S$480.33m bid
summary: SBS Transit won the Seletar bus package with a bid of S$480.33 million, beating eight other bidders. This is the first win for an incumbent public transport operator under the new bus contracting model. SBS will operate 26 bus services, including two new routes, from April 2018, and will implement the services in five tranches to ensure a smooth transition. The contract comes with an option for a two-year extension, subject to good performance.

site_title: Facebook pushes to augment reality through smartphones
summary: Facebook launches a mission to make smartphone cameras windows to augmented reality, focusing on incorporating AR features into social media applications. CEO Mark Zuckerberg predicts this technology will eventually be incorporated into eyeglasses, enabling users to interact with virtual objects in real-world scenes. The company unveils AR tools, but analyst Jan Dawson notes Facebook has been slow to enter the AR market. This move comes after Snapchat's success with its "Lenses" feature, which allows users to add digital decorations to real-world photos.

site_title: Revolt over Credit Suisse payouts rumbles on even after concessions
summary: Credit Suisse has failed to fully address shareholder concerns over payouts to senior managers, despite offering to cut top management bonuses by 40% and a pay freeze for the board. The bank's senior executives received 78 million Swiss francs (S$109.4 million) in bonuses last year, despite a net loss of 2.7 billion francs. The concessions made by the bank last week were insufficient to quash the shareholder revolt, highlighting ongoing tensions between the bank's management and its investors.

images.alt_text: If Credit Suisse shareholders reject the pay plan, it would be the first use of Swiss veto power at a leading company.

site_title: Banks, clients tussle over what it will cost to gain access to market research
summary: Banks and clients are locked in discussions over the cost of market research access as a European ban on bundling research with brokerage services approaches. Banks are pitching metered, "pay as you go" approaches for smaller investors, while larger hedge funds are offered all-inclusive packages with perks. Quotes range from US$50,000 to over US$100,000 per year, with regulators concerned that investors may route business to traders for privileged access to the best ideas. The European Union's MiFID II regulations aim to tackle conflicts of interest by separating trading commissions from investment-research fees.

site_title: Google to help train 1,000 SME business leaders
summary: Google has announced a plan to train 1,000 small and medium enterprise (SME) business leaders in Singapore by 2019 through its "Squared Online for SMEs" digital leadership and marketing program. The program, developed by Google and UK-based Avado, aims to help SMEs navigate the evolving digital landscape and boost their in-house digital marketing capabilities. The 24-week online courses will be hosted by Asia-Pacific region specialists and include face-to-face workshops, with a tuition fee of S$3,300. The program is supported by the Singapore government's "SMEs Go Digital" initiative and offers funding options for Singapore citizens and SMEs sponsoring their employees.

site_title: Australia's LNG exports face review amid gas crisis at home
summary: Australia's competition regulator is reviewing the possible sale of liquefied natural gas (LNG) intended for domestic use to overseas customers amid a gas crisis at home. The regulator will examine the Santos-led Gladstone LNG project's ability to export third-party gas, which has contributed to high wholesale prices in Australia. The country's energy producers have committed to delivering sufficient gas to avoid power blackouts, but domestic purchases of gas by Santos for export have boosted prices. The review aims to address the issue and ensure reliable and affordable gas supply for Australians.

site_title: Euro propped up by weak dollar, sterling near 6-month high
summary: The euro steadied near a three-week high against the dollar, supported by a weak US currency and doubts over President Trump's fiscal boost. Sterling remained near a six-month peak due to a snap British election. Analysts warn that the euro's gains will be capped due to the uncertainty surrounding France's presidential election and the potential for a far-left or far-right candidate to win. The US dollar index hit a three-week low due to weaker-than-expected economic data and low interest rates.

site_title: Japan government fund and bank mull over bid with Broadcom for Toshiba unit
summary: Japan's government-backed Innovation Network Corp of Japan (INCJ) and Development Bank of Japan (DBJ) are considering a joint bid with Broadcom Ltd for Toshiba Corp's semiconductor business. This move aims to prevent the sale of Toshiba's chip technology to rivals in China or South Korea. Broadcom had previously submitted the highest first-round offer of 2.5 trillion yen (S$32 billion) for the chip business, while Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co offered 2 trillion yen. The bid would allow the US chipmaker to secure the prized unit and potentially prevent national security risks.

site_title: China's shadow bank lending rises to record in Q1
summary: China's shadow bank lending surged to a record 2.05 trillion yuan in Q1, driven by the government's efforts to curb financial leverage and traditional lending. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has been raising interest rates and regulating the bond market, prompting borrowers to seek alternative financing through shadow banking. The industry, estimated to be worth $8.5 trillion, has raised concerns about the financial system's vulnerability to a property-related shock. Regulators are working to draft new rules to curb shadow banking, but experts warn that the measures may drive funding to unreachable areas, increasing overall risks.

site_title: How well are you being served?
summary: A recent survey by American Express and Ebiquity found that two-thirds of Singaporeans did not complete a purchase due to poor service, with two or more bad experiences leading to a switch to another company. Good customer service plays a significant role in buying decisions, with 7 in 10 customers willing to spend 16% more on excellent service. Two in five prefer human interaction for inquiries and troubleshooting, while seven in 10 believe most companies meet consumers' expectations for service experiences.

site_title: At Manhattan Tower, debt payments and losses increase
summary: Manhattan Tower, co-owned by Jared Kushner's family, reported a 2.7% increase in net operating income to $41.3 million in 2016, but debt payments rose 11% to $55.8 million, resulting in $14.5 million in losses. Occupancy jumped to 80% at the end of 2016. Kushner has divested his interest to prevent conflicts of interest, with his father searching for partners to convert the building into a luxury residential property. Repayment terms for over $1.2 billion of debt are becoming more punitive, approaching a 2019 due date.

site_title: Debate over stock tick size splits stakeholders
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering widening the tick size for certain stocks to improve market liquidity, but the proposal has sparked debate over whether it will benefit retail investors or only select traders. The proposed change, which could double the tick size for stocks between S$1 and S$1.99, aims to increase market making and retail participation. However, critics argue that it will increase costs for investors and lead to increased speculation. The Securities Association of Singapore and the Society of Remisiers support the move, while the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) expresses concerns over its impact on retail investors.

site_title: China sees higher risk of mass unemployment
summary: China's cabinet warns of a higher risk of mass unemployment, particularly in regions and sectors undergoing capacity cuts, and pledges fiscal and monetary policy support to stabilize the employment rate. The government plans to upgrade its economy and reduce pollution, but this move threatens to throw millions out of work. China's official unemployment rate remains around 4%, but the State Council emphasizes the need to address structural conflicts and ensure employment remains a top policy priority.

site_title: Markets taking a 'benign view' of global downside risks: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that markets may be taking a "benign view" of global downside risks, particularly as financial regulations are rolled back in the US and elsewhere. Elevated credit risks exist in emerging markets, with corporate debt already high, and China faces mounting risks to financial stability due to rapidly rising credit. A shift towards protectionism could reduce global growth and trade, and the IMF cautions that a broad rollback of financial regulations and loss of global cooperation could undermine financial stability gains.

site_title: Apple readies iPhone overhaul for smartphone's 10th anniversary
summary: Apple is preparing three iPhones for launch this fall, including a top-of-the-line model with a new, curved glass design and an OLED screen. The redesigned phone will also feature advanced cameras, including a vertical dual-camera system and a front camera with dual lenses. Supply constraints may delay the device's availability, potentially until one or two months after the typical fall introduction. The new iPhones will run iOS 11, a mobile operating system with a refreshed user interface.

site_title: Newest Silicon Valley perk: Paid time off to protest against Trump
summary: Silicon Valley companies are offering paid time off for employees to protest, following President Donald Trump's inauguration. Companies like Fauna, Turbine Labs, and Buoyant provide unlimited paid leave for rallies, voting, and civic activities. The move aims to support employees' right to participate in politics and align with the companies' commitment to fostering an inclusive workplace. Other tech giants like Facebook and Atipica have also announced similar policies, with Facebook allowing employees to take time off to participate in pro-immigration rallies.

site_title: Samsung heir's trial zeroes in on 5-minute chat with ex-president
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea's trial of Samsung heir Jay Y Lee focused on a 5-minute chat with then-president Park Geun Hye in 2014, alleging Lee accepted favors to support equestrian training for Park's friend's daughter. Lee's lawyers dispute this, saying the conversation was brief and Lee only conveyed Park's comments. The trial, dubbed the "trial of the century," threatens to expose ties between top officials and the richest family in the country, amid allegations of bribery and corruption. Lee and Samsung have denied wrongdoing.

site_title: Healthway shareholders should study outlined scenarios
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation is holding an extraordinary general meeting to vote on two major resolutions: a proposed S$60 million note issuance to Gateway and a proposed acquisition of Healthway Medical Enterprises. If both resolutions are approved, HMC will receive S$60 million and use it to meet short-term cash needs and expand clinics. However, this would dilute existing shareholders' stakes, with Gateway potentially holding 45.7% of the company. If the first resolution is not approved, HMC may face a going-concern issue, and shareholders may tender their shares to Gentle Care's offer, which could potentially save the company but is uncertain.

site_title: Property destocking in China's smaller cities to persist, says senior economic planner
summary: China's smaller cities are likely to continue prospering from property curbs in bigger cities, according to National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) vice-chairman Ning Jizhe. Despite an acceleration in home price growth in March, authorities are expected to maintain curbs to fend off bubble risks in bigger cities. China's smaller cities, known for having a large property overhang, have benefited from a spill-over in demand from bigger cities, with home prices rising in March. Authorities are speeding up work on a long-term property market regulation mechanism.

site_title: Europe's coal power vanishing fast as cost of switch to green energy dives
summary: Coal power generation in Europe is rapidly declining as the cost of transitioning to green energy decreases. Several countries, including the UK, France, and Austria, are phasing out coal with policies in place to end its use. The UK aims to end coal use by 2025, with the EU expecting just 114 gigawatts of coal capacity to remain by 2030, down from 177 GW in 2014. The shift to green energy is driven by decreasing costs and increasing competition from cheaper wind and solar power, making coal unaffordable.

site_title: IBM posts first revenue miss in five quarters; shares tumble
summary: IBM reported its first revenue decline in five quarters, with a 2.8% drop in the first quarter, exceeding analyst expectations of a 1.6% decline. The company's core IT services business was weak, with revenue down 2.5%, while "strategic imperatives" revenue grew 12%. IBM's shares tumbled 4.7% to $162, wiping out the year's 2.5% gain. The company's adjusted gross margin fell to 44.5%, missing estimates.

site_title: Britain's corporate bosses will soon know what Brexit really means
summary: The UK's corporate leaders are optimistic about Britain's future outside the EU, with a clearer Brexit strategy from the Conservatives potentially bringing back confidence in spending. A general election in June could provide the needed clarity, with Prime Minister Theresa May's softened tone on Brexit offering a more business-friendly stance. Financial markets are already pricing in a more solid Conservative majority, which could dilute the power of hardline Brexiteers and bring back investment. A clearer strategy could undo the negative impact of Brexit uncertainty, which has held back investment and construction projects.

images.alt_text: A still image taken from footage broadcast by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit on Wednesday showing Mrs May speaking in the House of Commons in April. The strong performance of the British economy since June has dispelled fears of a big near-term shock to corporate profits or financial stability. Firms are clearly hiring.

site_title: China carmakers may be hit if foreign caps lifted
summary: China's state-owned car giants, such as SAIC Motor Corp and Dongfeng Motor Group Co, may lose billions of dollars in profits if the government lifts protectionist measures allowing foreign companies to operate without local partners. China's policy, enacted two decades ago, requires foreign carmakers like General Motors, Toyota, and Volkswagen to form joint ventures with locals, capping foreign investment at 50%. This policy helped local brands develop manufacturing expertise while profiting from foreign sales. Lifting the policy could lead to significant losses for Chinese carmakers.

site_title: STI falls on UK poll move, Wall St loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.26 points or 0.4% to 3,126.28, marking its fourth consecutive decline, due to a confluence of factors including British Prime Minister Theresa May's surprise election call and lower Wall Street prices. Analysts attribute the decline to ongoing geopolitical and political risks, with Citi Research warning that investors in Asia remain anxious. The decline also affected Singapore's banking sector, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC leading the losses, while Singtel rose 1.3% on the back of a positive earnings preview.

site_title: Trump seeks headway on 'Buy American, Hire American' pledge
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued an executive order aimed at reforming the country's H-1B visa system, which is currently used to grant skilled worker visas to scientists, engineers, and computer programmers. The order calls for tightening rules and "abuses" in the system, with the goal of bringing it back to its original intent of awarding visas to the most skilled and highly paid applicants. The move is seen as a step towards broader congressional reform, but US businesses have voiced reservations, warning that eliminating the H-1B program would harm American businesses and make the US less competitive globally.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump displays an executive order in Kenosha, Wisconsin. His decree also calls for stricter implementation of existing laws that are intended to favour US-manufactured goods in public tenders.

site_title: Culture and corporate governance
summary: A review of the Code of Corporate Governance in progress highlights the importance of corporate culture in driving good governance and sustaining improvement. The Asian Corporate Governance Association (ACGA) considers "CG culture" as one of the five key areas of corporate governance. In hierarchical societies, such as those in Asia, corporate governance is challenged due to a reluctance to question authority and a lack of professional scepticism. To address this, companies need to appoint leaders sensitive to the difficulties others may face in speaking up, and have people from other cultures. Strong institutions, such as investor activism and whistleblower systems, are also crucial in fostering a strong CG culture.

site_title: Yahoo earnings beat expectations on cusp of Verizon merger
summary: Yahoo reported quarterly earnings of $99 million on $1.3 billion in revenue, beating expectations. The company is on track to be bought by Verizon, with the deal totaling $4.48 billion. Yahoo is selling its main operating business to separate it from its stake in Alibaba, which will become Altaba Inc, an investment company. The sale comes after Yahoo slashed the price of its core Internet business by $350 million due to a pair of cyber attacks that threatened to derail the deal. Yahoo will no longer be an independent company after the deal.

site_title: Uptick in complaints over US air passenger removal
summary: A growing trend of passenger removals due to racial, ethnic, or religious profiling has been observed in the US airline industry. Despite being regulated, the number of such incidents has increased, with 94 civil rights complaints filed in 2016, up 45% from the previous year. Airlines claim security concerns drive these decisions, but critics argue that bias and profiling are prevalent, contributing to a climate of inequality and undermining security. The incidents have garnered little outrage, with many passengers fearing future trouble on flights or not knowing how to file complaints.

site_title: Indian frog excretes mucus that can fight flu: study
summary: A study published in the journal Immunity found that a mucus excreted by a frog in south India, known as Hydrophylax bahuvistara, has antiviral properties effective against the H1 influenza type. The peptide, called urumin, was discovered when researchers applied electric shocks to the frog, collecting the mucus containing the peptide. Urumin protected lab mice from a lethal dose of H1 flu virus and appears to only disrupt the flu virus, not harm mammals. Further research is needed to determine if urumin could be used as a preventive treatment against the flu in humans.

site_title: Q1 pick-up in supercar, ultra luxe limo sales
summary: Sales of super high-end cars, including super sports cars and ultra-luxury limousines, have increased 20% in the first quarter of 2017, driven by high net worth and ultra high net worth individuals. Aston Martin saw a 150% surge with 10 units registered, followed by Rolls-Royce with a 100% increase to eight units. Bentley also gained 55% with 17 units, while Ferrari and Lamborghini experienced a decline in sales. Despite economic gloom, dealers attribute the sales increase to "very healthy interest" in the new Aston Martin DB11 and a growing sentiment among high net worth individuals.

images.alt_text: The new Aston Martin DB11 sports coupe leads the charge of supercar sales in Q1 with 10 units sold. The DB11 currently starts from S$860,000 before options and COE.

site_title: Europe's surprising tech success
summary: Europe is defying its digital laggard reputation, with startups leading in artificial intelligence and drawing significant investment. Last year, a record $13.6 billion was invested in Europe's tech sector, up from $2.8 billion in 2011. New tech hubs are emerging in cities like Paris, Munich, and Copenhagen, and traditional industries are investing heavily in tech. Foreign firms are also expanding their European tech hubs, with transactions worth over $88 billion taking place last year. Despite weaknesses, Europe's tech sector shows a positive trend, with a growing appetite for risk and a strong research talent pool.

site_title: French election: pollsters baffled by four-way race
summary: French presidential election pollsters are facing a challenge as a four-way race between Emmanuel Macron, Marine Le Pen, Francois Fillon, and Jean-Luc Melenchon tightens, with the top four candidates within a 4-point range. Polls show Macron would easily win the runoff, but the situation is unprecedented due to the two-round system and the reliance on internet polling. Bookmakers favor Macron, but Fillon has gained ground, with Le Pen and Melenchon within striking distance. The election's complexity has left pollsters struggling to predict the outcome.

site_title: Ballet dancers get naked (emotionally) in a modern Limón work
summary: Dance Theater of Harlem is staging a modern Limón work, Chaconne, which explores the emotional depth of ballet dancers. The piece, set to Bach's Violin Partita No 2 in D minor, requires dancers to dig into the floor and master contraction and release of the pelvis. Choreographer José Limón's work is reimagined for five dancers, each performing a solo, building momentum and ultimately swaying the stage in unison. The production aims to showcase the power of modern dance and the importance of emotional expression.

site_title: Verizon CEO open to deal talks, from Comcast to Disney
summary: Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam is open to merger talks with Comcast, Walt Disney, or CBS to reset the company's growth strategy. The largest US wireless carrier seeks new sources of growth as the mobile phone business matures and its new media ventures take time to gain traction. A potential deal with Comcast could help Verizon build a fiber-optic network to handle video streaming and ultra-fast 5G technology, while Disney's media business and CBS's assets would also be attractive options. The proposed mergers would dramatically reshape the media and telecommunications industry.

site_title: British firms to expand ad budgets despite Brexit: survey
summary: British companies plan to increase their advertising budgets despite the Brexit vote, according to a survey by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. The survey found a net 26.1% of UK companies will increase their ad budgets in the 2017/18 financial year, reversing a previous forecast for a decline. Growth in ad spending is expected to stagnate in 2018 before trending upwards in 2019 and 2020, driven by a 0.6% increase in corporate ad spending. Despite concerns over online ad platforms' content policies, marketers remain attracted to digital advertising's cost-effectiveness and targeting capabilities.

site_title: US working with allies to put pressure on N Korea: Pence
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence said the US will work with allies and China to put economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea, but vowed to respond "overwhelmingly" to any attack. Pence reassured Japan of the US commitment to reining in North Korea's nuclear ambitions, while China expressed concern over recent nuclear and missile development. North Korea's deputy representative to the UN threatened "all-out war" if the US takes military action. The US will maintain a strong presence in the Asia-Pacific, with Japan taking on a larger role in the alliance.

site_title: Malaysia developers tackle slump with job freezes, benefit cuts
summary: Malaysia developers have taken cost-cutting measures amid a weak property market, with 70% of respondents in an industry survey saying they were affected by unsold units in H2 2016. Builders froze recruitment, reduced staff benefits, and retrenched employees, with only 3% reducing salaries. The survey found that unsold units were mainly in the RM500,001-RM1 million range, with 42% of respondents in this category affected. Developers expect a pick-up in the second half of the year, but anticipate less than half of new launches to be sold out in six months, a significant decline from previous sales.

site_title: South Korea's ING Life banking on high dividends to help sell US$1.2b IPO
summary: South Korea's ING Life Insurance Korea is set to raise up to $1.2 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in May, the company's CEO said. The IPO comes as investors focus on the company's high dividend payouts, with 182.5 billion won paid in 2016, or 58% of net profit. ING Life has a strong risk-based capital ratio and depends on captive agents for growth, allowing it to continue paying high dividends. The company plans to sell 33.5 million shares at an indicative price range of 31,500-40,000 won per share.

site_title: China bonanza for four property companies
summary: Singapore-based property companies KSH Holdings, Lian Beng, Heeton, and Oxley Holdings have surged to year highs following China's announcement of the Xiongan New Area special economic zone. The four companies are part of a consortium building the Sino-Singapore Health City in Gaobeidian, a region near the new SEZ. Analysts predict further gains as Gaobeidian prices rise, driven by its proximity to Beijing and high-speed rail access, with some estimating profits exceeding S$600 million for each company.

site_title: Jakarta governor Ahok loses re-election bid
summary: Jakarta Governor Basuki Purnama, also known as Ahok, has lost his re-election bid to Anies Baswedan, a former education minister, in a landslide defeat. The loss sets the stage for a tough fight to retain the top job in 2019, with President Joko Widodo's close ally now a potential candidate. Ahok was accused of insulting Islam, leading to massive rallies against him, and his campaign was marred by controversy. Despite his loss, Ahok congratulated his opponent and vowed to work towards a smooth transition until October, when he will step down.

site_title: City Harvest case: Sharon Tan to start jail term earlier
summary: Former City Harvest Church finance manager Sharon Tan has been granted permission to start her seven-month jail term earlier, with the High Court allowing her to serve it sooner than initially planned. This follows a change of heart after she initially deferred her sentence by two weeks. The move comes as five others, including Kong Hee and Tan Ye Peng, are set to start serving their sentences at the State Courts tomorrow morning. Chew Eng Han's three-year and four-month jail term has been suspended pending the Court of Appeal's ruling on important questions of law.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Electronics won a contract to provide consultancy services for Sri Lanka's first National Cyber Security Operations Centre. Separately, ST Electronics signed an MOU with the Singapore Armed Forces to strengthen cyber defence training. Swiber Holdings failed to redeem S$160 million of outstanding medium-term notes, while UNITED Overseas Insurance posted a 0.6% year-on-year net profit decline. Sembcorp Industries retired its Audit Committee chairman and OUE Realty's deemed stake in International Healthway Corporation increased to 86.16%.

site_title: UK leader can make successive surprises successful
summary: Theresa May has announced an early election for June 8, aiming to become a substantial election victor and gain a strong mandate to steer the UK to a reasonable economic and political exit deal with the EU. This move comes after May's shift from keeping Britain in the EU to advocating for a "UK out" cause. With the Conservative Party leading the opposition Labour Party by 20 percentage points, May hopes to establish Britain as an island of relative stability in an uncertain continent, potentially gaining negotiating leverage for a "soft" withdrawal agreement.

site_title: Oil producers moving closer to rebalancing market: Opec chief
summary: OPEC's secretary-general Mohammad Barkindo announced that oil producers are moving closer to rebalancing the market, with benchmark Brent crude gaining 19% since the agreement to cut output in January. The group's compliance with cuts improved to 104% in March, exceeding the target. OPEC will decide in May whether to extend the output cuts beyond June, but participation from Iran, Nigeria, and Libya is uncertain due to internal conflicts. The collective action of OPEC and other major producers aims to end the global glut and restore market stability.

site_title: S'pore retains 10th spot in FDI Confidence Index
summary: Singapore retained its 10th spot in the 2017 AT Kearney Foreign Direct Investment Confidence Index, with 30% of respondents expressing optimism about the city-state's economic outlook. Despite geopolitical tensions and domestic policy changes, investors chose Singapore due to its long-term competitiveness and bullish outlook for the US. The US retained its top spot, while China fell to third place. The survey of 510 respondents, including C-level executives and regional business leads, showed that investors from the Asia-Pacific and industry sector were most interested in investing in Singapore.

site_title: Unconventional central banking here to stay, says ECB paper
summary: The European Central Bank has published a research paper suggesting that central banks worldwide will likely retain broader mandates and unconventional tools, such as negative interest rates and large-scale asset buys, in the post-crisis era. The paper indicates that central banks will focus on financial stability, use macro-prudential tools more widely, and communicate more actively, potentially crossing into politics. While some unconventional tools may be phased out, the costs and benefits require further study, and inflation targets should not change.

site_title: IMF says Trump corporate tax cuts could lead to financial risk-taking
summary: The International Monetary Fund warned that US President Donald Trump's proposed corporate tax cuts and roll-back of financial regulations could lead to financial risk-taking, similar to the 2008 crisis. The IMF says highly leveraged US companies may channel cash into risks like financial assets, mergers, and dividend payouts, potentially leading to market volatility and debt service costs. The report urges US policymakers to be vigilant about corporate leverage and suggests fine-tuning financial regulations to mitigate risks, particularly in emerging markets facing protectionism and rising interest rates.

site_title: China relaxes some cross-border capital curbs as yuan steadies: sources
summary: China's central bank has relaxed some capital controls on cross-border capital outflows, easing curbs put in place last year to stabilize the yuan currency. The move comes as the yuan has firmed nearly 1% in 2017 and China's foreign exchange reserves have increased above the $3 trillion level. The People's Bank of China no longer requires banks to match outflows with equal inflows, a change aimed at boosting market confidence in the yuan.

images.alt_text: China's central bank has relaxed some of its curbs on cross-border capital outflows put in place just months ago to shore up the yuan currency, banking sources said on Wednesday.

site_title: Lions to face Argentina in Kallang on June 13
summary: The National Stadium in Kallang, Singapore, will host a high-profile football friendly match between Argentina and Singapore on June 13. The match, featuring Lionel Messi, Sergio Aguero, and other world-class players, will mark the Football Association of Singapore's 125th anniversary. Argentina, currently second in FIFA's world rankings, will field a "full-strength" team, while Singapore's national coach V Sundramoorthy expects the match to provide valuable exposure for his players. Tickets go on sale on April 20, starting at S$25.

site_title: IHC announces AGM, Q1 financial statement dates
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) announced its FY2016 annual general meeting by July 14 and its Q1 2017 financial statements by July 31. The company also expects to meet regulatory timelines for Q2 and Q3 unaudited financial results, eliminating the need for extensions.

site_title: Danish court upholds extradition of daughter of ousted South Korean president's friend
summary: A Danish court upheld the extradition order of Chung Yoo-ra, the 20-year-old daughter of Choi Soon-sil, a friend of ousted South Korean President Park Geun-hye. Chung is wanted for questioning in relation to the scandal that brought down Park. The court backed the Public Prosecutor's decision, allowing Chung to be extradited to South Korea for prosecution. Chung had appealed the order, but the district court upheld it. Both Choi and Park have denied wrongdoing in the scandal.

site_title: Malaysia Air to use new flight tracker
summary: Malaysia Airlines has become the first airline to sign an agreement for space-based flight tracking of its aircraft. The deal with Aireon LLC, SITAONAIR, and FlightAware LLC enables real-time global aircraft tracking, including over polar regions and remote oceans. The move aims to improve aviation safety and follows the company's 2014 disappearance of a jet with 239 people aboard. Malaysia Airlines chief operating officer Izham Ismail said the airline is "proud to be the first airline to adopt this solution." The tracking system is part of Aireon's global satellite network, set to be completed in 2018.

site_title: Placement agreement for proposed issue of KOP shares lapses
summary: KOP Limited announced that the placement agreement for a proposed issue of up to 221.6 million shares has lapsed due to the inability of the potential subscriber to resolve its funding issue. The agreement, which had no effect, will no longer have any obligations or claims against each other. The lapse is attributed to "certain currency controls".

site_title: UK parliament votes in favour of early national election
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's call for an early national election was approved by parliament with a vote of 522 to 13. The election, scheduled for June 8, will allow May to strengthen her hand in Brexit negotiations with the European Union, which are set to begin in the coming months. The move has been praised by the Conservative Party but criticized by opposition politicians, who accuse May of being opportunistic and untrustworthy. The election is seen as a chance for May to heal divisions in Britain and present her plans for the country's future.

site_title: OUE Realty increases stake in International Healthway Corporation to 86.16%
summary: OUE Realty has increased its stake in International Healthway Corporation to 86.16%, up from 57.6% on April 13, 2017. The company's deemed interest has risen from 955.67 million shares to 1.43 billion shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 1.65 points to 1,738.95. Volume reached 2.85 billion lots worth RM2.19 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 661 to 258.

site_title: Gates backs Big Pharma push to wipe out tropical diseases
summary: Bill Gates and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation pledged $335 million over four years to wipe out tropical diseases, with a goal of reaching 90% of those in need of treatment by 2030. The diseases, affecting 1.5 billion people in Asia, Africa, and Latin America, include Guinea-worm disease, onchocerciasis, and sleeping sickness. Donors such as GlaxoSmithKline, Novartis, and Sanofi have also pledged support, with the UK and Belgium committing additional funds to eradicate these diseases.

site_title: UK parliament votes in favour of early general election
summary: The UK parliament voted 522-13 in favour of an early general election, set to take place on June 8, 2017. Prime Minister Theresa May sought to strengthen her hand in Brexit negotiations by bringing the election forward from 2020. The vote exceeded the two-thirds majority required, allowing May to proceed with the election plan.

site_title: Siam Commercial in exclusive talks with FWD for US$3b insurance deal: sources
summary: Siam Commercial Bank (SCB) is in exclusive talks with Hong Kong insurer FWD Group to sell its life insurance arm for US$3 billion, the largest insurance M&A transaction in South-east Asia. The deal could be finalized by the end of May and would help FWD expand its presence in Thailand's growing life insurance market. If successful, it would rank as the biggest insurance M&A transaction in Asia since the merger of two Indian insurance companies in 2016.

site_title: Cacola Furniture International responds to SGX queries
summary: Cacola Furniture International Limited responded to SGX queries regarding the resignation of executive chairman and director Chow Tat Ming Henry. The company stated that Mr. Chow acted in the best interest of the company and is not providing an exit offer. His resignation is due to personal and other work commitments, and the company does not have policies requiring the retention of services. The company will proceed with its imminent delisting process.

site_title: S&P, Nasdaq rise on bank and tech gains; IBM dents Dow
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose on Wednesday, driven by gains in bank and technology stocks, while IBM's drop weighed on the Dow. Morgan Stanley's quarterly profit boost and solid results from Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Wells Fargo contributed to the gains. Despite IBM's decline, overall profits of S&P 500 companies are estimated to have risen 10.7% in the first quarter, the best since 2011. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 12 points, while the Nasdaq Composite index rose 28.40 points.

site_title: China's Ant Financial buys helloPay
summary: China's Ant Financial acquired Singapore-based payment service helloPay Group, re-branding it as Alipay in markets including Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The deal aims to boost Ant's Alipay brand presence in South-east Asia. This acquisition follows recent investments in Asia and a strategic bid for US transfer service MoneyGram International Inc, as Ant seeks to grow its payments infrastructure beyond China.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SBS Transit won the tender to operate the Seletar Bus Package in Singapore. The country retained its 10th spot in the FDI Confidence Index. Businesses in Singapore are expecting higher costs due to the country's already high expense level. Google announced plans to train 1,000 SME business leaders by 2019. The Straits Times Index closed 0.4% lower, with the key index down 11.26 points. Swiber Holdings failed to pay coupon and redeem principal for some S$160 million of outstanding medium-term notes, and Keppel Reit appointed Penny Goh as board chairman.

site_title: HK, China stocks end lower on uncertainties
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.41% lower on Wednesday, following a sell-off across Asia, Europe, and the US due to geopolitical concerns and uncertainty about the global outlook. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,825.88, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.81% to 3,170.69.

site_title: Jachin Capital to offer robo investment portfolios to a wider audience
summary: Jachin Capital, a Singapore-based independent fund manager, has secured a capital markets services licence to offer its digital investment platform, iAdvisor, to a wider audience of accredited investors. iAdvisor provides robo-investment portfolios with distinct thematic exposures, offering total transparency and real-time updates. The platform is developed in collaboration with Quantifeed, a Hong Kong-based B2B fintech firm, and offers two types of mandates, including discretionary and advisory services. Investors can access the platform with a minimum investment of S$1,000 for advisory services and S$5 million for discretionary mandates.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% lower at 3,126.28 points, following overnight declines in Wall Street due to disappointing earnings data and a UK election. The local bourse saw 2.7 billion shares traded worth S$1.2 billion, with 179 counters up and 293 down.

site_title: China Aviation Oil's Q1 net profit up 4.72%
summary: China Aviation Oil reported a 4.72% increase in Q1 net profit to US$25.29 million, driven by higher revenue from middle distillates and other oil products, which surged 126.1% to US$3.3 billion. Earnings per share decreased to 2.94 US cents. The company's stock closed at S$1.63, down 3.6%.

site_title: Taiwan denies political asylum request from Chinese tourist
summary: Taiwan has rejected a political asylum application from Chinese tourist Zhang Xiangzhong, who is an anti-corruption campaigner and former prisoner. Zhang, who spent time in a mainland prison, applied for asylum after visiting Taiwan from April 12-20. Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council denied his application, citing that he did not qualify due to existing regulations. Zhang had left the island with his tour group, avoiding any potential strain on relations between Beijing and Taipei.

site_title: SBS Transit clinches tender to operate Seletar Bus Package
summary: SBS Transit has been awarded the Seletar Bus Package, a five-year public bus services contract. The company will operate 26 bus services, including two new ones, from Ang Mo Kio, Yio Chu Kang, and Yishun Bus interchanges. The contract can be extended for two more years. This is SBS Transit's first bus tender award under the new model.

site_title: French election shocker: pollsters baffled by four-way race
summary: French presidential election polls are showing a four-way race between Emmanuel Macron, Marine Le Pen, Francois Fillon, and Jean-Luc Melenchon, with Macron leading but steadily slipping. Pollsters are struggling to predict the outcome, citing the tight margin between the top four candidates and the large number of undecided voters, with 40% of voters yet to make a decision. The two-round system and reliance on internet polling are also complicating the forecasts. Experts say the situation is unprecedented and that French polling has a near-perfect record, but the current uncertainty is putting their usual accuracy to the test.

site_title: London stocks dip at open
summary: London's stock market fell 0.1% at the start of trading, extending a 2.5% decline from the previous session due to a rallying pound after Britain called a snap general election. The FTSE 100 index closed at 7,138.26 points. In contrast, the eurozone's main indices, such as the DAX 30 and CAC 40, rose 0.1% to 12,014.03 and 4,987.29 points, respectively.

site_title: Keppel Reit appoints Penny Goh board chairman
summary: Keppel Reit appoints Penny Goh as new board chairman, replacing Chin Wei-Li, effective April 22. Goh, 64, is a non-executive and independent director who has served since October 2016. Tan Chin Hwee and Tan Cheng Han will also step down on July 1 to assume other roles, resulting in a board comprising seven directors, four of whom are independent. Chin Wei-Li, 59, will resign from her roles as chairman and non-executive director.

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 DPU down 13.7% to 1.45 cents (Amended)
summary: Keppel Reit reported a Q1 DPU of 1.45 Singapore cents, down 13.7% from 1.68 cents last year. Distribution to unitholders fell 11.6% to S$48.1 million, primarily due to the absence of income from divested 77 King Street and lower income from Bugis Junction Towers. Net property income decreased 4.6% to S$31.4 million. The annualized distribution yield was 5.5%.

site_title: UOI posts Q1 net profit of S$7.01m, down 0.6%
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) posted a Q1 net profit of S$7.01 million, down 0.6% year-over-year, due to a 4.9% drop in gross written premium. The company's annualized earnings per share were 45.82 Singapore cents. The decline in premium is attributed to a timing difference in premium declarations.

site_title: China's Li says EU and China must promote free and fair trade
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang urged the European Union to promote free and fair trade, calling it a "positive signal" of economic globalization. He emphasized the need for cooperation and stability in China-EU relations, as both nations face global challenges. The EU, however, remains cautious about China's massive steel exports, militarization of islands, and increasing authoritarianism. Despite concerns, both sides agree to support the World Trade Organization and work towards a bilateral investment treaty, making it easier for European companies to do business in China.

site_title: Singapore is about to get more costly for businesses
summary: Singapore is set to become more expensive for businesses due to a 30% increase in water prices and higher diesel costs, with a looming carbon tax. Manufacturers will need to adjust operations to remain competitive in the economy, which is recovering from an export slump. The government aims to conserve the environment, despite the increased costs, citing other advantages such as reliable power and water supply, business-friendly framework, and competitive tax rates. The moves are part of the government's goal of forcing businesses to innovate to boost productivity.

site_title: China's Ant Financial buys Singapore-based helloPay in boost to SE Asia plans
summary: Ant Financial, the payment affiliate of Alibaba Group, acquired Singapore-based helloPay Group, expanding its presence in South-east Asia. helloPay, a subsidiary of Lazada Group, will be re-branded as Alipay in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. This move aims to boost Ant's Alipay brand recognition in these markets. The acquisition is part of Ant's drive to grow its payments infrastructure beyond China, with recent investments in Asia and a bid for US transfer service MoneyGram International Inc.

site_title: Tokyo: Japanese stocks end nearly flat as geopolitical tensions sour mood
summary: Japanese stocks ended nearly flat on Wednesday due to geopolitical tensions, with the Nikkei 225 share average edging up 0.07% to 18,432.20. Investors remained cautious amid escalating tensions between the US and North Korea, while sterling surged after British Prime Minister Theresa May called an early general election. Exporters were mixed, with Toyota and Honda falling, while shippers declined after the Baltic dry index dropped.

site_title: Sembcorp Audit Committee chairman retires
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced the retirement of its Audit Committee chairman, Bobby Chin Yoke Choong, effective April 19, 2017. He will be replaced by Yap Chee Keong, an independent director since 2016. Chin, who chaired the Audit Committee since 2011, opted not to re-elect. Yap, a trained accountant, brings experience as former executive director of The Straits Trading Company and chief financial officer of Singapore Power.

site_title: Christian governor loses Jakarta run-off: pollsters
summary: Christian governor Anies Baswedan won the Jakarta run-off election by over 10 percentage points against Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who was accused of blasphemy and standing trial. The results come after a divisive battle that has damaged Indonesia's reputation as a bastion of tolerant Islam. Official results are expected in early May, but private pollsters indicate Baswedan's victory.

site_title: Approval for Duterte's drug war slips in Philippines
summary: Philippines' satisfaction with President Rodrigo Duterte's war on drugs declined to 78% in the first quarter of this year, down from 85% in December. Human rights monitors believe many of the victims were killed by paid assassins operating with police backing, while police deny involvement. The survey also showed 73% of Filipinos worried about extrajudicial killings, and 92% wanted authorities to capture drug suspects alive. The decline in satisfaction may impact the police, not the president, according to reform advocates.

site_title: ST Electronics wins Sri Lankan cyber security contract
summary: ST Electronics won a contract with Sri Lanka's Information and Communication Technology Agency to design and implement a National Cyber Security Operations Centre's strategy. The contract also includes providing training and awareness programs to strengthen cyber readiness. This move aims to enhance Sri Lanka's digital team's and other key partners' cyber security capabilities.

site_title: Swiber not able to pay coupon, redeem principal of medium-term notes
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-based company, is unable to pay the coupon for and redeem the principal of S$160 million of outstanding medium-term notes. The notes, issued under a S$1 billion multi-currency debt program, matured on April 18, 2017, with a fixed interest rate of 7.125%. Judicial managers cited the company's inability to pay as the reason for the default.

site_title: Life's illusions catching up with Japan's middle-aged "parasite singles"
summary: Japan's middle-aged "parasite singles," who live with their parents, face a precarious future as their youth and savings dwindle. Over 4.5 million Japanese aged 35-54 rely on their parents for support, threatening to burden Japan's already strained social welfare system. This demographic trend, which emerged two decades ago, is driven by low-paying jobs, unstable careers, and an increase in irregular workers. Experts warn that these singles will struggle to find stable income and support themselves once their parents pass away.

site_title: Gold's top forecaster says prices may hit US$1,350 by year-end
summary: Gold prices may reach $1,350 by year-end, according to Intesa Sanpaolo's top forecaster Daniela Corsini. The prediction is driven by faster inflation and geopolitical tensions, particularly in Russia, Syria, and North Korea. Prices have risen 12% this year, supported by inflation concerns and geopolitical worries. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in mid-year may cause a temporary drop, but gold is expected to bounce back by year-end, making it the highest level since September. Silver is predicted to reach $19 an ounce by year-end.

site_title: Akzo plans break up within year to counter rival PPG's bid
summary: Akzo Nobel plans to break up its chemicals division within 12 months to counter a rival PPG Industries' $24 billion bid. The company will sell or spin off its specialty chemicals business and return 1.6 billion euros to shareholders. The separation will deliver superior shareholder value, according to CEO Ton Buechner, and create more value with less risk. Akzo Nobel reported better-than-expected first-quarter results, and the company aims to achieve a 15% return on sales by 2020 for its paint and coatings business.

site_title: Golf: Kiwi Ko fires yet another caddie
summary: New Zealand golfer Lydia Ko has parted ways with her ninth caddie, South African Gary Matthews, after the Lotte Championship in Hawaii. Matthews, who worked with Ko for only nine events, criticized her for having gone through so many caddies, suggesting she needs to prioritize relationships. This follows Ko's previous dismissals of her swing coach David Leadbetter and bag-man Jason Hamilton, citing a lack of communication within her team. Matthews expressed surprise at his dismissal and questioned the decision to hire a new caddie.

site_title: Trump era a new challenge for the IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) faces a new challenge under the Trump administration, with divergences on key issues such as financial regulation, climate change, and global trade. The IMF warns of the economic dangers of excessive deregulation and climate change, while the Trump administration casts doubt on these issues. The IMF has also defended multilateralism, which is seen as a counter-argument to Trump's protectionist policies. The IMF is holding its ground despite potential tensions with the US, which could impact its independence and influence.

site_title: South Korea set to open lavish casino as missile spat scares off Chinese gamblers
summary: South Korea's first casino resort, Paradise City, is set to open despite a diplomatic spat with China, which usually accounts for half of Korea's foreigner gaming revenue. A ban on Chinese travel agents selling tours to South Korea due to a planned anti-North Korea missile defence system has scared off Chinese gamblers. To offset the revenue drop, Paradise and Sega Sammy will target consumers in Japan and Southeast Asia. The resort's non-gaming amenities, such as hotels and convention halls, will also be marketed to South Koreans who cannot enter the casino.

site_title: Update: Indonesian Muslim candidate takes big lead in Jakarta election
summary: A former Indonesian education minister, Anies Baswedan, has taken a significant lead in the Jakarta governor's election, with 57% of the votes compared to 43% for Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, known as "Ahok". The election, which was marked by a polarizing campaign and concerns about voter intimidation and religious tensions, is seen as a test for Indonesia's young democracy and record of tolerance. The national elections commission will announce official results in early May.

site_title: China carmakers may be 'destroyed' if foreign caps lifted
summary: China's government may lift the 50% cap on foreign investment in the country's automotive industry, potentially destroying state-owned carmakers if they're not competitive. If lifted, foreign companies like General Motors, Toyota, and Volkswagen could earn billions of dollars in profits, but local brands may struggle to innovate and improve quality. Analysts say the policy change could lead to a more efficient and healthy automotive industry in China, but also risks forcing local manufacturers to dissolve partnerships and invest in other ventures.

site_title: Oil prices dip on bloated US market, mixed Saudi signals
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday as US market supplies outweighed Saudi Arabia's efforts to boost production. US crude inventories remained near record highs, while gasoline stocks rose due to increased refinery runs. Saudi crude exports fell to 6.96 million barrels per day in February, but domestic production rose to 10 million barrels per day. This move lent support to the market, which was also boosted by Opec's production cuts. US President Trump has ordered a review of lifting sanctions against Iran, which could impact global oil prices.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall on global uncertainty, pound holds rally
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday due to global uncertainty, with Britain's snap election announcement adding to the mix. The pound surged over 2% against the dollar, but London stocks still declined. The FTSE fell 2.5%, while the Dow sank 0.6%. Other markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, also fell. Safe haven assets, such as gold, rose as investors fretted over global uncertainty, including the French election and US-North Korea tensions.

site_title: Australia shares close at over 3-week low as banks lose; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.56% to a three-week low, closing at 5804.00, amid concerns over the country's housing market and persistent weakness in energy stocks. Investors dumped heavyweight bank shares following the Reserve Bank of Australia's risk warnings. Market sentiment was also dampened by global events, including the French presidential election and tensions between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Australia dollar sinks on sterling, NZ dollar more buoyant
summary: The Australian dollar declined 0.4% to US$0.7525, pressured by a 2.6% surge in sterling and iron ore price falls. Sterling's gain was attributed to a UK snap election, while iron ore prices dropped to 13-week lows due to Chinese supply concerns. In contrast, the New Zealand dollar rose 0.4% to US$0.7046, boosted by strong dairy prices and inflation forecasts.

site_title: Singapore retains 10th spot in FDI Confidence Index
summary: Singapore retains its 10th spot in the 2017 A T Kearney Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Confidence Index, retaining its ranking from last year. 30% of respondents showed increased optimism about the country's economic outlook, with investors from Asia-Pacific and industry sectors expressing the most interest in investing in Singapore. The US retained its top spot, while Germany rose two places to second, and China fell to third.

images.alt_text: The 2017 A T Kearney Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Confidence Index puts Singapore in 10th position this year - a ranking it retained from last year.

site_title: Google to help train 1,000 SME business leaders in Singapore
summary: Google has announced plans to train 1,000 SME business leaders in Singapore by 2019 through its Squared Online for SMEs programme, in collaboration with UK-based AVADO, Spring Singapore, and IMDA. The digital leadership and marketing course aims to equip businesses with skills to boost in-house digital marketing capabilities and reach global consumers online. This initiative aligns with the Singapore government's "SMEs Go Digital Programme".

images.alt_text: Google on Wednesday announced plans to work with leading global training providers to equip 1,000 business leaders in the small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) sector by 2019.

site_title: Death by overwork: Japan's 100-hour overtime cap sparks anger
summary: Japan's government has proposed a 100-hour monthly overtime cap to address the nation's health crisis caused by overwork, known as "karoshi." The plan, which aims to reduce deaths from strokes, heart attacks, and suicides, has been met with criticism from labor groups and relatives of victims, who say it is insufficient. The cap would limit overtime, but allow employers to make exceptions for busy periods. Critics argue that the plan does not go far enough to tackle the issue and that more stringent action is needed to prevent further deaths.

site_title: China's Xi restructures military, consolidates control
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has announced a military restructuring of the People's Liberation Army (PLA), transforming it into a leaner fighting force with improved joint operations capability. The new structure consists of 84 combined-corps units, with commanders holding major-general or rear-admiral ranks. This is the second major phase of Xi's military reforms, which aim to modernize the PLA and root out corruption. The restructuring is part of Xi's efforts to upgrade China's military hardware and expand its military prowess overseas, amid growing assertiveness in the South China Sea.

site_title: Toyota, Fiat Chrysler lead European car sales gain
summary: European car sales rose 10.9% in March, driven by strong demand in top five markets and gains from Toyota, Fiat Chrysler, and Nissan. Registrations reached 1.937 million, with Toyota recording the largest monthly advance at 18.8%, followed by Fiat Chrysler at 18.2% and Nissan at 17.7%. Volkswagen and PSA Group underperformed, while Renault saw a 14.4% increase in deliveries. Germany, Britain, France, Italy, and Spain all posted auto sales growth of between 7% and 18%.

images.alt_text: European car sales rose 10.9 per cent in March, led by buoyant demand in the region's top five markets and strong gains for Toyota, Fiat Chrysler and Nissan, according to industry data published on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia shares hover at 3-week low as banks struggle; NZ slips
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.5% to a three-week low, with heavyweight banks dropping 0.8-1.4% due to concerns over interest rate hikes and new prudential requirements. Energy shares also declined, while real estate stocks and telecoms rebounded. New Zealand shares slid 0.51% to a two-week low, dragged down by industrial and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges up on reduced North Korea tension, stocks down
summary: South Korea's won edged up 0.1% to 1,140.7 won per US dollar, as reduced North Korea tension partly alleviated market fears. US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis pledged cooperation with China to reduce tensions, while weaker-than-expected US economic data pressured the greenback. South Korean shares slumped 0.6% to 2,136.14 points, with offshore investors selling Kospi shares worth 77.5 billion won.

site_title: Chinese hunt 'once-in-a-lifetime' deals as Xiongan fever endures
summary: Chinese investors are seizing on the "Xiongan fever" as Beijing unveiled plans to create a new economic zone two hours southwest of the capital, sparking a surge in stock prices and domain sales. The region, named after three counties, is expected to receive government support, but experts warn of a correction as the market shows signs of fatigue. The Shanghai stock market has seen 14 of its top 20 performers since the announcement, with combined market value surging 139 billion yuan. Investors are advised to be patient, as significant development is expected to take 15-20 years.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines first to track fleet with satellites
summary: Malaysia Airlines has become the first airline to track its fleet using satellites, partnering with Aireon LLC, SITAONAIR, and FlightAware LLC. The deal allows the airline to monitor flight paths globally, including remote areas. The move comes three years after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which remains a mystery. The tracking system, set to be completed in 2018, uses a new satellite network and technology known as ADS-B, which can track aircraft from space or the ground.

site_title: Rebalancing oil market will take more time: UAE
summary: The UAE's energy minister, Suhail bin Mohammed al-Mazroui, stated that draining the global oil glut will take more time, despite producers cutting supplies. The correction process, which began in mid-2014, will continue.

site_title: Seoul: Won firms as North Korea tensions appear to ease, stocks fall
summary: South Korea's won edged up 0.2% to 1,140.2 won per US dollar, easing concerns over North Korea tensions. US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis vowed to work with China to calm tensions on the peninsula. However, South Korean shares fell 0.5% to 2,138.40 points, weighed down by foreign investor selling. A net 236.6 billion won was dumped from Kospi shares, adding to the downward pressure.

site_title: Singaporeans most demanding when it comes to good service
summary: Singaporeans are the most demanding when it comes to good customer service, with two-thirds of consumers not completing a purchase due to poor service in the past year. Two or more bad experiences trigger a switch to another company, and one in three will immediately switch. Good customer service plays a significant role in buying decisions, but value for money remains the top concern. Singapore ranks third in willingness to spend more due to excellent service, with over 70% willing to spend 16% more.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat at open on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks retreated 0.20% at open on Wednesday, following losses in New York due to geopolitical uncertainty and the UK's snap general election. The Hang Seng Index dropped 48.56 points to 23,875.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.38% to 3,184.67. The decline was attributed to the global market's reaction to the UK's election news.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust obtains URA nod to redevelop Golden Shoe Car Park
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) has received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to redevelop the 10-storey Golden Shoe Car Park in Singapore's Central Business District. The redevelopment plan includes a higher-value commercial development with an office tower, potentially creating 1 million sq ft of commercial space. CCT now awaits clearance from the Singapore Land Authority on the differential premium (DP) payable for the project.

site_title: How UOB Asset Management became an award-winning fixed income house
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has been awarded "Best Fixed Income Fund House" by Morningstar in 2017, thanks to its comprehensive risk management system. The firm's Chief Investment Officer, Mr Chong Jiun Yeh, attributes the success to managing downside risk and conducting fundamental research. UOBAM uses an internal credit scorecard to evaluate bond issuers and actively manages various risks, including duration and credit risk. The firm's bond funds have consistently generated stable returns, with 64% of its fixed income funds rated four stars and above by Morningstar.

site_title: Malaysia March inflation at highest in 8 years, but below forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price inflation reached an 8-year high of 5.1% in March, driven by higher retail fuel prices and a low-base effect. This is slightly below the forecast of 5.3% in a Reuters poll. Despite the increase, the central bank is unlikely to change its monetary policy stance, as global oil prices are expected to remain stable. The inflation rate is higher than the historical average, but it is expected to taper off in the second half of the year, according to Bank Negara Malaysia.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q1 DPU up 0.21 cents to 2.4 cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust reported a 0.21 cent increase in distribution per unit to 2.40 Singapore cents for Q1 2017, with net property income growing 34.3% to S$69.9 million. Gross revenue also rose 33.9% to S$89.5 million. The trust's positive results are attributed to higher occupancy rates and revenue consolidation of CapitaGreen's assets. However, the Singapore office market remains challenging, with downward rental pressure expected to continue throughout 2017.

images.alt_text: Capitaland Commercial Trust reported an estimated distribution per unit of 2.40 Singapore cents for the first three months of 2017, 0.21 cents higher than the 2.19 cents reported the same period a year ago

site_title: Singapore ties with Germany for most powerful passport in the world
summary: Singapore has tied with Germany as the country with the most powerful passport in the world, according to Arton Capital's Passport Index 2017. This marks the first time Singapore has reached the top spot. Both Singapore and Germany have the most visa-free travel destinations, with 192 and 190 options respectively. The ranking is based on the number of visa-free travel destinations a passport offers to its holders.

site_title: China renewable power waste worsens in 2016: Greenpeace
