summary: China's renewable power waste worsened in 2016, with wasted wind power reaching 17% of total generated by wind farms, up from 8% in 2014. Solar curtailment rates rose 50% over 2015 and 2016, with over 30% of available solar power in Gansu and Xinjiang failing to reach the grid. The industry lost 34.1 billion yuan (S$7 billion) in earnings due to waste. Greenpeace urges upgrades to the grid, efficient transmission channels, and smart peak load operation to address the issue.

site_title: May sees election opportunity in Brexit economy's sweet spot
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has called a snap election on June 8, capitalizing on the country's low unemployment and forecast-defying growth. The economy is in a "sweet spot," with exporters benefiting from a weaker pound and full access to the single market. The IMF has upgraded Britain's outlook, and economists see 1.8% growth this year, matching 2016's pace. The election aims to strengthen May's hand in Brexit talks, but the opposition Labour Party may capitalize on the bleaker economic outlook, particularly on inflation and wage growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.44% and the Topix index declining 0.40%. The decline was attributed to a firm yen and drops on US and European markets following British Prime Minister Theresa May's call for a snap election.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.42% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks dropped 0.42% on Wednesday, mirroring Asian market declines due to political uncertainties. The Straits Times Index fell to 3,124.40, with 39.8 million shares traded worth S$70.2 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 49. This move comes after a 5-day rally, and investors are awaiting GDP data.

site_title: Venezuela braces for 'mother of all protests'
summary: Venezuela is bracing for rival demonstrations on Wednesday, with opponents of President Nicolas Maduro vowing to stage the "mother of all protests" against his rule. The protests follow two weeks of violent demonstrations that have left five dead and dozens wounded. Maduro has urged his supporters and security forces to defend the leftist "revolution" launched by his late predecessor Hugo Chavez in 1999. The move is seen as a bid to tighten his grip on power amid the country's deepening political and economic crisis.

site_title: Oil slides more after US settlement on API inventory report
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday after the American Petroleum Institute reported that US crude stockpiles declined less than expected, while gasoline stockpiles grew unseasonably. Crude prices dropped over 1% to $52.32 a barrel, and global benchmark Brent crude futures fell to $54.61, the lowest since April 7. The US shale production is expected to rise to 5.19 million barrels per day, putting pressure on crude prices amid OPEC production cuts.

site_title: US 'Facebook killer' takes own life after police chase
summary: A 37-year-old US gunman, Steve Stephens, who posted a video of an elderly grandfather's murder on Facebook, took his own life during a brief police chase in Pennsylvania. Stephens had been on the run since Easter Sunday, when he killed 74-year-old Robert Godwin Sr in Cleveland, Ohio. Facebook removed the footage and acknowledged its role in the disturbing trend of violent content being shared on social media, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg vowing to prevent similar tragedies. The incident has sparked a nationwide debate on the issue of violence on social media and gun crime in America.

site_title: Yahoo earnings beat expectations on cusp of Verizon merger
summary: Yahoo reported quarterly earnings of $99 million on $1.3 billion in revenue, beating expectations, as it nears completion of its $4.48 billion sale to Verizon. The deal will integrate Yahoo's core internet operations into Verizon's "Oath" unit, marking the end of Yahoo's 20-year run as an independent company. The sale comes after Yahoo slashed the price of its core business by $350 million, partly to offset the costs of two major hacks. Yahoo shares remained flat at $47.56 after the earnings release.

site_title: Taipei: Stocks drop tracking Asian shares
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.68% to 9,679.40, tracking Asian shares, amid disappointing US economic data and uncertainty over tax cuts. The electronics subindex dropped 0.7%, while the financial subindex slipped 0.6%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$30.380 to the US dollar.

site_title: Facebook pushes to augment reality through smartphones
summary: Facebook has launched a mission to integrate augmented reality (AR) features into its social network, focusing on smartphone cameras rather than high-tech eyewear. CEO Mark Zuckerberg predicted the technology would eventually be incorporated into eyeglasses. The company showcased AR tools, including the ability to add digital decorations to real-world photos and paint 3D images with taps of smartphone camera screens. This move aims to compete with Snapchat and other AR platforms, following Facebook's slow entry into the AR space.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Ezra, Healthway
summary: Three companies saw new developments affecting their share prices: CapitaLand Commercial Trust reported higher distribution per unit, increased net property income, and initial approval for a redevelopment plan. Ezra Holdings' noteholders urged the founding Lee family to consider a rights issue as part of a restructuring plan. Healthway Medical Corporation faces concerns from minority shareholders about a private-equity fund's involvement in a proposed S$60 million convertible note issuance.

site_title: Vanguard is growing faster than everybody else - combined
summary: Vanguard, a US$4.2 trillion mutual fund giant, is experiencing unprecedented growth, with investors pouring US$823 billion into its funds over the last three years. This influx of money has led to a significant shift away from actively managed funds, with Vanguard's low-cost index mutual funds and ETFs attracting 8.5 times more assets than its competitors. The company's assets under management have skyrocketed to US$4.2 trillion from US$1 trillion seven years ago, with US$3 trillion invested in passive index-based strategies. Vanguard's success has led to a "Vanguard effect," with rival BlackRock announcing changes to its stock-picking operations.

site_title: UOB ties up with KrisFlyer to land S$1.5b in deposits
summary: UOB and Singapore Airlines' KrisFlyer have launched a new current account that allows customers to earn miles for every dollar spent using a debit card. The account aims to attract customers who prefer debit cards or millennials who may not be eligible for credit cards to accumulate miles. UOB expects to bring in S$1.5 billion in deposits in the next five years through this initiative. Customers with a monthly balance of S$350,000 can earn up to 5.4 KrisFlyer miles per dollar spent, while those with a balance of S$3,000-S$100,000 can earn up to 1.4 miles per dollar spent.

site_title: Getting onto the tech bandwagon
summary: Retail investors can tap into the long-term growth prospects of technology and innovation by investing in technology equity funds. Disruptive technologies like cloud computing, AI, and machine learning are expected to drive growth, with global revenue for AI products projected to grow 57 times by 2025. Technology stocks, such as those in the US automotive industry, are also making attractive investments. Investing in technology equity funds, like UOB Asset Management's United Global Technology Fund, which holds companies like Salesforce, Alibaba, and Tesla, can provide retail investors with opportunities to capitalize on these trends.

site_title: Trump seeks headway on 'Buy American, Hire American' pledge
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued an executive order tightening skilled-worker visa rules, aiming to "Buy American, Hire American." The decree instructs government agencies to tackle "abuses" of the H-1B visa system, which awards time-limited work permits to scientists, engineers, and computer programmers. Trump argues the current system harms American workers, but the US Chamber of Commerce warns against eliminating the program altogether. The decree is seen as a transitional step towards broader congressional reform, with the White House hoping to spur momentum for a more skill-based and merit-based system.

site_title: Three dead as man goes on killing spree in California town
summary: A 39-year-old man, Kori Ali Muhammad, went on a shooting spree in Fresno, California, killing three people and injuring another before being arrested. Muhammad, who had previously shot a security guard, shouted "Allahu Akbar" as he was taken into custody. He faces four counts of murder and two counts of attempted murder, and had indicated hatred for white people and the government. The motive behind the killings is unclear, and authorities have not confirmed whether they are terror-related. Muhammad used an unknown weapon during the rampage.

images.alt_text: A road is blocked by police tape after a multiple victim shooting incident in downtown Fresno, California, U.S on April 18, 2017.

site_title: Indonesia's capital votes amid religious tension
summary: Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, held a closely watched election runoff, with Christian Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama facing a Muslim challenger, Anies Baswedan. The vote comes amidst religious tensions and a blasphemy trial for Purnama, who was accused of insulting the Koran. The outcome will test Indonesia's tolerant brand of Islam against the rising influence of hardliners, with analysts warning of a "new type of political Islam" if Purnama loses. Over 7.2 million people are registered to vote, with polls opening and closing at 7am and 1pm local time.

site_title: Trump team bluster exposed as aircraft carrier steams in opposite direction
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed to have sent an "armada" to warn North Korea, but a US aircraft carrier strike group was actually headed in the opposite direction, away from the Korean peninsula. The group was still undergoing training with Australia before moving to the Western Pacific as ordered. Meanwhile, North Korea displayed new missiles and staged a failed missile test. The US military's Pacific Command clarified the situation, stating the strike group was proceeding to the Western Pacific as planned. Trump's boast was exposed as bluster.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 3-week lows amid jitters over British, French votes
summary: European shares hit 3-week lows amid concerns over British and French elections. The STOXX 600 index closed down 1% and Britain's FTSE 100 fell 2.5%. Theresa May's call for an early election in Britain and the first round of France's presidential election loomed. The decline was the worst in 10 weeks, largely due to uncertainty over Britain's exit from the EU.

site_title: Former US President George HW Bush hospitalised again in Houston
summary: Former US President George HW Bush was hospitalized in Houston for the second time in 2017, this time for an unspecified condition, and is expected to make a full recovery. He was readmitted to Houston Methodist Hospital, where he was treated earlier for pneumonia. Bush, 92, is the nation's oldest living ex-president.

images.alt_text: Former US President George HW Bush was been readmitted to the hospital in Houston where he was treated earlier this year for pneumonia but "is going to be fine," his spokesman said on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Wall Street hit by weak Goldman, J&J results
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday due to disappointing earnings from Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson, with the Dow experiencing its sharpest drop. The sell-off was partly driven by European markets, which were affected by a surprise call for snap British elections and concerns over the French presidential election. Despite this, US equities remained near fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs.

site_title: Goldman Sachs shares fall as profits up less than expected
summary: Goldman Sachs reported sharply higher first-quarter profits, but they fell short of analysts' expectations due to a sluggish trading performance. The bank's earnings surged to $2.3 billion, up 80.2% from last year, but the profit per share of $5.15 was below the estimated $5.31. Goldman's trading revenues were down 2% from the year-ago period, while its debt and equity underwriting business saw a more attractive backdrop. The bank's CEO, Lloyd Blankfein, attributed the weak performance to a "mixed" operating environment and client activity challenged in certain market-making businesses.

site_title: G-7 right to hold back on sanctions against Russia and Syria
summary: The G-7 foreign ministers rejected proposed US and UK sanctions on Russia and Syria following the April 4 chemical attack on Khan Sheikhoun. Sanctions alone would not convince Vladimir Putin to abandon his strategic relationship with Bashar al-Assad. The US should learn from history, as sanctions are rarely effective and can lead to war. Examples of failed sanctions include the Athenian empire's imposition on Megara, Napoleon's blockade of Britain, and US sanctions against Cuba, which failed to provoke a regime change.

site_title: Credit Suisse pay revolt rumbles on even after concessions
summary: Credit Suisse has failed to completely quash a shareholder revolt over payouts to senior managers, despite offering to cut bonuses by 40% and a pay freeze for the board of directors. Proxy advisors ISS and Glass Lewis softened their stance, urging shareholders to vote in favor of the board's pay and executive committee pay proposals. However, ISS still opposes the proposed short-term variable pay for the executive committee, and Glass Lewis calls the concessions "too little too late." Shareholders will vote on April 28, which could be the first use of Switzerland's veto power over management and board pay.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has failed to completely quash a shareholder revolt over payouts to the bank's senior managers, even after offering to cut bonuses for top management by 40 per cent and a pay freeze for its board of directors.

site_title: Singapore still No 1 draw for talent among Asia-Pacific countries
summary: Singapore retains its top spot in the Asia-Pacific and second globally for the fourth consecutive year in the Global Talent Competitiveness Index 2017, making it the only Asian country to emerge in the top 10. Switzerland is ranked first, while the UK clinches the third spot. The report highlights Singapore's strong talent readiness, education system, and regulatory landscape, but notes that countries like China and India face challenges in attracting and retaining talent.

images.alt_text: Singapore retains its top spot in the Asia-Pacific and second globally for the fourth consecutive year in the Global Talent Competitiveness Index (GTCI) 2017, making it the only Asian country to emerge in the top 10 this year.

site_title: Rise of underdogs on Easter Sunday
summary: Several underdog teams achieved surprise victories on Easter Sunday, including Canada's rugby team, Indian shuttlers B Sai Praneeth and K Srikanth, and US golfer Wesley Bryan. Canada won the HSBC World Rugby Sevens, while Bryan claimed his first US PGA title, defeating former World No. 1 Luke Donald by one shot. These upsets showcase the power of determination and grit, inspiring wild celebrations among the teams and fans.

site_title: Beijing to gather friends for biggest summit of the year on its New Silk Road plan
summary: China is set to host its biggest diplomatic event of the year in May, a summit on its New Silk Road plan, with most Asian leaders attending. The summit aims to build a new Silk Road linking Asia, Africa, and Europe, investing billions of dollars in infrastructure projects. Foreign Minister Wang Yi announced the list of attendees, including Russian President Vladimir Putin, Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, but excluded Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and officials from Japan, South Korea, and North Korea. Only one G-7 leader, Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni, is expected to attend.

site_title: Strong subscriber outlook pushes Netflix shares towards all-time high
summary: Netflix reported a 5 million global subscriber increase in the first quarter, slightly below analyst projections. Despite this, the company forecast 3.2 million additional subscribers in the second quarter, exceeding expectations. This growth is expected to propel Netflix towards an all-time high, with the company aiming to surpass 100 million global subscribers. Net income rose to $178 million, and revenue increased 35% to $2.64 billion. CEO Reed Hastings emphasized the importance of looking at growth over time, shifting the focus from subscriber numbers to revenue growth and global operating margins.

site_title: Regulator scrutiny blamed for speeding up bank Brexit
summary: Regulators' demands for full contingency plans for a worst-case "Brexit" scenario are accelerating the relocation of banking operations from London to the continent. The Bank of England and European Central Bank have given lenders a July 14 deadline to submit plans, which could spur firms to move their operations to the eurozone to secure office space and staff. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU is causing foreign bankers to ask to relocate, and firms may start to implement their plans before clarity is reached on the transitional arrangement.

site_title: Global economy may be turning around from stagnation: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) suggests that the global economy is gaining momentum, potentially ending a decade of sluggishness since the 2008 global financial crisis. Global growth is projected to increase to 3.5% this year and 3.6% next year, with emerging-market and developing economies expected to see significant growth. However, the report warns that the post-World War II system of international economic relations is under strain due to rising protectionism, and policy must address these disparities to ensure the stability of an open, collaborative trading system.

site_title: Nippecraft told to make cash exit offer to shareholders
summary: Nippecraft, a Singaporean paper products maker, has been ordered to make a cash exit offer to its shareholders after failing to meet the Singapore Exchange's watch-list requirements. The company was put on the list three years ago, but was denied an extension. Trading of its shares will continue until May 9, with a suspension from May 11 until the offer is completed. Nippecraft hopes to obtain an extension, citing one-off expenses that prevented the company from being profitable in 2016.

site_title: Not too late to board investment train
summary: Global financial markets have surged significantly since the start of 2017, driven by economic optimism across the developed and emerging world. Analysts say it's not too late to invest, citing improved economic fundamentals and lower valuations in Europe and Asia. Despite potential volatility due to geopolitical risks, many experts expect gains of 5% for global equities in the rest of the year. Opportunities abound in emerging markets, particularly in Asia and Europe, with asset classes like bonds and commodities also showing promise.

site_title: Indonesia, Vietnam are JLL's industrial picks
summary: JLL has identified Indonesia and Vietnam as its top picks for industrial investments in Southeast Asia, citing higher yields of 10-12% compared to more mature markets like Singapore and Malaysia. The effective cash-on-cash yield can be as attractive as 11-15%, driven by strong rental growth and lower land tenures in these countries. The shift of manufacturers from China, driven by rising labor costs and land prices, is expected to further boost the region's industrial land market.

site_title: United Airlines posts earnings that top forecasts, vows to treat customers better
summary: United Airlines reported first-quarter earnings of 41 cents per share, beating forecasts and exceeding revenue expectations. The airline attributed the results to a strong financial performance, despite higher fuel costs and labor agreements. CEO Oscar Munoz vowed to treat customers better, citing the recent controversy over a passenger being forcibly removed from a flight. United shares rose 0.9% after the announcement, as the company aims to rebuild its reputation and focus on customer service.

site_title: China is home to world's hottest property stocks as investors ignore curbs
summary: China's real estate market is experiencing significant growth, with Chinese companies accounting for nine of the 10 best performers on the Bloomberg World Real Estate Index. Companies like Country Garden Holdings Co, Sunac China Holdings Ltd, and China Evergrande Group have seen gains of over 70%, outpacing the benchmark measure by five times. Despite stricter measures to curb prices, investors remain optimistic, highlighting China's dominance in the world's hottest property stocks.

site_title: Australia toughens foreign worker visa
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced the abolition of the 457 visa program, replacing it with a new visa requiring better English language and work skills. The move aims to attract skilled workers and prioritize Australian jobs over cheap foreign labor. The new temporary visa will be limited to two years, with a higher standard of English language required for a four-year visa. The change is seen as a step towards Australian jobs and values, with Turnbull rejecting suggestions that it was driven by nationalistic policies.

site_title: Private debt investments garner interest
summary: BlackRock's managing director James Keenan says the private debt market is "incredibly attractive" with stable cash flows and higher yields. The private debt universe has grown quadrupling since 2006, reaching $595 billion in assets under management as of June 2016. Investors are attracted to the asset class, with 93% meeting or exceeding performance expectations over the past year. BlackRock is raising capital for two middle-market secure investing private debt strategies, targeting opportunities in dislocations and lower volatility. Keenan notes that investors must be disciplined and have the right team to achieve long-term risk-adjusted returns.

site_title: Retirement planning: different options to suit individual needs
summary: Singaporeans preparing for retirement face various options to suit their individual needs. The Central Provident Fund (CPF) is a key option, providing a basic standard of living, but it may not be enough on its own. Supplements such as the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS), endowment policies, and investments in equities, ETFs, and Reits can help achieve financial goals in a shorter period. Bonds and annuities can also provide stable income streams, while annuities offer certainty of an income stream and hedge against longevity risks. It's essential to consider risk appetite, investment horizon, and financial resources when choosing a retirement plan.

site_title: China Construction Bank expands in S'pore with eye on infrastructure projects
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB), the country's second-largest lender, has established a centre in Singapore to focus on infrastructure financing, part of its over US$90 billion "One Belt, One Road" projects. This move comes as the bank also launched a private banking centre and set up a Singapore subsidiary of its investment services arm, CCB International. The expansion aims to tap into Singapore's infrastructure development opportunities.

site_title: STI rebound fades as N Korea concerns return
summary: The Straits Times Index closed at 3,137.54, down 0.76 points, after an overnight rise on Wall Street was overshadowed by geopolitical concerns, particularly surrounding North Korea. Moderate trading of 2.6 billion units worth S$1.05 billion occurred, with the average value per unit traded at S$0.40. M1's shares finished weaker at S$2.12, while Hotung Investment Holdings rose S$0.015 to S$1.74. Macquarie Equities Research raised its STI target to 3,235, citing stronger non-oil domestic exports readings. DBS's chief investment officer advised investors to stay cautious towards risk assets due to geopolitical events and high US equities valuations.

site_title: Upcoming French election will be most unpredictable in decades
summary: The French presidential election, scheduled for two stages, is considered the most unpredictable in decades due to the rise of left-wing candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon, who has surged in polls and could potentially face off against National Front leader Marine Le Pen in the second round. The outcome is uncertain, with up to a third of voters potentially abstaining and many undecided between the 11 candidates. The election's unpredictability has been fueled by anti-establishment anger, economic pain, and distrust of the political class, with all four major candidates having differing views on the euro, European Union, and NATO.

site_title: South32 scraps US$200m acquisition of Australian coal mine from Peabody
summary: South32 Ltd scrapped a US$200 million deal to acquire Peabody Energy's Metropolitan coal mine in Australia due to competition concerns. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) blocked the deal, citing concerns over the concentration of coal reserves in the hands of a few big miners. Steel producers opposed the deal, fearing South32 would become the sole supplier to the eastern Illawarra steelmaking hub. Peabody Energy will retain the mine and coal terminal, and resume shipments after completing a move in May.

site_title: P&G makes US$100m digital innovation move at Singapore centre
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has launched a US$100 million digital innovation centre in Singapore, focusing on supply chain management, e-business strategy, and e-analytics. The E-Center, in partnership with the Economic Development Board, aims to boost digital capabilities and strengthen partnerships with small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The centre will hire up to 50 people and expand further in the next few years, supporting SMEs in developing new digital solutions. This move is part of Singapore's push towards digitalisation, a major priority for the country.

site_title: Russian shipping firm Soufflot holds Venezuela tanker's cargo over unpaid fees
summary: Russia's shipping firm Soufflot is holding onto a tanker's cargo of crude oil from Venezuela due to unpaid shipping fees. The tanker, NS Columbus, was sent to the Caribbean with an expected payment of $20 million but Sovcomflot is seeking $30 million. A court in St Maarten has allowed Sovcomflot to impose garnishment on the cargo, which was discharged at a storage terminal on St Eustatius. The dispute highlights how shipping companies are aggressively pursuing PDVSA's debts, despite Venezuela's political ally Russia's support.

site_title: Is there a future for the private shipowner?
summary: A debate at Singapore Maritime Week 2017 questions whether the private shipowner has a future, with some experts arguing that family businesses can thrive in the face of challenges, while others believe the trend is shifting towards corporate ownership. The debate features speakers from various companies, including Citigroup and Louis Dreyfus Armateurs, who argue that private shipowners can adapt and innovate to stay ahead, while others see increased challenges and the need for alternative financial solutions. The outcome of the debate is uncertain, but it highlights the ongoing debate about the future of private shipownership.

site_title: British PM calls June 8 election to raise Conservative majority
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May called a June 8 election to counter Brexit divisions in parliament and provide certainty and stability. The move aims to strengthen the government's negotiating position with the EU and address concerns over the Conservative Party's minority majority. May's decision follows polls showing public support for her Brexit team, but the party faces opposition from within and outside parliament, with Labour and other parties threatening to vote against the deal. The election is seen as a crucial test of May's leadership and the UK's ability to navigate Brexit negotiations.

site_title: China's Bright to sell Weetabix to Post Holdings for US$1.76b
summary: China's Bright Food Group Co Ltd agreed to sell iconic British cereal brand Weetabix to US cereal company Post Holdings for US$1.76 billion. This sale marks the end of Chinese ownership after Bright took control in 2012. The deal is part of Bright's internationalization strategy, allowing the company to expand overseas. Weetabix, a 85-year-old brand, had earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) of £130 million in 2016. The sale does not signal the end of Bright's international ambitions.

site_title: Volatile markets in 2017 bring trading opportunities
summary: Global financial markets experienced a surge in 2017, with the US, Europe, Hong Kong, and Singapore markets rising 6-10% in the first three months of the year. Investors can gain exposure to these markets through Index CFDs, which offer leveraged investments with a small deposit. IG, a market leader in CFD trading, allows investors to trade 24/7 in Singapore dollars. To mitigate risks, investors should consider attaching a guaranteed stop to their positions and incorporating risk management tools into their trading strategy.

site_title: Q1 car registrations surge 12.1%
summary: Singapore's car registrations surged 12.1% in the first quarter of 2017, with 22,315 units registered. Honda retained its top spot with 4,893 units, followed by Toyota with 4,286 units. Mercedes-Benz moved up to third place with 2,127 registrations. Mazda's Mazda3 took the top spot in terms of model, with 1,347 registrations, followed by the Nissan Qashqai and Mitsubishi Attrage. Luxury brands saw significant growth, with Mercedes-Benz and Audi entering the Top 10 for the first time.

site_title: Why don't all jobs matter?
summary: US President Donald Trump's promises to revive coal jobs have been met with skepticism, as the underlying reasons for the decline, including automation and cheap natural gas, persist. Meanwhile, declines in service sectors such as retail and newspaper publishing have been largely ignored in public discussion. The focus on mining and manufacturing jobs may be driven by the need for villains and the perception that these workers are more likely to be male and white. However, all jobs matter, and efforts can be made to limit the human damage of job losses by guaranteeing healthcare, retirement income, and aid to the unemployed, as well as investing in infrastructure and education.

site_title: US trade deal with S Korea falling short: Pence
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence stated that the US-South Korea free trade deal is "falling short" and the trade gap between the countries has more than doubled since its implementation. Pence attributed the issue to "too many" barriers to entry for US businesses, calling it a "hard truth." South Korea has responded by announcing plans to import more energy products from the US and encouraging its companies to invest in America, amid efforts to avoid being labeled a currency manipulator.

site_title: FGL ditches US$1.6b deal with Anbang
summary: US annuities and life insurer Fidelity & Guaranty Life (FGL) has terminated its US$1.6 billion acquisition deal with Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group Co Ltd, following regulatory approval issues. This marks the latest deal involving Anbang to fall through, following its abandoned attempt to acquire Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc for US$14 billion. The development raises doubts on Anbang's commitment to US deals amid a sharp decline in Chinese outbound investments. FGL is now exploring alternative strategies.

site_title: Keppel signs deal with EDB to build gasification plant on Jurong Island
summary: Keppel Infrastructure has signed an agreement with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to develop a gasification plant on Jurong Island. The facility, which will use coal and other feedstocks, marks a six-year progression from the initial 2011 Jurong Island version 2.0 initiative. Keppel will own and operate the facility, with no specific timeline for completion mentioned.

images.alt_text: Singapore is moving ahead with a gasification facility that uses coal and other feedstock on Jurong Island, some six years after it first studied the idea as part of the Jurong Island version 2.0 initiative.

site_title: Last orders for Uncle Pan's noodles
summary: Bangkok's Governor has ordered the closure of street food stalls, including a 67-year-old vendor, Uncle Pan, who has been serving noodles on the curb for three decades. The vendor must either relocate or downsize his stall by the end of the week. Uncle Pan's stall is a fixture in the Thonglor neighborhood, where it attracts a diverse clientele, including office workers, police, and soldiers. The decision has sparked concerns among the street food vendors, who fear losing their livelihoods and relationships with customers.

site_title: Vacuum cleaner maker SharkNinja up for sale: sources
summary: SharkNinja, the privately held US manufacturer of Ninja blenders and Shark vacuum cleaners, is exploring a sale valued at over $1.5 billion including debt. Private-equity firms have expressed interest in the company, which has hired investment bank Goldman Sachs to run an auction. SharkNinja's owners, Mark Rosenzweig and Mark Barrocas, have stated they have no intention to leave the company, but are seeking a strategic partner to aid in global expansion. The company has built its brand through television advertising and sells products worldwide, with competitors including Dyson.

site_title: Labour friction, politics stoke anti-Chinese ire in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's capital Jakarta is experiencing heightened anti-Chinese sentiment ahead of a bitter election, fueled by conspiracy theories about an influx of illegal Chinese workers. Foreign direct investment from China reached a record high of $2.67 billion last year, but tensions have risen due to Chinese companies bringing in their own workers and machines, creating friction with locals. The issue has been politicized, with rivals of the government capitalizing on anti-foreigner sentiment, and has sparked vigilantism. Chinese investment in Indonesia is at risk due to the volatile political environment.

site_title: Ezra's OSV arm faces winding-up threat
summary: Ezra's offshore support vessel business unit, Emas Offshore Ltd, faces a winding-up threat after receiving a statutory demand from ICBC Financial Leasing Co for a claim exceeding $195 million. The claim, which includes a termination sum of $194.5 million and accrued interest, was made after Ezra's associate, Emas Chiyoda Subsea, rejected a back-to-back bareboat charter for the Lewek Champion vessel. Ezra is seeking legal advice and assessing the impact of the statutory demand, which could lead to the subsidiary's winding up if the claim is not paid within 21 days.

site_title: Germany's VCs hunt for software startups
summary: Germany's venture capital firms have invested US$467 million across 87 equity deals in German-based startups in the first quarter of 2017, a 32% increase from the same period last year. Despite a decline in consumer deals, VCs are shifting focus to software startups, citing Germany's strengths in engineering and high-quality manufacturing. This trend is also driven by UK and US investors, who see Germany's proximity to major companies and its ability to serve global markets as attractive.

site_title: US business group urges govt to 'use every arrow' against China
summary: The US business lobby, American Chamber of Commerce in China, urged the government to "use every arrow" to ensure a level commercial playing field in China, citing China's policies that narrow the space for foreign companies. The report warned that 2017 could be the toughest year for American firms in the country due to market imbalances and Beijing's plans for subsidies and regulations. The chamber hopes for more attention to market access for American firms, but does not want to push the US and China towards a trade war.

site_title: How political events in Europe may impact Asia markets
summary: European Union events may impact Asian markets due to economic ties and access to credit and financial risk markets. Three scenarios are possible: a positive scenario where Greece receives a bailout, mainstream candidates win elections in France, Germany, and Italy, and the euro rises; a neutral scenario where uncertainty persists, and the eurozone falters; and a negative scenario where Greece and Italy's woes worsen, and the eurozone experiences a crisis. These scenarios may influence Asian currency, equity, and bond markets, with a focus on China equities and Asian USD bonds.

site_title: Drone delivery to start on NUS campus by early next year (Amended)
summary: Airbus Helicopters and Singapore Post have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop a safe and economically viable aerial unmanned delivery system for parcels in urban environments. The project, named "Skyways", aims to deploy drones to deliver small parcels across the NUS campus by early next year, with the potential to expand to the entire city. The partnership will leverage SingPost's expertise in software systems and logistics domain knowledge, and will also utilize its parcel locker technology. The goal is to revolutionize the logistics industry with total automation, prioritizing safety and meeting customer needs.

site_title: Ex-monk, 91, builds his own 'cathedral of faith'
summary: A 91-year-old ex-monk, Justo Gallego, has built his own "Cathedral of Faith" in Mejorada del Campo, Madrid, despite never receiving a building permit or public financing. The striking landmark, which he began building in the 1960s, features a 125-foot-tall cupola and attracts tourists on weekends. Gallego, who has never received official support from the Catholic Church, is determined to die in the cathedral, which he considers his life's mission. His project has raised questions about its long-term future, but local residents and clergy support his work, viewing it as an example of faith and determination.

site_title: Healthcare, semiconductor companies looking attractive this year: RHB
summary: RHB Research Institute has highlighted 25 small-cap stocks, including healthcare and semiconductor companies, as attractive picks for the year. The research house expects the semiconductor sector to see a bull market due to increasing output and the introduction of the iPhone 8. In the healthcare sector, consolidation is expected, with private players like TalkMed Group and Singapore Medical Group making acquisitions. Companies such as Avi-Tech Electronics and Moya Holdings Asia are also seen as promising investments.

site_title: Private-hire drivers, home offices could retain protection if insurer collapses
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing changes to the Policy Owners' Protection Scheme, which would provide protection to private-hire drivers and home office owners if their insurers collapse. The scheme, currently funded by insurance providers, would be updated to include "owned by a natural person" policies, covering personal motor insurance and home office insurance. Proposed caps on payouts would limit damages to S$50,000 for personal property and S$300,000 for commercial property. The changes aim to clarify ambiguities and ensure the scheme's fund is not overly exposed to high-value claims.

site_title: Tax players worry that KL's tougher tack on dodgers blurs evasion line
summary: Malaysia's Inland Revenue Board (IRB) has tightened its stance on tax dodgers, adopting stricter interpretations of tax laws to meet rising collection targets. However, tax experts warn that the IRB's measures may blur the line between tax evasion and avoidance. The IRB aims to collect RM127 billion in direct taxes this year, with tougher penalties and increased scrutiny of underground economy operators. Tax consultants suggest the government needs to raise its targets to generate more tax revenue, given the ongoing budget deficit.

site_title: Shire marks Haemophilia Day with kids' visit to plant
summary: Shire, a biotechnology company, marked the 28th World Haemophilia Day by hosting a visit to its Woodlands manufacturing plant for children living with haemophilia. The event aimed to educate them about biologics and blood clotting factors used in haemophilia treatment. About 400,000 people worldwide live with haemophilia, with only 25% receiving adequate treatment. Shire emphasized its commitment to improving haemophilia understanding and treatment, stating that serving the patient community gives it tremendous pride. The event was part of Shire's efforts to engage with the haemophilia community.

site_title: J&J revenue misses on lower-than-expected pharmaceutical sales
summary: Johnson & Johnson reported quarterly revenue of $17.77 billion, missing analysts' estimates due to lower-than-expected pharmaceutical sales, rising 0.8% to $8.25 billion. Net earnings were $4.42 billion, beating expectations. The company's earnings per share, excluding items, beat Street estimates. J&J is the first major pharmaceutical company to report quarterly results after a failed Republican attempt to overhaul the US healthcare system.

images.alt_text: Johnson & Johnson, which is in the process of completing its US$30 billion acquisition of Swiss biotech Actelion, reported on Tuesday quarterly revenue that missed analysts' estimates, hurt by lower demand for its pharmaceutical products.

site_title: Greenback slips against yen on trade concerns
summary: The US dollar slipped against the yen on Tuesday, pressured by concerns over US-Japan economic talks and potential protectionist trade policy. Despite US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments favoring long-term dollar strength, the dollar traded 0.1% lower at 108.68 yen. Meanwhile, the British pound surged 0.9% to its highest levels since early February after Prime Minister Theresa May called for an early general election. Investors remain cautious ahead of the French presidential elections and ongoing North Korea tensions.

site_title: iRobot sues rivals over robot vacuum patents
summary: iRobot, maker of Roomba robot vacuums, filed lawsuits against several companies, including Hoover, Black & Decker, and Bissell, accusing them of infringing on its patented technology. iRobot claims the companies used its autonomous floor-cleaning robot concept without permission. The lawsuits target companies that manufacture robotic vacuums, including Hoover's Quest line and Bissell's SmartClean. The move comes as the robotic vacuum market is expected to reach $2.5 billion by 2021, up from $1.5 billion in 2016.

site_title: The why, how and what next of digital wallets
summary: Digital wallets, which store and transfer funds electronically, are evolving to address the need for seamless transfers across geographies. Initially, mobile phone companies developed digital wallets to facilitate peer-to-peer money transfers. The physical funds are held in a bank account, with the wallet service provider (WSP) acting as a fiduciary. However, the emergence of services like the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) threatens the future of digital wallets, as they eliminate the need for intermediaries and facilitate direct payments. Despite this, digital wallets will continue to evolve to offer seamless transfers, making them a space to watch.

images.alt_text: The emergence of digital payments and wallets is the direct outcome of the smugness and lack of innovation by card-issuance companies.

site_title: MAS, UN unit team up for Asean digital finance with a social mission
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered with the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) to promote digital finance in Asean. The partnership, under the Shaping Inclusive Finance Transformations (Shift) program, aims to digitize low-tier financial institutions, increasing access to financial services for marginalized populations, including women. The collaboration will support projects in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam, with a focus on regulated international remittances. The initiative is expected to spur innovations in women-inclusive business models and contribute to the growth of the local digital financial services ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has sealed a partnership with a United Nations unit to encourage the development of and access to digital financial services in Asean.

site_title: Citigroup names Saudi Arabia CEO as it plans return
summary: Citigroup has appointed Carmen Haddad as its CEO in Saudi Arabia, as the US bank plans its return to the market. Haddad, leading strategy and business development for the kingdom, is set to become CEO once Citigroup secures a banking licence from the Capital Market Authority. This move comes after the bank lost a key licence in 2004 and is in advanced discussions for an investment-banking licence. Haddad's appointment is seen as a step towards Citigroup's return, following successful lead roles on Saudi Arabia's record-breaking bond sales.

site_title: Phoenix Property Investors puts Peck Seah shophouses on the market for $57.8m
summary: HONG KONG-BASED Phoenix Property Investors has put six adjoining shophouses along Peck Seah Street in Singapore on the market for $57.8 million, with an indicative price of $2,900 per square foot. Currently 82% of the 19,938 sq ft GFA is leased, and the asking price reflects a gross yield of close to 3% if fully leased. The property is being marketed through an expressions of interest exercise closing on May 23.

site_title: Gateway's sale of Healthway Medical notes to third parties raises eyebrows
summary: Minority shareholders of Healthway Medical Corporation are questioning Gateway Partners' decision to sell its first tranche of S$10 million in convertible notes to third parties, despite a rival offer from Gentle Care at the same price. This move comes ahead of the company's extraordinary general meeting to vote on the second tranche of S$60 million convertible notes. The sale has raised concerns that Gateway is prioritizing profits over shareholders' interests.

site_title: A nation bids final farewell to a pioneer
summary: Singapore bids farewell to pioneer Cabinet minister Othman Wok, who died on Monday at 92, as the nation pays tribute to one of its founding fathers. Hundreds gathered at the Sultan Mosque for a private funeral prayer, followed by a 26km journey to the Choa Chu Kang Muslim Cemetery. The state flag was draped over the casket, the highest state honour, and a memorial service will be held on Wednesday evening. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Othman for his courage and conviction in achieving racial and religious harmony.

site_title: Taxi officials call on Uber to provide tipping in its app
summary: New York's Taxi and Limousine Commission proposes a rule requiring Uber to provide a tipping option in its app, following a petition from the Independent Drivers Guild. The proposal, which aims to improve earning potential for drivers, comes after Uber drivers have long complained about the lack of a tipping option. The city's taxi commissioner says the rule will help drivers make a decent living, while Uber has expressed concerns that adding tipping could add "friction" to the in-app experience. The proposal will be formally introduced in July and requires approval by the taxi commission's board.

site_title: Jurong West site slated for international school
summary: The Singapore Land Authority and Economic Development Board have announced a tender for a former secondary school site in Jurong West to be repurposed for a foreign system school (FSS). The site will be open for proposals from operators interested in providing affordable international education. The tender specifies a 3+3+3 year rental scheme, allowing operators to provide quality international school education at a more affordable fee, with a focus on quality and price evaluation. The site conversion is expected to be cheaper for operators, with a holistic evaluation process to be conducted.

site_title: Edison, GE unveil new battery systems at gas plants
summary: Southern California Edison and General Electric unveiled a new battery storage system at two gas plants, enabling instant power output and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The 10-megawatt batteries, installed at two peaker plants, cut plant startups in half and reduced total run hours by 60%. The system will work well during periods of low solar power demand, such as at the end of the day, when demand rises. The utility plans to add the systems to three more peaker plants in its territory.

site_title: Najib's appointment of Hishammuddin to new post a bid for political survival
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak appointed Defence Minister Hishammuddin Hussein as special functions minister at the Prime Minister's Department, seen as a calculated move to secure his party's survival ahead of a contentious election this year. This appointment comes as Najib steps up his "lawan tetap lawan" rhetoric to rally supporters and signal to detractors that he is on the offensive. The move is part of his efforts to woo a more hostile voter base and overcome the aftermath of a massive financial scandal. Najib's party, Barisan Nasional, is expected to face a bitter election in September or October.

site_title: Swiss Re to set up new Asian HQ in Singapore
summary: Swiss Re is setting up a new Asian headquarters in Singapore in 2018, to oversee its reinsurance operations in Asia. The entity, Swiss Re Asia, will be wholly owned by the global parent and share its credit rating. The move aims to capitalize on the region's strong growth in the insurance sector, with Asia accounting for 30% of global insurance premiums. The new structure will not affect Swiss Re Corporate Solutions in Asia, and the integration is expected to complete by 2020. Swiss Re expects the region's non-life and life premiums to grow by 5% and 6% annually.

site_title: Factory output, housing starts tumble in March
summary: US factory output declined 0.4% in March, the largest drop in seven months, due to a contraction in car production. Housing starts fell 6.8% to 1.22 million units, with single-family homebuilding in the Midwest dropping 35% to its lowest level since August 2015. Building permits, however, increased 3.6% due to a surge in multi-family housing. The decline in factory output was partly offset by an 8.6% surge in utilities generation, driven by heating demand.

site_title: BP takes Monroe Energy to court for alleged wrongful termination of contract
summary: BP has filed a lawsuit against Monroe Energy, accusing the company of terminating a crude supply contract in 2016, resulting in at least $59 million in damages. BP claims Monroe misinterpreted a provision regarding crude oil blending, while Monroe alleged that BP intentionally blended batches of crude oil that did not meet the required API gravity grade. The dispute marks the second time in two years that BP has been accused of supplying lesser-grade crudes, with another refiner, NARL Refining, also embroiled in an arbitration dispute over the issue.

images.alt_text: The dispute with Monroe marks at least the second time in the past two years that BP has been accused by a refiner of supplying lesser-grade crudes.

site_title: Closing the talent gap
summary: Maritime companies in Singapore need to invest in developing the skills of their employees to stay competitive, as new technologies transform the industry. By 2025, around 13,000 new jobs will be created, with a focus on data scientists, operations research analysts, and other knowledge-intensive roles. To address the talent gap, companies are adopting long-term training programs, such as on-the-job learning, developmental relationships, and structured learning solutions. Governments and institutions are also supporting talent development through scholarships and sponsorships, with the aim of attracting and retaining top talent in the industry.

site_title: Silver Lake closes fifth buyout fund at US$15b
summary: Silver Lake has closed its fifth buyout fund at $15 billion, exceeding its initial target of $12.5 billion, to invest in technology deals. The fund brings the firm's total assets to $39 billion and follows a successful track record of helping portfolio companies expand through acquisitions, such as Dell's purchase of EMC for $67 billion. The firm's approach, known as "roll-ups," has garnered returns of nearly 31% for its fourth fund. Silver Lake's new fund is smaller than SoftBank's $100 billion Vision fund, but the firm remains optimistic about opportunities in the technology sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker on geopolitical concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day at 3,137.54, down 0.76 points due to geopolitical concerns, particularly surrounding North Korea. The index initially rebounded with Wall Street gains but ultimately declined. Moderate trading volume of 2.6 billion units occurred, with a 224-262 advance-decline score.

site_title: Ezra noteholders seek rights issue, cash from escrow
summary: Ezra Holdings' noteholders are seeking a rights issue and cash from an escrow account as a restructuring plan is being drawn up for its Chapter 11 filing in the US. The noteholders, who attended a dialogue session, want the Lee family to consider a rights issue and subscribe additional equity to show commitment. However, observers caution that noteholders may not recover most of what they owe, with some warning that rescue financing could subordinate their claims.

images.alt_text: Mr Gerald said SIAS will take up the unsatisfactory status of the trust deed with the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Noble says listing top execs' pay would hurt its standing
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd, a Singapore-based commodity trader, has pushed back against guidelines in Singapore for disclosing information on executives' remuneration, citing it would put the company at a disadvantage. The company, which is seeking a replacement for chairman Richard Elman, claims many competitors are private and do not publish remuneration information, and that listing this data would be "sensitive and confidential". Noble Group earned S$1.5 million or above for its top five management executives, but declined to provide a more detailed breakdown.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1 Limited reported a weak Q1 2017 with total service revenue declining for the eighth consecutive quarter. Mobile and IDD services fell 3.6% and 10.9% YoY, respectively, while fixed network services revenue grew 22.4% YoY. The company's Ebitda declined 5% YoY to S$79 million. Analysts believe M1 is vulnerable to the potential entry of a fourth mobile operator and that the current stock price does not fully reflect the increasing competitive dynamics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.67 points to 1,740.60. Volume reached 2.79 billion lots worth RM2.45 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 552 to 327.

site_title: IMF warns of growing risks to improving global recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of growing risks to the global economic recovery, citing the rise of protectionist rhetoric, trade warfare, and weakening multilateral trading system. Despite a revised global growth forecast of 3.5% for 2017, the IMF notes significant downside risks, including the potential for financial crises, a rising US deficit, and a weakening of financial regulations. The fund's chief economist, Maurice Obstfeld, emphasizes the need for policymakers to implement the right set of policies to avoid missteps and ensure the stability of an open, collaborative trading system.

site_title: Boeing to dismiss hundreds of engineers amid sales slowdown
summary: Boeing plans to lay off hundreds of engineers in Washington state and other locations due to a sales slowdown. The company, which has already pared 1,332 jobs since 2016, may eliminate more jobs later this year. Boeing's commercial airplanes unit will hand out pink slips on Friday, with 305 engineers and technical workers leaving voluntarily. The company's total headcount has shrunk 7.6% to 146,962 since March 2016, amid declining sales and reduced production of the 747 jumbo jetliner and 777 twin-aisle plane.

images.alt_text: The latest cut follows a separate exodus of 1,500 mechanics who agreed to leave voluntarily earlier this year.

site_title: Suu Kyi needs to show more leadership over Rohingya crisis
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's state counsellor, is facing criticism for her silence on the Rohingya crisis, with over 65,000 fleeing to neighboring Bangladesh. Despite her Nobel Peace Prize and international recognition, Suu Kyi has refused to condemn the violence, citing a need for time and a focus on national reconciliation. However, human rights organizations and world leaders, including Pope Francis and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, have condemned the atrocities. Suu Kyi's inaction has led to a slowdown in foreign investment and a hardening of attitudes towards the Rohingya. A regional approach is needed to resolve the crisis, but Suu Kyi's leadership is crucial in unlocking investment and boosting trade.

site_title: ST Engineering's electronics arm bags S$464m jobs in Q1 2017
summary: ST Engineering's electronics arm, ST Electronics, secured contracts worth S$464 million in Q1 2017. The projects include rail electronics, broadband network, satellite network equipment, and advanced electronics. These contracts are expected to be completed by 2022 and 2023, with no significant impact on the company's financials. The group's shares ended higher by 1.4% at S$3.75.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M Dental places 57m shares at S$0.20 each in IPO
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group is issuing 57 million placement shares at S$0.20 each in its Catalist initial public offering, aiming to raise S$9.1 million. The funds will be used for business expansion, mergers, and acquisitions, as well as infrastructure and working capital. The company, a dental business in China, recorded a net profit of S$109,900 in FY2015 and has a 54.7% stake owned by Q&M Dental Group. Trading is expected to begin on April 26, with a close of the application list on April 24.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q1 profit down 13.1%, revenue slips 15.6%
summary: Keppel T&T's first-quarter net profit fell 13.1% to S$11.57 million, with revenue dropping 15.6% to S$40.72 million, mainly due to a decline in revenue from its Logistics and Data Centre divisions. The company attributed the decline to disposal of subsidiaries, higher start-up expenses, and market competition. Despite this, the Data Centre Division will expand its footprint with new developments and asset acquisition opportunities. Keppel T&T is also undergoing a strategic review of its shareholdings in telco operator M1.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Goldman, J&J results disappoint
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson reported disappointing quarterly results, dragging down the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite. Goldman Sachs declined 3.5% and Johnson & Johnson fell 2.6% after missing analyst expectations. Investors are now focused on quarterly earnings to justify market valuations, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warning that tax reforms could be delayed.

site_title: British PM calls for early general election on June 8
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced an early general election on June 8, calling for a one-off chance to address Brexit negotiations. May cited the need to prevent division in Westminster, despite previously denying an election. Polls show the Conservative Party ahead of Labour, prompting senior Conservatives to call for an election. EU leaders will meet on April 29 to agree on the Brexit strategy, with negotiations expected to start in May or June.

site_title: Goldman Sachs misses estimates on weak trading, shares drop
summary: Goldman Sachs reported earnings that missed Wall Street expectations due to weak trading revenue. The bank's trading revenue dropped 2% to $3.36 billion, while equities trading revenue fell 6%. Despite a 80% profit increase to $2.2 billion, the results were short of analyst forecasts. Goldman's CEO, Lloyd Blankfein, attributed the business environment as "mixed" with client activity "challenged."

site_title: US industrial output jumps 0.4% in March but manufacturing falls
summary: US industrial output increased 0.4% in March, driven by a 8.6% surge in utilities output due to colder weather. However, manufacturing output fell 0.4% due to a 3% drop in motor vehicle and parts production. Overall, manufacturing remains 0.8% higher than last year, with a 2.7% annual increase in the first quarter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering's electronics arm, ST Electronics, secured contracts worth S$464 million in the first quarter of 2017, including S$67 million for rail electronics and S$318 million for advanced electronics and ICT. King Wan Corp secured S$33 million worth of new contracts for mechanical and electrical projects in Singapore, bringing its order book to S$163 million.

site_title: BofA's profit boosted by surge in trading
summary: Bank of America reported a 44% rise in quarterly profit to $4.35 billion, driven by higher interest rates and increased trading revenue. Earnings per share rose to 41 cents, beating analyst expectations. Total revenue rose 7% to $22.25 billion, with trading activities generating $4 billion, a 21.2% increase. The bank's shares rose 1% in premarket trading, following a 34% increase since President Trump's election. Higher interest rates boosted earnings from loans, while trading activity reflected the "Trump trade" and volatility around interest rate hikes.

site_title: Skyways
summary: Singapore-based SUTD launched a new office of AI and Digital Innovation to enhance Design AI skills in students. Meanwhile, Amazon Web Services and NIE established an AI-focused innovation hub for edtech research. Mining giant BHP, along with Oracle, Grab, and PwC, also joined forces to create an AI Hub in Singapore. These developments highlight the growing importance of AI in various industries, including education and business operations.

site_title: Time will tell if Trendlines has mastered art of early investing
summary: Trendlines, an Israel-based startup incubator, is celebrating its 10th anniversary and second year as a publicly listed company. Despite a disappointing stock performance, the group has built 75 companies since 2007, with six acquired by healthcare giants and two listed on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. Trendlines has a robust investment strategy, reviewing 500 projects a year and investing in only 2%. The group is poised for exits in 2017, with US$3.6 million generated from the sale of ETView Medical last year. As the company expands into new markets and incubates more startups, its future direction and stock price remain uncertain, pending significant breakthroughs and exits.

site_title: YouTube is hurting independent media
summary: YouTube's algorithm-based ad system has caused financial struggles for independent media creators, including David Pakman, who lost ad revenue on his show after YouTube's stricter ad rules. The platform's system often misfires, suppressing political commentary and jokes, and punishing creators who don't align with extremist views. The changes have hit popular channels, including PewDiePie, who has become a symbol of resistance to the "adpocalypse." YouTube claims the changes aim to increase brand safety, but creators argue the system is overly sensitive to bad press and advertisers.

site_title: Keppel Corp unit to develop gasification facility on Jurong Island
summary: Keppel Corp's unit, KIH Holdings, has signed an agreement with Singapore EDB to develop a gasification facility on Jurong Island. The facility will produce hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and other industrial gases from coal and refinery by-products. The project aims to meet the growing demand for hydrogen ahead of the 2020 sulphur emission limit, while minimizing environmental impact using best-in-class technologies. The agreement has no material impact on Keppel's financials.

site_title: EOL unit faces winding-up threat from bareboat charter claims
summary: Ezra's subsidiary, Lewek Champion Shipping, faces a US$195 million claim from vessel owner Hai Jiang 1401 Pte Ltd over a bareboat charter. A statutory demand has been served, threatening a winding-up application if payment is not made within 21 days. The claim includes a termination sum and accrued interest under the charter. EOL and its subsidiary are seeking legal advice and assessing the impact of the demand, amid a larger claim of US$194.5 million from Lewek Champion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes caps on policy owners' protection scheme to keep levies and premiums affordable. UOB expects to bring in S$1.5 billion in deposits via a new current account tied to KrisFlyer. Swiss Re to set up regional headquarters in Singapore in 2018. P&G invests US$100 million in its first digital innovation centre in Singapore. China Construction Bank expands services in Singapore, while Aoxin Q&M Dental Group offers 57 million shares at S$0.20 each. Keppel Corp unit to develop a gasification facility on Jurong Island.

site_title: China Construction Bank expands services in Singapore
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) has launched two major banking centres in Singapore to provide infrastructure financing and private banking services. The bank has also established the Singapore subsidiary of CCB International, its investment services arm. This move is part of CCB's expansion in Singapore, in line with China's "One Belt, One Road" programme, which aims to increase investment and network presence in the country. The bank's expansion is seen as a strategic move to tap into Singapore's growing economy and strengthen its position in the region.

site_title: VW plans to launch electric car in China this year
summary: Volkswagen plans to launch a pure battery electric vehicle in China this year, amid uncertainty over the country's electric car quotas. The company's China Chief, Jochem Heizmann, cited a lack of clarity on the rules for New Energy Vehicles (NEVs) as a reason for the accelerated launch schedule. VW is lobbying Chinese authorities to soften the proposals, which could benefit the company's electric car plans.

site_title: US dollar off 5-month low vs yen, trade issues weigh
summary: The US dollar steadied against the yen on Tuesday, reaching a 5-month high, as US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed support for a strong US dollar in the long term. However, concerns about North Korea and French presidential elections, as well as Japan's efforts to weaken the yen, kept investors cautious. The dollar index was 0.1% lower, while the euro was slightly higher. The Australian dollar declined 0.6% due to weaker iron ore prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed after Easter break
summary: Europe's main stock markets started trading on Tuesday after the Easter break, with mixed results. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.5% to 7,295.84 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.3% to 12,149.99 points. Asian markets were weaker due to ongoing geopolitical tensions in the Korean peninsula, but Tokyo stocks closed higher as the yen fell. The US stock market also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: King Wan secures S$33m of contracts lasting till 2024
summary: King Wan Corporation secured S$33 million in new contracts from January to March 2017, bringing its order book to S$163 million. The contracts include mechanical and electrical projects in Singapore, such as a rail and bus depot, shopping mall, and mixed-use development, with completion dates by 2024.

site_title: MAS proposes caps on policy owners' protection scheme to keep levies, premiums affordable (Amended)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes caps on policy owners' protection scheme (PPF Scheme) to keep levies and premiums affordable. The caps will cover over 99% of claims, with specific limits of S$50,000 for personal motor insurance and S$300,000 for personal property insurance. The review aims to clarify the scope, coverage, and operation of the PPF Scheme, recognizing the growing trend of individuals using personal properties for commercial purposes. The proposal is part of a larger review of the PPF Scheme, last reviewed in 2011.

site_title: HK, China stocks sink by the close
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined on Tuesday, closing 1.39% lower, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 23,924.54. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.79% to 3,196.71, and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.62% to 1,946.42. The declines followed a positive lead from Wall Street, shrugging off post-holiday trade.

site_title: China-made truck used in North Korea parade to show submarine-launched missile
summary: North Korea used Chinese-made Sinotruk trucks to display submarine-launched missiles and two new types of intercontinental ballistic missiles during a military parade last week. The trucks, which were painted in North Korean navy camouflage, were seen in photographs released by state media. China claims to have "normal contacts" with North Korea, but strictly adheres to UN sanctions on shipping military hardware. The use of Sinotruk trucks highlights the difficulty in enforcing sanctions against the isolated state.

site_title: Oil edges down after expected climb in US output
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday after a US government report indicated rising US production. Benchmark Brent crude futures dropped 4 US cents to US$55.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 4 US cents to US$52.61 a barrel. The report showed US shale production is expected to rise by 123,000 barrels per day in May, the largest monthly gain in over two years. This increase may put pressure on the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to cut production further.

site_title: Australia shares end lower as resources drag; NZ steady
summary: Australian shares closed 53.25 points lower, or 0.9%, at 5836.7 due to aggressive selling of resources stocks amid fears of oversupply. Global oil prices and iron ore futures in China slipped, and data showed China's crude steel output hit a record 72 million tonnes in March. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index remained steady at 7233.61, with gains in industrial stocks offset by declines in financial and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Swiss Re to set up regional headquarters in Singapore next year
summary: Swiss Re to establish a regional headquarters in Singapore in 2018 under Swiss Re Asia, overseeing its Asian reinsurance operations. The entity will be wholly owned by Swiss Re Ltd and share its credit rating. The Asian reinsurance network is expected to realign by 2020, subject to regulatory approval. This move aligns Swiss Re's legal entity structure across Asia, Europe, and the Americas, reflecting the company's commitment to the region, which now accounts for 30% of global insurance premiums.

site_title: Flash: MAS proposes caps on policy owners' protection scheme to keep levies, premiums affordable
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed capping policy owners' protection scheme levies and premiums to keep them affordable. This move aims to maintain the sustainability of the protection scheme, which provides financial support to policy owners in the event of insurer insolvency. The proposed cap is part of the MAS's efforts to ensure the long-term stability of the Singapore insurance industry.

site_title: Keppel T&T reports 13.1 per cent drop in first quarter net profit to S$11.57m
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 13.1% drop in first-quarter net profit to S$11.57m, due to lower revenue from its Logistics and Data Centre divisions. Revenue decreased 15.6% to S$40.72m, and earnings per share dropped 12.5%. The company attributed the decline to the disposal of subsidiaries and higher start-up expenses. Operating loss for the quarter was S$1.67m, compared to an operating profit of S$6.7m in the previous year.

site_title: Seven hurt in twin blasts in southern Philippines
summary: Seven people were injured in twin bomb blasts at a petrol station in Tacurong city, southern Philippines, on Monday night. The explosions occurred near rebel enclaves and have raised concerns about a possible act of terrorism. Two suspects have been arrested, but the motive and identities of the perpetrators are still under investigation. The incident occurred in an area plagued by a decades-old Muslim insurgency and high crime, with nearby towns also home to communist rebels. The government is looking into all angles, including extortion, and has not yet concluded whether the attack was a terrorist act.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group offers 57m shares at S$0.20 each
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group is offering 57 million placement shares at S$0.20 each in its initial public offering, aiming to raise S$9.1 million. The company plans to use most funds for business expansion and the remaining for infrastructure and working capital. Aoxin, a dental business in China, has a 54.7% stake owned by Q&M Dental Group and 36.61% by its CEO, Shao Yongxin. The IPO application closes on April 24, with trading starting on April 26.

site_title: KrisFlyer UOB accounts expected to bring in deposits of S$1.5b
summary: UOB expects to bring in S$1.5 billion in deposits over the next five years through its KrisFlyer UOB Account, a new current account tied to Singapore Airlines' KrisFlyer programme. The account allows customers to earn KrisFlyer miles based on account balance. The bank aims to open at least 200,000 KrisFlyer UOB accounts, starting from Wednesday, with applications accepted from then.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down on North Korea worries; stocks firmer
summary: The South Korean won fell to a one-week low due to concerns over North Korea's nuclear and missile ambitions, despite US Vice President Mike Pence's reassurances to Japan. The won dropped 0.4% to 1,142.4 to the US dollar, its lowest close since April 11. Meanwhile, South Korean shares ended slightly higher, with the Kospi index rising 0.1% to 2,148.46 points, driven by domestic investors' focus on first-quarter earnings and the May presidential election.

site_title: New Zealand inflation on the rise, cenbank unlikely to waiver on record low rates
summary: New Zealand's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to reach a record low of 2% growth in the first quarter, surpassing the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's target for the first time since 2011. Economists predict the CPI will rise 0.8% on a quarterly basis, lifting annual inflation to 2%. Despite this milestone, the RBNZ is unlikely to adjust interest rates, maintaining a cautious stance due to temporary factors and global risks. Annual inflation is expected to ease to 1.5-2% over the remainder of 2017.

site_title: Bangladesh trains teenage girls to fight cyber crime
summary: Bangladesh has begun training over 10,000 teenage girls to combat cybercrime, particularly online harassment targeting adolescents, which has grown alarmingly with the rise of smartphones. The government-led workshops will teach girls what to look out for and how to respond. The move aims to empower girls to protect themselves and others from online abuse.

site_title: Sweden mulls sovereign wealth fund as government debt keeps falling
summary: Sweden is considering setting up a sovereign wealth fund to address its low government debt and liquidity premium issues. Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson cited Norway's US$915 billion wealth fund as an example, but noted the Swedish fund would be smaller. The government projects debt to fall to 31% of GDP by 2020, and Andersson suggests a fund could help maintain liquidity in government bonds, making borrowing more costly. The plan would involve borrowing 5% of GDP and putting the funds into a rainy-day fund.

site_title: Woodleigh MRT station shut down due to 'security incident'
summary: Woodleigh MRT station in Singapore's North-East Line was shut down due to a "security incident" involving a suspicious substance. The police are handling the incident with the Singapore Civil Defence Force. This comes two weeks after a similar incident at Hougang station, where a man was arrested for public nuisance. Free bus rides are available between Serangoon and Potong Pasir stations while the station is closed.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges up as US dollar, Wall Street climb
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index rose 0.4% to 18,418.59, following a rebound in US shares and a weaker yen. The US dollar added 0.2% to 109.08 yen, while Wall Street rebounded from recent lows. Market focus shifted to earnings later this week, lifting Japanese banking and financial shares. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained, ending away from recent five-month lows.

site_title: South Korea's Daewoo Shipbuilding unlocks US$2.6b bailout after bondholder approval
summary: South Korea's Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co Ltd has secured a US$2.6 billion bailout from bondholders, meeting a condition for a bank bailout. The company, the world's largest shipbuilder, won near-unanimous approval from over 96% of bondholders to swap debt for equity. The bailout will provide up to $3.5 billion in funding, helping Daewoo meet its operating needs and allowing it to continue building ships on time. The move is seen as South Korea's largest state-backed rescue of a single company in over a decade.

site_title: Australia toughens foreign worker visas, says Australian jobs for Australians
summary: Australia is abolishing its 457 visa program, which allows foreign workers to fill skill shortages, and replacing it with a new visa requiring better English-language and work skills. The change, announced by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, aims to attract skilled workers and prioritize Australian jobs for Australians. The new visa will be limited to a two-year period and a higher standard of English language for a four-year visa. The move is seen as a shift towards a more nationalistic immigration policy, with Turnbull stating that "Australian jobs and Australian values" are the focus.

site_title: Australian dollar falters on iron ore, RBA; NZ$ near two-week peak
