summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.4% to US$0.7556, weighed down by iron ore prices and minutes from the Reserve Bank of Australia's April meeting, which reinforced views of low interest rates. The New Zealand dollar reached a two-week high at US$0.7034, but remained stable. Investors are cautious amid geopolitical tensions and ahead of the French presidential election, with financial markets implying a low chance of interest rate cuts this year.

site_title: China March home prices rise 0.6% m-o-m, 11.3% y-o-y
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.6% from February to March, and 11.3% from a year ago, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. In major cities, prices increased in Beijing for the first time since October 2016, while Shenzhen and Shanghai saw gains of 9.1% and 16.8% from last year. However, Shanghai's monthly pace slowed due to local government measures. The deceleration in price growth is a sign of market cooling.

site_title: China March outbound direct investment slumps 30.1% to US$7.11b
summary: China's non-financial outbound direct investment (ODI) plummeted 30.1% in March to US$7.11 billion, with the first quarter total falling 48.8% to US$20.54 billion. ODI in countries involved in China's "One Belt one Road" initiative reached US$2.95 billion, or 14.4% of the total. Authorities have maintained a tight grip on capital outflows to support the yuan and safeguard foreign exchange reserves, citing concerns over "irrational" investment in certain sectors.

site_title: Australia shares tumble to 3-week low as resources struggle; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell to a 3-week low, dropping 1.09% to 5,826.4, as miners struggled due to a growing glut in iron ore and steel prices. Crude oil prices also slipped, affecting energy stocks, and profit-taking in the sector. The Reserve Bank of Australia's concerns about a housing bubble also contributed to the decline. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat.

site_title: Japan govt nominates reflationist economist for BOJ board
summary: Japan's government nominated reflationist economist Goushi Kataoka and 63-year-old Hitoshi Suzuki to join the Bank of Japan's policy board, replacing two former market economists. The nominations suggest Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's massive stimulus program will continue, with Kataoka favoring easy monetary policy to combat deflation and Suzuki's stance is unknown. The nominations need parliamentary approval, which is considered a near certainty with the ruling coalition holding a solid majority. The appointments aim to support Kuroda's pro-growth economic policies.

site_title: Trump to seek changes in visa programme to encourage hiring Americans
summary: US President Donald Trump will sign an executive order directing federal agencies to recommend changes to the H-1B visa program to encourage hiring American workers and increase the purchase of American products in federal contracts. The order aims to crack down on visa abuse and ensure that the most skilled applicants are awarded visas. It also seeks changes in government procurement practices to increase the purchase of American products and reduce unfair trade with foreign companies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.42% in post-holiday trading, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 102.97 points to 24,158.69. This follows a positive lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.08%. The decline was attributed to cautious trading despite the positive start to the week from US markets.

site_title: Asia: Traders wary but Tokyo up on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on a weaker yen, despite geopolitical concerns and North Korea's defiant missile test. US Vice-President Mike Pence's visit to Tokyo and renewed US commitment to Japan's security eased tensions. Markets were cautious, with Hong Kong, Seoul, and Shanghai falling, and Sydney slipping due to iron ore price slump. A weaker yen boosted Japanese exporters, and some analysts believe easing geopolitical concerns may be behind the yen's retreat.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.57 points to 1,735.50 on Tuesday, with a gain in volume of 89.68 million lots worth RM27.93 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 207 to 29, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Yuan slips with weaker midpoint as US dollar holds ground
summary: China's yuan eased against the US dollar on Tuesday, closing at 6.8849 per dollar, 59 pips weaker than the previous day's close. The US dollar held ground following overnight retreats amid North Korea tensions, with US Vice President Mike Pence warning Pyongyang. Despite US President Donald Trump linking the yuan to North Korea, analysts expect limited impact on the currency. The offshore yuan traded 0.07% away from the onshore spot, while one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded at 7.0585, -2.46% away from the midpoint.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8849 per US dollar versus the previous day's fix of 6.8785.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Super, Q & M, Nippecraft
summary: Several Singapore companies made announcements affecting their share prices. Super Group will end its 20-year public listing after a Dutch company's offer to take it private met a threshold. Q & M Dental Group's share trading has been suspended pending an announcement. Nippecraft Limited must make a cash exit offer to shareholders by May 9.

site_title: Tycoon backs opponent, looks to oust Ahok in Jakarta elections
summary: Indonesian tycoon Sandiaga Uno is set to find out if his bid to oust Jakarta Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama (Ahok) was successful in a run-off vote. Uno backed former general Prabowo Subianto, who is neck-and-neck with Ahok in polls. A win for Prabowo would boost his chances of running against President Joko Widodo in 2019. The Jakarta governorship is seen as a litmus test for winning the presidency, and a victory for Prabowo would put Widodo on the defensive.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.63% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.63% on Tuesday, driven by easing economic and geopolitical woes. The benchmark index closed at 3,158.17 points, with 41.4 million shares changing hands. Top gainers included DBS and UOB, while M1 and CDL Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust were top early losers. The news followed contradictory statements from US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and President Donald Trump regarding the US dollar's strength, which eased investor concerns.

site_title: MAS partners UNCDF to drive financial inclusion in Asean
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered with the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) to promote financial inclusion in Asean through digital financial services. The partnership aims to digitize low-tier financial institutions, particularly in extending last-mile distribution of financial services to marginalized populations, including women. The collaboration will support innovative business models that foster regulated international remittances in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam. The partnership will culminate in the showcase of selected projects at the Singapore FinTech Festival later this year.

site_title: RBA shines spotlight on weak Aussie jobs, strong housing market
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has highlighted weak labour market conditions and a strong housing market, citing moderate economic growth in early 2017. Labour market conditions are "somewhat weaker than expected" with high underemployment, and wages have stagnated. Housing credit growth outpaces household incomes, posing risks to the housing market and household balance sheets. The RBA maintains interest rates at a record-low 1.5% and expects headline inflation to accelerate to above 2% this year, with core consumer prices taking longer to reach the 2-3% target.

site_title: Bangkok to ban street food stalls in clean-up crusade
summary: Bangkok plans to ban street food stalls from main roads as part of a clean-up crusade. The ban, announced by a city official, aims to improve the city's sanitation and reduce the presence of counterfeit goods. The move has sparked outcry among food enthusiasts who view street food as an integral part of Thai culture. The ban will apply to all types of stalls, including clothes and food vendors, on main city roads.

site_title: China plans 2 million new units of public housing for 2017
summary: China plans to build 2 million new units of public rental housing in 2017 to provide affordable homes for low-income groups. The move aims to address the issue of high house prices and the country's household registration regime, which has left many families unable to afford or access to buy homes. The plan is part of the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development's efforts to increase public housing availability, with local governments in some regions having already lowered the threshold for access. This is part of China's broader efforts to address the housing crisis.

site_title: Uber's vice-president of global vehicle programs leaves company
summary: Uber's vice-president of global vehicle programs, Sherif Marakby, has left the company, citing the self-driving car project as one of the most interesting challenges he's worked on. Marakby, a former Ford executive, joined Uber in April 2016 and departed without explanation. This departure is the latest in a series of high-profile exits at the company, which has been dealing with setbacks including accusations of harassment and a lawsuit over stolen self-driving technology. Uber is seeking a new COO to improve its culture and image.

site_title: Procter & Gamble to invest US$100m in its first digital innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is investing over US$100 million in its first digital innovation centre in Singapore, set to be completed over the next five years. The E-Center will focus on supply chain management, e-analytics, and e-business, with partnerships with local SMEs and start-ups. The centre will also train 40 employees and collaborate with Institutes of Higher Learning to develop industry-relevant curriculum. Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, S Iswaran, said the E-Center will position P&G and Singapore to capture future opportunities in the digital economy.

site_title: Q & M requests for trading halt
summary: Q & M Dental Group has requested a trading halt pending an announcement, with shares last trading at 70 Singapore cents apiece. This is the second time the company has requested a halt, following an announcement in March to spin off its Chinese dental business. The exact details of the announcement are not disclosed.

site_title: IRobot sues Hoover, other rivals over robot vacuum patents
summary: IRobot, maker of Roomba, filed federal court lawsuits against Hoover, Black & Decker, and other rivals accusing them of using patented technology without permission. IRobot claims its autonomous floor-cleaning robot patents are infringed upon by these companies' products, including Hoover's Quest robotic vacuums and Black & Decker's BDH5000WM. The lawsuits were filed in Boston and also target China-based Shenzhen Silver Star Intelligent Technology Co, which manufactures Hoover and Black & Decker vacuums.

site_title: Trump advisers to meet on Tuesday to discuss Paris climate agreement
summary: US President Donald Trump's advisers will meet on Tuesday to discuss whether to recommend withdrawing the US from the Paris climate accord, a decision that has sparked debate over the country's role in global efforts to combat climate change. The agreement, signed by nearly 200 countries in 2015, aims to limit planetary warming by slashing carbon dioxide emissions. Environmental groups and some energy companies have urged the US to remain in the agreement, while others have suggested it should be withdrawn. The meeting comes ahead of a Group of Seven summit in May.

images.alt_text: Advisers to President Donald Trump will meet on Tuesday (April 18) to discuss whether to recommend that he withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord, a White House official said on Monday.

site_title: US Vice-President Pence says South Korea-US free trade agreement to be reviewed, reformed
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced plans to review and reform the 5-year-old free trade agreement between the US and South Korea, citing a significant doubling of the US trade deficit and numerous barriers for US businesses in the country. This comes ahead of Pence's meeting with Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso in Tokyo, where he aims to open doors for US-made products. The review and potential reforms are seen as a significant development in the US-South Korea trade relationship.

site_title: Sean Tang Wen-Wei appointed C K Tang CEO
summary: Sean Tang Wen-Wei, 32, has been appointed CEO of C K Tang Limited, effective April 18, 2017. He is the eldest son of executive committee chairman Tang Wee Kit and sits on the boards of both C K Tang and Tang Holdings Pte Ltd. The appointment completes succession planning steps taken by Tang Wee Kit and his brother Tang Wee Sung, who sold their shares in C K Tang in May 2016 to ensure the family's assets remained in the family. The move comes after former CEO Kevin Dyson left the company in August 2016.

images.alt_text: Sean Tang Wen-Wei will be appointed the chief executive officer of C K Tang Limited with effect from April 18.

site_title: South32 scraps US$200m Australian coal acquisition from Peabody
summary: South32 Ltd scrapped a $200 million deal to acquire Peabody Energy's Metropolitan coal mine in Australia due to competition concerns. The decision was made after negotiations with the Australian competition watchdog and steel makers over supply of coal to local steel makers. South32 CEO Graham Kerr stated that taking steps to appease steel makers would compromise the merits of the transaction. Peabody Energy plans to operate the mine and resume shipments after completing a move to a new coal panel. The deal's collapse highlights concerns over Australia's coal reserves and supply to steel makers.

site_title: Nippecraft told to make cash exit offer to shareholders
summary: Nippecraft, a Singapore-based paper products maker, has been ordered to make a cash exit offer to its shareholders by May 9. The company had requested to extend its timeline to leave the Singapore Exchange's watch-list, but this request was denied. Nippecraft has until May 9 to make a cash offer to its shareholders, after which trading of its shares will cease on the main board.

site_title: Hotels draw up battle plans as Airbnb poses rising threat
summary: The US hotel industry is launching a coordinated effort to counter Airbnb's growing threat, with the American Hotel and Lodging Association (AHLA) drawing up a "multipronged, national campaign approach" to regulate the short-term rental platform. The plan includes lobbying politicians, funding studies to expose Airbnb's non-compliance with local regulations, and targeting key markets. AHLA claims Airbnb is "operating a lodging industry, but not playing by the same rules," and has secured support from several high-profile Democrats, including Senators Elizabeth Warren and Dianne Feinstein.

site_title: US insurer withdraws from deal with China's Anbang
summary: US insurer Fidelity & Guaranty Life (FGL) has withdrawn from a proposed $1.6 billion deal to be acquired by China's Anbang Insurance Group, citing it no longer being in the best interests of shareholders. FGL stated it was open to alternative deals but had been barred from striking another deal while the Anbang transaction was alive. The decision comes amid reports of obstacles with state regulators, with FGL not providing a reason for the demise of the transaction.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.86% and the Topix index rising 0.85%. The move followed a weaker yen and US Treasury Secretary's remark that a strong dollar is "a good thing" over long periods of time.

site_title: United reports solid profits, vows better customer treatment
summary: United Continental reported a 69.3% decline in first-quarter net income to $96 million, but still beat analyst expectations. The airline's customer service is under scrutiny after a passenger was forcibly removed from an overbooked flight, prompting widespread public condemnation. United has vowed to remake its customer service, stop using police to remove passengers, and undertake further changes after a full audit. Despite the challenges, the airline projected positive growth in passenger revenue per seat mile for the second quarter. United's president and CEO acknowledged the incident and expressed a commitment to putting customers at the center of everything.

images.alt_text: United Continental reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings Monday but they still bested analyst expectations, and the airline vowed to remake its customer service after its rough treatment of a passenger stoked global outrage.

site_title: Pyongyang should not 'test Trump's resolve': Pence
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence warned North Korea not to test President Donald Trump's resolve, stating "all options are on the table" in curbing its missile and nuclear programs. The warning came amid heightened tensions following North Korea's latest missile test. Pence said the US would "defeat any attack" and meet any use of conventional or nuclear weapons with an overwhelming response. The US has indicated it will not allow North Korea to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of delivering a nuclear warhead to the US, and Pence urged the international community to join demands for an end to North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

site_title: Prince's doctor prescribed medicines under friend's name: warrants
summary: Prince's doctor, Michael Todd Schulenberg, prescribed opioid painkillers, including Percocet, under his friend Kirk Johnson's name to protect the singer's privacy. Investigators found evidence of Prince's painkiller use at Paisley Park, where he died from a fentanyl overdose in 2016. No one has been charged in the ongoing investigation, which is still seeking information on the source of the fentanyl and Prince's possible interactions with others. Prince had no prescriptions under his own name, and witnesses reported a history of withdrawal symptoms from prescription medication abuse.

site_title: Snapping up Snap? Mutual funds beat you to it
summary: Mutual funds have been investing in private companies, including Snap, since at least June 2017, beating individual investors who bought shares after the company's IPO. According to a Morningstar study, 23 funds held pieces of Snap, with median ownership at 0.51% of assets. Private-firm equity investments can be profitable but come with significant risks, including stale pricing and potential write-offs. Companies like Uber and Airbnb are also attracting private investments, with fund managers seeking to buy in at lower valuations before they go public.

site_title: Boeing to cut hundreds of engineering jobs
summary: Boeing plans to cut hundreds of engineering jobs in its civil aviation business due to slowing sales. The cuts, primarily affecting production sites in Washington, will take effect June 23. This is part of Boeing's ongoing effort to increase competitiveness and reduce costs. The company has already eliminated 305 engineering jobs and cut 1,500 mechanics as part of a voluntary program. The move comes as Boeing's workforce has decreased by 7.6% from the previous year, with the company currently having 146,962 employees.

site_title: Snap stock falls as alleged CEO comments rile some on social media
summary: Snapchat's stock fell 1.5% on Monday as CEO Evan Spiegel faced criticism for allegedly saying he wouldn't prioritize growth in India and Spain because they are "poor" countries. The comments were made in a 2015 legal document filed by an employee who left the company. Snap has denied the claims, calling them a publicity stunt. The stock is now down 26% from its public listing and has fallen to its lowest level in nearly a month.

site_title: US: Stocks rally ahead of big earnings reports
summary: US stocks rallied ahead of a heavy week of corporate earnings, driven by China's better-than-expected first quarter growth and stabilisation in the world's second-biggest economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.9% each, with technology companies such as Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet rising 1.5% or more. Other notable movers included Boeing, Arconic, and Alere, while Eli Lilly dropped 4.1% after the FDA rejected its application for a rheumatoid arthritis treatment.

site_title: Oil edges lower, trade thin as some cash in after 3-week rally
summary: Crude oil prices slipped 1% on Monday after a 3-week rally, with benchmark Brent crude futures ending at $55.36 a barrel and US WTI crude futures settling at $52.65 a barrel. US shale production is expected to increase in May, adding to concerns of a glut and undermining efforts to cut output. Market conditions encouraged profit-taking, with speculators booking profits after a strong week. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet on May 25 to consider extending output cuts, but Saudi Arabia's energy minister expressed doubts about an extension.

site_title: Analysts try to identify North Korean failed missile type
summary: North Korea's failed missile launch on Sunday may have been a test of a new, untested system being developed by Kim Jong Un's regime, according to a weapons expert. The launch, which occurred on the east coast, was of a medium-range device, and analysts speculate it could be a new Scud-like missile called the KN-17. The US has not confirmed the exact type of missile, but officials suspect it was a new system, possibly one shown off in a recent military parade. The launch failure may have been due to technical issues, and some speculate that US hacking efforts may have played a role.

site_title: Netflix growth misses mark despite strong earnings
summary: Netflix reported a net increase of 4.95 million subscribers in the first quarter, missing the mark compared to the prior quarter's 7.05 million gain. Despite this, the company expects to hit the 100-million subscriber milestone this weekend. The majority of new subscribers are from overseas, where Netflix is investing in becoming a global entertainment network. Strong earnings were also posted, indicating the company's continued growth despite market expectations.

site_title: Is American retail at a historic tipping point?
summary: US retail is experiencing a historic tipping point, driven by the rapid growth of e-commerce. The industry's restructuring is reflected in declining sales, store closures, and job losses. Between 2010 and 2014, e-commerce grew by $30 billion annually, but this growth accelerated to $40 billion over the past three years. Traditional retailers are struggling to compete, with over 89,000 workers in general merchandise stores laid off since October. Economists say the shift is accelerating, with some predicting that traditional retail may never recover, while others argue that the market is undergoing creative destruction, leading to new opportunities and wealth creation.

site_title: US court fines Brazil's Odebrecht US$2.6b over bribes
summary: A US federal court has fined Brazil's Odebrecht US$2.6 billion over bribes, part of a record-breaking corporate settlement for international bribery. The construction giant, along with its petrochemical affiliate Braskem, admitted to paying nearly US$800 million in bribes to win business on three continents. The fine is a reduced amount from the original US$4.5 billion, as Odebrecht was unable to pay the full amount. The settlement resolves a case involving corruption and bribery in Brazil's state oil company Petrobras.

site_title: Super expected to delist soon
summary: Super Group, a Singaporean food and beverage company, is expected to delist soon after a Dutch company's offer to take it private met a crucial threshold. The Dutch company owns 91.73% of Super Group's shares, with its offer price set at S$1.30 in cash for each share. With the number of issued shares in public hands below 10%, trading of the shares will be suspended at the close of the offer, effectively ending Super Group's two-decade public listing.

site_title: Millennials give the prep staple, a pink shirt, vibrant new life
summary: Millennials are giving the classic pink shirt a vibrant new life, making it a popular choice for the fashion-conscious. The color, once associated with femininity and preppy stereotypes, has been reimagined as a versatile and elegant option for modern adult males. Brands like Thomas Mason and Brooks Brothers are seeing a surge in demand for pink shirts, which can add a touch of joie de vivre to any outfit. The trend is also influenced by the Broadway revival of John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation," which features a memorable pink-shirt moment.

site_title: Buyout firms are magically - and legally - pumping up returns
summary: Buyout firms in the private equity industry are artificially inflating their returns by using short-term bank loans to delay investing in companies, boosting their internal rate of return (IRR) by 25% or more. This strategy, which is not illegal, allows firms to make their investments look more profitable and can make mediocre funds appear excellent. The use of this tactic has spread rapidly across the industry, with firms seeking to one-up rivals that also employ the strategy. Concerns have been raised about the distortion this creates and its potential to lower actual cash returns for investors.

site_title: Maritime industry to brainstorm for ideas to face global challenges
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is hosting the Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) to address global challenges facing the maritime industry. The event will include a record 34 events and agreements to advance innovation and R&D in the sector. Industry leaders will brainstorm ideas to respond to weaker global trade, new regulations, and technological advances. MPA will sign seven memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with industry players, focusing on joint innovation and research efforts. The event aims to foster greater awareness and adoption of new technologies and business models to drive growth and competitiveness in the sector.

images.alt_text: Maritime players face the challenge of navigating through a weaker world economy, slowing global trade and disruption brought on by new regulations and technological advances.

site_title: How can Singapore companies ensure equality in the gig economy?
summary: Singapore companies can ensure equality in the gig economy by rethinking their workforce management and adopting a more ownership mindset towards freelance workers. Employers must provide ongoing learning and development opportunities, mentoring, and leadership opportunities to contingent workers to prevent them from becoming temporary and dispensable resources. Companies must also invest in digital intelligence, cultural intelligence, and business intelligence to effectively manage the workforce of the future and unleash the boundless talent available. This shift in approach will help Singapore companies tap into the benefits of the gig economy while addressing its shortcomings.

site_title: Amex, challenged by Chase, is losing the snob war
summary: American Express (Amex) is facing a decline in revenue for the second consecutive year, sparking concerns that the company's traditional approach to attracting affluent customers may be losing its appeal. Rival credit card company Chase has successfully lured millennials with its Sapphire Reserve card, offering a sign-up bonus and benefits that resonate with younger generations. Amex has responded by introducing new perks and increasing sign-up bonuses, but its efforts may be hindered by its own image of conspicuous consumption and the shift in demographics among its target market.

site_title: KIT's first-quarter DPU steady at 0.93 cent
summary: Keppel Infra Trust (KIT) reported a steady distribution per unit of 0.93 Singapore cent for its first quarter, unchanged from last year, with a 7.3% distribution yield. Net profit grew to S$6.8 million, driven by higher contributions from Basslink and Keppel Merlimau Cogen, while revenue increased 18.3% to S$155.3 million. Distributions will be paid on May 19, 2017.

site_title: Stock market trading hit by system glitch
summary: Stock market trading was disrupted in Singapore on Monday morning due to a data connectivity glitch in Fidelity National Information Systems' (FIS) SunGard system, affecting some traders from local brokerages. The glitch caused intermittent data to appear on screens, preventing order execution. The incident did not appear to have a broader impact on the market.

site_title: China's Q1 property investment accelerates, defying curbs
summary: China's Q1 property investment accelerated to 9.1% from a year earlier, defying government cooling measures. New construction starts also quickened to 11.6% in the first quarter. Despite the robust investment and new construction, policymakers expect moderation in property activity from April, citing the impact of recent cooling measures. The government has implemented measures to curb soaring prices, including requiring buyers to hold homes for at least two to three years before selling.

images.alt_text: At least 50 Chinese cities have slapped on tougher cooling measures to limit price gains since mid-March, after Beijing's harsh curbs that hiked downpayment ratios for second homes to as much as 80%.

site_title: Changi Airport, SIA partner STB in push for Singapore stopover
summary: Singapore Changi Airport, Singapore Airlines, and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have partnered to invest S$33.75 million in promoting Singapore as a stopover destination globally. The joint marketing efforts will focus on attracting travelers beyond long-haul markets, aiming to increase tourism revenue. This partnership aims to position Singapore as an attractive stopover and twin destination for travelers, enhancing its reputation as a premier travel hub.

site_title: Italian football clubs look to China to bankroll revival
summary: Italian football clubs are increasing their reliance on Chinese investment to revive the league, which has seen declining TV audiences and revenues. Serie A officials plan to sell a separate Chinese package of media rights to boost international revenue by 50% to around 300 million euros per season. Chinese entertainment giant Dalian Wanda already underwrites the competition's media rights, and online broadcaster PPTV is a leading contender to buy Serie A rights in China. The league aims to generate 80 million euros from China rights alone, but domestic revenues are still uncertain.

site_title: 'Disruption is creation', a mantra for business leaders
summary: Singapore business leaders must adapt to a digital era by leveraging technology to create innovative business models. Key considerations include: starting with customers and their data, transforming company culture to foster collaboration, embracing the skills of the future, and finding the right technology partner. Disruption is not just about technology, but also about creating a culture of innovation and empowering employees to upskill and stay relevant.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Japan Foods Holding Ltd is expected to increase dividends in line with earnings growth, following a 9.4% compound annual growth rate in sales turnover from FY2009 to FY2016. The company has consistently expanded its restaurant network and managed underperforming outlets to improve same-store sales. Analysts have set a target price of S$0.56 for the stock, indicating a potential buy. In contrast, Singapore Press Holdings has downgraded Japan Foods to a sell with a target price of S$3.41, citing concerns over the company's dividend growth.

site_title: Over-valued lithium mine in Argentina sold for a song
summary: A lithium mining company, Lithea, once valued at $1.4 billion, has been sold for $44 million after a series of lawsuits and legal issues. The company's chairman, Kwon Ohjoon, had partnered with a Hong Kong-based firm to assess potential lithium deposits in Argentina, but the partnership was marred by controversy and unpaid debts. The sale of Lithea marks a significant decline in the value of the company, which had previously predicted it would quintuple in value once it went public. The deal highlights the risks of investing in natural resources and the importance of due diligence.

site_title: Billionaire Taizo Son ditches Japan to start afresh in Singapore
summary: Billionaire Taizo Son, the founder of Puzzle & Dragons, has relocated to Singapore from Japan and plans to invest $100 million in Southeast Asia within five years. Son, a SoftBank executive, aims to start anew in the city-state. His move comes after building his fortune on the hit smartphone game, which has generated billions of dollars in revenue. Son's investment plans are seen as a significant boost to Singapore's tech industry, with the city-state looking to capitalize on the growing demand for gaming and mobile technology in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint to pay 315m euros for 86.56% of Amsterdam property firm
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has agreed to acquire an 86.56% stake in Amsterdam-based real estate investment company Geneba Properties for 315.9 million euros (S$467.8 million). The acquisition also includes a 13.44% free-float offer for the remaining shares. FCL intends to delist Geneba following the acquisition, subject to regulatory and competition authority approval. The deal is seen as a strategic move to expand FCL's international property activities in Europe.

site_title: Asian currencies rise as US$ loses lustre
summary: Asian currencies rose on Monday as the US dollar lost its value due to President Donald Trump's comments on interest rates. Trump stated he prefers low interest rates, making regional currencies more attractive. The US stock market also fell, contributing to the decline in the dollar. This trend is expected to continue, making Asian currencies relatively more appealing investment options.

site_title: Tributes
summary: Singapore's founding father and former cabinet minister, Encik Othman Wok, has passed away. Tributes poured in from prominent leaders, including President Tony Tan, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, who remembered his sincerity, courage, and passion in building a harmonious multi-racial Singapore. Othman Wok played a pivotal role in keeping the Malay community united and contributed to the development of the Administration of Muslim Law Act, which established the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore and the Syariah Court. His legacy will be remembered as a key figure in Singapore's history.

site_title: European chemical companies steel for disruptive Brexit, regulatory challenges
summary: European chemical companies are preparing for a potentially disruptive "Brexit" as the UK's withdrawal from the EU threatens an integrated market worth over 40 billion euros. Industry leaders warn of regulatory challenges, tariffs, and disruptions to cross-Channel shipments, which could boost costs for manufacturers and end users. A business-friendly transitional arrangement will be crucial for the period between the UK's departure in 2019 and any accord on its future relationship with the EU.

site_title: Amazon, Flipkart battle in India for e-commerce's 'last frontier'
summary: Amazon and Flipkart are intensifying their battle for India's e-commerce market, with Flipkart securing a $1.4 billion investment from top international companies, including Microsoft and Tencent. Amazon has earmarked $5 billion in investment funds for India, fueling the competition between the two giants. The Indian e-commerce market is growing rapidly, with 100 million new internet users annually, making it a strategic priority for both companies.

site_title: Rex unit to test production from North Sea oil well in 2019
summary: Rex International Holding's subsidiary Lime Petroleum Norway AS plans to start testing production from the Edvard Grieg South oil well in 2019, potentially yielding 77.9 million barrels of oil and 78.7 billion standard cubic feet of natural gas. The well's development is being carried out using Rex's Rex Virtual Drilling (RVD) technology, which has proven accurate in predicting dry wells. The project is part of Lime Norway's efforts to secure more efficient use of capital, having previously avoided drilling in licences where RVD analyses indicated a high risk of dry wells.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Raffles Education Corp. won a 163.2 million rupee arbitration award against Educomp in India for breaching a share purchase agreement. First Reit reported a 1.4% increase in distribution per unit to 2.14 Singapore cents in Q1. Qian Hu Corp. saw its net profit surge 300% to S$36,000 in Q1, driven by a 10% jump in group revenue. First Reit's net property income rose 2.5% to S$26.87 million. Qian Hu's earnings per share rose to 0.03 Singapore cents, up from 0.01 Singapore cents.

site_title: Can US living standards be said to be truly stagnant?
summary: A recent article challenges the notion that US living standards have stagnated, suggesting that income growth may be higher than previously thought. Data indicates that companies have been laying off fewer workers, which could be a sign of a strengthening economy. This contradicts the common perception of stagnant wages. However, the article does not provide a clear conclusion on the overall state of US living standards.

site_title: Chinese developer to bring Xiongan frenzy to offshore investors
summary: Chinese property company China Fortune Land Development plans to raise $1 billion through its first offshore bond offering, amid the frenzy surrounding the Xiongan New Area project. The company, which has been given the task of developing 500 square kilometers of the new area, aims to access Xiongan-related assets. The bond deal has caught the attention of potential underwriters and investors, despite some concerns over the project's uncertainties and the potential for overshot property prices.

site_title: Trump's 'reciprocal tax' keeps analysts guessing
summary: US President Donald Trump has hinted at a "reciprocal tax" plan, implying taxing imports from other countries at the same rates those countries impose on US products. This approach, which has been met with skepticism from economists, would tax imports and potentially lead to higher prices for consumer goods. Trump's comments, which were seen as a shift from his previous criticism of the "border-adjusted tax" (BAT), have left room for interpretation, but many experts believe he is heading towards broader import tariffs.

site_title: Othman Wok, member of Singapore's first Cabinet and founding father, dies at 92
summary: Othman Wok, a founding father and key member of Singapore's first Cabinet, has died at 92. Wok was a strong leader and advocate for racial and religious reconciliation, contributing to Singapore's success. He was a close companion of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and a signatory to the separation agreement with Malaysia. The government will accord him the honor of being borne on a ceremonial gun carriage for his final journey, and a memorial service will be held on Wednesday. Wok's passing marks the loss of the last two surviving members of Singapore's first Cabinet.

images.alt_text: Mr Othman began his political career in 1963, as assemblyman for Pasir Panjang. He was Minister for Social Affairs from 1963 to 1977. The PMO described him as one of Lee Kuan Yew's "closest comrades".

site_title: 'Skinny bundles' seen to challenge established pay-TV providers
summary: Google's YouTube TV enters the US pay-TV market with a 40-channel bundle for $35/month, challenging established providers with slim packages. The "skinny bundle" model, which offers live and on-demand programming, has gained popularity among young viewers and "cord cutters" dissatisfied with traditional pay-TV services. Analysts predict the model will eat away at the market share of established providers, leading to a huge upheaval in the television ecosystem and more choices and lower costs for consumers.

site_title: To rule the world, Uber must first conquer India
summary: Uber aims to dominate India's transportation market, but faces numerous challenges. The company, valued at nearly $70 billion, has lost $2.8 billion in 2016 and is not profitable in any Indian city. Despite these struggles, Uber sees India as a key opportunity for growth, with a large and growing middle class. The company has set up hundreds of offices, known as "UberDost," to recruit and train drivers, many of whom are unskilled and lack experience with smartphones. Uber's aggressive expansion plans are hindered by India's poor infrastructure, lack of reliable cellular networks, and complex bureaucracy. The company faces stiff competition from local rival Ola Cabs, which operates in 100 cities and offers a wider range of services.

site_title: Will China rein in North Korea?
summary: The US is pushing for more stringent sanctions on North Korea following the failed missile test, citing the need to curb Pyongyang's nuclear ambitions. China, North Korea's largest trading partner, is seen as a key player in reining in the regime. US President Donald Trump has made an effort to persuade China's Xi Jinping to take action, offering trade deficits in exchange for cooperation. China, however, argues that sanctions don't prohibit trade and has been accused of enabling North Korea's nuclear progress by supplying banned technology. A recent editorial by a state-run newspaper suggested restrictions on North Korean oil imports, a proposal that could strengthen sanctions and demonstrate China's commitment to addressing the issue.

site_title: China's growth robust in Q1 but rates unsustainable, analysts warn
summary: China's economy grew 6.9% in Q1, its fastest in five years, driven by government support in the real estate and construction sectors. Fixed-asset investment, retail sales, and industrial output all expanded, with credit boom being a key driver of growth. Analysts warn, however, that growth rates are unsustainable and will slow later this year due to systemic risks, including high debt levels and inefficient investment projects. They suggest policymakers need to tackle debt and structural reforms to stabilize growth, potentially at a rate of 4-5% in the coming decade.

site_title: Asia-Pacific to overtake Europe with second-largest helicopter fleet by 2026
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is expected to surpass Europe as the second-largest fleet of civil helicopters by 2026, with North America maintaining a 37% share. The Asia-Pacific's share will rise from 17% to 21%, while Europe's will shrink from 28% to 20%. The inaugural Rotorcraft Asia event is taking place in Singapore, featuring the latest products and technologies, as well as strategic conferences to discuss key issues in the sector.

site_title: Daewoo Shipbuilding bondholders accept bailout plan
summary: South Korea's Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co Ltd won near unanimous approval for a debt-to-equity swap plan, allowing the world's largest shipbuilder to meet conditions for a $2.6 billion bank bailout. The proposal, agreed to by the National Pension Service (NPS), the world's third-largest pension fund, involves swapping half of the debt owed to bondholders for equity and suspending repayment for three years. The plan has been supported by other large bondholders, including Korea Post, and is expected to be approved at all five planned meetings.

site_title: Leading through turbulent times
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to continue slowing down, with uncertain global conditions and a backlash against globalisation. The government has announced measures to promote a digital economy, encouraging innovation and entrepreneurship. However, this has led to challenges for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with some struggling to survive. Recent news includes a specialist centre opening in Tokyo, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and a major retailer's vacant units due to poor footfall. Despite efforts to boost the economy, SMEs face significant challenges, with some forced to cut staff and rebrand to stay afloat.

site_title: With SATS Coolport, New Zealand meats headed for EU can now tranship through Singapore
summary: New Zealand meats can now transit through Singapore to the European Union via SATS Coolport, Asia's first on-airport perishable cargo handling centre. SATS received the world's first EU approval to provide transhipment services for meat, marking a significant milestone. This development is expected to increase trade between New Zealand and the EU, providing a new route for the country's meat exports.

site_title: Shareholders now increasingly engaged, key that they attend AGMs
summary: Shareholders are increasingly attending annual general meetings (AGMs) as companies prioritize their engagement. A recent letter to the editor expressed disappointment over the rejection of a proposed solution to reduce the clustering of AGM dates for companies with December year-ends. The issue is expected to worsen with new Singapore Exchange (SGX) listings. The article does not provide a conclusion on the matter, but highlights the growing importance of shareholder engagement in corporate governance.

site_title: Indian tribunal dismisses ex-chairman Mistry's plea against Tata Sons
summary: An Indian tribunal has dismissed a petition by former Tata Sons' chairman Cyrus Mistry, alleging mismanagement and discrimination against minority shareholders at Tata Sons. The tribunal also refused to grant a waiver to Mistry's family-owned companies on minimum shareholding requirements. Tata Sons, the holding company for the Tata group, had forced Mistry from the chairmanship last October and has since been involved in a public dispute with him. The tribunal's order was welcomed by Tata Sons, but the outcome has been met with criticism from Mistry's supporters.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 13.2% rise in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 13.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.89 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended March 31, 2017, driven by a 47.6% rise in distributable income. Gross revenue climbed 30.1% to S$32.2 million, while net property income rose 36.1% to S$28.8 million. The Reit attributed the growth to increased demand for data centre services and lower property-related expenses. Despite a near-term pressure on rental rates due to new supply, Keppel Reit expects the digital economy to continue driving growth opportunities.

site_title: Pence warns North Korea of US resolve shown in Syria, Afghan strikes
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence warned North Korea of the US resolve shown in recent strikes in Syria and Afghanistan, urging the country not to test President Donald Trump's resolve. Pence also announced the early deployment of the THAAD missile defense system to strengthen anti-North Korea defenses. The US and its allies are working on responses to North Korea's failed ballistic missile test, with China supporting UN sanctions and calling for talks. Tensions remain high, with the US considering economic sanctions and a possible oil embargo.

site_title: Trump plays the global game, but a big-picture framework seems missing
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy is marked by a series of assertive actions, including a missile strike in Syria and the deployment of anti-missile systems in South Korea. However, critics argue that these actions lack a coherent framework, instead relying on "games of chicken" with adversaries. Trump's approach has led to improved relations with China, but its effectiveness in addressing regional conflicts, particularly in North Korea, remains uncertain. A more comprehensive strategy is needed to align US interests and achieve lasting results in the Middle East, East Asia, and beyond.

site_title: OCBC internship to build a 'bank for the future'
summary: OCBC Bank has selected 26 students for a six-month internship, dubbed "FRANKprenuers," to build a bank for the future. The program, starting in May 2017, will introduce entrepreneurship skills and knowledge, and the interns will be attached to various units in the bank. Working in groups, they will pitch their ideas to a panel of judges and be assessed for suitability to join the bank's management trainee program. This program is a unique twist to traditional banking internships, focusing on innovation and entrepreneurship skills.

site_title: Turkey's weak economy exposed after referendum
summary: Turkey's economy faces significant challenges after a narrow referendum victory for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, granting him sweeping powers. Unemployment hit a 7-year peak in early 2017, while the budget deficit rose, highlighting the nation's economic struggles. The referendum's outcome has exposed deep divisions within the country, with supporters waving flags and opponents protesting. The move marks the biggest overhaul in Turkish politics since its founding, abolishing the prime minister position and concentrating power in the president's hands.

site_title: US messaging upstart Slack now faces giant tech rivals
summary: Slack, a US messaging software, faces significant competition from giant tech rivals like Microsoft, Facebook, and Atlassian. Despite its success with 5 million daily users, Slack needs to compete for large corporate clients to rival Microsoft's Teams. Slack's focus on user experience and customer satisfaction has helped it maintain a loyal user base, but the company must now fend off its competitors to remain a major player in the workplace software market. Slack's CEO, Stewart Butterfield, believes that small tech companies with new ideas have long defeated larger rivals, and the company is determined to build a product that people love.

site_title: Ant Financial raises MoneyGram bid by 36% to fend off Euronet
summary: Ant Financial raised its bid for MoneyGram International Inc by 36% to US$18 per share, valuing the company at US$1.2 billion. The revised bid aims to outdo Euronet Worldwide Inc's previous offer of US$15.20 per share. The move comes as MoneyGram's board considers the competing bid, with potential regulatory obstacles, including a review by the US Committee on Foreign Investment in the US, under President Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Transforming change into opportunity
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink notes that technological innovation and globalization have transformed the world, creating unprecedented opportunities, but also exacerbating wealth gaps. The company faces a challenging environment, with pension funds facing widening liability gaps and retirees ill-prepared for the future. Fink argues that companies, governments, and asset managers must work together to improve education, support innovation, and build 21st-century infrastructure. BlackRock aims to leverage technology to help investors achieve better outcomes, with a focus on portfolio construction, asset allocation, and digital distribution. The company seeks to be the most sophisticated user of data and technology in the financial services industry.

site_title: M1's Q1 profit falls 14.6% to S$36.3m despite revenue rise
summary: M1's Q1 net profit fell 14.6% to S$36.3 million, despite a 1.2% rise in revenue to S$260.7 million. Higher depreciation and interest expenses, driven by a 59% increase in finance costs, contributed to the decline. Earnings per share dropped to 3.9 Singapore cents, and the telco's service revenue margin decreased to 39.2%. However, mobile data contribution increased to 55.1% of service revenue, and fixed services revenue grew 22.4% to S$30 million.

site_title: Developers' private home sales soar
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in March, with 1,780 units sold, the highest since June 2013. This represents an 82% increase from February and a 111% jump from March 2016. The strong showing was driven by new launches and confidence from the government's recent cooling measures tweaks. Resale transactions also rose 50% month-on-month and year-on-year, with developers selling 578 EC units. Property consultants have revised their forecasts upwards, expecting a 20% increase in new sales and firmer prices, with prices expected to bridge the gap bridged by the cooling measures.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: SGX trading glitch a blip on the radar
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1% to 3,138.3 points, largely due to a Wall Street selloff triggered by geopolitical risk. A data connectivity glitch on Fidelity National Information Services' SunGuard systems also disrupted trading. However, the real story lay in the penny stock segment, where shares of ArtiVision Technologies plummeted 9.5% after announcing the cancellation of a $50 million sale. Non-oil domestic exports rose 16.5% year-on-year in March, with exports reaching a two-year high. Economists expect GDP growth to be upgraded, citing improving external environment and demand.

site_title: Tokyo to have 45 new skyscrapers by 2020 Olympics
summary: Tokyo plans to add 45 new skyscrapers by 2020, nearly doubling the city's high-rise space in the next three years. The surge is driven by Japan's economic expansion under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics program and ultra-low interest rates. New leaseable office space in central Tokyo will rise to 1.8 million sq m, with most buildings concentrated in prime areas near Tokyo Station. The influx of new construction may heat up competition for tenants in other areas, with demand tied to the city's hosting of the 2020 Olympics.

site_title: First Reit's Q1 DPU up 1.4%
summary: First Reit reported a 1.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.14 Singapore cents for Q1 2017, up from 2.11 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Net property income rose 2.5% to S$26.87 million, while interest income increased to S$310,000, mainly due to a progress payment from the development of new Siloam Hospitals Surabaya.

site_title: March exports power ahead to score fifth straight monthly gain
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) posted a 16.5% increase in March, its fifth consecutive monthly rise, exceeding market expectations. This growth was driven by double-digit increases in shipments to top 10 markets, particularly in Greater China, and a 68.5% jump in oil domestic exports. Economists predict this growth will lead to an upward revision of the preliminary first-quarter GDP growth figure, estimated at 2.5%. The strong performance is seen as a sign of the recovery in global demand, with the World Trade Organization forecasting a 2.4% global trade growth this year.

site_title: China says graft suspect on run in Canada gives self up
summary: A Chinese corruption suspect, Li Shiqiao, has returned to China after nearly a decade on the run in Canada. Li, a former real estate company manager, was on China's list of 100 most wanted corruption suspects abroad and was persuaded to surrender. This is the 40th person on the list to be captured as part of China's Operation Fox Hunt, a war on deep-seated corruption led by President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Trump's North Korean calculus needs a new direction
summary: US President Donald Trump's approach to North Korea has raised concerns among regional powers, with some comparing his decisiveness to his predecessor's measured approach. Following recent US strikes in Syria and Afghanistan, Trump has threatened North Korea, stating that if China doesn't help, the US will deal with North Korea on its own. In response, North Korea vowed to go to war, while China warned of escalating tensions. To prevent a crisis, experts suggest the US should work closely with regional partners, particularly China, to devise sanctions and carrot-and-stick mechanisms to restrain North Korea and encourage dialogue.

site_title: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secures contracts worth S$1.11b for Q1
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secured contracts worth S$1.11 billion for Q1 2017, including performance-based logistics operations, component repair, and overhaul agreements. The arm also opened its second hangar in Guangzhou, China, and broke ground for a new facility in Germany, increasing production capacity. Additionally, ST Aerospace received AS9100 Quality Management System certification for its in-house designed aircraft seats.

site_title: Japan's change of tack on TPP seen as gambit in talks with US
summary: Japan has signaled its willingness to pursue a Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement without US participation, seen as a gambit in talks with the US. The move aims to give Tokyo leverage in negotiations over trade access and investment, as well as counter China's influence in the region. The US-Japan Economic Dialogue will focus on bilateral cooperation issues, with Vice-President Mike Pence set to meet with Japan's Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso. The talks aim to address bilateral trade issues, but no free-trade deal is expected to be reached in the current circumstances.

site_title: Beijing tells state developers to stop hyping up property market: media
summary: The Beijing municipal government has told state-owned property developers to refrain from hyping up the property market through operational activities. This follows aggressive land bids by these firms, which have driven up home prices in the past year. The move aims to prevent market speculation and force developers to change their land strategies. Representatives of the firms were summoned to a meeting with the government to discuss the matter, according to a Chinese real estate industry portal.

site_title: Claims-based pricing for rider only a band aid
summary: Insurer Prudential has introduced a claims-based pricing approach for its PRUshield Extra A Premier plan's "claimable from first dollar" rider, which covers private hospital treatments. The rider will now be priced based on policyholders' claims, affecting new sign-ups and renewals starting May. Industry players have dismissed the approach as going against the principle of risk pooling, and it's unclear if it will effectively curb rising medical claims. The move is part of a broader effort to address escalating healthcare costs, with other insurers also considering similar pricing strategies.

site_title: Americans crave muscular SUVs, and carmakers oblige
summary: The US market favors muscular SUVs, with carmakers like Ford, Jeep, and Mercedes-Benz releasing new high-performance models at the New York International Auto Show. The trend is driven by low oil prices and President Trump's efforts to cut fuel-economy regulations, resulting in a surge in SUV sales. The shift is permanent, with pickup trucks and SUVs accounting for 62% of new vehicle sales in the US so far this year. Environmentalists worry about the impact on emissions, but companies are prioritizing SUV sales due to their high profit margins.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor has released a more powerful version of its extra-large Lincoln Navigator.

site_title: Saudi Arabia 'to shelve, reform billions of dollars of unfinished projects': sources
summary: Saudi Arabia's government is reviewing billions of dollars' worth of unfinished infrastructure projects, aiming to either shelve or restructure them due to low oil prices. The review, led by the Bureau of Capital and Operational Spending Rationalization, will assess projects under 25% complete, with a focus on prioritizing social welfare and business-justified projects. Officials may suspend or retender projects to involve the private sector, while others may be cut back. The move is part of the government's reform drive to diversify the economy beyond oil exports.

site_title: China's top insurance regulator removed for suspected disciplinary violations: Xinhua
summary: China's top insurance regulator, Xiang Junbo, was removed from his position for suspected serious disciplinary violations, according to the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. Xiang, 60, had been under investigation since April 9 and was chairman of the China Insurance Regulatory Commission from 2011. His removal comes as part of China's government fight against graft, following a similar probe of former deputy head of the China Securities Regulatory Commission in 2015. Xiang's name was removed from the CIRC website shortly after the announcement.

site_title: 4 ways your company will benefit from Grab for Work
summary: Grab's ride-hailing app, Grab for Work, offers corporations a convenient and cost-effective solution for on-demand transportation. With over 780,000 drivers in South-east Asia, it provides an enormous reach and low prices. Businesses can easily use the platform by logging in, setting up a group, and adding employees, with no admin fees. Launched in May, Grab for Work is already benefiting companies, providing a powerful corporate solution for transportation expense management.

site_title: US: Stocks up at start of heavy earnings week
summary: US stocks rose early Monday ahead of a heavy week of corporate earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% to 20,515.17. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Investors focused on earnings reports from major companies, including Bank of America and Netflix, which are expected to show 9.2% growth in first-quarter earnings. Tensions between the US and North Korea and the French presidential election also influenced market sentiment.

site_title: North Korea said to snub Chinese diplomats as tensions mounted
summary: North Korea has snubbed senior Chinese diplomats, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and special envoy Wu Dawei, amid escalating tensions with the US. The snub comes after China's President Xi Jinping met with US President Donald Trump in Florida, prompting Trump to pressure Xi to take stronger action against North Korea's nuclear program. China wants to resume negotiations on North Korea's nuclear issue, but high-level dialogue between the two countries has been cut back since the 2013 execution of Kim's uncle.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.94 points to 1,733.93 on Monday, driven by a gain of 456 to 397 gainers to losers. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at RM1.78 billion in volume.

site_title: Depreciation and interest costs pull down M1's Q1 net 14.6% to S$36.3m
summary: M1's first quarter net profit fell 14.6% to S$36.3 million due to higher depreciation and interest expenses. Revenue rose 1.2% to S$260.7 million, while earnings per share decreased 14.2%. The telco's mobile customer base grew 27,000 to 2.05 million, and fibre customer base increased 8,000 to 168,000. Despite a 9.2% increase in handset sales, overall service revenue remained stable.

site_title: OCBC gives 26 students six months to come up with bank of the future ideas
summary: OCBC Bank has selected 26 top Singapore university undergraduates for a six-month internship to develop innovative banking ideas. The FRANKprenuers will work on a "bank of the future" project, combining entrepreneurship skills and knowledge with hands-on experience. They will be attached to various units and tasked with creating a solution to the "new world economy." The interns will be assessed for suitability to join the bank's management trainee program, with their ideas to be pitched to a panel of judges at the end of the period.

site_title: Delta to pay up to US$10,000 to bumped customers
summary: Delta Air Lines has increased the maximum payout to passengers who voluntarily give up a seat on an overbooked flight to nearly US$10,000, up from the prior cap of US$800. This move comes in response to global outrage sparked by the violent removal of a customer from a United Airlines flight. Delta's customer service employees will now be able to offer up to US$2,000 in these cases, aiming to improve passenger satisfaction and reduce conflict.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q1 DPU up 13.2%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 13.2% increase in its distributable income for the first quarter of 2017, reaching S$21.8 million. Gross revenue and net property income also rose 30.1% and 36.1% respectively, while property expenses decreased 5.7%. The distribution per unit (DPU) increased 13.2% to 1.89 Singapore cents, marking a 47.6% year-on-year growth.

site_title: Update: Singapore stocks finish weaker, STI down 1% on geopolitical worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to 3,138.3 points, amid geopolitical worries and a data connectivity glitch. The decline followed a Wall Street selloff triggered by heightened tensions in North Korea, Afghanistan, and Syria. Dow futures traded in the red throughout Asian hours, further exacerbating market jitters. Turnover was low at 1.3 billion units worth S$746 million due to Hong Kong's Easter closure and the morning trading disruption.

site_title: Qian Hu's Q1 profit up 200% at S$36,000
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a Singapore-listed ornamental fish service provider, reported a 200% increase in net profit to S$36,000 in the first quarter of 2017. The company's revenue rose 10% to S$21.58 million, driven by higher contributions from its core business segments. Executive Chairman Kenny Yap expressed confidence in the company's future, citing its focus on innovation and expansion into the aquaculture business, which has the potential to be "many times bigger" than its existing businesses.

site_title: SATS Coolport to provide meat transshipment services between NZ and EU
summary: SATS Coolport, Asia's first on-airport perishable handling centre, has received EU approval to provide meat transshipment services between New Zealand and the European Union. The services, which include breaking down and reconsolidating meat shipments, will allow for cost-effective multimodal freight solutions and increase New Zealand's capacity to export lamb shipments to the EU. This new trade route is expected to result in a 10% increase in lamb shipments over the next two years, with SATS establishing itself as a consolidation hub and redistribution centre for perishable products.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors charge ousted leader Park and Lotte chief with bribery
summary: South Korean prosecutors have charged ousted President Park Geun-hye and Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong-bin with bribery, marking the latest development in a corruption scandal. Park is accused of colluding with her friend, Choi Soon-sil, to receive 7 billion won from Lotte for favors. Shin was charged without detention, while Samsung Group's chief Jay Y Lee is also under arrest for bribing Park and Choi. All four deny wrongdoing, with Lotte and Samsung Group also denying improper deals with Park or those linked to her.

images.alt_text: South Korean prosecutors on Monday charged ousted president Park Geun-hye and Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong-bin with bribery in the latest twist to a corruption scandal that rocked the country for months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 16.5% year-on-year in March, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth. Former Cabinet minister Othman Wok, a proponent of multi-racialism, passed away at 92. Developers sold 1,780 private homes in March, a 111% increase from the previous year. Changi Airport, Singapore Airlines, and the Singapore Tourism Board will invest S$33.75 million in a three-year promotion partnership. Frasers Centrepoint acquired an 86.56% stake in Geneba Properties for S$467.8 million, and ARA Asset Management will be delisted on April 19.

site_title: Gold hits 5-month high on rising geopolitical risks
summary: Gold prices reached a 5-month high on Monday, driven by rising geopolitical tensions over North Korea, including a failed missile test launch. Investors sought refuge in safe-haven assets, causing spot gold to rise 0.3% to US$1,288.50 per ounce. The US dollar rebounded against the yen, offsetting some gains in gold. The French presidential election on April 23 is also expected to impact gold prices, with analysts predicting a bullish sentiment.

site_title: South Korea: Won, stocks edge up after US Treasury report passes without event
summary: South Korea's won strengthened 0.2% to 1,137.5 to the dollar after the US Treasury currency report passed without significant changes, easing market concerns. The KOSPI index rose 0.3% to 2,142.29 points. North Korea's failed missile launch also calmed market worries. However, analysts predict the won's rise would be temporary due to ongoing risks, including a possible North Korean nuclear test and the upcoming French presidential election.

site_title: Fostering an enterpreneurial culture to take Singapore into the future
summary: Singapore is focusing on fostering an entrepreneurial culture to stay ahead in a challenging future. A roundtable discussion emphasized the need for innovation, value creation, and entrepreneurship. The Committee on the Future Economy has prescribed this as a key strategy for the city-state. The government and global players are expected to play a crucial role in supporting entrepreneurship, including training and grants. The push for entrepreneurship aims to drive growth and development in Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia revises Feb trade data
summary: Indonesia revised its February trade data, showing exports worth $12.62 billion and imports worth $11.35 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $1.27 billion, down from a preliminary report of $1.43 billion. This marks the fifth consecutive month of a trade surplus for Indonesia, since the start of 2016.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares fall as regulator warns against speculation
summary: China's share markets fell 0.2-0.7% on Monday, with the CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index declining due to speculation and market misbehaviours. The China Securities Regulatory Commission warned against such behaviour, prompting over 100 stocks to slump by 10% or more. Analysts attribute the downturn to concerns about a potential economic slowdown and increased regulation, particularly in the Xiongan special economic zone. The market is also hurt by worries about the end of the "reflation trade" and increased risk appetite for large-cap blue chips.

site_title: HSBC predicts Saudi privatisation drive to list 100 entities
summary: HSBC predicts that around 100 Saudi entities in various sectors, including mining, healthcare, and energy, will be listed on the Saudi stock market by 2030 as part of the country's diversification efforts. This is part of plans to reduce reliance on oil and expand the economy. The bank also expects the region's debt capital market issuance to exceed last year's record level. HSBC will play a key advisory role in the listing of Saudi Aramco, in addition to advising the Saudi stock exchange on its own listing.

site_title: Tokyo's skyline set to see 45 new skyscrapers by 2020 Olympics
summary: Tokyo's skyline is set to undergo significant changes by 2020, with 45 new skyscrapers planned, nearly 50% more new high-rise space than in the preceding three years. The increase is attributed to Japan's fiscal expansion and monetary easing under Prime Minister Abe's economic program, as well as ultra-low interest rates. The new constructions will mainly be located in central Tokyo's Chiyoda, Chuo, and Minato wards, which will heat up competition for tenants in other areas of the city, particularly due to the Olympics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks snap four-day losing streak
summary: Tokyo stocks ended Monday higher, snapping a four-day losing streak. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.11% to 18,355.26, while the Topix index gained 0.45% to 1,465.69. The gains came despite tensions on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Developers' sales in Singapore soar to 1,780 private homes in March: URA data
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 1,780 private homes in March 2017, a 111% increase from the same period in 2016, and the highest since June 2013. Including executive condominiums, 2,358 units were sold, up from 1,328 in March 2016. Median prices ranged from S$1,406 to S$1,805 per square foot, with notable sales at Grandeur Park Residences and Park Place Residences at PLQ.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at more than 1-week high, won firmer
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose on Monday, driven by easing concerns over the US Treasury's currency report and reduced geopolitical tensions with North Korea. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,145.76 points, its highest level in over a week, and the won rose 0.2% to 1,137.7 to the US dollar.

site_title: China gas output rises to record as coal production rebounds
summary: China's natural gas production surged to a record 13.6 billion cubic meters in March, rising 8.2% from the first two months of the year. Coal output also rebounded, increasing 13% to a daily average of 9.67 million tons, the highest since December. The nation's economy accelerated for a second-straight quarter as investment picked up and factory output accelerated, with power output increasing 7.2% from a year ago. This growth is attributed to China's economic growth accelerating power use.

site_title: China firm scraps deal to buy Southampton FC stake
summary: China firm Lander Sports Development has scrapped plans to buy a stake in English football club Southampton FC due to unspecified "policy" changes amid a Chinese government crackdown on overseas investments. The acquisition would have made Southampton the latest top-flight English club to gain Chinese investment. Lander Sports cited difficulties in completing procedures, including asset restructuring, as the reason for the cancellation. This move comes as China's government restricts overseas investments, impacting several Chinese companies' international expansion plans.

site_title: Othman Wok, member of Singapore's first Cabinet, dies at 92
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Othman Wok, a key proponent of multi-racialism, died peacefully at 92 on April 17, 2017. Born in 1924, he was a founding leader of Singapore's first Cabinet and played a crucial role in building a harmonious multi-racial society. As Minister for Culture and Social Affairs, he developed national policies and infrastructure, laying the foundation for the administration of Muslim affairs in Singapore. Wok is remembered for his tireless work in promoting peace and unity, and will be buried with honors on Tuesday.

site_title: China's Q1 property investment accelerates, defying curbs
summary: China's Q1 property investment surged 9.1% year-over-year, defying government cooling measures. New construction starts also accelerated to 11.6% in the first quarter. Despite slower sales growth, the robust investment and new construction starts suggest the property market remains a crucial driver for China's economy. Analysts warn of an overheating market, while policymakers expect moderation in property activity, citing the impact of recent cooling measures.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall but China growth figures upbeat
summary: Asia markets fell on Monday as tensions on the Korean peninsula weighed on sentiment, despite China's GDP growth figures showing signs of stabilization. China's 6.9% growth in the first quarter was higher than expected, but markets declined as tensions between North Korea and the US escalated. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.3% and other Asian markets fell, including Taiwan, Manila, and Singapore. The US Navy's naval strike group remains in the region, adding to geopolitical risk.

site_title: South Korean economy to suffer if US put trade curbs on China: think tank
summary: South Korea's economy would experience modest damage if the US imposes trade curbs on China, according to a Korea Development Institute report. A 10% fall in Chinese exports to the US would result in a 0.31% drop in South Korea's GDP, but not a crisis. Conversely, a 10% US export curbs on China would result in a 0.04% drop in South Korea's GDP. The report suggests South Korea should continue diversifying its export markets to mitigate potential losses.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI Securities starts coverage of Japan Foods; S$0.56 target price
summary: KGI Securities initiates coverage on Japan Foods, citing its diverse F&B brands and efficient food production as key strengths. The broker sets a target price of S$0.56, making the shares an attractive buy despite the slowdown in the F&B sector. Japan Foods' extensive portfolio and centralised production enable steady expansion, setting it apart from peers. The counter was at S$0.445 before trading commenced on Monday.

site_title: Oil falls after failed N Korean missile test, US rig count gains
summary: Crude oil prices fell on Monday after North Korea's failed missile launch, with benchmark Brent crude futures down 56 US cents at US$55.33 a barrel. The US rig count increased, undermining Opec efforts to support prices. The market digested the news amidst a quiet trading session following the Easter break. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were down 51 US cents at US$52.67 a barrel. The failed missile test and rising US oil output contributed to the bearish sentiment.

site_title: Changi Airport, SIA, STB to invest S$33.75m in Singapore promotion
summary: Changi Airport, Singapore Airlines, and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have invested S$33.75 million in a three-year partnership to promote Singapore as an inbound destination. The joint marketing efforts will focus on stopover and twin destinations, targeting global travelers, and will also expand the Free Singapore Tour program, which attracted 59,000 passengers last year, a 8% increase from the previous year. The partnership aims to attract more business and MICE visitors to Singapore.

site_title: China Q1 GDP grows 6.9% y-o-y, better than expectations
summary: China's economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter, beating expectations and the fastest pace since 2015. The growth was driven by government infrastructure spending and a housing market showing signs of overheating. The government aims for 6.5% growth in 2017, slightly lower than last year's target. However, analysts expect the economy to slow later in the year due to fading stimulus measures and efforts to control hot housing prices.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall slightly; US keeps country on currency monitoring list
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell slightly on Monday, tracking regional shares and following the US Treasury's decision to keep Taiwan on a monitoring list for its trade practices.
