The US Treasury maintained Taiwan's material current account surplus but dropped a second criterion, warning that Taiwan's authorities must demonstrate a shift to limiting foreign exchange interventions to exceptional circumstances. The main TAIEX index was down 0.16% at 9,717.28, with Cathay Financial Holding also dipping 0.84%. Analysts say the trend may not last, with some predicting a depreciation of the Taiwan dollar in Q2.

site_title: China's graft watchdog investigates senior inspector in drive to tackle internal rot
summary: China's top anti-graft watchdog, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI), has launched an investigation into a former senior inspector, Zhang Huawei, suspected of serious disciplinary violations, including graft. The move is part of the CCDI's drive to tackle corruption within its own ranks, as Chinese President Xi Jinping continues his war on graft. The investigation aims to expose corruption and demonstrate the CCDI's commitment to reform, ahead of a potential leadership reshuffle later this year. This move could also be seen as a way to justify retaining top graftbuster Wang Qishan in a central leadership position.

site_title: Singapore's March non-oil domestic exports up 16.5% y-o-y
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 16.5% year-on-year in March, marking a fifth consecutive month of growth. Shipments to China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong contributed significantly to this growth. Non-oil re-exports increased 9.4% and total trade rose 18.9% in March, following a 21.1% growth in February.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks down at open
summary: Shanghai stocks dropped 0.50% at open on Monday, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index falling to 3,229.95. This decline comes after regulators over the weekend called for controls on speculative trading and ahead of the release of GDP figures. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.53%. Hong Kong stocks were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Malaysia March inflation seen hitting 8-year high of 5.3% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to reach 5.3% in March, its highest in eight years, according to a Reuters poll. The increase is driven by higher fuel prices, despite stagnant oil prices. The central bank expects headline inflation to be "relatively high" in the first half of 2017, but dip in the second half. The forecast is higher than the 4.5% rise in February and is expected to dip to 3-4% in 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.24 points to 1,731.23. Gainers outnumbered losers 136 to 81, and trading volume reached 110.7 million lots worth RM26.2 million.

site_title: ARA Asset Management to delist on April 19
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED ARA Asset Management will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on April 19, following a payment by Athena Investment Company (Cayman) Limited to acquire its shares at S$1.78 per share. The acquisition places ARA's market capitalization at S$1.78 billion. Trading of ARA's shares has been halted since April 6, and the company's board of directors expressed gratitude to shareholders for their continued support throughout the years.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed ARA Asset Management will be delisted with effect from April 19.

site_title: Pence lands at Korean DMZ day after North Korea's failed missile test
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence landed at a US military base near the Korean DMZ, a day after North Korea's failed missile test, pledging an "unshakeable" commitment to South Korea. Pence's visit came amid a range of international responses to North Korea's latest test, with the US, allies, and China working together on responses, including economic sanctions and diplomatic negotiations. The Trump administration is focusing on tougher economic sanctions, including an oil embargo, as options for dealing with North Korea's nuclear and missile programs appear limited.

site_title: South Korea pension fund accepts Daewoo Shipbuilding bailout proposal
summary: A South Korean pension fund, the National Pension Service, has accepted a debt-to-equity swap proposal for Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, allowing the country to bail out the world's largest shipbuilder. The proposal, agreed upon after marathon negotiations, involves a 50% debt-to-equity swap and a three-year grace period. The bailout plan aims to save an estimated 50,000 jobs and prevent a significant economic hit. The government plans to sell Daewoo after reducing its size to about 7 trillion won in two years.

site_title: United Airlines removes engaged couple travelling to wedding from plane
summary: A United Airlines flight from Houston to Costa Rica was diverted after a federal law enforcement officer removed an engaged couple, Michael Hohl and Amber Maxwell, from the plane due to disputed circumstances. The couple claimed they were told they couldn't upgrade to "economy plus" seats, but were not removed until they were seated in a different row. The incident occurred amid heightened scrutiny of the airline's customer service after a video emerged showing a passenger being dragged off a flight in Chicago. The couple was rebooked on a new flight.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint to acquire 86.56% stake in Geneba Properties
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has entered into a conditional agreement to acquire 86.56% of Geneba Properties, an Amsterdam-based real estate investment company, for 467.8 million SGD. Frasers Property also reached a conditional agreement for the remaining 13.44% free-float stake. Geneba's portfolio consists of logistics and light industrial properties in Germany and the Netherlands with an average occupancy rate of 98%. The acquisition is expected to be completed within a month.

site_title: Raffles Education wins case against India's Educomp
summary: RAFFLES Education Corporation Limited (REC) won a 163.2 million rupee arbitration case against India's Educomp, finding Educomp breached a prior share purchase agreement. The tribunal ruled Educomp failed to complete a transaction to acquire a 41.82% stake in ERHEL by REC's subsidiaries. As a result, REC will not proceed with the sale and purchase, and will retain its 41.82% stake in ERHEL. The decision was made in accordance with a Singapore Exchange filing on Monday.

site_title: Ant Financial raises MoneyGram takeover by 36% to US$1.2b
summary: China's Ant Financial has raised its takeover bid for MoneyGram International Inc to $1.2 billion, increasing the offer by 36% to $18 per share. The deal was unanimously approved by MoneyGram's board and is Ant's first major overseas expansion. The transaction is expected to be reviewed by the US Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS) and the Federal Reserve. A successful deal would add cross-border remittance capabilities to Ant's ecosystem, serving its 630 million users globally.

site_title: Rex unit to test production from North Sea oil well in 2019
summary: Rex International Holding plans to test production from its Edvard Grieg South oil well in 2019. The North Sea well may yield 77.9 million barrels of oil and up to 78.7 billion standard cubic feet of natural gas. Developmental feasibility studies are underway, with Rex's technology proving accurate in predicting dry wells, saving the group millions in futile capital expenditure. This is part of Rex's interests in six offshore assets in Norwegian waters.

site_title: 'We expected more': Erdogan supporters relieved after narrow 'Yes' win
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan won a referendum to boost his powers by a narrow margin, with supporters taking to the streets in Istanbul to celebrate. The 'Yes' vote secured 51.4% of the total, surpassing the 50% needed. However, the margin was narrower than expected, with many initially anticipating a larger victory. Despite this, Erdogan's supporters were relieved, waving flags and selling campaign merchandise, marking a significant shift in Turkey's politics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, extending four days of losses due to strong yen on geopolitical risks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.42%, closing at 18,258.64, while the Topix index dropped 0.23%. This marks a 2017 low for the benchmark index, following a four-day losing streak.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint, Raffles Education
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has entered into a conditional agreement to acquire 86.56% of Geneba Properties for S$467.8 million. Raffles Education Corporation Limited was awarded S$3.52 million by an Indian arbitration tribunal for breaches by Educomp. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.44% down on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.44% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 14.05 points to 3,155.19. The decline came amidst geopolitical pressures, with Asian stocks continuing to face uncertainty. The market saw 97.3 million shares worth S$63.2 million traded, with losers beating gainers 122 to 49.

site_title: Chinese developer to bring Xiongan frenzy to offshore investors
summary: Chinese property developer China Fortune Land Development plans to raise US$1 billion through its first offshore bond offering, benefiting from the central government's Xiongan New Area project. The company, which has secured contracts to develop 500 square kilometers of the new area, faces challenges in marketing the credit to foreign investors due to its unconventional business model. Despite uncertainties surrounding the project, Fortune Land's bond offering is seen as a chance for investors to gain access to Xiongan-related assets, with some bankers eager to get in on the action.

images.alt_text: Days after plans for a new economic hub south of Beijing ignited a frenzy among mainland investors, a Chinese property company with links to the zone has unveiled plans to sell overseas bonds.

site_title: West reacts cautiously to Turkish referendum result
summary: Western leaders reacted cautiously to Turkey's referendum result, with some expressing concern over the expansion of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's powers. The European Union urged the Turkish government to seek broad national consensus in implementing the constitutional changes, while the Council of Europe's rights watchdog called for securing the independence of the judiciary. Austria's foreign minister expressed concerns over the divided country, while Denmark's prime minister expressed concern over the new constitution. A NATO official stated that the constitutional referendum is a matter for the Turkish people.

site_title: China to post solid, steady Q1 growth on building boom, but debt risks loom
summary: China's economy is expected to report 6.8% growth in the first quarter, surpassing Beijing's target of 6.5%, driven by government infrastructure spending and a booming property market. However, debt risks remain a concern, with analysts warning of a potential asset bubble and concerns over the government's reliance on stimulus measures. Policymakers are seeking to keep the economy stable ahead of a major leadership transition later this year, but may face challenges in tackling debt risks and slowing growth later in the year.

site_title: US dollar at 5-month low vs yen on increasing North Korea tensions
summary: The US dollar fell to a 5-month low against the yen, down 0.3% at 108.235 yen, due to rising tensions over North Korea. The yen's demand increased as investors sought safe-haven assets amid geopolitical risks. The US Treasury report, which had been expected to name China as a currency manipulator, did not receive significant attention, and the Trump administration's stance on currency policies remains uncertain. The dollar index against a basket of major currencies fell 0.1% to 100.470, while other currencies like the euro and pound also slid to 5-month troughs.

site_title: Oil down slightly in subdued trade after failed North Korean missile test
summary: Oil prices fell slightly in subdued trading on Monday, after a third consecutive weekly gain, following North Korea's failed missile launch. Benchmark Brent crude futures dropped 18 cents to $55.71 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 18 cents to $53. The failed test has sparked concerns of increased geopolitical tensions, but investors seem to be digesting the news, allowing oil prices to stabilize. The US is working with allies and China to respond to the failed test, according to the national security adviser.

site_title: British MPs call for Assad's wife to lose citizenship
summary: British MPs, including Liberal Democrats' Tom Brake and Conservative MP Nadhim Zahawi, have called on the government to strip Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's wife, Asma, of her British citizenship due to her support for her husband's regime during the ongoing war. The move could be taken if Asma continues to defend the regime's actions, with the Liberal Democrats citing the need to deprive her of her UK citizenship for the public good.

site_title: Prince Harry suffered 'total chaos' over Diana's death
summary: Prince Harry revealed he suffered "total chaos" after his mother Princess Diana's death in 1997, struggling to cope for 20 years before seeking help from mental health professionals at age 28. He credits his brother Prince William's support and a boxing experience as helping him open up about his emotions. Harry aims to normalize conversations about mental health, encouraging others to share their struggles, and is part of his family's Heads Together initiative.

site_title: Updated quick takes: Singapore NODX continues to surpass expectations
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew for a fifth straight month in March, posting a 16.5% year-on-year jump, driven by increases in electronic and non-electronic exports. The largest contributors to this growth were China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. This marks a fifth consecutive month of surpassing expectations.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew for a fifth straight month in March, posting a 16.5 per cent year-on-year jump due to the increase in both electronic and non-electronic exports.

site_title: Cocoa hits one-month lows, white sugar falls in volatile trade
summary: Commodity markets experienced volatility on Thursday, with refined sugar futures retreating after a day of expiry-driven trade. Cocoa prices hit one-month lows due to concerns over weak demand and ample supplies, while coffee prices fell. Sugar prices surged over 2% before closing down, and Egypt imposed a sugar export tariff of 3,000 Egyptian pounds per tonne. Cocoa prices also fell in London and New York, with July London settling down 2.59% at £1,544 per tonne and July New York cocoa finishing down 2.64% at US$1,915 per tonne.

site_title: Jared Kushner in talks to sell stake in real estate tech firm
summary: Jared Kushner, a senior White House official, is in talks to sell his stake in real estate technology firm WiredScore, a company he valued at $5-25 million. Kushner is part of efforts to divest from business investments amid criticism of potential conflicts of interest. Fifth Wall Ventures, a Los Angeles-based firm, is leading the negotiations. This move comes as Kushner works to separate his business ties from his role in the Trump administration.

site_title: Need to fight for survival makes Israel the hotbed for innovation
summary: Israel has emerged as a global hub for innovation, driven by the need to fight for survival. The country's entrepreneurial spirit, fueled by its history of hardship and necessity, has led to significant advancements in medical, agricultural, and defense technologies. With a high concentration of startups and a supportive government, Israel has become a model for innovation, attracting investors and talent from around the world. The country's unique approach to innovation, combined with its strategic location, has made it an "island of success" in the face of adversity.

images.alt_text: Networking lunch at The Trendlines Group's 7th Annual Company Showcase at Hagan b'Shefayim, near Tel Aviv.

site_title: Boeing's largest 737 Max takes flight amid headwinds from Airbus
summary: Boeing's largest 737 Max, the Max 9, successfully completed its maiden flight on April 13, 2017, at Lake Washington, south of Seattle. The single-aisle jet is designed to seat 204 travelers, with the company aiming to introduce five Max models targeting different niches. Boeing faces competition from Airbus's A321neo and is working to balance production with the risk of delays and snarls in manufacturing. Despite concerns about the market, Boeing has secured 3,703 orders for the 737 Max family, with the Max 8 expected to begin deliveries this quarter ahead of schedule.

site_title: Japan facing internal economic threats as external security risks loom
summary: Japan faces internal economic threats, including a rapidly ageing population, slowing productivity, and high government debt, which continue to rise despite efforts to address these issues. The OECD report highlights the need for Japan to raise productivity and tackle labour market dualism, which drives up inequality and holds back productivity growth. With the US and North Korea posing external threats, analysts see a dual challenge for Japan's economic sustainability. The government's high social security spending and low interest rates pose risks to fiscal sustainability, and the OECD warns that debt may persist beyond the target balance year of 2020.

site_title: BP races to shut Alaska North Slope well after finding a leak
summary: BP is racing to shut a well on Alaska's North Slope after discovering a leak. The well, located in the Greater Prudhoe Bay area, is venting gas, causing crude oil to impact the well pad. A safety valve has stopped one leak, but a second leak from the bottom continues. Crews are on site, and temperatures in the area are about -11°C. There have been no injuries or reports of harm to wildlife. The incident is the latest in a resurgence of North Slope production, with output rising to 565,000 barrels a day in March.

site_title: US cities shelving plans for more self-storage buildings
summary: US cities are shelving plans for more self-storage buildings, citing concerns that these facilities take up space that could be used more productively. The move comes as cities look for ways to optimize land use and increase productivity.

site_title: Investor-friendly Jakarta chief faces ouster over Islam insult
summary: Jakarta Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, nicknamed Ahok, is facing ouster in the city's runoff election after allegations of insulting Islam. Despite his track record of success in tackling corruption and streamlining bureaucracy, Ahok trails in polls to former education minister Anies Baswedan. The winner will control Indonesia's financial center, which contributes nearly a fifth of the nation's GDP. A blasphemy trial is expected to be resolved the day after the election, with Ahok potentially facing up to five years in prison if found guilty.

site_title: Refurbs and rental planes in vogue in China
summary: China's business elite are opting for second-hand or rented private jets instead of new ones, as the country's economic growth slows down. This trend reflects a broader shift towards more practical displays of wealth, with luxury goods now often viewed as a less desirable status symbol. Dealers say second-hand jets are a more affordable option, with prices often 20-30% lower than new ones, and offer a lower risk of depreciation. The private jet market in China is expected to experience its weakest growth in a decade, with consultancy Asian Sky Group estimating a 1% growth rate this year.

site_title: Trendlines to deepen presence in Singapore
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israel-based startup incubator, plans to deepen its presence in Singapore by establishing Trendlines Medical Singapore (TMS), its first incubator outside of Israel. TMS will incubate up to four Singapore-based healthcare companies, focusing on early-stage companies with a focus on Singapore and the Asia-Pacific. The incubator aims to partner with local universities, research institutions, and hospitals to develop innovative healthcare technologies. Trendlines' CEO Eric Yeo notes that the startup environment in both Israel and Singapore receives strong government support, and the group believes this is key to catalyzing startups.

site_title: Danish firm wins offshore wind deals, sans govt subsidy
summary: A Danish firm, Dong Energy, has won the right to build two large offshore wind projects in the German North Sea without government subsidies, marking a significant milestone for the industry. This achievement comes after European governments have invested heavily in subsidizing offshore wind projects to create a clean energy source. The move is seen as a major breakthrough, potentially paving the way for the industry to pay for itself without government support. Dong Energy's success could set a new standard for the sector.

site_title: IE S'pore helping local firms build infrastructure value chain potential
summary: Singapore is helping local firms build infrastructure value chain potential by supporting small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to expand into the region. The government is sharing risks with financial institutions and grooming industry talent to help SMEs acquire financing know-how. IE Singapore is partnering local universities to expose students to the infrastructure sector, while also launching programs for professionals to receive on-the-job training and gain exposure to regional infrastructure projects. The goal is to enable SMEs to build their track record in South-east Asia and eventually globally, with a focus on smaller-scale projects in countries like Vietnam, Myanmar, and Indonesia.

site_title: UOB draws US$600m investments into Myanmar since May 2015
summary: UOB has attracted over US$600 million in investments into Myanmar since opening its Yangon branch in May 2015. The majority of these investments came from multinational and regional companies, primarily from China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand. UOB has provided financial solutions to companies in the manufacturing, hospitality, and commercial real estate industries, with clients seeing long-term potential in Myanmar's economy.

site_title: Maureen Chiquet's move from Chanel to self-empowerment
summary: Maureen Chiquet, former global chief of Chanel, has published a memoir and embarked on a speaking tour, shifting her focus from fashion to self-empowerment. After being abruptly fired from the fashion house in 2016, Chiquet left her husband, started a new relationship, and lost her job, leading to a dramatic transformation. Her book, "Beyond the Label," explores her journey, offering a private memoir and professional self-help guide. Chiquet's transition positions her as a life coach and empowerment guru, similar to Sheryl Sandberg and Elizabeth Gilbert, with a unique perspective on defining one's value system.

images.alt_text: "I had been through my own, obviously very different, period of grief, both splitting from the husband and then splitting with Chanel, but it made me realise there was a huge need for stories that are real," said Ms Chiquet.

site_title: While some robots learn to deliver pizza, others are saving lives
summary: Northrop Grumman's robotics division has been creating advanced robots for decades, including bomb-disposal aids and law enforcement tools. The company's robots, such as the FX model, can perform tasks like climbing stairs, lifting heavy objects, and communicating with hostages. Over 400 US police departments use these robots, which have saved lives in situations like the 9/11 terrorist attacks. While tech companies aim to create autonomous robot helpers, experts believe human involvement is necessary for safety and decision-making, and Northrop Grumman's robots will remain under human control.

site_title: South Asian economies could gain from globalisation backlash: World Bank
summary: The World Bank's report "Globalisation Backlash" suggests that South Asian economies, led by India, can benefit from the backlash against globalisation due to the region's resilience to higher trade barriers. The report forecasts South Asia's GDP growth to rise to 6.8-7.1% in 2017 and 2018, driven by the recovery of advanced economies and the potential for trade diversion. The region is expected to diversify its exports and enhance its supply response to create jobs, while also promoting human capital accumulation, investment in infrastructure, and a more business-friendly environment.

site_title: Tee Land unit sells Sydney hotel for A$32m
summary: Tee Land has sold its 55% stake in Quality Hotel CKS Sydney Airport in Australia to Australia Ao Bo Assets Management Pty Ltd for A$32 million, with the sale expected to be completed by May 25, 2017. The group's share of the net proceeds will be A$6.82 million, used to repay debts. This sale is part of Tee Land's efforts to restructure and repay existing debts, with the group's earnings per share potentially increasing by 2.06 Singapore cents if the sale occurred in 2015. The sale of the other Australian hotel is still ongoing.

site_title: China tech giant's American dream awakes to harsh reality
summary: LeEco, a Chinese technology giant, has failed to acquire US big-screen TV brand Vizio for $2 billion, citing "regulatory headwinds." The company, which had ambitious plans to disrupt the US market, is also grappling with financial problems, including a $820 million loss by its mobile affiliate in the first nine months of 2016. LeEco's founder, Jia Yueting, had invested heavily in various business lines, including electric cars, smartphones, and movie production, but the company's vision has not come to fruition, leading to a retreat from its US ambitions.

site_title: A boring business Warren Buffett would love
summary: Industry Dive, a Washington-based digital publication, targets executives in various industries with in-depth analysis and news on specific topics. The company has 600,000 daily subscribers and generates $15 million in sales, with profit margins of 20-30%. Industry Dive charges advertisers $60 for every 1,000 impressions, a premium price compared to Facebook's $2-10. The company's focus on saving executives time and providing a clutter-free experience drives its success, with a team of 12 engineers and developers optimizing its mobile performance.

site_title: Making sense of Trump's U-turns
summary: US President Donald Trump's U-turns on campaign promises have added to market uncertainty, with investors struggling to separate rhetoric from reality. Trump's reversal on China being a currency manipulator, support for low interest rates, and comment on the US dollar's strength have raised questions about his policies. A proposed theory is that Trump's comments came before the US Treasury's bi-annual currency report, which may reach the same conclusion as the previous report that no economy satisfies all three criteria for intervention.

site_title: Staff drive Shell Singapore's social investment efforts
summary: Shell Singapore has launched a staff-driven social investment programme called Shell iVolunteers, aiming to promote sustained and integrated volunteering efforts across the organisation. Launched in 2015, the programme has seen strong growth, with 15 times increase in membership and over 12 hours of volunteering activities completed each month. The initiative promotes diversity and inclusiveness in the workplace and has partnered with various beneficiaries, including Lakeside Family Services and the Southwest Community Development Council. The programme's objectives are to achieve measurable and impactful outcomes for beneficiaries and to foster a sense of community among Shell employees.

site_title: Fighting fake news
summary: Society is combating the rise of fake news through individual critical thinking, rebuilding trust in credible sources, and educating staff to identify disinformation. Businesses can protect themselves by working with communications partners, monitoring social media chatter, and responding quickly to falsehoods. Governments and media agencies should also prioritize transparency and humility to regain public trust. Key to stopping fake news is verifying information through multiple sources and being cautious when sharing content. Implementing robust digital presence, monitoring social media, and using technology to detect and flag fake news can also help.

site_title: Investors nervous ahead of unpredictable French election
summary: Investors are nervous about the French presidential election due to its unpredictability, with National Front candidate Marie Le Pen and extreme left-wing candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon gaining significant youth support. The election is expected to be a close contest, with a potential second round between Macron and Le Pen being described as a "catastrophe" for France. A victory for Macron could be a positive turning point for the European Union, while a win for Le Pen could lead to economic disaster and chaos.

site_title: United, Pepsi consumer outrage forces brands to respect social media
summary: Pepsi and other major brands are taking social media seriously, installing screens to display real-time conversations about their brands. This is a response to the growing power of social media in shaping consumer opinion and the potential for crises to impact profits. Companies like United Airlines and Pepsi have faced backlash after slow or unapologetic responses to consumer outrage, highlighting the need for two-way dialogue with consumers. Brands are now investing in analytics and social media monitoring tools to respond promptly to potential problems and maintain a positive online presence.

site_title: Protesters across the US call on Trump to release his taxes
summary: Protesters across the US gathered on April 15, 2017, to call on President Donald Trump to release his personal tax returns as part of a nationwide Tax March. The event coincided with the traditional deadline to file taxes. Despite Trump's voluntary release of tax returns dating back to the 1970s, protesters argue that it's the only way to ensure transparency about potential conflicts of interest. The march was held in cities nationwide, with thousands attending in Washington D.C., New York City, and other locations.

site_title: Five stocks of the fascinating sixth letter
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

The article highlights five Singapore Exchange-listed companies starting with the letter "F" - Fraser & Neave, Food Empire, Frencken, Fu Yu, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust. These companies operate in various sectors, including food, electronics, and property. Fraser & Neave has a strong presence in the food industry, while Food Empire dominates instant coffee sales in Russia and Ukraine. Frencken and Fu Yu are precision engineering firms with significant revenue streams from global customers. Frasers Centrepoint Trust is a real estate investment trust with defensive nature and stable rental income. The companies' valuations and growth potential are analyzed.

site_title: Investing in Quality via SGX's new index
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched the Developed Asia ex-Japan Quality Index, allowing investors to invest in top-quality stocks from Singapore, Korea, and Hong Kong. This new index provides a chance to invest in high-quality Asian stocks, making it a notable addition to the exchange's offerings.

site_title: Steel net to be built along Golden Gate Bridge to deter suicides
summary: The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco will be equipped with a $200-million stainless steel net to deter suicides. The 1.7-mile-long net, spanning both sides of the 220-foot-tall bridge, is expected to be completed in 2021. Studies have shown that barriers to suicide can stop people from taking their lives, with a 28% decrease in suicides by jumping per year. The net will be 20 feet down from the pavement and will have a slightly upward slope to prevent jumpers from climbing out. The San Francisco Chronicle reported that similar deterrent systems have been successful in various locations around the world.

site_title: George Soros sued by fellow billionaire in US$10b mine brawl
summary: Billionaire George Soros is being sued by Israeli mining magnate Beny Steinmetz, who claims Soros' defamation campaign cost him at least $10 billion. Soros funded efforts to strip Steinmetz's company, BSG Resources Ltd, of rights to the Simandou iron ore deposit in Guinea. The lawsuit was filed in Manhattan federal court, alleging Soros' actions were part of a coordinated effort to harm Steinmetz's business interests.

site_title: Tears and cheers greet China's new economic zone
summary: China's new economic zone, Xiongan, has sparked both tears and cheers after its transformation into a modern metropolis. The 2,000-square-kilometer zone, near Beijing, aims to boost the regional economy, but many local businesses, like Hu Weibing's clothing factory, fear forced relocation and modest compensation. Analysts predict limited economic impact, but residents see it as "life-changing." Housing prices doubled in a single day, with some speculators willing to pay 300% more for properties. Authorities hope Xiongan will flourish into a growth hub, but critics warn of the potential for displacement and economic disruption.

site_title: Global carmakers converge on China as rare slowdown looms
summary: Global carmakers, including Volkswagen, Toyota, and GM, are converging on China for the Shanghai motor show, amid concerns of a sharp sales slowdown and potential price war due to increasing competition. China's passenger vehicle sales nearly quintupled over the past decade, but are expected to be flat this year and potentially shrink in 2018. A price war is already underway, with manufacturers slashing prices to move growing stock, posing a threat to international automakers. Despite this, China remains a lucrative market for carmakers, with a growing middle class and increasing demand for SUVs and electric vehicles.

site_title: More volatility for Wall Street this week
summary: US stocks lost ground last week due to mounting tensions between the US and its rivals, including North Korea and Russia. The Trump administration's actions, such as the US bombing in Syria and the deployment of a warship to Korean waters, created market uncertainty. Strong bank earnings may not be enough to offset these concerns, with investors already expecting significant growth. The IMF's Christine Lagarde expressed confidence in global growth, but warned that trade tensions and war could impact this momentum.

site_title: Bankers' fading fear of oil lending is boon for shale
summary: US banks' growing optimism about the energy industry has led to a decrease in bad loan provisions, freeing $370 million for oil and natural gas producers. Rising oil prices have helped US energy companies raise $26.8 billion in leveraged loans, a 86% increase from last year. This could accelerate US oil production, which is expected to rise above 10 million barrels a day, and put pressure on Opec's efforts to restrain supply.

site_title: Russian funds seeking higher returns from Croatian firm's distressed debt
summary: Russian investors are seeking higher returns from Agrokor, Croatia's largest company, due to low yields in Europe. Agrokor's distressed bonds trade at about a third of their face value, offering "interesting" propositions for speculators. Russian investors, including local banks and wealthy individuals, are betting on the bonds' price doubling. With a record-low debt load, Agrokor is a rare opportunity for Russian investors to find distressed debt opportunities, as sanctions have limited new debt issuances for major companies since 2014.

site_title: Italy's wine producers lagging in fight for sales in China
summary: Italian wine producers are struggling to gain a foothold in China, accounting for only 5% of the US$2.4 billion worth of wine imported in 2016. Despite being the world's largest wine producer, Italy lags behind other European countries such as France and Germany in the Chinese market. China is expected to become the world's second-largest wine importer by 2020, presenting a significant opportunity for Italian producers to expand their sales.

images.alt_text: Liquor retailer 1919's Mr Tan sees the Chinese joining the Prosecco party going on in many mature wine markets.

site_title: Robert Taylor, innovator who shaped modern computing, dies
summary: Robert Taylor, a key figure in shaping modern computing, has died at 85. He played a pivotal role in the invention of the Internet, the mouse, and the design of the Alto computer, a precursor to the modern personal computer. Taylor's idea for a single computer research network led to the creation of the Arpanet, the precursor to the Internet, and his funding of the Alto computer design revolutionized the personal computer industry. Taylor's contributions were instrumental in launching the personal computer revolution and earning him recognition as a key architect of the modern connected computer world.

images.alt_text: At Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center, Mr Taylor was instrumental in funding the design of the Alto computer, which is widely described as the forerunner of the modern personal computer.

site_title: Bihar's alcohol ban succeeds as village women take matters into their hands
summary: In Bihar, India, a prohibition law has led to a sharp decline in crime rates, including murders, gang robberies, and riots, with a 20% decrease in the past year. The law, implemented by Chief Minister Nitish Kumar, imposes severe penalties for alcohol consumption and sale. Women in the state have taken matters into their own hands, enforcing the law and even forming vigilante groups to identify and shut down illicit liquor operations. Household spending has increased, and poverty rates have decreased, with households spending more on essentials like milk and two-wheeled vehicles.

site_title: In farewell speech, Fed's Tarullo offers fixes on bank regulation
summary: Federal Reserve Board of Governors member Daniel Tarullo delivered a farewell speech before leaving his position, offering fixes on bank regulation in his absence. He acknowledged the limitations of the Dodd-Frank Act, which regulates Wall Street, stating it "forgoes structural solutions" and instead imposes numerous restrictions and requirements. Tarullo proposed increasing the threshold for "systematically important" banks and raising the minimum capital requirement. He also conceded that the Volcker Rule, aimed at preventing proprietary trading, was a mistake. Tarullo's parting words emphasized the importance of maintaining a strong capital regime, warning against weakening it to appease regulatory change proponents.

site_title: Turkish farmers suffer Putin's wrath over Syria
summary: Turkish farmers are struggling due to Russian President Vladimir Putin's sanctions imposed after a 2016 incident involving downed Russian jets. The sanctions, which include a ban on Turkish tomatoes worth $250 million annually, are exacerbating unemployment and a trade deficit in Turkey. In response, Turkey is retaliating with its own sanctions, including a ban on Russian wheat imports. The dispute is further complicated by the ongoing Syrian conflict and differing policies between Turkey and Russia. The situation is having a significant impact on both countries' food industries and economies.

site_title: Values of director buying, selling rise
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a rise in buying activity by directors, with 14 companies purchasing shares worth S$48 million and only one company disposing of shares worth S$1.88 million. Despite lower buyback activity, insider buys were reported in Auric Pacific Group, S I2I Limited, GSS Energy Limited, and Zico Holdings. Substantial shareholders also made purchases, with Oxley Holdings' Tee Wee Sien buying 150,000 shares, and Thai Beverage Public Company ceasing to be a substantial shareholder after selling 18.58 million shares.

site_title: Beijing warns steelmakers of 'year of attack' on overcapacity
summary: Beijing has warned China's steelmakers of a "year of attack" on overcapacity, aiming to cut 50 million tonnes of capacity this year and eliminate low-grade steel furnaces by the end of June. Despite last year's 65 million tonnes of capacity cuts, the overcapacity problem remains, and the government is intensifying its efforts to reform the sector. The state will make bigger efforts to reduce capacity, urging industry officials to plan ahead, as the country seeks to reduce its annual crude steel capacity by 100-150 million tonnes within three to five years.

site_title: Solar, wind investment prospects look good in coal & oil moment
summary: US investments in alternative energy, particularly wind and solar power, appear promising despite the Trump administration's pro-coal stance. Wind and solar power have gained significant market acceptance, with wind producing 5.5% of America's electricity and solar employing over 260,000 workers nationwide. Governors from Republican states have expressed support for expanding renewable energy production, suggesting a potential shift within the GOP. However, the solar industry's recent past has been marred by oversupply and government subsidies, which may soon phase out. Despite this, some investors remain optimistic about the sector's long-term potential.

site_title: US$ set for weekly losses on N Korea tensions
summary: The US dollar is expected to lose value this week due to ongoing tensions in North Korea, with the dollar index down 0.6% for the week. US President Donald Trump stated that North Korea is a problem that "will be taken care of," amid speculation of a potential sixth nuclear test. The dollar rose against the South Korean won, but fell against the Japanese yen. Market liquidity was thinner than usual due to holiday observances, and yields declined after Trump expressed a preference for low interest rates.

site_title: A gym where Comic-Con is the reigning spirit
summary: A gym in North Hollywood, California, called Nerdstrong, has become a haven for fans of fantasy and science fiction. Founded by Andrew Deutsch in 2013, the gym offers high-intensity interval training workouts inspired by popular video games, movies, and books. Members, including lawyers and graphic designers, attend classes dressed in costume, with props and targets used to enhance the workout experience. Since joining, many members have reported significant weight loss and improved motivation, with Deutsch's goal of creating a "gamified" workout experience that makes members feel like they're in the game.

site_title: Keeping the 'ding dings' ringing
summary: Hong Kong's iconic trams, known as "ding dings," are facing declining ridership, with an average of 178,000 daily passenger journeys in 2015, down 2.1% from the previous year. To ensure their future, operators are exploring measures such as designated car-free lanes and fare hikes to fund upgrades. Despite being a cheap and emissions-free mode of transport, the trams lack dedicated lanes, resulting in slower speeds. The government has acknowledged the trams' importance, but the lack of fare increases and limited revenue growth pose significant challenges for the operator's financial sustainability.

site_title: Modern life intrudes on Ethiopia's ancient salt trade
summary: In Ethiopia's Danakil depression, a centuries-old salt trade is threatened by modernization. Hundreds of men extract salt from a dry lakebed using handaxes, but new roads and investment are expected to disrupt the traditional industry. Foreign firms are also exploring potash mining, and a government-built salt evaporation plant is set to compete with manual mining. The change is feared to put the livelihoods of laborers and traders at risk, with some welcoming the improved journey to market but others worrying about the loss of their traditional way of life.

site_title: Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump: Pillars of family-driven West Wing
summary: Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump have emerged as President Donald Trump's most important advisers, following the marginalization of Stephen Bannon. Despite concerns about nepotism, the couple has achieved few concrete victories and their influence is seen as driven by a desire to protect the Trump family brand. Kushner has expanded his portfolio into various issues, including Middle East peace and the opioid epidemic, while Ivanka Trump views her role as guardian of the family reputation. The Trump presidency is characterized by a paradox, with the president needing a strong hand to guide him but insisting on appearing in firm command.

site_title: Japan's frugal households offer no respite for BOJ, retailers
summary: Japan's economy remains sluggish despite a growing economy, with households cutting back on spending due to frugality. A 37-year-old systems engineer, Naruhiro Nogami, drives to discount stores to buy cheap groceries, despite earning enough to make ends meet. This trend reflects the country's conservative spending habits, which are not expected to improve anytime soon, leaving the Bank of Japan with limited room to maneuver. The BOJ's monetary policy options are constrained, and the economy's growth prospects remain uncertain.

site_title: Referendum inflames concerns over Turkey's deep reach in Germany
summary: Turkey's President Erdogan is set to vote on a referendum that could expand his powers, sparking concerns over the country's deep reach in Germany. Germany's largest Muslim association, DITIB, is being singled out for special concern due to its close association with Turkey's state religious authority. The Turkish government has been accused of using its diaspora in Germany to hunt down and punish opponents, with intelligence agencies and politicians charging that imams are spying on Turkish citizens and denouncing critics. The move has fueled support for Erdogan among Turkish-Germans, who feel ostracized in their host country.

site_title: N Korean missile 'blows up' on Sunday's test launch
summary: A North Korean missile "blew up almost immediately" during its test launch on Sunday, according to the US Pacific Command. The failed launch occurred hours before US Vice-President Mike Pence's visit to South Korea to discuss the North's increasingly defiant arms programme. The incident came a day after North Korea held a military parade in Pyongyang, showcasing what appeared to be new long-range ballistic missiles.

site_title: Formula One: Alonso Indy 500 deal 'barking mad', says Red Bull boss
summary: Red Bull team chief Christian Horner criticized McLaren's decision to allow Fernando Alonso to miss the Monaco Grand Prix and compete in the Indianapolis 500. Horner called the move "barking mad" and questioned Alonso's preparation, stating he would not have allowed any driver to leave the team for another series. Despite Horner's skepticism, McLaren's team principal Zak Brown expressed confidence in Alonso's abilities, saying he would put on a good show and be extremely prepared. Alonso will be replaced by Jenson Button at the Monaco Grand Prix.

site_title: PBA Group remains as lean and fast as a startup
summary: PBA Group, a Singapore-based company, has undergone significant transformation over its 30-year history, evolving from a distributor to a manufacturer, designer, and now a training center for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to adopt Industry 4.0 technologies. The company has expanded its footprint geographically and adopted advanced manufacturing, enabling it to maintain a lean startup culture despite being established. PBA Group's CEO, Derrick Yap, attributes its success to progressive and incremental growth, empowering employees to react quickly to changes and embracing innovation.

site_title: Plaque commemorating Thai revolution removed, prompting outcry
summary: A plaque commemorating the 1932 Thai revolution, which abolished absolute monarchy and established democracy, has been removed in Bangkok, prompting outcry from pro-democracy activists. The plaque, which highlighted the importance of democracy, was replaced with a new one praising the monarchy. Authorities are investigating the removal, while ultra-royalist groups had previously threatened to take action. The move is seen as an attempt to rewrite history and suppress democracy, amid a government crackdown on critics of the monarchy.

site_title: Trump administration says no US trading partners manipulate currency
summary: The US Treasury declined to label China a currency manipulator, backing away from a Trump campaign promise. China remains on a currency "monitoring list" due to its bilateral trade surplus with the US, while five other countries - Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Germany, and Switzerland - also face extra scrutiny. The report acknowledged China's recent intervention in foreign exchange markets to prop up the yuan, but experts say a manipulator label is unlikely. The Treasury warned China to demonstrate a durable policy shift and warned Japan against resuming currency interventions.

site_title: Hacking group claims America's NSA infiltrated Mid-East banking system
summary: The Shadow Brokers, a hacking group, released a trove of classified NSA hacking tools and claimed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) had infiltrated the Middle East's banking infrastructure through EastNets, a Dubai-based company that manages transactions in the Swift system. The leaked documents suggest that the NSA may have hacked or targeted computers inside major banks in the Middle East, including those in Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Kuwait, Qatar, Syria, Yemen, and the Palestinian territories. EastNets denied being hacked, but the leaked documents appear to show thousands of stolen credentials and computer addresses targeted by NSA analysts.

images.alt_text: For the past few months, an elite hacking group calling itself the Shadow Brokers has sporadically leaked sensitive data from the US National Security Agency (NSA).

site_title: Woodlands set to become 'star destination'
summary: Woodlands in Singapore is set to become a "star destination" with a revamp that includes nearly 10,000 new housing units and a new business hub. The project, part of the Remaking Our Heartland programme, aims to transform the area into a major hub for businesses, especially those with Malaysian and Asean linkages. The makeover is expected to be completed within 5-10 years, with a budget yet to be finalized.

site_title: Singapore aims to house the most globally competitive plants
summary: Singapore aims to become the hub for the most globally competitive plants, with the country's manufacturing sector reaching a critical mass for the fourth industrial revolution, Industry 4.0. The government has set aside S$3.2 billion for advanced manufacturing and engineering, and companies such as Shell and Chevron Oronite are already adopting technologies like drones and wireless networks to boost productivity. The goal is to make Singapore's plants the most competitive globally, ensuring the manufacturing sector contributes 20% to the country's economy, and creating new jobs like data scientists while phasing out low-skilled manual intensive jobs.

site_title: National Mall to stop being free parking zone; meters coming
summary: The National Mall in Washington D.C. will begin charging for parking starting June 12, 2017. The National Park Service has installed 90 multi-space pay stations, with parking rates set at $2 per hour from 7am to 8pm, seven days a week. The goal is to increase the turnover of parking spots and encourage visitors to use public transportation, with revenue from parking fees expected to fund affordable transportation options.

site_title: Takata rescue talks extended, even as bankruptcy risk looms
summary: Potential rescuers of Japan's Takata Corp, a key air bag maker, have extended talks for a deal to take over the company at the heart of the auto industry's biggest safety recall. Car-parts maker Key Safety Systems Inc and Bain Capital LLC are the preferred bidder, with discussions likely to run until at least end-May. The parties aim to thrash out a deal on an indemnity agreement covering estimated $10 billion in recall costs. Automakers, including Honda, want Takata restructured through a transparent court-ordered process, while the company prefers a private restructuring to preserve its founding family's stake.

site_title: Apple considers backing Hon Hai bid for Toshiba chip unit: report
summary: Apple is considering backing Taiwan's Hon Hai bid for Toshiba's lucrative memory chip business, reportedly worth $38.4 billion. The tech giant plans to secure stable supplies of key memory chips for its iPhone by supporting Hon Hai's bid. Other bidders include Google, Amazon, and US private-equity firm Silver Lake Partners. Toshiba, the world's number two supplier of memory chips, plans to sell off the business to turn itself around after suffering huge cost overruns and construction delays. A Japanese government review would be required for any foreign buyer.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Apple is considering backing Hon Hai's multi-billion dollar bid for Toshiba's lucrative memory chip business, a report said on Saturday.

site_title: SMEs eye advanced manufacturing with curiosity and caution
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are cautiously approaching advanced manufacturing, driven by curiosity and fear. While many see its potential, others are hesitant due to high capital expenditure and uncertainty about technology adoption. Industry 4.0 is often misperceived as automation, when in fact it involves complex, multi-directional flows and seamless production lines. As a result, many SMEs are receiving inquiries but struggling to place orders, with some hesitant to change their existing models.

site_title: China's Q1 growth stabilises at 6.8%: poll
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth stabilised at 6.8% in the first quarter, driven by rising investments and a recovery in exports. Experts warn that the reprieve may be temporary, with full-year forecasts predicting a slowdown to 6.6% due to slower real estate activity and less accommodative macroeconomic policy. The government aims for 6.5% growth, which would mark a new slowdown. Policymakers are prioritising efforts to address credit risks over supporting growth, with further interest rate hikes expected in the coming quarters.

site_title: First Star Wars: The Last Jedi trailer thrills fans
summary: Disney unveiled the first trailer for Star Wars: The Last Jedi at the "Star Wars Celebration" fan event in Orlando, sending fans into a frenzy. The 132-second clip shows Luke Skywalker teaching Rey the ways of the Force, beginning with her meeting him on the island where she found him in The Force Awakens. The trailer was met with excitement and speculation, with the film set for release on December 15, 2017.

site_title: United changes crew booking policy after passenger dragged off plane
summary: United Airlines has changed its crew booking policy after a passenger was dragged off a plane to make way for a flight crew member. The airline now ensures crew members are booked into seats at least 60 minutes before departure. The change aims to prevent a similar incident from occurring again. The airline's CEO, Oscar Munoz, has faced criticism and pressure to resign following the incident, but he has stated he has no plans to step down. The passenger who was removed, David Dao, suffered serious injuries and is likely to sue the airline.

site_title: Aramco CEO sees oil market closer to balance despite US boom
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser stated that despite a US oil boom, the global oil market is moving closer to balance. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development's combined inventories are flattening, indicating a tightening market. Saudi Arabia, the largest OPEC producer, is cutting output to eliminate a global crude glut and bolster prices. Aramco is planning to increase its global refining and marketing capacity, with a focus on growth in Asia, particularly in China's downstream sector. The company is also evaluating opportunities in the US and is on track to become the world's largest stock sale, with a potential IPO in 2018.

site_title: United Air passenger says scorpion bit him on flight from Texas
summary: A United Airlines passenger, Richard Bell, claimed a scorpion bit him on a flight from Houston to Calgary, Alberta. Bell said a scorpion dropped on his head from an overhead storage bin and stung him under his fingernail. United apologized to the customer and assured that the incident was not life-threatening. This incident follows a week of controversy after a passenger was dragged off a United Express flight in Chicago, sparking international outrage and changes to the airline's policies.

site_title: Opec has to stick to agreed production cuts to keep oil prices steady
summary: OPEC is expected to maintain production cuts to keep oil prices steady, with global consumption falling to 96.58 million barrels a day in March. US oil production has increased, but is still below Saudi Arabia's output. The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a global supply-demand balance in deficit for the next six months, but notes that non-OPEC supplies could rise if prices remain buoyant. The IEA also predicts weaker-than-expected growth in demand, particularly in Russia, India, and the US.

site_title: Here's why robust US job market isn't producing better pay
summary: The US job market's growth in wages has plateaued despite a low unemployment rate of 4.5%, due to dismal productivity and lingering slack in the labor market. Productivity growth has averaged 0.7% a quarter over the last five years, the slowest since 1982, and companies are reluctant to raise wages due to weak productivity and the difficulty of raising prices. Economists project modest wage growth, with some forecasting 3% annual growth by year-end, but actual wage performance may be slower than expected.

site_title: DineNow
summary: Local restaurants Gemmills and Mitzo offer special Easter weekend brunches. Gemmills features an all-day menu with heartier options like squid ragu and Inka oven-baked pizzettes. Mitzo serves egg-centric Cantonese-style dishes, including deep-fried quail eggs and stir-fried eggs with abalone, from 11.30am to 2.30pm at S$88++. The Easter brunch runs until Sunday.

site_title: Hackers release files indicating NSA monitored global bank transfers
summary: Hackers released documents and files indicating the US National Security Agency (NSA) accessed the Swift interbank messaging system, allowing it to monitor global bank transfers, particularly in the Middle East and Latin America. The release included computer code that could be adapted by criminals to break into Swift servers. The authenticity of some documents bearing NSA seals could not be confirmed. The NSA declined to comment. The hack was attributed to The Shadow Brokers group, who also published programs for attacking Windows operating systems.

site_title: Facebook shareholders propose reports on 'fake news', pay equality
summary: Facebook shareholders propose a report on the threat of "fake news" and its impact on democracy and free speech, as well as the company's strategies to combat it. The report would review the extent of fake posts blocked, its effects on free speech, and how claims are evaluated. Additionally, shareholders suggest a gender pay equality report by December, which would disclose the pay gap between male and female employees across different demographics. The board of directors has recommended a vote against both proposals.

site_title: Abbott agrees to buy Alere at lower price from earlier offer
summary: Abbott Laboratories agreed to buy Alere Inc at a lower price of $51 per share, valuing the company at $5.3 billion, down from an earlier offer of $5.8 billion. The revised deal is a better outcome for Alere's shareholders, who had priced in a lower value given the company's shares closed at $42.31 on Thursday. The deal, which had been delayed due to legal issues, is expected to close by the end of the third quarter of 2017, and will help Abbott expand its presence in point-of-care diagnostic testing.

site_title: Uber's revenue hits US$6.5b in 2016, still has large loss
summary: Uber reported US$6.5 billion in revenue for 2016, with gross bookings doubling to US$20 billion. The company's adjusted net loss was US$2.8 billion, excluding its China operation. Despite growing losses, Uber's revenue growth and bookings are promising. The company is seeking to repair its tarnished image and improve its culture following recent setbacks, including accusations of sexual harassment and a video showing CEO Travis Kalanick's behavior. Uber is also in the process of hiring a new chief operating officer to help address these issues.

site_title: EC World Reit riding e-commerce boom
summary: EC World Reit, a Chinese specialized logistics and e-commerce trust, is riding the e-commerce boom, with its shares trading 6.8% below their IPO price. Deputy CEO Alvin Cheng attributes the trust's success to its focus on humility, gratitude, and positivity, as well as its exposure to China's rapidly expanding e-commerce industry. The trust aims to invest in e-commerce, supply-chain management, and logistics assets, with a focus on China and Southeast Asia. Cheng expects the trust to benefit from China's e-commerce growth, which is projected to reach 9.4 trillion yuan by 2020, and is eyeing opportunities to diversify outside China.

site_title: How to stand up to Trump and win
summary: A growing resistance movement against President Donald Trump is shifting from emotional protests to strategic efforts, focusing on research, networking, and preparation. Experts such as Gene Sharp and Sam Daley-Harris advise channeling passion into a movement with specific goals, using tactics like grassroots organizing, research, and polite, specific communication with lawmakers. Effective resistance requires a long-term strategy, not just symbolic protests, and often involves working with people from different backgrounds and ideologies.

images.alt_text: Protesters holding signs during a demonstration against the immigration ban that was imposed by President Trump at Los Angeles International Airport on Jan 29.

site_title: North Korea warns against US "hysteria" as it marks founder's birth
summary: North Korea warned the US to end "military hysteria" or face retaliation as a US aircraft carrier group approached the region, marking the 105th birth anniversary of its founder Kim Jong Un. The warning came after the US Navy fired Tomahawk missiles at a Syrian airfield, raising concerns about Trump's plans for North Korea. The North's military parade displayed submarine-launched ballistic missiles, suggesting a commitment to its nuclear program. China called for talks to defuse the crisis, but North Korea reiterated its threat of a "merciless" counteraction.

images.alt_text: North Korea warned the United States on Saturday to end its "military hysteria" or face retaliation as a US aircraft carrier group steamed towards the region and the reclusive state marked the "Day of the Sun", the 105th birth anniversary of its founding father.

site_title: Soros sued by fellow billionaire in US$10b mine brawl
summary: Billionaire Beny Steinmetz's company, BSG Resources Ltd, sued fellow billionaire George Soros in a US$10 billion lawsuit alleging Soros funded a defamation campaign that cost Steinmetz's company the rights to an iron ore deposit in Guinea. The lawsuit claims Soros' efforts stripped Steinmetz's company of rights and business opportunities worldwide. Steinmetz accuses Soros of a long-standing grudge and animus towards Israel, while Soros' spokesman denies any wrongdoing. The lawsuit marks the first time Steinmetz has taken direct action against Soros.

site_title: Traders go against the grain to gluten-free produce for profits
summary: Traders are shifting to niche produce, such as gluten-free tomatoes and organic grains, due to shrinking margins in traditional grain markets. Firms like BayWa AG and Glencore Plc are entering these markets, while smaller traders are benefiting from higher margins and demand from health-conscious shoppers. The gluten-free products industry is expected to expand by 10% annually, reaching $7 billion by 2020, with companies like Bunge and Cargill expanding into costlier processed commodities.

site_title: Apple receives permit in California to test self-driving cars
summary: Apple has secured a permit in California to test self-driving cars, fueling speculation about its involvement in autonomous vehicle technology. The permit allows Apple to conduct test drives in three vehicles with six drivers, all 2015 Lexus RX450h. Apple has recruited auto experts and the permit suggests the company is exploring software or hardware related to autonomous technology, not necessarily building a car. This move joins a growing list of companies, including Google, Ford, and Tesla, testing self-driving vehicles in California, with many expecting commercially viable vehicles in 2020 or later due to regulatory challenges.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc has secured a permit to test autonomous vehicles in California, fueling speculation that it is working on self-driving car technology in a crowded arena of companies hoping to offer those cars to the masses.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: Gregory Porter's album "Take Me To The Alley" (2016) is praised for its soulful baritone voice and jazzy tunes with social commentary. The album has drawn comparisons to the legendary Nat King Cole. Meanwhile, various lifestyle and business articles cover topics such as innovative cuisine, volunteer engagement, zero-waste living, financial literacy, and corporate purpose. These articles highlight initiatives and solutions in Singapore, showcasing a range of creative and practical approaches to various social and economic issues.

site_title: In about-face, Trump nominates new head of export bank
summary: US President Donald Trump nominated former Republican lawmaker Scott Garrett as president of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, reversing his earlier criticism of the institution. Garrett's nomination, along with Spencer Bachus, must be approved by the Senate. The bank provides loans to foreign entities to purchase American-made goods, benefiting manufacturers like Boeing and General Electric. Trump's backing of the bank represents a victory for these companies, which have overseas customers that use government-backed loans to purchase their products.

images.alt_text: US president Donald Trump told the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday (April 12) that he would fill the two vacancies on the bank's five-member board that have prevented it from having a quorum and being able to act on loans over US$10 million.

site_title: Game for a peek?
summary: A themed microsculpture exhibition by Russian artist Salavat Fidai will run at the K+ Curatorial Space from April 22 to June 4, featuring miniature versions of Game of Thrones icons. The exhibition is free to attend and will be a preview to the upcoming season of the popular series.

site_title: Olden & Golden
summary: Architect Leong Hon Kit praises the Golden Mile Complex in Singapore for its unique blend of old and new urban environments. The complex's design, featuring a large slanted atrium space and an open deck with badminton courts, creates a natural and ventilated atmosphere. Kit notes that the area's mix of old bakeries, sundry shops, and modernist architecture gives it an "organic vitality" and "human-ness" that is not typically found in urban masterplans. The area's gritty, yet charming, character has made it a favorite among locals and designers alike.

site_title: Chow Yun Fat GIFs a better tomorrow
summary: A Hong Kong actor's GIF has become a symbol of digital communication, but its demise may be imminent as companies adopt new email systems that ban GIFs. The GIF, which showcases Chow Yun Fat's character from the movie "A Better Tomorrow," has been used to convey approval and humor in online chats. The loss of GIFs could lead to a more formal and exhausting form of communication, but new digital tools like emojis and stickers are evolving to provide alternative forms of expression.

site_title: Maserati 'final sale' on before new dealer takes over
summary: Maserati is holding a "final sale" of its remaining stock in Singapore, with discounts ranging from S$100,000 to S$121,000 off the original prices, due to the upcoming takeover by Ital Auto on May 18, 2017. The sale includes models such as the Ghibli, Quattroporte, and GranTurismo, with a few dozen cars available, including some from 2014. Hong Seh Motors, the current importer, will focus on luxury yacht business after the sale, and Ital Auto will provide aftersales service for the cars after the takeover.

site_title: Smart & Sporty
summary: TAG Heuer's Connected Modular 45, a Swiss-made smartwatch, is a luxury timepiece that combines traditional watch-making techniques with modern technology. The watch features a modular design, allowing users to customize their watch face and interchangeable straps. TAG Heuer's commitment to Swiss craftsmanship and quality is reflected in the watch's luxe touch, setting it apart from other smartwatches.

site_title: 4 fun
summary: The Audi S4 has received a powertrain and styling upgrade. The new 3.0-litre turbocharged V6 engine produces 354 hp and 500 Nm of torque, a 21 hp and 60 Nm increase over its predecessor. The eight-speed tiptronic transmission and quattro all-wheel-drive system provide improved traction and agility. The S4 boasts a more efficient design, weighing 75 kg less, and features Audi's B-cycle compression process. The car's performance, handling, and equipment level have been enhanced, making it an ideal daily drive.

site_title: Manulife AM seeks unique solutions to address income gap in retirement
summary: Manulife Asset Management is developing innovative solutions to address the growing retirement income gap in Asia, driven by aging populations and low fertility rates. The firm is exploring unique asset classes, such as timber and farmland, and real assets like private equity and real estate, to provide consistent income streams. Manulife AM has already launched several products, including a US office Reit and an Asian Bond Fund, and plans to expand its offerings through digital channels, such as an online transaction site in Indonesia. The firm aims to help individuals migrate away from deposits and towards more productive investments to better position themselves for retirement.

site_title: My weekend
summary: A Singaporean food enthusiast shares his weekend routine, detailing his favorite food spots and activities. On Saturdays, he teaches cooking classes and visits markets for fresh ingredients, stopping by places like Alakai Poké and Tom's Palette for his favorite Hawaiian-style sashimi and gelati. On Sundays, he browses cookbooks at library@chinatown and explores Little India's markets for exotic ingredients. His culinary adventures showcase the diversity of Singapore's food scene, from traditional to international flavors.

site_title: For variety
summary: Lexus has upgraded the IS Turbo F Sport with new features, including a restyled spindle grille, re-shaped headlamps, and new tail lights. The refreshed interior features a 10.3-inch centre screen with navigation, a Blind Spot Monitor, and a "Customise" option for personalized driving settings. The engine remains unchanged, but the eight-speed automatic transmission has been improved for a silky smoothness. The IS Turbo F Sport now offers a more complete driving experience with the added "Customise" mode.

site_title: Upward mobility in Maybank
summary: Maybank's CEO, Abdul Farid Alias, credits the bank's meritocracy and diversity for its success, citing his own experience growing up poor and receiving a scholarship to attend university. The bank has implemented policies such as extended maternity leave and a sabbatical leave policy, allowing employees to recharge and find themselves. With three women on its 12-member board, Maybank is recognized for its commitment to gender diversity, and its approach is seen as a model for organizations in the region.

site_title: Ford Foundation - an unlikely convert to social impact investing
summary: The Ford Foundation, a US$12 billion endowment, has announced a shift towards socially impactful investments. Chairman Peter Nadosy, a Wall Street veteran, has led the effort to allocate US$1 billion to investments that generate both attractive financial returns and concrete social returns. The move breaks with traditional investment orthodoxy, which prioritizes maximizing returns. The foundation's president, Darren Walker, believes that 95% of the endowment's assets can be invested in ways that support the foundation's mission and purpose, rather than just generating returns. The new approach aims to balance financial returns with social impact, particularly in affordable housing and access to financial services in emerging markets.

site_title: Credit Suisse execs take bonus cuts of 40% after outcry
summary: Credit Suisse executives agreed to cut their 2017 bonus packages by 40% following investor concerns over the size of the proposed compensation. The bank's CEO, Tidjane Thiam, and other top executives will see their bonuses reduced, while the board of directors will maintain its compensation at the same level as 2015 and 2016. The move aims to alleviate concerns expressed by shareholders, who were upset by the bank's significant losses and restructuring efforts in 2016.

site_title: The conservative banker
summary: Maybank CEO Abdul Farid Alias emphasizes the bank's conservative approach to financial services, prioritizing team work and risk aversion. He aims to make Maybank the top Asean community bank by 2020, with a focus on Singapore operations. The bank plans to expand its wholesale and global banking businesses, and has achieved significant growth in Singapore. Farid believes that size does not matter, and that the bank's humanizing financial services motto is essential to its DNA. Maybank's mission statement focuses on providing convenient access to financing, fair terms and pricing, and advising customers based on their needs.

site_title: Toronto-based CIBC to move to new HQ after almost a century
summary: Toronto-based CIBC is relocating to a new headquarters after nearly a century at Commerce Court. The bank will occupy two 49-storey towers, bringing together approximately 15,000 employees from across 20 buildings. Construction is set to begin in June 2023, with the south tower expected to be completed by mid-2020 and the north tower by late 2023. The move aims to create a modern workspace, fostering flexibility and attracting talent, with exclusive naming rights to the complex.

site_title: Help! I'm a permanent temp
summary: Contract workers, despite often feeling unstable, have agency and can take steps to mitigate the risks associated with their employment. With the rise of the gig economy, workers can develop a "portfolio career" by acquiring multiple skills and working on various projects, giving them greater freedom and flexibility. Experts advise workers to expand their interests, acquire diverse skills, and network to prepare for an uncertain future, where traditional employment models may not be as secure.

site_title: Singapore has 7th largest mid to large-sized private jet fleet in Asia-Pacific region
summary: Singapore has the 7th largest mid to large-sized private jet fleet in the Asia-Pacific region, comprising 45 aircraft that make up 75% of the country's business aircraft fleet. This surpasses Malaysia, which has 50 such aircraft, representing 55% of the country's business jets.

site_title: Hatched, Batched and Dispatched
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In 1950s Singapore, traditional chicken farms were common, with many farms operating in rural areas. By the late 1960s, there were approximately 20,000 farms occupying 14,000 hectares of land. However, with the establishment of Seng Choon Farm in 1987, these traditional farms were phased out as the farm turned to automation to expand its egg-packing operations. This marked a significant shift in the industry, replacing the need for manual labor and changing the way chicken farms operated in Singapore.

site_title: Don't stint on food for shareholders at AGMs
summary: Singaporean listed companies have largely abandoned the traditional annual general meeting (AGM) buffets, sparking criticism from minority shareholders who once enjoyed the free food. The decision is seen as a cost-cutting measure, but supporters argue it would be a small gesture to boost goodwill. Some companies, such as OCBC Bank, have found alternative solutions, such as serving bento boxes, to still engage with their shareholders.

site_title: Strong performance for most asset classes in Q1 2017
summary: Global markets experienced strong performance in Q1 2017, with most asset classes rising. The MSCI AC World index dropped -0.5% in March, but the portfolio gained 1.1% due to overweight exposure in Asia ex-Japan equities and US high yield. The Asia ex Japan and emerging markets regions were the strongest performers, with gains of 9.2% and 7.3%, respectively. Fixed income segments also saw gains, with emerging market debt and US high yield posting returns of 3.9% and 2.4%, respectively. Despite a decline in bond yields, investors are advised to maintain a defensive stance due to the risks facing fixed income instruments.

site_title: Gabrielle Tay
summary: Singaporean Gabrielle Tay, founder of Action From Switzerland, was inspired to help refugees after witnessing the 2015 European refugee crisis on TV. She set up the non-profit organization in 2015 and has since spent time on the Greek island of Chios, delivering supplies and providing emotional support to refugees. Tay's experience has been marked by intense situations, including witnessing a mother suffocate her baby during a boat arrival. She has established a "safe house" for women, offering basic necessities and services like language classes and yoga. Tay's background in law and public relations has been valuable, but she emphasizes the importance of finding committed volunteers and trusting one's instincts in this work.

images.alt_text: Gabrielle Tay.

site_title: Hainan acts to clamp down on property speculation
summary: Hainan, China's southern island province, has introduced measures to curb real estate speculation, including banning non-residents from buying second newly built homes and requiring 50% downpayments for residents. The city of Sanya has also raised downpayments for second homes to 50% for residents and those paying back previous loans. These measures aim to tame hot property prices and contain resurgent demand from homebuyers and speculators.
