The restrictions may eventually curb investment and construction, potentially weighing on economic growth.

images.alt_text: Hainan's new measures prevent buyers from getting mortgages to purchase third homes and will also ban non-residents from buying second newly built homes in the province.

site_title: Retail sales, consumer prices slump in March
summary: US retail sales dropped 0.2% in March, the second consecutive month of decline, and consumer prices fell 0.3% for the first time in 13 months. The decline supports views that the economy lost momentum in the first quarter, but economists expect a temporary slowdown due to the labor market near full employment. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in June, despite the unexpected drop in core inflation.

site_title: Geo Energy optimistic about prospects after restructuring
summary: Geo Energy, a Singapore-based company, has restructured its business to focus on mine ownership, aiming to expand coal production and acquire more mines. After selling its mine operation and contracting services business, the company has acquired several coal mines, including those in East and South Kalimantan. Geo Energy plans to continue using offtake agreements with global trading houses to reduce costs and mitigate market risks. The company aims to produce 10 million tonnes of coal this year, making it one of the largest coal producers in Indonesia, and has set its sights on expanding its reserves to over 90 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: "We have to invest in the future. If we don't invest, my earnings capacity is limited." - Mr Tung

site_title: Why 'sorry' is still the hardest word
summary: Two high-profile figures, United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz and White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer, issued public apologies in response to controversy. Munoz apologized for a viral video of a passenger being violently evicted from a United flight, while Spicer apologized for comparing Hitler to Bashar al-Assad and referring to Nazi death camps as "Holocaust centres." Critics argue that both apologies came too late, with Spicer taking two days to acknowledge his mistake, while Munoz waited two days before appearing on TV. Experts say that sincerity, humanity, and a plain-spoken demeanor are key to a genuine apology, but both figures fell short in executing their apologies.

site_title: Just take my money, Massdrop
summary: A startup called Massdrop offers community-driven bulk buying of unique, high-quality products, including audiophile-grade headphones and handmade items like fountain pens. Users create polls to gauge demand, and if successful, the company sources the item and lowers the price as more people buy in. The author, a self-proclaimed scatterbrain, discovered Massdrop while searching for a lost item and found a handmade fountain pen at a significant discount, praising the website's design and community-driven approach.

site_title: JPMorgan seeks to regain its footing in US mortgage market
summary: JPMorgan Chase is revamping its mortgage lending strategy after stepping back from the US market in the aftermath of the housing crisis. The bank plans to launch a new advertising campaign featuring TV stars and upgrade its smartphone app with mortgage tools. It aims to attract mass market customers who were previously left behind, and boost its market share of conventional mortgages. JPMorgan's efforts may be paying off, with the bank making $9 billion of home loans directly to customers in the first quarter, 3% more than in the same period last year.

site_title: United Airlines, Public Enemy Number One
summary: United Airlines has faced widespread condemnation after forcibly removing a 69-year-old passenger, David Dao, from a flight due to overbooking. The incident, which was caught on video, sparked outrage and criticism of the airline's handling. CEO Oscar Munoz's initial response was criticized as flippant, and the airline has since apologized and offered refunds to affected passengers. The incident is likely to result in a multi-million dollar lawsuit and has raised concerns about the treatment of passengers in Economy class.

site_title: Tableware in the Air
summary: Delta Air Lines has partnered with Italian designer brand Alessi to introduce unique tableware and glassware in its premium cabins. The partnership brings Alessi's fine bone china, crystal glassware, and tabletop accessories to Delta One, First Class, and Delta Premium. This addition aims to enhance the dining experience for passengers. The collaboration marks a significant upgrade to meals on board, although the food itself is not provided by Alessi.

site_title: SP Setia seeks expansion through I&P buy
summary: SP Setia, Malaysia's largest residential property developer, has proposed to acquire I&P Group Sdn Bhd from Permodalan Nasional for up to RM3.75 billion, expanding its total landbank to 10,000 acres. The deal aims to "fast track its expansion plan" and tap synergies between the two companies. I&P's strong balance sheet and low debt level are seen as attractive assets. The acquisition is part of SP Setia's strategy to focus on affordable township projects due to the softer property market in Malaysia and London.

site_title: Dinner, Theatre, Discounts
summary: Marina Bay Sands has launched new entertainment packages offering shows and pre/post-theatre dinners at celebrity chef restaurants for up to 20% savings. Packages are priced from S$100 and include perks like complimentary parking and champagne. The entertainment options include Sister Act, ballet Giselle, and Michelle-Chong's stand-up comedy revue. Bookings are available at MarinaBaySands.com/Packages.

site_title: Plumping for a pink pump, to pursue a new path
summary: Hillary Clinton appeared on Katy Perry's Instagram as a shoe model, wearing a pink pair of "The Hillary" pump, promoting the designer's shoe collection. The move is seen as a daring statement, as Clinton knows her every public move is scrutinized. The post received over 309,000 likes, and Perry's collection sold out of pink shoes. The reaction highlights Clinton's continued appeal and her willingness to have fun with fashion, marking a new stage in her public image.

site_title: Japan goes into panic buying of chips at S$16 a packet after harvest crunch
summary: Japan experiences a "Potato Crisis" as snack company Calbee Inc. temporarily halts the sale of 15 types of potato chips due to a bad crop in Hokkaido, leading to panic buying and shortages. Prices for the affected chips skyrocket to six times their retail price online, with some varieties selling for S$16 per packet. The shortage is expected to spread to fast-food chains and restaurants, with regulatory hurdles and limited imports from the US cited as contributing factors.

site_title: SICC's charity drive to benefit elderly, children, disabled
summary: The Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) is hosting its 46th May Day Charity, themed "The Joy Of Giving", with over S$1 million pledged and more expected. The event will support 14 charitable organisations, benefiting the elderly, children, and disabled, who have received over S$20 million from the charity. Fringe activities include a golf event, art exhibition, dance ball, and sports events. SICC captain Andrew Lim hopes the event will reach more people and touch the hearts of disadvantaged individuals.

site_title: Toshiba loses access to unit's cash after hedge fund sues
summary: Toshiba's subsidiary, Toshiba Plant Systems & Services Corp, has lost access to its $1.1 billion cash reserve after a hedge fund, Oasis Management, sued the company to retrieve the funds. Toshiba Plant had parked the cash at its parent firm due to internal control issues and the risk of bankruptcy. The move is seen as a victory for minority shareholders, who had urged the company to return the funds. Toshiba's shares rose 5% on the news, with some analysts predicting up to $90 billion in funds could be returned to shareholders through a buyback or payout.

site_title: Bill Gross says stocks, other assets priced at unrealistic levels
summary: Billionaire bond guru Bill Gross says stocks and other assets are priced at unrealistic levels due to overly optimistic forecasts of global growth. Gross, manager of the Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund, cites low business investment and an ageing population as factors hindering growth. He believes stocks need at least 2% economic growth to rise and that a potential reappointment of Fed chair Janet Yellen could benefit bond markets. Gross is "de-risking" by reducing exposure to high-yield bonds and shortening duration as part of his strategy.

site_title: Investors flee to safe havens amid geopolitical tensions
summary: Investors are shifting to safe-haven assets amid geopolitical tensions, with US$1 billion in new money going into gold funds and T-Bills, according to Lipper data. Taxable bond funds and non-taxable US municipal bond funds also saw significant inflows, while US-based stock mutual funds posted outflows for the third consecutive week. The trend is attributed to concerns over North Korea, Syria, and China's economic policies, with investors seeking protection in Treasuries and munis, and gold. International equity funds also saw significant inflows, totaling US$4 billion, their largest since 2015.

site_title: Fuss-free Duty-free
summary: DFS, a luxury travel retailer, hosts its sixth annual Masters of Wine and Spirits event, featuring over 60 cognacs, wines, and whiskies from 50 brands. The event aims to cater to the short time travellers spend in-store and offer a great experience with clear messaging and well-trained staff. DFS invests in training programs, including the Apprentice Masters Programme and DFS University, to educate sales associates on products and industry trends. The company seeks to engage customers by telling a story behind the products, rather than just selling them.

site_title: Toshiba creditors likely to approve chip unit collateral for 1 trillion yen
summary: Toshiba is likely to secure creditors' approval for offering its prized memory chip business as collateral for new loans worth around 1 trillion yen (S$12.8 billion). The approval is crucial for the conglomerate, which needs fresh funding to complete the sale of the memory chip unit, expected to raise 2 trillion yen. Toshiba hopes to secure 300 billion yen in fresh loans and draw down loan commitments worth 680 billion yen in exchange for the chip unit stake as collateral.

site_title: Who is Charles Spackman?
summary: Charles Spackman, a wealthy businessman and Harvard alumnus, heads the Spackman Group, a Hong Kong-based global investment holding company with over $1.5 billion in proprietary assets. He is also the executive chairman and CEO of Spackman Entertainment Group, which produced films such as "Snowpiercer" and "The Throne: The Lee Kuan Yew Story." Spackman is a permanent resident of Hong Kong and a generous philanthropist, sponsoring the Charles C Spackman Scholarship Fund at Harvard. A legal dispute involving him is ongoing, but it is unlikely to affect his business, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Charles Spackman, chairman and chief executive of Korean film production company Spackman Entertainment Group.

site_title: From whiner to winner
summary: Sergio Garcia, a 37-year-old Spaniard, has matured as a golfer after winning his first Major at the 2017 Masters. Garcia, who had previously lost several Majors, including a play-off at the 2007 British Open, overcame his nerves and anxiety to sink a winning putt on the 18th hole. The victory marked a significant turning point in his career, as he transformed from a whiner to a winner, demonstrating growing maturity and confidence. Garcia credits his girlfriend, Angela Akins, with helping him calm down and overcome his past struggles, and he is now poised to win more Majors in the future.

images.alt_text: "I think life has a purpose for all of us. For me, it was mentally now. I'm glad it was because of what all the things that had happened throughout my career. I think I learned so much, it helped me grow up not only as a golfer but also as a person."- Sergio Garcia.

site_title: Saudi banks, bin Laden firms face US$4.2b US lawsuit by 9/11 insurers
summary: US insurers affiliated with Travelers Cos have sued two Saudi banks and companies affiliated with Osama bin Laden's family for at least $4.2 billion over the 9/11 attacks. The lawsuit, filed in the US District Court in Manhattan, aims to hold entities in Saudi Arabia liable for the attacks. The case is the latest effort to seek compensation from Saudi entities.

site_title: Aes-TECH-tics
summary: In Singapore, non-invasive treatments are gaining popularity for lifting the face, tightening skin, and removing fat. Three treatments were highlighted: Instant Youth Intensive Anti-ageing Programme at EstheClinic, Zeltiq CoolSculpting for fat loss, and PicoToning Laser for pigmentation and skin irregularities. The Instant Youth Programme uses Thermo-controlled Radiofrequency, micro-needling, and LED photomodulation for a youthful appearance. CoolSculpting freezes fat cells, while PicoToning Laser uses picosecond pulses to target pigmentation and skin issues. Experts, including surgeon Jennifer Harrington, praise these treatments as safer alternatives to liposuction, offering faster and quicker recovery times.

site_title: Russia to boycott Eurovision song contest due to Ukraine row
summary: Russia's state broadcaster Channel One will boycott this year's Eurovision song contest due to Ukraine's decision to bar entry to Russian singer Yulia Samoylova, citing her 2014 performance in Crimea. Moscow rejects two compromise options and claims discrimination. The contest's organisers condemn the Ukrainian decision but will proceed with the event. The boycott is seen as a blow to the contest's reputation, with many countries viewing participation as a matter of national pride.

site_title: Living Large in Black and White
summary: A Norwegian family of four, who lived in Singapore's iconic black-and-white houses for 23 years, has traded in their heritage home for a modern apartment. The family, who had experienced issues with termites and structural problems, opted for a spacious 3,700sq ft unit near Orchard Road. Award-winning interior designer William Chan transformed the apartment into a bright and airy space with clean lines, simple design, and practical storage solutions. The family now enjoys a "Nordic touch" with neutral colors, white walls, and colorful accents through furniture and accessories, saying they no longer miss their old home.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Air China cancels some Beijing-Pyongyang flights
summary: Air China has cancelled some flights to Pyongyang, North Korea, citing poor demand, but not suspended all flights. The airline had previously operated flights on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday between Beijing and Pyongyang, starting in 2008. The cancellation is not a result of diplomatic tensions, as Air China denied a report that all flights would be suspended indefinitely. The airline will reschedule flights according to ticket sales, and China remains North Korea's sole major ally despite disapproving of the country's nuclear programs.

site_title: Abbott said to agree to buy Alere at lower price
summary: Abbott Laboratories has agreed to buy Alere Inc at a lower price of $51 per share, valuing the company at $4.4 billion, after a year-long legal battle over the merger. The deal is 21% more than Alere's closing share price and follows the company's disclosure of bribery investigations, restated earnings, and product recalls. Abbott had previously sued to break up the deal, but the new agreement brings an end to the legal battle.

site_title: Samsung Group building in Seoul evacuated on report of explosives
summary: A Samsung Group office building in southern Seoul was evacuated after a report of explosives being planted inside. The building's occupants were safely evacuated following a safety announcement. The exact building was not immediately confirmed, and Samsung officials were unavailable for comment. The incident is currently under investigation, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.400 points to 1,736.780. Losers outnumbered gainers 154 to 83, with volume reaching 151.73 million lots worth RM35.46 million.

site_title: French presidential race tightens further as vote nears
summary: France's presidential election is nearing, with polls showing a tight race among the four main candidates. A recent Ipsos-Sopra Sterna poll found Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen tied at 22% each, while Jean-Luc Melenchon and Francois Fillon trail behind. Melenchon's rise in popularity is concerning investors due to his anti-EU stance and plans to repeal labor reforms. The election is now considered wide open, with Macron seen as a likely winner in a two-person run-off.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on worries economic recovery losing steam
summary: China's stocks fell on Friday, with the CSI300 index down 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.4%, amid concerns the economic recovery is losing steam. Data showed inflation, trade, and property sales growth are weakening, and investors suspect government intervention is limiting losses. The market has not fully priced in these changes, with regulators intervening in a brokerage account contributing to a flash crash in Ping An Insurance Group shares. Defensive stocks rose, while cyclical shares declined.

site_title: Malaysian property developer S P Setia to buy I&P Group for over RM3.5b
summary: Malaysian property developer S P Setia Bhd will acquire privately held I&P Group for over RM3.5 billion, creating one of the country's largest real estate firms. The deal is supported by Permodalan Nasional Bhd, a state investment fund and significant shareholder in both companies. This combination will create the largest property company in Malaysia, with a total land bank of close to 10,000 acres.

site_title: Tokyo: Geopolitical fears push Nikkei to lowest 2017 close
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index, the Nikkei 225, fell 0.49% to 18,335.63 on April 14, 2017, due to escalating geopolitical tensions. The US military's decision to drop a massive bomb in Afghanistan heightened concerns, contributing to the decline. The Topix index also dropped 0.63%.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slide on North Korea worries, end the week lower
summary: South Korea's currency, the won, and shares fell on Friday, ending the week lower, due to increased tensions between North Korea and the US. The won dropped 0.9% and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.6%. Foreign investors sold 75.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, citing concerns of a potential sixth nuclear test or more missile launches by North Korea. The US has warned of a policy of patience being over, with a US aircraft carrier group steaming to the area as a show of force.

site_title: China credit growth accelerates, defying property purchase curbs
summary: China's credit growth accelerated in March, defying efforts to curb property purchases, with aggregate financing reaching 2.12 trillion yuan. New yuan loans stood at 1.02 trillion yuan, exceeding estimates. The acceleration suggests a government campaign to ease financial and property-market risks may take longer to implement. Despite policy makers cutting the money supply growth target to 12% this year, caution is advised to avoid market volatility.

site_title: Strong US dollar a threat to Trump campaign pledges
summary: US President Donald Trump acknowledges that his strong dollar campaign pledge may be a threat, as the dollar has risen 6% against major currencies since his inauguration. A strong dollar hurts American exports and threatens his goal to correct the US trade deficit, particularly in manufacturing. Trump may consider using import duties to make foreign goods less competitive, but first needs to clarify his administration's position on the issue, which currently supports a stable reserve currency.

site_title: Saipan casino workers protest for payment as FBI cites illegal labour
summary: More than 50 construction workers on the Pacific island of Saipan staged a protest demanding payment from their employer, MCC International Saipan, after being charged with illegally importing Chinese workers on tourist visas. The workers, who are not allowed to work, held a banner reading "MCC return my hard earned money." MCC and casino contractor Imperial Pacific International were charged by the FBI with illegally importing and employing Chinese workers. The protests come amid concerns over workplace safety and the deaths of at least one construction worker on the project.

site_title: US retail sales, consumer prices slump in March
summary: US retail sales fell 0.2% in March, the second consecutive decline, and consumer prices dropped 0.3% for the first time in 13 months, indicating a slowdown in the economy in the first quarter. Despite this, economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in June due to a strong labor market. Core retail sales rebounded 0.5% after falling in February, while core CPI dropped 0.1% for the first time since 2010, with gasoline prices being the main factor in the decline.

site_title: China's dilemma over North Korea on show at border
summary: China is struggling to balance its relationship with North Korea, a key trading partner, amid tensions over the North's nuclear program. The two countries share a long land border, and China relies on North Korea for about three-quarters of its trade. Despite China's opposition to North Korea's nuclear ambitions, it fears pushing too hard could lead to a regime collapse, potentially flooding China with refugees. Tensions have heightened, with North Korea possibly conducting a sixth nuclear test, and the US sending an aircraft carrier group to the region.

site_title: Dinner Is Served
summary: Four home cooks have opened their own restaurants without leaving their homes. Lynnette Seah, a violinist and Singapore Symphony Orchestra member, runs Lynnette's Kitchen, serving mod-Indian cuisine. Seah's passion for food stems from her love of music and cooking. The other home cooks, though not publicly disclosed, share a similar passion for culinary arts. Their home restaurants offer a unique dining experience, combining food and entertainment in the comfort of their own homes.

site_title: North Korea condemns US for bringing "huge" nuclear assets to region
summary: North Korea condemned the US for deploying "huge nuclear strategic assets" to the Korean peninsula, amid concerns of a possible sixth nuclear test. The US has warned of a shift from its "strategic patience" policy, following the recent attack on a Syrian airfield. China has called for talks leading to a peaceful resolution and denuclearization of the peninsula, while the US has focused on economic sanctions. The US has also diverted the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier to the region as a show of force.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as TSMC earnings below forecast; Apple supplier Largan soars
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.65% on Friday, led by a decline in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) earnings below forecast, with the main TAIEX index closing at 9,771.26 points. In contrast, Largan Precision, a major supplier of Apple's camera phone lenses, surged 9% after beating earnings expectations and providing a bullish outlook. The Taiwan dollar also weakened to NT$30.430 per US dollar.

site_title: Huge US bomb kills dozens of IS militants: Afghan officials
summary: The US military used its largest non-nuclear bomb, the GBU-43/B, to kill at least 36 Islamic State (IS) militants in a tunnel complex in eastern Afghanistan's Nangarhar province. The bomb, also known as the "Mother Of All Bombs," destroyed key IS hideouts and caused significant damage. US President Donald Trump called the mission "very, very successful." Afghan officials confirmed there were no civilian casualties, and the mission was part of a broader effort to combat IS militancy in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, Mumbai markets closed for holiday
summary: Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, and Mumbai financial markets are closed on Friday for a public holiday. The Singapore stock market has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Traders are brushing off new US President Trump threats to extend the stocks rally. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq have edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the US stock market showing resilience.

site_title: China to create 10 "mega" coal companies through M&As
summary: China plans to create 10 "mega" coal companies by the end of the decade through mergers and acquisitions to tackle overcapacity and consolidate the industry. The new guidelines will require coal mining regions to consolidate smaller mines and close unproductive ones. China aims to shut at least 500 million tonnes of production capacity by the end of the decade, with smaller mines shut or consolidated, and has already driven up coal prices by over a quarter since the beginning of the year.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment chief in cross-border legal battle
summary: Hong Kong-based Spackman Entertainment Group chief Charles Spackman may have to pay around US$12 million to a Korean investor, Woo Sang Cheol, if a lawsuit filed against him in Hong Kong succeeds. The payment is related to a 2011 Seoul High Court judgment stemming from the 2001 collapse of infotech firm Littauer Technologies Company Ltd, of which Mr Spackman was a major investor and director. Mr Spackman has denied committing any offenses and is being pursued by Woo Sang Cheol's team, who have also launched legal proceedings in the US and at Harvard University to trace Mr Spackman's assets.

site_title: The demons arising from grief
summary: Singaporean director Guy Unsworth believes the play "Hand to God" will resonate with the local audience due to its themes of grief and community. Set in a devoutly religious town, the play explores the complexities of faith and relationships. Unsworth notes that Singapore's multi-religious and close-knit community will provide a unique perspective on the play's themes.

site_title: Facebook cracks down on 30,000 fake accounts in France
summary: Facebook has suspended 30,000 fake accounts in France ahead of the country's presidential election, marking the social network's most aggressive move to combat misinformation and spam. The action follows increased pressure from European governments to remove extremist propaganda and content violating local laws. Facebook's efforts come as US intelligence agencies warn of a similar Russian campaign to promote right-wing parties and undermine the European Union. The company has also launched a full-page ad campaign in Germany to educate readers on spotting fake news.

site_title: Apple considering multi-billion dollar investment in Toshiba chip unit: NHK
summary: Apple is considering a multi-billion dollar investment in Toshiba's chip business, seeking a stake of over 20% and potentially partnering with Taiwan's Foxconn to own around 30%. This move aims to maintain US and Japanese control over the business, addressing Japanese government concerns. Toshiba is selling its memory chip unit to raise cash after facing financial crisis due to writedowns at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse.

site_title: US immigration crackdown heats up for border crossers and tech workers
summary: The US administration, under President Donald Trump, is ramping up a crackdown on undocumented immigrants, targeting both Central American laborers and Indian tech workers in Silicon Valley. The number of illegal border-crossers has dropped to a four-decade low, with 16,600 apprehensions in March, down 30% from February and 64% from last year. The administration is ordering police, prosecutors, and judges to take a harder line, detaining anyone without papers and vigorously prosecuting more undocumented immigrants. The crackdown also includes easing hiring standards for immigration agents, building more facilities to hold detained immigrants, and adding more judges to handle cases, with the goal of expelling the estimated 11 million people living in the US illegally.

site_title: Global Chinese-sauce firm Lee Kum Kee to expand in S-E Asia
summary: Lee Kum Kee, a century-old global Chinese sauce firm, is set to expand in Southeast Asia, focusing on developing products that cater to local tastes while continuing to market its Chinese sauces. The company plans to tap mainstream consumers in countries such as the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam, and has already established an R&D base in Malaysia. Lee Kum Kee aims to increase its market share and introduce new sauces that meet local preferences, with a focus on younger generations and digital marketing. The expansion is part of the company's efforts to achieve long-term growth and success in the region.

images.alt_text: Ms Lim says Lee Kum Kee's sauces need to be Asian, rather than Chinese. The company is working on developing new sauces that cater to local tastes.
Ms Lim says Lee Kum Kee's sauces need to be Asian, rather than Chinese. The company is working on developing new sauces that cater to local tastes.

site_title: Europe: Shares post weekly loss as banks weigh, SCA gains on bid report
summary: European shares closed down 0.4% on Thursday, ending the week with a 0.2% decline, due to declines in the bank sector. The STOXX 600 index fell 1.2% as investors fled risky assets. German airline Lufthansa fell 3.1% and Svenska Cellulosa Aktiebolaget rose 7.8% after a private equity bid report. Gold climbed to a five-month high on geopolitical tensions and US President Trump's comments. Investors are focusing on upcoming European company earnings and expect results to reflect the macro-economic picture.

site_title: Foxconn asks for SoftBank cooperation in bid for Toshiba chip unit
summary: Foxconn, Taiwan's largest electronics manufacturer, has asked SoftBank Group for cooperation in its bid for Toshiba's prized memory chip unit. Foxconn aims to smooth the way with Japanese banks and may also team up with Apple Inc. for the bid. This move comes after a report by public broadcaster NHK earlier.

site_title: Man dragged off United flight plans to sue: lawyers
summary: A 69-year-old doctor, David Dao, was dragged off a United Airlines flight, sparking international outrage, and suffered a broken nose, concussion, and lost two front teeth. His lawyers plan to sue the airline, citing bullying tactics, and a city council hearing in Chicago heard tough questioning from United representatives. The airline has apologized and committed to changing its procedures, while lawmakers signal potential action, including a bill to end the practice of denying boarding to passengers on overbooked flights.

site_title: Formula One: Button deputises for Indy 500-bound Alonso in Monaco
summary: Formula One driver Jenson Button will replace Fernando Alonso for one race in the Monaco Grand Prix, taking place on May 28. Alonso is competing in the Indianapolis 500 on the same date. Button, a former Formula One world champion, will drive Alonso's McLaren-Honda MCL32 for the Monaco Grand Prix, which will be his "one race only" appearance.

images.alt_text: Britain's Jenson Button will come out of retirement for "one race only" to replace Fernando Alonso in a McLaren at next month's Monaco Grand Prix, the Formula One team announced Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after US strike on Afghanistan
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.11% on April 14, 2017, due to rising geopolitical fears after the US dropped a massive bomb in Afghanistan, adding to tensions in the Middle East and Korean peninsula. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 19.66 points to 18,407.18, while the Topix index lost 7.18 points to 1,461.13.

site_title: Toddlers playing with touchscreens sleep less: study
summary: A study in Scientific Reports found that toddlers aged six months to three years who played with touchscreen devices slept nearly 16 minutes less per 24-hour period for every additional hour of screen time. The study, conducted in Britain, tracked 715 infants and toddlers' sleep patterns and found that 92% of two- and three-year-olds used touchscreens daily. Experts have raised concerns about the study's methodology and potential explanations for the link between screen time and less sleep, but the findings suggest a potential cause for concern about the impact of touchscreen use on young children's sleep.

site_title: US banks report solid earnings, still hopeful on Trump agenda
summary: US banks reported solid earnings in the first quarter, driven by strong trading results rather than lending growth. JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup saw significant increases in net income, while Wells Fargo reported flat profits due to lingering effects from a fake accounts scandal. Loan growth was weak, particularly in corporate loans, indicating sluggish economic activity. Despite this, executives expressed optimism about President Trump's pro-growth agenda.

site_title: Self-driving 'arms race' complicates supplier tie-ups
summary: The development of autonomous vehicles is driving a shift in the automotive industry, replacing traditional top-down manufacturing relationships with complex webs of alliances and acquisitions. Companies like Bosch and Mercedes are partnering to develop self-driving technology, while others like Intel and Mobileye are acquiring automotive vision technology leaders. Major carmakers are struggling to acquire the necessary engineering talent, leading to a "self-driving arms race" with some companies buying startups and others forming partnerships. Experts predict that fully self-driving cars will be in production by 2020-2021, with widespread use expected by 2030.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble ahead of long weekend
summary: US stocks tumbled on Thursday ahead of the long weekend, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% to 20,453.25, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also falling 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. The decline was attributed to the US military's massive bomb drop in Afghanistan targeting an Islamic State complex and concerns about geopolitics, particularly in Syria and North Korea. Petroleum-linked shares were big losers, while Tesla Motors gained 2.4% after announcing plans to launch its first semi-truck in September.

site_title: Rise in boxes handled, bunker sales for 3rd straight month
summary: The Port of Singapore reported its third consecutive month of increases in container throughput and ship-fuel sales. In March, container throughput reached 2.69 million TEUs, a 6.1% increase from the previous year. Ship fuel sales also rose, with 4.34 million tonnes sold in March, up 4.5% from last year. This brought first-quarter bunker sales to 12.65 million tonnes, a 9.6% increase. The Port of Singapore's vessel arrivals also increased, with 12,318 vessels arriving in March and 34,909 for the first quarter.

images.alt_text: In March, container throughput came in at 2.69 million TEUs (20-foot-equivalent units), compared to 2.52 million TEUs a year ago, preliminary data from the Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) showed.

site_title: Apple hires secret team to develop sensors to treat diabetes: report
summary: Apple has hired a team of biomedical engineers to develop sensors to treat diabetes, a secret initiative initially envisioned by Steve Jobs. The engineers will work at a Palo Alto office, combining biology, software, and hardware to tackle chronic diseases. This move blurs the line between pharmaceuticals and technology, joining forces with other companies like GlaxoSmithKline and Alphabet to market bioelectronic devices. The initiative marks a growing trend in bioelectronics, a novel field of medicine that uses high-tech devices to treat illnesses.

site_title: A gentle, ambling charmer of a fable with a big heart
summary: Singaporean director Kirsten Tan's film "Pop Aye" made history as the first-ever Singapore movie to compete in the Sundance Film Festival's World Cinema Dramatic Competition. The film won the Special Jury Award for Screenwriting and the VPRO Big Screen Award at the International Film Festival Rotterdam. "Pop Aye" is a buddy road caper about a disenchanted architect and his long-lost elephant companion, exploring themes of alienation and redemption. The film premiered to a full house at Sundance and features a standout performance by veteran actor-musician Thaneth Warakulnukroh.

site_title: Third derivatives exchange may open in Singapore
summary: Singapore may be set to receive its third derivatives exchange, called Apex, backed by China. Asia Investment Pte Ltd, majority-owned by former China Financial Futures Exchange chief Eugene Zhu Yuchen, is operating the potential bourse. If successful, Apex would challenge Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE) and Singapore Exchange (SGX). The new exchange could list commodity futures and interest rate options, and its plans are still in the early stages. Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the proposal.

images.alt_text: Singapore may be set to get a third derivatives exchange, this time backed by China.

site_title: Delta Air tops profit estimate, may cut orders
summary: Delta Air Lines reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit, citing improving demand and average fares. The company may consider reducing its wide-body aircraft orders due to excess capacity in the industry. Delta forecast second-quarter passenger unit revenue to increase 1-3% and expects a positive passenger unit revenue for the rest of the year. Despite a 0.5% drop in stock price, the company's shares rose earlier in the day, and it forecast an operating margin range of 17-19%.

site_title: Oil near flat in strong week for crude
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Thursday, recovering from March's losses as the market nears balance between supply and demand. The US oil rig count reached its highest level in two years, with 683 rigs operating, and OPEC is set to meet on May 25 to consider extending output cuts. Benchmark Brent crude futures rose 3 cents to $55.89 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 7 cents to $53.18 a barrel. The International Energy Agency (IEA) said global oil supply and demand are close to matching, with oil stocks in developed countries falling by 17.2 million barrels in March.

site_title: Trump flipflops on Nato, China, Russia, Syria, trade and more
summary: US President Donald Trump has made a series of 180-degree reversals in recent days, abandoning long-held campaign promises and world views. Trump has retracted statements on NATO, China, Russia, Syria, and trade, with notable shifts on Syria, where he has condemned President Bashar al-Assad, and China, where he has praised leader Xi Jinping. Trump's reversals have left Washington and foreign capitals reeling, with some speculating that a more conventional, fact-based approach is emerging under new National Security Council head HR McMaster.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has long been seen as mercurial, but maybe never quite so much as this past week.

site_title: Singapore stock market needs more innovation, less emulation
summary: The Singapore stock market is considering reversing rules that were introduced in the past decade, including a potential reintroduction of a lunch break and wider tick sizes for certain stocks. However, experts argue that this approach is flawed, as Singapore cannot replicate the success of major exchanges like New York or London by emulating their rules. Instead, the market needs to focus on innovation and finding new ways to attract startups and retail investors, such as creating over-the-counter or members-only platforms. This approach will be key to Singapore's future success as a destination exchange.

site_title: US drops 'Mother Of All Bombs' in Afghanistan
summary: The US military dropped the "Mother Of All Bombs" in Afghanistan, targeting an Islamic State complex in the Achin district of Nangarhar province. The GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast bomb, with a blast yield equivalent to 11 tons of TNT, was delivered via an MC-130 transport plane and hit the tunnel complex at 7:32 pm local time. US President Donald Trump described the mission as "very, very successful." The bomb's deployment aimed to intimidate foes and clear broad areas, according to the Pentagon.

site_title: Trump's DC hotel seen facing new set of legal challenges
summary: US President Donald Trump's DC hotel, the Trump International Hotel Washington, DC, faces new legal challenges after a US agency ruling confirmed his right to operate the hotel in a government-leased building. The General Services Administration (GSA) decision allows the Trump Organization to keep its 60-year lease despite concerns over potential Constitutional breaches under the domestic emoluments clause. This clause prohibits the president from receiving compensation from federal or state governments. The ruling has sparked a new legal battle over whether the contract grants Trump benefits in violation of the Constitution.

images.alt_text: The Trump International Hotel Washington, DC is the result of a US$212 million renovation of the Old Post Office building on Pennsylvania Avenue.

site_title: Ancient perspectives on the universe
summary: The ArtScience Museum in Singapore has launched "The Universe and Art" exhibition, exploring humanity's age-old fascination with the cosmos through science, religion, and art. The show features over 120 original artworks, scientific artefacts, and manuscripts, including masterpieces by Copernicus, Galileo, Kepler, and Newton. The exhibition delves into Eastern and Western cosmologies, astronomy, and the origins of life in the cosmos, offering new insights into the universe through the intersection of art and science.

site_title: Prada reports lowest profit since IPO
summary: Prada SpA has reported its lowest full-year profit since its 2011 IPO, with net income falling 16% to 278.3 million euros. Despite this, the company sees signs of revival, particularly in Europe, where sales have returned to growth and the UK has seen double-digit growth. Prada raised its dividend and believes it is at the trough of Ebit margin, with new products in store for consumers. The company aims to speed up recovery through e-commerce and social media engagement, and is open to possible acquisitions.

site_title: Entertainment-driven formula delivers again
summary: The Fast and the Furious 8, the eighth installment in the franchise, delivers an entertainment-driven formula with car races, revved-up chases, and familiar faces. The movie, directed by F Gary Gray and written by Chris Morgan, stars Vin Diesel as Dominic Toretto and features an all-star cast, including Michelle Rodriguez, Dwayne Johnson, and Charlize Theron. The film follows Dom as he's forced to go up against a mysterious blonde named Cipher, who causes him to turn against his mates. The movie features extravagant stunts and expensive hardware, but its narrative is predictable and formulaic, earning a B- rating.

site_title: Flavour of the month
summary: Chef John-Paul Fiechtner's new pop-up restaurant, Bistro November, serves produce-driven, progressive fare in Chinatown. The menu changes daily, featuring unusual ingredients like frog livers and squid. Dishes like "brownie and ice cream" and "parfait, egg yolk and longan" showcase the chef's experimental approach, with some successes and others falling short. Despite the pressure to be cool, Fiechtner's passion for finding fresh ingredients shines through, but diners may find the unconventional flavors and presentation challenging to enjoy. The restaurant is open until November, after which its fate is uncertain.

site_title: Hope is painful, but powerful
summary: A Malay adaptation of the Haresh Sharma play "Hope" by Teater Ekamatra tells two interconnected stories of survival, hope, and despair. The play centers on a car crash survivor and a compulsive gambler whose lives intersect with a surreal dream sequence and a breaking news report of mass suicides. Despite the bleak subject matter, the production employs ethereal sound design and Islamic symbols to convey a message of hope and rebirth, offering a powerful and poignant portrayal of the human experience.

site_title: What Google, Facebook must do about one of their biggest problems
summary: Facebook and Google are under scrutiny for their role in spreading misinformation and hate speech on their platforms. The two tech giants have lost billions of dollars in ad revenue due to a boycott by advertisers who protest the placement of ads next to extremist content. Facebook, in particular, has been accused of enabling the spread of fake news that may have influenced the outcome of the US elections. To address these issues, Facebook has pledged to build a safe and informed community, but critics argue that the company cannot effectively review billions of posts daily and that there is insufficient motivation to control the misuse of its platforms.

site_title: New US pipelines help drive natural gas boom
summary: US energy firms are rapidly completing pipelines in Pennsylvania, West Virginia, and Ohio to tap into rich shale gas reserves, positioning the US to become the world's top natural gas exporter. The pipelines will provide access to new domestic and international markets, significantly boosting output from shale fields in the three states. This development is expected to drive the US natural gas boom, with the nation poised to surpass other major gas exporters globally.

site_title: Mammoth task for Pop Aye's sound editor
summary: Sound designer Lim Ting Li overcame a "mammoth" task to bring the titular elephant in director Kirsten Tan's film Pop Aye to life on the big screen. Using recordings of elephants, animals, and a seal, Lim created Pop Aye's voice, with 50% of the work done in the studio. The film won two prestigious awards at Sundance and Rotterdam festivals, cementing Lim's skills in film sound design. Despite working in radio, TV, and commercials, Lim believes the industry lacks film specialists, and her own journey into sound design was a chance discovery while studying film.

site_title: S Korea freezes rates, raises economic outlook
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept interest rates unchanged at a record low of 1.25% for the 10th straight month, despite raising its economic growth forecast for 2017 to 2.6% due to improving exports. Governor Lee Ju-yeol shifted policy to a more hawkish stance, citing better-than-expected economic conditions. The bank also raised inflation forecasts to 1.9% and warned of potential downside risks from unexpected events, including North Korea's geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: "When considering the growth and inflation path going forward, it is true the need for rate cuts has diminished. However we will keep an accommodative stance to support economic growth." - Lee Ju-yeol, BOK governor

site_title: Bank Negara said to mull enforcing cap on foreign insurer ownership
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, is considering stricter enforcement of a cap on foreign insurer ownership, with a possible cap of 70% on foreign stakes in local insurance firms. The move aims to boost local participation in the industry and promote more customer-centric practices. The bank may also require foreign insurers to hire more Malaysians for highly skilled jobs and create products tailored to local market needs. This follows warnings from Governor Muhammad Ibrahim that foreign insurers need to contribute more to justify their presence in the Malaysian market.

site_title: Americans' view of taxes not as one-sided as believed
summary: The conventional wisdom that Americans hate paying taxes is challenged by a new Gallup poll. While 50-60% of Americans believe their federal income taxes are too high, this view oversimplifies the tax system. The poll suggests that taxes are not just a divisive issue, but also a unifying force. This finding counters the long-held notion that taxes are solely unpopular.

site_title: Fund managers oppose dual-class shares plan for Singapore
summary: Singapore's stock market may be damaged and the region harmed if dual-class shares are allowed, according to fund managers and industry groups. The Asian Corporate Governance Association and international investors, including BlackRock and the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, have voiced concerns over the plan. They warn that dual-class shares will likely trigger a "race to the bottom" regionally, damaging the city's stock market and harming the region. The SGX's consultation on the plan has sparked opposition from industry stakeholders.

site_title: Grit, charm and gear in BT Weekend
summary: Four home cooks are serving private dinners in their homes, offering a mix of grit and charm. The Lexus IS Turbo F Sport and Audi S4 are featured in Weekend Drive. The Business Times magazine will highlight the home cooks in its Weekend edition.

site_title: No two wines are the same, so try all
summary: A wine grower and winemaker face numerous challenges due to nature's unpredictability, unlike other farmers who have more control over their crops. Fine wine production is a product of constant thinking and activity, with human intervention kept to a minimum. Understanding factors like weather and vintages is crucial to producing quality wine. A general rule of thumb is to wait at least 10 years for top wines in great vintages, with lesser vintages suitable for consumption 2-3 years after release. Trying every wine is essential for exploring the diverse world of wine and avoiding monotony.

site_title: UK eyes Wall Street access in post-Brexit trade deal with US
summary: The UK is seeking a post-Brexit trade deal with the US, aiming to secure easier access to Wall Street for London-based banks. International Trade Secretary Liam Fox predicts the UK's economy will thrive despite a potential lack of a Brexit deal. He wants to open up commerce in every sector, including financial services, and has expressed a willingness to liberalize trade in all areas. The UK's financial sector is expected to benefit from opportunities for expansion in the world, particularly in fintech innovation, and Fox believes London's status as a world leader for finance is secure.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research predicts mm2 Asia's growth at a 52% EPS CAGR due to Unusual's listing and expansion into China. The cinema arm contributes to a recurring income base. OCBC Investment Research reports Soilbuild Business Space Reit's 1Q17 gross revenue of S$22 million, a 9.2% year-on-year increase, but DPU fell 4.4% y-o-y. The research team values mm2 Asia's core business at 28x PE and expects North Asia to contribute over 70% of core revenue by FY17F.

site_title: SunEdison sells US$1b of assets following bankruptcy
summary: SunEdison Inc, the world's biggest renewable-energy company, has sold at least $1 billion of assets following its bankruptcy. The company's debt-induced collapse enabled competitors to strengthen their positions or enter new markets, with wind and solar supplying over 11% of global electricity. Key deals include a $2.49 billion sale to Brookfield Asset Management and a $500 million acquisition by Greenko Energies Pvt in India. The sale of prized assets has left questions about SunEdison's potential comeback, with analysts describing it as "not coming back as anything material."

site_title: Bank Negara to liberalise regulated short-selling of bonds
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia is liberalizing the regulated short-selling of bonds, starting May 2, to provide flexible hedging of interest-rate exposure and generate liquidity in the secondary government bond market. The move aims to add liquidity to the bond market and facilitate better price discovery for resident investors. The Securities Commission also announced a new guideline to allow the regulated short-selling of corporate bonds. The easing of short-selling is expected to attract onshore investors and existing institutional funds to trade at the short end of the yield curve, but may not stimulate US dollar inflows.

site_title: Berkshire cuts Wells Fargo stake to under 10%
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is selling 8.99 million shares of Wells Fargo, reducing its stake to under 10%, due to Federal Reserve restrictions. The move is aimed at avoiding limitations on commercial activity with the bank. Berkshire cited a desire to return to a percentage ownership below the 10% threshold, which US rules restrict outside influence on banks. The decision follows a year-long discussion with the Federal Reserve, during which Berkshire concluded that retaining ownership above 10% would restrict its commercial activities with Wells Fargo.

images.alt_text: Berkshire has said that the sale of its Wells Fargo shares is to enable it to return to a percentage ownership below the 10 per cent notification threshold as stipulated by the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Global sovereign fund assets stall at US$6.59 trillion
summary: Global sovereign fund assets stalled at US$6.59 trillion in the year to March 2017 due to weak markets, low oil prices, and shifts in government policy. Assets under management have levelled off for two years, with a 3% growth in 2015 and 1% in 2016. Only 29% of sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) suffered a decline in assets, while 51% saw their assets increase, with hydrocarbon-backed SWFs growing by US$60 billion. The sector continues to evolve, with increased investments in alternatives like private equity and real estate.

site_title: Gearing up for Record Store Day
summary: Record Store Day is set for April 15, featuring a Fred Perry Records Rally at Chye Seng Huat Hardware, where vinyl enthusiasts can dig through crates and enjoy live performances by indie acts Ffion and These Brittle Bones, as well as DJ sets. The City 65 Music Festival, also on the same day, will feature 13 bands and a BBQ with complimentary drinks and food, while a #Sleeveface exhibition will showcase album covers in creative ways.

site_title: Mercedes undecided on US diesel vehicles
summary: Mercedes-Benz USA has not decided whether to resume selling diesel vehicles in the US due to a lack of approval from the US Environmental Protection Agency. The company has not received approval for 2017 model diesel vehicles, leaving the future of diesel sales uncertain.

images.alt_text: Mr Exler said the carmaker plans a big boost in electric vehicles, adding 10 new EVs by 2025 worldwide.

site_title: Q1 growth at 2.5%; manufacturing still plays heavyweight role
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.5% in the first quarter of 2017, slightly below market consensus. Manufacturing sector posted a 6.6% year-on-year growth, while services sector saw a 1.5% uptick. The construction sector shrank 1.1% in the first quarter. Economists expect slower growth in the manufacturing sector, signaling a potential decline in March factory output. Despite structural headwinds, the government's full-year forecast remains 1-3% growth for 2017.

site_title: Singapore property prices to double by 2030: Morgan Stanley
summary: Singapore property prices are expected to double by 2030, according to a report by Morgan Stanley, contradicting concerns about a slowdown in the property market. The bank forecasts a 5% annual rise in home prices from 2018 to 2030, driven by rising household formation rates and a shift in foreign labor towards higher-skilled workers. Despite concerns about population growth and aging, Morgan Stanley believes the long-term outlook is positive, citing a rising household formation rate and Singapore's strong economy, which is expected to average 3% annual GDP growth.

site_title: US scientists track fish migration using DNA in water samples
summary: US scientists successfully tracked fish migration using DNA in water samples from New York rivers, providing an easy and inexpensive method for monitoring and protecting aquatic life. Researchers analyzed DNA from 42 species of fish, including common and uncommon species, and matched the results against an online public reference library. The technique, known as environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling, has broad applications in monitoring and protecting aquatic life and could help identify endangered species sold in markets and restaurants.

site_title: Trump on Syria and China: Pragmatic or just fickle?
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy and trade stance have undergone significant changes since his election. Initially, he advocated for an "America First" approach, which critics labeled as isolationist. However, after launching airstrikes in Syria, many of Trump's critics have hailed him as a symbol of American commitment to internationalist principles. Trump's policy on China remains unclear, with no signs of a trade war or renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. His administration's stance on trade and China appears to be shifting towards a more globalist approach, potentially undermining his protectionist rhetoric.

site_title: Guitar hero
summary: Singaporean classical guitarist Kevin Loh, 19, has won top prizes at the Guitar Foundation of America's International Youth Competition and the 9th Andres Segovia International Competition for Young Guitarists in Germany. Loh, who studied at Yehudi Menuhin School in the UK, has been steadily garnering awards since age 12. He will return to Singapore to perform at the Esplanade's Picnic Suite concert, marking the Singapore premiere of French composer Claude Bolling's piece. Loh aims to contribute to the Singapore music scene and plans to perform professionally with his siblings in the future.

site_title: Life from different angles
summary: Four Singaporean female photographers, Amrita Chandradas, Juliana Tan, Charmaine Poh, and Grace Baey, are making a name for themselves in the industry despite facing challenges and stereotypes. Chandradas, a photojournalist and documentary photographer, has had her work featured in international media channels and is working on a project about a girl with alopecia areata. Tan, a portrait photographer, is publishing a zine about her experiences abroad and hopes to become a world-class photographer. Poh, a freelance photographer, uses her camera to tell stories about social issues, such as the transition from female adolescence to adulthood. Baey, a full-time photographer, documents the lives of marginalized communities, including migrant workers and those affected by addiction.

site_title: Swissco judicial managers table US$7.2m vessel sale
summary: Swissco Holdings' interim judicial managers have signed a memorandum of agreement with Australian Maritime Systems Asset Holdings Pty Ltd (AMSA) to sell the 2014-built vessel Coral Knight for US$7.2 million. The sale includes a sales commission and will help Swissco pay down debts and discharge mortgage on another vessel. Swissco took the judicial management route in November after its main lenders rejected its debt restructuring plan. The company will seek a waiver from the Singapore Exchange to obtain shareholders' approval for the proposed sale.

site_title: China avoids US manipulator tag, but not off the hook on trade
summary: US President Donald Trump has decided not to label China a currency manipulator, easing some concerns of an imminent trade war. However, this decision does not mean Beijing is off the hook, as Washington has opened new fronts to target its large trade deficit with China. The US has already launched a review of whether China should be allowed the status of a "market economy" and is studying trade abuses affecting US trade deficits. Despite this, analysts warn that the Trump administration's resolve to shrink the trade deficit remains unchanged.

site_title: DBS seeks to tap US$289b in Indonesian wealth
summary: DBS Group Holdings, the largest lender in South-east Asia, aims to tap into Indonesia's wealth by acquiring businesses from Australia & New Zealand Banking Group, boosting its customer base by six times. The tax amnesty has prompted rich Indonesians to declare billions of dollars, with DBS planning to offer mobile-banking services and invest in assets like gold, property, and infrastructure. The bank expects its total wealth and retail-banking customers in Indonesia to surge to over 600,000 after the acquisition, which is part of a broader deal worth several billion dollars.

site_title: MAS stays the course with neutral stance on monetary policy
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), maintained its neutral stance on monetary policy in its second policy statement this year, dismissing expectations of a tightening move amid a growth pickup. The MAS cited a stable economic outlook and low inflation, stating it would continue to monitor the situation closely. This decision is a continuation of the MAS's dovish stance, indicating a willingness to support the economy rather than tightening monetary policy. The MAS will continue to monitor the economy and adjust its stance as needed.

site_title: Qantas probed after mid-flight incident injures 15
summary: Qantas is under investigation by Australian transport safety officials after a mid-flight incident injured 15 passengers on a Melbourne to Hong Kong flight. The Qantas Boeing 747 experienced a "stick shaker" alert, warning of an imminent stall, about 100km from its destination. The flight crew responded by disconnecting the autopilot and maneuvering the aircraft, but 15 passengers were left with minor injuries. Qantas described the incident as "unexpected turbulence" that lasted two minutes. An investigation is ongoing to determine the cause of the incident.

site_title: Aviation poised for 'third revolution'
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders predicts a "third revolution" in the aerospace industry, driven by technological advancements in electric propulsion, autonomous flight, artificial intelligence, and new materials. This revolution will bring significant changes, similar to the first two revolutions, which transformed the industry in the 1950s and 1980s. Airbus aims to play a leading role in this new era, leveraging its expertise and innovations to stay ahead in the industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Enders is determined that Airbus will play a leading role in the aerospace industry's future.

site_title: Central London house prices fall in March on Brexit, tax: survey
summary: House prices in central London fell in March due to Brexit uncertainties and high transaction costs, with a survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) showing the lowest decline since 2009. The RICS monthly house price index remained at +22, unchanged from February, as high-end properties in central London were under pressure. Outside London, price momentum strengthened, while the wider residential market was supported by a lack of stock. Economists forecast further pressure on British house prices this year due to stagnant wages and inflation.

site_title: Burger King's 'OK, Google' ad doesn't seem to be OK with Google
summary: Burger King's TV ad aimed to prompt Google voice-activated devices to describe its Whopper sandwich, but Google blocked the ad, preventing it from being heard. The ad was part of a marketing stunt to promote the burger. Despite the setback, Burger King's plan to use Google's voice-activated technology remained intact, suggesting the company was prepared to adapt its strategy. The incident highlights the complexities of integrating third-party advertising with voice-activated services.

site_title: Ringgit 'looks set for revival'
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, is experiencing a revival after a decline in November when trading in offshore ringgit forwards was restricted. Global funds are once again investing in Malaysian assets, a sign of confidence in the country's economy. This resurgence is attributed to increased cooperation between the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) in green and transition finance, which is expected to boost economic growth and stability. The revival of the ringgit is seen as a positive development for Malaysia's economy and investors.

site_title: More institutional investors use ESG factors but firms' disclosure found wanting: EY
summary: Institutional investors increasingly use environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment decisions, with 68% of respondents citing its importance, up from 52% in 2015 and 58% in 2013. However, many investors find companies' non-financial disclosure lacking, with over 80% stating that companies do not adequately disclose ESG risks. Investors are pushing for improved and better integrated non-financial reporting, with some citing the need for companies to articulate environmental and social challenges.

site_title: Australia plans to let companies bargain collectively for power
summary: Australia's antitrust regulator plans to let 24 companies, including miners and winemakers, bargain collectively for electricity purchasing contracts in the state of South Australia. The move aims to guarantee supply and improve competition, following power outages last year. The proposed 11-year collective bargaining agreement has been approved by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, with the regulator citing potential benefits of increased efficiency and new entry into the electricity generation market. The South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy expects a final decision in June.

site_title: AGM bunching: Don't fight it, just step around it
summary: A recent study found that the bunching of annual general meetings (AGMs) in Singapore is inevitable and cannot be effectively reduced. The study suggests that as the market grows, the number of AGMs will increase, making it difficult for shareholders to attend. There is no fair or practical way to force companies to spread out their meetings, and implementing solutions like a rotating roster or first-come, first-served systems may create more problems. Instead, the authors recommend focusing on improving shareholder engagement through better recording and distribution of AGM minutes, technological solutions, and more frequent avenues for engagement with management.

site_title: Market hit by geopolitical uncertainty
summary: Singapore stocks fell 16.77 points to 3,169.24 on Thursday, bringing the week's loss to eight points, amid geopolitical uncertainty. The main concerns were US missile attacks in Syria, tensions on the Korean peninsula, and US-China relations. Trading was muted, with daily volume near S$1 billion, as traders wait for the impact of escalating tensions. The Straits Times Index has lost 8 points for the week, with blue chip Singtel falling 2.8% to S$3.77. Market analysts say the US president's comments on interest rates have little long-term impact, and the economy is on track to meet its full-year GDP growth forecast of 2.8%.

site_title: Wholesale inflation dips in March for first time since August
summary: US wholesale inflation decreased 0.1% in March for the first time since August 2016, but the annual measure rose 2.3% to its fastest pace in five years. This slowdown in wholesale prices suggests gradual price growth, but the annual core PPI still rose 1.7% and goods prices increased 4% year-over-year, posing a threat to the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: The Producer Price Index, which measures input costs from the seller's perspective, dropped 0.1 per cent for the month.

site_title: Global Wellness banks on beauty offerings
summary: Global Wellness Holdings (GWH) is investing in Singapore's aesthetics industry with its new luxury aesthetics arm, Uber-Aesthetics. The company has opened its second clinic in Serangoon Gardens, offering FDA-approved medical technologies and treatments. GWH plans to expand its presence in Singapore and neighboring countries, capitalizing on the growing demand for beauty and wellness services. The new arm will feature cutting-edge technology and techniques from South Korea, and is expected to cater to both men and women, serving two generations under the same roof.

site_title: Witch-hunt of Barclays whistleblower tests mettle of new UK regime
summary: Barclays CEO Jes Staley is facing scrutiny for his attempts to unmask a whistleblower who wrote a letter revealing "concerns of a personal nature" about an unnamed senior employee. The incident tests the mettle of the UK's Senior Managers Regime, which aims to hold bank bosses accountable for their actions. Staley has been reprimanded and his bonus cut, but regulators and lawmakers are investigating further penalties. The case is seen as a test case for the regime's efficacy, with some lawmakers calling for stricter sanctions, while others defend Staley's actions as a "petty human failing."

site_title: Western Digital takes issue with Toshiba's sale of chip unit
summary: Western Digital Corp, a joint venture partner with Toshiba Corp, warned the Japanese company that selling its semiconductor unit may violate their contract. Western Digital's CEO Steve Milligan advised Toshiba to exclusively negotiate with them, citing unsuitable bidders and above-market prices. Toshiba disagrees, and the US company's recent $15.8 billion purchase of SanDisk Corp has added debt to its balance sheet, potentially restricting its ability to match bids. The sale of Toshiba's chip unit is ongoing, with Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co reportedly willing to pay up to $38.4 billion.

site_title: China orders miners, utilities to sign more long-term coal deals to ease price woes
summary: China's state planner has ordered coal miners to increase the share of supplies sold through lower-priced long-term contracts to 75% by April 30, aiming to ease rising coal prices and reduce costs for utilities. The move follows a surge in coal prices, with thermal coal futures rising nearly 25% this year. The goal is to benefit China's electric utilities, which have suffered mounting losses, but may harm coal producers who will sell less supply at higher spot prices.

site_title: Airline overbooking can be a win-win practice
summary: A United Airlines flight was overbooked, resulting in a passenger, David Dao, being forcibly removed from his seat. The incident sparked outrage worldwide and led to an apology from the airline's CEO. Overbooking is a common practice in the aviation industry, where airlines sell more tickets than available seats to minimize empty seats and keep prices competitive. While it may seem counterintuitive, overbooking can be a win-win for airlines and passengers, offering opportunities for additional compensation or upgrades. The incident highlights the complexities of airline policies and passenger rights.

site_title: Vietnam's PV Power could raise US$600m from IPO and key investors
summary: Vietnam's PV Power Corp, the country's second-largest power producer, plans to raise up to $600 million through an initial public offering (IPO) and stake sale to strategic investors. The company, which expects to complete its corporate valuation this month, aims to list on the Ho Chi Minh City or Hanoi stock exchange this year. PV Power, a wholly-owned unit of Vietnam Oil and Gas Group, plans to spread the sale of additional shares over three years and has met with investors from Singapore, Japan, South Korea, and the US.

site_title: Plans afoot to make Orchard Road pedestrian-friendly
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road is set to undergo a rejuvenation to make it more pedestrian-friendly, with plans to reclaim a traffic lane and create more pedestrian space. A scramble-crossing is also being considered at a major junction, similar to those in Japan. The government aims to inject vibrancy into the iconic shopping street with experiential concepts, street markets, and lifestyle events. The move is seen as crucial to revive the shopping belt, which has faced pressures from suburban malls and e-commerce.

site_title: Singapore's healthcare stocks generate higher returns than global peers
summary: Singapore's 14 primary healthcare listings on the SGX generated a 12-month median return of 23.5%, surpassing the 4% in the Asia-Pacific region and the 4.6% for global primary listings. This includes a 115% gain for newly-listed HC Surgical Specialists. The stocks maintained higher median return-on-equity ratios and competitive price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios, with some stocks generating returns over 50% over the past 12 months.

site_title: Tesla's Musk tells unhappy shareholders to buy Ford stock
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla's CEO, has responded to investor concerns about the company's governance structure by suggesting that unhappy shareholders buy Ford stock instead. A group of investors, including the California State Teachers Retirement System, urged Tesla to add independent directors to its board to provide a "critical check" on Musk's leadership. Musk, however, stated that the investors' proposal has nothing to do with his plan to appoint more independent directors. Tesla's market value has slipped to just shy of General Motors' after passing GM for the top spot in recent months.

site_title: Suspect in Borussia Dortmund bus attack cleared
summary: German federal prosecutors cleared the sole suspect in custody for a bomb attack against Borussia Dortmund's football team bus, stating they found no evidence of his involvement. The suspect, 26-year-old Abdul Beset A, was sought for alleged ties to the ISIS group, but investigators now pursue leads in the extreme-right and far-left scenes. The attack left one player and a policeman injured, prompting Chancellor Angela Merkel to call for harmonization of surveillance laws to strengthen the country's fight against terrorism.

site_title: World Bank joins chorus of optimism on Asia's economic prospects
summary: The World Bank has released a report stating that East Asia's economic growth outlook is expected to remain "broadly positive" over the next three years, with the region's economies projected to expand at 6.2% this year and 6.1% next year. The growth will be driven by robust domestic demand and a gradual recovery in the global economy and commodity prices. Meanwhile, poverty in the region is likely to continue to fall, driven by sustained growth and rising labor incomes.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on anxiety over Syria, French election
summary: US stocks dipped on Thursday as investors expressed anxiety over the French presidential election, Syria, and other geopolitical issues. The US and Russia's spat over Syria and tightening polls in France heightened uncertainty, while President Donald Trump's comments on low interest rates and the strong dollar sparked market speculation. Despite better-than-expected banking earnings, the Dow Jones fell as investors remained cautious.

site_title: Everyone - ordinary citizens, schools, businesses - needs to help curb rise of fake news
summary: The rise of fake news has become a significant concern globally, with the 2016 US elections and the spread of misinformation on social media platforms being key examples. Fake news can cause widespread panic, waste resources, and erode faith in public institutions. It can also impact the future workforce by promoting simplistic explanations and ungrounded generalisations. To combat this, ordinary citizens, businesses, and educators must work together to educate themselves and others on how to discern facts from falsehoods, and to promote critical thinking and media literacy.

site_title: Sotheby's International Realty to enter HK
summary: Sotheby's International Realty plans to enter Hong Kong by September with 10-15 employees, aiming to increase the number to 60 in three years. The move follows successful openings in Singapore and follows a second attempt at entering Hong Kong and a second attempt at Japan. The company, a subsidiary of Realogy Holdings Corp, will focus on leveraging its international franchise network and exploring opportunities in the Japanese market.

site_title: Trump wants to revive US Export-Import Bank
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to revive the Export-Import Bank of the United States, a move welcomed by American manufacturers such as Boeing and General Electric, who rely on the agency's government-backed loans to purchase their products. Trump's decision reverses his earlier criticism of the bank, which conservatives have targeted for alleged cronyism and lack of job creation. The bank provides loans to foreign entities to purchase American-made goods, and its revival is seen as a boost to US exports and job creation.

site_title: Hong Kong, S'pore set to make fee disclosures mandatory
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore are set to introduce mandatory fee disclosure rules for wealth managers, aiming to reveal conflicts of interest. The move, aimed at transparency, could disrupt a business generating billions of dollars in fees. Under the new rules, wealth managers will be required to disclose the overall revenues they make from recommending funds to clients. The regulations are part of efforts to enhance investor protection and promote fair market practices in the two Asian wealth hubs.

site_title: US-Japan war games near N Korea far from amusing
summary: US President Donald Trump has dispatched a US Navy strike group to the western Pacific in a show of force towards North Korea, with Japan joining in the "war games". The move has raised tensions, with North Korea warning of a nuclear attack on the US if it perceives aggression. Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for a peaceful resolution, while warning North Korea against nuclear and missile activities. The exercises have been criticized as a simplistic and provocative approach, potentially escalating the situation and pushing North Korea into an aggressive reaction.

site_title: China, South Korea urge calm as North Korea prepares big celebration
summary: China and South Korea have urged calm amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula, with North Korea preparing for a major celebration. The US has dispatched a US aircraft carrier group to the area, raising concerns of a potential pre-emptive strike. China has called for a peaceful resolution, urging North Korea to halt its nuclear program in exchange for greater protection. South Korea has expressed its intention to be consulted by the US before any military action, while US officials focus on tougher economic sanctions against North Korea.

site_title: Lao Jiu: a superb S'pore musical
summary: The Theatre Practice's musical "Lao Jiu: The Musical" is a standout production in Singapore, featuring emotive songs, effective choreography, and a moving story that resonates with ordinary Singaporeans. Based on the 1990 play by Kuo Pao Kun, the musical tells the story of a young boy who struggles to balance his desire for self-determination with the expectations of his family and society. The show features a talented ensemble cast, impressive music, and poignant choreography, with notable songs and a powerful conclusion.

site_title: Citi profit rises 17% as fixed-income trading jumps
