The Monetary Authority of Singapore has approved fintech experiments in insurance and wealth management, and has recommended increased transparency and fair dealing in insurance sales. This comes as Singaporeans increasingly turn to online platforms to buy insurance and manage their finances, with 72% of online users purchasing travel insurance online.

site_title: China, South Korea discuss more sanctions on North Korea
summary: China and South Korea agreed to impose tougher sanctions on North Korea if it conducts nuclear or long-range missile tests. The agreement was made during talks between South Korea's chief nuclear envoy Kim Hong-kyun and China's Special Representative for Korean Peninsula Affairs Wu Dawei. The US has also announced a show of force with a Navy strike group heading to the region, following comments from US President Donald Trump's top aides suggesting a hardening of US policy on North Korea.

site_title: BOJ upbeat over Japan's regional economies
summary: The Bank of Japan has expressed optimism about Japan's regional economies, with eight of the nine regions showing moderate expansion, a first in nine years. However, some firms warned that uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade policies could impact their capital expenditure plans. The BOJ maintained its monetary stimulus, aiming for a 2% inflation target, despite concerns about the global outlook and potential attacks on its loose monetary policy.

site_title: sgsme.sg: SPH's new bilingual portal to help SMEs get up to speed
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has launched a bilingual portal, sgsme.sg, to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) stay informed and connected. The portal features news, features, and interviews from various SPH publications, as well as a discussion board called "Just Ask" where SME owners can ask questions and receive expert answers. The goal is to build an online community of SMEs and provide easy access to policy announcements, business trends, and expert insights to help them grow their businesses.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OCBC Investment Research initiates coverage on Straits Trading Company (STC) with a buy recommendation, citing its solid track record of creating value for shareholders and stable dividend yield. The research team believes the privatisation of ARA Asset Management will be positive for STC, unlocking S$48.2 million in cash and retaining exposure to ARA's unique value proposition. Meanwhile, Thai Beverage is also initiated with a buy recommendation, driven by expected normalisation in alcohol consumption and potential margin uplift in its beers segment.

site_title: Pliskova, Wozniacki on course for Singapore
summary: The 2017 WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global will take place from October 22-29 at the Sports Hub. Karolina Pliskova leads the "Road to Singapore" singles leaderboard with a six-point lead over Caroline Wozniacki, who is poised to take top spot in the coming weeks. Other top contenders include Johanna Konta and the Williams sisters, Serena and Venus. The public sale of tickets starts on April 25, with pre-sales available for OCBC cardmembers and StarHub customers.

site_title: Eco-friendly housing: the way forward is more promotion
summary: Singapore's Green Mark Scheme has encouraged the development of environmentally-friendly buildings, with a significant increase in eco-friendly housing projects since its introduction in 2005. Analysis of condo transactions and surveys found that buyers are willing to pay a premium for eco-friendly condominiums, with the premium varying by location and tenure. However, the survey also revealed that buyers are unaware of the BCA Green Mark scheme and its benefits, suggesting a need for better communication from developers. To further enhance adoption, the government should continue to improve the scheme and promote its benefits to buyers.

site_title: Lucky country's energy riches turning into a curse
summary: Australia's abundance of mineral wealth has turned into an energy paradox, with the country struggling to keep its lights on despite being a world's largest exporter. The nation's wrangling over coal mining and climate change has contributed to the turnover of prime ministers. The country's reliance on coal and lack of investment in renewable energy have exacerbated the issue, leaving many to question the country's governance and its "lucky country" status.

site_title: Korean-themed mall opens in Bangkok
summary: A US$275 million Korean-themed shopping mall and entertainment complex opened in Bangkok, targeting Thai fans of K-Culture and foreign visitors. The 180,000 square metre mall features stores, restaurants, and a concert hall dedicated to Korean brands and K-pop artists. The mall aims to attract 10 million visitors annually, capitalizing on growing regional interest in South Korean pop culture. Lotte Group is among the companies to open a store at the mall.

site_title: Heightened uncertainty shrouds market
summary: Singapore stocks remained volatile, with the Straits Times Index ending 4.18 points higher at 3,181.45, but the broad market was weak. Turnover was low at S$943.3 million, reflecting heightened uncertainty from France's upcoming presidential election and Syria's geopolitical risk. Analysts expect an upturn for Thai Beverage following the end of the Thai King's 100-day mourning period. The European Central Bank's ability to counterbalance the potential impact of a Marine Le Pen presidency is seen as limited, with Philippe Waechter warning of systemic risk.

site_title: Singapore SMEs going places
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are evolving, expanding into new economy sectors like fintech, medtech, and e-commerce, and setting up F&B outlets in malls. According to OCBC Bank executive vice-president Tan Chor Sen, SMEs are now well-known in countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, China, Hong Kong, and Myanmar. The government supports SMEs with funding and risk-sharing loans, and initiatives like the Emerging Enterprise Award and Startup SG Equity scheme. Despite the support, SMEs still face challenges with funding, particularly due to a lack of track record and proper documentation.

site_title: Wall St higher as oil rises, earnings season nears
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as oil prices increased and investors prepared for the first-quarter earnings season of major banks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite indices gained 0.16%, 0.19%, and 0.23% respectively. Oil prices rose over 1% and energy stocks led the gains. Investors are watching earnings reports from JPMorgan, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo, which could impact the US banking industry's performance.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific sells Sydney office tower for A$158m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has sold its Sydney office building at 59 Goulburn Street for A$158 million (S$166.3 million) to I-Prosperity Group and Toga D&C. The 28-storey freehold office building was purchased by Roxy-Pacific in 2014 for A$90.2 million. The sale marks a two-month search by the Singapore property and hospitality group to smoothen its earnings. The building has a net lettable area of 19,410 square metres and was fully leased at the time of sale.

site_title: Toronto mayor open to sale of city real estate assets
summary: Toronto Mayor John Tory is open to selling some of the city's prime downtown real estate to fund critical transit upgrades and housing improvements. The city's real estate portfolio, valued at C$27 billion, includes 6,976 buildings with 106.3 million square feet. Selling buildings in the downtown market might be less politically charged than other assets, and the mayor considers the business case for handling real estate differently to address the city's financial demands.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Attorney-General Chambers filed a Criminal Reference with the Court of Appeal to reinstate the original convictions of City Harvest Church leaders, while ST Kinetics will develop autonomous buses and self-driving shuttles in Singapore. Rio Casa, a former HUDC estate, is up for en bloc sale, and SPH launched a bilingual portal for SMEs. OCBC advises CWT shareholders to accept HNA's takeover offer, and Spackman issued positive profit guidance for Q1 FY2017.

site_title: Unusual more than doubles in trading debut
summary: UnUsUal Limited, an events production unit of mm2 Asia, made its trading debut on the Catalist board of Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 10, 2017. The company's shares opened at 45.5 Singapore cents, a 117.5% increase from its IPO price of 20 Singapore cents. The firm plans to use IPO net proceeds for promotion and production projects, expansion via acquisitions, and working capital. CEO Leslie Ong expects combined resources from Unusual, mm2 group, and SPH AsiaOne to achieve regional expansion and business growth.

site_title: JDE says it will not revise offer price for Super Group
summary: JDE, a subsidiary of Jacobs Douwe Egberts, has announced it will not revise its offer price of S$1.30 cash per share for Super Group, as stated in a Singapore Exchange announcement. This decision was made on behalf of JDE by its financial adviser JP Morgan (SEA).

images.alt_text: Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) said on Monday that it will not revise its offer price of S$1.30 cash per share for Super Group.

site_title: KS Energy shares plummet as chairman and son face CAD probe
summary: KS Energy's shares plummeted to a 52-week low after its executive chairman and son faced investigations by the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department for potential breach of the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation relates to false trading and market rigging transactions. The chairman and son have cooperated fully with the investigation and will provide access to electronic data and equipment. The company has also posted a net loss of S$126 million for FY16 and is negotiating debt restructuring.

site_title: End users in Singapore must be taught better cyber hygiene
summary: Singapore's cybersecurity threat is a collective issue, not just a government concern. Recent high-profile cyber attacks have highlighted the need for better cyber hygiene among individuals, who are increasingly using digital services. Despite efforts by the government and private sector, 38% of Singaporeans use unapproved personal devices for work, 50% do not comply with IT policies, and 31% use the same password across devices. To combat this, education and awareness campaigns are crucial, including the government's "Live Savvy" tips and companies introducing measures to ensure employee compliance with best practices.

site_title: Sembcorp wins 19b rupee wind power project in India
summary: Sembcorp Industries has won a 19 billion rupee (S$405 million) wind power project in Tamil Nadu, India, with a capacity of close to 250 megawatts. The project will be connected to India's central transmission utility and sold to PTC India under a 25-year power purchase agreement. The project will be funded with internal funds and debt, with development expected to be completed by the second half of 2019. This win marks a significant boost to Sembcorp's renewable energy business in India, which currently has a power capacity of over 3,800 MW in operation and under development.

site_title: Tillerson is in for a tricky trip to Moscow
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow, where tensions over Syria are expected to dominate the discussion. The US missile strikes on a Syrian airbase following a poison gas attack have widened differences between Washington and Moscow, with Russia asserting that the attack was a mistake. The meeting comes amid rising tensions between the two nations, with the US seeking ways to de-escalate the situation and Russia looking to protect its ally, Syrian President Bashar Assad. The meeting may impact prospects for a warming of relations between the US and Russia, which had appeared to be on the path to a rapprochement before the recent events.

site_title: Barclays, its CEO probed over whistleblower programme
summary: Barclays CEO Jes Staley is under investigation by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) over his attempts to identify a whistleblower within the bank. Staley had viewed an anonymous letter as "an unfair personal attack" and requested the bank's security team to find the author. The bank's board has concluded Staley "honestly, but mistakenly" believed it was permissible to try to identify the whistleblower. A significant compensation adjustment will be made to Staley's pay packet.

site_title: UK consumers squeezed as wages, inflation diverge
summary: UK consumers face a squeeze in their pockets as inflation accelerates, while wage growth weakens, making it difficult for pay to keep pace with price increases. This divergence in inflation and wage growth is expected to impact household spending habits in 2017, with consumer-price growth already above the Bank of England's 2% target. The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee has expressed concerns about the fundamentals for consumers weakening, with retail sales plunging and consumer confidence on a downward trend. This may threaten UK growth prospects, with experts warning of a further weakening of consumer spending.

site_title: Mid-sized theatre to be built on Esplanade waterfront
summary: Singapore's Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay plans to build a mid-sized waterfront theatre, funded by the government (S$10m) and Esplanade (S$20m). The 550-seat theatre will focus on local productions and enable arts groups to operate sustainably. Construction will start in 2019, with a planned opening in 2021. The new theatre will promote regional collaborations, deepen productions, and provide more opportunities for schools and traditional arts groups. Esplanade aims to develop a "raw and casual theatre that is functional, accessible and welcoming".

site_title: OUE's wholly-owned unit to issue S$200m 3.75% notes due 2022
summary: OUE's wholly-owned unit, OUE Treasury, has proposed issuing S$200 million 3.75% notes due 2022 under a S$3 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme. The notes are expected to be issued on April 17, 2017, and are unconditionally guaranteed by OUE. Joint lead managers and bookrunners for the issue are the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited, Singapore Branch, and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific finds buyers for Sydney office building for A$158m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has agreed to sell its freehold office building in Sydney, Australia, to I-Prosperity Group and Toga D&C for A$158 million. The sale, jointly marketed by Jones Lang LaSalle and Colliers International, is subject to due diligence and definitive agreements. Roxy-Pacific will announce any material developments as they occur.

site_title: Singapore shares close broadly weaker despite STI's rise
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.18 points to 3,181.45 on Monday, despite a weak broad market with 201 gains and 295 losses. The low turnover of 2 billion units reflected heightened uncertainty, with sentiment influenced by US jobs report, Syria events, and France's presidential election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.2 points to 1,739.52. The market saw 3.66 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 468 to 430.

site_title: Keppel O&M to sell Dutch shipyard to Damen Shipyards Group
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has agreed to sell its Rotterdam-based shipyard, Keppel Verolme, to Damen Shipyards Group as part of efforts to optimise operations and rationalise its global network. The sale, which has been filed with the Dutch Authority for Consumers & Markets, will not affect Keppel O&M's offshore oil and gas market presence, with services to be maintained through its Singapore and global yards. The sale will not impact the 250 employees currently working at the yard, with Damen planning to continue activities there.

site_title: Crowe Horwath acquires Partners Capital
summary: Crowe Horwath Singapore has acquired Partners Capital Singapore, a corporate finance firm, and renamed itself Crowe Horwath Capital Pte Ltd. The acquisition expands Crowe Horwath's services to include corporate finance advisory for listed companies and privately owned clients on the Singapore Exchange. The transaction amount was not disclosed.

site_title: US banks scrambling to fix old systems
summary: US banks are struggling to maintain outdated COBOL systems, a vintage programming language developed nearly 60 years ago. The language underpins critical financial services, including deposit accounts and cheque-clearing services, with an estimated $3 trillion in daily commerce flowing through these systems. A dwindling community of IT veterans specializing in COBOL is needed to fix glitches and rewrite coding manuals, with experienced programmers earning over $100 an hour. To address the issue, banks are shifting towards newer languages, while companies like IBM are launching training programs and fellowships for young IT specialists.

site_title: Midas Holdings JV secures 543m-yuan metro train car contract in China
summary: MIDAS Holdings' joint-venture CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co secured a 543 million yuan (S$111 million) metro train car supply contract in China for Shanghai Metro Line 2. The contract, worth 32.5% of NPRT's interest, is expected to contribute positively to the group's financial performance for the 2018 financial year.

site_title: Civmec tie-up wins contract for Gruyere Gold Project in Australia
summary: Civmec Limited, a MAINBOARD-LISTED construction and engineering services provider, has won an engineering, procurement and construction contract for the Gruyere Gold Project in Western Australia as part of the Amec Foster Wheeler Civmec JV (ACJV). Onsite work is scheduled to start in July 2017, with over 300 personnel involved and completion by December 2018. The project is considered one of the largest in Western Australia, and Civmec CEO Patrick Tallon expressed confidence in delivering a successful outcome for all stakeholders.

site_title: Spackman issues positive profit guidance for Q1 FY2017
summary: SPACKMAN Entertainment Group reported a positive profit guidance for Q1 FY2017, expecting a net profit compared to a net loss in the previous period. The turnaround is attributed to revenue recognition from Master, an upcoming thriller movie, and lower operating expenses after disposing of Opus Pictures Ltd in August 2016.

site_title: ComfortDelGro launches new flat fare option for app bookings
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean taxi giant, has launched a new flat fare option in its booking app, aiming to simplify fares and provide commuters with more certainty on the cost of their rides. This move comes after other cab operators introduced dynamic pricing systems, which adjust fares according to demand. The new offering is part of ComfortDelGro's efforts to adapt to the changing transportation market.

site_title: Insurance tops Google searches for financial services in 2016
summary: In 2016, Singaporeans searched for insurance-related terms more frequently than other financial services, with 8 out of the top 10 Google queries focusing on insurance policies. The top search terms included health, business, housing, and car insurance. Additionally, Singaporeans inquired about home equity loans and investing tips. This trend highlights the importance of insurance in the country's financial landscape.

site_title: Citic Envirotech secures 20b yuan for five years to fund water, environmental projects
summary: CITIC Envirotech secures 20 billion yuan (S$4.07 billion) in credit facilities for five years from China Merchants Bank to fund water and environmental projects. The credit facilities will support projects in water treatment, river restoration, and public-private partnership initiatives. This follows a 62.1% spike in revenue to S$544.6 million and a two-fold increase in net profit after tax to S$102 million in the previous year. CITIC Envirotech is confident of securing large-scale contracts to boost financial performance in the water and environmental sector.

site_title: China's yuan weakens as US dollar hits 3-week high, but no panic selling
summary: China's yuan weakened to a three-week low against the US dollar, reaching 6.9042 per dollar, amid expectations of further US rate hikes. However, there was no panic selling, with China's foreign exchange reserves staying above $3 trillion in March, marking the first time reserves had increased two consecutive months since 2016. Economists say the yuan's weakness may peak next year, reversing expectations of further depreciation, as market outlook changes and China strengthens controls on capital outflows.

site_title: HK stocks close flat; China sinks
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday due to geopolitical concerns following the US missile strike on Syria, while China's markets declined. The Hang Seng Index edged down 5.12 points to 24,266.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.52% to 3,269.39. The US stock markets also reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: SPH Reit Q2 net property income rises 5.2%
summary: SPH Reit reported a 5.2% year-on-year increase in second-quarter net property income to S$42.7 million, driven by a lower property tax burden and an adjusted utility contract. Income available for distribution rose 2.4% to S$37.3 million, with distribution per unit holding at 1.40 Singapore cents. The Reit's gearing level was 25.7% as of Feb 28, 2017.

images.alt_text: SPH Reit's second-quarter net property income increased by 5.2 per cent year-on-year to S$42.7 million as the retail real estate investment trust adjusted its utility contract and enjoyed a lower property tax burden.

site_title: New members appointed to SGX's disciplinary and appeals committees
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has appointed six new members to its disciplinary and appeals committees, effective April 10, 2017. The new members come from diverse backgrounds, including law, corporate finance, and accounting. The appointments were made in consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, with the goal of strengthening the committees and ensuring compliance with SGX rules.

site_title: Former Hougang HUDC estate Rio Casa up for en bloc sale
summary: A former HUDC estate, Rio Casa, in Hougang, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale by its marketing agent, Knight Frank Singapore. The estate, comprising seven residential blocks, is expected to fetch offers of over S$450.8 million, with a land rate of S$586 per square foot per plot ratio. The site has a 99-year lease and is zoned for residential use, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of about 1.1 million square feet. The tender for the site will close on May 23, 2017.

images.alt_text: Rio Casa, a former HUDC (Housing and Urban Development Company) estate, was on Monday put up for collective sale by its marketing agent, Knight Frank Singapore.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC initiates a buy call on Straits Trading Co
summary: OCBC Investment Research has initiated a buy call on Straits Trading Co due to the diversified investment group's ability to create value for shareholders, providing a stable dividend yield. Analyst Eli Lee estimates the fair value at S$2.73 per share, citing the potential privatization of ARA Asset Management, divestment of property assets, and revaluation of a site in Penang as catalysts to rally the stock price.

site_title: IHH completes divestment of stake in PCH Holding to China's Taikang
summary: IHH Healthcare has divested a 29.9% stake in PCH Holding to China's Taikang, with primary proceeds of 807.11 million yuan (S$164.37 million). The divestment was completed through a combination of a secondary sale of shares by Parkway Group Healthcare and proposed allotment of shares by PCH to Taikang. A shareholders' agreement was signed, granting Parkway Group Healthcare an option to purchase 10.1% of PCH's issued share capital at a later date.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won dip to near 1-mth low on geopolitical jitters
summary: South Korean shares and the won plummeted to near one-month lows on April 10, 2017, amid rising geopolitical risks from North Korea's advancing weapons program. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 0.9% to 2,133.32 points, while the won fell 0.7% to 1,142.2 to the dollar, its lowest intraday level since March 15. The decline was attributed to growing concerns about potential conflict and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: VWs pile up by thousands awaiting fix or scrap yard in buyback
summary: Volkswagen is struggling to resolve its US emission-cheating scandal by buying back or repairing nearly 500,000 diesel cars. The company has agreed to buy back around 500,000 vehicles, but it's unclear when or if the cars will be fixed or scrapped. The buyback process, which began in 2017, has been a costly logistical headache for the company, with around 288,000 owners opting for the buyback or early lease termination. The only cleared repair for most cars is a software update, but older models will require more extensive repairs, which may be too costly.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat at open
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Monday, following a lackluster start to the week. Investors are digesting the US missile strike in Syria and weaker-than-expected job data, which has raised concerns about US President Donald Trump's job creation pledge. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.1%, while the DAX 30 increased 0.1%, despite losses in the mining sector and a drop in the yen against the dollar.

site_title: AGC file criminal reference with Court of Appeal over City Harvest Church verdict
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) has filed a Criminal Reference with the Court of Appeal to reinstate the original convictions of City Harvest Church (CHC) leaders, who were found guilty of misusing $24 million in church funds. The convictions of six leaders, including Kong Hee, were reduced by the High Court in a split decision. The AGC will seek to have the court reinstate the original sentences and make necessary orders.

images.alt_text: THE Attorney-General Chambers said it has filed a Criminal Reference with the Court of Appeal on Monday to reinstate the original convictions of the six leaders of City Harvest Church.

site_title: Flash: AGC files criminal reference with Court of Appeal over City Harvest Church verdict
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) has filed a criminal reference with the Court of Appeal over the verdict in the City Harvest Church trial. The Church's leaders were convicted of misusing church funds. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: BOJ paints rosy picture of regional Japan, Trump uncertainty niggles
summary: The Bank of Japan has expressed optimism about regional Japanese economies, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stating that the economy is recovering moderately and expected to expand moderately. Despite this, uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade policies has raised concerns among some firms, potentially affecting capital expenditure plans. The BOJ reiterated its commitment to maintaining massive monetary stimulus, with inflation still distant from its 2% target.

site_title: Court of Appeal reserves judgement in appeal over Lee Kuan Yew's interview transcripts
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore has reserved judgment in an appeal over an interview agreement made by the late Lee Kuan Yew with the Government. The estate of Mr Lee filed an appeal after a High Court ruling stated that while the estate held copyright over the interview transcripts, it did not have custody or the right to freely use them. The final arguments were heard on April 10, 2017.

site_title: US dollar at 3-week highs, though Syria, North Korea concerns temper gains
summary: The US dollar reached three-week highs against a currency basket on Monday, driven by a key Federal Reserve official's comments on continued interest rate hikes. New York Fed President William Dudley said the Fed might avoid raising interest rates simultaneously with shrinking its bond portfolio, bolstering US Treasury yields. However, geopolitical concerns, including the Syrian civil war and tensions with North Korea, tempered gains, with the euro and yen also experiencing fluctuations.

site_title: US Fed could end reinvestment policy this year: Fed's Bullard
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard suggests the Fed may end its balance sheet reinvestment policy later this year, which could limit future interest rate hikes. Bullard, considered a policy dove, favors only one more interest rate hike this year and believes inflation will remain around 2%. The decision would make it easier for the Fed to maintain low interest rates, potentially boosting economic growth.

site_title: Residential site at Stirling Road triggered for tender
summary: A residential site at Stirling Road has been triggered for public tender after a developer committed to bid at least S$685.25 million. The 2.11-ha land parcel is expected to yield 1,110 units and is under the Reserve List of the Government Land Sales programme. The tender period will last about four weeks, with the launch date to be announced later.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as Syrian jitters ease
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday as investor concerns over the US missile strike in Syria eased, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.71% and the Topix index climbing 0.66%. A weaker yen boosted automakers and exporters.

site_title: Update: ST Kinetics to develop autonomous buses, self-driving shuttles
summary: ST Kinetics will develop two autonomous buses and four self-driving shuttles in Singapore, partnering with the Land Transport Authority. The 12-meter long buses can seat 40 people and run on fixed routes, with trials set to begin in 2020. The project, spanning 42 months, aims to showcase the results for potential export to other cities. This marks ST Kinetics' first major non-defence venture, with the goal of demonstrating autonomous bus technology.

site_title: HK opens China bond futures trade as investors search for upside
summary: Hong Kong's China bond futures market launched on Monday, with six contracts traded, sparking cautious investor participation due to operational issues and contract limits. The market, re-launched in 2013, aims to allow offshore investors to manage interest rate risk and express views on China's onshore bond market. Despite China's large bond market, foreign investor participation remains limited due to concerns over protracted yuan weakness and repatriation issues. Analysts expect volumes to rise gradually, with contract sizes set at 500,000 yuan.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC advises CWT shareholders to accept HNA's offer
summary: OCBC Investment Research recommends CWT shareholders to accept HNA Holding's takeover offer, valuing CWT at S$1.4 billion. The offer price is a 12.6% premium to CWT's closing price on Friday, representing a 19.5% premium to OCBC's fair value. HNA intends to delist CWT once public float falls below 10%. The offer must be fulfilled or waived by September 9, 2017, and is subject to anti-trust approvals from various countries. CWT shareholders who accept the offer will be entitled to retain the FY16 proposed final dividend.

site_title: Tillerson dismisses North Korea 'regime change' as warships move
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated that the US is not interested in "regime change" in North Korea, despite diverting warships to waters near the country due to heightened tensions over its nuclear program. The US wants a denuclearized Korean peninsula, but only after North Korea stops all weapons testing. Tillerson warned that if North Korea becomes a threat to others, a response is likely. The move comes as President Donald Trump seeks to prevent North Korea from acquiring a nuclear capability to strike the continental US.

site_title: Hong Kong protester jailed over anti-China clashes
summary: A Hong Kong technician, Yeung Ka-Lun, was jailed for 4 years and 9 months for rioting and arson during anti-China protests in February 2016. The case marks the harshest punishment yet for demonstrators, amid a wave of legal action against protesters and the selection of pro-Beijing leader Carrie Lam as Hong Kong's leader. The incident occurred during a period of heightened tensions, with protesters fearing Beijing's tightening grip on the city.

site_title: Australia: Shares close near two-yr high, oil stocks support
summary: Australian shares closed near a two-year high on April 10, 2017, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.9% or 50.43 points to 5,912.9. Energy and material stocks found support from higher global oil prices, with oil majors Woodside and Oil Search gaining 0.7% and 0.9% respectively. BHP Billiton also rose 4.6% due to its significant exposure to the oil sector. The market's gain was attributed to strong demand and uncertainty over the conflict in Syria, which feeds fears about oil supplies.

site_title: Asia: Traders tread uneasily as Syria strike fuels tensions
summary: Asian investors moved cautiously on Monday due to heightened geopolitical tensions following the US missile strikes on a Syrian airfield. The US urged Moscow to remove Bashar al-Assad as Syria's president, potentially straining relations with Russia and Iran. Global markets reacted with minor losses, except for Tokyo, which rose 0.7% due to a drop in the yen. Investors were also underwhelmed by the US employment report, which showed fewer jobs created than expected. Oil prices continued to gain, driven by concerns over Middle East supply.

site_title: Tuan Sing buys Sime Darby Centre for S$365m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings has signed an agreement to purchase Sime Darby Centre in Bukit Timah, Singapore, for S$365 million. The 13,088.8 sq m commercial property sits on part-freehold and part-leasehold land and is currently 96% occupied. The deal is expected to be financed by internal and external resources and is not expected to impact Tuan Sing's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. The company plans to reposition the property into a hub of activities in the future.

site_title: China steel outlook drags on raw materials futures
summary: China's steel production has led to concerns over raw materials, with key futures indicators such as iron ore, coke, and rebar trading lower. Analyst Vivek Dhar from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia notes that steel output rose 6% in January and February, and demand is unlikely to absorb the excess. This has resulted in a 1.47% drop in Shanghai Futures Exchange rebar prices to 3,013 yuan (S$613) a tonne. The surplus of steel is attributed to China's production, putting pressure on industrial raw materials markets.

site_title: Keppel Seghers completes capacity upgrade at Ulu Pandan NEWater plant
summary: Keppel Seghers, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure Holdings, completed a capacity upgrade at the Ulu Pandan NEWater Plant ahead of schedule and on budget. The project, which began in April 2016, increased the plant's capacity from 148,000 cubic meters to 162,800 cubic meters. The upgrade, which included a third-stage reverse osmosis system, is the first large-scale plant in Singapore to adopt this configuration. The plant started commercial operations in 2007 and will support Singapore's aim to achieve a sustainable and secure water future.

site_title: New York State passes US$163b budget, raises criminal responsibility age
summary: New York State has passed a $163 billion budget that includes a provision to raise the age of criminal responsibility to 18, eliminating the imprisonment of minors with adults. The measure, part of a deal between Governor Andrew Cuomo and lawmakers, also includes free public college tuition for students from low-income families and extends a tax cut program for affordable housing developers. The budget aims to offset a $3.5 billion deficit and fund income tax cuts for high-income earners.

site_title: sgsme.sg: SPH launches bilingual portal for SMEs
summary: SPH launches a bilingual portal, sgsme.sg, aimed at connecting local small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with relevant information, services, and resources. The portal features a Q&A platform for SME owners and entrepreneurs to ask questions and receive responses from experts. It also connects SMEs with specialized service providers, government agencies, and trade associations. The portal is a one-stop shop for SME-related news and features from SPH publications, building an online community for SMEs in Singapore.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars lower on geopolitical risks, greenback rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to multi-week lows due to geopolitical risks and a rally in the US dollar after US Federal Reserve President William Dudley hinted at further interest rate hikes. The Australian dollar slipped to US$0.7480, its lowest level since mid-January, while the New Zealand dollar fell to US$0.6929, its lowest since March 15. Investors are also watching developments in the Syrian civil war and tensions in Asia, driving risk-averse investors to safer assets.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slide to near 4-week low on geopolitical risks
summary: South Korea's won fell 0.7% to 1,142.3 against the US dollar, its weakest since March 15, amid rising geopolitical risks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) declined 0.8% to 2,133.59 points, near a four-week low. Investors sought safe-haven assets, while defence-related shares rose. The decline was attributed to the lack of a clear solution on North Korea's nuclear programmes from the US-China summit.

site_title: World Bank targets Singapore retail investors
summary: The World Bank is exploring a potential issue of retail bonds in Singapore to boost interest in sustainable development bonds and tap the affluent population. However, the institution faces regulatory hurdles, as only plain vanilla structures are allowed for retail investors, unlike institutional investors. The World Bank has previously sold retail bonds in Japan and Italy, but Singapore's low yields and high-net-worth investors' preference for higher yields make it challenging to attract retail investors. The World Bank is discussing with the Monetary Authority of Singapore about a potential exception for the instruments.

site_title: Hong Kong concerned about some property developer mortgage risks
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, expressed concern about the riskiness of high loan-to-value mortgages issued by property developers, which may change the risk profiles of these developers and banks with exposures. The mortgages, often offered through finance subsidiaries, have no limits imposed by the monetary authority, unlike traditional bank mortgages. The HKMA may ask banks to strengthen their risk management in the sector as the growth rate of these mortgages increases. The authority has been monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CWT, Vard, Tuan Sing, Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Infrastructure
summary: CWT and Vard Holdings made announcements after the market closed on Friday. CWT received a pre-conditional voluntary general cash offer from HNA Holding Group for S$2.33 per share, valuing CWT at S$1.4 billion. Vard Holdings won a contract for designing and constructing a live fish transportation vessel for Fjordlaks Aqua in Norway.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks little changed; healthcare stocks fall on report of govt share sale plan
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Monday, with the TAIEX index nearly unchanged at 9,869.86. The healthcare sector fell 1.14% after a government-run fund announced plans to sell its holdings in healthcare companies, citing the Economic Daily News. The National Development Fund will sell its holdings after market hours and via auctions. The electronics subindex was down 0.2%, while the financials subindex rose 0.2%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.668 per US dollar.

site_title: NY regulator wants other states to model cyber laws after its rules
summary: New York's financial regulator, Maria Vullo, urged US state insurance regulators to model their cyber security laws after New York's rules, which took effect on March 1. The regulations require insurers to protect their networks and disclose cyber events to state regulators. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners is developing a uniform cyber security law, with a draft expected by May 9. The aim is to create a consistent framework for the industry to focus on the threat of cyber security.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.14% to 24,302.01, despite a below-forecast US jobs report and uncertainty fueled by the US missile attack on Syria. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.15%. The gains were tempered by global market volatility and ongoing US trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.090 point to 1739.730. The index had a higher volume of 313.13 million lots worth RM63.7 million, with 245 gainers and 77 losers.

site_title: China to reduce planned power output of coal-fire power plants
summary: China plans to gradually reduce the power output of existing coal-fired generating plants, according to the National Development and Reform Commission. The move aims to promote reform and encourage power producers to sign contracts with clients. This step is part of China's efforts to transition away from coal-fired power and reduce its reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.80% to 18,814.07, driven by a weaker yen. Carmakers and exporters benefited from the currency's decline. The Topix index also increased 0.74%. The rally followed a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data, and despite US-EU trade talks and uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US also edged to fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: A dash of bugs with that? Insect-topped noodles sell out in Tokyo
summary: In Tokyo, a ramen restaurant sold out of "insect tsukemen" noodles within four hours of its single-day event. The dish featured deep-fried crickets and mealworms served with soups flavored with insects. The event aimed to promote alternative food culture in Japan and worldwide through ramen. Insects are consumed in various countries, including Japan, China, and Thailand, but are not commonly eaten in urban areas. The full course cost 3,000 yen and included insect ramen, rice, spring rolls, and ice cream. The event's organizer hopes to increase insect-eating awareness globally.

images.alt_text: Curious Japanese foodies queued up outside a Tokyo restaurant for a taste of a rare dish - ramen garnished with deep-fried worms and crickets.

site_title: LTA partners ST Kinetics to develop and trial autonomous buses
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has partnered with ST Kinetics to develop and trial autonomous buses in a 2.5-year project. Two 40-seater electric buses will be equipped with satellite-based GPS, sensors, radars, and sonars to detect surroundings and location. The autonomous buses will be deployed for fixed and scheduled services within and between towns. This partnership aims to integrate autonomous vehicle technology into Singapore's public transportation system, enhancing safety and efficiency.

site_title: Not chickening out of his dream
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Alson Teo's company, Stamfles Group, has developed the iKook, a patented, automated poultry cooker that can cook up to 10 birds in 40 minutes. The machine, conceptualized and assembled in Singapore, uses a touch screen and Japanese parts, and can cook various types of meats, including chicken and other Asian dishes. Teo aims to bring the iKook to the world, not just to grow chicken rice restaurants in Singapore, but to scale up the food and beverage business globally.

site_title: Australia shares hit near 2-year high as oil firms; NZ steady
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to a near two-year high, driven by higher oil and metal prices, despite regional weakness. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,901.7 points. Oil producers benefited from strong crude prices, while energy and material stocks gained support from strong commodity prices. New Zealand shares were steady, with the S&P/NZX 50 index remaining unchanged.

site_title: At strategic shoal, China asserts power through control, and concessions
summary: China maintains control over the Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea, despite a 2016 international ruling that deemed its blockade of the lagoon illegal. The country has eased restrictions, allowing Philippine boats to fish on the edges of the rocky outcrop and has even allowed foreign journalists to enter the shoal. However, tensions remain high, with concerns that China may have ambitions for the area similar to its artificial islands in the Spratly archipelago. The improved access is seen as a sign of China's willingness to coexist peacefully with the Philippines.

site_title: US officials say Russian inaction enabled Syria chemical attack
summary: US officials blame Russia for inaction enabling a deadly poison gas attack in Syria, which killed scores of people. Russia failed to secure and destroy chemical weapons in Syria as agreed in 2013, allowing the attack to occur. The US has taken retaliatory measures, and officials warn of further action if necessary. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says Russia's failure to live up to its commitments is the real failure, while National Security Adviser HR McMaster accuses Russia and its allies of enabling President Bashar al-Assad's "campaign of mass murder."

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.68 points or 0.05% to 3,177.27 on Monday, driven by a voluntary general cash offer by Hong Kong-listed HNA Holding Group to Singtel and CWT. 74.5 million shares worth S$72.2 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 77 to 64. The Straits Times Index reached a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Bet big in times of crisis: GCP Global's Gabriel Yap
summary: Veteran investor Gabriel Yap, executive chairman of GCP Global, advises investors to "bet big" during times of crisis, citing historical examples of significant market recoveries. He suggests investors must identify a market bottom before making a move, and notes that assets like real estate can provide substantial returns during such periods. Yap shares his own experience of investing in Australian dollar-denominated carpark buildings, which have seen a four-fold increase in value. He also expresses skepticism about a potential stock market crash, citing low interest rates and other indicators.

site_title: Sembcorp wins bid for 250MW wind-power project in India
summary: Sembcorp Industries won a bid for a 250MW wind-power project in India, valued at approximately 19 billion rupees (S$415 million). The project, located in Tamil Nadu, will be connected to India's central transmission utility and sold to the Power Trading Corporation under a 25-year power purchase agreement. The project is expected to be fully commissioned by March 31, 2019, and will not significantly impact Sembcorp's earnings per share or net asset value. This win brings Sembcorp's total power capacity in India to over 3,800MW.

site_title: Dancers remember Madonna's tour that shook pop world
summary: A documentary, "Strike a Pose," revisits the lives of seven dancers from Madonna's 1990 Blond Ambition tour, which sparked controversy due to its provocative imagery and themes. The dancers, six of whom were gay at the time, faced taboos and repercussions, including HIV positive dancers keeping their status secret. Thirty years later, the dancers have struggled with addiction, failed careers, and strained relationships with Madonna, who has maintained a grueling schedule. Despite this, some have found new paths and maturity, with one dancer saying, "There's life after Madonna."

site_title: Xi buys time with Trump as tensions loom over North Korea threat
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping met in Florida, marking a positive start to their relationship despite ongoing tensions, particularly over North Korea's nuclear threat. The two leaders agreed to "tread water" on key issues, including trade, currency, and security, and established a new negotiation framework to discuss economic and security concerns. Xi views the meeting as a win, particularly in a sensitive year for China's leadership, while Trump needs to show progress to his working-class base. A follow-up meeting and potential state visit by Trump to China are expected to determine the stability of the US-China relationship.

site_title: Hot stock: Unusual more than doubles from IPO price in trading debut
summary: UnUsUal Limited, a unit of mm2 Asia's events production arm, made a strong trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, with shares more than doubling to 45.5 Singapore cents. The firm, which organizes concerts and events, raised S$17.4 million in its IPO and plans to use the funds for expansion and production projects. The listing brings the Catalist's total firms to 191, with a combined market capitalization of over S$12 billion. The move is seen as an opportunity for investors to tap into the region's growing entertainment and lifestyle industry.

site_title: Google offers at least 1t won to LG Display for OLED investment
summary: Google has offered to invest at least 1 trillion won (S$1.24 billion) to LG Display to boost OLED screen production for its smartphones. The investment aims to secure a stable supply of flexible OLED screens for the next Pixel smartphones. This move comes as Samsung's Galaxy smartphones and Apple's iPhones are expected to use bendable displays. LG Display declined to comment on the offer, while Google was unable to be reached for immediate comment. The investment is part of Google's efforts to secure reliable suppliers for its high-end devices.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices near peak as risks mount, JPMorgan says
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is near its peak and economically unsustainable, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co's Asia Pacific equity research unit. Home prices have outpaced the city's GDP growth since 2009, and a bubble bursting could lead to increased borrowing costs and losses for buyers. The market is being driven by wealthy individuals leveraging their assets and parents' homes as collateral, and the government is considering ways to curb the rally in home prices, including increasing supply by selling public flats.

site_title: Food fight: To beat China fakes, NZ and Australian produce firms raid tech larder
summary: New Zealand and Australian food firms are using anti-counterfeiting technology to protect their exports from China. The move comes as the global food industry loses an estimated $40 billion annually to counterfeiting. Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba has launched a blockchain-based tracing system in partnership with Kiwi dairy giant Fonterra and Australian vitamin supplier Blackmores. Suppliers are using tracking systems, codes, and powders to combat fakes, and apps like WeChat are being used to scan products and verify authenticity.

site_title: Stockholm suspect, IS sympathiser who 'partied and drank': media
summary: A 39-year-old Uzbek construction worker and father-of-four, believed to have IS sympathies, is the main suspect in the Stockholm truck attack that killed four people and injured 15 others. The suspect, identified as Rakhmat Akilov, fled the scene and was later arrested at a petrol station convenience store after raising suspicions. He allegedly confessed to the crime, saying he was "pleased with what he had done" and had "accomplished what he set out to do". Akilov had been living in Sweden without a permanent residency permit and had shown sympathies for extremist organizations, including IS.

site_title: State of emergency in Egypt after IS church bombings kill 44
summary: Egypt declared a three-month state of emergency after twin church bombings by the Islamic State group killed 44 people, mostly Coptic Christians, on Palm Sunday. The bombings in Tanta and Alexandria followed a Cairo church bombing in December and came weeks before a planned visit by Catholic Pope Francis. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi vowed to take action against the jihadists, while IS claimed responsibility for the attacks and threatened further violence.

site_title: UK consumer spending grows at slowest rate in 3 years: Visa
summary: British consumer spending increased at the slowest annual pace in over three years, growing 0.9% year-on-year in the first quarter of 2017, according to Visa. This is the weakest calendar-quarter performance since 2013. Spending dropped 0.7% in March, following a flat February. Rising inflation, partly caused by the post-Brexit pound tumble, is squeezing household purchasing power, with 46% of households planning to cut back on spending.

site_title: "Harry Potter" triumphs with magical sweep at Olivier Awards
summary: The stage adaptation of "Harry Potter And The Cursed Child" won nine Olivier Awards, including best new play, best actor, and best director, making it the most decorated production in the ceremony's history. The play, which follows the story of Harry Potter and his friends into adulthood, took home awards for best lighting design, best sound design, and best set design. Director John Tiffany and actor Jamie Parker were among the winners, with Tiffany stating "the power of imagination is infinite" and Parker praising the play's magical sweep.

site_title: China says insurance regulator head probed for suspected graft
summary: China's insurance regulator head, Xiang Junbo, is under investigation for suspected disciplinary violations, according to the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. The ruling Communist Party's anti-corruption watchdog described the suspected violations as "serious". No further details were provided. This development marks a significant move against corruption within the Chinese government and regulatory bodies.

site_title: Spain's first female defence minister, Carmen Chacon, dies at 46
summary: Spain's first female defence minister, Carmen Chacon, died at 46. Chacon, a former Socialist party leadership contender, served as defence minister from 2008 to 2011. Her death comes after she narrowly lost the party leadership in 2011. The cause of death has not been confirmed, but reports suggest she had been suffering from heart disease. The Socialist party mourned her death, describing it as a "premature departure".

site_title: Major protest in Hungary over Soros university law
summary: Tens of thousands of Hungarians protested against a new higher education law seen as targeting the Central European University, a respected institution founded by billionaire George Soros in the 1990s. The law bars institutions outside the EU from awarding Hungarian diplomas without an agreement with national governments, a condition not met by the CEU, which is registered in the US. The legislation has attracted widespread criticism, including from the US State Department and academics, and has been described by protesters as an attack on Soros and democracy.

images.alt_text: Hungary saw the biggest anti-government protest in three years on Sunday, as tens of thousands demonstrated against new higher education legislation seen as targeting the respected Central European University.

site_title: Corn sags, soyabeans post longest weekly skid in 30 months
summary: US corn futures hit a one-week low, settling down 11/4 cents at US$3.591/2 per bushel, amid expectations of rising grain inventories and big South American crops. Soybean futures posted their longest weekly decline in 30 months, falling 1/2 cent to US$9.42 a bushel, due to rising global supplies and favorable weather prospects for Brazilian soybean harvests. Wheat prices ended little changed.

site_title: Stuck in a trading range - for now
summary: US military strikes in Syria and a mediocre US payrolls report have led to a trading range in markets, with investors factoring in geopolitical risk. The French presidential elections, particularly a potential win by Marine Le Pen, pose a risk to European markets, with estimates suggesting bond yields could rise and equities might fall by 10%. The Federal Reserve's minutes also raised concerns about two more rate hikes this year, but the Atlanta Fed's GDP model suggests a lacklustre Q1, potentially limiting rate hikes.

site_title: Oil prices firm on strong demand, political uncertainty in Syria
summary: Oil prices remained firm on Monday due to strong demand and ongoing political uncertainty in Syria, supporting Brent crude futures at $55.28 per barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $52.34 per barrel, despite US drilling activity increasing for the 12th consecutive week. The rising US production, coupled with OPEC's supply cuts, has led to a deeper discount for US crude, potentially supporting exports to Asia. However, the US will remain a small player in the Asian market, according to BMI Research.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were firm on Monday, supported by strong demand and political uncertainty in Syria, although another rise in US drilling activity kept a lid on gains.

site_title: US stock indexes may make another run for records
summary: US stock indexes may continue their upward trend this week, driven by bank earnings reports and President Trump's foreign policy moves, particularly the military response to the Syrian government's use of sarin gas. The US jobs market lost steam in March, but the unemployment rate remains low, and expectations of a rate hike have increased. Strategists say a crisis of confidence in "Trump trades" could end in losses for investors in financial, materials, and industrials sectors, but a near-decade of listless profit growth could give way to a new boom if borrowing rates rise and compliance costs fall.

site_title: London to crack down on traffic pollution
summary: London is cracking down on traffic pollution, with Mayor Sadiq Khan introducing plans to charge £24 per day for diesel cars and older petrol vehicles entering central London by 2019. The move aims to reduce nitrogen dioxide emissions, a major contributor to pollution, which causes over 9,000 premature deaths per year in the city. The issue is not limited to London, with over 40,000 British deaths attributed to outdoor air pollution annually, and many nurseries and schools located near polluted roads.

site_title: South Europe leaders to seek stronger EU after Brexit shock
summary: Leaders from southern European countries, including Spain, France, Italy, Portugal, Greece, Cyprus, and Malta, will meet in Madrid to show unity and support for greater EU integration following the UK's Brexit decision. The meeting, held at El Pardo palace, aims to launch a message of unity and commitment to European integration. The gathering comes as the EU faces a significant challenge in the wake of the UK's departure, with leaders seeking to strengthen the bloc's unity and cohesion.

site_title: A booze ban stresses Indian business
summary: India's Supreme Court has banned the sale of alcohol within 500 meters of highways, affecting thousands of liquor outlets, bars, and hotels in the country. The ruling aims to curb drink driving, but has also disrupted the booming alcohol industry, which is expected to grow by 6% annually. Many businesses, including hotels and restaurants catering to tourists, have been forced to close or restrict services, with some finding creative ways to circumvent the ban. The ban has hit share prices of listed alcohol makers and caused financial losses for businesses.

site_title: AA Group warrants: unique because they're not listed
summary: AA Group, a Malaysian company specializing in cold forging technology, issued unlisted warrants as part of a 10-for-one rights issue. The warrants, which have an exercise price of S$0.012, have already been exercised by 246.6 million warrant holders, resulting in S$2.96 million in net proceeds for the company. The warrants are not traded, allowing holders to exit only through exercise, providing a fresh injection of cash for the company. The exercise price is below the current market price of S$0.037, making it a lucrative opportunity for some warrant owners.

site_title: Le Pen says France not responsible for WWII round up of Jews
summary: Marine Le Pen denied France's responsibility for the 1942 round-up of Jews at the Vel d'Hiv cycling track, saying those in power at the time were accountable. The comments sparked criticism from centrist rival Emmanuel Macron and French Jewish organizations, who described them as "revisionist" and an "insult to France." Le Pen claimed France was based in London during the Nazi occupation and that the Vichy regime, which collaborated with Nazi Germany, was "illegal."

site_title: Young directors take top prize at Hong Kong Film Awards
summary: Three emerging directors, Frank Hui, Jevons Au, and Vicky Wong, won top prizes at the Hong Kong Film Awards for their crime drama "Trivisa." The film, set in 1997, received five awards, including best film and best director, beating out veterans like Stephen Chow and Johnnie To. The film's political themes were seen as reflecting anxiety over Hong Kong's future, following controversy over mainland Chinese sites blocking news of the film's wins last year.

site_title: Trump lowers tone on China, remains at odds on North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump's two-day summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping at his Florida villa was deemed a success despite little concrete action. The meeting addressed trade differences, with China agreeing to a 100-day plan to address trade imbalances and participate in China's "One Belt, One Road" project. However, the talks were overshadowed by US air strikes against Syria and Trump's continued hawkish stance on North Korea, with analysts suggesting that the summit set the stage for healthier bilateral relations.

site_title: Carriers brace for US$60 billion fuel shock
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) will enforce stricter sulfur emission rules in 2020, requiring ships to reduce sulfur content from 3.5% to 0.5%. This will result in a $60 billion annual fuel cost increase for the global merchant fleet, potentially disrupting shipments and trade. Only 2.2% of ships will have scrubbers installed by 2020, and oil refiners are struggling to meet demand for lower-sulfur fuels. A transition period is likely to be implemented to mitigate the impact on the shipping industry.

site_title: Gender diversity: supply or demand?
summary: Singapore's efforts to boost gender diversity on corporate boards have been slow, with women holding just 9.6% of board seats as of 2016. Despite initiatives to raise awareness, the pace of change has been sluggish. Debates center on whether it's a supply or demand issue, with some arguing that there's a lack of qualified women, while others point to lukewarm demand from existing boards. Experts propose measures to address the "old boys' network" and improve board renewal, and the government has set targets of 20% women on boards by 2020 and 25% by 2025.

site_title: US$ extends gains on Dudley remarks, C$ strengthens
summary: The US dollar strengthened against most major peers after New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley commented on the pace of interest-rate increases, erasing initial losses. The Canadian dollar also rose against the greenback, boosted by stronger-than-expected domestic jobs data. Canada added 19,400 jobs in March, marking the fourth month of job growth, but economists doubt the Bank of Canada will drop its cautious tone this week. The Canadian dollar ended at C$1.3410 to the US dollar, slightly stronger than Thursday's close.

site_title: OCBC, UOB waive fees for withdrawals from each other's ATMs
summary: OCBC and UOB have waived fees for customers to withdraw cash from each other's ATMs in Singapore, available since 1988. The promotion, which ends on December 31, aims to increase usage by at least 10%. The two banks reported a 30% increase in cross-bank transactions over the last decade, with over five million transactions in 2016. This move is part of a broader effort to increase awareness of the shared ATM network service, which also benefits other banks in Singapore.

site_title: YTL in expansion mode, eyes acquisitions
summary: YTL Hotels, a hospitality arm of Malaysian conglomerate YTL Corporation, is expanding its portfolio by acquiring assets to be injected into the global hospitality Reit. The company is targeting "first-world" markets with prime locations and values assets that can be enhanced through asset enhancement and partnering with international brands like Marriott. YTL Hotels has already acquired properties in the UK and is focusing on Malaysia, with plans to open new hotels and renovate existing ones. The company aims for 20% growth in turnover and profit annually, and is exploring opportunities in Europe and Japan.

site_title: India woos Bangladesh with defence loan, credit
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi offered $4.5 billion in concessional loans to Bangladesh, and $500 million for defence procurement, during a visit by Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. This move aims to strengthen ties between the two nations, amid growing competition from China. Despite progress in other areas, a long-standing dispute over the Teesta river's water sharing remains unresolved. Modi also announced a documentary on the 1971 War of Liberation of Bangladesh, likely to irk Pakistan.

site_title: Once a Trump critic, Haley casts herself as his top diplomat
summary: US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley has carved out a significant role in the Trump administration, pushing for tougher stances on issues like Syria and Russia. She has become a leading voice on US diplomacy, making key statements and warning of potential unilateral action. Haley's office drafts policies and sends them to Washington for clearance, and she has been praised by some for her pragmatism and courage. However, her lack of foreign policy experience and sometimes thin substance on key issues have raised questions about her qualifications and motivations.

site_title: Time for Rooney to move on
summary: Wayne Rooney, Manchester United's long-time talisman, is facing an uncertain future at Old Trafford. Despite being 31, Rooney's injury-plagued campaign has reduced him to a fringe player, with younger teammates taking over major roles. Rooney's performances have been average and inconsistent, and his lack of first-team appearances has raised questions about his motivation. With England manager Gareth Southgate still open to him, Rooney may need to move to another club to regain his form and justify his continued involvement with the national team.

site_title: Buying stays flat, selling falls
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Buying activity remained flat for the second straight week, with 17 companies making purchases worth S$2.17 million. Selling activity, however, decreased significantly, with only six companies making disposals worth S$0.24 million. The bulk of significant trades were purchases, including by directors of AnnAik, iFast Corporation, and Kimly Limited. Insider acquisitions were also recorded, including by Nordic Group and United Industrial Corporation. The buys and sells were largely driven by the companies' share price movements, with many trades being made at prices higher than the companies' IPO prices. The buyback activity was flat for the second week.

site_title: Failed Pepsi, Nivea ads show industry's diversity problem
summary: Pepsi and Nivea's failed advertising campaigns have sparked criticism over the industry's diversity problem. The "Moments" Pepsi spot, featuring Kendall Jenner, was pulled after being criticized for trivializing the "Black Lives Matter" movement. Nivea's "White is Purity" ad was also met with backlash, with white supremacists embracing it. Industry data shows a diversity deficit, with only 4.1% of advertising industry employees being African American. Major advertisers have threatened to fire firms that aren't diverse enough, and the industry's lack of diversity has been compared to the "white male bubble" of the 1960s.

site_title: US carrier group diverted to Western Pacific amid Korean peninsula tensions
summary: The US Navy has diverted the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier group to the Western Pacific amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula due to North Korea's nuclear program. The strike group, including guided-missile destroyers and a cruiser, will operate near the Korean peninsula, with the US Pacific Command citing North Korea as the main threat. The move comes as US President Donald Trump warned North Korea of potential action over its nuclear program, following a recent ballistic missile test. The strike group's deployment was reportedly planned before the recent tensions escalated.

site_title: Observers laud S'pore's food, nutrition potential
summary: Singapore is seen as a prime location to become Asia's food and nutrition hub, with its existing industry capabilities, infrastructure, and multicultural diversity giving it an advantage. Global companies such as Symrise have set up regional innovation bases in the country, leveraging its sensory and consumer insights research capabilities. However, observers say more needs to be done to develop a viable pipeline of skilled talent and build a food innovation ecosystem, with government, research organisations, and companies needing to collaborate closely to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: Singapore has the winning recipe to become a food and nutrition hub in the region, but some key ingredients are still missing from the mix.

site_title: London finance chief upbeat after Brexit trigger
summary: London's financial sector chief, Mark Boleat, remains optimistic about the city's outlook despite the Brexit trigger, urging speedy trade talks to minimize disruption. Banks have contingency plans to shift jobs to other European hubs, but many will not close operations in London, according to Boleat. Historic insurance market Lloyd's of London has announced plans to open a Brussels subsidiary, while euro clearing is expected to remain in London due to its expertise and market presence.

site_title: HNA offers just under S$1.4b to buy out CWT
summary: HNA Holding Group is acquiring Singapore-listed logistics company CWT for approximately S$1.4 billion, with shareholders holding over 65% agreeing to accept the offer. The deal, valued at S$2.33 per share, is subject to regulatory hurdles and shareholder approval. CWT's senior management team will retain their positions for three years under the new ownership. The acquisition is expected to enhance HNA's logistics services and expand its presence in the industry.

site_title: Trump's building promises boost prices of lumber
summary: US lumber futures prices are rising due to strong demand from millennial homebuyers and low mortgage rates. The National Association of Home Builders reports a surge in new homes available and sales, with home builders increasing their orders for raw materials. With US mortgage rates still near historic lows, buyers are eager to purchase homes now rather than wait for potential future rate hikes. Additionally, President Trump's trade policies, particularly his push for a new North America Free Trade Agreement, could further boost lumber prices by limiting Canadian lumber imports.

site_title: French govt enshrines decision to close country's oldest nuclear plant
summary: The French government has published a decree to close the country's oldest nuclear plant, Fessenheim, near the border with Germany, as part of a plan to reduce France's dependence on atomic energy. The closure will occur when a new reactor at Flamanville, currently under construction, "enters service". President Francois Hollande, who is leaving office, had promised to close Fessenheim during his 2012 campaign, aiming to reduce nuclear energy from 75% to 50% of France's energy mix. The closure is part of a broader effort to boost renewable energy.

images.alt_text: Protesters demonstrating on April 6 in front of EDF's Paris headquarters against the closing of the Fessenheim nuclear power plant. The move is part of a plan to slash France's dependence on atomic energy.

site_title: Trump's charm offensive has US unions divided
summary: US President Donald Trump's charm offensive has divided US unions, with some supporting his push for blue-collar issues like infrastructure spending and tariffs. Trump has championed issues like keeping jobs overseas, promising $1 trillion in infrastructure spending, and threatening a 35% tariff on Mexican imports. This aligns with Reagan's strategy to win over blue-collar voters in Midwestern swing states. Trump's efforts aim to secure a lasting Republican majority.

site_title: Hamilton roars to victory in F1 opener in China
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his fifth Chinese Grand Prix win, defeating Sebastian Vettel by six seconds in the Formula One season opener. Hamilton started on pole and maintained his lead throughout, with Vettel recovering from a poor start to finish second. Max Verstappen took third after early safety car drama. The result marked Hamilton's swift revenge after his loss to Vettel in the season opener in Melbourne two weeks ago.

site_title: China tightens collateral rules involving corporate bonds amid rising defaults
summary: China has published rules barring the use of lower-rated corporate bonds as collateral in short-term borrowing to reduce financial risks amid rising defaults. The rules, effective April 8, apply to repurchase agreements in the exchange bond market and exclude bonds rated below AAA. The move aims to strengthen risk controls and promote stable market development. China has witnessed a surge in corporate bond defaults due to economic slowdown and the government's economic restructuring efforts, with over 5.5 trillion yuan of debts due in 2017.

site_title: Unlike 10 years ago, bull markets don't mean extra Wall Street jobs
summary: Bull markets in the US stock market are not translating into job creation as they once did. Despite record profits on Wall Street, job growth has slowed, unlike a decade ago. The financial crisis and Great Recession may be contributing factors.

images.alt_text: Mr Dudley says the securities industry is not really contributing to growth in the number of jobs.

site_title: Sampling the future of food innovation in Singapore
summary: Singapore is witnessing a surge in food innovation, with companies seeking assistance from institutes of higher learning and consultancies to transform their food services and manufacturing businesses. Concepts such as zero manpower interaction, 3D printing of food, and meal kit subscription boxes are being explored. Industry players believe that automation will not lead to job displacement, but rather relieve workers to focus on higher-value tasks. Trends such as efficient cooking methods, extended shelf-life products, and alternative dining formats are also emerging, with some companies investing in recycling food waste and developing new products from by-products.

site_title: Britain plans to identify foreign owners of UK properties
summary: The UK government plans to create a public register of foreign owners of UK properties, aiming to increase transparency and curb foreign investment that prices out local buyers. The register, to be launched by 2018, will require overseas investors to disclose beneficial owners. International buyers, particularly from Asia and the Middle East, have been blamed for driving up prices in London, with 60% of prime homes sold to overseas buyers in 2016. The move is seen as a response to concerns of money laundering and the diversion of funds to lower-priced properties outside London.

site_title: 40 bucks, 40 years and proof that Chase CEO Jamie Dimon is right
summary: A writer's $40 investment in a Detroit bank stock in 1974 has grown to nearly 100 times its original value after 43 years, with a 100-to-1 return on investment. This is attributed to reinvesting dividends, starting in 1999, which increased the writer's stake in the bank to 44 shares of Chase. The writer's investment outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, rising 2,700% compared to the 1,208% gain of the S&P 500 during the same period.

site_title: New SIAS chair aims to grow investor activism, education
summary: Magnus Bocker, the new honorary chairman of the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), aims to grow investor activism and education. He will focus on growing investor advocacy and board accountability, while also addressing the challenge of securing funding. Bocker's three-year tenure will mainly support SIAS President and CEO David Gerald, with his role focusing on supporting the CEO rather than taking the lead.

site_title: Failed Pepsi, Nivea ads show industry's diversity problem
summary: PepsiCo and Nivea recently faced backlash for advertising missteps that highlighted the industry's diversity problem. Pepsi's "Moments" ad featuring Kendall Jenner was criticized for trivializing the "Black Lives Matter" movement, while Nivea's "White is Purity" ad was embraced by white supremacists. Industry data shows a significant diversity deficit, with only 4.1% of advertising employees being African American. Many advertisers, including Verizon and General Mills, have threatened to fire firms that aren't diverse enough, with the American Association of Advertising Agencies calling for more inclusive hiring practices.

site_title: Indonesia's police kill six suspected Islamic militants
summary: Indonesian police killed six suspected IS-linked militants in a gunfight on Java island after a group of seven men fired shots at a traffic police post, sparking a car chase. The attackers were part of the Jamaah Ansharut Daulah network, blamed for recent attacks in Indonesia. One militant was arrested alive, and police claim the others died in a shootout.
