The incident is the latest in a series of foiled IS-linked plots in Indonesia, which have weakened the country's militant networks.

site_title: Where non-techies can get with the programming
summary: Georgetown University Law Center has expanded its computer programming course, now offering five classes with a waitlist of over 130 students. The program teaches law students to write tailored programs that can analyze Supreme Court rulings more accurately than Google searches or standard software. The skills gained through programming are seen as valuable for lawyers, making them better equipped to analyze complex legal data. The program is an example of the growing recognition of programming skills in non-tech fields, with potential applications beyond law.

site_title: Trump national security aide McFarland may become envoy to Singapore: official
summary: President Donald Trump's deputy national security adviser, K.T. McFarland, may become the US ambassador to Singapore, according to a US official. This move comes as Trump's national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, is putting his stamp on the team. McFarland's departure follows the resignation of retired General Michael Flynn as Trump's first national security adviser in February. The expected appointment is part of Trump's efforts to reshape his national security team.

site_title: Vard wins live fish vessel order
summary: VARD Holdings has won a contract to design and construct a live fish transportation vessel for Fjordlaks Aqua in Norway. The vessel will be built in Romania and delivered in the third quarter of 2018. This contract aligns with VARD's strategy to expand its services for the aquaculture business, and Fjordlaks Aqua expects the vessel to help with in-house control of its operations. The deal is seen as a major importance for Fjordlaks Aqua, with its CEO expressing appreciation for VARD's cooperation.

site_title: Greece to cut corporate tax in 2020 if fiscal targets exceeded
summary: Greece agreed with international creditors on a plan to cut corporate tax by 3 percentage points to 26% in 2020 if it meets fiscal targets, including a 3.5% budget surplus in 2018. The deal includes tax reforms and spending cuts, including a 1% reduction in government pensions and a 2 percentage-point cut in income tax for low- and middle-income taxpayers. The reforms aim to generate additional revenue and boost the economy if budget targets are exceeded.

site_title: HNA offers to buy out CWT
summary: HNA Holding Group has made a pre-conditional voluntary general cash offer (VGO) for all issued and paid-up ordinary shares in Singapore-listed CWT, valued at S$2.33 per share, totaling S$1.4 billion. The offer is subject to several pre-conditions, including shareholder approval and a 90% acceptance rate. CWT shareholders representing 65.13% have extended irrevocable written undertakings to the offer. The long-stop date for the VGO is September 9, 2017.

site_title: UPS buys first used Boeing 767s as new ones are out of reach
summary: UPS has purchased its first used Boeing 767s as the company struggles to acquire new planes due to production delays. The three 767-300ERs, originally ordered in 1993, will be converted to carry freight and deployed globally. The purchase was made "within the past couple of days" and the cost was not disclosed. This move is part of UPS's plan to invest in capacity for growth, following the recent order of 14 Boeing 747 jumbo jets. The acquisition is also seen as a response to the increasing demand for package shipments worldwide.

site_title: Motor racing-Hamilton wins in China
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Chinese Formula One Grand Prix, his 54th career win, by 6.2 seconds ahead of Sebastian Vettel. Hamilton's victory returned Mercedes to the top of the podium after Vettel's win in Australia. Hamilton, who started from pole position, navigated changing track conditions to take the lead, while Max Verstappen finished third for Red Bull.

site_title: Collective action to meet community needs sustainably
summary: Credit Suisse has adopted a collective impact approach to address community needs sustainably. By partnering with public institutions, non-profit organizations, and corporations, the bank aims to create lasting social impact and address complex issues in a scalable and sustainable manner. The "collective impact" model involves collaboration among various stakeholders to fund and drive programs that address social challenges. Credit Suisse has launched a collaborative platform called CoLABS to bring about scalable impact and create innovation solutions, and has partnered with the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre and Community Foundation of Singapore to provide education for disadvantaged children.

images.alt_text: Representatives from 38 organizations at a children and youth CoLABS session, which enables companies to deepen their understanding about education needs and bring about scalable impact.

site_title: China tightens collateral rules involving corporate bonds amid rising defaults
summary: China has published rules barring the use of lower-rated corporate bonds as collateral in short-term borrowing to reduce financial risks amid rising defaults. Starting April 8, bonds rated below AAA won't be used in repurchase agreements, affecting newly-issued bonds. The rules aim to strengthen risk controls and promote stable market development. China's corporate bond defaults have surged due to economic slowdown and restructuring efforts, with $797.36 billion in debts due in 2017. The rules may make borrowing more difficult in the exchange bond market, aligning with Beijing's efforts to reduce deleverage and ward off asset price bubbles.

site_title: Brexit repercussions
summary: Brexit's impact on London's global financial centre is uncertain, but the City of London's resilience is expected to prevail. John Bittleston, founder of Terrific Mentors International, believes the UK's 65 million population and strong consumer base will enable successful trade agreements. Singapore businesses and investors may also benefit from the shift, as London's financial hub could attract more investment. However, the UK's economic slowdown poses a challenge, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row, further affecting the country's global standing.

site_title: New HK leader's affordable homes plan runs up against wall of Chinese capital
summary: Hong Kong's incoming leader Carrie Lam aims to make the city's property prices more affordable by increasing housing and land supply. However, her plan faces significant challenges from mainland Chinese developers, who are bidding up land prices and pushing out local developers. Chinese companies have dominated land deals in Hong Kong, accounting for 44% of total transactions in the fiscal year starting April 2016. This influx of capital makes it difficult for Lam's government to control housing prices, with prices in areas like Kai Tak rising by as much as 50% in less than a year.

site_title: At US-China summit, Trump presses Xi on trade, North Korea; progress cited
summary: US President Donald Trump pressed Chinese President Xi Jinping to curb North Korea's nuclear program and reduce the US trade deficit during their summit. Trump expressed progress on various issues, including a 100-day plan for trade talks aimed at boosting US exports and reducing China's trade surplus. Xi agreed to cooperate on North Korea, but no new formula was proposed. Trump also discussed China's activities in the South China Sea, and both leaders emphasized a positive mood, despite deep differences.

site_title: Uber smartphone apps provisionally banned in Italy
summary: An Italian court has provisionally banned the use of Uber smartphone apps in Italy, citing unfair competition with traditional taxis. The ban, subject to appeal, gives Uber 10 days to end the use of its apps and stop promoting them on Italian territory. Failure to comply could result in a fine of 10,000 euros per day. Uber has stated it will appeal the ruling, seeking suspension of the ban. This ruling follows similar bans in Milan and Turin, which deemed UberPop applications as encouraging unlicensed taxi services.

site_title: A treasure chest of Chinese literature beneath the Spanish moss of Florida
summary: A 92-acre property in Florida's gulf coast, once the home of a 48-year-old scholar, Elling O Eide, has been transformed into a vast library of Chinese literature. Eide, a voracious collector, amassed 75,000 volumes, including 50,000 in Chinese, to create one of the largest private Chinese-language libraries in the world. After his death in 2012, his cousin Harold Mitchell oversaw the completion of the library and visitor center, which opened in 2022 for the annual conference of the T'ang Studies Society. The library's collection poses a challenge, as it lacks a university specializing in Chinese studies, but its trustees plan to establish a fellowship for researchers to visit and stay on the grounds.

site_title: US unemployment rate near 10-year low, but job creation falters
summary: The US unemployment rate fell to 4.5% in March, its lowest level in nearly 10 years, but job creation tumbled unexpectedly, adding only 98,000 net new positions. This fell short of analyst expectations and blunted the previous month's surge in job creation. Despite a decrease in the long-term unemployed, economists say the US is not yet at full employment, and the low unemployment rate could lead to higher inflation.

site_title: Beijing to release more land for 1.5m homes: Xinhua
summary: Beijing plans to release 6,000 hectares of land by 2021 to meet demand for 1.5 million residential housing units, with 1,200 hectares supplied this year. 70% of the land will be used for homes with property rights, while 30% for rental homes. The move aims to alleviate pressure from soaring home prices and inventory overhang in smaller cities, as urged by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang.

site_title: Japan, US move to fend off China bids for Toshiba
summary: US and Japanese authorities are working to prevent China from acquiring Toshiba's key nuclear power and electronics sector technologies. Toshiba's US nuclear unit Westinghouse has filed for bankruptcy, while its flash memory business is seeking investors. The Trump administration is blocking Chinese bids for Westinghouse and Toshiba's flash memory business, citing concerns over China's global acquisition strategy. Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe has signaled approval of the US stance, and talks are underway about forming a public-private partnership to buy a stake in Toshiba's flash memory business.

site_title: Russia warns of serious consequences from US strike in Syria
summary: Russia warned of "extremely serious" consequences from US cruise missile strikes on a Syrian air base, amid a rift between Moscow and Washington. The strikes targeted the Shayrat air base, allegedly involved in a chemical attack that killed at least 70 people. Russia has advisers on the ground aiding Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and US officials informed Russian forces ahead of the missile strikes. The US aims to deter future chemical attacks, while Russia calls the strike "illegitimate" and a threat to regional stability.

site_title: Adidas to mass-produce 3D-printed shoe with Silicon Valley start-up
summary: Adidas partnered with a Silicon Valley start-up to mass-produce a 3D-printed shoe, with plans to launch the new sneaker next year. The shoe features a customized sole designed to fit an individual's weight and gait, making small production runs and limited edition shoes more economical. This marks Adidas' push to react faster to changing fashions and create more customized products, a trend also adopted by rival companies Nike, Under Armour, and New Balance, who have primarily used 3D printing for prototypes and specialty shoes.

site_title: 20 killed in Myanmar wedding boat crash
summary: At least 20 people were killed in a boat crash in western Myanmar on Friday, with 16 women and 4 men confirmed dead. The boat, carrying 60-80 guests, collided with a river barge in the middle of the river and sank, with 30 people rescued alive. A search operation is ongoing, with 9 people still missing. The accident is the latest in a series of fatal boat accidents in Myanmar, where many people rely on overcrowded ferries for transport.

site_title: Swedish police arrest second man after Stockholm attack: SVT
summary: Swedish police have arrested a second man connected to the Stockholm truck attack, which killed four and injured 15 people. The arrest was made in the northern suburb of Hjulsta, and the suspect is believed to be linked to the first man arrested earlier on Friday. The Swedish public broadcaster SVT reported the arrest, citing police sources.

site_title: Trump explained US position on Thaad to Xi: South Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump informed South Korean Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-Ahn of his discussion with Chinese President Xi Jinping about the deployment of the US-supplied Thaad anti-missile defense system in South Korea. China has opposed the deployment, citing it could threaten its security, but South Korea and the US say it's aimed at countering North Korea's missile threat.

site_title: Dalai Lama visits disputed monastery, angering China
summary: The Dalai Lama visited a disputed monastery in Tawang, Arunachal Pradesh, India, drawing protests from China, which claims the Himalayan area as its territory. The 81-year-old monk addressed devotees on his last possible visit, amid a diplomatic row between China and India. The visit has heightened tensions between the two countries, with China viewing the event as a challenge to its sovereignty. The Dalai Lama has taken shelter at the monastery since fleeing Tibet. The visit has sparked widespread protests in China, with Beijing urging India to refrain from allowing the Dalai Lama to address devotees.

site_title: Australia appoints former spy boss to advise on foreign investment
summary: Australia has appointed David Irvine, former director of the domestic spy agency, as chairman of its foreign investment advisory committee. Irvine will advise the government on investment policy and administration, including vetting bids for critical infrastructure. His appointment comes after the government blocked foreign firms bidding for critical infrastructure assets on national security grounds, citing risks from a more assertive China and cyber attacks. The move strengthens the national security side of foreign investment decisions, amid growing concerns over the security implications of foreign investment in Australian infrastructure assets.

site_title: Headcount at China's four biggest banks shrinks as payments move online
summary: China's four largest banks, ICBC, China Construction Bank, Agricultural Bank of China, and Bank of China, reduced their workforce by 17,824 in 2016, marking the first decline in six years. This shift reflects the banks' efforts to adapt to online payment giants Ant Financial and Tencent Holdings, with over 84% of transactions completed outside brick-and-mortar branches. The banks aim to trim their estimated three million branch network employees by 20% over the next decade, focusing on ATMs, online banking, and AI services.

site_title: US threatens further strikes in Syria
summary: The US has threatened to launch further strikes in Syria after a missile attack that infuriated Russia and fueled calls for a diplomatic solution to the six-year war. The US strike, which destroyed a Syrian airfield, was launched to punish an alleged chemical attack by Bashar al-Assad's regime. Russia has declared the strike a violation of international law and an "act of aggression." US Ambassador Nikki Haley warned that the US is prepared to do more, but hopes it won't be necessary. The UN Secretary-General has urged restraint and a renewed push for peace in Syria.

site_title: Shocked Stockholm eerily silent after truck attack
summary: A truck plowed into a crowd outside a department store in Stockholm's city centre, killing four people and injuring 15. The attack occurred just before 3:00pm local time and was described as a "terror attack" by police and Prime Minister Stefan Lofven. Witnesses reported seeing the truck slam into the corner of the store and the pedestrian street Drottninggatan, with several bodies lying on the ground covered in orange blankets. Despite the chaos, Stockholm's residents appeared to be following police advice to stay indoors and avoid crowded areas, with the city's central streets and squares blocked off.

site_title: Update: Four killed by truck driven into crowd in Swedish capital
summary: A truck hijacked by a masked hijacker ploughed into a crowd on a shopping street in central Stockholm, killing four people and wounding 15 in what the Prime Minister described as a terrorist attack. Police detained one suspect, who was ordered arrested on suspicion of terror crime, and a second man was also arrested with a connection to the first. Security at Swedish borders was heightened, and the attack was condemned by European leaders. This incident follows a series of attacks in Europe using vehicles to target crowds, and Sweden has not seen a large-scale attack in recent years.

images.alt_text: A truck ploughed into a crowd on a shopping street and crashed into a department store in central Stockholm on Friday, killing 4 people and wounding 15.

site_title: US: Wall Street down after weak jobs, Fed comments, Syria airstrikes
summary: US stocks declined on Friday as investors reacted to a weaker-than-expected job report, comments from the Federal Reserve, and the US airstrike in Syria. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite ended lower, with the Dow down 6.85 points and the S&P 500 losing 1.95 points. The US unemployment rate fell, but wage growth was slower than expected. The airstrikes in Syria may delay other issues and programs, according to analysts, who are also questioning the feasibility of President Trump's pro-business agenda.

site_title: New York Fed's Dudley supports reconsidering key banking rules
summary: New York Fed President William Dudley suggests reconsidering key banking rules, including the Volcker Rule and annual stress tests, as the financial crisis has passed nearly a decade ago. He proposes easing smaller-bank regulations and giving larger banks more discretion in trading. Dudley also suggests revamping a Dodd-Frank Act requirement that subjects banks with over $50 billion in assets to stringent oversight. These comments come as the Trump administration works to reduce banking regulations and dismantle some of the Dodd-Frank rules.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by oil stocks after US strike in Syria
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Friday, reversing earlier weakness, driven by oil stocks and precious metal miners benefiting from a surge in gold prices following a US cruise missile strike in Syria. Energy stocks surged to their highest level in 10 weeks, with majors BP, Total, and Royal Dutch Shell up around 1%. Precious metals miners, including Randgold Resources and Fresnillo, also gained, while real estate stocks reached fresh six-month highs.

site_title: US dollar net longs fall to five-week low
summary: The US dollar rose to three-week highs after a Federal Reserve official stated that the central bank's plan to shrink its bond portfolio this year would not significantly delay interest rate hikes. New York Fed President William Dudley said the plan would only cause a "little pause" in rate hikes, providing relief to dollar bulls. Despite a softer-than-expected jobs report, the dollar rebounded due to geopolitical events and safe-haven buying, with the US dollar index rising 0.5% to 101.16.

site_title: Triyards sinks into the red with Q2 net loss of US$6.25m
summary: Triyards Holdings, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, reported a Q2 net loss of US$6.25 million, mainly due to an allowance for doubtful receivables from related entities. Revenue increased marginally to US$70.64 million. The company is diversifying its clientele base and expanding product offerings, with new contract wins in April 2017 contributing to future earnings. Triyards is seeking advice on Ezra's Chapter 11 filing and assessing its impact on the group.

site_title: Gold rallies on haven demand following US strike against Syria
summary: Gold prices surged to almost five-month highs after the US launched a missile strike against Syria, with gold climbing 1.4% to US$1,269.46 an ounce. The strike marked a reversal for US President Donald Trump's stance on Middle East conflicts. The move is seen as a sign of risk aversion in the market, leading to increased buying of gold, which has risen 10% this year.

site_title: Cruise operators, convenience stores and cosmetics makers seen as good stock picks as China ages
summary: China's demographic shift, driven by its one-child policy, may benefit investors in sectors such as cruise operators, convenience stores, and cosmetics makers. By 2030, about a quarter of the population will be 60 years old or older, leading to increased spending patterns. Deutsche Bank Wealth Management recommends investing in these sectors, citing the growing demand for travel and convenience services among the elderly. Companies like Royal Caribbean Cruises, Seven & i Holdings, and cosmetics firms in China are expected to benefit from this trend.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: Cigarette After Sex, an indie band, gained recognition after their 2012 EP was discovered by a music enthusiast. The band's smoky-pop ballads evoke a '90s dream-gaze vibe.

site_title: Oil rises on Syria attack, US dollar shrugs off weak jobs report
summary: Oil prices rose to a near-one-month high on Friday after a US missile strike on a Syrian air base, despite a weak US jobs report and a strong dollar. The US crude settled 54 cents higher at $52.24 a barrel, while Brent rose 35 cents to $55.24 a barrel. The jobs report, which showed a decline in unemployment to 4.5%, kept expectations for two more interest rate hikes in 2017. The US dollar rose as investors dismissed the report as not enough to derail the economy or interest rate hikes, while stocks initially fell before closing higher.

site_title: Swedish workers get microchipped
summary: In Sweden, some workers at Epicenter, a digital hub in Stockholm, are voluntarily getting microchipped for convenience. The chip, the size of a grain of rice, allows them to unlock doors, operate printers, and buy smoothies with their hand. The technology, similar to RFID tracking, does not allow for monitoring and is not linked to personal data. Management consultants say there is little interest in the concept, citing a lack of business case and creep factor, but some experts predict it may be tried in the US within a few years as a next iteration of biometric scanners.

site_title: Myth and market analysis
summary: The article discusses market analysis, debunking claims of imminent collapse in the S&P 500 and Dollar Index. Experts argue that markets do not suddenly collapse without warning signs, and that the S&P 500 is showing no end-of-trend patterns. The Dollar Index has a well-established uptrend line and trading band, indicating strong bullish pressure. A breakout above 2,400 on the S&P 500 is predicted, with an upside target near 2,530. The article concludes that neither the S&P 500 nor the Dollar Index are falling down, and that investors should be looking for buying opportunities.

site_title: Tesla continues to bewitch investors but will it go on to dominate the industry?
summary: Tesla's stock price surged past $300, surpassing Ford's market value, despite the company losing $773 million last year. Founder Elon Musk acknowledged on Twitter that Tesla was "absurdly overvalued" based on traditional valuation measures. The company's valuation has made it a "story stock" that defies conventional valuation methods. Despite this, investors remain enchanted by Tesla's prospects, leaving questions about whether the company will maintain its dominance in the industry.

site_title: Lives shared live
summary: BeLive, a Singapore-founded live streaming app, has gained popularity, especially among millennials, with a market worth $5 billion in China. The app allows users to share their everyday lives and earn money through virtual gifts, which can be redeemed for real cash. Founder Kenneth Tan reported that top streamers can earn up to $500 for a 30-minute stream, surpassing the income of a "super tutor". BeLive has secured $2.2 million in funding and aims to become the No. 1 app in Asia, rivaling Snapchat's popularity.

site_title: Ancient cannibals didn't eat just for the calories, says new study
summary: A new study on Paleolithic cannibalism suggests that ancient humans did not consume human flesh solely for nutritional reasons. Researchers estimate that a whole human body provides over 125,000 calories, making it an unlikely source of sustenance. Archaeologist James Cole's decade-long study on "nutritional human cannibalism" during the Paleolithic period (2.5 million - 10,000 years ago) found that cannibalism may have been practiced for social or cultural reasons rather than nutritional needs.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cosco Corp announced a delay in the delivery of two jack-up rigs to Northern Offshore Ltd due to unfavourable international marine market conditions. Falcon Energy Group sold 21.83% of CH Offshore shares for S$20 million, citing decreasing oil prices and industry dependency. Pollux Properties explained unusual trading activity but confirmed compliance with listing rules. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received a 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: Superfan is Letterman's unlikely archivist
summary: David Letterman's late-night talk show legacy is fragile due to the ephemeral nature of the format. Unlike other hosts, Letterman's work is relatively easy to find, thanks to superfan Don Giller, who has collected videos of all but two of Letterman's 6,028 shows. Giller's efforts serve as a crucial archive of Letterman's comedy, preserving his legacy for future generations.

site_title: A Moment to Share
summary: A new store, Monument Lifestyle, has opened in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar/Duxton area, blending retail and F&B offerings. The store, founded by American couple Dustin Ramos and Iris Sangalang, serves specialty coffee and healthy food alongside a curated selection of men's fashion and accessories. The duo, formerly in the finance and technology industry, wanted to recreate the relaxed urban vibe they enjoyed in California and New York City, but tailored it to the Singaporean market. Brands featured include Alex Mill, Faherty, and Happy socks, with collaborations with local companies planned.

site_title: Yesterday Once More
summary: Furniture store Journey East is reviving its Vintage Fair for the third time, featuring European vintage accessories and lighting. The event will take place this weekend at Tan Boon Liat Building and will include 20% off all vintage furniture for April. Local vendors like By My Old School, Vinyl Kakis, and The Paper Pan will also participate, offering unique vintage items.

site_title: Course set for mega QE unwinding
summary: The US Federal Reserve may start unwinding its massive $4.5 trillion balance sheet this year, reversing the last remnants of its quantitative easing policies. This move could have a reverse impact on the US economy, potentially slowing it down. The decision is not a surprise, as Fed officials had hinted at a balance sheet reduction in recent speeches. Investors are hoping for a predictable and gradual unloading, but the pace and impact will depend on the Fed's decisions.

site_title: Wooing Asia's ultra high net worth families
summary: Sandaire, a multi-family office, caters to ultra-high net worth families seeking investment advisory services. Alexander Scott, a fourth-generation family business owner, sold his UK insurance business in 1994 due to volatile and risky sectors. The sale netted £300 million, prompting Scott to seek advice on managing family assets. Sandaire aims to provide tailored investment solutions for families like Scott's, helping them navigate complex financial decisions.

site_title: Azure Capital's stock portfolio up 17% since inception: CEO
summary: Azure Capital's CEO, Terence Wong, reported a 17% increase in his stock portfolio since its inception. He expects a "healthy correction" in the Singapore market this quarter, but is open to accumulating more shares. Wong's fund has assets under management of S$100 million, with 18 companies invested, including Global Logistic Properties and smaller counters like Avi-Tech Electronics and Fu Yu Corporation. Wong attributes his success to his ability to identify undervalued companies and his focus on dividend income.

site_title: Pent-up demand expected for Seaside Residences in Siglap
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited's condominium project at Siglap Link is expected to generate strong demand due to its prime location and affordable unit prices. The project, scheduled for launch on April 22, comes after successful sales in earlier launches this year. It will be the first project built along the ECP in 15 years, marking a significant development in the area.

site_title: Travis Chia
summary: Travis Chia, 28, founded Alcohol Delivery in 2012 as a pet project, aiming to deliver chilled alcohol within an hour. The company has delivered 500,000 bottles, with 500 products in its inventory. Chia attributes his success to focusing on one business, investing time and attention, and differentiating through fast delivery and chilled beverages. Plans include software automation and an app, as well as expansion overseas. Chia advises young entrepreneurs to focus on one business, be prepared for hard work, and take calculated risks.

site_title: Life is a Cabaret
summary: Tropicana The Musical, a glitzy show, opens at Capitol Theatre April 13-30, featuring a star-studded cast and exploring Singapore's permissive '60s nightlife. The musical, directed by Beatrice Chia-Richmond, is based on the real-life nightclub Tropicana, which operated from 1968 to 1989.

site_title: Only 28% of Aussie millennials own a home: survey
summary: Australian millennials have the second lowest home ownership rate among peer groups, with only 28% owning a home between ages 19 and 36. This is behind the UAE (26%) and far below China (70%). The main barrier to ownership is saving a deposit, with three-quarters of Aussie millennials citing this as their biggest challenge. Despite rising property costs, 83% of Aussie millennials intend to buy a home in the next five years.

site_title: US jobless rate near 10-year low but job creation falters
summary: The US unemployment rate fell to 4.5% in March, its lowest level in nearly 10 years, but job creation unexpectedly stalled at 98,000 net new positions, below analyst expectations. This marks the weakest job creation figure since May 2016. Despite the slowdown, hourly wages rose 0.2% in February, indicating a tightening labor market. The Federal Reserve's views on full employment may be supported by these figures, but the US economy still faces challenges in meeting President Trump's job creation goals.

site_title: New agency to help legal, accountancy services grow beyond local markets
summary: Singapore is setting up a new inter-agency office to help grow its legal and accountancy services beyond local markets. The office, launched in May, aims to enhance capability development, collaboration, and innovation in the industries. Despite having a strong presence, senior minister Indranee Rajah noted that companies must look beyond the domestic market for growth, citing areas such as business valuation, internal audit restructuring, and intellectual property. The industries are expected to continue growing, with a combined S$1.1 billion worth of service exports last year.

site_title: Xi urges trade cooperation in first meeting with Trump
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with US President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago in Florida, urging cooperation on trade and investment. Xi invited Trump to visit China, while Trump plans to discuss sensitive security and commercial issues, including China's trade practices and North Korea's nuclear ambitions. No major deals are expected, but the meeting marks a cordial start to their first meeting.

site_title: 'Skew Me, Are You The Satay Master?'
summary: A 59-year-old former street vendor, known as Ah Pui, has gained fame for his exceptional Hainanese pork satay despite operating without a license for decades. He spent years evading authorities and fined multiple times, but eventually switched to private catering after the last fine. Ah Pui's secret recipe, passed down from his brother, remains unchanged and he has refused to share it, even with potential partners, citing concerns about losing his prized skill and control over his life's work.

site_title: Heeton consortium's Leeds hotel to be run by Hilton
summary: Heeton Holdings' consortium has signed a franchise agreement with Hilton to operate a 192-bedroom hotel in Leeds, UK, under the Hampton by Hilton brand. The hotel is part of a new regeneration project, expected to start operations in late 2019. The consortium, comprising Heeton Holdings, KSH Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and Ryobi Kiso Holdings, is developing the project.

site_title: Street Food Festival
summary: The Michelin Guide Street Food Festival will take place at Resorts World Sentosa from April 14-15, featuring popular Singaporean street food vendors and Michelin-starred restaurants like Liao Fan Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice & Noodle and The Song of India. The festival offers entry for S$20, which includes S$20 in coupons to be spent at the event. This year's lineup includes Bib Gourmand recipients and traditional Malay food options, providing a unique opportunity for food enthusiasts to try various Singaporean dishes.

site_title: Mercedes's BRAKE-through
summary: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled the refreshed CLA250 Sport Shooting Brake, featuring new LED headlamps, updated front and rear aprons, and a sloping roofline. The car boasts a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine, producing 218 hp, and 4Matic permanent all-wheel-drive. The AMG Line bodykit and lowered suspension make the CLA250 Sport Shooting Brake a sporty wagon. With a 0-100 km/h acceleration time of 6.7 seconds, the car offers confident handling and a smooth driving experience, making it a desirable option in the compact luxury segment.

site_title: Founder of impact-investing platform in Singapore bags award
summary: Durreen Shahnaz, founder of Impact Investment Exchange (IIX) in Singapore, has won the Oslo Business for Peace Award alongside Elon Musk and two others. IIX is the world's first stock exchange dedicated to social enterprises, positively impacting 10 million lives and mobilizing over S$10 million in capital for sustainable development projects. Shahnaz, a Bangladeshi woman, began her career at Morgan Stanley and later worked at Grameen Bank, recognizing the gap between finance and development. Her work in impact investing led to the creation of the women's livelihood bond, supporting microfinance institutions and women's enterprises.

site_title: Malaysia confirms F1 pull-out in 2018 on diminishing returns
summary: Malaysia has confirmed it will end its 19-year hosting of the Formula 1 Sepang Grand Prix in 2018 due to diminishing returns and high costs. The decision, made by Prime Minister Najib Razak, comes amid a decline in popularity and a worsening economic situation, including a slump in oil prices. The event's annual sponsoring costs were also high, prompting the government to redirect funds to other motor sports. The move is expected to have a minimal impact on tourism numbers, but Malaysia is introducing a tourism tax bill to boost revenue.

site_title: Growing global
summary: Four Singaporeans have started their own farms overseas, inspired to grow kai lan. Lai Poon Piau, a former civil servant, re-connected with his farming heritage by cultivating Kampot peppercorns in Cambodia, which he owns. Kampot peppercorns have a delicate flavor profile, available in white, pink, and black varieties. Piau's journey is a testament to his childhood experiences on his father's rubber plantation, where his grandfather and father were also involved in plantation ownership.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Si Chuan Duo Hua Restaurant in Singapore is offering an omakase dining experience from April 7 to May 7, featuring a seven-course meal and dessert bar for S$120 or S$150 per person. The menu, crafted by Sichuan chef Zeng Feng and consultant chef Peter Tsang, will feature Sichuan and Cantonese dishes. Meanwhile, Bird Bird has introduced a new lunch set at S$19++ and new dishes like a five-cheese grilled cheese sandwich and duck and peach glazed pop tarts.

site_title: Panasonic opens global HQ for refrigeration unit in Singapore
summary: Panasonic has opened its global headquarters for its Refrigeration Compressor Business Unit (RCBU) in Singapore, marking the company's first relocation of a business unit outside Japan. The move aims to align business and manufacturing functions, with a focus on adopting smart technology. The RCBU now occupies part of the Panasonic Appliances Refrigeration Devices Singapore premises. The company plans to transform its Singapore factory into a smart facility, with advanced automation and collaborative robots, and expand its R&D team from 50 to 120 engineers over the next five years.

site_title: Winter WONDERLAND
summary: Club Med is set to expand its Hokkaido resort, Club Med Sahoro, with a new property at Tomamu, targeting a more upscale and trendy crowd. The Tomamu resort will offer 22km of ski runs, an indoor wave pool, and a chapel designed by world-renowned architect Tadao Ando. The expansion aims to capitalize on the resort's popularity, which saw full occupancy last winter and earned a Certificate of Excellence from Tripadvisor. Club Med Sahoro, meanwhile, has been a hit with families from Singapore and offers a range of activities, including skiing, snowboarding, and kids' clubs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sunningdale Tech's share price has been upgraded to "buy" by Singapore Myanmar Investco, with a target price of S$0.97, following the company's substantial free cash flow and solid balance sheet. This comes after the company's recent announcement of a possible transaction, which is part of the M&A fever in the precision engineering space. The upgrade suggests that Sunningdale remains a prime target for mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Deals on WHEELS
summary: The Renault Megane Sedan and Mitsubishi Space Star are two value-for-money models on the market. The Megane Sedan boasts a more spacious interior, a longer wheelbase, and more standard features, including a blind spot monitoring system and a 7-inch TFT LED instrument cluster. The Megane Sedan's 1.5-litre turbodiesel engine offers impressive fuel efficiency, with a claimed 3.7 litres per 100 km under the combined cycle. The Mitsubishi Space Star, on the other hand, has a more sophisticated engine and better acceleration, but slightly higher fuel consumption. Both models offer a good balance of features and affordability, making them attractive options for buyers.

site_title: More hummus, please: US chickpea acreage seen hitting record
summary: US chickpea acreage is expected to reach a record 498,000 acres, a 53% increase from the prior season, according to the US Department of Agriculture. This marks the highest amount of chickpea planting in the US since 2013, driven by growing demand for gluten-free products and "more healthful and varied snacking". The surge in chickpea production is also attributed to declining wheat acres and increasing prices, which have reached as high as 47 cents per pound in mid-March.

site_title: Chinese brokers muscling in on Asia's junk-bond underwriters
summary: China's brokerages have gained market share in Asia's junk bond underwriting business, with Haitong Securities topping the league table for high-yield notes in US dollars, euros, and yen in the first quarter. Mainland banks and brokerage firms have expanded their presence, taking share away from international peers. The rise in Asia high-yield bond sales reflects a positive outlook for China's economy, with Chinese firms increasingly helping borrowers raise foreign currency debt. This shift is driven by mainland banks' strengths in onshore investors seeking dollar assets and the 'eat what you kill' style of remuneration for bankers.

site_title: Van drives into crowd in Stockholm, killing at least 2, injuring others: police
summary: A van drove into a crowded area outside a department store in central Stockholm, killing at least 2 people and injuring many others. The incident occurred just before 1:30 PM local time, with thick smoke rising from the scene. Police initially reported that a person in a vehicle had injured and killed people, but it was unclear whether it was an accident or an attack. Helicopters were seen hovering over the area, and a large number of police cars and ambulances were dispatched to the scene.

site_title: US job creation tumbles in March
summary: US job creation fell in March, with the Labour Department reporting 98,000 net new positions, significantly below analyst expectations. The unemployment rate dropped to 4.5%, its lowest level in nearly 10 years. This marks a reversal from previous months of steady job growth, raising concerns about the economy's momentum.

site_title: Classic Movie
summary: In 1950, Singapore's film industry began its golden age with the release of "Bakti," starring P Ramlee and directed by Lakshmanan Krishnan. Based on Les Miserables, the movie tells the story of an adopted orphan who saves his step-brother when their fortunes change. "Bakti" marked P Ramlee's first leading role and catapulted him to fame, setting the stage for Singapore's cinematic history. The film's production was notable for its use of sound man Chong Chee Liat's 35mm reel projection at Shaw Brothers' studio.

site_title: Palm planters in Malaysia face labour shortage as Indonesia workers stay away
summary: Malaysian palm oil planters are bracing for a severe labour shortage due to the weaker ringgit and increased job opportunities in Indonesia. About 70% of the industry's workforce comes from Indonesia, with workers typically drawn by higher wages. The plunge in Malaysia's ringgit currency and tighter employment regulations are deterring Indonesian workers, potentially delaying harvests and curbing output. The shortage may delay harvests and impact the country's top commodity export industry, but could support prices that have dropped nearly 15% this year.

site_title: Samsung heir accused of bribery, perjury as trial opens
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong, vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, began his trial for embezzlement and perjury, accused of bribing former South Korean President Park Geun-Hye and her friend Choi Soon-Sil with nearly $40 million. Four other Samsung executives are also charged. Lee's lawyers claim the payments were charitable contributions, not bribes. The trial's outcome is expected in late May, amid a broader corruption scandal that brought down Park Geun-Hye and saw millions protest in the streets.

site_title: Fitch cuts South Africa's credit rating to 'junk'
summary: Fitch has cut South Africa's credit rating to 'junk' status, citing recent political instability. The downgrade was prompted by a cabinet reshuffle, and the sovereign debt rating was lowered from 'BBB-' to 'BB+'. The outlook remains stable.

site_title: Trump's Syria strike sends not-so-subtle warning to US rivals
summary: US President Donald Trump's strike on Syria sends a warning to US rivals, including Russia, North Korea, and China. The strike, in response to a chemical attack, shows the US is willing to act unilaterally and will not tolerate close ties between Russia and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. The US is also warning North Korea that it will take action if China doesn't do more to stop its nuclear missile program. The attack has disrupted diplomatic efforts between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who was dining with Trump before the strike.

site_title: Tight at the top, edgy at the bottom
summary: The English Premier League is entering its final stretch, with six weeks and a handful of fixtures left. Chelsea, led by Antonio Conte, had a double-digit lead over Tottenham Hotspur but suffered a shocking 1-2 defeat to Crystal Palace, giving Spurs fresh life in the title race. Tottenham is now just seven points behind Chelsea and has a chance to reduce the deficit with a win against Watford on Saturday. Meanwhile, Liverpool and Manchester City are battling for third and fourth place, with Liverpool's position precarious after a recent loss to Bournemouth.

site_title: Death, metal and all that jazz
summary: Jah Wobble's album "Everything is No-Thing" is a genre-bending release that defies categorization, blending jazz, funk, and New Age elements. The album features complex instrumentation and freeform jazz as its guiding imperative. Meanwhile, Mastodon's "Emperor of Sand" is a heavy metal album that tells the story of a character forced to wander a desert after being sentenced to death. The album features the band's signature pounding riffs and angst-ridden vocals. In a separate article, Kronos Audio's Pro turntable with Black Beauty tonearm is reviewed, praising its engineering and ability to deliver high-quality vinyl playback.

site_title: Great Singapore Sail
summary: The Singapore Yacht Show at ONE°15 Marina Sentosa Cove is underway, featuring world-class yachts, glamorous parties, and high-end entertainment. The largest yacht, the 77m Silver Fast, is a must-visit for Instagram enthusiasts. The show showcases an enviable range of prestige products, including supercars, timepieces, and hand-crafted jewelry. The event is open to the public and promises to be an exciting experience for those interested in luxury lifestyle and entertainment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks pare Syria losses to end flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Friday, paring initial losses from a US missile attack on Syria. The Hang Seng Index edged down 6.42 points to 24,267.30, after diving over 1% earlier. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index inched lower. The flat close was attributed to traders brushing off new US threats to extend the stocks rally, despite geopolitical concerns.

site_title: STI closes higher despite US missile strike
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed higher on Friday, April 7, 2017, despite a US missile strike on Syria, with a net gain of 1.68 points to 3,177.27. The index rebounded from a 20-point drop earlier in the day, driven by a rebound in Dow futures. Turnover reached S$1.25 billion, the highest for the week, with 271 rises and 205 falls.

site_title: Falcon Energy, subsidiary dispose shares in CH Offshore for S$20m in strategic move
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a subsidiary of Falcon Energy, sold 21.83% of CH Offshore (CHO) shares for S$20 million, maintaining a 64.91% stake. The disposal was strategic, considering the decline in oil prices and CHO's industry dependency. It will be used to repay a CIMB term loan instalment and working capital purposes, with a remainder of S$4.32 million. The sale is aimed at meeting pressing obligations and funding general requirements.

site_title: India inks weapons deal worth nearly US$2b with Israel
summary: India has signed a nearly $2 billion defense deal with Israel, described as the country's largest defense contract. The deal includes advanced defense systems, including medium-range surface-to-air missiles, launchers, and communications technology, as well as a naval defense system for India's first aircraft carrier. The agreement is part of India's "Make in India" campaign to reduce reliance on costly imports and is seen as a major boost to Israel's defense industry. The deal follows India's recent purchase of 36 Rafale fighter jets from France for $12.34 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.160 points to close at 1,741.720 on Friday, driven by a 5.22 billion lots traded valued at RM3.39 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 535 to 425.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore High Court reduced jail terms for City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee and five other leaders to 3 years and 6 months from 8 years. TRIYARD Holdings reported a net loss of US$6.25 million for the second quarter. US job growth is expected to slow due to fading warm weather boosts. Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong began his trial for embezzlement and perjury. The Straits Times Index rebounded from a decline caused by the US missile strike on Syria.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher; STI shrugs off US missile strike on Syria
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore rebounded from a 20-point decline due to a US missile strike on Syria, closing at 3,177.27 with a 1.68-point gain. The index rose for the week, despite hawkish Federal Reserve minutes and concerns about the Trump administration's budget claims. Market observers attributed the rebound to a rebound in Dow futures and a surge in trading volume, with 271 rises versus 205 falls on Friday.

site_title: France was informed of Syria strikes, says Russia should heed US "warning"
summary: France was informed of US military strikes on Syrian military positions, with US President Donald Trump reportedly clarifying his position. French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault stated that Russia should heed the "warning" and push for a political solution to the Syrian conflict. France, a key backer of rebel groups opposed to President Bashar al-Assad, has repeatedly called for his step-down. The US strikes came after a suspected chemical attack by Assad's forces, which France saw as a test for Trump's administration.

site_title: The GRAND Tour
summary: Three international chefs - John-Paul Fiechtner from Australia, Emmanuel Xu from China, and Andrea Tarini from Italy - have opened new eateries in Singapore. Fiechtner's Bistro November, which closed after two months, is set to close in November due to a lease expiry. Xu's Ginett, a French-inspired restaurant, offers Asian influences on European dishes. Tarini's Atmastel serves authentic Italian food, with a focus on traditional family recipes.

site_title: UK house price growth weakest in nearly four years: Halifax
summary: British house price growth has slowed to its weakest in nearly four years, with a 3.8% increase in the three months to March, according to Halifax. This marks the weakest increase since May 2013 and is slower than a Reuters poll forecast. For the second month in a row, prices were flat in monthly terms, with the year-on-year increase being the weakest since August 2015.

site_title: Heeton, KSH, Lian Beng consortium's Leeds hotel to be operated by Hilton
summary: A consortium of Heeton Holdings, KSH Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and Ryobi Kiso Holdings has signed a franchise agreement with Hilton for their 192-bedroom hotel in Leeds, UK. The hotel, operated under Hampton by Hilton, is part of a regeneration project currently under construction. Operations are expected to start in late-2019, with projected increased visitor numbers in the next five to 10 years due to the UK government's Northern Powerhouse proposals.

site_title: Sterling set for first fall in four weeks, eyes on output data
summary: Sterling is poised for its first fall in four weeks as investors await UK economic data crucial to the country's growth outlook during its Brexit process. The pound has slipped 0.7% against the US dollar, down 0.1% at US$1.2455. Data releases on Friday are expected to show a 1.9% year-on-year increase in construction volumes and a 3.7% year-on-year increase in industrial output. Economists believe these data will contribute positively to Q1 GDP growth, despite January's disappointing outturns.

site_title: Singapore office market improving as supply tapers off: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, expects Singapore's office property market to improve as supply tapers off. Rents have dropped by over 10% in the past two years due to oversupply, but analysts predict a shift to a landlord's market, leading to rising rents. BlackRock is considering investments in malls and industrial properties in Singapore, while also expanding its real estate presence in Japan and Australia. The firm's Asia-Pacific head believes the market is past its inflection point and that strong investment interest from funds and corporates will drive growth.

images.alt_text: BlackRock last year sold its 43-storey Asia Square Tower 1 for US$2.5 billion to Qatar Investment Authority in what was Singapore's largest office transaction.

site_title: British government says 'fully supports' US strikes on Syria
summary: The British government has expressed full support for the US military strike against a Syrian airfield, stating it was designed to deter chemical attacks and not the start of a new military campaign. Defence Secretary Michael Fallon described the strike as "limited and entirely appropriate" and emphasized the UK's support for the US operation, despite not being directly involved. The strike came in response to a poison gas attack in a rebel-held area, and Fallon clarified that the UK is focused on the fight against Daesh in Syria and Iraq.

site_title: Cosco Corp's shipyard unit to defer delivery of two jack-ups
summary: Cosco Corp's shipyard unit, Cosco (Dalian) Shipyard Co, has agreed to delay the delivery of two jack-up rigs, Energy Engager and Energy Encounter, to the end of September 2017 and the end of March 2018, respectively, due to unfavourable international marine market conditions. The agreement was made with Northern Offshore Ltd, a Bermuda-based rig owner.

site_title: Australia shares held back by US missile strikes on Syria; NZ down
summary: US missile strikes on Syria's airbase led to a global flight to safety, causing Australian shares to decline 0.1% and New Zealand shares to fall 0.6%. Gold prices rallied 2.9%, while the US dollar slipped. Investors were cautious ahead of talks between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, and a key jobs report. Markets will be watching the response from Russia and Syria, with concerns about escalating tensions between the US and Russia.

site_title: US employment growth seen slowing as warm weather boost fades
summary: US employment growth is expected to slow in March after warm weather boosted hiring over the prior two months, but still likely increased by 180,000 jobs, near 2016's average monthly average of 187,000. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain unchanged at 4.7%. Despite a recent slowdown in economic growth, job gains and gradual wage increases are expected to keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates again in June.

site_title: Trump accepts Xi's invitation to visit China: Xinhua
summary: US President Donald Trump accepted Chinese President Xi Jinping's invitation to visit China, marking the first meeting between the two presidents. Xi urged cooperation on investment, infrastructure, and energy during their two-day meeting at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.

site_title: Eurozone ministers push for Greece bailout deal
summary: Eurozone finance ministers met in Malta to discuss a reform deal with Greece, aiming to release billions in bailout cash and stabilize the country's economy. The deal, which has been stalled since October, is crucial to prevent Greece from defaulting on its creditors this summer. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said the country is close to reaching an agreement, but talks are still ongoing, with the IMF's involvement pending a united front from eurozone ministers.

site_title: Malaysia palm planters face labour shortage as Indonesia workers stay away
summary: Malaysian palm oil planters face a severe labour shortage due to the weaker ringgit, which has made it less attractive for Indonesian workers to cross the border. The shortage is expected to delay harvests and curb output, potentially hurting the country's top commodity export industry. The labour shortage is attributed to increased opportunities in Indonesia, tighter employment regulations in Malaysia, and the decline in the ringgit's value, which has fallen 15% against the Indonesian rupiah since 2015.

site_title: Wave of attacks across southern Thailand after new constitution signed
summary: A wave of 23 coordinated attacks, including bomb blasts, occurred in southern Thailand, with no casualties reported, shortly after the signing of a new constitution. The attacks targeted 19 districts in the region, which has seen a recent surge in a decades-old Muslim separatist insurgency. The incidents were described as aimed to create disturbances, destroy the government's credibility, and instill fear among people. The attacks' timing coincided with the signing of the new constitution, but no conclusive evidence links the two events.

site_title: LG Electronics estimates Q1 profit surged, likely best in nearly 8 years
summary: LG Electronics reported its first-quarter operating profit surged 82% to 922 billion won (S$1.14 billion), the highest in nearly eight years, beating market expectations. Revenue likely rose 9.7% to 14.7 trillion won. Analysts attribute the profit increase to improved product mix in appliances and televisions, as well as efforts to sell high-end products. However, the company's mobile business likely turned an operating loss for the eighth-straight quarter due to the delayed impact of its new G6 flagship smartphone.

site_title: Samsung heir accused of bribery, perjury as trial opens
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong has begun his trial in Seoul Central District Court for bribery and perjury, as part of a corruption scandal that led to the impeachment of former President Park Geun-Hye. Lee, vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, is accused of paying nearly $40 million to Park's friend Choi Soon-Sil as bribes to secure policy favors. Lee's defense claims the payments were charitable contributions, while prosecutors argue they were bribes for policy favors, including a merger of two Samsung units in 2015. The verdict is expected in late May.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Friday, influenced by geopolitical concerns and anticipation of US jobs data. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices dropped 0.5% and 0.3%, respectively. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns over Middle Eastern instability and the launch of US missile strikes on Syria, with safe-haven assets such as bonds and precious metals rising. The US jobs report, due on Friday, is also expected to influence markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end at 3-wk lows after US missile strikes on Syria
summary: South Korean won and shares fell to three-week lows on Friday after US missile strikes on Syria, denting risk appetite globally. The won closed at 1,134.5 to the dollar, down 0.1%, and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended at 2,151.73 points, the lowest since March 16. The won snapped a three-week winning streak, falling 1.4% for the week, while equities lost 0.4%.

site_title: China March FX reserves rise slightly, remain above US$3t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose US$3.96 billion in March to US$3.009 trillion, exceeding market expectations of a US$5 billion increase. The slight rise helped contain capital outflows, despite capital control measures. China's reserves have fallen by nearly US$320 billion since last year, leading to a 6.5% drop in the yuan against the US dollar. Gold reserves value also fell to US$73.74 billion. The yuan's value is expected to be impacted by the ongoing meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Trump jokes he's 'gotten nothing' from Xi so far
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago, a Florida resort, for a 24-hour summit. Trump jokingly said he had "gotten nothing" from Xi, but expressed optimism about a "very great" relationship. The two leaders discussed trade, jobs, and security, with China offering investments and concessions in exchange for US assurances on tariffs and arms sales to Taiwan. The summit aims to build a rapport between the two nations, which have a complex and often tense relationship.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump predicted a "very great" relationship with China's Xi Jinping as the pair met for the first time at his Florida resort of Mar-a-Lago Thursday, when cordiality replaced tough anti-China rhetoric.

site_title: Malaysia confirms F1 race to be halted from 2018 due to low returns
summary: Malaysia confirms it will end its contract to host the Formula One Grand Prix starting in 2018 due to declining sales. The decision was made after considering the lower returns compared to the cost of hosting the championships. The Malaysian Grand Prix, sponsored by Petronas, will continue to be held in 2017, but the company will maintain its sponsorship with the Mercedes AMG Petronas Formula 1 Team.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up after US air strikes in Syria
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Friday following US missile strikes in Syria, fueling geopolitical concerns. The Nikkei index rose 0.36% to 18,664.63, while the Topix index gained 0.65%. The US strikes sparked market volatility, but investors remained optimistic, with the Nikkei closing at a one-day high. The rally was attributed to traders brushing off new Trump threats, which had initially sparked uncertainty.

site_title: A red line already crossed in Syria
summary: President Donald Trump has ordered a military strike against Syria in retaliation for a suspected chemical attack that killed at least 86 civilians, including 27 children. The strike, which involved 59 precision-guided missiles, targeted Shayrat Airfield in Syria, where the US believes the attack was launched. This decision comes four years after President Barack Obama's predecessor, President Obama, faced a similar challenge in Syria and chose not to intervene militarily, instead opting for a deal with Damascus to dismantle the country's chemical weapons arsenal.

site_title: New museum reveals power of poo in Italy
summary: In Italy's Castelbosco, a museum showcases the power of poo, transforming cow waste into plates, bricks, and other objects. Farmer Gianantonio Locatelli collects 1,500 quintals of waste daily from his 3,500 cattle, which is then processed into methane to generate electricity. The leftover faeces is used as fertilizer and created into "Merdacotta" products, including tableware and bricks, with the goal of rehabilitating the perception of excrement. The museum, founded in 2005, aims to promote an ecological approach to waste management and challenge societal norms around feces.

site_title: PBOC to skip open market operations for the 10th straight session
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), skipped open market operations for the 10th consecutive session due to "relatively high" liquidity levels in the banking system. A net drain of 100 billion yuan (S$20.3 billion) from the interbank market is expected for the week. This decision comes as China's financial markets resumed trading after the Tomb-Sweeping festival.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said it would skip open market operations on Friday, citing "relatively high" liquidity levels in the banking system.

site_title: US lets 23andMe market genetic health risk reports
summary: US regulators granted Silicon Valley biotech firm 23andMe permission to market genetic health risk reports, allowing customers to access information on conditions like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease. The first reports will be available in the US this month, with test results costing $199. The FDA emphasized that genetic risk is just one factor in overall health, and test results should not be used as the sole basis for medical treatment decisions.

site_title: Gold surges on haven demand as US missiles hit Syrian targets
summary: US President Donald Trump launched a punitive strike against a Syrian airfield, targeting hangars, planes, and fuel tanks with 60 Tomahawk missiles after Bashar al-Assad's regime used poison gas to kill civilians. The attack led to a surge in gold prices, with bullion for immediate delivery climbing 1% to $1,263.56 an ounce. This marks the metal's fourth consecutive weekly rise and a 10% gain this year, driven by "haven" demand amid the volatile situation in Syria.

site_title: Philippines to upgrade facilities, not occupy new areas in disputed sea: military
summary: The Philippines will upgrade existing facilities in the South China Sea, adhering to a 2002 informal code, instead of occupying new territories. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered troops to occupy uninhabited islands and shoals claimed by the Philippines, but this move may anger China. Duterte may also visit a Philippine-controlled island to raise the national flag, in a change of tack from previous statements. This decision aims to assert Philippine sovereignty without escalating tensions with China.

images.alt_text: The Philippines will upgrade existing facilities on its inhabited islands and reefs in the South China Sea and not occupy new territories, adhering to a 2002 informal code in the disputed waters, defence and military officials said on Friday.

site_title: Oil prices jump 2% after US launches missile strike in Syria
summary: US President Donald Trump launched dozens of cruise missiles at a Syrian airbase on April 6, 2017, in response to a deadly chemical attack. Oil prices surged 2% to US$55.75 per barrel, with Brent crude futures reaching a 6-month high, after the strikes rattled global markets. The strikes did not target areas with Russian forces present. The US dollar and stock markets slumped, while gold prices rose. Analysts expect potential implications for oil markets, particularly from Iran and Russia, which are major oil producers and allies of the Assad regime.

site_title: Japan households' inflation expectations rise for 1st time in 7 quarters: BOJ
summary: Japan's households have raised their inflation expectations for the first time in 7 quarters, with 67% anticipating price hikes one year from now, up from a 4-year low. The Bank of Japan's quarterly survey also showed 79.3% expect inflation to rise in 5 years. Despite this, core consumer prices rose 0.2% in February, still below the BOJ's 2% target. Weaker yen and labor shortages are contributing to rising prices, with some firms already increasing prices for items like butter and tissue paper.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open after Syria strikes
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.46% in the first minutes of trade following the US launch of missile strikes against Syria, fuelling geopolitical concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,162.44, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat. The decline was attributed to the heightened tensions and uncertainty in global markets.

site_title: Putin says US strikes on Syria illegal, harm US-Russia ties
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin views US cruise missile strikes on a Syrian airbase as "aggression against a sovereign nation" and a "cynical attempt to distract the world" from civilian deaths in Iraq. The strikes, which targeted a base from which the US claimed a deadly chemical attack was launched, have seriously hurt US-Russia relations. Putin believes the US action broke international law and will create a serious obstacle to creating an international coalition to fight terrorism. Russia plans to call for an urgent UN Security Council meeting to discuss the matter.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin believes that US cruise missile strikes on a Syrian air base broke international law and have seriously hurt US-Russia relations, Russian news agencies cited the Kremlin as saying on Friday.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink after US launches Syria strikes
summary: US President Donald Trump launched missile strikes on Syria's Shayrat Airfield in retaliation for a chemical attack, causing Asian markets to sink and safe havens to rally. The strikes also raised concerns about frictions with Russia. Meanwhile, a two-day meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping began in Florida, with Trump accusing Beijing of manipulating its currency and killing US jobs. The meeting comes as investors weigh the impact of US trade policies.

site_title: US launches missile strike against Syria
summary: US President Donald Trump ordered a military strike against Syria in response to a chemical attack blamed on President Bashar al-Assad. 59 precision-guided missiles were launched from the USS Porter and USS Ross, targeting Shayrat Airfield in Syria. The strike was in retaliation for a sarin-like nerve agent attack that killed at least 86 people, including 27 children. The UN Security Council failed to agree on demands for a thorough investigation of the strike. The US assesses with high confidence that the chemical attack was launched from this site by air assets under the Assad regime.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.63% to 18,714.98, and the Topix index increasing 0.67% to 1,490.14. Markets focused on the US-China summit and awaited US payroll figures.

site_title: Australia's counterterrorism unit investigates fatal petrol station stabbing
summary: Australia's counterterrorism unit is investigating a fatal stabbing at a petrol station in Queanbeyan, near Canberra. Two 15- and 16-year-old males were arrested in relation to the attack, with the 16-year-old being investigated for suspected links to global militant groups. Authorities believe the attack may be linked to a modus operandi indicative of a terrorist attack, but no formal charges have been made. The investigation is being led by the country's joint counter-terrorism team, amid heightened concerns of attacks by sympathisers of the Islamic State militant group and home-grown militants.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks, US dollar fall as geopolitical risks rise
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% to 9,852.47, following regional peers, due to rising geopolitical risks. The US missile strike in Syria and US-China summit raised concerns, while the Taiwan dollar weakened to a three-week low against the US dollar. The electronics and financial subindices also declined, with Hon Hai Precision and Fubon Financial Holding losing over 1%. The strikes and summit added to investor uncertainty, despite the US stock market reaching fresh records.

site_title: Samsung forecasts best quarterly profit in over 3 yrs as chips soar
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd forecasted its best quarterly profit in over 3 years, beating expectations, driven by robust demand for memory chips. The company expects a 9.9 trillion won operating profit in the January-March period, surpassing analyst forecasts. Revenue rose 0.4% to 50 trillion won, with chip division earnings projected at a record 5.8 trillion won. Samsung's Galaxy S8 premium smartphone launch on April 21 will be a key factor in its future performance, with some analysts projecting a first-year sales record.

site_title: Yum's KFC to curb antibiotic use in the chickens it buys
summary: Yum Brands' US KFC chain plans to curb antibiotic use in its chicken supply by the end of 2018, becoming the last of the big three chicken restaurants to join the fight against antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The move comes as concerns grow over the overuse of antibiotics in meat and dairy production, potentially diminishing their effectiveness in treating human diseases.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars tumble vs yen after US missile strikes on Syria
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted to four-month lows against the yen following US missile strikes on a Syrian air base. The Australian dollar fell to 82.84 yen and the New Zealand dollar to 76.74 yen, driven by concerns about a potential escalation in the Syrian conflict. Investors sought safer havens, leading to a flight to the yen.

site_title: Scarlett Johansson says she's 'baffled' by Ivanka Trump's advocacy comments
summary: Scarlett Johansson expressed disappointment with Ivanka Trump's comments stating she would prefer to be an advocate behind the scenes rather than in the public arena, calling it "cowardly" and "old-fashioned." Johansson criticized the idea that a woman's impact is diminished by being in the public eye, advocating for women to take a more prominent role.

images.alt_text: Actress Scarlett Johansson said on Thursday she was "baffled" by Ivanka Trump's recent comments that she would prefer to be an advocate for issues behind the scenes of President Donald Trump's administration rather than in the public arena.

site_title: New Zealand PM grilled after spaghetti pizza outrage
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English faced backlash after sharing a photo of a pizza topped with spaghetti and pineapple on social media. The unusual topping sparked outrage among pizza enthusiasts, with some calling for his impeachment. English defended his taste, stating that many people in his country also put spaghetti on their pizzas. The controversy came after Iceland's president revealed he hated pineapple on pizzas, but English was unaware of this.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 2.3 points to 3,173.29 at 9:01am. Volume was 38.6 million shares worth S$ 43.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 87 to 36.

site_title: US dollar falls against yen after US missile launch in Syria
summary: The US dollar fell against the Japanese yen, losing 0.3% to 110.46 yen, after the US launched cruise missiles at an airbase in Syria. The move followed a deadly poison gas attack in the country, with US President Donald Trump stating that "something should happen" with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. The strike's completion did not impact the dollar's decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 1.110 points to 1740.820. The index saw 181 gainers and 53 losers, with a total trading volume of 110.6 million lots worth RM31.59 million.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares tumble after US missile strikes on Syria
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares plummeted after the US launched cruise missile strikes on a Syrian airbase, sparking geopolitical anxieties. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.3% following President Donald Trump's order, amid concerns of escalating tensions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Triyards Holdings, Healthway Medical
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a net loss of US$6.25 million for the second quarter ended Feb 28, 2017. Healthway Medical Corporation plans to conduct a shareholders' meeting to discuss a proposed issuance of S$60 million in convertible notes.

site_title: Nintendo traders signal Switch could be bigger hit than the Wii
summary: Nintendo's Switch console is outperforming expectations, surpassing the company's best-selling home console, the Wii, in terms of sales and market performance. The Switch has exceeded the broader Japanese stock market by 20 percentage points, despite criticism of its software lineup and hardware issues. Analysts estimate that 2.5 to 3 million units were sold in March, ahead of Nintendo's target of 2 million. However, concerns remain about the company's conservative production targets and potential underperformance in its upcoming sales forecast. The limited supply has driven up prices on some auction sites, with the Switch selling for an average of $450 on eBay.

site_title: Singapore High Court cuts jail terms for Kong Hee and 5 City Harvest Church leaders
summary: The Singapore High Court has reduced the jail terms for Kong Hee, City Harvest Church founder, and five other church leaders. Kong Hee's sentence was reduced from 8 years to 3 years and 6 months, while the others' sentences were also reduced. The court found the six guilty of a less serious charge of criminal breach of trust, rather than the original charges of misusing funds. The judges ruled that the defendants' actions were ultimately in the interest of the church and did not involve personal financial gain.

site_title: Triyards in the red for Q2 with US$6.25m loss
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a net loss of US$6.25 million for Q2 2017, primarily due to an allowance for doubtful receivables from related entities of Ezra Holdings. Revenue increased marginally to US$70.64 million. This is a significant decrease from the previous year's net profit of US$5.28 million.

site_title: Japan overtime pay up for first time in 9 months, real wages flat
summary: Japan's overtime pay increased 0.6% in February, the first rise in nine months, while real wages remained flat year-on-year. The increase was due to a higher number of overtime hours worked. This contrasts with inflation-adjusted real wages, which dipped 0.1% in January. The data suggests corporate activity is showing signs of recovery, but real wages remain stagnant.

site_title: Airbus loses Q1 order race as delays hamper A320neo
summary: Airbus lost the first-quarter order race to Boeing, securing 26 orders, compared to Boeing's 226. Airbus' A320neo deliveries were delayed due to engine problems, while the company shifted focus to earlier A320 models, resulting in 18 new A320 orders. Despite this, Airbus aims to deliver 200 A320neos this year. Boeing's deliveries were lower than expected, leading to a cut in earnings forecast by Wells Fargo Securities. The order gap is hotly contested each year, with Boeing expected to retain its title as the world's largest jetliner producer.

site_title: Amazon plans to hire 30,000 part-time workers over next year
summary: Amazon plans to hire 30,000 part-time workers over the next year to staff its US warehouses and handle customer service issues. This is in addition to 100,000 full-time jobs with benefits announced earlier. About 5,000 part-time jobs will be at-home customer service representatives. The new hires demonstrate the continued demand for the e-commerce giant.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher, banks waver on policy outlook talk
summary: European shares ended 0.2% higher on Thursday, driven by a dovish tone from ECB chief Mario Draghi, which shifted investors' focus to the longer-term outlook for interest rates. Banks saw a volatile session, with the euro zone banking index rising 0.3% after initial losses. Real estate stocks also gained, with the sectoral index reaching a six-month high. However, some banks fell, including Austria's Raiffeisen Bank and Germany's Commerzbank.

site_title: Lyft filling tank with cash as value revs: report
