summary: Lyft has reached a valuation of $7.5 billion after securing a $500 million funding round, surpassing its previous valuation of $5.5 billion. The company is expanding rapidly, with downloads of its mobile application increasing as Uber faces controversies over sexism and workplace tactics. Lyft has cultivated a reputation as a more socially responsible and driver-friendly alternative, with a recent $1 million donation to the American Civil Liberties Union. The funding round brings Lyft's total funding to over $2 billion, with investors including General Motors and Alibaba.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks fall after US missile strike in Syria
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted after the US launched cruise missile strikes on an airbase in Syria, sparking risk-off sentiment globally. The won dropped 0.4% to its lowest intraday level since March 15, while the Kospi index fell 0.4% to its weakest level since March 16. Tech giant Samsung Electronics' shares dropped 1% despite forecasting its best March-quarter profit in over three years. Investors are cautious ahead of a meeting of US and Chinese leaders and the release of the US Treasury's exchange rate report, leading to a fifth straight selling session of Kospi shares.

site_title: Malaysian minister sees no need for more currency measures
summary: Malaysia's Second Finance Minister Johari Abdul Ghani stated that there is no need for additional measures to curb the ringgit's volatility, citing the currency's current stability. Bank Negara Malaysia previously warned foreign banks against speculating against the ringgit and has vowed to limit such activities. The finance minister believes the country's economic growth will provide sufficient ammunition for the currency to strengthen.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia to recall cars in US and South Korea over engine issue
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. and Kia Motors Corp. plan to recall tens of thousands of vehicles in South Korea and the US due to engine issues. Hyundai will recall 171,348 vehicles in South Korea, while Kia will submit plans for an unspecified number of US vehicles. The recalls are related to metal debris in crankshafts that could cause engine damage. Hyundai will replace defective engines with new ones starting May 22. The move may fuel quality concerns in Korea, affecting the companies' sales.

site_title: Oil prices hit one-month highs as buyers stay upbeat
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, reaching one-month highs, as buyers remained upbeat despite record-high US crude inventories. Brent crude futures settled at $54.89 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1.1% to $51.70. Refinery runs are increasing ahead of the US summer driving season, but analysts are cautious about speculators jumping back into the market due to inventory figures. US oil production rose to 9.2 million barrels per day, and crude exports reached a record 1.1 million barrels per day.

site_title: YouTube channels must win audiences before winning ads
summary: YouTube has implemented a new policy requiring channels with fewer than 10,000 views to win audiences before ads are displayed. This move aims to prevent people from profiting from offensive or pirated content. YouTube will also introduce a review process for new creators to ensure their content adheres to community guidelines and advertiser policies. The platform plans to use artificial intelligence systems to enforce video policies and adapt to advertiser preferences. The move comes after a boycott by companies, including AT&T and Verizon, due to concerns over hateful content on the platform.

site_title: US confident it can thwart North Korean missiles: US general
summary: The US is confident in its ability to defend against North Korean missile threats, according to General Lori Robinson, head of NORAD. Despite Pyongyang's rapidly evolving weapons program, the US can intercept an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) bound for America. However, the warning time ahead of a launch is shrinking, and the US must continue to invest in the latest sensors and radar systems to keep up with threats. The Pentagon has successfully defended against North Korean missiles in the past, but the rapidly evolving technology poses a challenge to the US defense capabilities.

site_title: Twitter rejects US effort to unmask anti-Trump users
summary: Twitter has filed a lawsuit against the US government, seeking to protect the identities of users claiming to be federal employees who have been criticising President Donald Trump's administration. The lawsuit claims the government's request to unmask the @ALT-USCIS account holder is an "unlawful abuse" of a limited-purpose investigatory tool. Twitter argues that the users' right to anonymous speech under the First Amendment of the US Constitution should be protected, and the company will defend the user's right to anonymous speech in court.

site_title: IMF sees 'progress' on Greece loan talks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) says Greece's bailout talks have made some progress, but key issues remain unresolved. The IMF is awaiting the next installment of an 86-billion-euro aid package, which Greece needs for debt repayments in July. Disagreements over debt relief and budget targets have stalled talks, with the IMF pushing for credible debt relief and economic reforms. The IMF expects Greece's debt to be unsustainable without restructuring or relief, and a meeting of eurozone finance ministers in Malta on Friday may yield a breakthrough on debt relief.

site_title: US warehouse operators entering robot business
summary: US warehouse operators are entering the robot business as Amazon's e-commerce growth drives demand for faster shipping. Quiet Logistics, a company that ships apparel, spun out a new company called Locus Robotics, which developed its own warehouse robotics solution called the LocusBot. Locus has landed a major deal with DHL Supply Chain to use its robots to ship surgical devices. The robots work alongside human workers, reducing the need for physical labor and improving productivity. This shift towards collaborative robotics is in response to the rise of e-commerce, which requires shipping companies to pack and route diverse items to customers' homes.

site_title: Mutual trust needed in dispute between Freeport and Jakarta
summary: The dispute between PT Freeport Indonesia and the Indonesian government revolves around the country's new law requiring mining companies to build smelters and pay export taxes. Freeport, a US-based mining giant, has refused to comply, halting production at its Grasberg mine in Papua. The government seeks 51% stake in Freeport's Indonesian unit, aiming to give Indonesians a fair share in the company. Negotiations between the two sides are ongoing, with the goal of finding a mutually beneficial solution, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: US: Wall St posts slight gain, investors anxious on Trump-Xi meet
summary: US stocks closed slightly higher on Thursday as investors anxiously awaited talks between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago in Florida. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 14.8 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 4.54 and 14.47 points respectively. Investors are concerned about the potential for a negative tone in the talks, which could impact China-US trade relations and discussions on North Korea's arms program.

site_title: SIA, Ethiopian Airlines to expand codeshare agreement from June 1
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Ethiopian Airlines will expand their codeshare agreement starting June 1, offering passengers seamless connectivity between Asia and Africa. SIA passengers will have access to Ethiopian Airlines' inter-African network, while Ethiopian Airlines passengers will be able to access multiple destinations in Australia, China, Japan, and Southeast Asia via SIA's network. The expanded agreement aims to enhance investment, trade, and tourism ties between Africa and Singapore.

site_title: Facebook adds tips for spotting 'fake news'
summary: Facebook has introduced an initiative to combat "fake news" by adding tips to its news feeds to help users identify and report false information. The US-based social network has partnered with the News Integrity Initiative, a global alliance of tech and academic organizations, to promote critical reading of information. The initiative, which includes a dedicated area with tips and a "journalism project" to support the news ecosystem, aims to counter the spread of misinformation that affected the 2016 US election and is now a concern in Europe.

site_title: Draghi says EU inflation not high enough to tighten policy
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the EU's inflation rate is not high enough to justify tightening monetary policy, contradicting some policymakers who urged a shift in the central bank's strategy. Draghi emphasized that the current policy path, which includes keeping interest rates low, is still appropriate to ensure growth and inflation stability. The euro dropped to its lowest level since mid-March following Draghi's speech, and investor expectations of an early interest rate hike have decreased.

site_title: First-time buyers on Affordable Art Fair's radar
summary: The Affordable Art Fair (AAF) in Singapore is set to attract first-time buyers and new art collectors with its eighth year edition. Last year's spring fair saw 22% of visitors buying their first art piece, with women driving sales and buyers mainly between 25-44 years old. The fair features 42 galleries with works priced from S$100 to S$15,000, with 75% of works under S$7,500. The event aims to educate the public and engage with galleries and the audience, with dedicated workshops and a charity feature wall.

site_title: An earnest, plodding, sappy and poorly acted adaptation
summary: The film adaptation of "The Shack" is widely panned as a poorly acted and sappy adaptation of the best-selling novel by William P. Young. The movie follows Mack Phillips, a devoted husband and father, as he searches for answers after his daughter's abduction and murder. The film's depiction of God and the Holy Trinity is deemed kitschy and lacking in faith, reducing spiritual lessons to platitudes. The 132-minute film, narrated by country singer Tim McGraw, receives a rating of C, highlighting its lackluster quality.

site_title: Urban regeneration - it's still about creating places where people want to be
summary: The United Nations predicts 70% of the global population will be urban dwellers by 2050, putting pressure on cities to house, transport, and supply residents with services. Urban regeneration aims to create authentic, livable spaces that meet community needs, often through collaborative efforts between governments, developers, and local communities. Successful examples include Singapore's Marina Bay area and Paya Lebar Quarter, which have transformed run-down areas into vibrant spaces with green public spaces, retail, and housing options. Effective urban regeneration requires a 360-degree approach, balancing economic, social, and environmental goals.

site_title: HNA close to making S$2.30 a share offer for CWT: report
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is reportedly close to making a formal takeover offer for logistics provider CWT Limited, valued at approximately S$1.38 billion at S$2.30 per share. The potential offer represents an 11% premium over CWT's last traded price. CWT's largest shareholder, C&P Holdings, may sell its stake to HNA, triggering a mandatory general offer. The deal's success is uncertain, with HNA still negotiating terms and facing potential financing challenges.

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders' revolt against manager set for April 28
summary: Sabana Reit unitholders will vote on April 28 to potentially remove the manager, Sabana Real Estate Investment Management, amid a revolt from dissenting unitholders. The manager has warned that voting against the resolutions would have "serious consequences." This is the first time such a vote is being held in Singapore's Reits history. The outcome of the vote will determine the future of the manager and the Reit.

site_title: Sustainable palm oil sector is a shared responsibility
summary: Asian Agri, an Indonesian palm oil company, emphasizes the need for a shared responsibility in achieving a sustainable palm oil sector. Smallholder farmers, who account for 40% of palm oil cultivation, require support from governments, NGOs, and palm oil users to adopt sustainable practices. The company offers certification and price guarantees to incentivize smallholders, and the Indonesian province of South Sumatra has implemented a Green Growth Development plan to manage forested lands sustainably.

site_title: O&M counters taking big impairment hit
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector is experiencing significant impairment, with many listed companies taking huge writedowns. However, some industry experts believe that the bloodletting is not yet complete, and the sector is still in a recovery phase. Despite the recent impairment, some companies, such as M3 Marine, are cautious, indicating that the industry is not yet at the bottom of the cycle. The sector's recovery is uncertain, and more impairment is expected before it can be considered fully recovered.

site_title: Shop artisanal, chill, tuck in
summary: Artbox Singapore, a pop-up creative market modeled after Artbox Thailand, will open in Marina Bay on April 14-16 and April 21-23. Over 500 vendors from Singapore and the region will sell unique items, including handmade soaps, tie-dye clothing, and desserts. The event will feature 320 booths, including 128 F&B booths, and will be held in a 50,000 sq ft site. The market aims to support budding artists and entrepreneurs, with live performances and a variety of food options.

site_title: Intrepid farmers and corporate heavyweights in BT Weekend
summary: A group of Singaporean farmers have started their own farms overseas, showcasing their entrepreneurial spirit. This trend is featured in BT Weekend magazine. In other news, the NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, and Helen Wong is set to retire as OCBC CEO with Tan Teck Long taking over.

site_title: Trump adviser from Wall St backs US bank breakup law
summary: White House economic adviser Gary Cohn expressed support for reviving the Glass-Steagall Act, a Depression-era law that would split consumer-lending businesses from investment arms in Wall Street banks. This move would fundamentally overhaul the banking system, with firms focusing primarily on trading and underwriting securities or issuing loans. Big banks have opposed such a move, but Cohn's backing suggests a shift in the White House's stance on banking regulations.

images.alt_text: White House economic adviser Gary Cohn said he backed bringing back the Glass-Steagall Act, a Depression-era law that would revamp Wall Street banks by splitting their consumer-lending businesses from their investment arms.

site_title: Malaysia prefers to use diplomacy to fight haze-causing fires
summary: Malaysia has decided to prioritize diplomacy over enacting a law to combat haze-causing fires, following Singapore's experience with the Transboundary Haze Pollution Act. The law, introduced in 2014, allows for fines of up to $2 million for companies causing haze in Singapore. Malaysia's Minister of Natural Resources and Environment Wan Junaidi bin Tuanku Jaafar cited the complexity of enforcing the law, citing cases where companies failed to respond to notices despite repeated reminders. Instead, Malaysia is focusing on diplomatic efforts with Indonesia to address the issue.

site_title: Fight to save James Baldwin's Southern France home
summary: A group in France is trying to buy James Baldwin's former home in Saint-Paul-de-Vence to turn it into a writers' retreat, but faces opposition from the Baldwin family, who claim the group registered a website using the author's name without permission. The property, which was once Baldwin's tranquil retreat, is now in disrepair and will be redeveloped into apartment buildings and a swimming pool. The group, which includes an African-American dancer and the daughter of Alice Walker, aims to preserve Baldwin's legacy, but the developer plans to sell the property for 9 million euros.

site_title: SRX to launch free app that connects homebuyers to buyer agents
summary: SRX to launch a free app connecting homebuyers to buyer agents in Singapore, allowing real-time correspondence throughout the property-buying process. The app, called "SRX property", aims to facilitate a smoother transaction experience for consumers and buyer agents.

site_title: The real battle over GST is yet to begin
summary: India's Goods and Services Tax (GST) is nearing its final phase, with the determination of its rate structure and cesses. The GST Council must deliver a passable outcome to justify the reform, which has been debated for nearly a decade. The tax structure, with five proposed slabs, may be regressive, affecting the poor disproportionately. Luxury goods, such as gold and cars, are not taxed at a higher rate, raising concerns about the tax's pro-rich nature. The GST's impact on state finances and the economy will depend on its effective implementation, with the country watching closely as it enters its final critical phase.

site_title: Patent case: Samsung units ordered to pay 80m yuan to Huawei in China
summary: A Chinese court ordered three Samsung units to pay 80 million yuan (S$16.25 million) to Huawei Technologies for patent infringement. This verdict is Huawei's first victory against Samsung in its legal challenges over intellectual property. Huawei filed lawsuits against Samsung in China and the US, claiming infringement of smartphone patents. The court ordered the Samsung units to stop infringing Huawei's copyrights and pay the damage for over 30 million products worth $12.7 billion.

site_title: Making things tough for herself
summary: Carrie Pilby, a 19-year-old Harvard graduate, navigates her isolated life in New York City. With an aversion to human interaction, she struggles with relationships and friendships. Directed by Susan Johnson and adapted from Caren Lissner's novel, the film attempts to capture the magic of Diary of a Teenage Girl, but falls short. Carrie's therapist, Dr. Petrov, encourages her to meet people, get a pet, and form meaningful connections, but her grouchy demeanor hinders her progress. The film explores the challenges of being young, single, and adrift in the city.

site_title: Who won and who lost in IMDA's spectrum auction?
summary: The Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) held a spectrum auction in Singapore, resulting in a record-breaking S$1.14 billion spent by four telcos (Singtel, StarHub, M1, and TPG) for 175 MHz of spectrum. The final prices were four to seven times higher than the reserve price, surprising the market. Singtel, with its significant size and earnings, is expected to amortise the spectrum cost easily, while M1 and StarHub face challenges due to their smaller size and lower earnings. TPG's entry into the market with 60 MHz of spectrum at a low price may impact the incumbents' ability to retain customers.

site_title: Cohn backs policy that forces banks to rethink how they do business: sources
summary: White House Economic Adviser Gary Cohn expressed support for a policy that separates banks' consumer-lending businesses from their investment banks, echoing President Trump's desire to bring back the Glass-Steagall Act. This proposal aims to reduce the influence of Wall Street on Washington policy and allow smaller banks to fail without threatening the economy. The remarks surprised lawmakers and banking executives, who had expected a more cautious stance from a former top Wall Street executive. The exact details of an updated Glass-Steagall law remain unclear, but the move has sparked concerns about the potential impact on the financial industry.

site_title: Host Italy promises a G-7 with geopolitical focus
summary: Italy is hosting a G-7 foreign ministers meeting ahead of the annual summit of presidents and prime ministers in May, with a focus on geopolitical issues. The meeting, which includes US President Donald Trump's first scheduled visit to Europe, aims to discuss protectionism, climate change, and the ongoing turmoil in Ukraine. Italy, which has been preparing for the summit despite the slow transition of the Trump administration, is promoting stability in Libya and tackling migration issues. The G-7 will also address the nuclear standoff with North Korea and the territorial disputes in the South China Sea.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Yunfeng's robo-adviser app targets the masses
summary: Yunfeng Financial Group, backed by Alibaba-billionaire Jack Ma, has launched a robo-adviser app called Youyu to manage the wealth of regular Chinese and Hong Kong investors. The app targets those with at least $800 to invest and aims to attract tens of thousands of investors by the end of this year. The service partners with 13 global mutual and money-market funds, providing investment advice based on risk tolerance and personal decisions. This move aims to expand Yunfeng's services beyond its roots as a brokerage and cater to a traditionally neglected market segment.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing close in on Qantas' ultra-long haul dream
summary: Airbus and Boeing are close to offering commercial flights from Sydney to London, a 20-hour journey, potentially within 5 years if oil prices stay around $70 per barrel. Qantas, an Australian carrier, is pushing for non-stop flights, which could charge a 20% premium and differentiate its product. The airline aims to offset higher fuel costs by saving on stopover costs. Airbus has increased the range of its A350-900ULR to 9,700 nautical miles, while Boeing's 777-8 could carry around 280 passengers on the route.

site_title: CDL prices first green bond in S'pore
summary: CDL, a Singapore property developer, became the first local company to sell a green bond, raising S$100 million at 1.98% per annum. The funds will be used to repay a loan to CDL Properties, which owns Republic Plaza, a building that saves over S$1.2 million annually on energy and water consumption. This move is part of CDL's commitment to sustainability and aligns with the Green Bond Principles. Moody's expects global green bond issuances to reach US$206 billion this year, more than doubling from 2016.

site_title: HDB resale volume surges 75%, prices rise 0.3% in March: SRX data
summary: Resale prices of HDB flats in Singapore rose 0.3% in March, driven by increased volume and higher prices in mature and non-mature estates. The surge in resale volume, 75.4% higher than February, was attributed to a shorter month and additional CPF housing grants for first-time buyers. Resale prices have fallen 0.6% in the first quarter of 2017 and 0.1% year-on-year, with volume increasing 14.1% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: What might the new OSIM be worth?
summary: Singapore's V3 Group, formerly OSIM, is set to relist in Hong Kong with a potentially richer valuation than its 2016 delisting. The new OSIM is powered by luxury tea retailer TWG Tea and homegrown store fixtures manufacturer Futuristic, which contributed S$15 million and S$10 million to the bottom line, respectively. The company's core massage products business has declined, but TWG's tea distribution business can generate high net margins. With a buoyant market and rising investor sentiment, V3 Group's valuation may exceed S$1 billion, despite concerns over a potential conglomerate discount and the ongoing China hard landing.

site_title: ChemChina's takeover of agriculture giant Syngenta gets EU nod
summary: China's ChemChina has received EU approval to acquire Swiss farm chemical and seed company Syngenta in a $43 billion deal, marking the largest Chinese takeover of a foreign company. The acquisition aims to upgrade productivity and increase influence over the world's food supply, as China seeks to feed its growing and increasingly affluent population. The deal is part of a global consolidation in the agricultural chemical industry, with Dow Chemicals and DuPont also working to close their merger. The acquisition has raised concerns about genetically modified food and competition in the industry, with EU officials requiring ChemChina to sell prized assets to appease regulators.

site_title: OCBC Bank chairman volunteers for 26% pay cut
summary: OCBC Bank chairman Ooi Sang Kuang took a 26% pay cut in 2016, reducing his chairman fees from S$1.8 million to S$1.4 million. The bank's CEO, Samuel Tsien, also took a 20% pay cut to S$8.3 million. The pay cuts came amid a difficult economic environment and higher non-performing loans. The move was seen as a gesture by Ooi, who was the only chairman of the local banks to make the cut, while his counterparts at DBS and UOB also saw lower pay due to similar challenges.

site_title: Czech crown surges to 3 1/2-year high
summary: The Czech crown surged 1.5% to its highest level against the euro in 3 1/2 years, reaching 27 per euro, after the Czech National Bank scrapped the cap on the currency. The move was seen as limited, with little impact on other currencies and markets. The euro edged down to US$1.0659, while the crown jumped 1.6% against the US dollar. The central bank reiterated its willingness to intervene if necessary, but analysts expect it to maintain a trading range of 1.25-1.29 crowns per euro.

site_title: GP Hotels' privatisation bid declared unconditional
summary: GP Hotels' privatisation bid has been declared unconditional with major shareholder Koh Wee Meng controlling 90% of the company's shares. The offer of 36.5 cents per share, launched in February, remains open until April 27, 2017. This move comes after Mr. Koh's stake increased to 71.86% prior to the offer. The company will become private with the successful completion of the offer, marking a significant change in its ownership structure.

site_title: Startups AdAsia, 99.co raise US$20m in Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based startups 99.co and AdAsia Holdings have secured nearly $20 million in Series A funding, signaling investors' confidence in early-stage startups. 99.co, a property search portal, raised $7.9 million to expand into new markets and improve its tech offerings, while AdAsia, an advertising technology firm, secured $12 million to accelerate its integration of AI and machine learning. Both companies plan to use the funds to grow their teams and expand their offerings, with 99.co aiming to become a unicorn in the next five years.

site_title: Exquisite art from 'exquisite corpse' game
summary: Four international artists - Carsten Holler, Tobias Rehberger, Anri Sala, and Rirkrit Tiravanija - collaborated on a "cadavre exquis" art game, creating large-scale artworks that are playful, clever, and exuberant. Each artist contributed a portion of the artwork without seeing the previous part, resulting in unexpected yet effective combinations of familiar forms and images. The artists were surprised by how well their individual contributions came together, with Tiravanija stating that a common aesthetic and spirit guided the final result.

site_title: Twitter creates 'lite' version for data-starved users
summary: Twitter launches Twitter Lite, a faster version of its mobile service aimed at users with sporadic connections or little data, particularly in emerging markets. The browser-based app has a similar experience to WhatsApp and is designed to reduce data consumption by 40% and 70% with additional features. The launch targets countries such as India, Indonesia, and Brazil, where Twitter has struggled to gain traction. The move is seen as an attempt to expand the company's user base and compete with other social media platforms.

site_title: After SGX exit, OSIM heads for HK listing as V3 Group
summary: OSIM International, formerly listed on Singapore Exchange (SGX), is relisting in Hong Kong under the name V3 Group. The company plans to use IPO proceeds to acquire homegrown store fixtures maker Futuristic and repay a S$321.9m loan. V3 Group aims to expand its business, finance new store openings, and repay debts. Analysts suggest the Hong Kong listing will command a better valuation due to its deeper market and liquidity. The company's founder, Ron Sim, will serve as executive chairman and CEO of V3 Group.

site_title: Policymaker Lacker's departure leaves US Fed on shakier ground
summary: US Federal Reserve policymaker Jeffrey Lacker resigned due to his involvement in the 2012 leak of confidential information on monetary policy. His departure leaves the Fed on shakier ground, and the Trump administration is expected to reshape the board by filling several empty seats.

site_title: US restaurant chain Panera to be sold for US$7.5b
summary: US restaurant chain Panera is set to be sold to JAB Holding Company for $7.5 billion, including debt, following a deal agreed by a European billionaire family. The acquisition is the latest in JAB's string of purchases, including Keurig Green Mountain and Krispy Kreme. Panera's founder and CEO Ronald Shaich expressed support for the deal, citing the company's commitment to long-term decision-making and stakeholder interests. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter, subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A Singtel consortium has partnered with Alcatel Submarine Networks to build a new international subsea cable system between Australia and South-east Asia, enhancing connection speed and reliability. Meanwhile, Singapore Myanmar Investco will introduce retail and F&B operations in Yangon's Junction City. Lian Beng Group Ltd has executed a non-binding letter of intent to sell eight strata office units in Prudential Tower.

site_title: Strong global IPO activity in Q1: EY
summary: Global IPO activity surged in Q1 2017, with 369 deals raising $33.7 billion, a 92% year-over-year increase. Asia-Pacific, led by China, dominated the market, accounting for 70% of global IPOs and 48% of proceeds. The New York Stock Exchange was the most active exchange by proceeds, with the US$3.4 billion Snap Inc IPO and US$1.8 billion Invitation Homes Inc listing contributing to this. This marked the strongest Q1 for global IPOs since 2007, with EY predicting accelerated growth in 2017 despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Reject privatisation offer for Kingboard Copper: independent directors
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil (KCF) Holdings' independent directors have advised shareholders to reject a S$0.40 per-share takeover-cum-privatisation offer by Provenance Capital, citing the offer as "not fair and not reasonable". The independent directors rely on valuation summary letters from Roma Appraisals Ltd, which estimated the company's revalued net tangible assets (RNTA) per share at S$0.7086. The offer price represents a 43.6% discount to the RNTA per share, with the majority of the offer price allocated to the company's significant cash balance.

site_title: How race and creed colour our friendships
summary: A 1991 Singaporean play, "This Chord and Others," by Haresh Sharma, remains relevant today due to its universal exploration of friendship and local race relations. The story revolves around three colleagues, Sukdev, Gerald, and Thomas, whose bond is tested when Thomas, an Eurasian, faces prejudice and the others struggle with their own identities and cultural differences. The play's agelessness lies in its honest portrayal of Singapore's social dynamics, with a recent restaging showcasing the actors' ensemble work and physical theatre, elevating the characters to a more engaging level.

site_title: Coldplay goes Up and Up in sold-out shows
summary: Coldplay sold out two consecutive nights at the National Stadium in Singapore, drawing over 100,000 fans to their A Head Full of Dreams World Tour. The band's energetic performance featured a mix of old and new songs, with visually stunning light and fireworks displays. Coldplay's popularity has grown significantly since their 2001 co-headlining show with Travis at the Singapore Indoor Stadium. The band's charismatic frontman Chris Martin joked about being "fresh" after a break from touring, and the sold-out shows showcased the band's continued musical and physical prowess.

site_title: Ex-ST Marine senior executive jailed 16 weeks
summary: A former senior executive at ST Marine, Tan Mong Seng, was sentenced to 16 weeks' imprisonment for making false entries in petty cash vouchers for entertainment expenses, totaling S$419,994. Tan is one of seven executives embroiled in a corruption scandal that began in 2014. This conviction marks the sixth person from ST Marine to receive a sentence, with another awaiting sentencing. The company has cooperated fully with the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau since 2011.

site_title: Ivan Heng: 'I intend to age disgracefully'
summary: Singaporean actor Ivan Heng is set to reprise his role as Zsa Zsa in the musical La Cage Aux Folles, adapting the 1983 Broadway show for the local audience. Heng, 53, is known for his versatility and has played a range of roles, including female impersonations, which he finds liberating. He believes that female impersonation is not just about dressing up, but about revealing character and exploring the complexities of gender. Heng aims to "age disgracefully" and is excited to bring the musical back to the stage, with further localisation to make it "completely Singaporean".

images.alt_text: Heng dances up a storm with the chorus girls and boys in the musical.
Ivan Heng in his corset, plumes and wig to play Zsa Zsa in La Cage Aux Folles.
On average, Heng takes about two-and-a-half hours getting ready to play a woman and just one hour to play a man.

site_title: Infiniti mentors 7 startups in Singapore over next 8 weeks
summary: Infiniti, a luxury carmaker, is mentoring seven high-potential startups in Singapore over the next eight weeks in the areas of smart mobility and connected technology. The startups, from the US, Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, and Canada, have validated their business models and will receive coaching on business case, marketing, and media training. The program aims to facilitate partnerships between Infiniti and the startups, with the potential for future collaborations and investments.

site_title: India makes surprise move in bid to curb prices
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its reverse repo rate to 6% from 5.75%, while keeping the benchmark repurchase rate at 6.25%, to combat accelerating inflation. The move, seen as a surprise, aims to tighten policy and step up the fight against inflation. The RBI cited excess funds in the banking system and the government's clampdown on cash as reasons for the decision. The move is the latest in a string of policy surprises under Governor Urjit Patel, who has shifted the RBI's stance to neutral from accommodative.

site_title: ETF market still in infancy, but Singapore should keep up with it
summary: Singapore's stock market, while significant in Southeast Asia, is still underdeveloped, with many smaller companies and lower liquidity. However, the country is well-positioned to become a hub for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the region, thanks to its regulatory expertise and established network of financial market participants. The recent listing of the One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend ETF, which includes stocks from frontier markets like Vietnam, is a step in this direction. Despite challenges such as tracking error and currency volatility, Singapore is on the right path to becoming a major player in the Asean ETF market.

site_title: WSG ropes in foreign recruitment firms to help jobless PMETs
summary: Workforce Singapore (WSG) has partnered with two foreign recruitment firms, Ingeus Pte Ltd and another firm to be named, to help jobless PMETs in Singapore. The two-year pilot project aims to provide career-matching services and coaching to those who have been seeking employment for at least three months or made redundant. The firms will localise their know-how and provide free help to PMETs, with payment based on outcome. This move comes after WSG failed to get desired results with local employment agencies, which often prioritised employed workers over job-seekers.

images.alt_text: After failing to get the desired results with local employment agencies, Workforce Singapore (WSG) has turned to foreign recruitment firms for help to tackle joblessness among local professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) here.

site_title: SGX forms regulatory spin-off with veteran lawyer as chairman
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has formed a regulatory spin-off, SGX Regco, with veteran lawyer Tan Cheng Han as its chairman. SGX Regco will handle regulatory functions, starting in the third quarter of 2017, and will have its own board of directors separate from SGX's board. The move aims to enhance governance and segregate commercial and regulatory obligations. Tan Cheng Han, a senior counsel, will step down from other directorships to ensure independence.

site_title: Trump's moves won't stop coal's decline
summary: US President Donald Trump's efforts to revive the coal industry by rolling back the Clean Power Plan have made little difference to electric utilities, which continue to plan for a transition away from coal. Despite the announcement, utilities like Southern Co and American Electric Power say they have no plans to build new coal plants and will instead rely on cheaper natural gas and renewable sources like wind and solar power. The industry shift is driven by economics, including the expected introduction of a carbon tax, and is not environmentally driven.

site_title: Bar food grows up at Atlas
summary: The Atlas Bar, located in Parkview Square, Singapore, offers a unique dining experience that combines high art and fine dining. The bar features an ornate decor, a wide selection of champagnes, wines, and spirits, and a menu crafted by executive chef Daniele Sperindo. While the food has an uphill battle to dominate the conversation, the chef shows flashes of ingenuity and strong technical grounding. Standout dishes include raw oysters, mini croque monsieur, charred octopus, and desserts such as madeleines and a complex chocolate composition. Despite some missteps, the chef has potential to create a new identity for Atlas. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: Out with the old, in with the new Chianti
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The current releases of Chianti Classico, a classic Italian wine, are impressive. The 2010 Isole e Olena Chianti Classico Gran Selezione DOCG is a prime example, with a rich, fragrant bouquet and perfectly ripe fruit. The new DOCG rules, introduced in 1996, have led to a significant improvement in wine quality, with a minimum 80% Sangiovese requirement and a maximum 20% of other permitted grapes. The Chianti Classico Gran Selezione is the highest level of wine in the appellation, requiring exclusive use of the winery's own grapes and stricter regulations.

site_title: Elections a step closer as Thai King endorses new charter
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn ratified a military-backed constitution in a televised ceremony, paving the way for an election in late 2018. The new charter enhances the power of appointed officials to block elected politicians, and foreign investors are pouring money into Thailand as a result. An election is expected to take place in the fourth quarter of 2018, following a 19-month timeline outlined in the constitution. The move marks a step towards representative democracy in Thailand after a 2014 coup.

site_title: Outlook across most of Asia continues to brighten: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has released a report stating that most economies in Asia are well-positioned to weather potential short-term shocks, despite threats to global trade and concerns over capital outflows. The ADB's chief economist, Yasuyuki Sawada, notes that the region's growth is expected to slow to 5.7% this year, but remain stable through next year, driven by higher external demand and domestic reforms. South Asia is projected to grow at 7% this year, with India's growth expected to pick up to 7.4% in fiscal year 2017.

site_title: Overheated housing markets may hamper Canada's growth -RBC
summary: Royal Bank of Canada CEO Dave McKay warned that Canada's overheated housing markets could hinder economic growth, urging federal and provincial governments to address the issue. Toronto home sales surged in March, fueling concerns of a real estate bubble. McKay called for a multi-faceted solution to address supply constraints and speculative forces, and emphasized the need for coordinated government interventions. He also defended RBC's sales practices, stating that only a small fraction of customers raised concerns about account openings. The issue highlights the pressure on Ontario to cool its housing market.

site_title: Mercatus buys Guthrie-Lee Kim Tah stake in Jurong Point
summary: Mercatus Co-operative, an NTUC social enterprise, has acquired a 658,000 sq ft commercial net lettable area in Jurong Point for S$2.2 billion, working out to S$3,343 per square foot. The deal reflects a 4.2% net yield. This marks the largest property investment sales deal so far this year, and Mercatus is expected to complete the transaction by July. The sale follows an expressions of interest exercise launched in the fourth quarter of last year, and analysts expect Mercatus to buy out DBS's and Golden Village's space to gain full ownership of Jurong Point.

site_title: Healthway to hold dialogue session over convertible notes
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation will hold a dialogue session on April 12, 2017, with Gateway Partners regarding the proposed S$60 million issuance of convertible notes. The session, moderated by David Gerald, aims to inform shareholders about the proposed deal. Shareholders are required to RSVP by April 11, 2017, to participate in the meeting.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine is expected to benefit from the potential acquisition of the US$568 million harsh environment semi-submersible West Rigel, removing a risky order from its balance sheet and allowing it to deleverage. Spackman Entertainment Group has acquired a Korean movie equipment business for S$1.12 million, expected to be earnings-accretive and provide a recurring business stream. The European Parliament's new palm oil resolutions may lower future EU demand, negatively impacting the agribusiness sector, which CIMB maintains its average CPO price forecast of RM2,600 per tonne for 2017.

site_title: Transocean said to be eyeing Sembmarine's West Rigel rig
summary: Transocean is reportedly eyeing the US$568 million West Rigel rig currently held by Sembmarine under a standstill agreement with Seadrill's subsidiary. A potential acquisition by Transocean could "free up capital" for Sembmarine, bolstering its cash flows. The deal would be a significant move for Transocean, which has been acquiring rigs at discounted prices. If materialized, it would also alleviate insolvency risk for Sembmarine, which has dozens of rigs yet to be delivered from its order books.

site_title: ECB calls for tougher regulation of foreign bank branches
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has proposed stricter regulations on foreign bank branches in the European Union, requiring them to be included in a holding company with higher capital requirements. This move aims to increase the resilience of foreign banks and reduce the risk of financial instability. The proposal, which is part of a draft EU law, would impact US and Asian lenders, including British banks after Brexit, and is expected to raise costs and bureaucracy for operating in the EU.

site_title: US:Wall St little changed ahead of Trump-Xi meeting
summary: US stocks were little changed on Thursday ahead of a meeting between President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The meeting's focus is on US-China trade ties and North Korea's arms program. Investors are reassessing bets due to concerns over Trump's ability to deliver on pro-growth promises. The Federal Reserve hinted at changes to its bond investment policy, and earnings season is approaching with S&P 500 companies expected to have risen 10.1%.

site_title: Chairman of Parkway Life Reit's management board resigns as part of 'succession planning'
summary: Parkway Life Reit's chairman, Lim Kok Hoong, resigns as part of succession planning, effective April 24, 2017. He will be succeeded by Ho Kian Guan. The Reit also appoints Cheah Sui Ling as independent director, who will also lead the audit committee and chair the board alongside Guan. This move is part of the Reit's strategy to ensure smooth transition and continuity.

site_title: Europe's other populist problem
summary: European governments must implement structural reforms to combat right-wing populists and achieve higher long-term economic growth. Economic populism, characterized by growth and income redistribution, can emerge when policymakers and citizens are dissatisfied with the economy's performance. The eurozone's policies since the 2008 financial crisis, including high public debt and stagnant GDP growth, have contributed to the rise of populists. To address these issues, European countries should focus on resolving market problems, reducing excessive fiscal burdens, and promoting deregulation, vocational training, and education. By doing so, they can cut taxes on labor, boost innovation, and avoid laying new debt traps.

site_title: Chinese university buys campus space near Oxford
summary: China's Peking University has agreed to buy a 19th-century manor house in southern England, Foxcombe Hall, for a multimillion-dollar deal. The campus, located near Oxford, will serve as a branch of Peking University's HSBC Business School. The price of the transaction has not been disclosed, but the estate was originally listed at £7 million (S$12.2 million). The campus, spanning 6.17 hectares, features a vaulted banqueting hall, Italian-style gardens, and a lake. The deal is part of Peking University's expansion into international academia, ranking 71 globally.

site_title: Bank of England plans liquidity tool for Islamic banks
summary: The Bank of England plans to develop a sharia-compliant liquidity tool for Islamic banks, aiming to attract business from the Middle East and South East Asia. The tool, a fund-based deposit model, would help Islamic lenders meet regulatory requirements for liquid asset buffers. The facility, expected to be ready by spring 2018, would be comparable in pricing to conventional tools and use an agency contract known as 'wakala'. Stakeholders have until May 23 to provide feedback on the proposal.

site_title: Weak session in wake of Wall St reversal
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 0.96 points to 3,175.59 amid weak sentiment following Wall Street's reversal on Wednesday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reversed a 200-point rise to close in the red due to concerns over tax reform and the Federal Reserve's March meeting, which suggested three rate hikes. Trading was subdued, with 160 rises and 325 falls in turnover worth S$1.03 billion.

site_title: Russian police find explosives similar to device used by suicide bomber
summary: Russian police discovered explosives similar to those used in a suicide bombing that killed 14 people at a St. Petersburg metro station on Monday. The explosives were found in an apartment building in the city, and several people were detained. Authorities believe a string of bomb attacks may have been planned in the city involving a group of plotters. The discovery raises concerns about potential accomplices, including individuals from central Asian states who have moved to Russia.

site_title: Air travel demand up in Feb, despite US travel restrictions
summary: Global air travel demand rose 4.8% in February, driven by lower fares and improving economies, with no significant impact from the US travel ban. Middle Eastern carriers saw a 9.5% increase in demand. Capacity and load factor also rose, with a 2.7% increase in capacity and a 1.6 percentage point rise in load factor to 79.5%. Falling fares have led to a 10% drop in real terms over the last year, putting pressure on airline earnings. IATA Director General Alexandre de Juniac criticized the US travel ban, citing a lack of consultation with the airline industry.

images.alt_text: Global demand for air travel rose 4.8 per cent in February, thanks to lower fares and improving economies, with no major impact from an attempted US travel ban, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) said on Thursday.

site_title: OCBC chairman asked for lower fees in light of difficult economic environment
summary: OCBC Bank chairman Ooi Sang Kuang took a 26% pay cut in 2016 due to the difficult economic environment, bringing his total pay to S$1.6 million. This was the only bank chairman among the three Singapore banks to lower his fees. OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien also took a 20% pay cut, while DBS CEO Piyush Gupta reduced his pay by 23%. The lower pay was largely due to higher non-performing loans, which affected all three banks.

site_title: BP slashes CEO's remuneration by 40% after shareholder backlash
summary: BP has reduced CEO Bob Dudley's annual remuneration package by 40%, cutting it from $19.4 million to $11.6 million, following a shareholder backlash against his pay deal. The move comes after the company made changes to its remuneration policy, including a 25% reduction in bonuses for reaching certain targets. The cut is in response to growing scrutiny of executives' pay in Britain, following corporate scandals.

images.alt_text: BP has trimmed Chief Executive Bob Dudley's annual remuneration package by almost US$8 million to US$11.6 million, it said in its annual report on Thursday, after shareholders last year voted against his pay deal.

site_title: SGX forms new regulatory unit; names Prof Tan Cheng Han as first chairman
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has established a new regulatory unit, Singapore Exchange Regulation Pte Ltd (SGX Regco), to handle its regulatory functions. Prof Tan Cheng Han, a veteran lawyer and director, has been appointed as the first chairman of SGX Regco. The creation of SGX Regco aims to enhance governance and segregate regulatory functions from commercial activities, ensuring independence and objectivity. The new unit will undertake front-line regulatory functions and have a separate board of directors from SGX.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.110 points to close at 1,739.560 on Thursday, with 3.86 billion lots valued at RM3 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 526 to 452, resulting in a lower market performance.

site_title: New members appointed to Council of Presidential Advisers
summary: The President of Singapore has appointed two new members and two alternate members to the Council of Presidential Advisers (CPA). Lim Chee Onn, former Keppel Corp chairman, and Stephen Lee, former Singapore Airlines chairman, have been made members, while Lim and Lee remain as alternate members.

site_title: Lian Beng-led consortium to sell another 8 office units at Prudential Tower
summary: A consortium led by Lian Beng Group Ltd has signed a non-binding letter of intent to sell 8 office units at Prudential Tower, totaling 55,711 sq ft, to an unrelated third party. The sale includes nearly all available office units in the building. The buyer has a 6-week exclusive period to conduct due diligence, with an option to extend for 2 weeks. The consortium, Epic Land Pte Ltd, owns 32% of the building and has been selling strata units in the past few years.

site_title: Country Garden says some buyers of Malaysia project want to cancel deals
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese property developer, says a small number of buyers (fewer than 60) of its $100 billion Malaysia project, Forest City, want to cancel their purchases due to Beijing's capital controls on overseas property investments. Buyers will be charged a penalty of 10-30% of deposits if they cancel. The move affects both buyers and developers, with Country Garden halting sales and Greenland Holdings ceasing travel-related support services. The capital controls have created uncertainty over the developers' business plans, with some considering shifting marketing focus away from China.

site_title: Bowie's former apartment on sale in New York
summary: David Bowie's former New York apartment, featuring views of Central Park and a Yamaha piano, is up for sale for US$6.5 million. The ninth-floor condominium, where Bowie and his wife Iman lived from 1992 to 2002, includes three bedrooms. The apartment was the rocker's residence before he moved to the Soho neighborhood, where he died in 2016 after a secret battle with cancer. The listing was provided by real estate agency Corcoran.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco to open retail, F&B outlets in downtown Yangon
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) will open retail and F&B outlets in Yangon's Junction City, a mixed development with a 260,000 sqm built-up area. The group plans to open up to 10 retail brands and F&B concepts, including Coach, Aigner, Benetton, and Shiseido, in a five-year lease. Other outlets include Crystal Jade Kitchen and Japanese ramen restaurant IPPUDO. This marks SMI's entry into Myanmar's retail and F&B market.

site_title: India's central bank holds rates at 6.25 per cent
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), held interest rates at 6.25% during its latest monetary policy committee meeting. This decision was in line with analysts' expectations and cited inflationary pressures from a new tax reform and a possible poor monsoon. RBI Governor Urjit Patel attributed the decision to uncertainty surrounding the monsoon and the one-off effects of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) set to be introduced on July 1. The RBI forecast inflation to be 4.5% for the first half and 5% for the second half of the fiscal year 2017-18.

site_title: BlackRock sees Singapore office market improving as supply tapers
summary: BlackRock expects Singapore's office market to improve as supply tapers off, with prime office rents dropping by over 10% in the past two years. Analysts predict limited new developments until 2021, creating a landlord's market and attracting investors. BlackRock is considering investments in malls and industrial assets in Singapore, and is also looking to raise its real estate exposure in Japan and Australia. The firm's Asia-Pacific head notes strong investment interest from funds and corporates, despite Singapore being ranked 21st out of 22 Asia Pacific real estate markets.

site_title: Former Oz PM Bob Hawke launches lager to round of applause
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke launched his own craft lager, "Hawke's Lager," at a Sydney pub, receiving a round of applause. The lager will be served at 11 pubs across Sydney and Newcastle, with cans bearing his likeness to be released on ANZAC Day. Hawke, 87, plans to donate any profits to environmental charity Landcare, which he established during his prime ministerial term.

site_title: Ryanair to pivot growth away from UK for next 2 years due to Brexit
summary: Ryanair, Europe's largest airline, plans to pivot its growth away from the UK over the next two years due to Brexit. The airline had initially planned to grow 15% in the UK but posted 6% growth instead. Finance director Neil Sorahan stated that Ryanair is shifting its focus away from the UK. This decision is likely a response to the uncertainty and potential economic disruption caused by the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: 7-Eleven operator to buy US stores from Sunoco for 364.6b yen
summary: 7-Eleven operator Seven & i Holdings Co. agreed to buy US convenience stores and petrol stations from Sunoco LP for about $3.3 billion. The deal, valued at 364.6 billion yen, is part of Seven & i's goal to reach 10,000 North American outlets. The purchase comes as traditional retailers face weak sales due to changing consumer preferences. The deal will add 1,108 Sunoco stores to 7-Eleven's US operations, further expanding the convenience store chain.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

OSIM International, delisted from the Singapore Exchange, re-emerged as V3 Group seeking a Hong Kong listing. Sabana Reit will hold an EGM on April 28. Workforce Singapore has appointed two private-sector placement providers to support PMET jobseekers. OCBC chairman asked for lower fees amid economic difficulties. HDB resale prices rose 0.3% in March, while SIA and Ethiopian Airlines expand their codeshare agreement starting June 1. Singapore stocks declined due to Wall Street's reversal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip on Fed minutes before Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday amid concerns about the Federal Reserve scaling back stimulus, with investors also focusing on a looming meeting between US and Chinese presidents. The benchmark Hang Seng index dropped to 24,273.72 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index fell 0.9%. Analysts say the Fed's potential balance sheet reduction and trade tensions ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting are key factors contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Fed's quantitative tightening looms over Asia as yields the key
summary: The Federal Reserve's quantitative tightening is expected to impact Asian emerging markets, particularly bonds and equities. However, if 10-year US Treasury yields remain below 3%, investors may seek higher returns elsewhere. This marks uncharted waters for the Fed, following unprecedented rounds of quantitative easing. Meanwhile, emerging markets continue to enjoy strong capital flows, with Thailand considering measures to limit gains in the baht. The outcome of the Fed's asset wind-down and its impact on Asian markets will be closely watched.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte plans to visit disputed South China Sea island
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte plans to visit the disputed South China Sea island of Thitu in June, where he will raise the Philippine flag and fortify the island with barracks. Thitu is near China's militarized manmade island of Subi Reef, which is part of the Spratlys archipelago. The visit is seen as a show of strength for the Philippines' claim to the island, which is also claimed by China, Brunei, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Taiwan.

site_title: Update:Thai king signs constitution, paving way for election
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn signed a new constitution, paving the way for an election expected late next year. The constitution is the 20th since the end of absolute monarchy in 1932, but critics say it will maintain military influence over politics. The move comes after the 2014 coup, which the military government has promised to restore democracy. The signing gives the government a crucial step towards holding elections, despite concerns over the constitution's impact on democracy.

site_title: Euro hits three-week low as Draghi cools tightening expectations
summary: The euro hit a three-week low against the US dollar after ECB chief Mario Draghi stated there's no need to deviate from the ECB's policy path, which includes record-low interest rates and bond-buying until at least the end of the year. Despite Draghi's comments, ECB policymakers later indicated that markets had priced in policy tightening too aggressively, causing the euro to drop. This move reverses the currency's recent jump above $1.09 in March, which was fueled by concerns about an interest rate hike in early 2018.

site_title: Australia shares slip on Fed, Trump-Xi summit anxiety; NZ edge up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.34% to 5,856.30, pressured by signs the US Federal Reserve may trim its asset holdings earlier than expected and a US-China summit. Australian banks fell 0.9-1.4%, while the gold index rose 1.1%. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.34% to 7,289.52, driven by utilities and consumer stocks. The US-China summit's potential impact on trade and global markets weighed on investors' confidence.

site_title: China court orders Samsung to pay 80m yuan to Huawei over patent case
summary: A Chinese court has ordered Samsung's Chinese subsidiaries to pay 80 million yuan (S$16.3 million) to Huawei Technologies over patent infringement. The Quanzhou Intermediary Court ruled that three Samsung units infringed on a patent held by Huawei Device Co Limited. Samsung said it will respond after reviewing the ruling, while Huawei was unavailable for comment. This is the latest development in a long-standing patent dispute between the two technology giants.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won hit 3-week closing lows as geopolitical tensions weigh
summary: South Korean stocks and the won closed at three-week lows due to geopolitical tensions, particularly after North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.4% to 2,152.75, while the won dropped 0.8% to 1,133.2 to the US dollar, its lowest level since March 15. Foreign investors sold 93.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares, marking a fourth consecutive net selling session. The tensions come ahead of a US-China summit discussing North Korea's arms program.

site_title: EU's Tusk to meet May in London: official
summary: EU President Donald Tusk is set to meet British Prime Minister Theresa May in London, as the two sides prepare for Brexit talks. The meeting comes after the European Parliament adopted "red lines" for the negotiations, stating that divorce terms must be agreed before any discussion of a new trade deal. No specific details or agenda were announced for the meeting.

images.alt_text: EU President Donald Tusk will meet British prime minister Theresa May in London later Thursday, his office announced, as the two sides prepare for tough Brexit talks.

site_title: Ex-ST Marine executive jailed for conspiracy to make false entries in petty cash vouchers
summary: A former executive at ST Marine, Tan Mong Seng, was sentenced to 16 weeks' jail for conspiring to make false entries in the company's petty cash vouchers. Tan, 65, had falsified claims as reimbursement of entertainment expenses, despite no actual expenses being incurred. He was found guilty of 101 charges and had previously been convicted.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower after Fed minutes
summary: Tokyo stocks fell to a four-month low on Thursday, closing 1.40% lower at 18,597.06, due to a rise in the yen hurting exporters. Federal Reserve minutes suggested the US central bank may consider tightening monetary policy, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Unilever promises cash to shareholders after rebuffing Kraft approach
summary: Unilever has promised a multi-billion pound programme of shareholder rewards after rebuffing Kraft Heinz's US$143 billion takeover offer. The company will spend 5 billion euros on a share buyback and raise its dividend by 12% this year. Unilever aims to improve investor rewards and justify its rejection of the Kraft offer, which was sparked by a corporate rethink. The company plans to speed up a cost-saving plan, targeting a 20% underlying operating margin by 2020, and will take on more debt to finance acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Unilever promised a multi-billion pound programme of shareholder rewards on Thursday after a corporate rethink sparked by a takeover approach from Kraft Heinz, aiming to prove it can generate lucrative returns as an independent company.

site_title: Ford to launch plug-in car in China next year, electrify most by 2025
summary: Ford plans to launch a plug-in hybrid car in China in 2018 and a fully electric SUV by 2025, aiming to electrify 70% of its Ford brand vehicles sold in China by 2025. This move follows China's efforts to reduce air pollution and promote electric vehicles. Ford's first hybrid, the Mondeo Energi sedan, will be locally made with Changan and launched early next year. The company's expansion in electric vehicles comes as Beijing sets strict fuel economy targets and subsidizes electric vehicle models.

site_title: No ECB interest rate rise before end of bond-buying: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi announced that interest rates will not rise before the end of the ECB's mass bond-buying program. Draghi stated that inflation dynamics are not yet self-sustaining, and interest rates will remain low until "well after" the end of the bond-buying scheme, set to continue until December this year. The ECB's policy instruments are deliberately chained together, with bond-buying ending before interest rate hikes. Draghi expressed confidence in a budding eurozone recovery, but noted "geo-political risks" and inflation dependence on central bank interventions.

site_title: Gold firm as US dollar, equities fall ahead of Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Gold prices remained stable on Thursday, influenced by a weaker US dollar and cautious investor sentiment ahead of a potentially tense meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Spot gold inched down 0.1% to $1,253.75 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.6% to $1,255.60. The market's focus on the Trump-Xi meeting led to a decline in equities.

site_title: China: Stocks end at 4-month high, aided by new economic zone plan
summary: China's stocks ended at a 4-month high, rising 0.3-0.4% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively. The gains were driven by the government's new Xiongan special zone near Beijing, which is expected to boost infrastructure stocks. Indexes tracking major infrastructure players surged, with China State Construction Engineering and China Railway Group jumping 6% and 5%, respectively. Investors remain optimistic despite a private survey showing China's service sector expanded at its weakest pace in six months.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall with broader Asia ahead of Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on Thursday, mirroring broader Asia's decline ahead of the US-China meeting between President Trump and Xi Jinping. The main Taiex index closed at 9,885.83 points, its largest one-day percentage gain since November. The Taiwan dollar also softened to NT$30.520 per US dollar. Investors are cautious due to trade tensions and uncertainty about the meeting's outcome, leading to a decline in the region's markets.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink with Wall St after Fed minutes
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, following Wall Street's sell-off after Federal Reserve minutes revealed a plan to tighten monetary policy. The Fed's decision to stop reinvesting in its US$4.5 trillion-worth of Treasury bills could reduce the amount of cash in the system, sparking concerns about global financial markets. Despite a better-than-forecast jobs report, investors were spooked by the Fed's move, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul experiencing significant losses.

site_title: Singapore to release Monetary Policy Statement, advance GDP estimates on April 13
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore will release its semi-annual Monetary Policy Statement on April 13, along with advance GDP estimates for the first quarter of 2017. This release will provide insights into the country's economic performance and monetary policy decisions.

site_title: SIA, Ethiopian Airlines to expand codeshare agreement from June 1
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Ethiopian Airlines are expanding their codeshare agreement, starting June 1, to provide seamless connectivity between Asia and Africa. SIA passengers will have access to Ethiopian Airlines' inter-African network, while Ethiopian Airlines passengers will be able to access multiple destinations in Australia, China, Japan, and Southeast Asia. The expansion aims to offer customers more travel options and convenience. The partnership is significant, following the announcement of Ethiopian Airlines' daily non-stop services from Addis Ababa to Singapore in June.

site_title: Thai king to sign junta's new constitution
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn will sign the country's new constitution, which critics say entrenches army influence and limits democracy. The charter, touted as a cure for political instability, was rewritten by the king to include tougher controls on lawmakers and a fully appointed senate. Analysts say it reverses progress made in the 1997 "People's Constitution" and harks back to Cold War-era "guided democracy." The military hopes the charter will pave the way for elections by mid-2018, but opponents warn it will only offer a neutered form of democracy.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall in broad sell-off after Fed minutes
summary: European shares fell 0.6% in early trade after the Federal Reserve's minutes raised concerns over high stock market valuations, leading to a broad sell-off. Banks, autos, and commodity stocks were particularly affected, with the Stoxx 600 index down 0.6% and the FTSE down 0.7%. The only sector in positive territory was real estate, which rose 0.5%. The decline was attributed to record US crude inventories and lower crude prices.

site_title: Twitter creates 'lite' version for data-starved users
summary: Twitter launches Twitter Lite, a faster version of its mobile service for users with limited data or sporadic connections, particularly in emerging markets. The web-based version is nearly identical to the app, with a focus on users outside the US. This move follows similar low-data mobile apps from Facebook and YouTube, aiming to expand Twitter's reach in underserved areas.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc is launching a faster version of its mobile service on Wednesday aimed at people with sporadic connections or little data on their smartphone plans.

site_title: Australia and New Zealand companies whiplashed by China import regulations
summary: New Zealand and Australian companies are experiencing a downturn in sales due to China's changing import regulations. Daigou, unofficial shopping agents, are reducing purchases amid uncertainty about future regulations. Companies such as Comvita Ltd and Bellamy's have seen their shares plummet due to the decline in sales. A deal has been struck with official distributors to redirect sales to formal channels, with Comvita's CEO predicting it may take until next year for the daigou market to recover.

site_title: South Korea test fires 800km-range missile
summary: South Korea successfully tested a 800km-range ballistic missile, which can hit any part of North Korea, amid heightened tensions following North Korea's recent missile launch. The test comes ahead of a China-US summit, where North Korea's nuclear program is expected to be a major topic. The South Korean missile system, developed with a US security umbrella, aims to deter North Korea's nuclear threats. The new missile's successful test paves the way for its deployment this year, following further tests to ensure reliability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dipped 0.35% in early trading on Thursday, following losses on Wall Street in response to the Federal Reserve's consideration of tightening monetary policy. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,314.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.06%.

site_title: Developing Asia to fuel global growth but risks ahead: ADB
summary: Developing Asian countries, including India, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam, are expected to drive global growth over the next two years with a 5.7% increase in Asia-Pacific GDP. However, China's expansion is expected to moderate due to a slowdown in its economy, now forecasted to grow at 6.5% in 2017 and 6.2% in 2018. The Asian Development Bank warns of uncertainties from the US and Europe, particularly due to potential interest rate hikes and trade tensions, which could impact emerging economies.

site_title: Thousands of UK companies to report gender pay gap under new law
summary: Britain has become the first country to require large firms to report pay discrepancies between male and female employees under a new law. The law, which came into effect on Thursday, will cover companies with at least 250 workers and requires them to reveal pay gaps in bonus payments and publish the proportion of male and female staff across each salary bracket. The government aims to narrow the 18.1% pay gap to zero, with estimates suggesting it could add £150 billion to the country's GDP by 2025.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.3% in March; volume increases by 75.4%
summary: HDB resale prices increased 0.3% in March 2017, with 1,910 flats sold, a 75.4% rise from February. Year-over-year, prices decreased 0.1% from March 2016, while resale volume increased 14.1% from 1,674 units in March 2016.

site_title: Australia takes Apple to court over 'refusing service' claims
summary: Apple has been taken to court by Australia's consumer watchdog over allegations that the company refused to look at or repair iPads and iPhones previously serviced by a third party, violating the Australian Consumer Law. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) charged Apple with making false, misleading, or deceptive representations about consumers' rights. The case involves 275 consumers and could result in a fine of up to A$1.1 million per breach. The ACCC is seeking remedies, including financial penalties, and is highlighting the importance of consumer rights extending to software or software updates on goods sold.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slump to multi-week lows on geopolitical risk
summary: South Korean stocks slumped to multi-week lows on Thursday due to geopolitical risks, following Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump's agreement that North Korea's missile launch was a "serious threat". The won fell 0.7% to 1,132.2 to the US dollar, its lowest intraday level since March 17. Investors are concerned about Trump's firm stance on sanctions, which has triggered worries among investors and weighed on the local currency, but analysts expect the won to recover once the Trump-Xi summit is over.

site_title: More help for Singapore PMET jobseekers
summary: Workforce Singapore has appointed two overseas private-sector placement providers to offer career-matching services to local PMET jobseekers under a two-year pilot scheme called Adapt and Grow. The providers will offer customized career advisory and coaching sessions to help jobseekers assess their fit for certain job roles and industries based on their work experiences, skills, interests, and capabilities. This initiative aims to complement existing career-matching services provided by WSG and NTUC's Employability and Employment Institute.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.800 points to 1744.810. Despite this, volume was high at 148.98 million lots worth RM58.69 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 193 to 70.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 6, 2017, as investors were disheartened by the Federal Reserve meeting minutes suggesting a faster reduction of its balance sheet. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.41% to 18,784.09, while the Topix index declined 0.37% to 1,499.12.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 8.95 points to 3,167.6. Trading volume was 98.1 million shares worth S$57 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 62.

site_title: Ron Sim applies to list V3 in Hong Kong
summary: V3 Group, formerly OSIM International, is seeking a listing on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong. The company, led by Singapore's Ron Sim, is described as an Asian luxury group in lifestyle and wellness business. V3's management team is headed by Sim, who is also OSIM's founder, executive chairman, and CEO. Credit Suisse, Bank of China, and Jefferies are joint sponsors for the initial public offer.

site_title: China housing ministry calls on cities to adjust residential land supply
summary: China's housing ministry has called on cities with large unsold housing inventories to adjust land supply for residential housing. Cities with unsold inventories exceeding 36 months of sales should suspend land supply, while those under pressure from rising home prices should increase supply. The move aims to control rising home prices in major cities while supporting sales in smaller cities with a massive glut of unsold homes. The ministry's notice was released on April 1, 2017.

site_title: Trump to Abe: US to boost military defence against North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump told Japanese leader Shinzo Abe that the US will boost its military defense against North Korea, following a ballistic missile launch into the Sea of Japan. The White House stated that Trump emphasized the US's ability to deter and defend itself and its allies with military capabilities. Trump also reaffirmed that all options are available in dealing with North Korea's nuclear and missile programs, with Abe expressing concern over China's response to the issue. The statement came ahead of a US-China summit at Mar-a-Lago.

site_title: CDL markets Singapore's first Green bond
summary: City Developments (CDL) has launched Singapore's first Green bond, offering a 2-year, SGD 1.98% coupon. The unrated bond is secured against Republic Plaza, a platinum-rated office complex. The bond is intended to repay a loan used for the building's retrofit and upgrade. DBS is the sole bookrunner, and Sustainalytics provided a second-party opinion. This marks the first Green bond in the SGD market, testing local investor appetite for this asset.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Advance SCT, KS Energy, IEV, Lorenzo, telcos
summary: Stocks to watch: Advance SCT, KS Energy, IEV, Lorenzo, telcos. Advance SCT's creditor meeting result is uncertain, while KS Energy expects negative cash flows but anticipates positive cash flows from rig charter contracts. IEV Holdings and Lorenzo International were queried by Singapore Exchange on unusual share volume movements. Singapore telcos M1, Singtel, and StarHub saw their stock prices fall marginally after the conclusion of the general spectrum auction.

site_title: Developing Asia's 2017 growth seen as weakest in 16 years: ADB
summary: Developing Asia is expected to post its slowest annual growth in 16 years, with a forecasted 5.7% growth rate for 2017, according to the Asian Development Bank. The region's growth is expected to slow further to 5% in 2018. China's economy is expected to grow 6.5% in 2017, while India's growth is projected to pick up to 7.6% in 2018. Global policy uncertainty and interest rate normalization in the US are seen as contributing factors to the region's slow growth.

site_title: At 73, Barry Manilow comes out of closet
summary: Barry Manilow, 73, publicly came out as gay after decades of secrecy, citing fear of disappointing fans.
