He revealed his nearly four-decade relationship with manager Garry Kief, whom he married in 2014. Manilow said he kept his sexuality hidden to avoid disappointing his largely female fan base. He became a leading attraction in Las Vegas in recent years and released his latest album, "This Is My Town," which features songs about New York. Manilow expressed gratitude for his fans' support on Twitter after the announcement.

site_title: US dollar sags on Xi-Trump summit nerves, geopolitical worries
summary: The US dollar declined against a basket of currencies due to caution over the upcoming US-China summit and geopolitical concerns. Despite hawkish Federal Reserve minutes, the dollar fell 0.15% to 100.410. Regional tensions rose after North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile, and market nerves were heightened due to US President Trump's criticism of China's economic policies. The Japanese yen gained on its safe-haven status, while the euro, pound, and New Zealand dollar also saw gains.

site_title: Federal Reserve signals shift in balance sheet policy 'this year'
summary: Federal Reserve officials signaled a potential shift away from their post-financial crisis investment policy, which built a $4.5 trillion portfolio to boost economic growth. The shift in balance sheet policy was announced during their March meeting, amid considerable uncertainty about the effects of possible fiscal stimulus from the Trump administration. The news sent Wall Street lower, erasing earlier gains, and is expected to have implications for economic growth and monetary policy.

site_title: News agencies join forces for EU data journalism site
summary: European news agencies AFP, ANSA, and DPA are launching a new data journalism site, the European Data News Hub, in June. The website will provide data-driven content on EU issues in five languages, including English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish. The site aims to inform and inspire debate on topics such as the environment, migration, and unemployment. The European Commission will provide a grant, but the site will be editorially independent. The three agencies will distribute content through their networks, reaching a global audience.

images.alt_text: AFP is joining forces with Italy's ANSA news agency and Germany's DPA to launch a new website offering data journalism on the European Union.

site_title: UK woman arrested, millions recovered in tax probe
summary: A British woman, 46, was arrested in a joint tax probe with the British Revenue and Customs Service and Dutch authorities, recovering assets worth over six million euros. The investigation targeted Swiss bank accounts, allegedly linked to Credit Suisse. The woman and her 51-year-old Dutch husband are under investigation. Assets were confiscated in the Netherlands, with the Dutch Fiscal Information and Investigation Service confirming the recovery. The probe is part of a sweeping international investigation involving at least four European countries and Australia.

site_title: Sabana Reit to hold EGM on April 28
summary: Sabana Reit has scheduled an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for April 28, 2017, following a campaign by 66 unhappy unitholders against the Reit's manager, Sabana Real Estate Investment Management. The unitholders are dissatisfied with the Reit's manager, citing falling distribution per unit, overpriced acquisitions, and high fee payouts. Four resolutions will be tabled at the EGM, including removing the Reit manager, incorporating an in-house manager, and winding up the Reit if the manager cannot be replaced.

site_title: With leaks and vacancies, US Fed on shaky ground
summary: US Federal Reserve faces credibility crisis after the sudden resignation of President of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank, Jeffrey Lacker, amid controversy over a 2012 leak of confidential information. Lacker's departure follows that of Governor Daniel Tarullo, who departed in February, and paves the way for the Trump administration to reshape the Fed. The Fed's credibility is now under intense scrutiny, with lawmakers calling for an audit and legislative action to reduce the Fed's independence. The Trump administration plans to fill several vacant seats, potentially reshaping the Fed's balance of views on monetary policy.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat as commodity stocks rise but autos fall
summary: European shares ended flat on Wednesday, with commodity stocks rising and autos falling, despite solid economic data showing broad-based growth across Europe. The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended little changed, with individual countries' data improving and Euro zone businesses experiencing their best quarter in six years. Investors remained upbeat, with Citi upgrading continental European stocks to overweight, predicting a 8% rise by year-end. M&A activity also drove price action, with several companies announcing deals.

site_title: US authorities bust visa fraud scheme for wealthy Chinese
summary: US authorities have busted a visa fraud scheme that allegedly helped up to 100 Chinese nationals obtain US residency visas in exchange for bogus investments. Victoria Chan and her father, Tat Chan, allegedly convinced investors to put in over $50 million under the EB-5 programme, which requires $500,000 in a US business with 10 new jobs. Several beneficiaries were fugitives on China's most wanted list, and at least three obtained green cards with false information. No arrests have been made yet, and no formal charges have been filed.

site_title: Suu Kyi denies ethnic cleansing of Myanmar minority
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi denied ethnic cleansing of Myanmar's Muslim minority, stating "I don't think there is ethnic cleansing going on. I think ethnic cleansing is too strong an expression to use for what is happening." The UN rights council agreed to investigate allegations against the army, following international condemnation of the treatment of Rohingya Muslims, who are regarded as illegal immigrants from Bangladesh. Suu Kyi's one-year-old government faces criticism for its handling of the minority.

images.alt_text: Aung San Suu Kyi has denied the ethnic cleansing of Myanmar's Muslim minority, speaking to the BBC after the UN rights council agreed to investigate allegations against the army.

site_title: Kuroda likely favourite for new BOJ term, if willing
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is seen as the likely favourite for a second term, despite missing his inflation target and facing strain from the job. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has expressed support for Kuroda, citing his steady hand and ability to maintain the status quo. However, analysts note that the BOJ's policy arsenal is limited, and Kuroda's reappointment may not address long-term sustainability concerns. Kuroda, 72, has made no comment on his willingness to retain the post, which is considered one of the country's most punishing high-profile jobs.

site_title: Update: Driver arrested after HK tram flips over, injuring 14
summary: A double-decker tram in Hong Kong flipped over, injuring 14 people, including the driver. The 23-year-old driver, Lo, was arrested on suspicion of dangerous driving. This is the second incident on the city's public transport network this year, following a subway train fire in February that injured 17 people. The tram network, which carries over 200,000 passengers daily, is considered one of the safest in the world.

site_title: China dissident sees threat in new Interpol chief
summary: China's new Interpol chief, Meng Hongwei, poses a threat to dissidents who have fled the country, warns prominent exiled dissident Wei Jingsheng. Meng's role as vice-minister of public security in China gives Beijing leverage over critics, who fear he could use allegations of terrorism to have them sent home. Wei expressed concerns about the increased collaboration between China and Interpol, which could make it harder for officials suspected of corruption and dissidents abroad to escape justice. This risk is particularly alarming given China's anti-graft campaign and Operation Fox Hunt.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on concerns over tightening Fed policy
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's tightening policy, following the release of minutes from the March meeting. The minutes suggested the Fed could move to reduce its balance sheet sooner than expected, reversing earlier optimism over job growth. The Nasdaq fell 0.6%, while the dollar remained flat against the euro and down against the pound and yen. Analysts expect the dollar to potentially gain due to higher rates and a smaller balance sheet.

site_title: China firms looking to buy builders, rail projects in Brazil: chamber
summary: Chinese companies are interested in acquiring large engineering groups in Brazil and participating in government auctions for commercial railways. Chinese firms are willing to finance projects, taking advantage of Brazil's recession-reduced credit lines. Nearly all Brazilian engineering groups are under investigation in the "Operation Car Wash" probe. Companies such as China Railway Engineering Corporation and China Communications Construction Company are potential bidders for projects like the Ferrovia da Integração and Ferrogrão railways, which require around 13 billion reais in investment.

site_title: EU Parliament adopts tough Brexit 'red lines'
summary: The European Parliament has adopted tough "red lines" for Brexit negotiations, which EU lawmakers will have the final say in two years' time. The guidelines, largely based on EU President Donald Tusk's draft, insist that Britain must make "substantial progress" on divorce terms before striking a trade deal. The EU has rejected British Prime Minister Theresa May's call for parallel talks on the terms of the divorce and a future trade deal. The remaining 27 EU countries will rubberstamp the guidelines at a summit on April 29, paving the way for formal negotiations with Britain to begin at the end of May.

site_title: Aussie businesses eye backdoor listing through suspended Mercator
summary: Australian businesses Nickolaos Mitropoulos and Dimitrios Podaridis have agreed to transfer their equity to a Singapore-incorporated holding company, Essence Holdco, to pay off Mercator Lines' creditors and shareholders. The proposal involves listing Essence Holdco's shares on Catalist, with a planned distribution of S$5 million and S$1 million to creditors and shareholders. The deal aims to provide better returns for shareholders and creditors compared to a liquidation scenario, with Mercator's shares to be delisted following completion of the scheme.

site_title: Eurozone firms start 2017 with best quarter in 6 years: poll
summary: Eurozone businesses experienced their best quarter in six years at the start of 2017, with economic growth of 0.6% according to IHS Markit data. This surpasses a Reuters survey prediction of 0.5% and is a broad-based upturn among the eurozone's largest members. The Markit Composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to a near-six year high of 56.4 in March, and output prices increased to a near-six year high of 53.1. This growth is seen as a positive sign for the European Central Bank's inflation-targeting policy.

site_title: Exchange traded funds set for explosive growth in Asia
summary: Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are expected to experience explosive growth in Asia, driven by increasing investor interest and government backing. In Japan, the Bank of Japan has invested in around half of all ETFs launched, while other Asian authorities are exploring similar strategies. ETFs offer low-cost access to a wide range of assets, and their popularity is expected to surpass actively managed funds by 2024. The number of ETFs has grown from zero in 2000 to 4,874, with total assets reaching $3.7 trillion, mostly in the US and Japan.

site_title: Oil eases off one-month high on surprise US crude build
summary: Oil prices eased from one-month highs on Wednesday, supported by an outage at the UK's largest North Sea oilfield, but limited by a surprise increase in US crude inventories. The Buzzard field outage, which will take one to two days to repair, had initially supported prices. However, the US government reported a 1.6 million-barrel rise in crude inventories, offsetting the gains. Oil prices settled firmer but still below the previous day's one-month high.

site_title: New push to help SMEs in digitalisation (Amended)
summary: Singapore is launching a new push to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) digitalize, with a focus on areas such as cybersecurity and data analytics. The 12 SME Centres will remain the first point of contact for SMEs, while the new SME Digital Tech Hub will provide specialized assistance. The government has also announced plans to unveil the Tech Depot, a central listing of ready-to-go technology packages, to help SMEs improve in areas such as supply-chain management and inventory tracking. The initiatives aim to support SMEs in their digitalization journey and keep them competitive in the changing economy.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing close in on Qantas' ultra-long haul dream
summary: Airbus and Boeing are offering aircraft capable of non-stop commercial flights from Sydney to London, a goal for Qantas Airways Ltd. The Airbus A350-900ULR and Boeing 777-8 can potentially fly the 20-hour route, making it financially viable at around $70 per barrel of oil. Qantas could charge a 20% price premium for a non-stop flight, differentiating its product from competitors. However, fuel costs and headwinds are major concerns, with Qantas aiming to complete the route with 300 seats to maximize revenue and fleet flexibility.

site_title: German cabinet approves plan to fine social media over hate speech
summary: Germany's cabinet approved a plan to fine social media platforms up to 50 million euros for failing to remove hateful content within 24 hours, prompting concerns about limiting free expression. The law also requires companies to report back on their actions and could lead to fines of up to 5 million euros for their executives. Critics argue that the law could stifle free speech and that companies should be responsible for monitoring their own content.

site_title: Gig economy creates ripples in Australia's A$2.1 trillion pension pool
summary: Australia's A$2.1 trillion pension pool is being strained by the growing gig economy, where freelance work is becoming increasingly common. Independent contractors employed by companies like Uber and Deliveroo are not required to contribute to superannuations, resulting in a potential loss of A$150 million per year in super payments. This trend is expected to have significant implications for retirement savings, with many workers, like Rosalina Kariotakis, feeling uncertain about their financial futures.

site_title: NYC developer makes first foray into Brooklyn
summary: Tishman Speyer, a major NYC developer, is building a 620,000 sq ft office tower on top of the Macy's department store in downtown Brooklyn. The $500 million project will be ready for occupancy in mid-2019 and marks the company's first foray into Brooklyn. The new 10-storey building will integrate the top four storeys of the existing Macy's structure with new construction, without an anchor tenant.

images.alt_text: "Twenty-first-century real estate is defined by a 'live-work-play' dynamic. Brooklyn has mastered 'live-play', but now it needs world-class office space for 'work'." - Rob Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer
Interior demolition work and structural reinforcement are underway, with the external construction due to begin early next year.

site_title: Public Transport Council starts review of fare formula
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) in Singapore has started reviewing the fare formula for bus and train fares, aiming to maintain affordability while ensuring financial viability. The review will focus on the current formula, which has been in place since 2013, and propose improvements. The PTC targets to complete the review by 2018 and apply the new formula from that year's fare adjustment exercise. The review aims to balance cost sharing among commuters, taxpayers, and public transport operators, following the government's increased investment in public transport infrastructure.

site_title: Is there people power in Russia?
summary: Protests in Russia, sparked by corruption and demands for Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev's resignation, have been the largest since 2011 and 2012. The demonstrations, involving tens of thousands of citizens, are led by young people and middle-class Russians, who represent a cross-section of society. While the protests lack a unified opposition leader, Aleksei Navalny, a media-savvy anti-corruption campaigner, could potentially unite the opposition. The ruling coalition's divisions over corruption and modernization could lead to splits, and the security apparatus's divisions may help the protesters. However, Vladimir Putin's control over segments of the population and the state's resources make it unlikely that people power will threaten his removal, but may force him to address public unease over corruption.

site_title: Has Jumbo stock priced in growth story?
summary: Jumbo Seafood's stock price has risen from S$0.25 to S$0.72 since its listing on Catalist in 2015, driven by expansion plans in overseas markets. The company has announced a joint venture to open a Jumbo seafood restaurant in Beijing and plans to expand in Vietnam and other Asia Pacific markets. Analysts expect the stock to continue growing, but some have a "hold" call, citing that growth prospects may have already been priced in.

site_title: China becomes US's biggest oil buyer as exports hit record
summary: China surpassed Canada as the US's biggest oil buyer in February, importing 8.08 million barrels of US crude. This surge in exports came as Opec countries cut back output to combat a global energy glut. US crude exports reached a record 31.2 million barrels in February, a 35% jump from the previous month. The shift to Asia, dominated by Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern producers, is seen as a significant development in the global crude export market.

site_title: Trump-Xi meeting should set the tone for broader US-Asia relations
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping at Trump's private retreat in Florida, marking the first face-to-face encounter between the two leaders. The agenda is vague, but discussions are expected to cover global, regional, and bilateral issues, including trade deficits, intellectual property protection, and North Korea. Trump has expressed concerns over China's economic practices and currency manipulation, while Xi may offer concessions in areas such as market access and intellectual property protection. The meeting's outcome will be closely watched by Asia and the world, with a bilateral relationship that prioritizes transactional interests potentially detrimental to regional stability and the US's own interests.

images.alt_text: Over the coming two days, the attention of much of the world - certainly much of Asia - will be on the meeting between US President Donald Trump and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, at Mr Trump's private retreat in Florida.

site_title: Saudi Arabia picks hybrid structure for debut dollar sukuk
summary: Saudi Arabia has chosen a hybrid structure for its debut international sukuk, a format used in the local debt market but not for sovereign issues. The $10 billion Islamic bond will have two tranches, with 51% used in a mudaraba agreement and the remaining 49% in a murabaha facility to purchase sharia-compliant commodities. This hybrid structure was previously seen in Saudi Aramco's riyal-denominated sukuk offer. The sukuk is the country's second international debt sale, following a $17.5 billion conventional bond last year, aimed at diversifying funding sources amid lower oil prices.

site_title: Britain to help Saudi Arabia diversify economy
summary: Britain announced plans to help Saudi Arabia diversify its oil-dependent economy, with British Prime Minister Theresa May discussing "tax and privatisation standards" during her visit to the Gulf kingdom. The goal is to make Saudi Arabia less reliant on oil, with no specific timeline or details provided.

site_title: Asia's fintech wave good for financial sector: Nasdaq
summary: Nasdaq's Asia-Pacific unit is confident that fintech-driven disruption in the region's financial services sector will fuel significant growth, with data revenue tripling over the past three years. The US stock exchange aims to cash in on this trend by offering innovative products and services, with a focus on China and other key innovation hubs in Asia. Nasdaq has signed up 15 new brokers and vendors in the region and is developing new offerings using advanced analytics and machine intelligence to improve trading and investment decisions.

site_title: N Korea's missile test keeps US$ gains in check
summary: US dollar gains against yen were limited after North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile ahead of US-China talks, with investors seeking refuge in the Japanese currency. The missile launch, a day before key talks between President Trump and Xi Jinping, pressured the dollar in Asian trade. Despite this, the US dollar still edged up against the yen in European trading. The news did not impact broader market trends, and the dollar's gains were short-lived.

site_title: Shares lower ahead of Trump-Xi summit
summary: Shares in Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% on Wednesday, despite a mostly positive performance from other Asian bourses, ahead of a summit meeting between US and Chinese leaders. The STI was weighed down by conglomerate Keppel Corp, Singapore Press Holdings, and local banks. In other news, the local telecommunications sector was active after a general spectrum auction, with brokerages assigning neutral ratings to the sector.

site_title: Investment property sales drop in Q1
summary: Singapore's investment property sales declined 35% in Q1 to S$5.2 billion, but remain double the year-ago figure. Despite the drop, market sentiment remains positive, with anticipation of mega transactions in the CBD. The office sector has seen a dramatic reversal in investor tone, with oversupply concerns giving way to rental growth. Institutional investors are expected to divert interest from residential to office, retail, and hospitality sectors, driving investment sales to S$18-20 billion in 2017.

site_title: EU, Greece seek bailout deal by Friday
summary: Greece and its international lenders are at odds over a fresh bailout deal, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accusing creditors of "playing games" and causing delays. The EU and IMF have differing views on Greece's fiscal progress, labour and energy market reforms, and pension reform. Eurozone finance ministers will discuss the negotiations on Friday, but officials say a full deal is unlikely. Tsipras has threatened to ask for an EU leaders summit if a deal is not reached this week, citing Greece's readiness to leave the crisis behind.

images.alt_text: "Despite the impressive fiscal results, some of our creditors appear unrepentant," said Mr Tsipras (far left), after meeting Mr Tusk.

site_title: Asia investors eyeing infrastructure, says wealth manager
summary: Asian investors, including pension funds and insurers, are seeking stable returns by investing in global infrastructure projects due to low yields and negative interest rates. This has led to a significant increase in infrastructure debt investments, with Asian investors more than tripling their involvement since 2012. Major players such as AMP Capital Investors have raised billions of dollars for infrastructure strategies, with a record $413 billion invested globally last year. Investors are also drawn to Australian real estate for its relatively stable yields and favorable economic conditions.

site_title: London home completions forecast to fall
summary: London is forecast to see a 25% drop in new home completions by 2029, with 46,500 new homes expected to be built this year, according to Savills. This is attributed to a chronic supply shortage and developers adjusting to slower sales. Total sales in London fell 21% in 2016, and prices continue to rise. The Brexit vote and increased taxes have hit the priciest areas, leading to a 30% decline in sales in areas like Kensington and Westminster. This further curtails building and pushes up costs.

site_title: Lotte Group may list Malaysian petrochem unit in third quarter
summary: Lotte Group plans to list its Malaysian petrochemical unit in the third quarter, potentially raising up to $1.5 billion in an initial public offering. This could be one of the largest IPOs in years in Malaysia, last seen in 2012 with Astro Malaysia Holdings' $1.5 billion listing.

site_title: From haute fashion to hot mess: The rise and fall of J Crew
summary: J. Crew, a fashion brand that rose to prominence with Michelle Obama's endorsement, has reached a turning point. President and executive creative director Jenna Lyons is leaving the company, marking the highest-profile departure. Lyons' contract ends in December, and she will not be replaced. Instead, Somsack Sikhounmuong, head of women's design, will become chief design officer, overseeing women's, men's, and children's wear. The move is a mutual decision by Lyons and chairman Millard S Drexler, who will oversee the design teams directly.

site_title: Polytechnics start part-time courses for fresh graduates
summary: Singapore's polytechnics have launched eight new part-time courses for fresh graduates, with 24 more planned for the rest of 2017. The SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) is expanding its Earn and Learn Programme (ELP) to include 60 programmes, up from 40 in 2016. The ELP helps polytechnic and ITE graduates build work experience while pursuing structured learning. Polytechnics like Nanyang Polytechnic, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, and Temasek Polytechnic are offering new ELPs and Continuing Education and Training (CET) programmes in various industries.

site_title: For DBS, even car park charges are up for disclosure
summary: DBS Group Holdings' latest annual report has disclosed the compensation of its directors, including independent director Euleen Goh, who received S$5,778 for car park charges in 2017. Goh's total compensation was S$344,778, the second-highest among non-executive directors. The bank's head, Piyush Gupta, received S$8.44 million, including S$61,132 for car and driver benefits. The report, which departed from the norm, also showed Goh attended 30 board meetings, the second-highest among non-executive directors.

site_title: Financial institutions fear losing revenue to fintechs: PwC survey
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore are concerned about losing revenue to fintech firms, with 80% citing this as a concern, up 7 percentage points from last year. 76% of respondents believe wealth management, payments, and fund transfers are at risk of migrating to fintech companies. Despite this, 89% of respondents expect to grow fintech partnerships over the next three to five years. Regulatory uncertainty is a major obstacle to partnerships, but Singapore authorities are adopting a "progressive approach" to foster a conducive ecosystem for fintech growth.

site_title: Chatbot helps OCBC scoop up S$10m in home loans
summary: OCBC bank's chatbot application, named "Emma", has successfully closed over S$10 million in home loans in three months, receiving over 20,000 enquiries. The chatbot uses artificial intelligence to address consumer queries, including loan amounts and total debt servicing ratio. This is part of OCBC's fintech efforts, with similar digital tools being introduced by other banks such as POSB and Standard Chartered Private Bank. The bank's head of consumer secured lending sees chatbots as a natural progression to providing better access to basic loan information.

site_title: Mercedes joins hands with Bosch to develop self-driving taxis
summary: Mercedes-Benz and Bosch have formed an alliance to develop self-driving taxis, aiming to accelerate the production of "robo-taxis" and counter the autonomous car efforts of companies like Uber and Didi. The deal will allow Mercedes to use the jointly developed system for two years before it can be offered to competitors. The partnership is expected to help the automotive industry move beyond prototype vehicles towards industrial-scale production of self-driving cars. The alliance is part of a growing trend in the industry, with other companies like BMW and Intel also working on autonomous vehicle technology.

site_title: Samsung to ride soaring chip profits for Q1, Galaxy S8 aura in 2017
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is expected to report its highest first-quarter profit in three-and-a-half years, driven by record earnings from its chip division. The company's new smartphone, Galaxy S8, is set to launch on April 21 and analysts expect it to help Samsung regain its lead in the market. Despite recent challenges, including a costly failure of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone and management turmoil, Samsung's shares are near record highs, having gained nearly 17% so far this year. Analysts forecast a record profit of 11.9 trillion won in the second quarter.

site_title: Discount chain Payless enters bankruptcy, will close 400 stores
summary: Payless, a discount shoe chain, filed for bankruptcy and plans to close 400 underperforming stores in the US and Puerto Rico. The company aims to slash debt by nearly 50% and reduce interest costs through a restructuring proposal. Payless employs almost 22,000 people and operates over 4,000 stores in 30 countries. The filing follows a decline in US retailers due to changing consumer habits and shifting online shopping trends.

site_title: UK foreign bankers heading home ahead of Brexit
summary: UK-based foreign bankers at top global banks are proactively requesting to return to their native EU countries ahead of Brexit, aiming to secure their jobs and families. Many banks, including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and HSBC, are relocating staff to EU hubs to maintain operations and take advantage of attractive tax incentives. Staff members are seeking to return home due to uncertainty about job security, with some executives willing to relocate their families as well. This move is expected to save time and money for the banks, but may also lead to a significant loss of banking jobs in London.

site_title: Airbus remodels space on A380 flagship to fit 80 more seats
summary: Airbus is revamping its A380 flagship to accommodate 80 more seats, including 10 business-class seats, 20 premium and economy berths, and 23 extra people in coach. The changes aim to enhance the aircraft's economic credentials and address growing travel demand. The A380 typically seats 550 passengers, but airlines often configure it with fewer seats and add amenities. Airbus is making the changes in response to struggling sales and competition from Boeing, with Emirates being the only major operator to push capacity beyond 600 people.

site_title: Ital Auto to be new importer for Maserati
summary: Maserati will be imported by Ital Auto, starting May 18, after Hong Seh Motors' forecourt exit. The Italian luxury marque had been with Hong Seh since 1999, but the distributor cited "diminishing returns" for the high-end segment. Ital Auto, owned by Komoco Motors, will distribute both Maserati and Ferrari, with a new showroom and workshop to be opened at 30 Leng Kee Road in Singapore. The transition is amicable, with Hong Seh's executive director focusing on yachts and the Ferretti Group's luxury pleasure craft business.

images.alt_text: Mr Teo has confirmed that his company Ital Auto will officially assume the importership of the Italian luxury marque on May 18.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SINGHAIYI Group will not exercise its conditional right of first refusal to acquire 500 million shares in OKH Global at S$0.10 apiece. One Asset Management listed its One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend ETF on Singapore Exchange, tracking the Stoxx Asean Select Dividend 30 Index. Viant Commodities launched a joint venture with KME in Switzerland.

site_title: New hope for Reit unitholders with SFA Amendment?
summary: The Securities and Futures (Amendment) Act 2017 introduces a statutory duty on Reit managers to act in the best interests of unitholders, prioritizing their interests over the manager's own or shareholders'. Directors also face liability for breaching these duties. However, the Act's effectiveness is uncertain due to qualifiers, such as non-retroactive application and unclear court interpretations. The Reits regime may need further changes to address concerns about "clever financial engineering" and to align unitholders' interests with those of the Reit manager.

site_title: Apple tightens control over graphic chip design
summary: Apple has stopped licensing graphics chips from Imagination Technologies Group, tightening control over core technologies in its products, including iPhones. This move is part of Apple's strategy to reduce dependence on outside suppliers and focus on in-house development, particularly in augmented reality and virtual reality. By designing its own chips, Apple aims to improve innovation, quality, and cost, and to position itself for future technologies.

site_title: Choreographer, woman of all trades, dreamer
summary: Choreographer Blanca Li is a multifaceted artist who has worked with prominent stars such as Beyonce and Daft Punk. Li's latest performance, "Goddesses and Demonesses," is a tribute to the power of women and debuted in Paris over a year ago. The show features Li and principal dancer Maria Alexandrova bringing Greek mythology's feminine archetypes to life. Li aims to influence the world through the performing arts, particularly in the area of women's rights, which she feels are eroding.

site_title: StarHub, M1 stocks dip, Singtel stays flat after spectrum auction
summary: Singaporean telcos M1 and StarHub saw their stock prices dip, with M1 falling 4 cents (1.85%) to S$2.12 and StarHub falling 2 cents (0.69%) to S$2.86, after the conclusion of the General Spectrum Auction (GSA) in April 2017. Singtel remained flat at S$3.92. Analysts attributed the decline to high spectrum pricing, which may impact valuations of Starhub and M1.

site_title: SIA Engg in tie-up with 3D printing and solutions firm
summary: SIA Engineering Company has signed a memorandum of understanding with Stratasys to establish a strategic partnership to accelerate the adoption of 3D printed products for commercial aviation. The partnership aims to provide airline customers with scheduled maintenance and on-demand parts solutions through a Singapore-based additive manufacturing service centre. Stratasys will provide expertise in additive manufacturing and drive the development of aerospace applications. The joint venture, majority owned by SIA Engineering, is expected to strengthen the company's MRO solutions and enhance customer support.

site_title: Unfilled positions holding back Trump's bid to undo Dodd-Frank
summary: US President Donald Trump's push to roll back Wall Street regulations is being hindered by the lack of filled seats at the Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission. With only two members at each regulator, Democrats have the power to block policy moves they disagree with. This inaction has stalled Trump's efforts to undo Dodd-Frank, a financial regulation law enacted in 2010. The situation highlights the challenges Trump faces in implementing his regulatory reform agenda.

site_title: America's biggest coal miner hops onto comeback wagon
summary: Peabody Energy Corp, the US's largest coal miner, has returned to trading on the New York Stock Exchange after nearly a year in bankruptcy. The company's shares opened at $32 and were trading at $27.99. Peabody's CEO Glenn Kellow plans to focus on shareholder returns, citing a more favorable regulatory framework under President Trump. The US coal sector is staging a comeback amid rising coal prices and interest from investors. Peabody aims to reduce debt and eventually pay a dividend, with output from its Wyoming and Australia mines expected to help achieve this goal.

site_title: ST Telemedia invests US$89 million in Armor
summary: ST Telemedia has invested US$89 million in Armor, a managed security company for public and hybrid cloud environments. The investment, led by STT and The Stephens Group, aims to accelerate Armor's adoption and drive growth. Armor's platform integrates threat intelligence, automated security, and machine learning, providing 24/7 protection against cyber threats. With over 1,200 customers in 42 countries, Armor's revenue is expected to grow at 50% annually. The investment underscores STT's commitment to developing new growth verticals and building an integrated vertical stack in the growing cyber-security and cloud infrastructure markets.

site_title: S i2i's latest proposed deal sparks shareholders' dissent
summary: S i2i's proposed acquisition of an e-commerce platform for S$6.3 million, to be satisfied by issuing new shares, has sparked dissent from shareholders, including Blue Ocean Capital Partners, who claim it will lower proforma net tangible asset backing per share and hinder corporate recovery. The deal requires shareholder approval and comes as S i2i faces a March 3, 2018 deadline to exit the Singapore Exchange's distressed company list. The acquisition will dilute S i2i's interest in Affinity Capital, which holds shares of the group's subsidiaries in Indonesia.

site_title: Technological progress in a market economy need not impoverish unskilled workers
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers disagrees with Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin's views on artificial intelligence, citing a focus on job displacement in the future. Mnuchin believes AI's impact on jobs is distant, while Summers seems to emphasize the importance of addressing the issue now.

site_title: Australia finds scores of Swiss accounts still active in tax evasion hunt
summary: Australian authorities have identified over 340 secret Swiss bank accounts as part of a global tax evasion investigation, with some still in use. The investigation, involving Australia, the Netherlands, Britain, Germany, and France, has led to at least two arrests. Swiss bank Credit Suisse revealed its offices in London and Paris were contacted by local authorities over client tax matters. The Australian Tax Office is making inquiries with taxpayers and imposing penalties, with potential links to accountants subject to criminal investigation.

site_title: Top brands fleeing Fifth Avenue
summary: Fifth Avenue, once a hub for high-end retailers, is experiencing a decline in sales and foot traffic due to online shopping and tourism slowdown. Brands such as Ralph Lauren, Kenneth Cole, and Juicy Couture have closed or relocated stores, with an average asking price of over $2,900 per square foot. The area's high rents and lack of international tourists, who are hit by currency fluctuations, have made it difficult for retailers to justify their spaces. Despite this, some brands are adapting by downsizing or shifting focus to driving sales, and new stores are moving into the area.

site_title: KS Energy believes group will continue as a going concern
summary: KS Energy, a Singapore-based oilfield services firm, believes it will continue as a going concern despite a net loss of S$126 million in 2016. The group has a "reasonable expectation" to meet its debt obligations, with cash flows from existing and prospective rig charter contracts expected to remain negative. KS Energy is negotiating with bondholders and a shareholder to restructure some debts, totaling S$74.9 million, to prevent a cross-default clause trigger. The company has a capital commitment of S$245 million for an asset under construction, with plans to secure financing closer to its delivery date.

site_title: Britain to help reform Saudi economy
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May visited Saudi Arabia to help the country diversify its oil-dependent economy. The UK will assist in building a reformed Ministry of Defence and reviewing defence capabilities, while also discussing "tax and privatisation standards" to reduce reliance on oil. The visit comes as Saudi Arabia faces significant budget deficits and debts, and as the UK seeks to secure investment and trade after Brexit. However, May has faced criticism for her visit due to human rights concerns, particularly regarding arms sales to the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen.

site_title: Swiss AG says it's making progress in 1MDB case
summary: Swiss Attorney General Michael Lauber announced progress in the 1MDB money laundering investigation, stating that despite Malaysian authorities' refusal to cooperate, the case is making progress. Lauber highlighted the success of the investigation, particularly in obtaining payments from Swiss private banks BSI and Falcon. He emphasized that Switzerland does not tolerate international corruption and money laundering, and vowed to successfully conclude the process, particularly in open cases against the two banks.

site_title: Malaysian study finds shortfalls in internal audit among listed firms
summary: A Malaysian study by the Institute of Internal Auditors Malaysia found that many public-listed companies have shortfalls in their internal audit functions, including underqualified auditors and insufficient resources. The study, which examined 785 main-market public-listed companies, found that 54% outsourced their IA function, often to junior-level teams or small providers for low fees. The study also highlighted other areas for improvement, including a lack of diversity among audit committee members and chairs without professional accounting qualifications. The IIAM recommended strengthening IA functions and separating the roles of audit committee chairs and board chairs.

site_title: ExxonMobil in talks to buy JAC plant
summary: ExxonMobil is in talks to acquire Jurong Aromatics Corporation (JAC), one of the world's largest petrochemical plants, which is in receivership. JAC, located in Singapore, restarted operations last year under a tolling agreement but its one-year agreement is expiring. Industry observers see ExxonMobil as the most logical choice to integrate JAC's operations with its existing Singapore facilities. The acquisition is valued at US$2.4 billion, and negotiations are ongoing.

site_title: Cricketers go under the hammer
summary: The Indian Premier League (IPL) pioneered the use of auctions to distribute players in cricket leagues from the West Indies to Pakistan to Hong Kong, introducing transparency and adherence to a salary cap. Christie's auctioneer Richard Madley manages the process, keeping things professional despite the high stakes. Players, who set a base price, learn their fates through televised auctions, with teams competing for the best talent. The system has proven life-changing for some, with players fetching millions of dollars in previous auctions.

site_title: Zuellig pledges to invest over S$50m in S'pore centre
summary: Zuellig Pharma has committed over S$50 million to its new Singapore-based innovation centre, Zuellig Health Solutions (ZHS), over the next five years. The centre will develop predictive models for early health screening, treatment cost analysis, and disease management solutions to improve treatment plans and reduce healthcare costs. ZHS will employ over 50 healthcare, technology, and data specialists and focus on addressing gaps in the healthcare sector in Asia. The centre is supported by the Economic Development Board in Singapore, and its launch aims to leverage Zuellig's long history and partnerships in the region to create innovative solutions.

site_title: Facebook loses appeal to block bulk search warrants
summary: Facebook's appeal to block bulk search warrants in a disability fraud case was denied by New York state's highest court, upholding lower court rulings that social media companies cannot appeal a judge's decision to issue search warrants. The ruling, which was part of a broader battle over law enforcement requests for data, limits the ability of companies like Facebook to challenge search warrants as overly broad. The decision was a setback for civil libertarians and social media companies seeking to expand privacy protections.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CWT Ltd's strategic review has been ongoing for over 1.5 years, with HNA Group planning to buy at least a 35% stake in an Asia-focused Reit. HNA's acquisition could unlock synergy between the Reit and CWT. Meanwhile, Singapore's General Spectrum Auction resulted in 175MHz of bandwidth being assigned to four operators, with Singtel winning the largest chunk. This may impact telco M1's net debt/Ebitda, potentially knocking off 11.2% of its target price.

site_title: India, Pakistan clash over Jinnah House
summary: India and Pakistan are embroiled in a decades-long dispute over Jinnah House, a bungalow in Mumbai once owned by Pakistan's founding father Muhammad Ali Jinnah. An Indian lawmaker has called for the property to be labelled "enemy property" and handed over to Maharashtra state, citing the country's "conspiracy of partition". Pakistan claims ownership, while Jinnah's daughter is engaged in a separate legal battle with the Indian government. The dispute highlights strained relations between the two countries, with the Indian government facing criticism for not putting the property to better use.

site_title: Richmond Fed chief resigns, admitting violation of confidentiality
summary: Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, resigned on April 4, 2017, after admitting to violating the Fed's confidentiality rules in 2012. Lacker had spoken with a financial analyst about the Fed's plans to buy mortgage bonds, potentially benefiting investors. An investigation by the Fed and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was inconclusive, but Lacker cooperated and was told no charges would be brought. His resignation sheds light on a nearly five-year-old mystery surrounding a leak of confidential information about the Fed's plans.

site_title: UK economy slowing after strong end to 2016
summary: The UK economy has likely slowed down after a strong end to 2016, according to a survey. The Markit/CIPS Services Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 55.0 in March, its highest level in three months, indicating a cooling jobs market and increasing price pressures. As Brexit begins, these trends are expected to continue, posing a fresh challenge to the UK's economic recovery under Labour leader Keir Starmer.

site_title: US service industries expand at slowest pace in five months
summary: US service industries expanded at the slowest pace in five months, according to a survey by the Institute for Supply Management. The non-manufacturing index fell to 55.2 in March, down from 57.6 in February, indicating a decline in business activity and services employment. This marks a disappointing start to the year for Americans' spending, with softer consumption in the first quarter. The decline in the services employment gauge may also impact Friday's payrolls report, which is forecast to show 175,000 jobs added in March.

site_title: Swiss making progress in 1MDB case despite Malaysia's silence
summary: Swiss Attorney General Michael Lauber reported progress in the 1MDB money laundering investigation, despite Malaysia's refusal to cooperate. Swiss authorities are reviewing financial reports and bank documents with help from Singapore, Luxembourg, and the US, yielding positive results. Lauber stated that the investigation is not hopeless, but rather making progress.

site_title: Is the American Dream killing us?
summary: Economists Anne Case and Angus Deaton raise profound questions about the American Dream. Their recent work found that death rates among non-Hispanic, middle-aged whites have risen, with many dying younger. This phenomenon challenges traditional views of the American Dream as a guarantee of success and prosperity. The researchers' findings suggest that the pursuit of wealth and status may not lead to happiness or a long life, sparking a reevaluation of the concept of the American Dream.

site_title: Korea's high-tech economy threatened by Chinese catch-up
summary: South Korea's high-tech economy is facing a threat from China's rapid catch-up in technology, according to a report by the Korea Institute for Industrial Economics & Trade. In five years, there will be little difference between the tech of Korean and Chinese companies in most sectors, with Korea only maintaining a competitive edge in semiconductor and display industries. To stay competitive, Korea needs to invest more and create a cohesive blueprint for reforms, as China's "Made in China 2025" strategy aims to push the world's second-largest economy into more sophisticated sectors.

site_title: Concern over Beijing's latest housing curbs
summary: Beijing's housing market is facing significant curbs, with the government aiming to control price growth amid surging household debt. New measures include increasing minimum downpayments for second homes to 60% and suspending long-term mortgage loans. The number of new clients expressing interest to buy and home viewings have dropped significantly. Experts predict the market will freeze, with potential sales volumes dropping 90%. The restrictions may drive property investors to look beyond Beijing, shifting capital to smaller cities with less severe restrictions.

site_title: Takeda's largest study brings dengue vaccine step closer
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical has completed the largest clinical study in its history, enrolling 20,100 children and adolescents in a dengue vaccine trial in eight countries in Latin America and Asia. The trial aims to test the experimental vaccine's effectiveness against the mosquito-borne disease. Initial results are expected in 2018, with the goal of producing a vaccine that can protect against the four different serotypes of dengue. The study is part of Takeda's global ambitions to develop a dengue vaccine, following Sanofi's Dengvaxia vaccine, which has limitations in protecting against all four serotypes.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on solid March hiring data
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after solid March hiring data and better-than-expected earnings from Monsanto. The Dow Jones rose following ADP's report of 263,000 jobs added in March, beating expectations. Monsanto also reported a 28.7% increase in second-quarter net income. The gains came ahead of the US government employment report and despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: ExxonMobil, Qatar Petroleum sign Cyprus gas deal
summary: US giant ExxonMobil and Qatar Petroleum signed a licence to explore for oil and gas off the coast of Cyprus, with plans to start drilling next year. The venture, selected as part of Cyprus' third licensing round, aims to discover hydrocarbon reserves. A total of 12 exploration wells will be drilled, with ExxonMobil and Qatar Petroleum expecting to begin drilling operations in 2018. The deal is seen as a significant step for Cyprus, which aims to become a regional energy player and export gas by 2022.

site_title: Emerging Enterprise Award 2017 open for applications
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Award 2017 is now open for applications, recognizing promising startups and SMEs with annual sales turnover of up to S$20 million. The award, in its 10th year, aims to support emerging businesses and celebrate their achievements. Up to three winners will receive the Emerging Enterprise Winner title and prizes, including professional services and consultancy support. Eligible companies must be less than 10 years old with at least 30% shareholdings owned by Singaporeans or Singapore Permanent Residents, with applications closing on June 2, 2017.

site_title: BlaBlaCar unveils Opel leasing deal in boost for ride-sharing
summary: BlaBlaCar, Europe's largest ride-sharing startup, has partnered with Opel and Societe Generale to offer lower-cost car deals to its drivers. The deal, starting with 28,000 French drivers, will provide competitive zero-deposit terms for Opel leasing. This move aims to expand BlaBlaCar's car ownership model, which shields users from regulatory and tax obligations, and pave the way for a new approach to car ownership based on usage.

site_title: It looks like JPMorgan is building a robo adviser
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is developing a robo adviser, a free, automated investment service, as part of its digital-banking products. CEO Jamie Dimon announced the plan in his annual letter to shareholders, stating it will provide easy-to-use, inexpensive automated advice for both individual retirement and non-retirement accounts. The service will enable clients to buy and sell stocks and bonds inexpensively, aligning with JPMorgan's goal of becoming a one-stop shop for finance, similar to Amazon Prime.

site_title: British lawmakers call on firms to overhaul pay and diversity
summary: British lawmakers have called on companies to overhaul executive pay and diversity practices to rebuild public trust following corporate scandals. The report, from the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee, recommends publishing pay ratios annually, giving workers a seat on the pay committee, and increasing female representation in senior appointments. Companies must also simplify long-term incentive plans and align them with the interests of stakeholders, not just shareholders. The recommendations are non-binding but may influence the government's policies.

site_title: Central bank in neutral may be reading India's prices wrong
summary: The Reserve Bank of India's monetary policy committee is set to maintain interest rates at 6.25% amid concerns over sticky core inflation. However, economists in a Bloomberg survey predict a potential misreading of India's inflation rates due to the RBI's weighted CPI basket. The central bank's governor, Urjit Patel, is worried about core inflation, which he believes is a concern. The decision may be influenced by flawed price measures, casting doubt on the RBI's inflation-targeting strategy.

site_title: Xi extends 'panda diplomacy' to Finland
summary: China's President Xi Jinping extended his "panda diplomacy" to Finland, agreeing to cooperative panda research and making pandas "messengers of friendship" between the two countries. The move marks the 100th anniversary of Finland's independence and comes as Xi prepares to meet US President Donald Trump. China and Finland have also agreed to expand cooperation in areas like innovation, green development, and trade, with China leasing giant pandas to Ahtari zoo in central Finland. The visit is seen as a significant step in strengthening ties between the Nordic country and China.

site_title: Oil hits one-month high near US$55 on tighter supplies
summary: Oil prices rose near a one-month high, reaching $54.77 a barrel, due to a decline in US crude inventories and an outage at the largest UK North Sea oilfield. The US government's supply report is expected to confirm the inventory drop, potentially marking the start of a sustained tightening in US crude supplies. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' supply cuts have helped Brent recover from a 12-year low, but rising US output and stubbornly high stocks have limited the rally.

site_title: ChemChina gets EU nod for Syngenta deal one day after US win
summary: China National Chemical Corp. (ChemChina) received EU antitrust approval for its $43 billion takeover of Swiss pesticide maker Syngenta AG, one day after the US gave its blessing. The EU required ChemChina to divest some pesticides and products to address "problematic overlaps." The deal, one of three mega-deals in the agrochemicals industry, is expected to close by the end of June. This acquisition would make ChemChina, a state-owned Chinese company, a major player in the global agrochemicals industry, with a diverse portfolio of products.

site_title: Wells Fargo's aggressive sales tactics hit small firms
summary: Wells Fargo has restructured its credit card processing business after an internal probe found employees had falsely reported customer sales numbers, pushing small firms toward more expensive contracts as part of aggressive sales tactics. The scandal, which led to the firing of over 5,000 employees and a $190 million settlement, raises questions about the scope of the sales scandal that cost CEO John Stumpf his job. The company is also battling lawsuits from former employees, customers, and shareholders.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co has restructured its credit card processing business after an internal probe found some employees had falsely reported customer sales numbers, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Emirates lends tablet computers to cope with US ban
summary: Dubai's Emirates airline began lending tablet computers to premium US-bound passengers in response to a US ban on electronic devices larger than a smartphone. The measure aims to mitigate the inconvenience caused by the ban, allowing passengers in first and business class to borrow tablets and continue working. This move follows similar actions by other Gulf carriers, including Qatar Airways and Etihad, which have introduced measures to help passengers cope with the ban. The ban was intended to thwart possible attacks on airliners with small explosive devices hidden in consumer electronics.

site_title: Amazon acquires right to buy stake in fuel cell maker Plug Power
summary: Amazon has acquired the right to buy up to 23% of hydrogen fuel cell maker Plug Power, valued at $319 million. The deal aims to power Amazon's warehouses with hydrogen fuel cells, reducing battery attention and increasing efficiency. The retailer plans to equip forklifts at 11 warehouses this year, spending $70 million in 2017 and likely twice that next year. This move aims to improve warehouse operations and is seen as a strategic move to boost its logistics capabilities.

site_title: Monsanto earnings beat estimates as US seed sales climb
summary: Monsanto reported record fiscal second-quarter earnings, with profit excluding one-time items at $3.19 per share, beating analyst estimates. Sales rose to $5.07 billion, exceeding all forecasts. The US seed sales are expected to be record acreage this year, driven by soybean cultivation. The company's shares climbed 2.8% in pre-market trading following the earnings release.

site_title: UK services grow faster than forecast; price surge intensifies
summary: The UK's services sector grew faster than expected in March, with the Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 55 from 53.3 in February, beating forecasts. The sector's growth was driven by stronger new business, but hiring slowed. The pound rose 0.3% against the US dollar, while companies cited Brexit uncertainty but reported strong domestic and global economic conditions. Despite the growth, Markit warned of "intense cost pressures" due to the weaker pound, which could curb UK demand and growth.

site_title: Will Mar-a-Lago club enter history books?
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago, sparking concerns about the future of Sino-US ties. The meeting may shape the global balance of power, with both leaders challenging the current status quo. Trump's nationalist agenda and Xi's rising influence have led to a growing sense of competition between the two nations, with tensions over trade, territorial claims, and military presence in the South China Sea. The outcome of the summit could determine whether the two nations forge a global duopoly or lead to a trade war, potentially destabilizing the global economy.

site_title: UK economy probably slowing after strong end to 2016
summary: The UK economy likely slowed in the first quarter of 2017, with growth expected to be around 0.4% compared to 0.7% in the fourth quarter of 2016. The services sector, a key driver of the economy, showed a three-month high in March, but prices rose at the fastest pace since 2008, potentially leading to inflation above 3%. A cooling jobs market and higher prices are expected to become more apparent as Brexit begins, with the Bank of England likely to keep interest rates low.

site_title: Advance SCT flags uncertainty over results of scheme meeting with creditors
summary: Advance SCT, a copper supplier, is uncertain about the outcome of a scheme meeting with creditors after a court ruled incorrectly on a creditor's claim, potentially affecting the company's proposed arrangement. The court's decision deprived the objecting creditor of a larger share of votes. Advance SCT is now exploring its legal options, including an appeal against the decision. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain, and the company's future is in limbo.

site_title: Facebook adds Wifi hotspots to sustain Africa customer growth
summary: Facebook has added WiFi hotspots and fiber optic cables to expand its reach in Africa, increasing its user base to 170 million, a 42% growth since 2015. The rollout will be done through partnerships with international carriers and will also include the construction of 770km of fiber in Uganda. The company aims to provide internet access to the continent using various methods, including express WiFi, building fiber, and testing its Aquila project. This move is part of Facebook's long-term investment push in Africa, targeting a young population and increasing smartphone accessibility.

site_title: Zuellig Pharma to invest S$50m in Singapore innovation centre
summary: Zuellig Pharma has launched its Singapore-based innovation centre, Zuellig Health Solutions (ZHS), with a S$50 million investment over the next five years. The centre aims to develop data, digital, and disease management solutions to improve healthcare treatment plans, patient care, and payer management. ZHS will employ over 50 healthcare, technology, and data specialists, focusing on addressing healthcare sector gaps in Asia. The centre has entered into a memorandum of understanding with National Healthcare Group to develop predictive models for early health screening and treatment cost analysis using data analytics.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% to 3,176.55, with the Straits Times Index slipping 2.51 points. The decline occurred amid North Korea's missile firing before a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump. Noble Group led the decline, falling 0.004 to S$0.189. Despite this, the market still saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and was boosted by gains from mining and healthcare stocks in Europe.

site_title: Peugeot pledges to uphold Opel workers' wage, jobs deals
summary: Peugeot has pledged to uphold wages and jobs deals with Opel workers after its planned takeover of the German automaker. The deal includes a jobs guarantee until 2018 and a promise to continue investing in German sites until 2020. Peugeot CEO Carlos Tavares reaffirmed the company's commitment to respecting existing agreements covering jobs, salaries, and sites. The deal aims to achieve big economies of scale at the group, which would become Europe's second-largest carmaker after Volkswagen.

site_title: Glencore the fifth coal miner to declare force majeure in cyclone-hit Australia
summary: Glencore, the fifth coal miner to declare force majeure, cited damage to railway lines from Cyclone Debbie in Australia, disrupting coal shipments. The cyclone damaged a critical mountain pass, crippling coal exports. This move leaves rivals in the US to capitalize on the surge in coal prices as Chinese steelmakers scramble for supplies.

site_title: May suggests free movement could continue during Brexit implementation: BBC
summary: Theresa May has hinted that free movement of people between Britain and the European Union may continue during a transition period after Brexit. May, who triggered the formal divorce procedure, has not ruled out allowing the free movement during an implementation phase, which she expects to last two years. This would mean Britain would have to accept EU rules, including the four freedoms, to maintain the status quo. May has vowed to control Britain's borders and immigration, contrasting with her previous statement that she would respect EU single market membership.

site_title: Germany threatens online giants with 50m euro hate speech fines
summary: Germany has threatened social media giants like Twitter and Facebook with fines of up to 50 million euros if they fail to remove hate speech and other offensive content promptly. The move comes after a surge in xenophobic hate speech online since 2015, with the government citing poor progress in policing content. The companies have 24 hours to remove flagged content and seven days to review and delete other offending posts, with executives risking individual fines. Critics warn that the law could stifle freedom of expression, but the government says it's necessary to protect democracy.

site_title: Go to Everest Base camp - just for breakfast
summary: Chefs from Noma and London's Ledbury built a world's highest-altitude pop-up restaurant at Mount Everest Base Camp in December 2016, offering a unique breakfast experience. Guests travel by helicopter to South Base Camp, then to the adjacent peak of Kongde Ri, where they enjoy a private Champagne picnic with Everest views. Outfitters coordinate trips with Tashi Tenzing Sher, a sherpa grandson of Tenzing Norgay, who provides first-hand accounts of the climb. The experience costs $7,163-$10,000 for groups and can be booked as part of larger packages or à la carte.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Public Transport Council of Singapore began reviewing its public transport fare adjustment formula and mechanism. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann emphasized the importance of digitalization for Singapore's small and medium enterprises. Zuellig Pharma launched a new Singapore-based innovation centre, while a Thai firm listed an Asean Select Dividend ETF on the Singapore Exchange. Share prices of Singapore's telcos fell marginally, and the Straits Times Index ended 0.1% lower.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up ahead of US-China summit
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.27% on April 5, 2017, following US market gains ahead of a US-China summit between President Xi Jinping and Donald Trump. The Nikkei 225 index gained 51.02 points to 18,861.27, while the Topix index edged up 0.12 points to 1,504.66. Investors remained cautious due to the summit's potential impact on global markets.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the Frankfurt's DAX 30 opening flat and the Paris CAC 40 inching up by 0.1%. Investors awaited the release of the Federal Reserve's minutes and watched US jobs data due on Wednesday and Friday, as well as a US-China summit starting Thursday.

site_title: JPMorgan softens tone on Brexit jobs warning
summary: JPMorgan Chase's CEO Jamie Dimon has softened his stance on the impact of Brexit on the bank's jobs in Britain. Initially warning of up to 4,000 job losses, Dimon now says the bank is not planning to move many jobs out of Britain in the next two years. However, he acknowledged that the bank is preparing for a "hard Brexit," which would disrupt access to the EU's single market and its main trading partner.

site_title: KS Energy expects positive cashflow from charter contracts
summary: KS Energy expects to generate positive cash flows from existing and prospective rig charter contracts, despite anticipating an overall negative operating cash flow for the next 12 months. The company's cash flow forecast is based on chartering cash flow, operating costs, and changes in working capital, which are continuously reviewed by management. This positive outlook is a response to an emphasis of matter from its auditor regarding its full-year results for the period ended Dec 31, 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.520 points lower at 1,744.670 on Wednesday, with 4.437 billion lots traded worth RM3.487 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 612 to 353.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady ahead of earnings, Trump-Xi meeting
summary: South Korean stocks remained steady on Wednesday ahead of first-quarter corporate earnings and a US-China summit between President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index closed at 2,160.85 points, unchanged from the previous close. The South Korean won slumped 0.2% against the dollar due to increased demand. Market players await earnings releases and the summit, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: IEV Holdings, Lorenzo International respond to SGX queries
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried IEV Holdings and Lorenzo International about unusual trading activity in their shares. IEV Holdings' shares rose 15.1% to 9.9 Singapore cents, while Lorenzo International's shares increased 14% to 5.7 Singapore cents. Both companies attributed the surge to preliminary discussions with potential investors, with IEV Holdings stating there's no certainty a fund-raising will materialise. Both companies denied any information not previously announced as the cause of the unusual trading activity.

site_title: Digitalisation 'important way forward' for SMEs: Sim Ann
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Sim Ann emphasized the importance of digitalization for Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs), stating it enhances productivity, innovation, and global reach. The government will support SMEs in their digitalization journey through free consultation sessions, pre-qualified technology solutions, and specialized assistance at the SME Digital Tech Hub. Additionally, the Tech Depot, an expansion of the SME Tech Portal, is expected to be unveiled in the second quarter, offering a centralized listing of ready-to-go technology packages and digital solutions pre-qualified by the Info-communications Media Development Authority of Singapore.

site_title: US regulator fines Credit Suisse unit, adviser over improper investments
summary: Credit Suisse Securities (USA) and former investment adviser Sanford Katz agreed to pay US$8 million in fines to settle charges over improper investments. The SEC found that Credit Suisse collected US$3.2 million in avoidable fees from clients, mainly generated from Katz's advisory clients. The settlement includes disgorgement of US$3.2 million, US$600,000 in prejudgment interest, and penalties totaling US$4.1 million. This is part of a larger settlement by Credit Suisse to pay US$5.3 billion to US authorities over claims of misleading investors in residential mortgage-backed securities.

site_title: German services growth strengthens in March, PMI shows
summary: Germany's services sector growth accelerated in March, with Markit's final services index reaching a 15-month high of 55.6. This suggests the country will post healthy growth in the first quarter. The composite PMI, tracking manufacturing and services, rose to a 70-month high of 57.1, driven by strong expansion in new work and optimism about the business outlook. Despite inflation pressures, job creation rose at the fastest rate in six years, but outstanding business remained high. Markit's economist Trevor Balchin reaffirmed the full-year growth forecast of 1.9% for Germany's largest economy.

site_title: Trump declares end to "war on coal," but utilities aren't listening
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order to end Obama-era climate change regulations, claiming it would end the "war on coal" and boost energy production. However, major power generating companies, which consume most US coal, remain unconvinced, citing economic reasons such as cheap natural gas and falling solar and wind power costs. Only one utility, Basin Electric, said the order would prolong the life of some older coal-fired power units. The US coal industry faces a decline in domestic demand, with many plants set to retire or convert to alternative energy sources.

site_title: Singapore's Viant Commodities launches copper JV with KME
summary: Singapore's Viant Commodities Pte Ltd has launched a joint venture with European copper products maker KME in Switzerland, dubbed Tekvalia AG. The venture will focus on trading and distribution of copper products and services in Europe. Viant Commodities Managing Director Rene van der Kam stated that the company will leverage its strong capitalization and bank support to expand into the European market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.37% at open on Wednesday, driven by investor confidence ahead of a summit between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump. The Hang Seng Index rose 89.83 points to 24,351.31, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains come as traders brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Yuan slips against the US dollar as traders anxiously await Trump-Xi meeting
summary: China's yuan slipped against the US dollar on April 5, 2017, as traders awaited a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The yuan opened at 6.8872 per US dollar, 31 pips away from the previous close, and was seen as stable during the meeting. Trump warned of a "very difficult" meeting, but a trader said China's central bank would keep the yuan stable. The yuan's depreciation pressure had largely been released, according to the trader.

site_title: Shell sells Hong Kong, Macau energy assets
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has sold its liquefied petroleum gas business in Hong Kong and Macau to DCC Energy for $150.3 million, as part of its strategy to focus on competitive downstream activities. This sale is one of the last of Shell's wholly owned LPG businesses, with the company aiming to deliver $30 billion in divestments between 2016 and 2018.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell on Wednesday announced the sale of its liquefied petroleum gas business in Hong Kong and Macau to Irish group DCC Energy for US$150.3 million.

site_title: Australia shares end higher helped by materials, energy; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,876.20, driven by gains in materials and energy stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3% to 7,265.05, led by healthcare and consumer stocks. Investors remain cautious ahead of a potentially tense meeting between US President Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping. Oil prices jumped to a near one-month high on signs of a gradual tightening in global oil inventories.

site_title: BMW's UK workers to begin strike over pensions on April 19
summary: BMW's UK workers are set to begin an eight-strike campaign on April 19 over plans to close their final salary pensions. The strikes, which could involve up to 3,500 workers at four sites, will include working to rule and a ban on overtime. The Unite union, which represents 93% of affected employees, opposes the move to close two pension schemes and replace them with a less generous scheme. The strikes are expected to affect BMW's production of 210,000 Minis and 250,000 engines per year.

images.alt_text: British workers at BMW will hold eight strikes over the next few weeks to oppose plans by the carmaker to close their final salary pensions, beginning with a walkout at the firm's Mini plant and engine facility, Britain's biggest union said.

site_title: Applications open for Emerging Enterprise Awards 2017
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Award 2017 is now open for applications, with joint organisers The Business Times and OCBC Bank seeking promising startups and SMEs with annual sales turnover of up to S$20 million. To be eligible, companies must be less than 10 years old and have at least 30% shareholdings owned by Singaporeans or Singapore Permanent Residents. Applications must be submitted by June 2, 2017, and can be found on the EE Award website. The award aims to support outstanding SMEs in Singapore.

site_title: Taiwan to build 8 submarines under indigenous shipbuilding project
summary: Taiwan plans to build eight indigenous submarines to bolster its aging fleet, with the first vessel expected to enter operation within 10 years. The project, valued at NT$3 billion (S$138 million), is in the design contract phase and will rely on foreign technology support. The move comes ahead of a high-stakes meeting between US and Chinese leaders, which has raised concerns about Taiwan's security. The US is obligated to help defend Taiwan, but its arms sales to the island have been slowed by China's opposition.

site_title: Australia: Shares sluggish as Trump-Xi meeting looms; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.07% to 5,860.50, driven by gains in material and energy stocks, ahead of a potentially tense meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping. Global markets remain cautious, with North Korea's ballistic missile firing on Wednesday. Copper prices rallied as China bought metals, and oil prices jumped to near one-month highs. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark slipped 0.2% as material and utilities stocks declined.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won hold steady ahead of earnings, Trump-Xi summit
summary: South Korean stocks and the won held steady ahead of first-quarter earnings reports and a summit meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remained at 2,160.73 points, while the won was quoted at 1,122.7 against the US dollar. Analysts expect strong earnings and a recovery in macroeconomic data to lift the stock market.

site_title: Share prices of telcos dip marginally on Wednesday
summary: Telco share prices in Singapore fell marginally on Wednesday following the conclusion of the Info-communications Media Development Authority's spectrum auction. M1 dropped 1.85% to S$2.12, while Singtel fell 0.26% to S$3.91, and StarHub decreased 0.7% to S$2.86. The spectrum auction's aggressive bidding is seen as a sign of rising telecom competition, according to a Fitch Ratings report.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.910 points to 1745.630. The trading volume was 143.08 million lots worth RM56.95 million, with 225 gainers outnumbering 67 losers.

site_title: Marmite may be brain food: study
summary: A study found that eating a daily spoonful of Marmite, a tangy British yeast extract, may be beneficial for brain health. Volunteers who consumed Marmite had higher levels of a vital neuron chemical associated with a healthy brain. The researchers attribute this to Marmite's high levels of vitamin B12, a vital nutrient.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 3-week lows; market pares bets on RBA hike
