summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hit three-week lows due to a dovish commentary from the Reserve Bank of Australia, which left interest rates at 1.5% and described the labor market as "soft." The Aussie dollar fell to US$0.7570, while the New Zealand dollar dropped to US$0.6979, as traders became less optimistic about a potential interest rate hike and increased demand for safer assets amid global risk aversion.

site_title: Billionaire Warren Buffet becomes face of Coke in China
summary: Warren Buffett, Coca-Cola's largest investor, has become the face of Cherry Coke in China. Berkshire Hathaway, Buffett's investment firm, owns a 9.3% stake in Coca-Cola, valued at $17 billion. The billionaire's likeness will be featured on Cherry Coke cans and bottles in China for a limited promotional period. Buffett's business acumen has made him a celebrity in China, and he has expressed admiration for the country's "totally miraculous" growth. The partnership marks Buffett's enduring appreciation for Cherry Coke, which he has invested in since 1985.

site_title: Samsung to ride soaring chip profits in Q1, Galaxy S8 aura in 2017
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to report a three-and-a-half-year high in first-quarter profit driven by record earnings from its chip division. The company's new smartphone, Galaxy S8, is set to launch on April 21, with analysts forecasting a record-breaking profit of 11.9 trillion won in the second quarter. The S8's success could help Samsung regain its lead in the smartphone market, which it lost to Apple in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up as Hon Hai's shares surge on strong Q4 profits
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.1% on Wednesday, lifted by Hon Hai Precision's 8% surge in shares after the company posted a 30% rise in net profit for the fourth quarter. The electronics subindex rose 1.6%, while the financials subindex gained 0.2%. Hon Hai's strong profit gain was attributed to solid bookings for the iPhone 7 Plus models, and analysts predict the company's share price will rise by over 10% in the next 12 months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen strength capped
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 5, 2017, as the yen's rise stalled, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.47% to 18,898.63. This came ahead of a key US-China summit. Global markets had tentatively advanced.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 2.15 points to 3,176.91. Despite this, the previous 5-day rally suggests investors remain optimistic ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: PTC begins review of public transport fare adjustment formula, mechanism
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) of Singapore has begun reviewing its public transport fare adjustment formula and mechanism. The review aims to strike a balance between affordability and financial viability, with a proposed completion by the first quarter of 2018. The PTC will engage with commuters, operators, and experts to gather views and propose improvements. Chairman Richard Magnus emphasized the need for equitable cost sharing among commuters, taxpayers, and operators, stating that service improvements come at a cost. The review will inform the 2018 annual fare review exercise.

site_title: Trump officials alarmed Chinese may bid for Westinghouse unit
summary: The Trump administration is concerned that Chinese investors may bid for Westinghouse Electric Co's nuclear business, which could lead to the disclosure of sensitive nuclear technological secrets. Cabinet members, including Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, are discussing ways to prevent a Chinese purchase and have explored alternative bids from US or friendly foreign investors. The US government has the authority to regulate corporate acquisitions involving sensitive national security technology and would likely block an open Chinese bid for majority ownership.

site_title: New Zealand's finger-lickin' posties to deliver KFC
summary: New Zealand Post has started a trial where its couriers deliver KFC food to customers' homes in the North Island town of Tauranga. The pilot scheme is part of a bid to adapt to declining letter volumes and lost revenue. KFC partnered with NZ Post due to its extensive delivery network, and the goal is to expand home delivery services nationwide. This collaboration aims to capitalize on online orders and e-commerce growth, with NZ Post's experience in on-demand delivery making it a suitable provider for KFC's food delivery needs.

site_title: Oil rises to near 1-month high on gradual tightening of supplies
summary: Oil prices rose to a one-month high on April 5, 2017, as signs of gradual tightening in the market pushed prices up 23 cents to $54.40 per barrel for Brent crude futures and 27 cents to $51.30 per barrel for WTI crude futures. The market is responding to a decline in oil production and an increase in storage tank levels, indicating a shift towards a more balanced supply and demand. This move is seen as a positive sign for the oil industry, as it could lead to higher prices and increased investment.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as China gains; oil up on North Sea outage
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by a rebound in Chinese shares, despite cautious sentiment ahead of the Trump-Xi Jinping summit. Construction counters led gains in China and Hong Kong after Beijing announced plans to build Xiongan New Area, modeled on Shenzhen's special economic zone. Investors remain wary of taking big positions due to uncertainty over US-China trade talks.

site_title: PayPal extends partnership with Visa into Asia-Pacific region
summary: PayPal is extending its partnership with Visa into the Asia-Pacific region, allowing users of both services to choose either mode of payment. This move aims to boost digital transactions for both companies. The collaboration, similar to a US deal announced last year, follows years of competition between PayPal and credit-card firms over online and in-store transactions. The partnership is seen as a positive development, with PayPal citing increased usage frequency and reduced customer complaints as encouraging signs.

site_title: Brazil lawmakers vote to regulate Uber, other apps
summary: Brazil's lower house of Congress voted to regulate ride-hailing apps like Uber, giving cities greater power to charge taxes, require insurance and pension benefits for drivers. The bill, which needs Senate approval, would make ride-hailing services a public interest activity, potentially interrupting Uber services in unregulated cities. The move aims to address concerns over the impact of the apps on local economies and drivers.

site_title: Gig economy creates ripples in Australia's A$2.1t pension pool
summary: Australia's A$2.1 trillion retirement savings pool is under strain due to the growing gig economy, where freelance workers often lack benefits like sick leave and pension fund savings. A study by Rest Super found that contingent and part-time workers miss out on A$150 million annually in super payments. Digital companies, including Uber, are not required to contribute to superannuations, leaving workers vulnerable. The Australian government is considering changes to the national benefits framework to ensure employers, like Uber, pay pension benefits, similar to the approach in the US and UK.

site_title: Philippines' March inflation rises at fastest pace in more than two years
summary: The Philippines experienced its fastest inflation rate in over two years in March, with annual headline inflation reaching 3.4%. Core inflation, excluding volatile food and fuel items, accelerated to 2.9%. Despite the steady rise in inflation, the central bank expects it to remain within its 2-4% target this year and has maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3%. This is in line with the forecast of 3.4% inflation in the Reuters poll.

site_title: Share transfer: SingHaiyi won't exercise right of first refusal granted by Haiyi
summary: SingHaiyi Group announced it will not exercise its conditional right of first refusal to transfer 500 million shares in OKH Global at a consideration price of S$0.10 apiece. The right of first refusal, granted by Haiyi Holdings, lapsed on April 4, 2017. The decision will have no further effect on the company, and the shares will remain in the capital of OKH Global.

site_title: South Korea Feb s/adj current account surplus ticks down from Jan
summary: South Korea's current account surplus decreased to a US$10.01 billion in February, down from January's revised US$10.05 billion. Exports rose 5.6% to US$50.66 billion and imports gained 5.1% to US$35.98 billion, resulting in a goods account surplus of US$12.84 billion. The current account surplus in February, without seasonal adjustments, reached a three-month high of US$8.40 billion.

site_title: US dollar edges up vs yen on 'gotobi' payment date, faces summit pressure
summary: The US dollar edged up 0.1% against the yen on 'gotobi' payment date, but remained under pressure due to North Korea's ballistic missile launch and concerns about the upcoming US-China summit. The dollar index fell, and US Treasury yields touched their lowest levels since February. The euro and Australian dollar also edged up. Investors are cautious ahead of the summit, with speculation that US President Donald Trump will face challenges implementing his policies.

site_title: YouTube unveils India mobile app for spotty Internet signals
summary: YouTube has launched a mobile app in India, designed for users with spotty internet access. The app, called YouTube Go, allows users to save videos to watch offline and monitor data usage. A beta version was released in the Google Play Store in India, with plans to expand to other emerging markets later. This move aims to boost YouTube's presence in India, a growing market with limited internet connectivity.

site_title: S i2i updates on loss and profit in financial statements for Q4, FY2016
summary: S i2i announced a difference in figures in its audited and unaudited financial statements for Q4 2016 and FY2016, mainly due to an additional provision for impairment against a loan receivable. The audited statement shows a net loss of S$1.8 million for Q4 2016, widening from S$365,000 in the unaudited statement. The audited statement also shows a net profit of S$462,000 for FY2016, down from S$1.89 million in the unaudited statement. The difference was attributed to the dismissal of a borrower's application to set aside share issuance.

site_title: North Korea fires projectile into Sea of Japan: South Korea
summary: North Korea fired a suspected missile into the Sea of Japan, according to South Korea's defense ministry on April 4, 2017. The launch, if confirmed, would be the latest by Pyongyang, fueling international concerns about its military ambitions. The move comes amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula, following a joint US-South Korea-Japan military exercise and President Donald Trump's tough stance on North Korea. The incident is also set to be discussed during Trump's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.

site_title: SIA Engineering, Stratasys ink MOU for additive manufacturing tie-up
summary: SIA Engineering and Stratasys have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to establish a strategic partnership for additive manufacturing in commercial aviation. The partnership aims to accelerate the adoption of 3D-printed products and will be majority-owned by SIA Engineering. Stratasys will provide expertise in additive manufacturing and drive aerospace applications, while SIA Engineering will offer design, engineering, certification, and part production services. The Singapore-based Additive Manufacturing Service Centre will serve SIA Engineering's network of partners and customers globally.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up after choppy day helped by oil stocks
summary: European shares ended a choppy session 0.2% higher, driven by gains in oil-related stocks and miners. The FTSE 100 rose 0.5% and autos were the biggest sectoral losers, down 0.6%. Market uncertainty remains due to currency risk, particularly in the FTSE and Euro STOXX 50.

site_title: US military confirms North Korea fired missile into Sea of Japan
summary: The US military confirmed that North Korea fired a ballistic missile, known as the KN-15, into the Sea of Japan. The missile did not pose a threat to North America, according to the North American Aerospace Defense Command (Norad). The US Pacific Command vowed to work closely with regional allies to maintain security. The move comes after North Korea warned of retaliation if global sanctions increase. The launch is part of Pyongyang's quest to develop a long-range missile capable of hitting the US mainland.

images.alt_text: The US military confirmed Tuesday that nuclear-armed North Korea had fired a ballistic missile, finding it posed no threat to North America and vowing to work closely with its regional allies.

site_title: S&P raises Argentina's credit rating
summary: Standard & Poor's raised Argentina's credit rating from B- to B, citing progress in resolving macroeconomic imbalances and rebuilding credibility. The rating bump is seen as a boost to President Mauricio Macri's center-right government, which has implemented economic reforms aimed at reviving growth. S&P predicts Argentina will return to three percent economic growth and inflation will fall to 20 percent this year, but warns of uncertainties about the pace of implementation due to ongoing political challenges.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Swiber, Oxley, SIA Engineering
summary: Swiber Holdings' lead independent director Yeo Jeu Nam has resigned to pursue personal interests. Oxley Holdings has agreed to sell 2 private flats at the Royal Wharf Development for £18.5 million (S$32.2 million). SIA Engineering has signed a memorandum of understanding with Stratasys to accelerate 3D printed products for commercial aviation.

site_title: South African bank index tumbles as S&P's junk rating puts earnings at risk
summary: South Africa's bank index plummeted 9% since President Jacob Zuma fired finance minister Pravin Gordhan, becoming the country's worst performing stocks gauge this year. S&P Global Ratings cut the country's foreign currency debt rating to junk, increasing the likelihood of lenders facing declining returns and rising bad debts. The bank index, including Standard Bank Group Ltd and Barclays Africa Group Ltd, has fallen to its lowest in six months. This move puts earnings at risk and highlights the economic uncertainty in South Africa.

site_title: Thai firm lists One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend ETF on SGX
summary: One Asset Management, Thailand's largest ETF issuer, listed its One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend ETF on Singapore Exchange. The ETF tracks the Stoxx Asean Select Dividend 30 Index, which selects top Asean companies by dividend yield. This is OneAM's first ETF listing in Singapore and the first to use Asean's Collective Investment Schemes framework, which includes Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. The listing aims to provide investors with access to Asean dividend opportunities.

images.alt_text: THAILAND'S largest ETF (exchange-traded fund) issuer and asset management company, One Asset Management (OneAM), on Wednesday listed its One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend Exchange Traded Fund on Singapore Exchange.

site_title: A 3M outcome - May, Merkel, Macron - may boost Europe stability
summary: A potential alliance between Theresa May, Angela Merkel, and Emmanuel Macron could boost Europe's stability. May's UK will negotiate a relatively civilised divorce from the EU, with the other 27 members showing that a non-EU future will be poorer and unhappier. Merkel, likely to remain Chancellor for a fourth term, and Macron, who may win the French presidential election, could form a strong partnership. This 3M outcome could provide Europe with stability over the next two years, mitigating the risks of disintegration and promoting cooperation.

site_title: Amazon drops appeal, to pay US$70m for kids app buys
summary: Amazon has dropped its appeal of a US regulator's order to pay refunds up to $70 million for in-app purchases made by children on its tablet computers between 2011 and 2016. The Federal Trade Commission and Amazon agreed to withdraw the court challenge, similar to actions taken against Apple and Google. The order requires Amazon to refund some $70 million to affected customers, clearing the way for the refunds.

site_title: Argentina ex-leader Kirchner charged with fraud
summary: Argentina's ex-president Cristina Kirchner, 64, was charged with money laundering in real estate dealings, her fourth set of criminal charges in a year. The charge comes as Argentina heads for mid-term elections, with President Mauricio Macri seen as a key opponent. Federal judge Claudio Bonadio brought the formal charges against Kirchner, who has been under scrutiny for corruption cases. This latest development adds to the long-running legal saga and raises pressure on Kirchner ahead of the elections.

site_title: Trump's son Eric calls nepotism 'factor of life'
summary: US President Donald Trump's son Eric Trump believes nepotism is a "factor of life" in the White House, stating it's a reality they've "earned our stripes" to overcome. Eric Trump, 33, made the comments in an interview with Forbes, where he also defended his family's business dealings. Jared Kushner, Ivanka Trump, and Eric Trump are all White House advisers, and Ivanka Trump recently became a federal employee. The Trump Organization has faced criticism for concentrating power in the hands of relatives and potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Britain should overhaul corporate pay, ditch long-term incentives: lawmakers
summary: British lawmakers recommend overhauling corporate pay and scrapping long-term incentives to rebuild public trust in corporate culture following recent scandals. Companies should publish annual pay ratios and workers should be represented on remuneration committees. The report also criticizes the lack of transparency in long-term incentive plans, calling for reforms to incentivize decision-making for the business's long-term success. The Confederation of British Industry agrees that long-term plans can be too complex, but warns banning them could limit flexibility for companies to reward executives.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as investors await China meeting, earnings season
summary: US stocks remained flat on Tuesday as investors awaited the first-quarter earnings season and the potential meeting between President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Despite Trump's pro-business policy promises, recent setbacks in pushing reforms through Congress have led investors to question his ability to deliver. Retail stocks fell, with Ralph Lauren and Nordstrom Inc. downgrading, while airline stocks declined after Delta Airlines cut forecasts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.06%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.07%.

site_title: US approves ChemChina's $43 bn takeover of Syngenta
summary: US antitrust regulators approved ChemChina's $43 billion takeover of Syngenta, requiring the Chinese company to sell three products to address competition concerns. The Federal Trade Commission agreed that the merger would have likely led to higher prices for consumers. ChemChina's generics subsidiary ADAMA would have dominated the US market for the affected products, prompting the divestitures. The deal was approved under a preliminary settlement.

site_title: BI's top woman fights inflation with more than just interest rates
summary: BI's top woman, Rosmaya Hadi, enlisted 2,000 religious leaders to spread a message of moderation in Indonesia to combat inflation, particularly during the Eid al-Fitr festival. They preached about moderation, haggling, and responsible spending, aiming to curb excessive spending.

site_title: Trading reps should now raise their game and elevate service levels
summary: Trading representatives in Singapore face a challenging profession due to deregulation and technological disruption. A 17-year period of changes, including reduced broking commissions and tightened rules, led to a decline in TRs' incomes and working conditions. However, recent developments offer hope, with the Singapore Exchange considering a 12-1pm break and the Monetary Authority of Singapore amending rules to allow TRs more leeway in providing financial advice. This relaxation of rules could help TRs regain their value and elevate service levels, prompting them to "raise their game" to compete in the industry.

site_title: Women on boards: 20% target by 2020 and 30% by 2030
summary: The Diversity Action Committee (DAC) in Singapore has set escalating targets to increase women's representation on boards, aiming for 20% by 2020, 25% by 2025, and 30% by 2030. The committee believes that recognizing the business benefits of women on boards will drive change, rather than mandatory compliance. To meet the first target, companies will need to replace male directors with female appointments on 459 board seats. The DAC will focus on larger companies, which tend to have the resources and corporate-governance foundations to make quick changes.

site_title: Oprah Winfrey is Weight Watchers' best paid, most absent board member
summary: Oprah Winfrey, Weight Watchers' best-paid and most absent board member, received $264,753 for her services last year despite attending fewer than 75% of the company's 10 meetings in 2016. Winfrey's absences include skipping the annual meeting and won't attend this year's shareholder meeting, sparking concerns about her level of engagement. Despite this, Winfrey's significant stake in the company and voting agreement ensure her seat is secure.

site_title: Bad Brexit deal will hurt some EU states more than others
summary: A study by the Centre for European Policy Studies found that a bad Brexit deal would negatively impact some European nations more than others, with small member states and those with historical ties to the UK being severely damaged. The study estimated that Ireland would suffer similar losses as the UK due to its trade dependency on the UK, with Malta and Cyprus also among the most exposed. Germany, the largest exporter to the UK, would experience a relatively small impact, while the UK's exports to the EU would amount to 7.5% of its GDP.

site_title: Will 2017 be a better year for shipping?
summary: Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) is set to analyze the industry's prospects for 2017, with projected growth of 2-4% in container shipping demand and growing demand in bulk and tanker segments. Industry experts, including René Piil Pedersen, chairman of the International Committee of the Singapore Shipping Association, are optimistic about the year, citing digitalization as a huge opportunity to create more value for customers. However, confidence levels in the industry remain cautious, with many respondents expecting a year of retrenchment rather than improvement, citing high competition, overtonnaging, and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: With HK closed, it's quiet on trading front
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended with an 8.45-point loss at 3,179.06 due to quiet trading ahead of US President Donald Trump's meeting with China's President Xi Jinping on Friday. Chasen Holdings was the day's most active stock, with its shares jumping 17.4% after announcing contract wins in Malaysia and Vietnam. Analysts expect US equities to experience sideways drift to lower prices in coming weeks, citing uncertainty over the Trump administration's fiscal and infrastructure agenda.

site_title: Contractors' cash flows worsen; small guys hardest hit
summary: Contractors' cash flows worsened in Q1 2017, with the construction sector hit the hardest, experiencing a 55.22% slow payment rate, up from 47.97% in Q4 2016. The sector's payment performance declined quarter-on-quarter, and it registered the highest proportion of slow payments since Q4 2011. Economists predict the sector will remain the worst-performing sector in Singapore this year, with a forecasted growth rate of 0.3%. The government has announced plans to bring forward S$700 million in infrastructure projects to support the sector.

site_title: New One Stoxx ETF to track high dividend Asean stocks
summary: A new exchange-traded fund (ETF) tracking high-dividend paying companies in fast-growing South-east Asia will launch on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Wednesday. The One Stoxx Asean Select Dividend Index Fund will offer investors exposure to 30 high-dividend companies from Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines, with an annual management fee of 0.5%. The ETF aims to track the Stoxx Asean Select Dividend 30 index, managed by Thailand's largest non-bank asset manager, One Asset Management.

site_title: JPMorgan chief sees higher risk of EU breakup
summary: JPMorgan Chase's CEO Jamie Dimon expressed concerns about a higher risk of an EU breakup, citing Brexit as a catalyst. He fears that the resulting political unrest could force the EU to split apart, leading to "devastating" economic and political effects. Dimon had hoped the EU would focus on addressing issues like immigration and labor rules following Britain's exit. The EU's potential breakup would have significant implications for the global economy and politics.

site_title: URA to tackle developers that misrepresent info: Lawrence Wong
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore will take action against developers who misrepresent information about their units to prospective home-buyers. Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of providing accurate and drawn-to-scale floor plans. This move aims to protect homebuyers and maintain transparency in the property market.

site_title: Wall Street braces for rough ride as exchanges seek more speed bumps
summary: US stock exchanges, including the NYSE, Chicago Stock Exchange, and Nasdaq, are awaiting decisions by the SEC on proposals to introduce "speed bumps" and new order types to slow down trades and level the playing field for small investors. The proposals follow the launch of IEX Group, which introduced a speed bump and other features to protect small investors from high-speed trading. The SEC is expected to approve or reject the proposals in the coming weeks, with concerns that high-frequency traders are eating into the market share of ordinary investors.

site_title: New type of tenant in US growing like a weed
summary: In the US, the growing legal marijuana industry is transforming the real estate market, with many buildings being repurposed for cultivation and processing. Since legalization, over 2 dozen states have seen a surge in demand, with warehouses, factories, and strip malls being converted into storefronts selling pre-rolled joints and edibles. Landlords are charging premium rates, and the industry is expected to reach $20 billion by 2021. However, concerns arise about a potential real estate bubble, as millions are spent on making old warehouses suitable for cannabis cultivation, and the industry may eventually shift to less expensive greenhouses.

site_title: Singapore Prestige Brand Award 2017 launched
summary: The Singapore Prestige Brand Award (SPBA) 2017 was launched with a broader judging criteria that considers innovation and technology in branding. The award, now in its 16th year, honors local brands with compelling messages and strategies. Two new areas, "Digitalisation" and "Brand Innovation," have been added to the judging criteria, emphasizing the importance of harnessing digital technology for brands to compete effectively. Entries close on May 26, with winners announced in September.

site_title: Singapore making progress in advanced manufacturing
summary: Singapore is making progress in advanced manufacturing with 25 companies investing in the industry, including Seagate Technology's "dream factory" project. The government is committed to investing in advanced manufacturing technologies and supporting their adoption. Companies are leveraging technologies like additive manufacturing, the Industrial Internet-of-Things, and robotics to improve productivity and efficiency. New job opportunities such as industrial data analysts and robot coordinators are arising, and the government is accelerating reskilling efforts through various programs to equip workers with the necessary skills.

site_title: Qatar to lift ban on development of world's largest gas field
summary: Qatar Petroleum has lifted a self-imposed ban on developing the world's largest gas field, the North Field, which it shares with Iran. The ban, in place since 2005, was intended to study the impact of rapid output growth on the reservoir. The North Field, accounting for nearly all of Qatar's gas production and 60% of its export revenue, will have a capacity of 2 billion cubic feet per day when development begins in five to seven years. This move aims to counter expected competition from other LNG exporters.

site_title: Trump targets visa scheme that feeds Silicon Valley
summary: The US administration has introduced new guidelines to crack down on the H-1B work visa program, which channels thousands of skilled overseas workers to tech companies. The guidelines require applicants to prove that jobs are complicated and require advanced knowledge and experience. The changes, effective immediately, target outsourcing firms and will focus inspections on workplaces with the largest percentage of H-1B workers. The move aims to reduce exploitation of foreign workers and increase scrutiny on companies hiring lower-paid foreign workers.

site_title: Seadrill gets 3-month extension for debt restructuring talks
summary: Seadrill, a US$14 billion-debt-ridden rig owner-operator, has secured a 3-month extension for debt restructuring talks with its lenders until July 31. The company had warned of potential Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if an agreement cannot be reached. Its two subsidiaries, North Atlantic Drilling and Sevan Drilling, are still awaiting delivery of two rigs valued at over US$1 billion. Seadrill's lenders have agreed to extend the restructuring talks, allowing the company to continue exploring commercial opportunities for its units.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Airlines launched and priced S$700 million in bonds due 2025 with a 3.035% coupon rate. KS Energy secured a US$11.1 million contract for a jack-up drilling rig in Vietnam. Yeo Jeu Nam, lead independent director at Swiber Holdings, resigned to pursue personal interests. RH Petrogas' auditor noted significant liabilities exceeding assets by US$25.3 million. TEHO International filed a writ of summons against two vendors seeking S$6 million in damages.

site_title: S i2i subsidiary looks to acquire e-commerce platform for S$6.3m
summary: S i2i subsidiary Affinity Capital enters into an asset transfer agreement with SB ISAT Fund for the proposed acquisition of an e-commerce platform for S$6.3 million. The acquisition is in line with S i2i's plans to expand into innovative areas, including e-commerce. The deal will dilute Affinity's equity interest from 100% to 50% plus one share. The company will convene an EGM to seek shareholders' approval for the transaction, aiming to improve its financial performance and move off the Singapore Exchange's watchlist.

site_title: EU steps up efforts to deal with bad debts of more than one trillion euros
summary: The European Union is stepping up efforts to address the €1.1 trillion in non-performing debt (NPLs) affecting its lenders, with the Maltese presidency calling for a multi-faceted approach to prevent financial instability and hinder economic growth. EU officials aim to encourage the development of secondary markets for bad loans, increase transparency, and boost private investors. The European Commission will coordinate a European strategy, and an asset management company may be set up to take over and manage the selloff of banks' soured loans, although previous examples have shown limited success.

site_title: Share buybacks fall as stock prices move up
summary: Share buybacks in Singapore declined 57% in March 2017 to S$29.1 million, with 20 companies participating. The year-to-date repurchase stands at S$82 million. This decrease is attributed to rising stock prices.

site_title: Xi's Nordic stopover en route to US reveals shift in global trade focus
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's stopover in Helsinki, Finland, before meeting with Donald Trump, signals a shift in global trade focus. The Finnish trip reflects a commitment to open trade and cooperation, contrasting with protectionist sentiments in other regions. This move comes as China seeks to diversify its trade relationships and strengthen ties with Nordic countries. The trip underscores Xi's diplomatic efforts to promote China's interests and maintain global economic stability.

site_title: Laptop ban, KL airport attack highlight need to overhaul checkpoint security globally
summary: A recent surge in international air travel and major land infrastructure projects has highlighted the need for a global overhaul of checkpoint security. The US and UK's laptop ban and the assassination of Kim Jong-Nam at Kuala Lumpur International Airport demonstrate the need for advanced surveillance systems. Artificial intelligence (AI) can help predict potential wrongdoing by analyzing data from images, sounds, and video footage, and quickly search CCTV archival footage to identify patterns and collaborators. Implementing AI-driven surveillance systems and intelligent tools can help prevent security breaches and save precious minutes in emergency situations.

site_title: IMDA raises S$1.14b from spectrum auction
summary: The Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) has concluded the first stage of the General Spectrum Auction in Singapore, raising S$1.14 billion from the auction of 175 MHz of spectrum among four telcos, including new entrant TPG Telecom. The spectrum, including 900MHz, 700MHz, and 2.5GHz bands, will be granted following full payment and is expected to enable the industry to roll out or enhance mobile networks to meet increasing demand. The auction saw aggressive bidding, with Singtel spending S$563.7 million for 75MHz of spectrum and StarHub securing 60MHz for S$349.6 million.

site_title: Madrid show delves into Picasso's dark journey to Guernica
summary: The Reina Sofia museum in Madrid launched an exhibition to mark the 80th anniversary of Pablo Picasso's masterpiece, Guernica. The show explores Picasso's dark journey to the painting, delving into his work before and after Guernica, and sheds light on his creative process. The exhibition aims to provide new insights into the artist's inspiration and the making of one of the world's most famous paintings.

site_title: Choice of India's Adani for Carey port-city surprises market
summary: Malaysia has selected India's Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd (APSEZ) to conduct feasibility studies for a container terminal on Carey Island off Port Klang and an integrated maritime city. The project, worth US$36 billion, is part of a combined trade deal between Malaysia and India. Despite concerns about the project's viability, APSEZ's CEO Karan Adani sees Malaysia as a strategic location for investment, citing the Strait of Malacca as a global shipping route. The move has been met with skepticism, with some analysts labeling it "only for show" to boost election sentiments.

site_title: Goldman sees reasons for foreign investors to return to Japanese stocks
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts foreign investors may return to Japanese stocks, citing corporate governance reforms, domestic demand recovery, and strong performance in US dollar terms. This comes after a net 1.1 trillion yen sale by foreign investors in the last quarter. The Topix index rose 4.4% in dollar terms, but fell 0.4% in yen terms, and domestic flows are playing a greater role in the correlation with foreign fund flows. The yen's appreciation and concerns over Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's leadership also contributed to the recent selling.

site_title: Trump is wimping out on trade
summary: US President Donald Trump is failing to deliver on his campaign promise to renegotiate the country's "horrible trade deals", instead issuing two executive orders that were largely symbolic and duplicative. The executive orders were met with skepticism from business leaders and investors, who see Trump's trade policy as ineffective. The administration's proposal to revise the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) is also seen as modest, not the sweeping changes promised by Trump. This has led to a perception that Trump's trade policy is "talk loudly and carry a small stick", with many questioning the president's ability to deliver on his trade agenda.

site_title: Manhattan home resales rebound as sellers agree to cut prices
summary: Manhattan home resales rose 7.7% in the first quarter, reversing a year-and-a-half decline, as sellers lowered prices to seal deals before inventory and interest rates increase. Buyers secured discounts averaging 4.5% off asking prices, up from 2.7% last year. Contracts to buy homes rose 3% to 3,009 pending deals, while the median price of all apartments sold dropped 3.3% to $1.1 million. Sellers are softening their stances due to higher mortgage rates and increased listings.

site_title: Unusual Group launches S$19.4m IPO via placement
summary: Film and TV content producer mm2 Asia has launched the initial public offering (IPO) of its events production unit, the Unusual Group, on the junior Catalist board, seeking to raise about S$19.4 million. The Unusual Group will offer 96.99 million placement shares at S$0.20 each, with its market capitalisation expected to be about S$128.6 million after the placement. The IPO will be used to invest in promotion and production projects, expand via acquisitions, and for working capital.

site_title: Tech overthrows financials as king of emerging markets
summary: Tech stocks overtook financials as the main driver of emerging market shares, with a 17% surge in technology shares in the first quarter, surpassing financial shares for the first time since 2004. This push technology shares to 24% weight in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index, outperforming industrial and financial stocks every year since 2011. The sector's strong growth is attributed to the growing prominence of Chinese consumers and the increasing adoption of technology in emerging markets, with some firms experiencing returns of over 500%.

site_title: Feb trade deficit falls as exports hit two-year high
summary: The US trade deficit fell 9.6% in February to $43.6 billion, the lowest in six months, as exports hit a two-year high and imports declined due to slowing domestic demand. Exports of goods and services increased 0.2% to $192.9 billion, with gains in car and parts shipments. The trade deficit with China dropped 26.6% to $23.0 billion, while the deficit with Germany was at its smallest since January 2013.

site_title: Total is third oil major to back S'pore LNG bunkering ambition
summary: Total, a French oil major, has teamed up with Pavilion Gas to support Singapore's LNG bunkering ambitions ahead of the global sulphur cap on ship fuels. The agreement, signed at the Gastech 2017 exhibition, aims to secure 10% of the global LNG bunkering market by 2025. This is the third oil major, following ExxonMobil and Shell, to collaborate on LNG bunkering in Singapore, which has already set a world record for bunker sales. The partnership is seen as a key strategy for Total to develop a competitive worldwide LNG bunkering network.

site_title: Lavish car launches worth it, say luxury brands
summary: Luxury car brands, including Porsche, McLaren, and BMW, recently launched high-end models with significant budgets. The Porsche Panamera's unveiling at Marina Bay Sands Expo and Convention Centre was attended by 1,300 guests and cost around $750,000. The McLaren 720S supercar's launch, held at the same venue, was attended by 600 guests and cost "several hundred thousand dollars." BMW's introduction of the new 5 Series executive sedan, held over three days, was attended by over 4,000 customers and featured a theatrical show with aerialists and UN Patron Lewis Pugh.

site_title: Ex-Google self-driving car engineer made more than US$120m
summary: A former Google engineer, Anthony Levandowski, made over $120 million in incentive payments for recruiting from Google's self-driving car unit, Waymo, to his company Otto. Waymo claims Levandowski breached his contract and also founded companies that competed with Google. Levandowski's current employer, Uber, is trying to resolve the dispute in private arbitration. The case highlights the intense competition among tech companies and carmakers for talent in the autonomous vehicle sector.

site_title: Pushing for greater accountability of Reit managers in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Reit market is the second largest in Asia, but unitholders have limited rights to interfere with Reit management. The Securities and Futures (Amendment) Act 2017 introduces statutory protections for unitholders against Reit manager failure to act in their best interests. However, unitholders currently have limited options to hold managers accountable under the current regime. A two-part article explores available options for unitholders to hold Reit managers accountable.

site_title: Ascott sets its sights on South America
summary: Ascott Limited, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has signed franchise agreements with Vitacon to operate two serviced residences in Sao Paulo, Brazil. The 92-unit Citadines VN Jardins Sao Paulo and 122-unit Citadines VN Faria Lima Sao Paulo are set to open in 2017 and 2020, respectively. The partnership aims to establish a portfolio of at least 5,000 Citadines branded units in Sao Paulo, with plans to expand to other major cities in Brazil and neighboring countries, with a goal of 10,000 units in South America within five years.

site_title: BMW gains ground on Mercedes in US luxury car race
summary: BMW surpassed Mercedes in the US luxury car market for the first time this year, driven by strong sales of SUVs like the X3 and X5. BMW delivered 31,015 vehicles in March, outselling Mercedes by about 1,900 units. The victory narrowed the gap between the two brands to 7,500 vehicle sales through the first three months of the year. BMW's CEO plans to respond with a significant rollout of new and revamped models over the next two years, aiming to regain the global sales title from Mercedes.

site_title: Lessons from Trump's healthcare debacle
summary: US President Donald Trump's domestic economic agenda suffered a major setback as the House Republican leadership withdrew their draft to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA). This failure is a significant blow to Trump's policy push, particularly on taxes, due to three key reasons. The Republican majority's inability to produce a viable draft raises questions about the success of Trump's next major policy initiative. The outcome highlights the challenges Trump faces in implementing his domestic agenda.

site_title: European equity dividends 'worth another look'
summary: Allianz Global Investors' Holger Wehner suggests European equity dividends are worth re-examining due to their attractive yields and lower valuations. Despite concerns over "political overhangs," Wehner points to positive trends such as stronger domestic economies, expected earnings growth, and a shift towards value stocks. European equities are trading at a 40% discount to US stocks, and dividend yields are higher than many countries' 10-year government bond yields, providing stability to portfolios. Wehner's European Equity Dividend Fund aims to distribute a 5% annual dividend yield and has historically shown lower volatility than its benchmark index.

site_title: Spotify, Universal sign global licence agreement
summary: Spotify and Universal Music Group signed a multi-year global licence agreement, allowing Spotify's paying subscribers to access new Universal albums for two weeks after release. This deal will provide Universal with unprecedented access to Spotify's data, enabling the creation of new tools for artists and labels to engage with fans. The agreement comes as Spotify continues to grow, exceeding 50 million paying subscribers, and consolidates its position as the world's number one music streaming service.

site_title: Coal soars 15% as Australia shipments take a hit from cyclone
summary: Coal prices surged 15% on Monday, the largest daily gain in nearly four years, as damage from tropical cyclone Debbie disrupted Australia's top coal exports. Australia, the world's largest coal shipper, experienced floods and landslides in Queensland, where 50% of the world's seaborne coking coal is produced. The cyclone's impact is expected to last five weeks, with Wood Mackenzie and UBS predicting further price increases, potentially topping $300 a tonne.

site_title: Swiber's lead independent director resigns
summary: SWIBER Holdings announced the resignation of lead independent director Yeo Jeu Nam, citing a desire to pursue personal interests. Yeo is also a director at Vallianz Holdings and Frencken Group. The resignation occurred on April 4, 2017.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hires banks for debut US dollar benchmark sukuk
summary: Saudi Arabia has mandated Citigroup, HSBC, and JP Morgan as global coordinators to arrange meetings for its debut US dollar benchmark sukuk, offering 5- and 10-year maturities. The meetings will take place in Abu Dhabi, Dubai, and London starting April 9. BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank, and NCB Capital will join as joint lead managers and bookrunners. The sovereign is rated A1 by Moody's and A+ by Fitch.

site_title: Yen hits high against euro; A$ drops to 3-week low
summary: Risk-averse investors drove the yen to its highest level against the euro since mid-November, with the yen reaching a 9.8 times oversubscription for NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar dropped to a three-week low amid market nerves ahead of a US-China meeting and a suspected suicide bombing in St Petersburg, Russia. The Australian dollar's decline also contributed to a lower Wall Street opening on July 11, 2025, amidst fresh US tariffs on Canada.

site_title: From ganja to goats, there's a yoga class for each
summary: Yoga has evolved into a diverse and eclectic practice, offering various classes that cater to different interests and preferences. From "ganja yoga" with marijuana to "yoga with goats," studios have introduced unique and often humorous classes to attract a broader audience. While some argue that yoga has become too commercialized, others see this as a natural evolution of the practice, which has always been open to malleability. As the US$17 billion industry continues to grow, yoga is adapting to meet the needs of its diverse practitioners, making it more inclusive and accessible.

site_title: BMW pulls advertising from Fox News' "O'Reilly Factor"
summary: BMW has suspended its advertising on Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor" following a New York Times report that Fox and host Bill O'Reilly paid $13 million to five women who accused him of sexual harassment. This move makes BMW the third advertiser to pull its ads from the program, joining Mercedes-Benz and Hyundai Motor Corp. The decision comes amid growing concerns over O'Reilly's behavior and the network's handling of the allegations.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors cut China output amid tensions: sources
summary: Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors have reduced vehicle production in China due to anti-Korean sentiment and competition from Chinese brands. The move comes amid diplomatic tensions and follows a significant drop in March sales. China accounted for over a quarter of the pair's 2016 overseas sales, but their March sales were severely impacted. The production cuts threaten earnings for the companies.

site_title: US:Banks, tech stocks lead Wall St lower
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, led by financial and technology shares, due to concerns over President Trump's meeting with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 21.82 points, or 0.11%, to 20,628.39, while the S&P 500 dropped 4.6 points, or 0.20%, to 2,354.24. The Nasdaq Composite fell 7.90 points, or 0.13%, to 5,886.79. Investors are wary of Trump's potential use of trade as leverage against China, and his administration's struggles to pass legislation through Congress.

site_title: US trade deficit falls as exports hit two-year high
summary: The US trade deficit fell 9.6% in February to $43.6 billion, its lowest level in six months, as exports reached a two-year high. Exports of goods and services increased 0.2% to $192.9 billion, with gains in automobile shipments and industrial supplies. The real trade deficit decreased to $59.7 billion, and the US-China trade deficit dropped 26.6% to $23.0 billion. Economists expect trade to remain a small drag on GDP growth in the first quarter.

site_title: Credit Suisse probe is a blow for Swiss authorities
summary: Swiss authorities are facing damage-control mode after a probe into Credit Suisse Group AG, a blow to the firm and the attorney-general's office, which claims it was "astonished" it wasn't informed in advance of the March 30 raids in London, Paris, and Amsterdam. The raids follow a decade of financial scandals, including the Panama Papers. The Swiss financial watchdog, Finma, is hosting its annual press conference, where CEO Mark Branson is set to answer questions about the raids. The incident raises questions about the effectiveness of the attorney-general's office.

site_title: India, Britain talk up post-Brexit trade prospects
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley and British counterpart Philip Hammond discussed post-Brexit trade prospects during their meeting in New Delhi. Hammond downplayed risks of a "hard Brexit," aiming to negotiate a deep and special relationship with the EU for open trade and investment. The talks come after British Prime Minister Theresa May triggered the Brexit process, and India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi emphasized the importance of trade and freedom of movement for skilled workers. The two nations aim to rebuild relationships with partners worldwide while maintaining ties with the EU.

site_title: EU parliament urges new checks to stop emissions cheating
summary: The European Parliament has urged European authorities to establish new checks to prevent automakers from cheating on emissions testing, following the Volkswagen "dieselgate" scandal. MEPs called for swift action to improve tests and checks on new cars, recommending a single European commissioner oversee emissions legislative proposals. The parliament also urged manufacturers to compensate buyers and proposed a collective EU redress system. The recommendations aim to boost oversight and sanctions powers, addressing concerns over the flawed testing system and consumer protection.

site_title: SIA sells S$700m in bonds due 2025 at 3.035% coupon
summary: Singapore Airlines has sold S$700 million in bonds due in 2025 with a 3.035% coupon rate. The bonds, issued in denominations of S$250,000, are expected to be issued on April 11, 2017. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate and working capital purposes.

site_title: Boeing reaches $3b deal to sell jets to Iranian Airline
summary: Boeing has reached a $3 billion deal to sell 30 737 MAX jets to Iranian airline Iran Aseman Airlines, the second major deal in the country in four months. The agreement, valued at list prices, provides an option for 30 additional planes and is expected to create or sustain 18,000 US jobs. This sale comes after international sanctions on Iran were lifted as part of its nuclear deal with world powers, and is a potential test for US President Donald Trump's stance on the deal. Deliveries are scheduled to start in 2022.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Raffles Medical Group announced plans to develop a new 700-bed hospital in Chongqing, China, expected to start operations in phases from August 2018. CIMB analysts predict margin pressure will intensify due to the project's cost, potentially dragging down earnings. However, DBS Group Research sees growth potential, citing turnaround efforts in BreadTalk's foodcourt business and bakery cost efficiencies. Despite valuations, BreadTalk is reinstated with a Buy call, while CIMB maintains a Reduce call due to the Chongqing hospital's potential impact on earnings.

site_title: Tide is turning for Malaysian equities
summary: Malaysia's stock market has seen a strong comeback in 2017, with its key index up 6.2% year-to-date, driven by improving global growth and firming commodity prices. Foreign funds have been net buyers on Bursa Malaysia for three consecutive weeks, with cumulative purchases totaling RM4.7 billion, making Malaysia the most favored Asean emerging market among global investors. This turnaround is expected to boost the country's long-ruling Barisan Nasional party ahead of the 14th general election. Analysts predict the rally may shift to lower liners, fueled by various catalysts.

site_title: All euro business should be moved from London after Brexit -top lawmaker
summary: A top EU lawmaker, Manfred Weber, has stated that all euro business should be moved from London to the European Union after Brexit, citing the need for European supervision and job protection. This move would relocate the clearing business of derivatives denominated in euros, a lucrative business currently dominated by London. Weber's remarks could impact Brexit talks and may involve a proposal from the European Commission to force the relocation of London's clearing business to the EU.

site_title: China's 'new model' asks too much of the US
summary: China's "new model" of major-country relations, proposed by President Xi Jinping, aims to prevent US intervention in Beijing's foreign policy domain. The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, may have endorsed the concept, but it's unclear if Trump will accept the proposal. The "new model" demands the US cede geostrategic space, with no apparent concessions from China. The proposal, first offered to President Obama in 2013, has raised concerns about the US' growing dependence on China. Trump's stance on the issue remains uncertain, potentially altering the trajectory of US-China relations.

images.alt_text: Mr Tillerson with President Xi at their meeting in Beijing last month.

site_title: Azimo lets recipients sort out money transfer headaches
summary: Azimo, a UK-based online money transfer firm, has introduced a new feature allowing users to send cash to any mobile phone number via text message, eliminating the need for account details. Recipients can then claim the money through the Azimo app or at a local kiosk. This move aims to simplify the process of sending remittances, particularly in emerging markets where smartphones are prevalent. The service is available in 28 Eurozone countries and will be rolled out globally in 2017.

site_title: 'Pink Star' diamond fetches record $71.2 mn in Hong Kong
summary: The 59.60-carat "Pink Star" diamond, the largest in its class ever graded by the Gemological Institute of America, sold for a record-breaking $71.2 million at Sotheby's Hong Kong auction on April 4, 2017. This surpasses the previous record of $83 million set by the same diamond in 2013. The flawless oval-cut rock, discovered in Africa in 1999, was sold after a five-minute bidding process, with a phone bidder emerging as the winner. The sale marked a new world auction record for any type of jewel.

site_title: Alarm bells ringing for Trump bull market, but who's listening?
summary: The US stock market, despite an eight-day losing streak, has been generally buoyant in the Trump administration's opening weeks. However, key indicators, such as the Shiller CAPE ratio, suggest that the market is expensive and investor optimism is tinged with worry. The CAPE ratio, a measure of real stock price divided by a 10-year average of real earnings, is at its highest level since 1929, indicating a dim outlook for the market over the next 10 years. Investor sentiment surveys also show low valuation confidence and low crash confidence, but high one-year confidence, suggesting that investors are optimistic about the Trump boom.

site_title: Oxley grants leases for some London properties for £18.5m
summary: Oxley Holdings has agreed to grant leases for certain private flats at the Royal Wharf Development in London for £18.5 million (S$32.2 million). The leases are for plots 13, 14, 17, 18, 20, and 24, and will be granted to Weathercourt Limited and Claycourt Limited. The agreement is part of the company's efforts to monetize its assets and provide buyers with the opportunity to purchase the private flats.

site_title: Singapore shares finish lower; HK closure means thin volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 8.45 points to 3,179.06 on Tuesday, trading within a narrow band due to Hong Kong's closure for the Ching Ming festival. Turnover was low at S$882 million, despite expectations. The index had previously rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Shell to fuel world's first LNG-powered Aframax oil tankers
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will fuel the world's first LNG-powered Aframax oil tankers under a deal with Russian shipping company SCF Group. The deal aims to meet stricter emissions regulations in 2020, as oil tankers face tougher sulphur emissions limits. Shell will supply four Aframax tankers operating in the Baltic Sea and northern Europe with LNG from a bunkering vessel in Rotterdam and the Baltics, starting operations in the third quarter of 2018. LNG offers virtually no sulphur content and low nitrogen oxides, making it a cleaner alternative to traditional fuel oil and marine gasoil.

site_title: Teho seeks S$6m in damages from 2 vendors
summary: Teho International, a CATALIST-LISTED oil and gas-related company, has filed a writ of summons against two vendors of shares in its wholly owned subsidiary, TIEC Holdings, seeking approximately S$6 million in damages and costs. The claim is related to a breach of duties towards TIEC while the vendors were directors. This is the second writ of summons Teho has issued, following one in January over non-compliance with a 2014 sale and purchase agreement.

site_title: Alan Howard raises over $700 mln for his new fund - sources
summary: British hedge fund manager Alan Howard has raised over $700 million for his new fund, the AH Fund, which started trading on March 1. The fund, managed solely by Howard, has also received an additional $2 billion from the main fund at his firm, Brevan Howard Asset Management. The AH Fund seeks a minimum $50 million investment from each investor, charging a 0.75% management fee and a 30% performance fee. The launch comes as Brevan Howard has seen an asset decline of around $22 billion since 2012.

site_title: German car sales jump in March on extra selling days
summary: German car sales jumped 11% in March, with 360,000 new passenger cars registered, the highest in almost a year. This growth was largely driven by an increase in private demand and three additional selling days. First-quarter sales were up 6-7% to around 845,000 vehicles, with strong sales also reported in Italy and Spain. However, sales are expected to shrink in April due to the Easter weekend. This growth is a positive sign for the European auto market, but sales are still expected to decline.

site_title: LNG supply gap may form as investment drop stymies projects
summary: The global liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry is facing a potential supply gap in about five years due to low prices discouraging investment in new production. Major producers, including Total SA, warn of global overcapacity and reduced investments, which could lead to a lack of supply. This shortage is particularly concerning as the industry is expected to play a crucial role in reducing emissions from other fossil fuels to combat global warming. The industry's future investments are necessary to meet growing demand and mitigate this supply gap.

site_title: RH Petrogas' auditor flags cashflow concern
summary: RH Petrogas' auditor, Ernst & Young, has flagged a cashflow concern over the oil-and-gas firm's audited financial statements for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2016. The auditor noted a net loss of US$8.94 million, with current and total liabilities exceeding current and total assets by US$25.3 million and US$36.1 million, respectively. This indicates a material uncertainty about the group's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Indonesia gives Freeport temporary license to resume exports
summary: Indonesia's government has issued a temporary license to Freeport-McMoRan Inc's local unit, allowing the miner to resume copper concentrate exports from its Grasberg mine after a three-month gap. The license, valid for eight months, comes as Freeport had vowed to hold out for investment safeguards before agreeing to convert its Contract of Work into a special license. The move may enable Freeport to operate the mine at full capacity and resume concentrate exports, currently exported at 40% capacity to a smelter in Java island.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.700 points to 1,747.190 on Tuesday, closing higher. Volume was 3.974 billion lots worth RM2.871 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 533 to 384.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets stabilized on Tuesday, one day after a deadly subway explosion in Russia. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.2% to 7,299.89 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 remained flat. Global shares had declined after the explosion.

site_title: Contractors' cash flows continue to deteriorate; construction worst hit
summary: Contractors in Singapore are facing deteriorating cash flows, with the construction sector experiencing a significant increase in slow payments to 55.22% in Q1 2017, up from 47.97% in Q4 2016. This is the sector's worst performance in over five years. The construction sector is expected to grow only 0.3% this year, down from a previous forecast of 2.4%. The government has announced plans to bring forward S$700 million worth of infrastructure projects to support the sector.

site_title: Radical Islamist suspected in Russia blast that killed 14
summary: Russian investigators suspect a radical Islamist immigrant from Kyrgyzstan, Akbarzhon Dzhalilov, detonated an explosive in a St Petersburg subway car, killing 14 people in the worst attack in a major Russian city in years. The blast occurred as the train traveled between two major hub stations in the city center, and remains of the bomber are undergoing DNA testing. US President Donald Trump offered support for Russia in responding to the attack and bringing those responsible to justice, as the Kremlin tightened security measures following the attack.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau reported that overall payment performance improved in Q1 2017, with prompt payments accounting for less than half of total transactions. Total signed a memorandum of understanding with Pavilion Energy for LNG bunkering cooperation. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to US Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index. Thailand's Thaksin is confident of his daughter's court case outcome.

site_title: Mercedes joins forces with Bosch to develop self-driving taxis
summary: Daimler, parent company of Mercedes-Benz, has partnered with Bosch to develop self-driving taxis, with the goal of accelerating the production of "robo-taxis" and competing with companies like Uber and Didi. The alliance aims to bring forward the development of autonomous car systems by several years, with a production-ready system expected by the beginning of the next decade. The partnership will focus on developing software and algorithms for autonomous driving, with the ultimate goal of offering smartphone-based ride-hailing services.

site_title: Toshiba to seek loan support from creditor banks on Tuesday: sources
summary: Toshiba Corp will meet creditor banks on Tuesday to request loan support, offering shares in its memory chip unit and other businesses as collateral. The request, made previously, has failed to gain creditor support. Smaller creditors are hesitant due to unequal distribution of shares, with bigger lenders receiving more valuable chip unit shares. The meeting aims to persuade creditors to accept the offer, which could help Toshiba avoid a loan default.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp will meet creditor banks on Tuesday to ask them to accept as collateral shares in its soon-to-be-split-off memory chip unit and other businesses and not call in their loans, sources with direct knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Citadel names new commodities head after Ken Griffin's stint
summary: Citadel LLC has appointed Sebastian Barrack as the new head of commodities, replacing Mark Stainton who moved to head the firm's global equities unit. Barrack, previously co-head of metals, mining, and agriculture at Macquarie Group, will join in July and be based in Chicago. This move comes as investor interest in commodities has shown signs of recovery, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index gaining about 10% in the past year. Barrack will oversee Citadel's commodities business, which invests in natural gas, power, crude, and refined products, as well as agriculture.

site_title: Seoul: Won slumps to near 2-week low, stocks edge down
summary: The South Korean won fell to a near two-week low, closing at 1,121.9 to the US dollar, down 0.6% from Monday. The decline was attributed to risk-off sentiment following a suicide bombing in Russia. South Korean shares also edged down, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing 0.3% lower at 2,161.10 points. Foreign investors sold 101.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, accelerating selling pressure.

site_title: EU steps up efforts to deal With 1t euro bad-debt pile
summary: European Union leaders are addressing the bloc's €1 trillion non-performing debt, known as NPLs, which can stifle lending to healthy parts of the economy. The Maltese government is calling for action to prevent financial instability and economic growth harm. A European strategy on NPLs is being coordinated by the European commissioner, Valdis Dombrovskis, with a focus on policy actions and possibly European-level measures. Insolvency frameworks and secondary markets for bad loans are being encouraged to address the issue, which is particularly prevalent in Greece, Cyprus, Portugal, and Italy.

site_title: Blumont's auditor makes disclaimer of opinion
summary: BLUMONT Group's auditor has made a disclaimer of opinion due to the company's current liabilities exceeding its current assets by about S$2.9 million. Despite this, the group stated it can raise sufficient funds for operational requirements for the next 12 months.

site_title: China, Asean make progress on framework deal on disputed sea, says Philippines
summary: China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) have made progress in talks on a code of conduct for the disputed South China Sea. The Philippine acting foreign minister stated that Asean and China are more than halfway through identifying the contents of the framework, with several elements agreed upon. The talks aim to address concerns regarding China's militarization of the Spratly Islands. A bilateral mechanism will be held in August to tackle issues, with US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping expected to discuss Chinese ambitions in the South China Sea during their meeting in Florida.

site_title: Airbus to fit more seats into super-jumbo with slimmer staircase
summary: Airbus has developed a slimmer staircase for its A380 super jumbo to increase seating capacity by 20 extra seats. The new design replaces the traditional double staircase, reducing the aircraft's operating costs and fuel efficiency. The move aims to boost sales of the world's largest airliner, which has struggled to compete with newer, more efficient models. Airbus' cabin marketing executive, Ingo Wuggetzer, confirmed the design change would generate sufficient space for the additional seats. The upgrade is part of Airbus' efforts to improve the A380's competitiveness in the market.

site_title: China's new economic zone to focus on technology, innovation
summary: China has approved a new economic zone in Hebei province, Xiongan New Area, which will focus on building high-tech and innovative businesses. The zone, modeled after Shenzhen, will take over non-capital functions from Beijing and draw large state-owned companies. It will be expanded from 100 sq km to 2,000 sq km, but it's unlikely to replicate the success of Shenzhen in the current economic environment. Instead, it will likely create another economic hub, with a focus on building a new Beijing. The zone's development will be phased in.

site_title: Diversity committee targets 30% of board seats for women by 2030
summary: The Diversity Action Committee (DAC) sets targets for women on Singapore-listed company boards, aiming to reach 20% by 2020, 25% by 2025, and 30% by 2030. To meet the 20% target by 2020, companies would need to replace 459 male directors with female appointments. DAC chairman Loh Boon Chye acknowledged the challenges but described the targets as "pragmatic and aspirational." Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin expressed support for the tiered approach, seeing it as a journey to benefit businesses and the economy.

site_title: Total ties up with Pavilion Energy for LNG bunkering
summary: Total, a French oil major, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Pavilion Energy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering cooperation. The agreement aims to develop a worldwide LNG bunkering network, with Pavilion Gas supplying LNG as a ship fuel to Total Marine Fuels Global Solutions. This move supports Singapore's position as a leading bunkering port and contributes to establishing a global LNG bunkering ecosystem. The partnership follows the award of the first two LNG bunkering licenses by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore in 2016.

site_title: KS Energy wins US$11.1m contract for jack-up rig
summary: KS Energy has secured a US$11.1 million contract for a jack-up drilling rig to be deployed in Vietnam, with work expected to start in April 2017. The contract was won by KS Drilling Operating Company, a subsidiary of KS Energy.

site_title: Credit Suisse probe puts Swiss officials on back foot again
summary: Swiss authorities are dealing with a new probe into Credit Suisse Group AG, with raids in London, Paris, and Amsterdam targeting suspected tax evasion. The probes, which also involve Dutch and French authorities, raise questions about Credit Suisse's past business practices and its efforts to settle tax-evasion disputes with the US Department of Justice. Swiss officials are under scrutiny, with the attorney general saying he was "astonished" it hadn't been informed in advance of the raids, and the bank's CEO stating it has a strict zero-tolerance policy on tax evasion.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as RBA stands pat, financials weak
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index finishing 0.3% lower at 5,856.60. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates at a record low of 1.5%, despite concerns about the hot property market. Financials accounted for nearly two-thirds of the losses, while material stocks rose 0.6% due to gold price gains. Geopolitical tensions and a looming US-China meeting also contributed to investor risk aversion.

site_title: Asos shares drop on concern discounting may erode profitability
summary: Asos Plc shares fell 6.4% after the UK online fashion retailer reported a decline in profitability due to discounting and a weak pound. The retail gross margin contracted to 47% in the first half, with price cuts overseas being the main reason. Despite raising its full-year sales forecast, the company's shares were weighed down by concerns over how this may impact profitability. Asos expects to report a pretax profit broadly in line with consensus estimates, but its UK customers' disposable incomes are likely to come under threat.

site_title: IMDA bags S$1.14b from sale of spectrum to telcos
summary: The Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) sold 175 MHz of spectrum to four telcos in Singapore, raising S$1.14 billion. The spectrum, including 900MHz, 700MHz, and 2.5GHz bands, will be used for high-speed mobile broadband services. Industry analysts say the telcos were "aggressive" in their bids, with Singtel spending S$563.7 million for 75MHz, StarHub for S$349.6 million for 60MHz, M1 for S$208 million for 30MHz, and TPG Telecom for S$23.8 million for 10MHz. Spectrum rights will commence on July 1, 2017.

site_title: Bank Indonesia's top woman fights CPI with more than rates
summary: Bank Indonesia's Deputy Governor Rosmaya Hadi has introduced a bottom-up approach to controlling inflation, enlisting 2,000 religious leaders to spread a message of moderation. Hadi plans to utilize this approach in her new role, focusing on regional expertise and women's participation in the economy. Her promotion aims to address the country's inflation challenges, which have been hindered by ineffective policy implementation. Hadi's focus on regional expertise and women's empowerment seeks to address the country's economic gender gap, estimated to cost over 16% of GDP last year.

site_title: WhatsApp mulls foray into digital payments with India launch
summary: WhatsApp is reportedly planning to launch person-to-person payments in India, its largest market, within the next six months. The move would replicate similar efforts by messaging apps like WeChat in China. WhatsApp is hiring a digital transactions lead in India, indicating a foray into digital payments. The Indian government's "Digital India" program aims to boost internet-based services, and WhatsApp plans to work with companies sharing this vision. This move follows a surge in digital transactions in India after the government's ban on high-value bank notes in November.

site_title: ECB said to see Vicenza, Veneto as solvent, needing 6.4b euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) estimates that Banca Popolare di Vicenza SpA and Veneto Banca SpA need approximately 6.4 billion euros to bolster their balance sheets, considering the two Italian lenders to be solvent. This finding is crucial as it allows them to qualify for a recapitalisation that won't impose losses on senior bondholders. The ECB has informed the Italian Treasury of its findings, and a meeting was held in Brussels to review the request for a precautionary recapitalisation, with constructive talks ongoing to find a solution within weeks.

site_title: Australia keeps rates on hold, sizzling housing market a worry
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), held interest rates steady at a record low of 1.5% for an eighth consecutive month, citing concerns over soft labor data and a sizzling housing market. The decision was in line with market expectations. The Australian dollar fell by a quarter of a US cent following the announcement, while the housing market remains a worry for policymakers.

site_title: Genting invests US$2m in Singapore-based molecular diagnostics startup
summary: Genting invested US$2 million in Singapore-based molecular diagnostics startup Nova Satra Dx. The funding will be used for regulatory approvals and commercialization of its lead test, a non-invasive blood-based diagnostic test for breast cancer. Two directors nominated by Genting joined Nova Satra's board, and a Genting subsidiary acquired exclusive rights to distribute the test in Malaysia. The test uses a University of Oxford-developed epigenetic platform technology, and Nova Satra plans to develop a pipeline of molecular diagnostic tests for various cancer indications.

site_title: Overall payment performance improves in Q1, but construction sector lags
summary: Singapore's commercial credit bureau reports an improvement in overall payment performance in Q1 2017, with slow payments decreasing by 3.77 percentage points to 42.81% and prompt payments increasing by 4.33 percentage points to 45.44%. However, the construction sector remains the worst performer, with payment delays reaching a record high of 55.22%. Despite this, domestic-oriented sectors such as manufacturing and retail have shown slight improvements in payment performance over the past two quarters.

site_title: New Zealand hit by ex-Cyclone Debbie, heavy rains close highways
summary: New Zealand has been hit by the tail-end of Cyclone Debbie, causing heavy rains and a major landslip. The storm has closed highways and prompted severe weather warnings, with some regions expected to receive three months' worth of rain in 48 hours. The Met Office has advised residents to watch for rapidly rising rivers, flooding, and landslides. This comes as the country is still recovering from a devastating earthquake in November.

site_title: Trump aides, lawmakers hold talks to revive healthcare bill
summary: Top White House officials met with moderate and conservative Republicans to revive a plan to repeal and replace Obamacare. Vice President Mike Pence met with the Tuesday Group and the Freedom Caucus to discuss a revised bill. The White House aims to pass the bill by the end of the week, with US Representative Chris Collins stating it could move quickly. The bill's failure 10 days ago was a setback for President Trump and fellow Republicans, who had pledged to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

images.alt_text: Top White House officials met with moderate and conservative Republicans in the US House of Representatives on Monday in an effort to revive a plan to repeal and replace Obamacare.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars dented by RBA caution, dovish comments
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a three-week low against the US dollar after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates on hold and expressed caution on the job market. The currency dropped to US$0.7575, its lowest level this year against the yen. The RBA's dovish comments and cautious view on the economy led to a bout of risk aversion, causing the safe-haven currency to benefit. The move was seen as a response to concerns about the global economy and potential US tariffs.

site_title: US retail mall vacancies flat in first quarter: Reis
