summary: US retail mall vacancies remained flat at 9.9% in the first quarter of 2017, according to Reis Inc. New construction fell to a six-year low, with 796,000 square feet completed. Asking rent and effective rent rose 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. Net absorption more than halved to 1.25 million square feet. The national vacancy rate for neighborhood and community shopping centers remained unchanged. The flat vacancy rate suggests a cautious but not overly pessimistic outlook for the retail industry, according to Reis senior economist Barbara Denham.

images.alt_text: US retail mall vacancies were flat at 9.9 per cent in the first quarter of 2017, compared with the fourth quarter of 2016, as new construction fell to its lowest in six years, real estate research firm Reis Inc said in a report.

site_title: China, Hong Kong, Taiwan: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan are closed on Tuesday for a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore's stock market is experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, US stocks have reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging closer to new highs. Airalo, an eSIM platform, has raised $220 million in funding, valuing it over $1 billion. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) also rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite mixed Fed views and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: IMF releases US$1b loan for cash-strapped Ukraine
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has agreed to release the next $1 billion loan payment to Ukraine, which had been delayed due to a blockade in the separatist east of the country. This move is seen as a sign of ongoing reforms in Ukraine. The loan payment is part of a $17.5 billion rescue program agreed in 2015, which has been held up multiple times due to delays in implementing reforms. President Petro Poroshenko views this as a positive development for Ukraine's economic recovery.

site_title: Nikkei drops to 10-week lows; automakers tumble on weaker than expected US sales
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell to 10-week lows, dropping 0.9% to 18,810.25 points, amid weaker-than-expected US sales and a rise in the safe-haven yen. Automakers and financial stocks, particularly those seeking returns from higher-yielding US bonds, also declined. The US dollar extended overnight losses, down 0.4% at 110.51 yen, ahead of a meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips on risk-off sentiment, stocks flat
summary: South Korea's won slipped 0.2% against the US dollar as investors took a risk-off stance ahead of the US-China summit. Hyundai Motor and Kia Motor shares dropped 2.6% and 1% respectively due to reduced vehicle production in China amid diplomatic tensions. The meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping could impact South Korean markets, with any mention of tangible action against North Korea's missiles potentially weakening the won. South Korean shares were flat, with foreign investors set to be net sellers of local stocks.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten bets on post-app future with new gaming service
summary: Rakuten Inc has launched Rakuten Games, a browser-based gaming service that doesn't require app installation. The platform features 15 games, including Pacman and Space Invaders, and is powered by HTML5 technology. Rakuten aims to tap its 114 million shopper database and integrate with its messaging app Viber to encourage users to try the service. The move is seen as a response to the dominant mobile gaming-app market, with Rakuten seeking a slice of the $62 billion market.

site_title: BMW's first win over Mercedes in 2017 narrows US luxury race
summary: BMW topped Mercedes in the US luxury auto market for the first time in 2017, outselling its rival by about 1,900 units in March. BMW's deliveries of the X3 and X5 SUVs rose 43% and 35% respectively, contributing to its total sales of 31,015 vehicles. This victory narrowed the gap between BMW and Mercedes, bringing the German automaker within 7,500 vehicle sales of its competitor through the first three months of the year.

site_title: Tillerson to make first UN visit for meeting on North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will chair a UN Security Council meeting on North Korea on April 28, marking his first UN visit. The meeting follows a US-China summit this week and comes amid US concerns that China is not taking sufficient action to rein in North Korea's nuclear and ballistic programs. The US administration is seeking China's pressure on Pyongyang to change course, with Secretary of State Nikki Haley stating that the only one North Korea will respond to is China. The meeting is seen as an opportunity for the US to showcase its foreign policy priorities.

site_title: A slice of luxury: Hong Kong's high-end fruit fad
summary: In Hong Kong, a high-end fruit fad is gaining popularity, with luxury supermarkets and outdoor stalls offering expensive premium produce. Malaysian durians and Tasmanian cherries are selling for HK$600 and HK$550, respectively. This trend is not only attracting health-conscious consumers but also causing financial strain for shoppers. The premium fruit market is on the rise, with luxury supermarkets showcasing exotic fruits at high prices, indicating a shift in consumer spending habits.

site_title: Asia: Markets down, Tokyo hit by strong yen after Russia blast
summary: Tokyo's markets fell 0.4% on Tuesday due to a stronger yen amid concerns over a suspected terror attack in Saint Petersburg that killed 11 people and geopolitical tensions. The blast also affected US and European equities, despite a positive start to the week in Asia. Investors are on edge about the upcoming summit between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump, with Trump predicting a "very difficult" meeting.

site_title: Singapore shares opens lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 1.74 points to 3,185.77. Volume reached 31.3 million shares worth S$42.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 33. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte fires interior minister over corruption allegations
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has fired Interior Minister Ismael Sueno over "loss of trust and confidence" amid corruption allegations. This move marks the most senior government executive to be removed for corruption issues. Sueno was involved in organizing a pro-Duterte rally and had faced rumors about unexplained property acquisitions. The dismissal serves as a warning to other presidential appointees, following the removal of dozens of bureaucrats and senior officials under Duterte's administration.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.620 point to 1745.030. Gainers outnumbered losers 171 to 80, with a total volume of 146.23 million lots worth RM58.30 million.

site_title: Scientists find common antibiotic could prevent or treat PTSD
summary: Scientists in the UK and Switzerland have discovered that the antibiotic doxycycline can prevent or treat post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) by blocking proteins that form negative thoughts and fears in the brain. In a trial involving 76 healthy volunteers, those taking doxycycline had a 60% lower fear response than those receiving a placebo. The antibiotic works by blocking matrix enzymes that are necessary for memory formation, which may be disrupted in individuals with PTSD. This finding suggests a potential new treatment for the condition.

site_title: Harrison Ford avoids action over near-miss plane landing
summary: Hollywood star Harrison Ford avoided punishment for a near-miss incident at a California airport, where he landed his private plane on a taxiway instead of the runway, passing over a Boeing 737 with 110 passengers. Ford, a seasoned pilot, was captured on air traffic control recordings calling himself a "schmuck" and saying he was distracted by two jets. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) closed its investigation, citing Ford's long history of compliance and cooperative attitude. Ford's pilot's certificate remains intact, and he retains his license without restriction.

images.alt_text: Hollywood star Harrison Ford is to avoid punishment over a near-miss at a California airport as he was piloting his private plane, his lawyer told AFP on Monday.

site_title: US car demand collapses in threat to Trump's auto plant push
summary: US auto sales plummeted 1.5% through March, with sedan sales declining 37-36% compared to last year, as consumers shift to SUVs and crossovers. The industry's slowdown is attributed to a glut of new and used vehicles, slumping used-car values, and reduced subprime lending. Despite cheap gasoline and efficient engines, incentives are needed to keep sales moving, with popular SUVs requiring increasingly higher discounts. This slowdown threatens President Trump's push for new auto plant investments and hiring, with analysts predicting a 15-20% decline in sales this year.

site_title: Australian shares edge lower ahead of RBA decision; NZ slightly up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.13% on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index shedding 7.48 points to 5,865.20, as investors awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates. The central bank is expected to keep rates at a record low of 1.5%. Financials declined 0.2%, with consumer stocks also falling, while material stocks rose 0.9% led by gold miners and coal miners. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%.

site_title: S i2i to acquire e-commerce platform from Softbank-led fund
summary: S i2i's wholly-owned subsidiary Affinity Capital has entered into an asset transfer agreement with SB ISAT Fund to acquire an e-commerce platform. Affinity will allot 22.5 million new shares to SB ISAT Fund at $0.28 each, diluting S i2i's equity interest from 100% to 50.1%. The acquisition is in line with S i2i's plans to expand into e-commerce, and the company will convene an EGM to seek shareholder approval.

site_title: Twitter drops egg icon in battle with internet 'trolls'
summary: Twitter has removed its iconic egg icon from new user profiles, citing its use by "trolls" to launch anonymous online attacks. The egg icon, which was a playful reference to how eggs hatch into birds, was a standard feature for new Twitter users for seven years. Twitter attributed the removal to the icon's use by trolls, stating it was "no longer a useful or positive representation of Twitter." The change aims to reduce the use of anonymous accounts on the platform.

site_title: 11 dead in Russian metro 'terror attack'
summary: An explosion at a Saint Petersburg metro station in Russia killed 11 people and injured dozens, with authorities describing it as a "terror attack." The blast occurred in a train carriage and a second explosive device was found at a nearby station, which was defused. The Kremlin and international leaders, including US President Donald Trump and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, condemned the attack. Russia's Investigative Committee is probing the incident, with no immediate claim of responsibility from the Islamic State group.

site_title: mm2 Asia announces launch of unit's IPO shares on Catalist
summary: mm2 Asia's unit UnUsUaL launches an initial public offering (IPO) on Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at a placement price of S$0.20 per share. The company is placing 97 million shares, valued at approximately S$19.4 million, and retaining a 41.91% indirect shareholding interest. The IPO follows the lodgement of a preliminary offer document with SGX, and the shares are available to retail and institutional investors in Singapore.

site_title: Australia trade surplus swells in Feb, floods a temporary setback
summary: Australia's trade surplus widened in February, reaching A$3.57 billion, more than double the previous month's forecast. The surplus was driven by a 5.3% drop in imports and a 1.5% increase in exports, led by gold, iron ore, and coal. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at 1.5% due to concerns about inflation. A trade surplus of A$5 billion by the end of the first quarter would push the current account into surplus for the first time since the mid-1970s.

site_title: Amazon brings its business marketplace to Britain
summary: Amazon has launched its business marketplace in Britain, offering products such as office supplies, power tools, and lab equipment to enterprises, universities, hospitals, and charities. The platform aims to tap into the UK's £120.44 billion online business sector. This marks Amazon's third international launch, following the US and Germany, and is expected to serve businesses of varying sizes. The platform will provide a one-stop-shop for business customers, offering convenient and cost-effective purchasing options.

site_title: Australia losing AAA rating would spark turn to bank debt, NAB says
summary: Australia's top credit score is under threat, with S&P Global Ratings warning of a downgrade due to the country's underlying cash deficit. If this happens, Australia's big four banks may find new demand for their debt, as investors seek higher-yielding paper. The banks, including National Australia Bank, could face a 15-to-20 basis points hike in funding costs. However, experts believe this may not be a major issue, as investors have taken the UK's credit downgrade in stride after the Brexit vote, and Australia's economy is expected to continue growing.

images.alt_text: Australia's biggest banks would find new demand for their debt if the country loses its top credit score.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascott, S i2i, mm2 Asia
summary: The Ascott Limited plans to expand in South America with franchise agreements for two serviced residences in Sao Paulo, Brazil. S i2i's wholly owned subsidiary Affinity Capital has entered an asset transfer agreement for an e-commerce platform. Stocks to watch include Ascott, S i2i, and mm2 Asia, which may be in focus on Tuesday.

site_title: New York office rents hit new highs on robust demand: Colliers
summary: New York office rents reached a record high in the first quarter, averaging US$73.92 per square foot, driven by historically low unemployment and above-average leasing activity. This represents a 10.4% increase from the previous quarter and a 20.8% increase from the 2008 record. The downtown and Midtown South sectors saw significant rent increases, with downtown rents reaching new highs. The robust demand is attributed to the strong jobs market.

site_title: US dollar wobbles vs yen as risk aversion permeates, RBA awaited
summary: The US dollar wobbled against the yen due to a risk-averse mood in the markets, with investor appetite for risk dulled by factors such as the upcoming US-China meeting and a suspected bombing in Russia. The dollar fell 0.15% to 110.685 yen, its lowest in a week, while the euro remained steady at $1.0666. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to keep interest rates at a record low of 1.5% later, and the Australian dollar was flat at $0.7605.

site_title: South Korea March inflation jumps to near 5-year high on food, service costs
summary: South Korea's consumer price index rose 2.2% in March, the fastest pace in nearly five years, driven by increased food and service costs. Fresh food prices jumped 7.5% and insurance premiums rose 19.4%, while core inflation rose 1.4%. The inflation rate exceeds the central bank's target of 2% and dims expectations for interest rate cuts. Economists expect the Bank of Korea to maintain record-low interest rates, citing solid export growth and private consumption.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following Wall Street's decline after a deadly subway explosion in Russia. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.47%, and the Topix index dropped 0.46%. This move was likely influenced by global market sentiment and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Libyan production recovery weighs
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as Libyan oil production rebounded, weighing on benchmark Brent futures, which lost 41 cents to settle at $53.12 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude declined 36 cents to $50.24 per barrel. Libya's Sharara oil field, the country's largest, resumed production after a week-long disruption, adding volatility to oil prices. Despite this, data from Asia suggested solid energy demand, with manufacturing data showing factories expanded for a ninth straight month in China.

site_title: Melania Trump's new portrait divides public opinion
summary: The White House released the official portrait of Melania Trump, sparking public opinion. The photograph, taken by Regine Mahaux, shows the former model standing with arms crossed, wearing a black jacket and a large diamond ring. The image has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising her flawless visage, while others have criticized the perceived stiffness and lack of warmth in the portrait. The portrait's release comes amidst Melania Trump's efforts to establish her own identity and separate herself from her husband's presidency.

site_title: United hit by bout of seatless in Seattle
summary: United Airlines faces a setback in its bid to win back business customers due to production snags affecting deliveries of Boeing's 777-300ER aircraft outfitted with new luxury seats by French seatmaker Zodiac Aerospace. Delays of a month or two could hurt the airline's efforts to deploy the brand-new 777s on high-profile routes to Asia during the peak summer travel season, potentially leading to consequential damages. United and Boeing are working to expedite shipments, but Zodiac has struggled with production issues, including delays at its manufacturing hubs.

site_title: S&P cuts South Africa's credit rating to 'junk'
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded South Africa's credit rating to "junk" status, citing "heightened political and institutional uncertainties" following President Jacob Zuma's cabinet shuffle. The downgrade reflects concerns over fiscal and growth outcomes, and the rand fell 2% against the US dollar. Moody's also placed South Africa's rating on review for a downgrade, prompted by the leadership change. Opposition parties, including the Democratic Alliance, have vowed to press ahead with a no-confidence vote against Zuma, who has faced widespread criticism for the shake-up.

site_title: US newspapers cut more than half their jobs since 2001
summary: US newspapers have cut more than half their jobs since 2001, with 412,000 jobs in January 2001 compared to 174,000 in September 2016. The decline is offset by a 150% increase in internet publishing jobs from 67,000 in 2007 to 206,000 last year. The number of newspaper industry businesses fell 18% from 9,310 in 2001 to 7,623 last year, while internet publishing and web search portals jumped 150% from 2007 to 13,924.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip from 16-month highs as oil stocks, banks drop
summary: European shares dropped 0.5% on Monday, retreating from a 16-month high, as oil stocks and banking sector losses added pressure. The decline was partly due to a reversal in oil stocks and losses in the banking sector, which had previously risen as investors bet on a reflation trade. Banking stocks, including Banco Popular, fell 1.4%, while dealmaking helped shares in WS Atkins rise 26.6% after it confirmed a buyout offer.

site_title: Ascott expands to South America with two franchise properties in Brazil
summary: The Ascott Limited, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has expanded to South America with two franchise properties in Brazil. Vitacon will operate the 92-unit Citadines VN Jardins Sao Paulo and 122-unit Citadines VN Faria Lima Sao Paulo, scheduled to open in the last quarter of 2017 and 2020 respectively. Ascott aims to establish a portfolio of at least 5,000 Citadines branded units in Sao Paulo and expand to other major cities in Brazil, with a target of 10,000 units in South America over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Lee Chee Koon, Ascott's chief executive officer, said: "We see strong potential to scale up Ascott's presence in Brazil given its status as the powerhouse of South America, accounting for close to half of the region's foreign direct investments. This signifies great opportunities for serviced residences as the region continues to attract corporations and business travellers.

site_title: IMF chief warns slowing productivity risks living standards drop
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Christine Lagarde warned that living standards worldwide could drop unless governments invest in research and education to boost weak productivity growth. A recent IMF study found the 2008-2009 financial crisis slowed productivity more than thought, stifling global demand and investment. Lagarde stated that another decade of weak productivity growth would undermine global living standards and jeopardize financial and social stability. She advocated for governments to invest in education, retraining programs, and research incentives to stimulate innovation and boost productivity.

site_title: Automating HR functions may reduce risk for Singapore SMEs
summary: Singapore SMEs can reduce risk by automating HR functions, including payroll and employee benefits management. This can ensure compliance with government regulations, reduce calculation errors in tasks such as CPF contributions and overtime pay, and preserve institutional knowledge by storing company information securely in the cloud. Automating these processes can prevent errors, improve employee confidence and morale, and improve regulatory compliance, ultimately reducing the risk of penalties and reputational damage.

site_title: At least 10 dead, 50 injured in Russian train blast
summary: At least 10 people were killed and 50 injured in a train blast in the St Petersburg metro system on Monday. The explosion, caused by a bomb filled with shrapnel, occurred when the train was between two stations. Russian authorities are investigating possible terrorism, with surveillance cameras potentially capturing images of a suspect. The blast was followed by another explosive device found at another metro station, which was made safe. President Vladimir Putin is considering all possible causes, including terrorism, and has urged citizens to be alert and cautious.

site_title: Dyson is the Apple of appliances
summary: Dyson, a UK-based appliance manufacturer, has successfully created a profitable business model by focusing on high-end consumer electronics, exemplified by its latest robot cleaner. After 20 years of development, the company has cornered the market in premium vacuum cleaners, lights, and hair dryers, rivaling Apple's success in the premium gadget segment. Dyson's revenue rose 45% to £2.5 billion last year, with pretax profits increasing 41% to £631 million, driven by its growth in China and other emerging markets.

site_title: Overhaul of money funds spurs shake-up of dollar financing
summary: US regulators' overhaul of the money-fund industry has led to a $1 trillion exodus from prime funds, causing a ripple effect across financial markets. The overhaul, aimed at preventing a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis, has resulted in a shift towards safer US debt, with commercial-paper rates rising to their highest levels since the crisis. This has led to a bottleneck in funding for financial institutions and non-US banks, which have lost $555 billion in US dollar funding since 2015. The changes have also created potential risks, such as the concentration of money in government funds, which could be triggered by events like a US debt ceiling dispute.

images.alt_text: Regulators' effort to stamp out risk in the United States' US$2.6 trillion money-fund industry is creating unintended ripple effects across financial markets, with far-reaching consequences for companies and investors.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as March auto sales disappoint
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as auto giants Ford and General Motors retreated amid uncertainty over Washington's policy agenda. US auto sales for March were disappointing, leading to a shakeout among auto stocks, with Tesla surging 7.4% after reporting better-than-expected first quarter sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Analysts attributed the decline to questions about President Trump's tax cuts and other policies, citing a shift from post-election hope to acceptance of political reality.

site_title: Natural Cool's auditor adds 'emphasis of matter' relating to probe at paint units
summary: Auditor KPMG has added an emphasis of matter to Natural Cool's financial statements for 2016, related to a probe into alleged irregular transactions at the paint division. The investigation, which is still ongoing, has not been adjusted for any findings. The firm's financial statements were given an unqualified opinion, as the paint business' contributions were deemed not material. Natural Cool had previously flagged potential irregularities at its paint segment, citing employee-run competing businesses using company assets. The firm's shares slid 0.1 Singapore cent to end at 12.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's target price is set at S$0.76, but closed at S$0.69 on April 3, 2017. The article does not provide further information about the trust's performance.

site_title: US teen pleads guilty to 2015 Islamic State plot to kill pope
summary: A New Jersey teen, Santos Colon, 17, pleaded guilty to an allegedly Islamic State-inspired plot to kill Pope Francis in 2015. Colon sought to recruit a sniper and set off explosives during a mass in Philadelphia, but unwittingly recruited an undercover FBI agent. He pleaded guilty to one count of attempting to provide material support to terror, carrying a maximum 15-year prison sentence. Colon had used the name Ahmad Shakoor and was arrested 12 days before the planned event.

site_title: Japan business sentiment rises, buoyed by exports
summary: Japan's business sentiment rose to its highest level since December 2015, driven by strong exports, according to the Bank of Japan's tankan survey. However, the improvement was slower than expected and may soon deteriorate due to uncertainty over US and European economies. Despite this, the survey showed that firms remain optimistic about the outlook.

site_title: FCL, TCC Assets plan 120b-baht Bangkok mixed-use project
summary: Frasers Centrepoint (FCL) and TCC Assets have teamed up to build the One Bangkok mixed-use project in central Bangkok, Thailand's largest private sector development initiative. The estimated 120 billion baht (S$4.9 billion) project will feature five office towers, five hotels, three ultra-luxury residential towers, and retail outlets, with the first stage expected to open in 2021. The joint venture, One Bangkok Holdings, will be led by FCL with a 19.9% stake and TCC Assets with 80.1%.

site_title: Private access
summary: Investing in private markets is gaining traction in Asia among high net worth individuals (HNWIs) seeking yield and portfolio diversification. Private equity investments offer higher absolute returns and improved diversification, outperforming public indices by 4.2-7.6% annually over the past decade. Top-performing managers can generate top-quartile investment returns, and private equity investing has benefits such as less dependence on general stock market and interest rate trends. HNWIs are increasingly targeting private equity firms, with 77% of firms soliciting capital from them, and family offices investing heavily in alternative investments, including private equity.

site_title: Showing the way
summary: Philanthropist Robert Kee, founder of Operation Hope Foundation, believes corruption is prevalent in charities and NGOs in developing countries. He argues that donors must prevent dishonesty rather than relying on honesty, citing the need for accountability and feedback. Kee's charity has implemented measures such as detailed policies, procedures, and monitoring of expenditures to ensure transparency and efficiency. He advocates for donors to verify the effectiveness of their donations, such as through photos and GPS coordinates, and to focus on outcomes rather than just public relations.

site_title: It may be too soon for Trump to meet Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing significant challenges in meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, with many doubting his preparedness for the encounter. Trump has no experience in government, diplomacy, or the military, and lacks a comprehensive Asia policy. His foreign policy team is still largely unformed, and key figures like Elliott Abrams have been rejected due to criticism of Trump. The meeting's difficulties are likely to be greater than Trump anticipates, raising concerns about the US-China relationship and Trump's ability to navigate complex global issues.

site_title: Good vibes
summary: Global growth is expected to continue, driven by economic improvement in the US and emerging markets such as China. The eurozone is also showing green shoots, despite protectionist voices. Asia is likely to benefit from brighter prospects, with China leading the way. However, growth in South Korea and Taiwan may be clouded by political uncertainty. In India, demonetization is having a positive effect, and the economy is showing resilience. Interest rates in Asia are expected to rise, but spreads remain resilient. Stock markets are also showing signs of recovery, with earnings resuming and forward valuations in the early teens still compelling.

site_title: Staying power
summary: Investing in hotel and resort developments requires careful consideration of various factors, including location, segment, and service concept. A key aspect often overlooked by first-time hoteliers is selecting the right business management model. Professional management and distribution are crucial, but seasoned investors emphasize the need to monitor and challenge managers to enhance guest experience and drive asset performance. A passive real estate investment is rare in the hotel industry, which demands active day-to-day attention, making a well-chosen business model essential for success.

site_title: Shipping container price spike pointing to recovery in global seaborne trade
summary: Shipping container prices have surged to their highest level since October 2015, indicating a recovery in global seaborne trade. The Harpex Shipping Index has risen 40% to 439 points, driven by high demand and limited availability of containers. Lead times to order containers have increased, with some cases reaching over a month. This trend suggests a growth in seaborne trade, which should continue this year.

site_title: London putting up giant coffee cup-shaped bins to recycle 5 million small ones
summary: London is installing giant yellow coffee cup-shaped bins to collect and recycle 5 million discarded cups, with a goal to persuade consumers to recycle 50-300 million tonnes of waste annually. The initiative, led by British charity Hubbub, aims to address the lack of consistent recycling methods for coffee cups, with less than 1% of cups recycled due to a thin plastic coating. The bins will be installed in city offices, coffee retailers, and train stations, with the collected cups to be recycled into plastic or recovered fibre materials.

site_title: Aussie regulators crack down as home prices, building permits jump
summary: Australian regulators have introduced measures to cool the country's hot property market, with home prices hitting new records and building permits jumping. The Reserve Bank of Australia is under pressure to adjust interest rates, but cannot hike rates without fuelling the market further or cut rates without depressing the economy. Regulators have also tightened rules on interest-only loans, while banks have raised mortgage rates on these loans. Despite this, some economists expect home prices to temper as supply catches up with demand, and retail sales have unexpectedly fallen, suggesting debt-laden households are tightening their purse strings.

site_title: O&M stocks may decouple from oil prices: analysts
summary: Analysts predict a rebound in floating production contract awards, driven by cost reductions rather than oil prices. This could lead to offshore and marine (O&M) stock valuations decoupling from oil prices. Despite a high correlation between marine and offshore engineering share prices and oil prices, cost has become the key driver for floating production awards. Analysts project six to 10 FPSO orders for 2017, with costs containing and oil prices stabilizing within the $50-90 band.

site_title: From a father to his sons
summary: Wealth (April 2017) article: G S Sareen, founder of Omni United, credits his late father, Dr Surender Singh Sareen, as a role model in life. Despite his father's severe injuries in a 1971 road accident, he refused to remarry, prioritizing his commitment to his wife. This decision had a lasting impact on Sareen's life, influencing his values in marriage and giving.

site_title: Look before jumping into the mining sector
summary: Mining stocks on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have seen significant gains in the past half year, with Alliance Mineral Assets and BlackGold Natural Resources experiencing 318% and 257% returns respectively. The rally is attributed to a global economic recovery and positive announcements from mining companies. However, investors should be aware of sector risks, including commodity price volatility, regulatory risks, and capital cost risks. Experts predict the rally may continue for another 6-12 months, but caution is advised when investing in the mining sector.

site_title: Go-slow India may dilute Asia trade pact championed by China
summary: India's reluctance to sign the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade deal has raised concerns it may lead to the deal being diluted or delayed. The main issue is India's fear of being flooded by Chinese imports and its insistence on global mobility for its IT services workers. India has proposed a formula for deeper tariff cuts on goods to nations other than China, but other countries have opposed it. Without India's participation, the RCEP is likely to be concluded faster, but analysts predict it will be weaker than expected.

site_title: Fear factor
summary: Investors should reassess their market positioning based on current market action rather than relying on fear-driven decisions. Despite ongoing negative commentary, the global equity market continues to make new highs, with Emerging Markets and the Hong Kong/China stock markets leading the rally. A correction is inevitable, but one that occurs during economic growth tends to be short and shallow, presenting a buying opportunity. Investors should focus on aligning their portfolios with market action, rather than basing decisions on forecasts or opinions about the future.

site_title: SGInnovate focuses on 5 areas to help startups, entrepreneurs
summary: SGInnovate, a government-owned company, has finalized its focus areas to help startups and entrepreneurs. The company will concentrate on five key areas: deep technology in artificial intelligence, robotics, and blockchain, as well as talent and ideas. CEO Steve Leonard believes that if ideas and technology are of high quality, they can thrive globally, despite the company's limited size. SGInnovate will only assist those who are committed to making their businesses work, and will partner with organizations like Entrepreneur First and SMART to refer promising entrepreneurs.

site_title: World Bank mulling new issuance on SGX for retail investors
summary: The World Bank is exploring a new issuance of bonds for retail investors, to be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), as part of a partnership to raise awareness about sustainable development bonds. The move aims to bring high-quality investment products to retail investors in Singapore, with the first forum scheduled for April 4. The partnership is seen as an important development for Singapore as a key financial hub, and SGX shares rose 7 cents to close at S$7.77 on Monday. The World Bank's sustainable development bonds cater to discerning investors seeking social and environmental impact.

site_title: Tracking websites making it easier to locate yachts and jets of the mega-rich
summary: Wealthy individuals, including Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev and US President Donald Trump, have been tracked by private jet and yacht enthusiasts. Rybolovlev's plane and yacht were spotted in locations where Trump or his family were also present, raising questions about potential connections. However, Rybolovlev attributes these coincidences to his frequent travels. The ease of tracking these luxury assets, made possible by new technology and specialized websites, has sparked concerns about privacy and security, with some owners seeking to remove information about their boats or jets from public view.

site_title: Ezra chairman's villa in Sentosa Cove being sold
summary: Ezra Holdings' founder and chairman Lee Kian Soo's waterway-facing bungalow in Sentosa Cove, valued at S$26m when listed last year, is being sold through a private treaty deal. The sale price has declined steadily since its initial listing. An agent from Edmund & Tie Co Property Network was involved in the transaction, but declined to comment. The sale marks a significant move for Lee, who has held the property for an extended period.

site_title: A lasting legacy
summary: HSBC's global head of family governance and family enterprise succession, Bernard Rennell, emphasizes the importance of strategic thinking in inter-generational wealth transfer for wealthy families. He advises that families must define their success and think strategically about ownership, valuing not just business succession but also the contributions of children. Rennell suggests three options: splitting assets, selling the business, or planning for continuity, with the latter being the most preferred. He also stresses the need for family governance to provide a structure and process for decision-making, enabling families to adapt to changing circumstances and ensure a lasting legacy.

images.alt_text: 'Family governance need not be too different from corporate governance, but it is on the ownership level, not the business level. The two must be separate.'

site_title: Euro drops to 3-week low on mixed economic data
summary: The euro plummeted to a three-week low against the dollar, falling to US$1.0650, due to mixed economic data and concerns about political risk in Europe. Factory activity in the eurozone increased but struggled to meet demand, and France is set to vote in a presidential election, which investors fear could result in a surprise victory for the far-right Marine Le Pen. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 100.64, and markets are awaiting the US non-farm payrolls report for clues on interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Core driving force
summary: Omni United's founder G S Sareen emphasizes the importance of persistence and non-negotiable values in achieving business success. He believes that work, personal life, and philanthropy must be balanced equally, as the purpose of working hard is to have a fruitful life. Sareen's approach to business is reflected in Omni United's "Ikea" of tyres, a low-cost and accessible product that has contributed to the company's success. His personal values and business philosophy are key to his entrepreneurial achievements.

images.alt_text: 'If you want to make anything a success you have to stick with it... Failure is when you quit.'

site_title: Simmering Trump-Xi tensions shape landmark summit
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping for their first face-to-face session in Florida, with the meeting having significant stakes in play for the bilateral relationship. Trump's anti-China rhetoric has raised concerns, but he may be looking for a grand bargain to secure concessions from Beijing, particularly on trade and security issues, including the South China Sea and North Korea. The meeting's outcome is uncertain, but Trump needs to appear to secure concessions to underpin a renewed basis for bilateral relations.

site_title: US backs out of Latin American development fund in sign of policy shift
summary: The US has decided not to renew its contribution to an Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) fund supporting pilot development projects, marking a policy shift since Donald Trump's presidency. This decision was made by IDB President Luis Alberto Moreno, who linked it to the US's changing priorities. The move signals a shift in the US's historical support for multilateral lending institutions, reflecting broader policy changes under the Trump administration.

site_title: Having a bubbly good time, naturally
summary: Soap Ministry, a Singapore-based company, educates the public on the benefits of natural handmade soaps through workshops. Founded by Diana Ong, the company is a pioneer in conducting workshops on natural soaps in Singapore and has obtained a lye licence to use the cold process method. Soap Ministry aims to promote the benefits of going au naturale, offering a unique approach to soap-making.

site_title: EWI makes firm debut, mulls over redevelopment of Guoco Group's UK assets (Amended)
summary: Eco World International Bhd (EWI) made its debut on Bursa Malaysia's main board, listing at a 9% premium to its retail price of RM1.20, raising RM2.6 billion. The funds will be used to reduce borrowings and finance future projects, including collaborations with GuocoLand Ltd and Eco World Development Group Bhd, which hold 27% stakes. EWI aims to explore new opportunities in the UK, Australia, and other mature markets, with exploratory talks ongoing with GuocoLand on redevelopment of Guoco Group's UK assets, including hotels.

site_title: Huishan Dairy's 4 remaining non-exec directors resign
summary: Huishan Dairy Holdings Co, a Chinese farm operator, has seen four non-executive directors resign, citing other commitments. The company's treasury head, Ge Kun, is missing, and a missing person's report has been filed. An 85% share plunge on March 24 raised concerns about corporate governance and finances. The company is reviewing its financial position and plans to provide an update in a week's time. Majority shareholder Champ Harvest Ltd sold part of its stake during the share drop, and the company has no audit committee members left.

site_title: Politics takes centre stage
summary: European politics will be a significant factor in 2017, with key elections including the French presidential election in April-May, French parliamentary elections in June, and German legislative elections in September. Despite economic growth, investors face political risks, including the potential impact of a Marine Le Pen victory on the European Union's credibility. European equities are expected to be volatile, with a focus on export-oriented companies and sectors such as IT and energy. Fixed income markets are also sensitive to European politics, with concerns about the potential impact of a Le Pen victory on the euro and European sovereign corporate bond markets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezra Holdings announced it will meet noteholders on April 17 to update investors after filing voluntary petitions for reorganisation under US Bankruptcy Code. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding won 13 shipbuilding contracts worth $318 million for 2018-2020 delivery. MM2 Asia appointed Chang Long Jong as its CEO, and Secura Group reported KIP Industrial Holdings sold one million shares, reducing its holdings to under 5%.

site_title: S'pore design protection laws to be amended
summary: Singapore is set to amend its design protection laws to better support the country's design industry. The changes, proposed by the Ministry of Law, include broadening the scope of registrable designs, shifting ownership from commissioning party to designer, and making filing designs easier. The amendments will now protect virtual designs, colours as design features, and artisanal or handcrafted items. Designers will also have a 12-month grace period to apply for protection, and can register multiple designs under the same broad category in a single application.

site_title: Now and beyond
summary: Asian families are navigating the largest-ever inter-generational wealth transfer, valued in trillions of dollars. Experts say families must address challenges such as a lack of succession planning, cultural taboos, and tax complexities. Key principles include identifying core values, mapping out an inventory list of capital, and promoting a culture of allowing family members to pursue individual happiness. Successful transitions require design, not chance, and involve neutral external wealth managers, clarity on objectives, and flexibility to adapt to changing family circumstances. Developing a family charter or framework is crucial to ensure longevity and harmony.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser considering sale of French Foods unit
summary: Reckitt Benckiser is considering the sale of its French Foods unit, which includes brands like French's mustard and ketchup, to help pay for its $16.6 billion acquisition of Mead Johnson Nutrition Co. The food unit, which generated £118 million in adjusted operating profit last year, is considered "non-core" and may be sold for £2 billion. The sale would be a strategic move by the company to focus on its core businesses, such as Dettol cleaner and Enfamil baby formula.

site_title: Asia's economic outlook sunny with chance of rain
summary: Asia's economic outlook has improved significantly, driven by strong trade and output levels, as well as increased capital flows. The International Monetary Fund's Changyong Rhee described the Asia-Pacific region as "the strongest globally" and noted a pickup in momentum. However, recent events, such as the US tariff announcement on Vietnam and rising US tariffs on the Asian garment industry, pose challenges to the region's economic stability. Despite this, some experts, like Citigroup, are optimistic about the region's growth prospects, with a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Singapore's state of disruption
summary: Singapore aims to be a hub for disruption and innovation through its government-led initiatives, including the creation of a digital government and the development of a technologically conducive business environment. The country's Minister in charge of GovTech, Janil Puthucheary, has pledged to create a state that accelerates innovation and is not disrupted by external factors. However, critics argue that true disruption requires a culture that encourages entrepreneurship, invention, and diversity of thought, and that Singapore's education system needs to be reformed to foster this environment. The country's regulatory framework also needs to be relaxed to allow for the emergence of true unicorns of disruption.

site_title: HDB resale prices surprise with 0.6% slide in Q1
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore slid 0.6% in Q1 2017, surprising property consultants who had expected stabilization. The decline is attributed to traditionally quieter Q1 due to Chinese New Year holidays and February's shorter month. Consultants also point to the steady supply of new BTO flats and flat sellers opting to accept lower prices to quickly offload their unsold flats. While some believe the decline is a blip, others predict prices may weaken further, with some predicting a 1-2% year-on-year decline.

images.alt_text: Housing & Development Board (HDB) resale flat prices dipped 0.6 per cent in the first quarter of 2017 from the previous quarter

site_title: ComfortDelGro to offer new flat taxi fare for app bookings
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp, Singapore's largest taxi operator, will roll out a flat fare option on its app starting April 10, 2017. The option will be available alongside the traditional metered fare, allowing commuters to choose the best option. The flat fare takes into account distance and existing surcharges, with additional charges for enroute stops and destination changes. Travel delays from traffic jams will not result in higher fares. The move comes just days after Grab launched dynamic pricing for taxis and taxi-like services.

site_title: A fond farewell to Ringling Bros and the wonders of the circus
summary: Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey circus will shut down in May after its final tour. The circus, known as "The Greatest Show on Earth," held its final Washington, DC show on April 3, 2017, marking the end of a 146-year run. The circus's farewell tour was met with a packed show at the Verizon Center, featuring high-energy performances and a final appearance by the iconic circus. This marks the end of an era for the beloved circus, which will no longer be entertaining audiences.

site_title: Fiscal boost from tax amnesty puts Indonesia closer to S&P upgrade
summary: Indonesia's nine-month tax amnesty programme, which netted over $10 billion in revenue, may lead to a potential upgrade to investment grade from S&P Global Ratings, according to analysts. The programme, which ended on Friday, saw citizens declare 4,866 trillion rupiah of assets previously hidden from tax authorities. This success could be a step closer to Indonesia gaining investment grade, a move that could boost investor confidence and attract more foreign investment.

site_title: Mandatory board quota for women? CEOs' views mixed
summary: A poll of CEOs in Singapore found that nearly 30% oppose setting a mandatory 20% quota for women representation on corporate boards by 2020. However, 24% support mandating gender diversity, with 17% favoring a 20% target. CEOs expressed concerns about risks of cynicism and tokenism, and some advocate for a higher target. The poll was prompted by calls from the PAP Women's Wing and BoardAgender to increase female representation on boards.

site_title: US Court dismisses claims against Keppel and SembMarine (Amended)
summary: A US District Court has dismissed claims against Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine related to a Sete Brasil-linked lawsuit. The court's decision may mitigate litigation risks, but analysts say it may take years for the two groups to offload the rigs commissioned by the Brazilian owner. Excess capacity in the market and low oil prices make it challenging for Keppel Corp and SembMarine to secure buyers for the rigs, with some analysts estimating it could take until 2020 for the market to recover.

site_title: ECB does not think aggressive stimulus is a threat to financial markets
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) director Benoit Coeure stated that the bank's aggressive stimulus policy is not harming financial markets, despite negative yields on some bonds and scarcity signs. Coeure attributed the increase in demand for short-term German government bonds to political risk and stricter financial rules. The ECB will continue to buy government bonds according to each country's contribution to the bank's capital, with a reduction in purchases to 60 billion euros expected to provide some relief. The demand for short-term bonds is likely to remain high.

images.alt_text: Mr Coeure blamed political risk in some European countries and stricter financial rules since the crisis for boosting demand for short-term German government bonds.

site_title: Internet breach at Mindef took place weeks before detection: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Defence (Mindef) was breached by hackers weeks before detection, with 854 users' personal data stolen, including NRIC numbers, phone numbers, and dates of birth. The breach was detected on Feb 1, but the hackers' modus operandi was consistent with a covert attack, indicating the breach occurred earlier. Mindef will strengthen cyber systems, develop better assessment tools, and review data storage to minimize risks.

site_title: Undersea turbine maker in bid to help Britannia rule the waves
summary: A British developer, Atlantis Resources, is bidding to build undersea power turbines in Scotland as part of a government auction for £290m in electricity-generation contracts. The company aims to prove its technology is commercially viable and reduce costs to £100 per megawatt-hour, comparable to nuclear and offshore wind. If successful, it could unlock the vast potential of marine energy, supplying a fifth of the UK's electricity, and stimulate investment in a £100m manufacturing plant in Scotland.

site_title: Gaining ground
summary: Asian cities are expected to increasingly dominate the global wealth landscape, with the number of ultra-high net worth individuals (UHNWIs) in Asia forecast to grow by 91% over the next decade, surpassing Europe. Vietnam is expected to see its UHNWI population rise by 170% to 540 over the next decade, with China, India, and Sri Lanka also experiencing substantial growth. Hong Kong and Singapore are forecast to see a more modest 40% growth in UHNWIs over the next decade. The top global cities for the world's wealthiest individuals are New York, London, and Hong Kong, with London emerging ahead of New York overall.

site_title: High life on the high seas
summary: Luxury cruise operators are catering to high-end travelers with ultra-luxurious amenities and personalized services. Mega vessels like the MSC Splendida feature exclusive zones, such as the Yacht Club, offering suites, private pools, and lounges. Luxury cruise lines like Seabourn and Silversea offer bespoke experiences, including butler service, gourmet dining, and customized itineraries. Overnight stops in ports allow passengers to spend more time at their destinations, and some ships offer fly-cruise packages. These luxury cruises come with a hefty price tag, with prices ranging from $10,499 to $29,999 per person for a 24-day cruise from Singapore.

site_title: STI rises 12 points in quiet trading
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 12.4 points to 3,187.51 on April 3, 2017, driven by Jardine Matheson's 1.4% gain. Quiet trading saw 2.3 billion units worth S$1.1 billion in turnover. Jardine stocks, particularly Cycle & Carriage, contributed the most to the index's rise. Traders remain cautious, awaiting US market performance and assessing the impact of President Trump's economic policies.

site_title: Echoes of Watergate in Washington
summary: President Trump is facing major obstacles in advancing his policy agenda, and the ongoing "Russiagate" probe is likely to weaken him politically. The probe, reminiscent of the Watergate scandal that led to then-President Richard Nixon's resignation in 1973, involves criminal actions and cover-ups. John Dean, a key figure in the Watergate scandal, is now being scrutinized for his involvement in the events. The probe's impact on Trump's presidency remains to be seen, but it is expected to have significant implications for his ability to push through policy initiatives.

site_title: China's plan for new Shenzhen sparks frenzy of speculation
summary: China has announced plans to create a new economic zone, Xiongan, near Beijing, sparking a frenzy of speculation among investors. The zone, expected to cover 2,000 sq km, aims to boost economic growth and create an urban district to alleviate Beijing's pollution and traffic congestion. Shares of cement, building, and port-related firms surged in Hong Kong, with cement company BBMG Corp rising 46% and Tianjin Port Development Holdings Ltd rallying 14%. The government has banned property sales in the zone to curb speculation, but investors remain optimistic about the plan's potential to support demand for construction-related materials.

site_title: Central banks have no rulebook for ending quantitative easing
summary: Central banks are ending quantitative easing, a seven-year unorthodox policy, but there's no rulebook for normalizing monetary policy. Despite concerns about the long-term impact of substantial balance sheets, central banks have been successful in avoiding a repeat of the Great Depression and promoting growth. However, ending QE requires addressing fundamental questions about central bank involvement, the role of balance sheets, and the optimal involvement in free markets. Central banks must articulate a clear plan for shrinking balance sheets and be prepared for potential economic consequences to avoid causing damage.

site_title: Gateway doesn't intend to make offer for Healthway
summary: Healthway Medical said it has been informed by its investor GW Active that it does not intend to make a general offer for the company. This decision comes after Lippo-linked Gentle Care extended the closing date for its takeover offer of Healthway to May 2, 2017. GW Active will be prohibited from making any further offers for six months. Gentle Care is also making an offer to acquire Gateway Partners' S$70 million convertible notes, valuing Healthway at S$103 million. The decision follows Healthway receiving the net proceeds of the convertible notes deal to solve its immediate cash needs.

site_title: Editor's note
summary: Wealth experts predict the largest ever transfer of wealth from one generation to the next, with US$2 trillion to be transferred among today's billionaires over the next few years. The collective fortune to be transferred in the US is estimated to be around US$30 trillion. To ensure equitable distribution and protect wealth, planning is crucial, as 90% of billionaire fortunes fall below the billion-dollar mark within the first two generations. Experts advise separating ownership of family businesses from strategic thinking about assets, and prioritizing experience over monetary wealth.

site_title: BCG launches its first Asian innovation centre in S'pore
summary: BCG launched its first Innovation Centre for Operations (ICO) in Asia, in partnership with the Singapore Economic Development Board. The model factory, set to launch in 2017, will provide immersive learning and training on Industry 4.0 topics. The centre aims to boost labour productivity by 30% and create 22,000 new jobs by 2024, with potential revenue additions of S$36 billion. BCG's investment complements Singapore's advanced manufacturing ecosystem, developing deeper industry expertise and technological capabilities.

site_title: Turning Tokyo pretty for US$6.8b is Olympian Tepco task
summary: Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) has been assigned the task of removing hundreds of thousands of utility poles across Tokyo to improve the city's appearance for the 2020 Olympics, at a cost of up to $6.8 billion. The company, already struggling with $144 billion in cleanup costs for the 2011 Fukushima nuclear meltdown, will be responsible for removing 5.9 million poles, with the Tokyo government and municipalities covering two-thirds of the bill. The removal aims to reduce the risk of power poles collapsing during earthquakes and block emergency vehicles during disasters.

site_title: 2 positive signals from URA's Q1 private home flash estimates
summary: Singapore's private home price index remained flat in Q1 2017, with the non-landed segment showing a 0.1% increase for the first time in 13 quarters. The landed segment, however, slipped 2.8% q-o-q. Despite positive signals, most property consultants predict a full-year decline in the index, with forecasts ranging from -1.5% to -3%. The government's introduction of the Additional Conveyance Duty and reduced seller's stamp duty may impact prices, while weak household income growth and interest rate hikes are expected to rein in demand.

site_title: Bottom lines of China consumer firms paint patchy picture of spending
summary: China's top consumer firms, including Tsingtao Brewery and Tingyi, posted declining profits due to tough competition and weak demand. Despite official numbers suggesting a rosier 2017, the patchy spending picture raises concerns. Analysts predict these firms will innovate to fend off competitors, driven by increased caution and sophistication. The decline in profits may impact the country's overall economic growth.

site_title: Going global: Many Singapore businesses do get it, says IE
summary: Singapore businesses are increasingly looking to expand globally, with International Enterprise (IE) Singapore helping secure over 450 deals worldwide in 2017. The agency's CEO, Lee Ark Boon, advises companies to prioritize the global market for growth and expansion, as Singapore's limited size limits room for domestic expansion. IE Singapore has assisted 37,000 local companies, including notable brands like Bee Cheng Hiang, and aims to work with high-potential companies that bring economic value back to Singapore while retaining key personnel and Singaporean capabilities.

site_title: Consumer watchdog to keep eye on profiteering from water, power price hikes
summary: Singapore's consumer watchdog, the Consumer Association of Singapore (CASE), will monitor businesses for profiteering from price hikes in water and electricity. The government has implemented measures to increase water prices by 30% over two years and electricity prices by 21.39 cents per kilowatt hour from April to June. CASE will educate consumers to make informed purchasing decisions and provide feedback channels for consumers to report alleged profiteering. The government will continue to monitor the impact of these measures on industries and calibrate economic-support policies as necessary.

site_title: Comprehensive global agreement needed on MNC tax treatment
summary: Australia has implemented a 40% tax on Australian profits of multinational companies with over A$1 billion global revenue, targeting tax avoidance schemes. The move follows a similar initiative by the British, aimed at preventing companies like Google and Facebook from exploiting low-tax jurisdictions. The tax authority now has special powers to collect up to A$2 billion in revenue. Critics worry about potential abuse and uncertainty for businesses, but the government believes this will be seen as tough on global firms and generate political dividends. A comprehensive global approach to tax treatment is needed to address the issue.

site_title: Asia's factories on song in March amid fears of trade war discord
summary: Asia's factories experienced solid growth in March, with China leading the way as its manufacturing index expanded at its fastest pace in nearly five years. This growth was driven by higher commodity prices and a global demand for electronic gadgets. However, exporters are concerned about the potential impact of a US trade war, which could disrupt the global trade recovery. Despite this, factory surveys in Japan, India, and emerging Asia showed encouraging growth.

site_title: Britain will wait for final EU guidelines on Gibraltar
summary: Britain will wait until the end of the month to determine the EU's final guidelines on Gibraltar, following a meeting between Brexit minister David Davis and Spain's Foreign Minister Alfonso Dastis. The EU draft joint position suggests any agreement on Gibraltar must be between Spain and Britain, prompting concerns about the territory's future. Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman stated that Britain will protect Gibraltar's rights and sovereignty, but ruled out sending a naval taskforce, contradicting comments from former Conservative leader Michael Howard who suggested going to war to defend the territory.

site_title: China hints at high-yield bond crackdown
summary: China's top economic planning agency has raised concerns of a crackdown on high-yield bond issuances from lower-rated companies. The Shenzhen branch of the National Development Reform Commission requires companies to provide investment-grade ratings from global rating agencies to register bonds offshore. This move may limit access to offshore markets for lower-rated companies, potentially increasing borrowing costs. The action is seen as a step to curb risk in China's bond market and promote financial stability.

site_title: March manufacturing growth points to potential recovery
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the seventh consecutive month in March, with a 51.2 Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading, the highest since November 2014. The sector's growth is mirroring regional trends, with similar expansions in Vietnam, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, and Malaysia. Economists see this as a possible recovery, with OCBC economist Selena Ling stating that the trend is not a flash in the pan and could underpin growth in the first half of the year.

site_title: IE S'pore chief: The job is about securing deals for companies
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) Singapore CEO Lee Ark Boon describes his job as "exciting, fun and challenging" as he leads the government agency responsible for securing deals for Singaporean companies abroad. With 38 overseas centres globally, IE Singapore sends officers to engage with companies, stakeholders, and secure tangible results in profits and jobs. Officers undergo training and build expertise in various sectors before being posted overseas, often with local counterparts.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment auditor flags group's going concern risk
summary: An audit report by Ernst & Young LLP on Singapore eDevelopment Limited's financial statements for 2016 highlighted a going concern risk due to uncertainty over continued financial support from substantial shareholder Hengfai Business Development. The company's ability to continue as a going concern is dependent on this support.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher; STI gains 12 points in quiet trading
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 12.4 points to 3,187.51 on Monday, driven by gains in Jardine stocks, amid quiet trading. The session was described as cautious, with Wall Street futures suggesting a firm opening. European markets opened mostly red, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Qatar to drill in biggest gas field after 12-year freeze
summary: Qatar Petroleum plans to start a new development in the North Field, ending a 12-year freeze, with a capacity of 2 billion cubic feet per day. The project, expected to take 5-7 years to produce, aims to boost Qatar's natural gas production and increase its LNG market share. Qatar Petroleum's CEO, Saad Sherida Al Kaabi, believes global demand for gas will continue to rise, making Qatar a low-cost supplier. The move is seen as a threat to other developers of new capacity worldwide, as Qatar can add new capacity at a lower cost.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher ahead of economic data
summary: US stocks rose modestly on Monday ahead of key economic data, including the March jobs report and talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1%, 0.1%, and 0.3% respectively. Analysts expect the US to add 180,000 jobs last month, while minutes from the Federal Reserve's March monetary policy meeting also influenced the market. The stock market is expected to remain volatile amid trade controversies and uncertainty.

site_title: Grab buys Indonesia e-commerce startup Kudo
summary: Grab has acquired Indonesian e-commerce startup Kudo in a deal worth "high double-digit millions". The acquisition aims to boost Grab's digital payments capabilities in Indonesia and mark Grab's first investment under its "Grab 4 Indonesia" 2020 master plan. Kudo's online-to-offline platform allows unbanked consumers to shop online, and the deal will integrate Kudo's platform with GrabPay, expanding Grab's reach across Indonesia's major cities and rural areas.

images.alt_text: Grab said on Monday that it has acquired Indonesian e-commerce startup Kudo to boost its digital payments capabilities in Indonesia. While the acquisition sum was undisclosed, The Business Times understands it to be in the "high double-digit millions".

site_title: Art of the matter
summary: K11 Art Foundation, backed by Chow Tai Fook Holdings executive Adrian Cheng, has partnered with Vivienne Westwood to launch art and fashion installations in China questioning consumerism. The exhibitions, including "Get a Life!" in Shanghai, aim to inspire young Chinese artists and consumers to think critically about their consumption habits. The event highlights the growing influence of Chinese millennials, estimated at 31% of the population and a spending group of 400 million consumers, who are increasingly concerned about climate change and environmental issues.

site_title: GM, Ford miss estimates as car models plunge despite discounts
summary: GM and Ford reported US sales that missed estimates, with deliveries rising 1.6% for GM and declining 7.2% for Ford, trailing analyst projections. Heavy incentive spending failed to boost struggling sedan and compact models, which plummeted by over 35% in sales. Industry-wide US auto sales may not rise in March as expected, casting doubt on estimates. Automakers are using heavy discounts to trim inventory, and analysts predict more production cuts.

site_title: Germany wants G20 drive for global fast internet by 2025
summary: Germany aims to drive global fast internet by 2025 through its G20 presidency, promoting common technical standards and lifelong digital learning. Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries stated that the goal is to make digital opportunities accessible to all, while regulating the digital revolution through a framework of rules. The move comes amid concerns over the lack of global standards for the Internet of Things (IoT), with 21 billion devices expected to be in use by 2020. Despite US absence from the meeting, Zypries emphasized the importance of collaboration and free trade in the digital sector.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares end stronger on upbeat March exports data
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.28% to 1,115.3 to the dollar, its strongest closing level since March 29, due to strong exports in March and the dollar's weakness. Shipments rose for a fifth straight month, while imports surged at the fastest pace in over five years. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.34% at 2,167.51 points, supported by tech heavyweights Samsung and LG Electronics.

site_title: mm2 Asia appoints Mediacorp deputy CEO as its CEO
summary: mm2 Asia appoints Mediacorp deputy CEO Chang Long Jong as its CEO, effective immediately. The appointment follows a restructuring within the company. Chang Long Jong brings his experience from Mediacorp to the role, replacing the previous CEO. The move aims to drive growth and strategic development for mm2 Asia, a film and TV production company.

site_title: Manufacturing in US kept expanding at robust pace in March
summary: US manufacturing expanded at a robust pace in March, with the Institute for Supply Management's diffusion index easing to 57.2, indicating growth. Orders cooled to 64.5, but factory employment rose to 58.9, the strongest reading since June 2011. The prices-paid index increased to 70.5, the highest since May 2011. This marks the sixth consecutive month of expansion, boosting optimism among factory managers, particularly in Asia and Europe. The US manufacturing sector has been a bright spot for the economy, which has seen tepid gains in household spending.

images.alt_text: America's factories continued to expand in March at a robust pace, demonstrating momentum in an industry that struggled for the better part of the last two years, Institute for Supply Management data showed on Monday.

site_title: Oil trades near US$50 as Libya output rebound offsets Opec cuts
summary: Crude oil prices traded near US$50 a barrel as Libyan oil production rebounded, offsetting Opec's output cuts. Libya's output rose to 660,000 barrels a day after the Sharara field resumed pumping. US supply gains, including a 5.5% rise in oil rigs, also countered Opec's efforts to drain inventories. Opec Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo expressed cautious optimism about market rebalancing. Oil prices slipped 3 US cents to US$50.57 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

site_title: Asian forestry investment fund acquires Laos hardwood plantation
summary: New Forests, a forestry investment manager, has acquired a majority stake in a 22,000-hectare eucalyptus plantation estate in Laos through its Tropical Asia Forest Fund (TAFF). The purchase, valued at an undisclosed amount, will provide early cash flow and help balance TAFF's portfolio. The plantation will be redeveloped as a high-quality timber asset to serve regional markets for certified plantation hardwood. The acquisition is part of TAFF's strategy to invest in sustainably managed timber plantations in South-east Asia.

site_title: Delong's unit to sell production capacity for 400m yuan
summary: Delong Holdings' unit Aoyu Steel plans to sell 1.08 million tonnes of pig iron production capacity and 1.21 million tonnes of steel production capacity for 400 million yuan. This follows the Hebei province's plan to reduce steelmaking capacity by 31.86 million tonnes in 2017. The sale is part of the province's efforts to speed up steelmaking capacity reduction in cities like Langfang, Baoding, and Zhangjiakou.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The US District Court for the district of Columbia has dismissed a lawsuit against SembMarine, Jurong Shipyard, Keppel Corporation, and Keppel Offshore & Marine, filed by EIG Management against Brazil's national oil company Sete Brasil. The World Bank is exploring an issuance for retail investors listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Singapore's private-home prices fell 0.5% quarter-on-quarter in Q1, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

site_title: Eurozone unemployment falls to more than 7-year low
summary: The eurozone jobless rate has fallen to 9.5% in February, its lowest level since May 2009, according to Eurostat data. This decline is attributed to a resurgent hiring spree despite uncertainty over Brexit. The drop in unemployment adds to arguments from Germany that the European Central Bank should end its stimulus program early. Despite this, the ECB is cautious, citing low inflation at 1.5%, below its target. The rate has improved in several countries, including Germany, Spain, and Portugal, but remains high in others, such as Greece.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser considers selling French's Sauce brand
summary: Reckitt Benckiser considers selling its food business, which includes French's mustard and ketchup, to help finance its $16.6 billion acquisition of Mead Johnson Nutrition. The business, generating £411 million in sales last year, is deemed "non-core" by the company. This move comes as global consumer giants face slowing sales growth for staple brands, prompting portfolio reshuffling.

site_title: Secura Group says KIP Industrial ceases to be substantial shareholder
summary: Secura Group announced that KIP Industrial Holdings has ceased to be a substantial shareholder after selling 1 million shares at S$0.17093 apiece, totaling S$170,930. This sale brings KIP's holdings below 5%. Wee Ee Chao, a managing director at UOB-Kay Hian, has an indirect interest in KIP's issued share capital.

site_title: Update: Blasts in St Petersburg metro stations kill 10
summary: At least 10 people were killed and 50 injured in a blast at a train carriage in the St. Petersburg metro system in Russia on Monday. The blast was reportedly caused by a bomb filled with shrapnel. President Vladimir Putin said he was considering all possible causes, including terrorism, amid the incident.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Monday higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.62% to 24,261.48. The move came ahead of a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump later in the week. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Australia shares inch up; NZ rises too
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by gains in financials and real estate firms, offsetting losses in raw material stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,872.7, following a 0.5% decline on Friday. The Big Four banks and real estate developer Scentre Group were among the gainers, while home prices hit record highs due to increased building approvals.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing sector grows at faster pace in March
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the seventh consecutive month in March, with a 51.2 Purchasing Managers' Index reading, a 0.3-point increase from February. The sector's growth was driven by higher new orders, new exports, factory output, inventory, and employment. However, finished goods and order backlog showed slower expansion. The electronics sector also showed growth, with a 51.8 PMI reading, driven by higher electronic factory output and new orders. The expansion signals gradual growth despite global uncertainties, with manufacturing employment expected to stabilize.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks gain but Toshiba sinks
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.39% to 18,983.23, driven by a second consecutive quarter of business confidence growth. However, Toshiba plummeted after reports suggested it may delay releasing earnings. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index also rose, with the Nikkei up 0.39% and the Topix up 0.29%.

site_title: Ezra to meet noteholders on April 17
summary: Ezra Holdings announced a meeting with noteholders on April 17, 2017, to update investors following the filing of voluntary petitions for reorganisation under Chapter 11 of the US Bankruptcy Code. The meeting will be attended by Ezra's management and moderated by representatives from the Securities Investors Association (Singapore). Noteholders must contact the company by April 10 to attend the informal meeting.

site_title: Credit Suisse claims innocence in global press
summary: Credit Suisse denies involvement in tax evasion, claiming "zero tolerance" for the practice. The Swiss bank took out full-page ads in European papers stating it only works with clients who have paid taxes and declared assets. However, authorities in Europe and Australia launched a massive investigation with hundreds of possible suspects across five countries, including Dutch arrests and asset seizures. Credit Suisse confirmed local authorities searched its offices in London, Paris, and Amsterdam, but claims it is cooperating with the investigation. The bank's head of international wealth management, Iqbal Khan, said the probe is focused on clients, contradicting a Revenue and Customs statement.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to offer new flat taxi fare from Apr 10 for app bookings
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp, Singapore's largest taxi operator, announced a new flat taxi fare option for bookings made through its app, starting April 10. This comes just days after Grab introduced dynamic pricing for taxis and similar services. The flat fare will provide users with a more predictable cost, allowing them to plan their journeys more easily. This move is seen as a response to the increasing competition in the ride-hailing market.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm Grab agrees to buy Indonesian payment startup Kudo
