summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing firm, has agreed to buy Indonesian online payment startup Kudo for an undisclosed deal value. The acquisition is part of Grab's US$700 million investment plan in Indonesia, marking its largest market. Kudo's payment services will be integrated with Grab's GrabPay, and the company plans to expand financial services such as insurance and consumer loans. Grab has also hired Jason Thompson as head of GrabPay to oversee the integration. The deal creates immediate synergies and is expected to boost Grab's presence in Indonesia.

site_title: Gateway doesn't intend to make offer for Healthway
summary: Gateway Partners, a Singapore-based investment firm, does not intend to make a general offer for Healthway Medical. GW Active, its investor, made this declaration after receiving the net proceeds of a S$70 million convertible notes deal with Healthway. As a result, GW Active will be prohibited from announcing an offer or acquiring shares that would result in it holding at least 30% of Healthway's voting rights for six months. This decision follows Healthway's receipt of the funds to address its immediate cash needs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.5%. The Paris CAC 40 added 0.2% compared to Friday's close. This follows a rally in Asia, where Singapore stocks notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data, and US stocks edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Gold prices steady, buoyed by tepid US economic data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,248.21 per ounce, supported by weak US economic data and dovish remarks from a Federal Reserve official. Spot gold marked its best quarter in a year, driven by uncertainties around US President Donald Trump's policies and elections in Europe. Hedge funds increased their long positions in gold and silver, while platinum and palladium also rose. The main focus for markets this week is on US payroll figures and President Trump's meeting with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping.

site_title: Hyundai flags weaker China sales after missile row; Kia's March China sales halved
summary: Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp reported weaker sales in China in March, citing a diplomatic row over a missile system that led to increased anti-Korean sentiment. Kia's China sales likely halved from the previous year, while Hyundai declined to comment on the country-by-country breakdown. The weaker sales are attributed to a significant portion of the companies' 2016 overseas sales coming from China, which accounted for over a quarter of their total. This decline in China sales likely dragged down overseas sales for both companies in March.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.4 points to 1,745.49. The index saw 3.24 billion lots traded worth RM2.55 billion, with 499 gainers outpacing 430 losers.

site_title: Singapore and Japan to collaborate in development of ports
summary: Singapore and Japan signed a memorandum of cooperation to plan, manage, and develop ports in both countries. The agreement aims to address changes in the maritime industry, including larger container vessels, stricter regulations, and the rise of digital technologies. The partnership is expected to enhance cooperation between the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and Japan's Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (MLIT) for sustainable port development.

site_title: China vows fresh smog crackdown as toxic air shrouds capital
summary: China has vowed to crack down on pollution after air quality deteriorated in the first quarter of 2017, with smog blanketing the capital, Beijing, and surrounding cities. Top officials from seven districts and cities in Beijing, Tianjin, and provinces Hebei and Shanxi were scolded for lax control of pollution. They promised to submit plans to resolve the problem within 20 days. The province of Hebei, home to six of China's 10 smoggiest cities, will take more action to shut coal-fired power plants and promote new energy vehicles.

site_title: Australia shares flat; NZ up for a fifth straight session
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Monday, rising 0.1% to 5,868.8, as financial stocks gained but basic materials slipped due to falling iron ore and copper prices. Banks focused on loan books and investor lending, while the Australian Securities and Investments Commission launched a new surveillance round to ensure banks weren't recommending expensive interest-only loans. Meanwhile, home prices in major Australian cities jumped, driving annual growth to the fastest in almost seven years.

site_title: World Bank exploring new issuance for retail investors on SGX
summary: The World Bank is exploring a new issuance of sustainable development bonds for retail investors, to be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This follows a partnership between SGX and the World Bank, aiming to raise investor awareness and bring high-quality, triple-A investment products to retail investors in Singapore. The partnership will offer educational events on SGX Academy to promote sustainable development bonds.

site_title: Property agents shut, buyers still hunt as China plans new economic zone
summary: Real estate agents in China's Hebei province shut down on Monday after Beijing ordered a ban on property sales in an effort to curb a sudden housing boom triggered by plans for a new special economic zone. The zone, modeled after Shenzhen's, led to a surge in prices, with average apartment prices doubling and hotels filling up. The move aims to prevent a rapid appreciation in property values and alleviate traffic congestion. Despite the ban, buyers continue to hunt for properties, highlighting the strong demand for housing in the region.

site_title: Emirates, Etihad to boost screening on Australia flights
summary: Emirates and Etihad airlines will increase screening for passengers flying to Australia starting Thursday. The new requirements, imposed by Australia, include additional screening at the gate, but do not restrict electronic devices. The measures apply to direct flights on these airlines, as well as Qantas, and do not affect flights to the UAE. Unlike the US and British bans, Australian officials cited security concerns without specifying a threat. The move aims to enhance explosives detection following the US ban on laptops and tablets on direct flights from key Middle Eastern airports.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb as Xi-Trump meeting approaches
summary: Asia's stocks rose at the start of the week, driven by a strong first quarter and a busy week of economic data releases, including a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.2% as the US dollar weakened and the euro rose. Markets in China and Taiwan are closed for holidays, while oil edged lower after last week's biggest gain of the year. The improving global economic outlook is threatened by political developments, with investors waiting for clues from the US-China trade deficit and US non-farm payrolls due on Friday.

site_title: GIC-Intiland JV to own and develop South Quarter complex in Jakarta
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, has formed a 40-60 joint venture with Indonesia's PT Intiland Development to own and develop South Quarter complex in Jakarta. The 7.2-hectare integrated mixed-use complex is located in the TB Simatupang corridor, a business hub with direct access to Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. The project will include two condominium towers and is expected to launch in the fourth quarter of 2017, with GIC expressing confidence in Indonesia's long-term growth potential.

images.alt_text: PT Intiland Development Tbk, a leading property developer in Indonesia, and GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, have formed a 60-40 joint venture that owns and manages the integrated mixed-use complex, South Quarter.

site_title: China, Taiwan: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in China and Taiwan are closed on Monday for a public holiday. No specific market updates are provided in the article.

site_title: Indonesia's annual inflation rate cools in March
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate eased to 3.61% in March, below expectations of 3.84%. Consumer prices fell 0.02% on a monthly basis, with declines in rice, chilli, and eggs. Core inflation, excluding volatile food prices, slowed to 3.30%. The central bank aims for annual inflation between 3-5% this year, with its next policy review on April 19-20.

site_title: Rescuers dig for victims of Colombia disaster, death toll hits 254
summary: Rescuers in Colombia continue searching for victims of devastating floods and landslides in Mocoa, which have killed 254 people. The disaster occurred when several rivers burst their banks, sending mud and debris into homes. Many corpses are still trapped in debris, with 82 bodies recovered downstream. The incident has left entire neighborhoods devastated, with hundreds injured.

site_title: South Korea Lotte Group says will continue to invest in China despite tensions
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group plans to continue investing in its China business despite diplomatic tensions over the deployment of a US missile defense system. The move comes after Chinese authorities closed dozens of Lotte retail stores in response to the Thaad deployment, which Beijing claims can reach far into China. Lotte executive denies rumors of scaling back China operations, citing a commitment to investing in the country.

site_title: Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner visits Iraq: US official
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner visited Iraq with Marine General Joseph Dunford, the chairman of the US military's Joint Chiefs of Staff. Kushner aimed to show support for the Iraqi government and see the country for himself. This visit comes after Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi met with Trump on March 20, where he sought assurances of greater US support in fighting Islamic State militants.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Singapore eDevelopment, Natural Cool, Yangzijiang (Amended)
summary: The US District Court for the district of Columbia has ruled in favor of Sembcorp Marine and Jurong Shipyard in a lawsuit filed by EIG Management against Brazil's national oil company Petrobras.

site_title: South Korea, Japan and the US hold drill against North Korea submarines
summary: South Korea, Japan, and the US conducted a three-day naval exercise against North Korean submarine threats, amid concerns over Pyongyang's nuclear program. The exercise, involving over 800 troops, aimed to counter missile threats from North Korean submarines, including submarine-launched ballistic missiles. The drills followed US President Donald Trump's warning that the US would act unilaterally to address North Korea's nuclear program if China does not help. Tensions in the region have escalated following recent missile launches by North Korea, with the country preparing for another potential atomic test.

images.alt_text: South Korea, Japan and the US held a joint naval exercise Monday aimed at countering missile threats from North Korean submarines, Seoul's defence ministry said, amid mounting concerns over the hermit state's weapons programme.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 8.52 points to 3,183.63. Volume reached 83.2 million shares worth S$140.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 92 to 43. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Flash estimates show HDB resale prices fall 0.6% in Q1
summary: HDB resale flat prices fell 0.6% in Q1 2017, marking the first decline after four quarters of negligible movement. The HDB will offer 4,600 Build-To-Order flats and 3,000 balance flats for sale in May. These developments come as the market adjusts to changing demand.

site_title: Flash: URA's private home price index down 0.5% q-o-q in Q1 2017
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 0.5% decline in private home prices on a quarterly basis in Q1 2017. This marks a slight drop after the 0.6% increase in Q4 2016. The Q1 2017 decline is attributed to a slowdown in the market.

site_title: Japan's corporate sentiment improves as profits rise on weak yen
summary: Japan's corporate sentiment improved in the first quarter as profits rose due to a weaker yen, reaching a record high. The Tankan survey showed a rise in sentiment among large manufacturers to 12, up from 10 three months prior, and an increase in the outlook to 11 from 8. This marks the second consecutive quarter of improvement. The Bank of Japan reported a record high in profits, driven by the weaker yen.

site_title: Broker's take: China Everbright's new project will reinforce its market position, says DBS
summary: China Everbright Water won the bid for the Ji'nan Zhangqiu urban-rural integration water supply project in Shandong, marking its first project of this kind. The 3.1 billion yuan project will enhance the company's integrated business strength and reinforce its market position. DBS Group Research maintains a "buy" rating on the company, citing robust growth in construction revenue and increased operating services and cash flow. The significant improvement in deal flow is a substantial increase from the 2.5 billion yuan awarded for the full year of FY2016.

site_title: Oil prices fall on supply concerns as US rig count rises
summary: Oil prices fell in early Asian trade on Monday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dipping 5 cents to $50.55 a barrel, and Brent futures sliding 11 cents to $53.42 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over global oversupply and a stronger US dollar, following a 10-rig increase in the US, the strongest quarterly addition since 2011. Both contracts posted their worst quarterly losses since 2015, with Brent down 7% and US futures down 6%.

site_title: S'pore private-home prices ease 0.5% q-o-q in Q1: URA flash estimates
summary: Singapore's private-home prices fell 0.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2017, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimates. This marks the 14th consecutive quarter of decline in the private-home price index, which matches the rate seen in Q4 2016. The drop follows a similar trend to the previous quarter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.490 points to 1742.380. The trading volume was 235.75 million lots worth RM133.39 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 174 to 85.

site_title: Tesla tops quarterly sales forecast
summary: Tesla exceeded quarterly sales forecasts, delivering over 25,000 vehicles in the first quarter, a 69% increase from 2016. The company's upcoming Model 3, priced at $35,000, is expected to boost production. Tesla aims to meet its target of 50,000 units in the first half of the year. CEO Elon Musk expressed confidence in reaching 500,000 vehicles in production by next year. The company's Gigafactory in Nevada is also producing energy-saving batteries for its products and energy storage systems.

site_title: Less noodles, beer and movies? Clouds on Chinese consumption horizon
summary: China's top consumer firms, including brewers, noodle makers, and cinema chains, reported declining profits in 2017, citing tough competition and weak demand. Despite official data suggesting a strong start to the economy, consumption trends remain uncertain, with retail sales disappointing in the first two months of the year. Companies are expected to innovate and spend more to fend off competitors, as consumers become more cautious about spending. The uneven nature of China's shift to a consumer-driven economy poses challenges for brands and Beijing, which needs to stimulate domestic consumption and private investment to fuel growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher but Toshiba falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 3, 2017, but Toshiba fell after reports it may delay releasing its earnings for the third time. Japan's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.14%, while the Topix index gained 0.16%. Toshiba's decline overshadowed the overall market gain, with the index closing at 18,936.52.

site_title: CEO offers S$0.215 or stock per share to delist TEE Int'l
summary: TEE International's CEO Phua Chian Kin is offering S$0.215 or one new share in Oscar Investment for every TEE share, to take the company private through a scheme of arrangement. This offer allows shareholders to receive cash or new equity. The proposal was announced on April 2, 2017, and details on Oscar's issued shares were not disclosed.

site_title: Natural Cool's independent audit report includes emphasis of matter
summary: Natural Cool's independent auditor KPMG has released its FY2016 financial statement report, which includes an emphasis of matter regarding the group's internal investigation into irregular transactions and activities in the paint division. The investigation, announced on February 28, 2017, is related to companies set up by employees to operate a competing business using subsidiaries' assets and resources, with unsupported expenses incurred. The outcome of the matter cannot be determined at present, but the financial statements are not modified due to non-material contributions from the paint business.

site_title: Saving money while studying abroad
summary: A university student shares tips for studying abroad, focusing on saving money. Consider a self-proposed exchange program, which can be free or low-cost, and research options before applying. Rethink round-trip tickets and consider one-way or open tickets. Staying on or off campus, packing light, and cooking at home can also help reduce expenses. Take advantage of local events and festivals, and make friends with locals to get the most out of your experience. Additionally, consider getting an internship or part-time job to help cover expenses and make the most of your time abroad.

site_title: US dollar starts week on back foot, keeps above 4-month lows
summary: The US dollar started the week on a weak note, trading nearly flat at 100.390 against a basket of six major rivals, its lowest level since November 11. The dollar's weakness is attributed to lackluster US data and comments from Federal Reserve officials, who expressed cautious expectations on further rate hikes. Economists predict the US economy added 180,000 jobs in March, and the Bank of Japan's survey showed big manufacturers expect the dollar to average 108.43 this fiscal year, indicating a broader economic recovery.

site_title: China demand for bananas to cotton drives Asia export rebound
summary: China's demand for commodities such as bananas, cotton, and lamb has driven a rebound in Asia's exports, ending a two-year trade recession. Shipments to China have risen sharply in value and volume, boosting exports for countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, and India. The planned launches of new smartphones have also fueled demand for semiconductors and other components. However, economists warn that the sustainability of the export recovery is uncertain due to rising debt and leverage, and potential trade tensions between China and the US.

site_title: Australia home prices speed ahead in March, leave regulators lagging
summary: Home prices in Australia's major cities surged 1.4% in March, boosting annual growth to 12.9%, the fastest in almost seven years. This challenges regulators concerned about a debt-fueled housing market bubble. The Reserve Bank of Australia has warned further interest rate cuts could encourage more borrowing, while CoreLogic expects lending conditions to tighten for investment purposes. Home prices in Sydney rose 18.9% annually, while Melbourne saw a 15.9% gain. The rapid price increases have priced out first-time buyers and become a political issue.

site_title: Yangzijiang wins 13 shipbuilding contracts worth US$318m
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has won 13 shipbuilding contracts worth US$318 million for the first quarter of 2017. The contracts include five bulk carriers, five woodchip carriers, two containerships, and one ConRo vessel, scheduled for deliveries from 2018 to 2020. The company remains cautiously optimistic about the recovery in the second-hand vessel market and bulk carrier market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.29% on Monday, reaching 24,182.14, as investors look ahead to the US jobs data release and a meeting between Xi Jinping and Donald Trump. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: San Miguel planning US$34b investments, says president
summary: San Miguel Corp, the Philippines' largest company by sales, plans to invest $34 billion in an oil refinery, steel complex, and ocean-tide power plant. President Ramon Ang also mentioned the company is evaluating a bid for Vietnam's Saigon Beer, which could provide an anchor to boost its brewery business amid 10% annual growth in Vietnam. This investment is expected to increase the company's profit by at least 20% this year.

site_title: Survey: Asian consumers most optimistic in emerging markets
summary: A Credit Suisse survey of 14,000 Asian consumers across 8 emerging economies found Asian consumers to be the most optimistic. India tops the rankings with the highest consumer confidence, followed by Indonesia and China. The survey, conducted at the Asian Investment Conference, aimed to gauge consumer confidence in emerging markets, revealing a positive outlook for Asian consumers.

site_title: Putin, friend or foe? Russia looms over French election
summary: Russia is casting a large shadow over France's upcoming presidential election, with candidates on the hard left, right, and far right all vowing to improve ties with the Kremlin. US authorities are warning of possible Russian attempts to disrupt the vote, following allegations of interference in the 2016 US presidential election. The chairman of the US Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has accused Russia of an "overt effort" to disrupt the French election, which is set to take place from April 23 to May 7.

site_title: New EU rules aim to make power cheaper when the sun shines
summary: The European Union is proposing new rules that could lead to cheaper electricity prices when the sun shines, due to a surge in intermittent renewable energy. The rules, set to take effect in 2020, would require utilities to offer flexible prices to encourage consumers to use electricity during abundant and cheap periods. This approach aims to address price swings caused by the increasing use of renewable energy sources like solar power.

site_title: Thousands march in Paris after Chinese man's death by police
summary: Thousands of people in Paris marched after a Chinese man's death by police, with around 6,000 protesters taking part in the rally. Liu Shaoyo, a 56-year-old father of five, was shot by police in his apartment on March 26 over a suspected domestic dispute, but his family disputes the police version of the incident. The protesters, organized by Chinese associations in France, clashed with security forces, with sporadic skirmishes and tear gas used. Beijing has called on Paris to guarantee the safety and rights of Chinese citizens in France, amid a police investigation into the incident.

site_title: Trump hails EU for 'good job' uniting in Brexit era
summary: US President Donald Trump praised the European Union for "doing a very good job" in uniting after Britain's decision to leave the bloc. Trump said the EU is "getting their act together" and adopting a "different spirit for holding together" since the Brexit referendum. He claimed Brexit would be a "great deal" for both the UK and the EU, contradicting his previous prediction that other countries would follow Britain's lead. The EU leaders, including French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, reacted angrily to Trump's comments, stating the EU has no need for outside advice.

site_title: US urges China to take 'action' against North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump warned China to take action against North Korea's nuclear program, stating that if China won't help, the US will act unilaterally. Trump made the comments ahead of his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, saying China's influence over North Korea is crucial. US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley also urged China to take action, calling the current measures, including suspending coal imports, insufficient. China has expressed frustration with North Korea's nuclear and missile activities, but has not yet condemned the country.

site_title: HK warns of home loan risks as prices soar: report
summary: Hong Kong's property market continues to soar, with existing home prices reaching a record for six consecutive weeks. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has warned banks of rising property lending risks, citing highly leveraged mortgages provided by developers. The authority may tighten risk management and advise banks to be prudent in lending to clients buying multiple units. Citigroup expects new cooling measures, while Li Ka-shing believes the rebound could persist for two years due to growing demand. Hong Kong retains its position as the world's most expensive housing market.

site_title: Unwinding property curbs gives Singapore developers new headache
summary: Singapore's recent relaxation of property curbs has created a new headache for developers, who now face a choice between discounting unsold luxury homes or paying hefty penalties. The government's closure of a tax loophole has led to 2,098 unsold homes in 57 projects, with estimated penalties of S$647 million. Discounting homes could further lower prices, prolonging the three-year slide in property values, while paying penalties could be even more costly. This move may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf, potentially affecting the market's recovery.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment's auditor draws attention to group's ability to continue as a going concern
summary: Singapore eDevelopment's auditor has drawn attention to the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to material uncertainty. The company relies on financial support from substantial shareholder Hengfai Business Development. However, the auditor notes that if the company is unable to continue operating, it may be unable to discharge liabilities and assets may need to be realized at different values. The board responds by stating that it can continue as a going concern through raising funds and generating positive cash flows, with Hengfai providing irrevocable financial support for the next 12 months.

site_title: Shopped too much? These two girls turned to stocks
summary: Two Nanyang Technological University (NTU) undergraduates, Lim Yu Xin and Lim Jiing Wei, profited from stock trades made while studying abroad late last year. They invested in stocks like Global Logistic Properties (GLP) and CapitaLand, generating over S$8,000 in combined realised and unrealised profits. The duo, who are part of a male-dominated industry, have also excelled in stock pitch competitions, with their NTU team finishing as runners-up in the National University of Singapore-Singapore Exchange (NUS-SGX) competition. They attribute their success to a bottom-up approach and their ability to stay motivated and focused on their goals.

site_title: Tough-talking Haley, once a critic, is Trump's voice at UN
summary: US Ambassador Nikki Haley is making a bold presence at the United Nations as the chair of the Security Council, using "undiplomatic language" to defend her boss, President Donald Trump. She has criticized Russia for its actions in Ukraine and warned that any interference in the US election would be punished. Haley has also targeted China, calling on it to halt covert imports of North Korean coal and work to halt Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. Her blunt style has drawn attention at the UN, where she aims to reinvigorate the "stale" institutional culture.

site_title: Update: Lawsuit against SembMarine, Jurong Shipyard, Keppel dismissed by US district court (Amended)
summary: The US District Court for the District of Columbia dismissed a lawsuit filed by EIG Management against SembCorp Marine, Jurong Shipyard, Keppel Corporation, and Keppel Offshore & Marine, which had named them as defendants in a suit against Brazil's national oil company Sete Brasil. The ruling was made in favor of the four companies. This comes after SembCorp Marine reported a net profit of $34.29 million in its fourth-quarter results, reversing a net loss of $536.88 million due to the absence of impairment and provisions for its rig building projects.

site_title: Tennis: Federer downs Nadal to win Miami Open
summary: Roger Federer defeated Rafael Nadal 6-3, 6-4 to win the Miami Open, extending his dominant start to the year. Federer, 35, has now won the Australian Open and Indian Wells, and heads into a break before the French Open. Federer has beaten Nadal in all four events this year and has a 10-9 lead on hard courts. Nadal, playing in his fifth Miami final, remains without a win in the Masters series event, but feels in good form heading into the clay season.

site_title: Mercatus close to sealing Jurong Point purchase
summary: Mercatus Co-operative, an NTUC social enterprise, is close to sealing a deal to buy Jurong Point for S$2.2 billion, reflecting a net yield of about 4.2%. The 658,000 sq ft commercial space is nearly fully let, with a catchment of 150,000 households and an average of six million visitors a month. The acquisition aligns with Mercatus' strategy of providing retail space for NTUC social enterprises and generating sustainable returns. Market watchers expect Mercatus to acquire the remaining space held by DBS and Golden Village to gain full ownership of the property.

site_title: Greenback flat on Fed official's comments
summary: The US dollar remained flat on Friday after Federal Reserve official William Dudley's dovish comments and weak US consumer spending data. Dudley stated the Fed has no rush to tighten monetary policy, while consumer spending only edged up 0.1% in February. The dollar index fell 0.7% for the month, its second decline in three months. The euro rebounded from a two-week trough, and the dollar fell to its lowest against the Japanese yen.

site_title: Pink trucks, netballers now in Rinehart iron mine
summary: Billionaire Gina Rinehart's Roy Hill Holdings mine in Western Australia is expanding its workforce to ramp up production, hiring 858 people in the past 12 months and aiming to add another 650. The company is targeting "greenies" with little or no mining experience, paying them lower wages to keep costs low. This move comes as the iron ore industry faces a new glut, with prices expected to drop to US$58 by the end of 2017. The company's goal is to diversify its workforce and increase productivity, while also reducing costs to remain profitable.

site_title: Stocks set to test record highs this week
summary: US stocks are poised to test record highs this week after rebounding from a recent slump, with a focus on March jobs data and economic indicators. Consumer confidence has hit its highest levels since 2000, suggesting a potential economic boom, particularly from the consumer sphere. Oil prices may stabilize around $50 a barrel, supporting economies of both producers and consumers. However, a strong jobs report on Friday could lead to interest rate hikes, which may impact the long-term fate of the bull market.

site_title: Encouraging signs in Abundance
summary: Abundance International, a chemical industry firm, has issued a unique European-style warrant with a life span of four years. The warrant can be exercised only upon expiry and has an exercise price of S$0.02. Currently, the shares are at S$0.061, making the warrant deep in-the-money. If bought at S$0.027, it offers a 23% discount. However, the warrant's low gearing of 2.2 may justify the discount, considering the company's gradual downsizing and entry into chemical trading, which shows encouraging signs of a possible turnaround.

site_title: Myanmar the link for trade between South Asia and S-E Asia: ADB
summary: Myanmar has joined the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) partnership, opening up new markets and supply chain links for trade and business between South Asia and South-east Asia. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) claims this will promote and accelerate cooperation between the two regions. With Myanmar's membership, SASEC now includes seven countries, with the first meeting of finance ministers set to take place in New Delhi. The partnership aims to develop multimodal connectivity and strengthen trade and economic relations between the SASEC subregion and East and South-east Asia.

site_title: Carl's Jr, Hardee's find sex no longer sells fast food
summary: Carl's Jr and Hardee's, two fast-food chains, are rebranding their image by shifting away from racy commercials featuring scantily-clad women. The new message, "Food, not boobs," aims to appeal to a broader audience. The companies are attempting to reverse a decade of association with provocative advertising.

site_title: Getting women on board
summary: Singaporean business leaders weigh in on whether the city-state should mandate a 20% female board directors target. Advocates argue that promoting gender diversity can lead to better decision-making and business outcomes. Key supporters include CEOs from major companies such as Lombard Odier, Thales, and AXA Insurance, who emphasize the importance of recognizing capabilities and merit in all employees. Some also suggest that a 30-40% target would be more ideal. However, others express concerns about the risks of cynicism and tokenism, and some argue that a more inclusive approach should focus on diversity of skills and experience.

site_title: Director buying, selling consistent with week ago
summary: Singapore Exchange filings from March 27 to April 1 show a flat director buying and selling activity, with 38 purchases worth S$1.18 million and eight disposals worth S$0.78 million. Boustead Projects recorded its first buyback since listing in 2015, while Yanlord Land Group and Multi-Chem Limited increased their direct holdings. Other notable transactions include Singapore Medical Group CEO Beng Teck Liang buying 300,000 shares and Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore's non-executive chairman selling 3.64 million shares.

site_title: Airbus faces cash headache, lengthy talks over A400M delays
summary: Airbus faces a cash squeeze and uncertainty over its A400M troop plane project due to delays and technical issues, with European buyers upholding penalty clauses. The company needs help with a 20 billion euro program, mainly due to cash shortfall concerns, particularly from Germany, the largest customer. Germany is withholding 15% of cash payments due to unfulfilled contract requirements, putting pressure on Airbus's cash planning and relations with its government shareholder, Berlin. Buyers have agreed to continue talks, but no immediate solution is in sight.

site_title: After a 10.2% Q1 rise, consolidation likely
summary: Singapore stocks are expected to consolidate following a 10.2% Q1 rise. The UK's Brexit trigger may not have a significant impact on markets due to the two-year withdrawal period. In local news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. Other global news includes US stocks opening lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada and a possible fee hike at London's Heathrow airport.

site_title: In a sea of blue, watch makers also bet on brown
summary: At Baselworld 2017, watchmakers favored blue tones, with brands like Nomos, Breguet, and Rolex showcasing a range of blue-colored timepieces. However, brown watches also gained attention, offering a unique alternative. Despite the blue trend, brown watches stand out with their distinct style.

site_title: Fullerton Heritage banks on technology to raise its game
summary: The Fullerton Heritage is leveraging technology to boost productivity, improve processes, and reduce manpower dependence in a challenging operating environment. General manager Cavaliere Giovanni Viterale emphasizes the importance of innovation and smart use of resources. Initiatives include smart toilets, intelligent waste bins, automatic key management systems, and a centralized temperature monitoring system. The hotels also use customer relationship management software to enhance the customer experience and deploy manpower effectively. Occupancies are high, and the hotels are expected to maintain momentum despite industry-wide challenges, with a prime location in the Central Business District being a key advantage.

site_title: Australia sticks with blunt tools to battle housing bubble
summary: Australian regulators have implemented measures to cool the country's rapidly rising housing market, limiting new interest-only loans to 30% of total mortgage lending and increasing scrutiny on banks. However, industry players doubt the effectiveness of these measures, citing concerns about collateral damage to other markets. Unlike New Zealand and China, Australia's approach is more blunt, avoiding targeted measures that have shown success in those countries. The Reserve Bank of Australia has also been hesitant to raise interest rates, instead opting for more gradual action, amid record low inflation and weak wages growth.

site_title: BBC, British journalism schools trying to burst fake news bubble
summary: British lawmakers are investigating the rise of fake news, with a parliamentary probe warning it poses a threat to democracy. Journalism schools are adapting their teaching to combat the issue, and the BBC has issued guidelines for children. Tech companies are urged to help tackle fake news on social media platforms. Experts cite three factors contributing to the surge: political uncertainty, new technology, and armed conflict. The phenomenon is not new, but its scale has increased, and satirical news outlets are often blurred with factual reporting.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:

London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Staggering increase in US heroin use hits young, white men hardest
summary: US heroin use has increased fivefold over a decade, with dependence on the drug tripling, according to a major study. The sharpest increase was among young, white men with lower education and income levels, who accounted for the highest heroin-related death rate in 2015. Researchers attribute the rise to factors such as prescription opioid abuse and cheaper alternatives like heroin. The study found that heroin use and addiction have become more prevalent among whites, men with lower education, and those with lower income.

site_title: Australia creaks under the weight of its own success
summary: Australia is poised to become the country with the longest streak of economic growth, driven by population gains, resource exports to China, and low interest rates. However, stagnant living standards, a property bubble, and rising household debt threaten financial stability. The nation's top credit score is at risk due to spiraling budget deficits. Despite avoiding recession, Australia's economy has missed the opportunity for a slump to clean out areas of excess, such as housing, and has become overly dependent on China. The government's timid response to these issues has led to political gridlock and a looming AAA rating loss.

site_title: America running short of small apartment buildings
summary: US apartment buildings with 2-9 units are the cheapest option for renters, offering lower monthly rents. However, these "small and medium multi-family housing" units account for only 15% of new housing stock since 1990, down from 54% in the 1970s and 1980s. Zoning rules and regulatory costs discourage developers from building these types of units. Experts suggest rewriting zoning codes to favor smaller buildings, but the trend towards single-family homes and high-rise apartments may lead to a shortage of affordable housing in the future.

site_title: Five-nation tax evasion investigation takes Credit Suisse by surprise
summary: A tax evasion and money laundering investigation involving five countries, including Australia, the UK, France, Germany, and the Netherlands, has targeted Credit Suisse, surprising the bank. The probe, which began in 2016, may jeopardize CEO Tidjane Thiam's efforts to focus the bank on wealth management. The investigation has led to arrests, asset seizures, and dozens of suspected individuals. Credit Suisse has cooperated with authorities and implemented tax disclosure programs, but the bank's shares fell 1.2% due to the surprise probe. The investigation's international scope and potential impact on the bank's operations are being closely watched.

site_title: Fighting compulsive gambling among older women
summary: Older women are increasingly drawn to casinos due to their appealing environment, which includes perks like free food and drinks. However, this can lead to compulsive gambling, with many women losing control of their lives. Experts, including author Sandra Adell, argue that casinos use manipulative marketing tactics to target older adults, preying on their weaknesses. The industry's approach is deemed morally reprehensible, as it exploits vulnerable individuals for financial gain.

site_title: Tackling cancer via an Oxbridge classic
summary: The Oxbridge Society of Singapore, in collaboration with the National Cancer Centre Singapore (NCCS) and Tessa Therapeutics, hosted the Row for Hope event, raising over S$80,000 for cancer patients in financial need. The event, held on March 26, included a boat race, exhibitions, and booths to educate the public on cancer. Proceeds will benefit NCCS's Community Cancer Fund, supporting patient care, public education, and rehabilitation programs. The event aims to raise awareness and funds for cancer patients, with cancer remaining the number one killer in Singapore, accounting for 30% of all deaths in 2015.

site_title: Heavy-drinking Russians going for alcohol-free beer
summary: Russia's heavy drinkers are shifting towards alcohol-free beer, with sales jumping 12% in 2017 despite a broader market decline. The trend is driven by healthier lifestyles and government measures to curb drinking. Anheuser Busch InBev plans to promote its Bud brand's alcohol-free version during the 2018 FIFA World Cup, while Carlsberg's Baltika is investing in zero-strength beer. The segment accounts for 1.2% of Russia's beer market, with AB InBev aiming for 20% of its global sales by 2025.

images.alt_text: Mr Shpakov says AB InBev has closed five plants, and the firm's remaining five were running at between 40 and 90 per cent of capacity last year depending on season and the regions they serve.

site_title: The oil and gas value chain
summary: US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada, leading to a surge in gold prices. Oil prices fell amid concerns about bearish Trump tariffs, which may impact the global energy market. China's solar industry saw a significant surge as the government moved to calm price wars. Opec announced a reduction in oil demand for the next four years. Meanwhile, Indonesian investment from Chinese tycoons is transforming the country into a major aluminium producer.

site_title: Viacom hopes to rival major US cable channels with Paramount Network
summary: Viacom is rebranding Spike TV as the Paramount Network, aiming to challenge top US cable networks with high-quality shows, rivaling HBO. The move is part of CEO Bob Bakish's efforts to turn around the company's fortunes. The Paramount Network will be a key part of Viacom's pitch to advertisers during the upfront, where they sell advertising inventory for the next year. Viacom hopes to attract major advertisers with the caliber of shows offered by the network.

site_title: Chinese investment in Australia surges 11.7% as deals hit record
summary: Chinese investment in Australia surged 11.7% to A$15.4 billion in 2016, with a record 103 deals signed, mostly with private firms. Commercial real estate and infrastructure attracted the majority of investments, with agribusiness rising threefold. Despite government vetoes of two Chinese-led deals, the growth in investment outpaced increases in the EU and Brazil. China has attracted over US$90 billion in new investment since 2007, second only to the US.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan are closed on May 1, 2017, for a public holiday.

site_title: 130 units at Redhill's Artra sold over the weekend
summary: Singapore's Artra condo sold 130 units over the weekend, with an average price of S$1,700 per square foot. The 44-storey development, launched on April 29, features larger units and a supermarket. Real estate agents, including Knight Frank, reported a "very encouraging start" in sales. The project's location near the Redhill MRT station and lack of one-bedroom units are seen as attractions. Experts describe the launch performance as "decent," given the project's prices starting from S$1.2 million.

site_title: Japan counts down to cherry blossom fever
summary: Japan's cherry blossom season officially kicks off with boozy parties and tourist arrivals, but inspectors must confirm bloom timing by inspecting barometer trees. The short season, lasting about a week, has become a symbol of life's fragility in Japanese art and literature. Inspectors, like Hisato Nishii, monitor trees daily, with the timing influenced by weather conditions. The Japan Meteorological Agency has been monitoring blooms since 1953, but timing remains an exact science. Millions celebrate the blooms, with Tokyo's parks and restaurants packed, and companies releasing sakura-branded merchandise.

images.alt_text: Millions of Japanese celebrate the explosion of white and pink flowers heralding the change of season, with the Tokyo area expected to hit full bloom this week.

site_title: HSBC, RBS Saudi Arabian ventures in talks to merge
summary: HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland's Saudi Arabian ventures, HSBC's Saudi British Bank and Alawwal Bank, are exploring a potential merger to create the kingdom's third-largest lender with $78 billion in assets. The combined entity would be the largest after National Commercial Bank and Al Rajhi Bank. The negotiations come as banks in the Middle East grapple with the economic challenges posed by sustained low oil prices and slower economic growth. The merger could prompt other deals in the region and make it easier for RBS to exit Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Saudi Arabia offers size in drive to list shares of foreign companies
summary: Saudi Arabia aims to start listing foreign companies on its stock market this year, as part of its efforts to diversify its economy and become a regional centre for equity issuance. The Capital Market Authority has eased qualification requirements for foreign investors and is in talks with companies to select candidates for pilot listings. The move is expected to bring more foreign money to the Saudi market, which has a larger capitalization than its neighboring Dubai. The regulator believes this will provide better trading liquidity, higher valuations, and a larger investor base for companies raising fresh capital.

site_title: China posts rise in output, employment figures
summary: China's manufacturing activity remained strong in March, with the official Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) expanding to a five-year high of 51.8, driven by a strong construction sector and government-funded projects. However, analysts warn of unaddressed structural overcapacity risks and a potential slowdown in the coming quarters due to monetary tightening and a slowing property market. The non-manufacturing PMI also reached a two-year high, signaling the strength of the services sector.

site_title: Passenger travel at DC area airports is sky high
summary: Passenger travel at the Washington region's three airports (Baltimore-Washington International, Reagan National, and Dulles International) reached a record 70 million in 2016, with both Baltimore-Washington International and Reagan National setting passenger records. Dulles International Airport saw a small but significant gain, driven by international travelers. The airports' efforts to attract new airlines, upgrade amenities, and improve shopping and dining options appear to be paying off, as airport leaders continue to court new airlines and invest in upgrades.

site_title: Fame and flame in nickname game
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive-elect Carrie Lam received a nickname "777" due to her exact 777 votes in the election, which is a Cantonese homophone for an expletive referring to impotence or stupidity. The nickname sparked laughter and amusement among many, with some using it as a display of dissatisfaction with Beijing's perceived intervention. Lam has chosen to brush it off, but the nickname has become a symbol of the city's polarized politics and love of cheeky humor, reflecting Hong Kong's unique culture and tendency to poke fun at its leaders.

site_title: TEE Int'l CEO offers S$0.215 or stock per share to take company private
summary: TEE International CEO Phua Chian Kin is offering 21.5 Singapore cents or new equity per share to take the company private through a scheme of arrangement, valuing the company at a 12.6% premium to its closing price. The offer requires approval from 75% of shareholders, who will receive cash or new shares in Oscar Investment, a wholly owned vehicle. Existing shareholders, including Phua, have agreed to support the scheme and receive shares in Oscar instead of cash, if approved.

site_title: MAS to stick with current policy stance despite recent stronger data: economists
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, is unlikely to adjust its exchange rate policy in April or this year due to the country's still weak economy. Despite recent strong economic growth, economists believe the economy is not yet on a stable footing. The MAS will maintain its current policy stance, indicating no plans for tightening exchange rate policy in the near future.

site_title: What's in a Chinese name? Ancient rites and growing business
summary: Tech-savvy entrepreneurs in China are turning an ancient naming tradition into a lucrative online business, offering personalized names that can ensure good fortune and help children stand out in a crowded market. The business, which uses algorithms to compile the best names based on parents' responses to a personality quiz, has become increasingly popular, with over 10,000 people using the service. Rates range from $81 to $1,000 for a consultation with a fortune-teller or naming expert, who can also help choose an English name that adheres to traditional Chinese principles such as bazi, or "eight characters."

site_title: Money managers collaborate with activists to deal with failing firms
summary: Neuberger Berman, a pension fund manager, has shifted its investment strategy from buying and holding stocks to collaborating with activist investors to deal with failing firms. This change in approach is a departure from the firm's nearly 80-year-old "buy and hold" strategy. By working with activist investors, Neuberger Berman aims to address the financial struggles of public companies and potentially increase returns for its clients. This new dynamic is upending traditional relations between public companies and their investors.

site_title: Japan's labour shortage prompts grudging turn to permanent jobs
summary: Japan's labour market is shifting towards permanent jobs, with the number of full-time workers rising for the first time in years. The labour shortage has led to companies hiring more permanent workers, outpacing growth in temporary jobs. The shift could boost consumer spending, but economists caution that wages and productivity may remain stagnant. The country's 2.8% unemployment rate is the lowest since 1994, but most hiring has been for temporary, part-time positions. Experts say the trend reversal could help address weak consumer demand, but equal work for equal pay remains a challenge.

site_title: Japan Post's financial loss a further embarrassment to Tokyo
summary: Japan Post Holdings has reported a 400 billion yen (S$5 billion) writedown on its Australian logistics arm, Toll Holding, amid a corporate scandal. The loss comes ahead of a planned share sale of Japan Post, and Minister of Finance Taro Aso is expected to meet the Japan Post head to explain the situation. This is the latest in a series of financial scandals in Japan, including Toshiba Corporation's recent incident. The move is seen as an embarrassment for the country, which is already grappling with economic challenges.

site_title: Airlines make more money selling miles than seats
summary: US airlines generate more revenue from selling airline miles than selling seats, with each mile fetching 1.5-2.5 cents. Airlines partner with major banks to accumulate and distribute miles to credit cardholders, resulting in billions of miles. This business model is a significant contributor to the airline industry's financial health, with carriers such as American Airlines and Delta benefiting from the lucrative mile sales. The practice has grown in size and value, with airlines now relying on miles as a key revenue stream.

site_title: Australia floodwaters still rising
summary: Eastern Australia continues to grapple with severe flooding after Cyclone Debbie hit the region on Tuesday, causing widespread damage and displacement. At least two people are dead, several are missing, and over 500 homes were destroyed. Emergency workers are battling to restore water and electricity, with the recovery efforts expected to last several months. The Queensland and northern NSW regions have been declared disaster zones, with estimated damage bills reaching Aus$1 billion. Residents in areas such as Rockhampton and Lismore are bracing for further flooding, and the situation remains fluid.

site_title: Gold marks best quarter in a year despite uncertainties
summary: Gold notched a 8.4% quarterly gain, its best in a year, due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's tax and investment plans and European elections, fueling demand for bullion as a safe haven. Spot gold rose 0.4% to $1,247.40 an ounce, while the dollar index was little changed, setting it up for its best week since mid-February. Analysts expect gold prices to reach $1,259 an ounce this year, driven by fears of Trump's ability to enact tax cuts and an uncertain European political outlook.

site_title: Gogh See The Tulips
summary: Vincent van Gogh's masterpieces "Self Portrait" and "The Starry Night" are recreated at the Flower Dome at Gardens by the Bay with over 30,000 tulips and hyacinths, part of the annual Tulipmania event. The display features 90 different varieties of flowers, including Darwin hybrid tulips. The exhibit is open until May 7, with admission charges applying to the Flower Dome.

site_title: Sharing platform
summary: The Centre for Photography and Film hosts Platform 17.5, a show-and-share session, on May 2 at 7.30pm at Objectifs. The event features presentations by Yah-Leng Yu, co-founder of Foreign Policy Design Group, and photographers Geoff Ang and Jimmy Sng. Jimmy Sng will speak on his project Mamafuku, a series about his late mother. This is the latest event in the platform's series, which aims to share and showcase creative works.

site_title: GuocoLand scaling up in UK, Australia while keeping tabs on core markets
summary: GuocoLand is scaling up its operations in the UK and Australia while maintaining its presence in core markets of Singapore, China, and Malaysia. Following a stocktake of its business, the developer is shifting its strategy to diversify earnings streams and build a more diversified mix of income streams. GuocoLand plans to increase its contributions from China and the UK, while reducing its reliance on Singapore, which is expected to remain a challenging market. The company is also exploring new markets and launching residential projects in Malaysia and China to drive growth.

site_title: Why you won't be flying in a taxi anytime soon
summary: Uber has announced its vision for on-demand urban air transportation, partnering with five companies to develop battery-powered vertical takeoff and landing vehicles (VTOLs) for commercial use. The initial testing is expected in 2020 in Dallas and Dubai, with a goal of making the service affordable and common. However, significant regulatory and technical challenges must be overcome before the concept can become a reality, including advancements in battery technology, new standards and regulations, and software testing. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is also working on automation systems for unmanned aerial vehicles.

site_title: Cosplay with a difference showcased in Malaysia
summary: In Malaysia, a hijab cosplay event was held at a mall on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, showcasing Muslim women's love for anime and cosplay while wearing traditional hijab headscarves. Around 20 women participated, sharing costume and makeup tips and networking. Participants, including university student Nur Azlina and male cosplay enthusiast Raja Muhammad Rusydi, expressed support for hijab cosplay, citing positive reactions and the importance of female empowerment. The event aims to generate interest in hijab cosplay among Muslim women in Malaysia, a growing trend in the country's cosplay scene.

site_title: Australia floodwaters still rising; damage bill could hit A$1b
summary: Floodwaters in eastern Australia continue to rise, affecting thousands of people and causing widespread damage. At least two people are dead, and several are missing after Cyclone Debbie made landfall, bringing torrential rain and high winds. The damage bill is estimated to reach A$1 billion, with over 500 homes destroyed and 30,000 properties without power. Recovery efforts are expected to last several months, with emergency workers battling to restore essential services.

site_title: One hundred days of disquietude
summary: One hundred days into his presidency, Donald Trump marked a significant turning point with the French presidential election. Centrist Emmanuel Macron made it to the second round, alleviating concerns about the European Union's influence. Trump also continued to shape US foreign policy, with Wang Yi's European tour setting the stage for an EU-China summit later this month.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat after strong week, eye on US data
summary: Asian markets retreated on Friday, following a strong week, amid concerns over the US government shutdown and the upcoming release of US growth data. The week's gains were attributed to Emmanuel Macron's presidential win, upbeat US earnings, and reasserted monetary policies from the Bank of Japan and European Central Bank. Focus now shifts to Washington, where revised growth figures are expected to influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

site_title: Samsung reports biggest quarterly net profit since 2013
summary: South Korean tech giant Samsung reported its largest quarterly net profit since 2013, with a net profit of 7.68 trillion won (S$9.35 billion) in the first quarter of 2017. The company's semiconductor business saw the largest-ever operating profit of 6.3 trillion won, driven by strong sales of memory chips. However, Samsung's mobile business saw sales and profit slow, with its first quarter operating profit at 2.07 trillion won. The company's earnings were boosted by favorable memory chip and display panel prices, but the firm's reputation was still recovering from last year's Galaxy Note 7 recall.

site_title: To peace in a pod
summary: Nespresso CEO Jean-Marc Duvoisin emphasizes the "peacekeeping" effect of growing coffee, citing its ability to provide a stable income and promote community development. He notes that coffee farming can bring peace to regions where it is a significant economic activity. Duvoisin also highlights Nespresso's commitment to sustainability, including 100% sustainably-sourced coffee, carbon neutrality, and the development of fully recyclable aluminum coffee pods. The company's focus on quality and innovation is expected to drive growth, with global penetration predicted to increase in the coming years.

site_title: Islamic romance novels set hearts aflutter in Bangladesh
summary: Bangladesh's romance novels, popularized in the 1980s by author Kasm bin Abubakar, are experiencing a resurgence as the country shifts towards a more conservative interpretation of Islam. Abubakar's chaste romance novels, which explore devout young Muslims finding love within strict moral confines, have sold millions and inspired a new generation of Bangladeshi writers. The genre has become a favorite among young girls from rural, conservative areas, with many writing love letters to authors like Abubakar as a sign of devotion.

site_title: Asia investors increasingly seeking unorthodox data sources in battle to beat benchmarks
summary: Asia investors are increasingly seeking unconventional data sources to gain an edge over benchmarks, driven by fierce competition from low-priced exchange-traded funds. This shift is forcing fund managers to look at alternative sources of information, such as shipping logistics trends, social media chatter, and payments data for unlisted private companies. As a result, some top asset managers are hiring data scientists to mine mountains of data and supplement investment decisions. However, integrating such information into daily workflows is challenging due to issues with data quality, capture rate, and representativeness.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open flat after six-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Friday, following a six-day rally, after a tepid lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index inched down 7.19 points to 24,691.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.26% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shed 0.24%. This comes as investors unwind ahead of the weekend.

site_title: OCBC CEO cautions against hopes of strong growth in Singapore in '17
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien expressed caution about strong growth in Singapore's economy this year, despite signs of recovery in certain sectors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has noted volatile and uneven growth so far in 2017. Tsien's comments follow a review of Singapore's economic outlook, which highlights the need for careful management to achieve sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien on Friday said that while there are signs of recovery in certain sectors of the Singapore economy, he cautioned against hopes of strong broad-based growth this year.

site_title: FCT's Q2 DPU steady despite fall in portfolio occupancy
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) maintained its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) at 3.04 Singapore cents despite a 2.9% fall in gross revenue, mainly due to asset enhancement work at Northpoint. Portfolio occupancy declined to 87.2% in Q2 FY2017, but net property income and distributable income rose 3.3% and 0.4% respectively. The company expects certain zones to recover from the current occupancy slump, and its well-located suburban malls are expected to remain resilient.

site_title: Nassim bulk sale helps CapitaLand post 77% jump in Q1 gain to S$386m
summary: CapitaLand Ltd posted a 77.2% jump in net profit to S$386.8 million for Q1, driven by a S$160.9 million gain from the sale of 45 units at The Nassim. Group revenue grew 0.4% to S$897.5 million, with a surge in portfolio gains from China and rental contributions from newly acquired properties. The company expects recurring income to grow as more China malls become operational, with six new shopping malls set to open this year.

site_title: iFAST's Q1 profit surges 60.7%
summary: iFAST Corporation reported a 60.7% surge in Q1 net profit to S$2.01 million, driven by a 17.2% increase in assets under administration to S$6.46 billion. Revenue rose 18.3% to S$22.1 million. Improved market sentiment and expanded investment products contributed to the better performance. Net asset value climbed to 30.62 Singapore cents, while diluted earnings per share edged up to 0.76 Singapore cents.

site_title: Explosive electronics demand expected to propel Q1 GDP growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output surged 10.2% year-on-year in March, exceeding expectations, and potentially boosting the country's Q1 GDP growth to 2.7-3%. The strong electronics cluster, driven by semiconductor manufacturing, is expected to continue supporting the manufacturing sector, which may be the key economic engine of growth this year. Economists now expect a full-year GDP upgrade, with some predicting a 3% growth rate, up from the initial 2.5% estimate.

site_title: Healthway Medical shareholders voted overwhelmingly for resolutions at EGM
summary: Healthway Medical shareholders voted overwhelmingly at an EGM, approving two key resolutions. 95.2% supported issuing S$60 million convertible bonds to Gateway Partners, while 98.02% backed acquiring Healthway Medical Enterprises, a chain of 24 clinics, with only 1.98% opposing.

site_title: Coping with rising health insurance premiums
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums are rising, posing a threat to long-term affordability. Insurers are increasing premiums by 5-15% for private hospital coverage, while partial riders see a 30% jump. Average bill size for private hospitals is 2-3 times that of public hospitals, driving up claims costs. To mitigate costs, policyholders can downgrade to lower-tiered plans, change full cash riders to partial riders, or consider canceling and relying on MediShield Life, a basic national health insurance scheme. The Health Insurance Task Force aims to slow down premium increases through measures such as pre-authorisation and product design changes.

site_title: Samsung's Galaxy S8 hits stores, aims to move on from recall crisis
summary: Samsung's Galaxy S8 smartphone went on sale in South Korea, marking the company's first major launch since last year's Galaxy Note 7 recall crisis. The device received over 1 million pre-orders in South Korea and has received positive market reactions. Samsung's profits are rising, with shares jumping over 2.5% and a potential record-breaking 48.5 million unit sales. The S8 series features an "infinity display," upgraded digital assistant Bixby, and water-resistant design, with deliveries set to begin in the US and Canada later this week.

site_title: STI drops 0.9% this week on geopolitical worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 0.9% this week due to geopolitical worries, including the US-North Korea standoff and upcoming UK and European elections. The index rose 1.95 points to 3,139.83 on Friday, but fell 30 points for the week. Turnover was low at 2.2 billion units worth S$1.09 billion. Shares of blue chips like Singtel and Global Logistic Properties were affected, with SGX shares downgraded to "neutral" by Macquarie Equities Research.

site_title: PGIM unit buys Jurong building for S$194m
summary: US-based PGIM Real Estate has acquired a cold store logistics facility in Jurong, Singapore for S$193.8 million. The site, located at 1 Buroh Lane, has a 2.5 plot ratio and a 30-year leasehold tenure. The buyer will have to pay JTC Corporation an upfront land premium of S$11 million for the remaining term of the lease. The seller, Warehouse Logistics Net Asia (WLNA), will lease back the property for 10 years at a rental rate translating to slightly above 7% net yield.

site_title: Lippo's Gentle Care in deal to buy S$15m of Gateway's S$60m convertible notes
summary: Gentle Care, linked to Lippo, made an official offer to acquire all of Gateway Partners' S$60 million convertible notes at S$0.042 per share. The company also entered into a sale and purchase agreement to buy S$15 million of the notes. Gateway Partners declined the offer to acquire all notes but agreed to sell S$15 million to Gentle Care. The deal will make Gentle Care and Gateway Partners large shareholders in Healthway Medical Corporation, which is going through difficult times. The move aims to provide certainty to stakeholders and stabilize the company.

site_title: IMF can cooperate with Trump to improve global trade: Lagarde
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde expressed optimism about cooperating with the Trump administration to improve the global trading system, while emphasizing the need to preserve open trade as a growth engine. Lagarde stated that the IMF aims to reduce trade distortions and subsidies, but will avoid protectionist measures. She believes progress will be made in cooperation to support and improve the system.

site_title: Gathering of global maritime community
summary: Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) 2017, a major maritime event, took place from April 22-28, with a theme of "Navigating through challenging times." The event, organized by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, featured conferences, dialogues, exhibitions, and social events, gathering the international maritime community. SMW was co-located with SeaAsia and Iron Ore Week, with a focus on industry trends and challenges, including the impact of the iron ore supply and demand. The event aimed to promote maritime innovation and collaboration among industry players.

site_title: EU's top diplomat says China's New Silk Road must be open to Europeans
summary: EU's top diplomat, Federica Mogherini, stated that China's New Silk Road projects must be open to Europeans, emphasizing the need for inclusive economic opportunities. Mogherini, speaking at Tsinghua University in Beijing, also expressed her opposition to concerns about a more confident and outward-looking China. The New Silk Road summit, attended by representatives from 110 countries, aims to improve ties with Central and Eastern Europe, while also promoting globalisation and free trade.

site_title: Passion for the arts, love for the business
summary: Quek Chin Yeow, the deputy chairman of Sotheby's Asia and chairman of International Jewellery, Asia, is the driving force behind the company's impressive growth, particularly in Hong Kong. With a passion for both art and business, he successfully merged his interests to excel in the industry. Under his leadership, Sotheby's has set numerous auction records, including the world auction record for the most expensive jewel sold in Asia. Quek's success is attributed to his ability to balance artistic appreciation with business acumen, earning him the Outstanding Overseas Executive of the Year award at the 2016 Singapore Business Awards.

site_title: US eager to forge bilateral free-trade deal with Japan
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence and US Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross launched an economic dialogue with Japan, aiming to forge a bilateral free-trade agreement, with President Donald Trump viewing it as a model for US trade deals. Japan is hesitant, focusing on broader economic cooperation issues, and has expressed willingness to support the Trans-Pacific Partnership without US participation. The dialogue aims to produce "concrete results in the near term" and improve commercial relations, with a focus on sectors such as agriculture and motor vehicles.

site_title: Walmart seeks bigger online fashion presence through acquisitions
summary: Walmart is seeking to expand its online fashion presence through a potential acquisition of clothing retailer Bonobos, its fourth small online brand since 2017. The move aims to attract younger, millennial customers and counter Amazon's dominance in the online fashion market. Walmart's e-commerce sales account for only 3% of total sales, with the company targeting 20-30% growth in the second half of the year. Analysts say the deal could help Walmart gain a foothold in the fashion sector and stem the loss of market share to Amazon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.38 points to 1,740.98. The market saw 116 gainers and 96 losers, with a trading volume of 141.2 million lots worth RM28.8 million.

site_title: Trump White House will no longer publicly identify visitors: reports
summary: The Trump administration has ended the practice of publicly disclosing the identities of most White House visitors, citing "grave national security risks and privacy concerns." The new policy will leave it up to White House officials to decide whether to release visitor names. The move has been criticized by civil liberties and transparency groups, who see it as an attempt to hide information about the administration's actions. The policy change is expected to save taxpayers $70,000 by 2020.

site_title: Keppel Reit posts 13.7% drop in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel Reit posted a 13.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.45 Singapore cents in Q1 2017, mainly due to lower income from divested assets and Bugis Junction Towers. Net property income dipped 4.6% to S$31.4 million, but share of results from associates increased 23.2% to S$23.1 million. The Reit's tenant retention rate fell to 87% and committed portfolio occupancy remained at 99.4%. The company will continue to seek selective acquisitions and remains open to opportunistic divestments.

site_title: Australia shares rise on miners, but head for weekly loss; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.76% on Friday, driven by gains in miners as iron ore and steel futures recovered in China. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 44.11 points to 5865.5, despite being on track for a weekly loss. Materials and financials were top performers, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto reaching one-week highs. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.5% on consumer and healthcare stocks.

images.alt_text: Australian shares gained on Friday as miners bounced back on higher metal prices, while financials and utility stocks rounded off a relatively solid morning session.

site_title: Berlin startup out to prove universal basic income is workable
summary: A Berlin startup, Mein Grundeinkommen, is conducting a social experiment providing 85 recipients, including 10 children, with a monthly stipend of 1,000 euros each for a year, funded by 55,000 donors. Founder Michael Bohmeyer aims to prove that universal basic income (UBI) is workable. Recipients have reported improved well-being, creativity, and ability to pursue new opportunities, such as education and career changes. The experiment has sparked debate in Germany, with some supporting the idea and others criticizing it as a "reward for laziness."

site_title: A W!ld Time

The company is employing virtual reality (VR) technology to improve patient assessments and is expanding its operations in emerging markets. summary: South Korean prosecutors have charged ousted president Park Geun-hye and Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong-bin with bribery, marking the latest twist in a corruption scandal. Park is accused of colluding with Choi Soon-sil to receive millions from Lotte, while Shin is charged with embezzlement and breach of trust. The charges come amidst a broader corruption scandal involving Samsung Group's Jay Y Lee, who is suspected of bribing Park and Choi.

site_title: Ahok, opponent neck and neck in race for Jakarta governor

A candidate needs a simple majority to win, and the pollster Saiful Mujani Research Center found that Baswedan's support stems from his Islamic faith, while Purnama's popularity is due to his record in office.

site_title: Bullish oil bets gain on signs Opec cuts will beat US boom
summary: US crude prices surged to $53 a barrel for the first time in a month, driven by speculation that Opec's output cuts will outweigh US production. Hedge funds increased bets on higher prices, with the WTI net-long position rising 16% in the week ended April 11. Opec reported shrinking inventories in developed nations, while the International Energy Agency forecast a decline in global stockpiles. Analysts believe a more balanced market is emerging, with refineries set to increase crude processing ahead of the summer driving season.

site_title: Japan nominates NRA commissioner to take top post at atomic regulator
summary: Japan's government has nominated Toyoshi Fuketa, a commissioner of the Nuclear Regulation Authority (NRA), to replace Shunichi Tanaka as chairman of the regulator, effective September. Fuketa's appointment aims to address industry concerns over safety practices, particularly surprise inspections and spent uranium fuel storage. His nomination requires confirmation by lawmakers and follows the Fukushima disaster six years ago, which led to a revision of atomic regulations. Fuketa's background in reactor safety research and international connections may help Japan adopt internationally recognized safety practices.

site_title: Post-Brexit Britain more politically active: study
summary: A study commissioned by the Charities Aid Foundation found that the UK's vote to leave the EU has boosted public engagement with social and political causes, with over half of British people signing a petition and 3 million joining a protest in 2016. The study also revealed that almost nine in 10 people donated to charity, with a total of £9.7 billion donated in 2016. This surge in public engagement and charitable giving is attributed to the country's increased division following the Brexit referendum.

site_title: Telstra announces A$1 billion bond issue
summary: Telstra has announced a $1 billion bond issue, comprising three tranches: $300 million four-year fixed rate notes at 2.90% interest, $150 million four-year floating rate notes at 3.82% interest, and $550 million 10-year fixed rate notes at 4% interest.
