site_title: Singtel consortium appoints Alcatel Submarine to build new subsea cable
summary: A Singtel consortium, comprising Singtel, AarNet, Google, Indosat Ooredoo, SubPartners, and Telstra, has appointed Alcatel Submarine Networks to build the 9,000km Indigo subsea cable system. The system will connect Singapore, Perth, Sydney, and Jakarta, providing faster connection speeds and enhanced reliability. The two-fibre pair "open cable" design allows consortium members to share spectrum and independently upgrade technology. The project aims to strengthen links between Australia and South-east Asia, supporting economic growth and digital connectivity.

site_title: McLaren's Alonso to miss Monaco to race in Indy 500
summary: Fernando Alonso, a double Formula One world champion, will miss the Monaco Grand Prix in May to compete in the Indianapolis 500. McLaren announced the decision, citing scheduling conflicts. Alonso is out of contract with McLaren at the end of the season, and the team's struggles with their Honda engines have raised questions about his future with the team. Alonso expressed excitement about racing in the Indy 500, calling it a prestigious event. McLaren will enter a single car in the Indy 500, marking the team's return to the event after a 38-year absence.

site_title: China's SAIC Motor posts higher profit
summary: China's SAIC Motor Corp Ltd posted a 7.4% jump in 2016 profits, reaching 32.0 billion yuan (S$6.5 billion), slightly below its expected 7.5% rise. Revenue rose 12.8% to 756 billion yuan. site_title: Jail terms cut for CHC founder and five church leaders
summary: Singapore's High Court reduced sentences of City Harvest Church (CHC) leaders, including founder Kong Hee, in a split decision. Kong's 8-year jail term was cut to 2.5 years, while others received reduced sentences ranging from 3 years to 7 months. The decision was based on a lesser form of criminal breach of trust under Section 406 of the Penal Code, rather than the original charges under Section 409. The court found that the leaders' actions were driven by a desire to advance the church's interests, rather than personal gain.

site_title: Despite 'challenging' environment, GM CFO expects strong 2017
summary: General Motors Co's CFO, Chuck Stevens, expects a "very strong year" in 2017 despite a challenging environment due to rising interest rates and falling used-car prices. The company plans to reduce inventory levels to around 90 days in June and 70 days by the end of 2017, maintaining profit margins of around 10%. GM still expects full-year earnings per share of $6.00 to $6.50 and US new light-vehicle sales for the industry at around 17.5 million units.

site_title: Update: United under fire after passenger dragged from plane; officer put on leave
summary: A United Airlines passenger was physically dragged off a plane overbooked on Sunday after he refused to leave his seat. The incident sparked outrage on social media, with many criticizing the airline's handling of the situation. The passenger, who appeared to be Asian, was seen being dragged down the aisle on his back, bleeding from the mouth, and was heard saying "just kill me." The airline's CEO, Oscar Munoz, defended his employees, stating that the passenger had "defied" security officers. One of the officers involved in the incident has been placed on leave pending an investigation by the Chicago Department of Aviation.

This weekend, he'll attend the Fred Perry Record Rally in KL, where his girlfriend lives, and explore local food spots, including The Bee Publika and Kin Kin Restaurant.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker in response to Wall Street's Wednesday reversal
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 0.96 points to 3,175.59 on Thursday, following Wall Street's reversal on Wednesday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped after US House Speaker Paul Ryan stated tax reform would be harder than healthcare reform, and the Federal Reserve suggested three rate hikes in 2017. Trading was subdued, with low turnover and 325 falls against 160 rises. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong also fell 0.5%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick up before Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% to 24,400.80 points, driven by a mainland rally, ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting. Investors remain cautious due to trade and security issues on the agenda. Most sectors gained, with services and tech stocks leading, while coal miners advanced following a four-month high in coal prices. The Trump-Xi summit is set to take place Thursday and Friday, marking their first face-to-face meeting since Trump's inauguration.

site_title: Pratt asks airlines to perform early engine checks on CSeries
summary: Pratt & Whitney has requested early inspections of the combustor lining in the PW1500G engine used on Bombardier's CSeries planes after a series of problems forced emergency landings. The inspections will be performed on Swiss International Air Lines and airBaltic aircraft after 2,000 flight hours. Pratt & Whitney has also issued corrected liners that will be delivered to the first CSeries narrowbody delivered to Korean Air Lines this summer, with an expected lifespan of 6,000 hours.

site_title: Where China's sick and aged go to seek a cure
summary: China's Bama County, a rural village in southern China, has become a magnet for the country's sick and aged, seeking exotic medicines and advice on living healthier lives. Visitors, including those with grave illnesses, come seeking a cure, but many leave disappointed, and some fall victim to scams. The influx of tourists has created a thriving market for dubious health products, while the local government promotes the village as a longevity destination, turning centenarians into celebrities. The area's pristine air and "longevity water" have drawn visitors, but critics say it has ruined the tranquility of the area.

images.alt_text: Once a largely undisturbed hamlet hidden in the karst mountains of Guangxi province, Bama has in recent years become a magnet for China's sick and aged.

site_title: Tesco logs £40m annual net loss on accounting scandal
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest supermarket chain, reported an annual net loss of £40 million in 2016/2017 due to a £235 million accounting scandal. This contrasts with a net profit of £138 million in the previous year. The scandal led to a significant charge in costs, skewing the company's financial results. The accounting scandal has resulted in a substantial loss for the company.

site_title: Wall St's WhatsApp secret: illegal texting is out of control
summary: Wall Street firms are increasingly using encrypted messaging services like WhatsApp and Signal to circumvent compliance and share confidential information, despite industry efforts to crack down on unmonitored communications. The use of these apps, often for personal use, is widespread, with nearly two dozen employees surveyed saying policies to prevent unmonitored communications are routinely ignored. The SEC and Financial Industry Regulatory Authority have clear rules requiring financial firms to keep records of all written business communications, but compliance is struggling to keep up with the rapidly evolving technology.

site_title: Capital City Group to set eyes on S-E Asia after RTO
summary: Capital City Group, which has completed a reverse takeover (RTO) of Terratech Group, is confident of turning around the loss-making marble business in two years through development projects in Southeast Asia. The group is focusing on Malaysia and other Asean countries, with joint-venture partners owning land assets in strategic locations. Terratech's marble business is expected to benefit from the group's development projects, allowing it to lower costs and ensure quality delivery.

site_title: Knack for snacks
summary: Kellogg Company, known for its corn flakes, has transformed into a global snacking company under CEO John Bryant. The company's revenue grew from $6 billion in 2000 to $13 billion in 2016, with snacks now accounting for 49% of its business, up from 20% in 2000. The shift is attributed to the company's expansion into emerging markets and diversification into popular snack brands such as Pop Tarts, Eggo, and Pringles.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

"The emerging markets are the defining event in our careers in the food industry. We've made a number of investments to better position ourselves to take advantage of that trend, and I think we need to do more of that. We're making good progress down that path."

site_title: Hot stock: CWT shares surge on HNA offer
summary: CWT shares surged 9.7% on Monday after Hong Kong-listed HNA Holding Group made a S$1.4 billion offer to buy the logistics group. The stock opened at S$2.26 and reached S$2.28, with 16 million shares traded. HNA has secured commitments from 65.13% of CWT shareholders, representing 90% of issued shares, to accept the offer. The offer price is S$2.33 per share, and HNA plans to delist CWT from the Singapore Exchange once it receives acceptances from over 90% of shareholders.

images.alt_text: Shares of logistics group CWT surged on Monday morning following an offer by Hong Kong-listed HNA Holding Group to buy the firm for just under S$1.4 billion.

site_title: Ghosts of Mosul stalk Iraq's fleeing children
summary: Thousands of children have fled Mosul, Iraq, after the Islamic State group's stronghold was recaptured, with over 200,000 people displaced since the operation began last month. Children at a refugee camp, including 10-year-old Nora, bear signs of trauma, including fatigue and aggressive behavior, despite receiving psychological "first aid" at the camp. Aid workers say the children are struggling to express themselves creatively and are "burning inside" with unspoken pain, as their drawings depict both innocence and harrowing experiences in the city.

site_title: Oil rises, near 1-month high; US crude stocks seen down
summary: Oil prices rose to a near one-month high on Tuesday, with Brent futures increasing 2% to $54.17 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude gaining 1.6% to $51.03 per barrel. The increase was driven by an unplanned production outage in the North Sea and expectations of a drawdown in US crude and product inventories. Oil prices have recovered 9% since hitting four-month lows in late March, with analysts expecting the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to cut output, leading to higher prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices on Tuesday rose to a near one-month high, supported by an unplanned production outage in the North Sea and expectations of a drawdown in US crude and product inventories.

site_title: Trump tells Sisi US, Egypt will fight Islamist militants together
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, announcing a reset in US-Egypt relations and vowing to fight Islamist militants together. The two leaders agreed to advance peace in the Middle East and support Israel and the Palestinians. Trump praised Sisi's efforts, saying he has a "great friend and ally" in the US. The meeting was Trump's first official meeting with Sisi, who was previously frozen out by the Obama administration. However, no discussion on human rights issues occurred, sparking concerns from human rights groups about detained Egyptian-American Aya Hijazi.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump moved to reset US relations with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Monday after the prior Obama administration's strained ties, giving him firm backing and vowing to work together to fight Islamist militants.

site_title: Quest for safety, freshness drives Hong Kong's high-end fruit fad
summary: Hong Kong's high-end fruit market is experiencing a surge in demand for premium produce, with luxury supermarkets and outdoor stalls offering expensive fruits from far-flung countries. The trend reflects a quest for clean, fresh produce, despite reports of excessive pesticides and preservatives in China. The gifting of expensive fruit has become a status symbol, with wealthy customers willing to pay top dollar for the finest fruits. The trend is not limited to Hong Kong, with Japanese and South Korean cultures also embracing expensive fruit as gifts and luxury items.

images.alt_text: On the shelves of high-end supermarket City Super, a single Japanese strawberry recently fetched a whopping HK$168. Each strawberry nestled on a foam pillow, encased in a glossy cardboard box.

site_title: Trump, Xi at Mar-a-Lago for high-stakes summit
summary: US President Donald Trump welcomed Chinese President Xi Jinping to Mar-a-Lago for a high-stakes summit, marking their first face-to-face encounter. The two leaders are expected to discuss trade, jobs, and North Korea, with China offering investments to create American jobs and concessions on financial transactions with North Korea. Xi aims to build a rapport with Trump, while Trump seeks to assert US influence and address domestic concerns. The summit comes amid tensions over Taiwan and North Korea's missile tests.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump greeted Xi Jinping to his Florida resort of Mar-a-Lago with a smile and a handshake on Thursday, as cordiality replaced tough anti-China rhetoric during a first face-to-face encounter.
